classDefinition: An entity that exists in full at any time in which it exists at all, persists through time while maintaining its identity and has no temporal parts.
An entity that has temporal parts and that happens, unfolds or develops through time.

classDefinition: b is an independent continuant = Def. b is a continuant which is such that there is no c and no t such that b s-depends_on c at t. (axiom label in BFO2 Reference: [017-002])

classDefinition: A specifically dependent continuant  that inheres in continuant  entities and are not exhibited in full at every time in which it inheres in an entity or group of entities. The exhibition or actualization of a realizable entity is a particular manifestation, functioning or process that occurs under certain circumstances.
parentDefinition: A continuant that inheres in or is borne by other entities. Every instance of A requires some specific instance of B which must always be the same.

classDefinition: A biological process represents a specific objective that the organism is genetically programmed to achieve. Biological processes are often described by their outcome or ending state, e.g., the biological process of cell division results in the creation of two daughter cells (a divided cell) from a single parent cell. A biological process is accomplished by a particular set of molecular functions carried out by specific gene products (or macromolecular complexes), often in a highly regulated manner and in a particular temporal sequence.
parentDefinition: An occurrent that has temporal proper parts and for some time t, p s-depends_on some material entity at t.

classDefinition: A biological process represents a specific objective that the organism is genetically programmed to achieve. Biological processes are often described by their outcome or ending state, e.g., the biological process of cell division results in the creation of two daughter cells (a divided cell) from a single parent cell. A biological process is accomplished by a particular set of molecular functions carried out by specific gene products (or macromolecular complexes), often in a highly regulated manner and in a particular temporal sequence.
parentDefinition: p is a process = Def. p is an occurrent that has temporal proper parts and for some time t, p s-depends_on some material entity at t. (axiom label in BFO2 Reference: [083-003])

classDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentDefinition: A material entity consisting of multiple components that are causally integrated.
classComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: Any member of the class of organooxygen compounds that is a polyhydroxy-aldehyde or -ketone or a lactol resulting from their intramolecular condensation (monosaccharides); substances derived from these by reduction of the carbonyl group (alditols), by oxidation of one or more hydroxy groups to afford the corresponding aldehydes, ketones, or carboxylic acids, or by replacement of one or more hydroxy group(s) by a hydrogen atom; and polymeric products arising by intermolecular acetal formation between two or more such molecules (disaccharides, polysaccharides and oligosaccharides). Carbohydrates contain only carbon, hydrogen and oxygen atoms; prior to any oxidation or reduction, most have the empirical formula Cm(H2O)n. Compounds obtained from carbohydrates by substitution, etc., are known as carbohydrate derivatives and may contain other elements. Cyclitols are generally not regarded as carbohydrates.
parentDefinition: Any organooxygen compound that is a polyhydroxy-aldehyde or -ketone, or a compound derived from one. Carbohydrates contain only carbon, hydrogen and oxygen and usually have an empirical formula Cm(H2O)n; carbohydrate derivatives may contain other elements by substitution or condensation.

In general, a mineral is a chemical substance that is normally crystalline formed and has been formed as a result of geological processes. The term also includes metamict substances (naturally occurring, formerly crystalline substances whose crystallinity has been destroyed by ionising radiation) and can include naturally occurring amorphous substances that have never been crystalline ('mineraloids') such as georgite and calciouranoite as well as substances formed by the action of geological processes on bigenic compounds ('biogenic minerals').

classDefinition: In general, a mineral is a chemical substance that is normally crystalline formed and has been formed as a result of geological processes. The term also includes metamict substances (naturally occurring, formerly crystalline substances whose crystallinity has been destroyed by ionising radiation) and can include naturally occurring amorphous substances that have never been crystalline ('mineraloids') such as georgite and calciouranoite as well as substances formed by the action of geological processes on bigenic compounds ('biogenic minerals').

classDefinition: Any nutrient required in large quantities by organisms throughout their life in order to orchestrate a range of physiological functions. Macronutrients are usually chemical elements (carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, phosphorus and sulfur) that humans consume in the largest quantities. Calcium, sodium, magnesium and potassium are sometimes included as macronutrients because they are required in relatively large quantities compared with other vitamins and minerals.

In general, a mineral is a chemical substance that is normally crystalline formed and has been formed as a result of geological processes. The term also includes metamict substances (naturally occurring, formerly crystalline substances whose crystallinity has been destroyed by ionising radiation) and can include naturally occurring amorphous substances that have never been crystalline ('mineraloids') such as georgite and calciouranoite as well as substances formed by the action of geological processes on bigenic compounds ('biogenic minerals').

classDefinition: An astrononmical body part which delimited by physical discontinuities with its surroundings.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: This class is being depopulated and will be filled only with inferred subclasses. Please do not use this for direct annotation, favouring instead a more descriptive subclass.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: An anthropogenic geographic feature is a geographic feature resulting from the influence of human beings on nature.
parentDefinition: An astrononmical body part which delimited by physical discontinuities with its surroundings.
parentComment: This class is being depopulated and will be filled only with inferred subclasses. Please do not use this for direct annotation, favouring instead a more descriptive subclass.

classDefinition: A process during which a natural environmental system is altered by human action.
parentDefinition: A process during which an ecosystem - natural or anthropised - is changed by the actions of humans.
classComment: An area may be classified as anthropized even though it looks natural, such as grasslands that have been deforested by humans. It can be difficult to determine how much a site has been anthropized in the case of urbanization because one must be able to estimate the state of the landscape before significant human action.

classDefinition: Mine tailings are the materials left over after the process of separating the valuable fraction from the uneconomic fraction (gangue) of an ore.
parentDefinition: Anthropogenic material in or on which organisms may live.

classDefinition: Anthropogenic material in or on which organisms may live.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: Anthropogenic material in or on which organisms may live.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

parentLabel: fiat part of an astronomical object
parentDefinition: A part of an environmental system whose boundaries are determined by fiat.
parentComment: Subclasses of this class have fiat (and only fiat) boundaries - that is, boundaries which are determined by human consensus or opinion rather than (and sometimes in contrast to) well-defined physical discontinuities. We distinguish these from entities that have fuzzy or hard to define boundaries that do overlap some form of physical discontinuity.

classDefinition: A planned environmental usage process during which an environment facilitates the movement of materials and material objects (persons or goods) from place to place, typically with the assistance of a vehicle.
parentDefinition: A planned process during which humans access and obtain resources, benefits, or services from a natural or anthropised ecosystem.

classDefinition: An enclosure for displaying selected plant or animal life.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic geographic feature is a geographic feature resulting from the influence of human beings on nature.

classDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water.
parentDefinition: A material entity consisting of multiple components that are causally integrated.

classDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water.
parentDefinition: An astrononmical body part which delimited by physical discontinuities with its surroundings.
parentComment: This class is being depopulated and will be filled only with inferred subclasses. Please do not use this for direct annotation, favouring instead a more descriptive subclass.

classDefinition: An accumulation of water of varying size.
parentDefinition: A mass of water.
classComment: The term body of water most often refers to large accumulations of water, such as oceans, seas, and lakes, but it includes smaller pools of water such as ponds, wetlands, or more rarely, puddles. A body of water does not have to be still or contained; Rivers, streams, canals, and other geographical features where water moves from one place to another are also considered bodies of water.

classDefinition: A collection of caves interconnected by enterable passages or linked hydrologically or a cave with an extensive complex of chambers and passages.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which has been formed from and is composed primarily of the matter of that astronomical body.
classComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.
parentComment: Landforms may be natural or anthropogenic. This term has often has loose usage when referencing entities which are either subterranean or submerged below water bodies. In some cases, oceans themselves are considered landforms. Here, we have provided subclasses to resolve this ambiguity, but place oceans and other water bodies elsewhere.In later revisions, this hiearchy is likely to be reordered based on the formation processes of the entities within it.

classDefinition: Artificial watercourse with no flow or a controlled flow used for navigation, drainage or irrigation.

classDefinition: A flowing body of water.
parentDefinition: A lotic water body is a water body in which the accumulated water, in its totality, is flowing.

classDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's length being notably higher than its width.
parentDefinition: A morphological quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's ratios of distances between its features (points, edges, surfaces and also holes etc).

classDefinition: A marine water body which is constitutes the majority of an astronomical body's hydrosphere.
parentDefinition: A lentic water body which is composed primarily of marine water.

classDefinition: A marine water body which is constitutes the majority of an astronomical body's hydrosphere.
parentDefinition: A body of water which is primarily composed of saline water.
parentComment: This class has its subclasses populated by inference.

classDefinition: A lentic water body which is composed primarily of marine water.
parentDefinition: A lentic water body is a water body in which the accumulated water, in its totality, has very little to no directed flow.

classDefinition: A body of water which is primarily composed of saline water.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of water of varying size.

A body of water does not have to be still or contained; Rivers, streams, canals, and other geographical features where water moves from one place to another are also considered bodies of water.

classDefinition: Water which has physicochemical properties that have been determined by the processes occuring in a sea or ocean.
parentDefinition: Water which contains a significant concentration of dissolved salts.
classComment: This definition refers to water that is actually in a sea or ocean. This water may have a wide range of salinity levels.
parentComment: The threshold salt concentration for classifying water as saline varies, but typically begins at about 1,000 to 3,000 parts salt per million parts water or 0.1–0.3% salt by weight.

classDefinition: A large expanse of saline water usually connected with an ocean.
parentDefinition: A lentic water body which is composed primarily of marine water.

classDefinition: A large expanse of saline water usually connected with an ocean.
parentDefinition: A body of water which is primarily composed of saline water.
parentComment: This class has its subclasses populated by inference.

classDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water with a halinity above 30 ppt (roughly 35 g/L).
parentDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water.

classDefinition: Water which contains a significant concentration of dissolved salts.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.
classComment: The threshold salt concentration for classifying water as saline varies, but typically begins at about 1,000 to 3,000 parts salt per million parts water or 0.1–0.3% salt by weight.

classDefinition: A lake whose water contains a considerable concentration of dissolved salts.
parentDefinition: A body of water which is primarily composed of saline water.
parentComment: This class has its subclasses populated by inference.

classDefinition: A lake whose water contains a considerable concentration of dissolved salts.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

A body of water does not have to be still or contained; Rivers, streams, canals, and other geographical features where water moves from one place to another are also considered bodies of water.

classDefinition: A large continuous area of land, either surrounded by sea or contiguous with another landmass.
parentDefinition: A surface layer of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material and is not covered by oceans or other bodies of water.

classDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which has been formed from and is composed primarily of the matter of that astronomical body.

In some cases, oceans themselves are considered landforms. Here, we have provided subclasses to resolve this ambiguity, but place oceans and other water bodies elsewhere.In later revisions, this hiearchy is likely to be reordered based on the formation processes of the entities within it.

classDefinition: A lake of whose water contains low concentrations of salts.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake of whose water contains low concentrations of salts.
parentDefinition: A body of water which is primarily composed of freshwater, with low solute content.
parentComment: This class has its subclasses primarily populated by inference. The threshold for what constitutes "fresh" water is variable and should typically be deferred to an applicatoin layer resource.

classDefinition: A body of water which is primarily composed of freshwater, with low solute content.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of water of varying size.
classComment: This class has its subclasses primarily populated by inference. The threshold for what constitutes "fresh" water is variable and should typically be deferred to an applicatoin layer resource.
parentComment: The term body of water most often refers to large accumulations of water, such as oceans, seas, and lakes, but it includes smaller pools of water such as ponds, wetlands, or more rarely, puddles. A body of water does not have to be still or contained; Rivers, streams, canals, and other geographical features where water moves from one place to another are also considered bodies of water.

classDefinition: A stream which, through permanent or seasonal flow processes, moves from elevated land towards lower elevations through a definite channel and empties either into a sea, lake, or another river or ends on land as bed seepage and evapotranspiration exceed water supply.
parentDefinition: A watercourse which is linear and flows across the solid portion of a planetary surface.
classComment: "There are no official definitions for the generic term river as applied to geographic features, although in some countries or communities a stream is defined by its size. Many names for small rivers are specific to geographic location; examples are "run" in some parts of the United States, "burn" in Scotland and northeast England, and "beck" in northern England. Sometimes a river is defined as being larger than a creek, but not always: the language is vague."

classDefinition: A watercourse which is linear and flows across the solid portion of a planetary surface.
parentDefinition: A flowing body of water.

classDefinition: A stream channel which contains a river.
parentDefinition: A channel of a watercourse which contains a stream.

classDefinition: The sloping margin of a river, serving to confine it to its natural channel.
parentDefinition: The sloping margin of a stream, serving to confine it to its natural channel.

classDefinition: A channel of a watercourse which contains a stream.
parentDefinition: A depressed landform which physically confines a river, slough or ocean strait, and which consists of a bed and banks.

classDefinition: An artificial body of water, often contained by a dam, constructed for the purpose of water storage.
parentDefinition: A lake purposefully constructed.

classDefinition: A lake purposefully constructed.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: A lake purposefully constructed.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A cylindrical hole, pit, or tunnel drilled or dug down to a depth from which water, oil, or gas can be pumped or brought to the surface.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic geographic feature is a geographic feature resulting from the influence of human beings on nature.

classDefinition: An underground or underwater passage.
parentDefinition: A structure which traverses a mass of one or more environmental materials, and encloses a roughly tubular site.

classDefinition: A channel which is constructed by removing materials from land or submerged beds.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: A channel which is constructed by removing materials from land or submerged beds.
parentDefinition: A structure which traverses a mass of one or more environmental materials, and encloses a roughly tubular site.

classDefinition: A surface landform which provides an egress for groundwater or steam to flow out of the ground.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
classComment: Springs are typically where an aquifer surface meets the ground surface or where there is a fissure.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of solid environmental material.
parentDefinition: A layer of some material entity which is adjacent to one or more of its external boundaries and directly interacts with its immediate surroundings.
parentComment: This class is distinct from a geometric surface, which is two-dimensional. The idea of "uppermost" may be problematic. Further, the definition of layer (the superclass of surface in rev 133) references surface. This may be another issue. Perhaps this can be made into an inferred class using 'bounding layer of' some material entity, note that 'bounding layer' implies containment, which may not be valid here.

classDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of solid environmental material.
parentDefinition: A layer which is primarily composed of some solid material, allowing for non-solid parts such as interstitial pockets of gas or liquid.

classDefinition: A quarry from which sand is extracted.
parentDefinition: An open-pit mine from which rock or minerals are extracted.

classDefinition: An open-pit mine from which rock or minerals are extracted.
parentDefinition: A surface mine that utilizes a technique of extracting rock or minerals from the earth by their removal from an open pit or borrow.

classDefinition: A planned process during which a portion of environmental material is removed from a material entity.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
classComment: Created for SDGIO and intended to be a more general form of resource extraction process.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A planned process during which a portion of environmental material is removed from a material entity.
parentDefinition: A process that realizes a plan which is the concretization of a plan specification.
classComment: Created for SDGIO and intended to be a more general form of resource extraction process.

classDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is composed primarily of particles of sand with only minor proportions of other substances.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is composed primarily of particles.
classComment: This definition is intentionally ambiguous to support the multiple thresholds set by different authorities. Some authorities consider as sands soil material that contains 85% or more sand; the percentage of silt plus 1.5 times the percentage of clay does not exceed 15. coarse sand (sable grossier) 25% or more very coarse and coarse sand, and less than 50% any other one grade of sand.

classDefinition: A lotic water body is a water body in which the accumulated water, in its totality, is flowing.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of water of varying size.
parentComment: The term body of water most often refers to large accumulations of water, such as oceans, seas, and lakes, but it includes smaller pools of water such as ponds, wetlands, or more rarely, puddles. A body of water does not have to be still or contained; Rivers, streams, canals, and other geographical features where water moves from one place to another are also considered bodies of water.

classDefinition: A depressed landform which physically confines a river, slough or ocean strait, and which consists of a bed and banks.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A cave without streams or drips of water.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.

classDefinition: A wetness quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's not being covered by a liquid.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of whether the bearer's being covered by a liquid.

classDefinition: A cave containing a stream or active speleothems.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.

classDefinition: A valley or ravine, bounded by relatively steep banks, which in the rainy season becomes a watercourse.
parentDefinition: A depression which has been formed as a result of erosion by water or ice and which is low-lying, bordered by higher ground, and especially elongate.
classComment: The temporality of wadis is problematic in deciding whether they are watercourses or valleys.
parentComment: Valleys are typically located between hills our mountains.

classDefinition: A depression which has been formed as a result of erosion by water or ice and which is low-lying, bordered by higher ground, and especially elongate.
parentDefinition: A depression which is part of a planetary crust, is of geographic scale, and is partially or completely enclosed.
classComment: Valleys are typically located between hills our mountains.

classDefinition: A material transport process during which a volume of liquid water is transported due to a disequilibria in physical forces.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: A material transport process during which a volume of liquid water is transported due to a disequilibria in physical forces.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: A quality of a single process inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's being marked by breaks or interruptions.
parentDefinition: A quality of a single process inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's occurrence.

classDefinition: A process during which liquid water accumulates in a site, most often in some form of container.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: A process during which liquid water accumulates in a site, most often in some form of container.
parentDefinition: A material accumulation process during which the volume of liquid entity increases.

classDefinition: An area of water bordered by land on three sides.
parentDefinition: An opening of the sea into the land.

classDefinition: An opening of the sea into the land.
parentDefinition: An opening of the sea into the land, or of a lake into its shore.

classDefinition: A body of water, usually of smaller size than a lake.
parentDefinition: A lentic water body is a water body in which the accumulated water, in its totality, has very little to no directed flow.

classDefinition: An area of broken, fast flowing water in a stream, where the slope of the bed increases (but without a prominent break of slope which might result in a waterfall), or where a gently dipping bar of harder rock outcrops.
parentDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous volume of liquid water and is held in shape or sustained by an environmental process.
parentComment: Similar, in spirit, to landform.

classDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous volume of liquid water and is held in shape or sustained by an environmental process.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of liquid material.
classComment: Similar, in spirit, to landform.

classDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which includes communities of grasses, rushes, reeds, typhas, sedges, and other herbaceous plants (possibly with low-growing woody plants).
parentDefinition: A terrestrial ecosystem which is inundated or saturated by surface or ground water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances does support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions.

classDefinition: A terrestrial ecosystem which is inundated or saturated by surface or ground water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances does support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classDefinition: Artificial watercourse with no flow or a controlled flow used irrigation.
parentDefinition: Artificial watercourse with no flow or a controlled flow used for navigation, drainage or irrigation.
parentComment: This class refers to the water contained in a canal channel, and not the channel itself.

classDefinition: A small, human-made channel which has been dug for draining or irrigating the land.

parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

parentDefinition: A depressed landform which physically confines a river, slough or ocean strait, and which consists of a bed and banks.

classDefinition: A sheet of saline water separated from the open sea by sand or shingle banks. The sheet of water between an offshore reef, especially of coral and mainland. The sheet of water within a ring or horseshoe shaped atoll.
parentDefinition: A layer in a water mass, itself composed primarily of water.
parentComment: This class will eventually be populated by inference, and its asserted subclasses removed.

classDefinition: A layer in a water mass, itself composed primarily of water.
parentDefinition: A layer which is primarily composed of some liquid material.
classComment: This class will eventually be populated by inference, and its asserted subclasses removed.

classDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which overlaps both terrestrial and marine ecosystems.
parentDefinition: A terrestrial ecosystem which is inundated or saturated by surface or ground water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances does support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions.

classDefinition: That part of the land in immediate contact with a body of water including the area between high and low water lines.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A long and narrow sea inlet with high steeply sloped walled sides. A fjord is a landform created during a period of glaciation.
parentDefinition: An opening of the sea into the land.

classDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and relatively flat surrounding land.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which has been formed from and is composed primarily of the matter of that astronomical body.
parentComment: Landforms may be natural or anthropogenic. This term has often has loose usage when referencing entities which are either subterranean or submerged below water bodies. In some cases, oceans themselves are considered landforms. Here, we have provided subclasses to resolve this ambiguity, but place oceans and other water bodies elsewhere.In later revisions, this hiearchy is likely to be reordered based on the formation processes of the entities within it.

classDefinition: An erosion process during which the movement of a glacier across a terrestrial surface causes the removal of material from that surface.
parentDefinition: An action of exogenic processes (such as water flow or wind) which remove environmental material from one part of a planet's crust, transporting it to another location where it is deposited.

classDefinition: An erosion process during which the movement of a glacier across a terrestrial surface causes the removal of material from that surface.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which involves glaciers or ice sheets.
parentComment: Note that ice sheets and glaciers are confounded and confused in multiple communities and across multiple sources.

classDefinition: A sudden descent of water over a step or ledge in the bed of a river.
parentDefinition: A lotic water body is a water body in which the accumulated water, in its totality, is flowing.
