classDefinition: A sudden descent of water over a step or ledge in the bed of a river.
parentDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous volume of liquid water and is held in shape or sustained by an environmental process.
classComment: Should this be a hydroform?
parentComment: Similar, in spirit, to landform.

classDefinition: A tidal water channel. Creeks may often dry to a muddy channel with little or no flow at low tide, but often with significant depth of water at high tide.
parentDefinition: A watercourse which has the intensity and direction of its flow primarily determined by the tides.

classDefinition: A watercourse which has the intensity and direction of its flow primarily determined by the tides.
parentDefinition: A flowing body of water.

classDefinition: Artificial watercourse with no flow or a controlled flow used drainage.
parentDefinition: Artificial watercourse with no flow or a controlled flow used for navigation, drainage or irrigation.
parentComment: This class refers to the water contained in a canal channel, and not the channel itself.

classDefinition: An vegetated area which overlaps a wetland ecosystem.
parentDefinition: A vegetated area is a geographic feature which has ground cover dominated by plant communities.

classDefinition: A vegetated area is a geographic feature which has ground cover dominated by plant communities.
parentDefinition: An environmental zone which is bounded by material parts of a land mass or the atmosphere or space adjacent to it.

classDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which accumulates acidic peat, a deposit of dead plant material.
parentDefinition: A terrestrial ecosystem which is inundated or saturated by surface or ground water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances does support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions.

classDefinition: A histosol which is formed by the decomposition of vegetation or organic matter.
parentDefinition: Histosols comprise soils formed in organic material. These vary from soils developed in predominantly moss peat in boreal, arctic and subarctic regions, via moss peat, reeds/ sedge peat (fen) and forest peat in temperate regions to mangrove peat and swamp forest peat in the humid tropics. Histosols are found at all altitudes, but the vast majority occurs in lowlands.

classDefinition: A semi-enclosed coastal body of water with one or more rivers or streams flowing into it, and with a free connection to the open sea.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of water of varying size.
parentComment: The term body of water most often refers to large accumulations of water, such as oceans, seas, and lakes, but it includes smaller pools of water such as ponds, wetlands, or more rarely, puddles. A body of water does not have to be still or contained; Rivers, streams, canals, and other geographical features where water moves from one place to another are also considered bodies of water.

classDefinition: The place where a stream discharges into a lagoon, lake, or the sea.
parentDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous volume of liquid water and is held in shape or sustained by an environmental process.
parentComment: Similar, in spirit, to landform.

classDefinition: The place where a stream discharges into a lagoon, lake, or the sea.
parentDefinition: The exit or point of discharge of a stream into another stream, lake or sea.

classDefinition: A dense growth of shrubbery planted as a fence or boundary.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic geographic feature is a geographic feature resulting from the influence of human beings on nature.

classDefinition: Artificial watercourse with no flow or a controlled flow used navigation.
parentDefinition: Artificial watercourse with no flow or a controlled flow used for navigation, drainage or irrigation.
parentComment: This class refers to the water contained in a canal channel, and not the channel itself.

classDefinition: A hot spring that erupts periodically, ejecting a column of hot water and steam into the air.
parentDefinition: A spring through which groundwater, heated by geothermal energy, flows.

classDefinition: A spring through which groundwater, heated by geothermal energy, flows.
parentDefinition: A surface landform which provides an egress for groundwater or steam to flow out of the ground.
parentComment: Springs are typically where an aquifer surface meets the ground surface or where there is a fissure.

classDefinition: A temperature which is relatively high.
parentDefinition: A physical quality of the thermal energy of a system.

classDefinition: A temperature which is relatively high.
parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is increased compared to normal or average.

classDefinition: A alkaline spring through which groundwater, heated by geothermal energy, flows.
parentDefinition: A spring through which groundwater, heated by geothermal energy, flows.

classDefinition: A alkaline spring through which groundwater, heated by geothermal energy, flows.
parentDefinition: A mineral spring through which water with a high pH flows.

classDefinition: An acidic spring through which groundwater, heated by geothermal energy, flows.
parentDefinition: A spring through which groundwater, heated by geothermal energy, flows.

classDefinition: An acidic spring through which groundwater, heated by geothermal energy, flows.
parentDefinition: A spring through which water with a low pH flows.

classDefinition: A neutral spring through which groundwater, heated by geothermal energy, flows.
parentDefinition: A spring through which groundwater, heated by geothermal energy, flows.

classDefinition: A neutral spring through which groundwater, heated by geothermal energy, flows.
parentDefinition: A spring through which water with a neutral pH flows.

classDefinition: A lake contained within a volcanic crater.
parentDefinition: A lake contained within a crater.
parentComment: Note that this class does not commit to what kind of crater contains the lake in question. Please see the subclasses for more specificity.

classDefinition: A lake contained within a crater.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.
classComment: Note that this class does not commit to what kind of crater contains the lake in question. Please see the subclasses for more specificity.

classDefinition: A crater formed by a volcano, within which occurs a vent (or vents) from which magma erupts as gases, lava, and ejecta.
parentDefinition: A generally circular saucer or bowl-shaped depression caused by explosive action.

classDefinition: A marsh in which soils are saturated with water that contains low concentrations of salts.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which includes communities of grasses, rushes, reeds, typhas, sedges, and other herbaceous plants (possibly with low-growing woody plants).

classDefinition: Water which has a low concentration of dissolved solutes, particularly that of sodium chloride.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.
classComment: The lower bound of solute concentration required for water to be considered freshwater is variable, but is always less than that of seawater, and often cited as less than 1 gram of solutes per 1 litre of water.

classDefinition: A marsh whose water contains a considerable quantity of dissolved salts.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which includes communities of grasses, rushes, reeds, typhas, sedges, and other herbaceous plants (possibly with low-growing woody plants).
classComment: It would be more correct to say that this has_quality salty or has_part ((soil and water) and has_increased_levels_of salt.

classDefinition: A pond which is 1) shallow, 2) man-made, and 3) designed to produce salt from seawater through evaporation.
parentDefinition: A body of water, usually of smaller size than a lake.
classComment: In such ponds, water is drawn out of seawater through natural evaporation which allows the salt to be subsequently harvested.

classDefinition: A pond or lake used for the artificial culture of fish.
parentDefinition: A lentic water body is a water body in which the accumulated water, in its totality, has very little to no directed flow.

classDefinition: A swamp which is located in tropical or subtropical environments and is determined by communities of trees and shrubs growing saline coastal environments.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which overlaps both terrestrial and marine ecosystems.

classDefinition: A multi-species collection of organisms of at least two different species, living in a particular area. Must have at least two populations of different species as members.
parentDefinition: A collection of organisms that consists of two or more organisms from at least two species.
classComment: Ecological community is defined broadly here, but includes both ecological interactions (inherited from parent term community) and spatial co-existence. It may be used to describe every organisms living in an area, but is often used to refer only to organisms of a particular taxon or guild (e.g., the plant community, the insect community, the herbivore community). The word community, as it often used to describe a group of humans living together, is a type of single-species collection of organisms, not an ecological community.

classDefinition: A plant structure (PO:0005679) which is a whole organism.
parentDefinition: A plant anatomical entity (PO:0025131) that is, or was, part of a plant, or was derived from a part of a plant.
classComment: Examples include plant embryo (PO:0009009), megagametophyte (PO:0025279) and microgametophyte (PO:0025280).
parentComment: 'Part' includes both proper parts and the whole plant. CARO:0000003 'connected anatomical structure' is defined as: Material anatomical entity that is a single connected structure with inherent 3D shape, generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome.

classDefinition: A tropical condition is an environmental condition in which an environmental system receives high yearly solar irradiance per unit area and, on Earth, the Sun reaches a subsolar point at least once during the solar year. This results in a hot and moist year-round climate at low elevations, which have a monthly average temperature above 18 degrees Celsius.
parentDefinition: An environmental condition is a range of a determinate quality or combination of qualities that are present in an environmental system.
parentComment: A condition defines a restricted range of a given quality or combination of qualities. If an environment class, E, has_condition C, then all qualities listed in C are restricted to the ranges defined in C in E. This is not intended as a logical conditional.

classDefinition: A subtropical condition is an environmental condition in which an envrionmental system receives more solar irradiance than those with temperate conditions, but less than those with tropical conditions. At low elevations, this typically results in eight months of the year having average temperatures greater than or equal to 10 degrees Celsius with the coldest monthly temperature averaging between 2 and 13 degrees Celsius.
parentDefinition: An environmental condition is a range of a determinate quality or combination of qualities that are present in an environmental system.
classComment:
As with most other climatic zones and conditions, multiple classification schemes have somehat different definitions and criteria. To quote from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ "Several methods have been used to define the subtropical climate. In the Trewartha climate classification, a subtropical region should have at least eight months with a mean temperature of 10 °C (50.0 °F) or above. German climatologists Carl Troll and Karlheinz Paffen defined Warm temperate zones as plain and hilly lands having an average temperature of the coldest month between 2 °C (35.6 °F) and 13 °C (55.4 °F) in the Northern Hemisphere and between 6 °C (42.8 °F) and 13 °C (55.4 °F) in the Southern Hemisphere, excluding oceanic and continental climates. According to the Troll-Paffen climate classification, there generally exists one large subtropical zone named the warm-temperate subtropical zone,[4] which is subdivided into seven smaller areas.[5]

According to the E. Neef climate classification, the subtropical zone is divided into two parts: Rainy winters of the west sides and Eastern subtropical climate.[6] According to the Wilhelm Lauer & Peter Frankenberg climate classification, the subtropical zone is divided into three parts: high-continental, continental, and maritime.[7] According to the Siegmund/Frankenberg climate classification, subtropical is one of six climate zones in the world.[8]"
parentComment: A condition defines a restricted range of a given quality or combination of qualities. If an environment class, E, has_condition C, then all qualities listed in C are restricted to the ranges defined in C in E. This is not intended as a logical conditional.

classDefinition: A lake which is formed under the surface of the Earth. Such a lake may be associated with caves and aquifers and springs.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake which is formed under the surface of the Earth. Such a lake may be associated with caves and aquifers and springs.
parentDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water that is under the surface of the earth.
parentComment: This class should probably be replaced with a quality-like entity "underground" which can then be distributed to the subclasses, solving the double inheritance.

classDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water that is under the surface of the earth.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of water of varying size.
classComment: This class should probably be replaced with a quality-like entity "underground" which can then be distributed to the subclasses, solving the double inheritance.
parentComment: The term body of water most often refers to large accumulations of water, such as oceans, seas, and lakes, but it includes smaller pools of water such as ponds, wetlands, or more rarely, puddles. A body of water does not have to be still or contained; Rivers, streams, canals, and other geographical features where water moves from one place to another are also considered bodies of water.

classDefinition: A river that is under the surface of the Earth.
parentDefinition: A stream which, through permanent or seasonal flow processes, moves from elevated land towards lower elevations through a definite channel and empties either into a sea, lake, or another river or ends on land as bed seepage and evapotranspiration exceed water supply.
parentComment: "There are no official definitions for the generic term river as applied to geographic features, although in some countries or communities a stream is defined by its size. Many names for small rivers are specific to geographic location; examples are "run" in some parts of the United States, "burn" in Scotland and northeast England, and "beck" in northern England. Sometimes a river is defined as being larger than a creek, but not always: the language is vague."

classDefinition: A river that is under the surface of the Earth.
parentDefinition: A stream that is under the surface of the Earth.

classDefinition: A stream that is under the surface of the Earth.
parentDefinition: A watercourse which is linear and flows across the solid portion of a planetary surface.

classDefinition: A stream that is under the surface of the Earth.
parentDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water that is under the surface of the earth.
parentComment: This class should probably be replaced with a quality-like entity "underground" which can then be distributed to the subclasses, solving the double inheritance.

classDefinition: Place or area with clustered or scattered buildings and a permanent human population.
parentDefinition: A site which has its extent determined by the presence or influence of one or more components of an environmental system or the processes occurring therein.
parentComment: Formerly, this class was an experimental class and a subclass of "environmental feature". It is now aligned to BFO. The class was not obsoleted as the core semantics maintained their stability through its transition.

classDefinition: A site which has its extent determined by the presence or influence of one or more components of an environmental system or the processes occurring therein.
classComment: Formerly, this class was an experimental class and a subclass of "environmental feature". It is now aligned to BFO. The class was not obsoleted as the core semantics maintained their stability through its transition.

classDefinition: A site which has its extent determined by the presence or influence of one or more components of an environmental system or the processes occurring therein.
classComment: Formerly, this class was an experimental class and a subclass of "environmental feature". It is now aligned to BFO. The class was not obsoleted as the core semantics maintained their stability through its transition.

classDefinition: A permanent walled and roofed construction.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: A mass of water.
parentDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which is continuous and is delimited by physical discontinuities or non-liquid boundaries.

classDefinition: An astronomical body part which is composed of the combined mass of water found on, under, and over the surface of a planet.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of liquid material.
classComment: This is a very broad and, in practice, poorly defined term. Please consider using or requesting a more specific class.

classDefinition: An open way for the passage of vehicles, persons, or animals on land.
parentDefinition: A construction which comprises a durable surface layer overlying a solid surface intended to sustain vehicular or foot traffic.

classDefinition: A construction which comprises a durable surface layer overlying a solid surface intended to sustain vehicular or foot traffic.
parentDefinition: A construction which enables the movement of humans, their animals or their vehicles.

classDefinition: A permanent way having one or more rails which provides a track for cars.
parentDefinition: A construction which enables the movement of humans, their animals or their vehicles.

classDefinition: A tunnel constructed by human means.
parentDefinition: An underground or underwater passage.

classDefinition: A solid surface layer which 1)  forms part of the boundary between the cavity of a cave and its solid container and 2) is roughtly perpendicular to the cave floor.
parentDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of solid environmental material.

classDefinition: A solid surface layer which 1)  forms part of the boundary between the cavity of a cave and its solid container and 2) is roughtly perpendicular to the cave floor.
parentDefinition: A surface layer where the solid or liquid material of an astronomical body comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
parentComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities

classDefinition: A solid surface layer which 1)  forms part of the boundary between the cavity of a cave and its solid container and 2) is roughtly perpendicular to the cave floor.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

classDefinition: A solid surface layer which 1) forms part of the boundary between the cavity of a cave and its solid container and 2)  is the closest solid boundary to the gravitational centre of the astronomical body of which the cave is a part.
parentDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of solid environmental material.
classComment: surface layer with role "walking substrate" or similar. Indicate it is some sort of "bottom"

classDefinition: A solid surface layer which 1) forms part of the boundary between the cavity of a cave and its solid container and 2)  is the closest solid boundary to the gravitational centre of the astronomical body of which the cave is a part.
parentDefinition: A surface layer where the solid or liquid material of an astronomical body comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
classComment: surface layer with role "walking substrate" or similar. Indicate it is some sort of "bottom"
parentComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities

classDefinition: A solid surface layer which 1) forms part of the boundary between the cavity of a cave and its solid container and 2)  is the closest solid boundary to the gravitational centre of the astronomical body of which the cave is a part.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.
classComment: surface layer with role "walking substrate" or similar. Indicate it is some sort of "bottom"

classDefinition: A morphological quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's affording not completed blocked passage or view.
parentDefinition: A morphological quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's affording unobstructed passage or view.

classDefinition: A structure which traverses a mass of one or more environmental materials, and encloses a roughly tubular site.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which has been formed from and is composed primarily of the matter of that astronomical body.
parentComment: Landforms may be natural or anthropogenic. This term has often has loose usage when referencing entities which are either subterranean or submerged below water bodies. In some cases, oceans themselves are considered landforms. Here, we have provided subclasses to resolve this ambiguity, but place oceans and other water bodies elsewhere.In later revisions, this hiearchy is likely to be reordered based on the formation processes of the entities within it.

classDefinition: A stream that branches off and flows away from a main stream channel. They are a common feature of river deltas.
parentDefinition: A watercourse which is linear and flows across the solid portion of a planetary surface.

classDefinition: An process during which natural or manufactured materials and products are processed and arranged by humans or their technology into structures.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which is driven by the action of humans.

classDefinition: An process during which natural or manufactured materials and products are processed and arranged by humans or their technology into structures.
parentDefinition: A process that realizes a plan which is the concretization of a plan specification.

classDefinition: A material entity which has been assembled through the intentional, instinctual, or deliberately programmed efforts of an organism or machine.
parentDefinition: An independent continuant that is spatially extended whose identity is independent of that of other entities and can be maintained through time.

classDefinition: A material entity which has been assembled through the intentional, instinctual, or deliberately programmed efforts of an organism or machine.
parentDefinition: An independent continuant that is spatially extended whose identity is independent of that of other entities and can be maintained through time.

classDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which includes, as parts, all the entities which have been constructed or manufactured by humans or their technology and which are within the gravitational sphere of influence of that body.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: The gravitational sphere of influence referenced in this class' definition is the Hill sphere: a region in which an object dominates the attraction of satellites despite gravitational perturbations.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: A cave developed along a fault or fault zone, either by movement of the fault or by preferential solution along it.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.

classDefinition: Structure designed to transport water from a remote source, usually by gravity.
parentDefinition: Artificial watercourse with no flow or a controlled flow used for navigation, drainage or irrigation.
parentComment: This class refers to the water contained in a canal channel, and not the channel itself.

classDefinition: A building part is a construction which is part of a building.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.
classComment: Not recommended for annotation. This class is likely to be made into an inferred class as its subclasses are distributed among more meaningful superclasses (i.e. ceiling is_a surface layer). See for example, "building floor". The boundaries between building parts may be bona fide or fiat.

classDefinition: A barrier constructed across a watercourse to control the flow or raise the level of water.
parentDefinition: A constructed barrier is a freestanding wall, berm, or fence built to limit movement of entities across a boundary.

classDefinition: A constructed barrier is a freestanding wall, berm, or fence built to limit movement of entities across a boundary.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: A built structure erected over a depression or obstacle to carry traffic or some facility such as a pipeline.
parentDefinition: A construction which enables the movement of humans, their animals or their vehicles.

classDefinition: An excavation in the Earth for the purpose of extracting earth materials.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: A planned environmental usage process during which a non-renewable resource such as petroleum, natural gas, or water is extracted from an ecosystem.
parentDefinition: A planned process during which humans access and obtain resources, benefits, or services from a natural or anthropised ecosystem.
An ecosystem which is formed as a result of human activity or impact.
classComment: As with other classes that are "features", the subclasses of this class are being moved to more informative locations. Their relation to agriculture will be modelled by something more akin to a quality or relation to an agricultural process.

classDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
classComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: A process during which humans rear animals or plants on land for harvest and consumption.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which is driven by the action of humans.

classDefinition: A land conversion process during which terrestrial ecosystems are altered to facilitate agricultural activities such as crop cultivation or the rearing of livestock.
parentDefinition: An anthropisation process during which terrestrial environments - natural or anthropised - or parts thereof are altered to facilitate human activities such as agriculture, settlement, or commerce.
classComment: This process typically relies on the conversion and development of  forests, savannas or grassland. Creation of farmland from wasteland, deserts or previous impervious surfaces is considerably less frequent because of the presence of degraded soil or the lack of fertile soil.
parentComment: Further examples include subdividing real estate into lots, typically for the purpose of building homes and converting unused factories into condominia.

classDefinition: An ecosystem which is formed as a result of human activity or impact.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classDefinition: An ecosystem which is formed as a result of human activity or impact.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic environment is an environmental system which is the product of human activity.
parentComment: Unsatisfactory definition here. Must consider the threshold that makes an environmental system anthropogenic.

classDefinition: An area of land which is used for the cultivation of crops or grazing of livestock, including any agricultural constructions therein.
parentComment: As with other classes that are "features", the subclasses of this class are being moved to more informative locations. Their relation to agriculture will be modelled by something more akin to a quality or relation to an agricultural process.

classDefinition: A cropland ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic terrestrial biome is a terrestrial biome which has community structures determined by human activity.
parentComment: Preliminary definition.

classDefinition: A cropland ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which 1) is determined by communities of annual crops, perennial woody crops, or by actively tilled land, 2) is primarily used for agricultural activity, and 3) contains no village or larger human settlement.

classDefinition: A rangeland biome is an anthropogenic terrestrial biome which is primarily used for the rearing and grazing of livestock.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic terrestrial biome is a terrestrial biome which has community structures determined by human activity.
parentComment: Preliminary definition.

classDefinition: An open artificial water channel, that leads water from a diversion dam or weir completely aside a natural flow, often an elevated box structure (typically wood) that follows the natural contours of the land.
parentDefinition: Artificial watercourse with no flow or a controlled flow used for navigation, drainage or irrigation.
parentComment: This class refers to the water contained in a canal channel, and not the channel itself.

classDefinition: A range of mounts which is dominated by mountains.
parentDefinition: A field which includes at least two mounts connected by high ground and arranged in an approximately linear fashion.

classDefinition: A field which includes at least two mounts connected by high ground and arranged in an approximately linear fashion.
parentDefinition: An unbroken expanse (as of ice)
parentComment: This class was created to accommodate "fields" from agricultural fields to marine mesoscale eddy fields. Thus, it has a very broad definition which makes it less than informative when annotating. Please consider using or requesting an appropriate subclass.

classDefinition: A landform that extends above the surrounding terrain in a limited area.
parentDefinition: A mountain or a hill.
classComment: A mountain is generally steeper than a hill, but there is no universally accepted standard definition for the height of a mountain or a hill although a mountain usually has an identifiable summit. The USGS had previously defined mountains as localised elevations of more than 300 meters; however, the organisation has accepted there are no technical definitions in the US. In ENVO, we primarily use the UNEP-WCMC classification to be compliant with SDG monitoring, but we can host other classifications on request: http://www.fao.org/sustainable-development-goals/indicators/1542/en/
parentComment: This is not placed under surface landform, as seamounts are also mounts and are submerged.

classDefinition: A mountain or a hill.
parentDefinition: A landform elevated above the surrounding area.
classComment: This is not placed under surface landform, as seamounts are also mounts and are submerged.

classDefinition: A volcanic eruption is a process during which lava, tephra (ash, lapilli, volcanic bombs and blocks), and assorted gases are expelled from a volcanic vent or fissure.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: A volcanic eruption is a process during which lava, tephra (ash, lapilli, volcanic bombs and blocks), and assorted gases are expelled from a volcanic vent or fissure.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: A process during which pieces of a planetary crust and uppermost mantle move.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: A range of mounts which is dominated by hills.
parentDefinition: A field which includes at least two mounts connected by high ground and arranged in an approximately linear fashion.

classDefinition: A rounded elevation of limited extent rising above the surrounding land with local relief of less than 300m.
parentDefinition: A mountain or a hill.
parentComment: This is not placed under surface landform, as seamounts are also mounts and are submerged.

classDefinition: A lower point that allows easier access through a mountain range. A pass has the general form of a saddle between two mountains.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A concave 3-D shape quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's being shaped in the form of the letter U.
parentDefinition: A complete three dimensional shape in which there is a line connecting pair of points on the object that lies outside the object. Or: a shape with cavities. Contrast: concave.

classDefinition: A glacier contained in the site of a mountain valley.
parentDefinition: An ice mass which is of sufficient mass that the action of gravity upon it overcomes the frictional forces holding it in place, causing it to deform and flow towards lower elevation.
parentComment: The definition of glacier is highly variable. Two main issues exist: 1) Whether or not a mass of ice must currently show movement to be considered a glacier or not and 2) What is the relationship between ice sheets and glaciers (i.e., which is the parent in a parent/child relationship or whether they are distinct terms).

classDefinition: An ice mass which is of sufficient mass that the action of gravity upon it overcomes the frictional forces holding it in place, causing it to deform and flow towards lower elevation.
parentDefinition: An mass of environmental materials which has appreciable quantities of several individual materials, such that the removal of one would convert the mass into a different entity.
classComment: The definition of glacier is highly variable. Two main issues exist: 1) Whether or not a mass of ice must currently show movement to be considered a glacier or not and 2) What is the relationship between ice sheets and glaciers (i.e., which is the parent in a parent/child relationship or whether they are distinct terms).

classDefinition: A valley that contains, or contained, a glacier and was formed by glacial activity. Typically U-shaped in cross-section.
parentDefinition: A depression which has been formed as a result of erosion by water or ice and which is low-lying, bordered by higher ground, and especially elongate.
parentComment: Valleys are typically located between hills our mountains.

classDefinition: A region of general uniform slope, comparatively level, and of considerable extent.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's having a horizontal surface without a slope, tilt, or curvature.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's surface becoming more extended in a plane.

classDefinition: A slope which is part of a rocky elevation and which has a high degree of steepness.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and relatively flat surrounding land.

classDefinition: A cliff that is a margin of a sea or ocean.
parentDefinition: A slope which is part of a rocky elevation and which has a high degree of steepness.

classDefinition: The general region of indefinite width that extends from the sea inland to the first major change in terrain features.
parentDefinition: A coast is the area where land meets the sea, ocean, or lake.
parentComment: Used for both marine and lake coasts. The boundary of the coast is fuzzy and it overlaps both the water body and land in quesiton. Compared to 'shore'

classDefinition: A cliff which is not adjacent to a major water body.
parentDefinition: A slope which is part of a rocky elevation and which has a high degree of steepness.

classDefinition: An area of flat, low-lying land adjacent to a coast and separated from the interior by other features.
parentDefinition: A region of general uniform slope, comparatively level, and of considerable extent.

classDefinition: A landform consisting of loose rock particles such as sand, gravel, shingle, pebbles, cobble, or even shell fragments along the shoreline of a body of water.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is formed as a result of the transport and deposition of particles by flowing liquid.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is composed primarily of particles.
classComment: Sediment is typically deposited on the bed or bottom of a body of water or other liquid.

classDefinition: A piece of rock which is derived from clastic rock and has a grain size of 4 to 64 millimeters.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is composed primarily of rock.
classComment: The grain size classification is based on the Krumbein phi scale of sedimentology.

classDefinition: A piece of rock which has a grain size between 64 and 256 mm.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is composed primarily of rock.

classDefinition: An environmental material which is composed primarily of pieces of gravel.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
classComment: As with all size-based classifications, there is considerable variation in what is considered gravel.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: A rigid covering that envelops an object.
parentDefinition: Anatomical group that has its parts adjacent to one another.

classDefinition: A beach which is part of a sea shore.
parentDefinition: A landform consisting of loose rock particles such as sand, gravel, shingle, pebbles, cobble, or even shell fragments along the shoreline of a body of water.

classDefinition: That part of the land in immediate contact with a sea, including the intertidal zone.
parentDefinition: That part of the land in immediate contact with a body of water including the area between high and low water lines.

classDefinition: A beach which is part of a lake shore.
parentDefinition: A landform consisting of loose rock particles such as sand, gravel, shingle, pebbles, cobble, or even shell fragments along the shoreline of a body of water.

classDefinition: That part of the land in immediate contact with a lake.
parentDefinition: That part of the land in immediate contact with a body of water including the area between high and low water lines.

classDefinition: A part of an astronomical body associated with a volcano - an opening, or rupture, in that body's surface or crust - which allows hot, molten rock, ash and gases to escape from deep below the surface.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A feature formed by the collapse of land following a volcanic eruption.
parentDefinition: A generally circular saucer or bowl-shaped depression caused by explosive action.

classDefinition: A generally circular saucer or bowl-shaped depression caused by explosive action.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A region rendered barren or partially barren by environmental extremes, especially by low rainfall.
parentDefinition: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of bedrock, desert pavement, scarp rock, talus, material exposed by slides, volcanic material, glacial debris, sand, material exposed during strip mining, gravel, and other accumulations of earthen material in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
parentComment: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of barren land generally have less than 15% cover of vegetation. A specific threshold is not asserted in this definition.

classDefinition: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of bedrock, desert pavement, scarp rock, talus, material exposed by slides, volcanic material, glacial debris, sand, material exposed during strip mining, gravel, and other accumulations of earthen material in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
parentDefinition: An environmental zone which is bounded by material parts of a land mass or the atmosphere or space adjacent to it.
classComment: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of barren land generally have less than 15% cover of vegetation. A specific threshold is not asserted in this definition.

classDefinition: An environmental condition in which annual precipitation is less than half of annual potential evapotranspiration.
parentDefinition: An environmental condition is a range of a determinate quality or combination of qualities that are present in an environmental system.
parentComment: A condition defines a restricted range of a given quality or combination of qualities. If an environment class, E, has_condition C, then all qualities listed in C are restricted to the ranges defined in C in E. This is not intended as a logical conditional.

classDefinition: Area of dry or relatively dry land surrounded by water or low wetland.
parentDefinition: A landmass which is part of a planet.

classDefinition: A landmass which is part of a planet.
parentDefinition: A large continuous area of land, either surrounded by sea or contiguous with another landmass.

classDefinition: A landmass which is part of a planet.
parentDefinition: A planetary surface is a surface layer where the solid or liquid material of a planet comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
parentComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities

classDefinition: An island constructed by human effort.
parentDefinition: Area of dry or relatively dry land surrounded by water or low wetland.

classDefinition: A depression which is part of a planetary crust, is of geographic scale, and is partially or completely enclosed.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: An action of exogenic processes (such as water flow or wind) which remove environmental material from one part of a planet's crust, transporting it to another location where it is deposited.
parentDefinition: An action of exogenic processes (such as water flow or wind) which remove environmental material from one location on the surface of an astronomical body, transporting it to another location where it is deposited.

classDefinition: A tract of alluvium formed at the mouth of a river where the deposition ofsome of its load exceeds its rate of removal, crossed by the divergent channels (distributaries) of the river.
parentDefinition: The end of a stream where it enters a standing water body such as a lake, sea or ocean.

classDefinition: The end of a stream where it enters a standing water body such as a lake, sea or ocean.
parentDefinition: The place where a stream discharges into a lagoon, lake, or the sea.

classDefinition: A two-dimensional continuant fiat boundary which is used to demarcate the interior from the exterior of a cave.
classComment: The term "cave entrance" is typically used when ingress or entry to the cave is desired. The same fiat bondary can serve as a cave exit, although that may be less feasible due to the shape or other physical properties of the cave.

classDefinition: An island formed of trees and shrubs that grow in saline coastal habitats in the tropics and subtropics.
parentDefinition: Area of dry or relatively dry land surrounded by water or low wetland.

classDefinition: A hydrographic feature which is located below the surface of a marine water body.
parentDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water.
A liquid surface layer which is in contact with air.
A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of liquid material.
A surface layer where the solid or liquid material of an astronomical body comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
parentComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities

classDefinition: A liquid surface layer which is in contact with air.
parentDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of some liquid.

classDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of liquid material.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is composed of a continuous medium bearing liquid, gaseous, and solid material in variable quantities.

classDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of liquid material.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of fluid.

classDefinition: A surface layer where the solid or liquid material of an astronomical body comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: A surface layer where the solid or liquid material of an astronomical body comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
parentDefinition: A layer of some material entity which is adjacent to one or more of its external boundaries and directly interacts with its immediate surroundings.
classComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities
parentComment: This class is distinct from a geometric surface, which is two-dimensional. The idea of "uppermost" may be problematic. Further, the definition of layer (the superclass of surface in rev 133) references surface. This may be another issue. Perhaps this can be made into an inferred class using 'bounding layer of' some material entity, note that 'bounding layer' implies containment, which may not be valid here.

classDefinition: The mixture of gases (roughly (by molar content/volume: 78% nitrogen, 20.95% oxygen, 0.93% argon, 0.038% carbon dioxide, trace amounts of other gases, and a variable amount (average around 1%) of water vapor) that surrounds the planet Earth.
parentDefinition: A material entity which is composed of one or more chemical entities and has neither independent shape nor volume but tends to expand indefinitely.

classDefinition: An area in which grasses (Graminae) are a significant component of the vegetation.
parentDefinition: A vegetated area is a geographic feature which has ground cover dominated by plant communities.

classDefinition: An ecosystem in which grasses (Graminae) are the dominant form of vegetation and determine the system's structure and dynamics.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which primarily occurs on land.

classDefinition: An upland moor or sandy area dominated by low shrubby vegetation including heather.
parentDefinition: A vegetated area is a geographic feature which has ground cover dominated by plant communities.

classDefinition: A grassland ecosystem which contains a variety of annual, biennial and perennial plants growing on rolling or flat terrain.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem in which grasses (Graminae) are the dominant form of vegetation and determine the system's structure and dynamics.
classComment: Typically, meadows have higher botanical biodiversity than other grasslands.

classDefinition: Land having a cover of trees, shrubs, or both.
parentDefinition: A vegetated area is a geographic feature which has ground cover dominated by plant communities.

classDefinition: A tunnel formed by the flow of molten lava, which has subsequently drained out.
parentDefinition: A cave formed in volcanic rock.
classComment: These are usually classified as a sub-type of volcanic cave, rather than a tunnel.
parentComment: "Lave cave" is differentiated from "volcanic cave": the former is formed in volcanic rock, the latter is formed by volcanic processes.

classDefinition: A cave formed in volcanic rock.
parentDefinition: A cave formed at the same time as the surrounding rock.
classComment: "Lave cave" is differentiated from "volcanic cave": the former is formed in volcanic rock, the latter is formed by volcanic processes.

classDefinition: A cylindrical shape that is hollow.
parentDefinition: A convex 3-D shape quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's exhibiting a consistently-sized round cross section.

classDefinition: A cylindrical shape that is hollow.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's having an empty space or cavity within.

classDefinition: An area with a high density of trees. A small forest may be called a wood.
parentDefinition: Land having a cover of trees, shrubs, or both.
classComment: The definitions of forest can vary greatly, and different classes will be needed to support the major categories. Tree cover alone is not enough to distinguish between forests and plantations. The international definition proposed by the 2010 FAO Forestry Resource Assessment: "land spanning more than 0.5 ha with trees higher than 5 metres and canopy cover of more than 10 percent, or trees able to reach these thresholds in situ . It does not include land that is predominantly under agricultural or urban land use." - FAO.  2010. Global forest resources assessment 2010, Main report, FAO Forestry Paper 163. Rome.

classDefinition: An ecosystem which is determined by communities of plants with a tree growth form and in which members of those communities form continuous or discontinuous regions of canopy cover.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which primarily occurs on land.
classComment: The definitions of forest can vary greatly, and different classes will be needed to support the major categories. Tree cover alone is not enough to distinguish between forests and plantations. The international definition proposed by the 2010 FAO Forestry Resource Assessment: "land spanning more than 0.5 ha with trees higher than 5 metres and canopy cover of more than 10 percent, or trees able to reach these thresholds in situ . It does not include land that is predominantly under agricultural or urban land use." - FAO.  2010. Global forest resources assessment 2010, Main report, FAO Forestry Paper 163. Rome.

classDefinition: A vegetated area which is part of a tundra ecosystem.
parentDefinition: A vegetated area is a geographic feature which has ground cover dominated by plant communities.

classDefinition: A tundra ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which 1) typically has monthly average temperatures below 10 degrees Celsius 2) has a low evapotranspiration ratio 3) is dominated by treeless terrain, covered by communities of low-growing vegetation such as dwarf shrubs, sedges and grasses, mosses, and lichens, 4) contains areas of soil underlain by permafrost with a thin active layer and 5) occurs in both polar and alpine regions (i.e., both high latitudes and high altitudes), and 5) does not have permanent snow or ice cover.
parentComment: Tundra ecosysems are often underlaid by permafrost, with the result that drainage is bad and the soil may be saturated for long periods. It does not have a permanent snow-ice cover.  Productivity is low in this biome because of the extremes of climate.

classDefinition: A tundra ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentDefinition: A biome which is  primarily or completely situated on a landmass.

classDefinition: An tundra climatic condition is a polar condition in which at least one month's average temperature exceeds 0 degrees Celsius.
parentDefinition: An environmental condition is a range of a determinate quality or combination of qualities that are present in an environmental system.
parentComment: A condition defines a restricted range of a given quality or combination of qualities. If an environment class, E, has_condition C, then all qualities listed in C are restricted to the ranges defined in C in E. This is not intended as a logical conditional.

classDefinition: An ecotone which overlaps at least one biome which supports the growth and persistence of trees and at least one that does not. Before ceasing altogether, tree growth becomes sparse and trees appear stunted as conditions become less favourable along this ecotone.
parentDefinition: An envirommental system which bridges two or more biomes and which includes ecological communities which blend these biomes' phylogenetic and phenotypic compositions.
parentComment: There are many subtypes of ecotone, some with sharp transitions and others with gradual, patchy transitions between communities. From Wikipedia:Ecotone - The word ecotone was coined from a combination of eco(logy) plus -tone, from the Greek tonos or tension – in other words, a place where ecologies are in tension.

classDefinition: A field which is located on land and used for agricultural purposes, such as the grazing of livestock or the cultivation of crops.
parentDefinition: An unbroken expanse (as of ice)
parentComment: This class was created to accommodate "fields" from agricultural fields to marine mesoscale eddy fields. Thus, it has a very broad definition which makes it less than informative when annotating. Please consider using or requesting an appropriate subclass.

classDefinition: An unbroken expanse (as of ice)
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: This class was created to accommodate "fields" from agricultural fields to marine mesoscale eddy fields. Thus, it has a very broad definition which makes it less than informative when annotating. Please consider using or requesting an appropriate subclass.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: An intentional planting of trees or shrubs maintained for food, typically fruit, production.
parentDefinition: An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.

classDefinition: An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.
parentDefinition: An area of land which is used for the cultivation of crops or grazing of livestock, including any agricultural constructions therein.

classDefinition: A place where grapes are grown for making wine, raisins or table grapes.
parentDefinition: An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.

An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.

classDefinition: A forest that has been intentionally established by human intervention.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which is determined by communities of plants with a tree growth form and in which members of those communities form continuous or discontinuous regions of canopy cover.
parentComment: The definitions of forest can vary greatly, and different classes will be needed to support the major categories. Tree cover alone is not enough to distinguish between forests and plantations. The international definition proposed by the 2010 FAO Forestry Resource Assessment: "land spanning more than 0.5 ha with trees higher than 5 metres and canopy cover of more than 10 percent, or trees able to reach these thresholds in situ . It does not include land that is predominantly under agricultural or urban land use." - FAO.  2010. Global forest resources assessment 2010, Main report, FAO Forestry Paper 163. Rome.

parentDefinition: An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.

classDefinition: A small road, generally not paved.
parentDefinition: An open way for the passage of vehicles, persons, or animals on land.

classDefinition: A political entitity established by more than one state and with at least some influence over the affairs of its member states.
parentDefinition: A geographical region whose affairs and population are administered by an authority.

classDefinition: A spring which  water contains a significant amount of dissolved minerals, that derive from the rocks through which the water flows.
parentDefinition: A surface landform which provides an egress for groundwater or steam to flow out of the ground.
parentComment: Springs are typically where an aquifer surface meets the ground surface or where there is a fissure.

classDefinition: A spring through which water with elevated levels of dissolved derivatives of sulfur flows.
parentDefinition: A spring which  water contains a significant amount of dissolved minerals, that derive from the rocks through which the water flows.

classDefinition: An arid terrain with clay-rich soil that has been extensively eroded by wind and water.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A valley which no longer has water flowing or accumulating over its surface.
parentDefinition: A depression which has been formed as a result of erosion by water or ice and which is low-lying, bordered by higher ground, and especially elongate.
classComment: Typically found in either Karst (limestone) or chalk terrain.
parentComment: Valleys are typically located between hills our mountains.

classDefinition: A valley that contains, and has been formed by, a stream.
parentDefinition: A depression which has been formed as a result of erosion by water or ice and which is low-lying, bordered by higher ground, and especially elongate.
parentComment: Valleys are typically located between hills our mountains.

classDefinition: A ridge of rocks, lying near the surface of the sea, which may be visible at low tide, but is usually covered by water.

parentDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water.

classDefinition: Ice which is formed from water.
parentDefinition: An ice is an environmental material which is either frozen or which is maintained in a solid state by gravitational forces or pressure.
classComment:
Water ice can appear transparent or opaque bluish-white color, depending on the presence of impurities or air inclusions. The addition of other materials such as soil may further alter its appearance.

When speaking about ice on Earth, usually water ice is meant - the solid, crystalline form of water found in the atmosphere as snow crystals, hail, ice pellets, etc., and on the earth's surface in forms such as hoarfrost, rime, glaze, sea ice, glacier ice, ground ice, frazil, anchor ice, etc.

This form of water is, strictly speaking, called ice Ih, the Roman numeral I distinguishing it from more than a dozen other phases and the letter h distinguishing it from the metastable cubic phase ice Ic. Ice Ih is the only one of the several known phases of water ice that is stable at commonly occurring temperatures and pressures. (Some of the other forms have very unusual properties, ice VII, for example, being stable only at pressures above 22 400 kg/cm^2, but then existing at temperatures up to about 100C.)

It has an open structure with a specific gravity of 0.9166 which is slightly less than water; because the water molecules bond to their neighbors covalently only in four directions; it therefore floats on higher density water, where broken molecular bonds permit closer packing. All commonly occurring forms of ice are crystalline, although large single crystals are relatively rare except in glaciers. The ice crystal lattice possesses hexagonal symmetry that manifests itself in the gross forms of such single crystals as are sometimes found in snow. At an air pressure of one atmosphere, ice melts at 0 C by definition of the Celsius temperature scale. (Strictly speaking the equilibrium point among water, ice, and vapor occurs at +0.01C, the triple point.) On the other hand, ice does not invariably form in liquid water cooled below this temperature; it has a tendency to supercool, more so in the absence of ice nuclei.

In permafrost regions, ice may occupy voids in soils and rocks and may develop in a variety of forms. Ice may be colourless to pale blue or greenish-blue. It may appear white due to included gas bubbles; in exposures, ground ice may also appear black.

In nature ice is formed either by: (a) the freezing of water, (b) the condensation of atmospheric water vapour direct into ice crystals, (c) the compaction of snow with or without the motion of a glacier, or (d) the impregnation of porous snow masses with water which subsequently freeze.
parentComment: Note that ice may be formed at very high temperatures, due to gravitational effects and/or pressure.

classDefinition: Snow is an environmental material which is primarily composed of flakes of crystalline water ice.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: Snow is an environmental material which is primarily composed of flakes of crystalline water ice.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: A glacier which covers an area of greater than 50,000 square kilometers.
parentDefinition: An ice mass which is of sufficient mass that the action of gravity upon it overcomes the frictional forces holding it in place, causing it to deform and flow towards lower elevation.
classComment: This is not always classified as a glacier in the cryosphere community.
parentComment: The definition of glacier is highly variable. Two main issues exist: 1) Whether or not a mass of ice must currently show movement to be considered a glacier or not and 2) What is the relationship between ice sheets and glaciers (i.e., which is the parent in a parent/child relationship or whether they are distinct terms).

classDefinition: A size quality which is relatively high.
parentDefinition: A morphology quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's physical magnitude.

classDefinition: A size quality which is relatively high.
parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is increased compared to normal or average.

classDefinition: An mass of environmental materials which has appreciable quantities of several individual materials, such that the removal of one would convert the mass into a different entity.
parentDefinition: An object which is composed primarily of an environmental material
parentComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.

classDefinition: An ice is an environmental material which is either frozen or which is maintained in a solid state by gravitational forces or pressure.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
classComment: Note that ice may be formed at very high temperatures, due to gravitational effects and/or pressure.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: A material transport process during which the snow and ice constituting a glacier, and anything contained within it, is transported down a slope by gravitation.
parentDefinition: An advective transport process during which a mass of ice is transported from one location to another.
classComment: This must be differentiated from small ice masses simply falling or moving down slopes. In ENVO, this is a subclass of advective transport process, however, this may not be universally accepted by some which strictly limit advection to fluids.

classDefinition: A material transport process during which the snow and ice constituting a glacier, and anything contained within it, is transported down a slope by gravitation.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which involves glaciers or ice sheets.
classComment: This must be differentiated from small ice masses simply falling or moving down slopes. In ENVO, this is a subclass of advective transport process, however, this may not be universally accepted by some which strictly limit advection to fluids.
parentComment: Note that ice sheets and glaciers are confounded and confused in multiple communities and across multiple sources.

classDefinition: A rock is a naturally occurring solid aggregate of one or more minerals or mineraloids.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
classComment: From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ [A mineral] is different from a rock, which can be an aggregate of minerals or non-minerals and does not have a specific chemical composition. The exact definition of a mineral is under debate, especially with respect to the requirement a valid species be abiogenic, and to a lesser extent with regards to it having an ordered atomic structure.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: An environmental material which is 1) composed primarily of soil or rock and included ice or organic material and 2) at or below the freezing point of water for two or more years.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: Ice is not always present, as may be in the case of nonporous bedrock, but it frequently occurs and it may be in amounts exceeding the potential hydraulic saturation of the ground material.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: An environmental material which is 1) composed primarily of soil or rock and included ice or organic material and 2) at or below the freezing point of water for two or more years.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: Ice is not always present, as may be in the case of nonporous bedrock, but it frequently occurs and it may be in amounts exceeding the potential hydraulic saturation of the ground material.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentDefinition: An independent continuant that is spatially extended whose identity is independent of that of other entities and can be maintained through time.
classComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: A temperature which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A physical quality of the thermal energy of a system.

classDefinition: A temperature which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is decreased compared to normal or average.

classDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

" The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm."  Soil taxonomy, 2nd Ed., quoted in http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/edu/?cid=nrcs142p2_054280
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: A geographical region that serves the purpose of keeping two or more other areas (often, but not necessarily, countries) distant from one another, for whatever reason.

A geographical area, usually the frontier or boundary between two or more military powers (or alliances), where military activity is not permitted, usually by peace treaty, armistice or other bilateral or multilateral agreement.
