parentDefinition: A geographical region that serves the purpose of keeping two or more other areas (often, but not necessarily, countries) distant from one another, for whatever reason.

classDefinition: An opening of the sea into the land, or of a lake into its shore.
parentDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water.

classDefinition: A circular or round inlet with a narrow entrance.
parentDefinition: An opening of the sea into the land.

classDefinition: A shape quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's being such that every part of the surface or the circumference is equidistant from the center.
parentDefinition: A spheroid quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's being oval with two axes of symmetry, as produced by a conical section.

classDefinition: A ditch that supplies water to surrounding land.
parentDefinition: A small, human-made channel which has been dug for draining or irrigating the land.

classDefinition: A ditch that collects water from the surrounding land.
parentDefinition: A small, human-made channel which has been dug for draining or irrigating the land.

classDefinition: The sloping margin of a watercourse, serving to confine it to its natural channel.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and relatively flat surrounding land.

classDefinition: The sloping margin of a stream, serving to confine it to its natural channel.
parentDefinition: The sloping margin of a watercourse, serving to confine it to its natural channel.

classDefinition: A dome-shaped ice mass that covers less than 50,000 km2 of land area (usually covering a highland area).
parentDefinition: An ice mass which has formed over land.
parentComment: Land ice is any part of the Earth's seasonal or perennial ice cover that has formed over land as the result, principally, of the freezing of precipitation; opposed to sea ice formed by the freezing of seawater.  Thus, an iceberg or tabular iceberg is land ice as well as its parent glacier, ice sheet, or ice shelf. The two major concentrations of land ice are the ice sheets of Greenland and Antarctica. Glaciers and ice caps are the other important forms; however, some members of the glaciology community hold that glaciers (i.e. rock glaciers) need not have any ice.

classDefinition: An ice mass which has formed over land.
parentDefinition: A mass of water ice.
classComment: Land ice is any part of the Earth's seasonal or perennial ice cover that has formed over land as the result, principally, of the freezing of precipitation; opposed to sea ice formed by the freezing of seawater.  Thus, an iceberg or tabular iceberg is land ice as well as its parent glacier, ice sheet, or ice shelf. The two major concentrations of land ice are the ice sheets of Greenland and Antarctica. Glaciers and ice caps are the other important forms; however, some members of the glaciology community hold that glaciers (i.e. rock glaciers) need not have any ice.

classDefinition: A region of permanent snow in mountainous areas or high latitudes.
parentDefinition: An unbroken expanse (as of ice)
parentComment: This class was created to accommodate "fields" from agricultural fields to marine mesoscale eddy fields. Thus, it has a very broad definition which makes it less than informative when annotating. Please consider using or requesting an appropriate subclass.

classDefinition: A layer of some material entity which is adjacent to one or more of its external boundaries and directly interacts with its immediate surroundings.
parentDefinition: A layer which separates two portions of environmental material which possess 1) differing compositions, 2) a discontinuity of some property, or 3) some derivative of some property in a direction normal to the interface.
classComment: This class is distinct from a geometric surface, which is two-dimensional. The idea of "uppermost" may be problematic. Further, the definition of layer (the superclass of surface in rev 133) references surface. This may be another issue. Perhaps this can be made into an inferred class using 'bounding layer of' some material entity, note that 'bounding layer' implies containment, which may not be valid here.

classDefinition: The region occupied by any more or less continuous, directed movement of ocean water that flows in one of the Earth's oceans. Ocean Currents are rivers of hot or cold water within the ocean. The currents are generated from the forces acting upon the water like the earth's rotation, the wind, the temperature and salinity differences and the gravitation of the moon. The depth contours, the shoreline and other movements influence the direction and strength of the movements of water that forms a given current.
parentDefinition: A water current which is maintained by a continuous, directed movement of marine water, generated by forces caused by breaking waves, wind, Coriolis force, temperature and salinity differences, and tides caused by the gravitational pull of astronomical bodies. Depth contours, shoreline configurations and interaction with other currents influence a current's direction and strength.
classComment: Subclasses of this class are to be populated by inference. Definition modified from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ocean_current.

classDefinition: A water current which is maintained by a continuous, directed movement of marine water, generated by forces caused by breaking waves, wind, Coriolis force, temperature and salinity differences, and tides caused by the gravitational pull of astronomical bodies. Depth contours, shoreline configurations and interaction with other currents influence a current's direction and strength.
parentDefinition: A hydroform which is maintained by a continuous, directed movement of water, generated by disequilibria in a water mass.
parentComment: Depth contours, shoreline configurations and interaction with other currents influence a current's direction and strength.

classDefinition: A shallow stretch of a river or stream, where the current is above the average stream velocity and where the water forms small rippled waves as a result. It often consists of a rocky bed of gravels or other small stones.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is composed of a continuous medium bearing liquid, gaseous, and solid material in variable quantities.

classDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is composed of a continuous medium bearing liquid, gaseous, and solid material in variable quantities.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: A thickness quality which lacks pattern.
parentDefinition: A 1-D extent quality which is equal to the dimension through an object as opposed to its length or width.

classDefinition: Chains of rocks or coral at or near the surface of water constructed by man.
A marine reef which is composed primarily of aragonite structures produced by living organisms, found in shallow, low-nutrient waters.
parentDefinition: A reef which is located in a marine water body.

classDefinition: A reef which is located in a marine water body.
An alkaline flat, in the context of a marine environment.
parentDefinition: A dry lakebed consisting of fine-grained sediments infused with alkali salts. Generally the shore or bed of an endorheic lake.

classDefinition: A dry lakebed consisting of fine-grained sediments infused with alkali salts. Generally the shore or bed of an endorheic lake.
parentDefinition: A lake bed which is dry. That is, the bed of a dry lake.
parentComment: Deliberately disjoint with "lake bed", which must be covered with water.

classDefinition: A section of a river or stream that diverts from the main course and rejoins later.
parentDefinition: A watercourse which is linear and flows across the solid portion of a planetary surface.

classDefinition: The upper part of a river system, denoting the upper basin and source streams of a river.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is composed of a continuous medium bearing liquid, gaseous, and solid material in variable quantities.

classDefinition: A structural basin is a geological depression formed by tectonic warping of previously flat lying rock strata.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: An area of grassland or pasture beside a river, subject to seasonal flooding.
parentDefinition: A wet meadow is a type of wetland with soils that are saturated with water for part or all of the growing season.
parentComment: Debate exists whether a wet meadow is a type of marsh or a completely separate type of wetland. Wet prairies and wet savannas are hydrologically similar. Wet meadows may occur because of restricted drainage or the receipt of large amounts of water from rain or melted snow. They may also occur in riparian zones and around the shores of large lakes. Unlike a marsh or swamp, a wet meadow does not have standing water present except for brief to moderate periods during the growing season. Instead, the ground in a wet meadow fluctuates between brief periods of inundation and longer periods of saturation. Wet meadows often have large numbers of wetland plant species, which frequently survive as buried seeds during dry periods, and then regenerate after flooding. Wet meadows therefore do not usually support aquatic life such as fish. They typically have a high diversity of plant species, and may attract large numbers of birds, small mammals and insects including butterflies.

classDefinition: A wet meadow is a type of wetland with soils that are saturated with water for part or all of the growing season.
parentDefinition: A grassland ecosystem which contains a variety of annual, biennial and perennial plants growing on rolling or flat terrain.
classComment: Debate exists whether a wet meadow is a type of marsh or a completely separate type of wetland. Wet prairies and wet savannas are hydrologically similar. Wet meadows may occur because of restricted drainage or the receipt of large amounts of water from rain or melted snow. They may also occur in riparian zones and around the shores of large lakes. Unlike a marsh or swamp, a wet meadow does not have standing water present except for brief to moderate periods during the growing season. Instead, the ground in a wet meadow fluctuates between brief periods of inundation and longer periods of saturation. Wet meadows often have large numbers of wetland plant species, which frequently survive as buried seeds during dry periods, and then regenerate after flooding. Wet meadows therefore do not usually support aquatic life such as fish. They typically have a high diversity of plant species, and may attract large numbers of birds, small mammals and insects including butterflies.
parentComment: Typically, meadows have higher botanical biodiversity than other grasslands.

classDefinition: A depression which is semicircular or crescent-shaped, found towards the crest of a mountain, and formed by the erosional processes caused by the motion of a glacier.
parentDefinition: A valley that contains, or contained, a glacier and was formed by glacial activity. Typically U-shaped in cross-section.

classDefinition: A small, isolated, fertile or green area in a desert region, usually having a spring or well.
parentDefinition: An oasis is a vegetated area located in a desert, supplied with water from a water source which it surrounds, and surrounded by arid soil, sand, or rock.

classDefinition: An oasis is a vegetated area located in a desert, supplied with water from a water source which it surrounds, and surrounded by arid soil, sand, or rock.
parentDefinition: A vegetated area is a geographic feature which has ground cover dominated by plant communities.

classDefinition: An artificial working of peatland to remove the peat.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A road or railway elevated by a bank, usually across a broad body of water or wetland.
parentDefinition: A construction which enables the movement of humans, their animals or their vehicles.

An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.

An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.

An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.

An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.

An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.

classDefinition: A plantation which is used to grow Hevea brasiliensis or other species from which natural latex is harvested.
parentDefinition: An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.

classDefinition: A lake formed of a natural deposit of alphalt, a black, highly viscous liquid or semi-solid composed of fossil hydrocarbons.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: An oceanic island, often having a characteristic ring-like shape surrounding a lagoon. Atolls are formed when coral reef grows around a volcanic island that later subsides into the ocean.
parentDefinition: An island that does not sit on a continental shelf, and is of volcanic origin.

classDefinition: An island that does not sit on a continental shelf, and is of volcanic origin.
parentDefinition: Area of dry or relatively dry land surrounded by water or low wetland.

classDefinition: A linear shoaling landform feature within a body of water. Bars tend to be long and narrow (linear) and develop where a current (or waves) promote deposition of granular material, resulting in localized shallowing (shoaling) of the water. Bars can appear in the sea, in a lake, or in a river. They are typically composed of sand, although could be of any granular matter that the moving water has access to and is capable of shifting around (for example, soil, silt, gravel, cobble, shingle, or even boulders). The grain size of the material comprising a bar is related: to the size of the waves or the strength of the currents moving the material, but the availability of material to be worked by waves and currents is also important.
parentDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water.

classDefinition: A hole in coastal rock through which sea water is forced by a rising tide or waves and spurted through an outlet into the air.
parentDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water.

classDefinition: Relatively narrow, deep depression with steep sides, the bottom of which generally has a continuous slope.
parentDefinition: A depression which has been formed as a result of erosion by water or ice and which is low-lying, bordered by higher ground, and especially elongate.
parentComment: Valleys are typically located between hills our mountains.

classDefinition: A hill of sand built by eolian processes.
parentDefinition: A rounded elevation of limited extent rising above the surrounding land with local relief of less than 300m.

classDefinition: A material transport process during which one or more environmental materials are transported by the action of wind.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: A valley that contains, and has been formed by, a river.
parentDefinition: A valley that contains, and has been formed by, a stream.

classDefinition: A desert plain characterized by a surface veneer of sand.
parentDefinition: A region rendered barren or partially barren by environmental extremes, especially by low rainfall.
classComment: There should be  relation here to ENVO:sand, but it's more than "primarily composed of" and must call upon the idea of "ground surface" or layer.

classDefinition: A desert plain characterized by a surface veneer of rock.
parentDefinition: A region rendered barren or partially barren by environmental extremes, especially by low rainfall.
classComment: There should be  relation here to ENVO:rock, but it's more than "primarily composed of" and must call upon the idea of "ground surface" or layer.

classDefinition: Narrow section of land in a body of water connecting two larger land areas.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A surface landform which is formed by the dissolution of a soluble layer or layers of bedrock.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
classComment: Karsts usually form in masses of carbonate rock such as limestone or dolomite. Karst landscapes display distinctive surface features and underground drainages, and in some examples there may be little or no surface drainage.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A cave formed in limestone, usually by dissolution of limestone by acidic groundwater.
parentDefinition: A cave formed by the dissolution of soluble rock or other solid material such as limestone, chalk, dolomite, gypsum, salt or marble.
classComment: Can be linked to a solutional environmental process and acidic groundwater.
parentComment: Can be linked to a solutional environmental process and acidic groundwater.

classDefinition: A structural quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer bring gradually worn away.
parentDefinition: A morphology quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's relative position, shape, arrangements and connectivity of an organism's various parts; the pattern underlying its form.

classDefinition: An erosional process in which bedrock is converted from its solid form into a solute by the action of some solvent.
parentDefinition: An action of exogenic processes (such as water flow or wind) which remove environmental material from one part of a planet's crust, transporting it to another location where it is deposited.

classDefinition: A landform elevated above the surrounding area.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which has been formed from and is composed primarily of the matter of that astronomical body.
parentComment: Landforms may be natural or anthropogenic. This term has often has loose usage when referencing entities which are either subterranean or submerged below water bodies. In some cases, oceans themselves are considered landforms. Here, we have provided subclasses to resolve this ambiguity, but place oceans and other water bodies elsewhere.In later revisions, this hiearchy is likely to be reordered based on the formation processes of the entities within it.

classDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which has been formed from and is composed primarily of the matter of that astronomical body.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.
classComment: Landforms may be natural or anthropogenic. This term has often has loose usage when referencing entities which are either subterranean or submerged below water bodies. In some cases, oceans themselves are considered landforms. Here, we have provided subclasses to resolve this ambiguity, but place oceans and other water bodies elsewhere.In later revisions, this hiearchy is likely to be reordered based on the formation processes of the entities within it.

classDefinition: An elevation which is relatively high.
parentDefinition: A positional quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's vertical distance of a point above or below a reference surface.

classDefinition: An elevation which is relatively high.
parentDefinition: A position which is relatively high.

classDefinition: An accumulation of boulders, stones, or other debris carried and deposited by a glacier.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: An artificial slope or wall, usually earthen, which parallels the course of a river, built for the purpose of containing the river.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: An artificial slope or wall, usually earthen, which parallels the course of a river, built for the purpose of containing the river.
parentDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water.

classDefinition: An artificial slope or wall, usually earthen, which parallels the course of a river, built for the purpose of containing the river.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and relatively flat surrounding land.

classDefinition: An elevated area of land with a flat top and sides that are usually steep cliffs. Mesas form in areas where horizontally layered rocks are uplifted by tectonic activity.
parentDefinition: An elevation which is flattened across its highest surface.

classDefinition: An elevation which is flattened across its highest surface.
parentDefinition: A landform elevated above the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A rounded elevated area.
parentDefinition: A mountain or a hill.
parentComment: This is not placed under surface landform, as seamounts are also mounts and are submerged.

classDefinition: The exposed summit of a ridge, mountain, or peak not covered with ice or snow within an ice field or glacier. The term is typically used in areas where a permanent ice mass is present.
parentDefinition: The summit of a mount.
classComment: "peak" in the definition is understood as a synonym of mount, rather than of summit. Nunataks may also refer to areas of ridges. The definition and placement of this class may need to be revised.

classDefinition: The summit of a mount.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which has been formed from and is composed primarily of the matter of that astronomical body.
parentComment: Landforms may be natural or anthropogenic. This term has often has loose usage when referencing entities which are either subterranean or submerged below water bodies. In some cases, oceans themselves are considered landforms. Here, we have provided subclasses to resolve this ambiguity, but place oceans and other water bodies elsewhere.In later revisions, this hiearchy is likely to be reordered based on the formation processes of the entities within it.

classDefinition: An elevated and comparatively level expanse of land.
parentDefinition: An elevation which is flattened across its highest surface.

classDefinition: A desert plain characterized by a surface veneer of gravel or stones.
parentDefinition: A region rendered barren or partially barren by environmental extremes, especially by low rainfall.
classComment: There should be  relation here to ENVO:rock and ENVO:gravel, but it's more than "primarily composed of" and must call upon the idea of "ground surface" or layer.

classDefinition: A tributary valley with the floor at a higher relief than the main channel into which it flows. They are most commonly associated with U-shaped valleys when a tributary glacier flows into a glacier of larger volume.
parentDefinition: A valley that contains, or contained, a glacier and was formed by glacial activity. Typically U-shaped in cross-section.

classDefinition: Rain-fed, potentially deep peatlands occurring principally in lowland areas across much of Northern Europe, as well as in the former USSR, North America and parts of the southern hemisphere.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which accumulates acidic peat, a deposit of dead plant material.

classDefinition: Flat or concave peatlands with a string-like pattern of hummocks (hence the name), found principally in northern Scandinavia but occurring in the western parts of the former USSR and in North America. A few examples exist in northern Britain.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which accumulates acidic peat, a deposit of dead plant material.

classDefinition: A shape quality in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's curving inward.
parentDefinition: Surface shape that refers to the inward or outward curvature of the surface.

classDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's surface becoming more extended in a plane.
parentDefinition: A surface shape quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's exhibiting a degree of bending.

classDefinition: A patch of ground, distinct from and slightly above the surrounding plain or wetland. Often occurs in groups.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A patch of ground, distinct from and slightly above the surrounding plain or wetland. Often occurs in groups.
parentDefinition: A landform elevated above the surrounding area.

classDefinition: Peatlands with a shallow peat layer, only about 500 mm thick, dominated by sedges and grasses. They form in permafrost areas, covering around 110,000 to 160,000 km2 in Alaska, Canada, and the former USSR.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which accumulates acidic peat, a deposit of dead plant material.

classDefinition: An ecosystem which 1) typically has monthly average temperatures below 10 degrees Celsius 2) has a low evapotranspiration ratio 3) is dominated by treeless terrain, covered by communities of low-growing vegetation such as dwarf shrubs, sedges and grasses, mosses, and lichens, 4) contains areas of soil underlain by permafrost with a thin active layer and 5) occurs in both polar and alpine regions (i.e., both high latitudes and high altitudes), and 5) does not have permanent snow or ice cover.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which primarily occurs on land.
classComment: Tundra ecosysems are often underlaid by permafrost, with the result that drainage is bad and the soil may be saturated for long periods. It does not have a permanent snow-ice cover.  Productivity is low in this biome because of the extremes of climate.

classDefinition: Peatland typified by characteristic high mounds, each with a permanently frozen core, with wet depressions between the mounds.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which accumulates acidic peat, a deposit of dead plant material.
classComment: These develop where the ground surface is frozen only for part of the year, and are common in the former USSR, Canada and parts of Scandinavia.

classDefinition: A frost heave which is formed as the result of a perennial ice lens forming under soil, pushing a roughly oval portion land surface upwards.
parentDefinition: An elevation which is formed as an ice mass forms under soil, resulting in upwards deformation of the land surface.
classComment: Palsas typically occur in areas with discontinuous permafrost, frequently peat bogs. A palsa consists, similarly to a pingo, of an ice core and overlying soil materials, in case of a palsa usually boggy soil. Palsas are characteristically found in areas with discontinuous permafrost and in such areas bay be the only reliable surface evidence of permafrost. A palsa needs large quantities of water for the formation of its ice core (i.e. ice lens), which is why they frequently emerge from and are bound by boggy soils, which can store enormous quantities of water in their pores. Palsas develop particularly in moorlands and are therefore also named palsamoors.

classDefinition: Forested peatlands including both rain- and groundwater-fed types, commonly recorded in tropical regions with high rainfall.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which accumulates acidic peat, a deposit of dead plant material.
classComment: This type of peatland covers around 350,000 km2, primarily in south-east Asia but also occurring in the Everglades in Florida.

classDefinition: Feature on the ocean floor at a depth of 3500 - 6000 meters.
parentDefinition: A hydrographic feature which is located below the surface of a marine water body.

classDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is composed of a continuous medium bearing liquid, gaseous, and solid material in variable quantities.

classDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: A wetland that forms when mud is deposited by the tides, rivers, sea or oceans.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which overlaps both terrestrial and marine ecosystems.

An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.

classDefinition: Broken rock that appears at the bottom of crags, mountain cliffs or valley shoulders.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: A mass of solid material which is composed primarily of rock.
parentDefinition: An mass of environmental material which is composed primarily of a solid environmental material
parentComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.

classDefinition: A natural depression or hole in the surface topography caused by the removal of soil or bedrock, often both, by water. Sinkholes may vary in size from less than a meter to several hundred meters both in diameter and depth, and vary in form from soil-lined bowls to bedrock-edged chasms.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A natural depression or hole in the surface topography caused by the removal of soil or bedrock, often both, by water. Sinkholes may vary in size from less than a meter to several hundred meters both in diameter and depth, and vary in form from soil-lined bowls to bedrock-edged chasms.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A lake bed which is dry. That is, the bed of a dry lake.
parentDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of solid environmental material.
classComment: Deliberately disjoint with "lake bed", which must be covered with water.

classDefinition: A lake bed which is dry. That is, the bed of a dry lake.
parentDefinition: A surface layer where the solid or liquid material of an astronomical body comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
classComment: Deliberately disjoint with "lake bed", which must be covered with water.
parentComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities

classDefinition: A lake bed which is dry. That is, the bed of a dry lake.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.
classComment: Deliberately disjoint with "lake bed", which must be covered with water.

classDefinition: A lake from which there is no outflow of water, either on the surface as rivers, or underground by flow or diffusion through rock or permeable material.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A drainage basin from which there is no outflow of water, either on the surface as rivers, or underground by flow or diffusion through rock or permeable material.
parentDefinition: An extent or area of land where surface water from rain and melting snow or ice converges to a single point at lower elevation, usually the exit of the basin, where the waters join another waterbody.

classDefinition: A lake permanently covered by ice.
parentDefinition: A lake which is primarily composed of glacial meltwater and which fills a depression formed as a result of a glacial erosion process.

classDefinition: A lake which is primarily composed of glacial meltwater and which fills a depression formed as a result of a glacial erosion process.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake which has layers of water which do not intermix.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.
classComment: The deepest layer of water in such a lake typically does not contain any dissolved oxygen. The layers of sediment at the bottom of a meromictic lake remain relatively undisturbed because there are no living organisms to stir them up.

classDefinition: A holomictic lake is a lake which mixes at least once per year. Mixing is caused by a uniform temperature distribution from the upper to lower layers of the lake.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake, part of whose margin is formed by an ice mass, ice cap or glacier, the ice having obstructed the natural drainage of the land.
parentDefinition: A lake which is primarily composed of glacial meltwater and which fills a depression formed as a result of a glacial erosion process.

classDefinition: A lake in a glacially eroded valley, which has been eroded below sea level.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake which is formed when a wide meander from a stream or a river is cut off to form a lake. They are called oxbow lakes due to the distinctive curved shape that results from this process.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake which fills a depression that has formed as a result of subsidence along a a rift zone, an area of extensional tectonics in the continental crust.
parentDefinition: A lake which is contained in a depression formed by the deformation and resulting lateral and vertical movements of a lithosphere.

classDefinition: A lake which is contained in a depression formed by the deformation and resulting lateral and vertical movements of a lithosphere.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A process during which pieces of a planetary crust and uppermost mantle move away from one another.
parentDefinition: A process during which pieces of a planetary crust and uppermost mantle move.

classDefinition: A spring through which fluid intermittently flows.
parentDefinition: A surface landform which provides an egress for groundwater or steam to flow out of the ground.
parentComment: Springs are typically where an aquifer surface meets the ground surface or where there is a fissure.

classDefinition: A spring whose flow is continuous.
parentDefinition: A surface landform which provides an egress for groundwater or steam to flow out of the ground.
parentComment: Springs are typically where an aquifer surface meets the ground surface or where there is a fissure.

classDefinition: The water mass of an ocean directly above a continental shelf.
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of a marine water body.

classDefinition: A layer that is part of a marine water body.
parentDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous volume of liquid water and is held in shape or sustained by an environmental process.
parentComment: Similar, in spirit, to landform.

classDefinition: A layer that is part of a marine water body.
parentDefinition: A layer in a water mass, itself composed primarily of water.
parentComment: This class will eventually be populated by inference, and its asserted subclasses removed.

classDefinition: The water mass of an ocean that is not above a continental shelf.
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of a marine water body.

classDefinition: An open ocean region.
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of a marine water body.

classDefinition: The zone of an ocean from the surface to where photosynthesis can occur, due to the penetration of light.
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of a marine water body.

classDefinition: A planetary part which is exposed, at least periodically, to light.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: In some literature, the term photosphere is used; however, this is more correctly reserved for a part of a star.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: The zone of an ocean below 200m, in which photosynthesis cannot occur due to the lack of light.
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of a marine water body.

classDefinition: The one of an ocean below the 10degC thermocline down to a temperature of 4degC.
parentDefinition: The zone of an ocean below 200m, in which photosynthesis cannot occur due to the lack of light.

classDefinition: The zone of the ocean below the bathypelagic zone, with its lowest boundary at about 6000m.
parentDefinition: The zone of an ocean below 200m, in which photosynthesis cannot occur due to the lack of light.

classDefinition: The zone of an ocean immediately below the photic zone down to a depth where the water temperature is 10degC (the thermocline).
parentDefinition: The zone of an ocean below 200m, in which photosynthesis cannot occur due to the lack of light.

classDefinition: The zone of an ocean in oceanic trenches, lying between 6000m and 10,000m.
parentDefinition: The zone of an ocean below 200m, in which photosynthesis cannot occur due to the lack of light.

classDefinition: A fissure in the Earths's surface from which geothermally heated water issues.
parentDefinition: A surface landform which provides an egress for groundwater or steam to flow out of the ground.
parentComment: Springs are typically where an aquifer surface meets the ground surface or where there is a fissure.

classDefinition: A hole in the Earth's crust from which steam and gases are emitted.
parentDefinition: A geological fracture is any separation in a geologic formation, such as a joint or a fault that divides a mass of rock into two or more pieces.

classDefinition: A geological fracture is any separation in a geologic formation, such as a joint or a fault that divides a mass of rock into two or more pieces.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

classDefinition: A fumarole that emits sulfurous gases.
parentDefinition: A hole in the Earth's crust from which steam and gases are emitted.

classDefinition: A hydrothermal vent found on the ocean floor. The vents are formed in fields hundreds of meters wide when superheated water from below the Earth's crust comes through the ocean floor. The superheated water is rich in dissolved minerals from the crust, most notably sulfides, which crystallize to create a chimney-like structure around each vent. When the superheated water in the vent comes in contact with the cold ocean water, many minerals are precipitated, creating the distinctive black color. The metal sulfides that are deposited can become massive sulfide ore deposits in time.
parentDefinition: A marine hydrothermal vent is a marine benthic feature where heat generated due to tectonic activity, either at divergent plate boundaries or convergent ocean plates where back-arc spreading occurs, is released or 'vented' to the surface. The resultant high temperature water jets are laden with dissolved metals and minerals.

classDefinition: A marine hydrothermal vent is a marine benthic feature where heat generated due to tectonic activity, either at divergent plate boundaries or convergent ocean plates where back-arc spreading occurs, is released or 'vented' to the surface. The resultant high temperature water jets are laden with dissolved metals and minerals.
parentDefinition: A fissure in the Earths's surface from which geothermally heated water issues.

classDefinition: A sea that is not connected with an ocean.
parentDefinition: A large expanse of saline water usually connected with an ocean.
classComment: envoPolar

classDefinition: A group of geographically or geologically associated islands.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is composed of a continuous medium bearing liquid, gaseous, and solid material in variable quantities.

classDefinition: An island that lies on a continental shelf.
parentDefinition: Area of dry or relatively dry land surrounded by water or low wetland.

classDefinition: A slope which a) extends the perimeter of a continent, b) is covered by a shallow marine water body during interglacial periods, c) has a low degree of steepness relative to a continental slope or rise.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and relatively flat surrounding land.
classComment: The continental shelf is a gentle slope. This class refers to the geographical continental shelf and not the legal concept of the same name.

classDefinition: A slope which is part of the seafloor, descends from the continental crust to the oceanic crust, and comprises the continental shelf, continental slope, and continental rise.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and relatively flat surrounding land.
classComment: On Earth, continental margins constitute about 28% of the oceanic area.

classDefinition: A layer of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks that forms continents and the areas of shallow seabed close to their shores, known as continental shelves.
parentDefinition: A planetary structural layer is laminar part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough to have differentiation by density. Planetary layers have differing physicochemical properties and composition.
classComment: On Earth, all continental crust ultimately derives from the fractional differentiation of oceanic crust over many eons.

classDefinition: A slope which 1) is part of the seafloor and 2) extends from the end of the continental shelf (the shelf break) to the continental rise.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and relatively flat surrounding land.

classDefinition: An estuary in which river output is less than the marine input, resulting in the mixing of the whole water column by current-induced turbulence, such that salinity varies more longitudinally rather than vertically.
parentDefinition: A semi-enclosed coastal body of water with one or more rivers or streams flowing into it, and with a free connection to the open sea.

classDefinition: An estuary whose river output and marine input are more even, with river flow still dominant; turbulence induces more mixing of salt water upward than the reverse.
parentDefinition: A semi-enclosed coastal body of water with one or more rivers or streams flowing into it, and with a free connection to the open sea.

classDefinition: An estuary in which  river output greatly exceeds marine input, resulting in little mixing and thus a sharp contrast between fresh surface water and saline bottom water.
parentDefinition: A semi-enclosed coastal body of water with one or more rivers or streams flowing into it, and with a free connection to the open sea.

classDefinition: An estuary which is located in regions where evaporation greatly exceeds the inflow of fresh water, forming a zone of maximum salinity towards which both riverine and marine water masses flow, before sinking and spreading along the bottom in both seaward and landward directions.
parentDefinition: A semi-enclosed coastal body of water with one or more rivers or streams flowing into it, and with a free connection to the open sea.

classDefinition: An estuary which varies dramatically in its volume as a result of intermittent freshwater input, and is capable of changing from a wholly marine embayment to any other type of estuary.
parentDefinition: A semi-enclosed coastal body of water with one or more rivers or streams flowing into it, and with a free connection to the open sea.

classDefinition: A wetland found in upland areas, characterised by acidic soils.
parentDefinition: A wetland which is inundated with water that contains low concentrations of salts.

classDefinition: A wetland which is inundated with water that contains low concentrations of salts.
parentDefinition: A terrestrial ecosystem which is inundated or saturated by surface or ground water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances does support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions.

classDefinition: A freshwater peat land with chemically basic (which roughly means alkaline) ground water.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which accumulates acidic peat, a deposit of dead plant material.

classDefinition: Underground water which is located in pore spaces found in rock or unconsolidated deposits such as soil, clay, or gravel.
parentDefinition: Water which has physicochemical properties determined by processes which occur beneath the planetary crust.
classComment: The definition of aquifer is quite permissive, referencing any water bearing rock or unconsolidated material.
parentComment: This class references any water that's under a planetary surface. For water that is in an aquifer, see "groundwater" (ENVO:01001004). Previously, this class included both.

classDefinition: An medium acidity quality inhering in a solution by virtue of the bearer's a low concentration of H+ ions.
parentDefinition: A concentration quality inhering in a medium by virtue of the bearer's tendency to hydronate a specific reference base.

classDefinition: A wetland ecosystem in which land mass is permanently inundated by shallow bodies of water, generally with a substantial number of hummocks, or dry-land protrusions.
parentDefinition: A terrestrial ecosystem which is inundated or saturated by surface or ground water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances does support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions.

classDefinition: A small, slow-moving stream or creek; usually located in low-lying areas.
parentDefinition: A watercourse which is linear and flows across the solid portion of a planetary surface.

classDefinition: A fen which has developed to the point where it supports trees.
parentDefinition: A freshwater peat land with chemically basic (which roughly means alkaline) ground water.

classDefinition: A class of complex shallow wetlands in central, southern and eastern Africa, particularly in Zambia and Zimbabwe. They are generally found in higher rainfall flat plateau areas, and have river-like branching forms which may be nowhere very large, but common enough to add up to a large area.
parentDefinition: A wetland which is inundated with water that contains low concentrations of salts.

classDefinition: A danbo associated with a headwater.
parentDefinition: A class of complex shallow wetlands in central, southern and eastern Africa, particularly in Zambia and Zimbabwe. They are generally found in higher rainfall flat plateau areas, and have river-like branching forms which may be nowhere very large, but common enough to add up to a large area.

classDefinition: A dambo associated with a river.
parentDefinition: A class of complex shallow wetlands in central, southern and eastern Africa, particularly in Zambia and Zimbabwe. They are generally found in higher rainfall flat plateau areas, and have river-like branching forms which may be nowhere very large, but common enough to add up to a large area.

classDefinition: A palustrine wetland with deep, acidic, sandy, peat soils. Groundwater saturates the soil except during brief seasonal dry spells and during prolonged droughts. Pocosin soils are nutrient deficient (oligotrophic), especially in phosphorus.
parentDefinition: A wetland which is inundated with water that contains low concentrations of salts.

classDefinition: A wetland ecosystem in which soil is saturated with saline water.
parentDefinition: A terrestrial ecosystem which is inundated or saturated by surface or ground water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances does support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions.

classDefinition: A level tract lying at a small depth below the surface of water, or alternately covered and left bare by the tide.
parentDefinition: A wetland that forms when mud is deposited by the tides, rivers, sea or oceans.

classDefinition: A wetland that forms when mud is deposited by a stream.
parentDefinition: A wetland that forms when mud is deposited by the tides, rivers, sea or oceans.

classDefinition: A osmolarity which is relatively high.
parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is increased compared to normal or average.

classDefinition: A osmolarity which is relatively high.
parentDefinition: A concentration quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's amount of osmoles of solute per liter of solution.

classDefinition: A flat or very gently sloping areas of the deep ocean basin floor.
parentDefinition: A region of general uniform slope, comparatively level, and of considerable extent.

classDefinition: A marine bed which lies below an ocean.
parentDefinition: A submerged bed which underlies a marine water body.

classDefinition: A broad, low relief crater that results from a phreatic eruption or explosion caused by groundwater contact with hot lava or magma. The maar typically fills with water to form a relatively shallow crater lake.
parentDefinition: A generally circular saucer or bowl-shaped depression caused by explosive action.

classDefinition: An opening, or rupture, in the Earth's surface or crust, which allows hot, molten rock, ash and gases to escape from deep below the surface.
parentDefinition: A geological fracture is any separation in a geologic formation, such as a joint or a fault that divides a mass of rock into two or more pieces.

classDefinition: The parallel ridges of till deposited along the sides of an alglacier. The unconsolidated debris is deposited on top of the glacier by frost shattering of the valley walls and from tributary streams flowing into the valley. The till is carried along the glacial margin until the glacier melts.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of boulders, stones, or other debris carried and deposited by a glacier.

classDefinition: A moriane formed when the inside lateral moraines of two glaciers merge together. They form a ridge down the center of the combined glaciers.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of boulders, stones, or other debris carried and deposited by a glacier.

classDefinition: A till covered area with irregular topography and no ridges, often forming gently rolling hills or plains. Forms by the accumulation of till under the ice by lodgement, but may also be deposited as the glacier retreats.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of boulders, stones, or other debris carried and deposited by a glacier.

classDefinition: Ridges of unconsolidated debris deposited at the snout or end of the glacier. They usually reflect the shape of the glacier's terminus.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of boulders, stones, or other debris carried and deposited by a glacier.

classDefinition: A plain where a stream meanders across an area with a very low gradient, usually with a fairly continuous discharge. In addition to meanders, scroll plains are also characterised by many oxbow lakes.
parentDefinition: A region of general uniform slope, comparatively level, and of considerable extent.

classDefinition: An extensive flat plain of glacial till that forms when a sheet of ice becomes detached from the main body of a glacier and melts in place depositing the sediments it carried.
parentDefinition: A region of general uniform slope, comparatively level, and of considerable extent.

classDefinition: An area which is subject to periodic flooding.
parentDefinition: A region of general uniform slope, comparatively level, and of considerable extent.

classDefinition: The stream channel and adjacent areas that carry flood flows in a flood plain.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: The stream channel and adjacent areas that carry flood flows in a flood plain.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: Area of a flood plane covered by the flood, but which does not experience a strong current.
parentDefinition: An unbroken expanse (as of ice)
parentComment: This class was created to accommodate "fields" from agricultural fields to marine mesoscale eddy fields. Thus, it has a very broad definition which makes it less than informative when annotating. Please consider using or requesting an appropriate subclass.

classDefinition: An unusual accumulation of water above the ground caused by high tide, heavy rain, melting snow or rapid runoff from paved areas.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of water of varying size.
parentComment: The term body of water most often refers to large accumulations of water, such as oceans, seas, and lakes, but it includes smaller pools of water such as ponds, wetlands, or more rarely, puddles. A body of water does not have to be still or contained; Rivers, streams, canals, and other geographical features where water moves from one place to another are also considered bodies of water.

classDefinition: A relatively flat and gently sloping landform found at the base of a range of hills or mountains, formed by the deposition of alluvial soil over a long period of time by one or more streams coming from the mountains.
parentDefinition: A region of general uniform slope, comparatively level, and of considerable extent.

classDefinition: A mountain rising from the ocean seafloor that does not reach to the water's surface (sea level), and thus is not an island. Typically formed from volcanoes that rise abruptly and are usually found rising from a seafloor of 1,000 - 4,000 meters depth. Independent features that rise to at least 1,000 meters above the seafloor.
parentDefinition: A landform that extends above the surrounding terrain in a limited area.
parentComment: A mountain is generally steeper than a hill, but there is no universally accepted standard definition for the height of a mountain or a hill although a mountain usually has an identifiable summit. The USGS had previously defined mountains as localised elevations of more than 300 meters; however, the organisation has accepted there are no technical definitions in the US. In ENVO, we primarily use the UNEP-WCMC classification to be compliant with SDG monitoring, but we can host other classifications on request: http://www.fao.org/sustainable-development-goals/indicators/1542/en/

classDefinition: Soil which has been eroded and influenced by flowing water and redeposited in a non-marine setting.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
parentComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

" The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm."  Soil taxonomy, 2nd Ed., quoted in http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/edu/?cid=nrcs142p2_054280

classDefinition: A plain that originally formed in a lacustrine environment, that is, as the bed of a lake, but from which the water has disappeared, by natural drainage, evaporation or other geophysical processes.
parentDefinition: A region of general uniform slope, comparatively level, and of considerable extent.

classDefinition: An area of land of low topographic relief that historically supported grasses and herbs, with few trees, and having generally a mesic (moderate or temperate) climate. Dominated by tall grasses (contrast steppe).
parentDefinition: An area in which grasses (Graminae) are a significant component of the vegetation.

classDefinition: A grassland of the tropics or subtropics with scattered trees.
parentDefinition: An area in which grasses (Graminae) are a significant component of the vegetation.

classDefinition: A plain without trees (apart from those near rivers and lakes); it is similar to a prairie, although a prairie is generally considered as being dominated by tall grasses, while short grasses are said to be normal in the steppe. It may be semi-desert, or covered with grass or shrubs or both, depending on the season and latitude.
parentDefinition: An area in which grasses (Graminae) are a significant component of the vegetation.

classDefinition: A narrow, vertical cave passage, often developed along a joint but not necessarily so. Usually due to solution but sometimes to tension.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.

classDefinition: A planetary crust is the outermost solid shell of a rocky planet or natural satellite, which is chemically distinct from the underlying mantle.
parentDefinition: A planetary structural layer is laminar part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough to have differentiation by density. Planetary layers have differing physicochemical properties and composition.
classComment: This class is meant to be applicable accross planets. Earth's crust would be an instance.

classDefinition: A flat-topped seamount.
parentDefinition: A mountain rising from the ocean seafloor that does not reach to the water's surface (sea level), and thus is not an island. Typically formed from volcanoes that rise abruptly and are usually found rising from a seafloor of 1,000 - 4,000 meters depth. Independent features that rise to at least 1,000 meters above the seafloor.

classDefinition: A grassland ecosystem which is used for grazing of ungulate livestock as part of a farm or ranch.
parentComment: As with other classes that are "features", the subclasses of this class are being moved to more informative locations. Their relation to agriculture will be modelled by something more akin to a quality or relation to an agricultural process.

classDefinition: A grassland ecosystem which is used for grazing of ungulate livestock as part of a farm or ranch.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem in which grasses (Graminae) are the dominant form of vegetation and determine the system's structure and dynamics.

classDefinition: An area of land used for the herding and grazing of livestock.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: An area of land used for the herding and grazing of livestock.
parentDefinition: An area of land which is used for the cultivation of crops or grazing of livestock, including any agricultural constructions therein.

classDefinition: A steep-sided valley on the sea floor of the continental slope. Many submarine canyons are found as extensions to large rivers; however there are many that have no such association. Canyons cutting the continental slopes have been found at depths greater than 2 km below sea level. Many submarine canyons continue as submarine channels across continental rise areas and may extend for hundreds of kilometers.
parentDefinition: Relatively narrow, deep depression with steep sides, the bottom of which generally has a continuous slope.

classDefinition: A marine bed which lies below a sea.
parentDefinition: A submerged bed which underlies a marine water body.

classDefinition: The ground surface that lies beneath a lake.
parentDefinition: The portion of the ground surface which lies below water.

classDefinition: The portion of the ground surface which lies below water.
parentDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of solid environmental material.

classDefinition: The portion of the ground surface which lies below water.
parentDefinition: A surface layer where the solid or liquid material of an astronomical body comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
parentComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities

classDefinition: The portion of the ground surface which lies below water.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

classDefinition: A continental island connected to its adjacent land by a natural feature, such as a causeway.
parentDefinition: An island that lies on a continental shelf.

classDefinition: A pond that has formed as a consequence of the activities of beavers, building a beaver dam.
parentDefinition: A body of water, usually of smaller size than a lake.

classDefinition: A dry (salt) lake in the Saharan area of Africa that stays dry in the summer, but receive some water in the winter. This water may come as a groundwater discharge.
parentDefinition: A dry lakebed consisting of fine-grained sediments infused with alkali salts. Generally the shore or bed of an endorheic lake.

classDefinition: The point where a tributary joins a more major river.
parentDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water.

classDefinition: A slope which a) bridges, and thus lies between, a continental slope and an abyssal plain, b) is formed by the accumulation of sediments transported from a continental slope by processes including turbidity currents c) has a gradient less than a continental slope yet greater than a continental shelf.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and relatively flat surrounding land.
classComment: On Earth, the gradient of the continental rise is on the order of 0.5-1. It may extend as far as 500 kilometers from the slope,

classDefinition: Hemispheric-scale long but narrow topographic depressions of the sea floor. They are the deepest parts of the ocean floor.
parentDefinition: A trench is a type of excavation or depression in the ground that is generally deeper than it is wide (as opposed to a wider gully or ditch), and narrow compared to its length (as opposed to a simple hole).

classDefinition: A trench is a type of excavation or depression in the ground that is generally deeper than it is wide (as opposed to a wider gully or ditch), and narrow compared to its length (as opposed to a simple hole).
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: An elongated whale-shaped hill formed by glacial action. Its long axis is parallel with the movement of the ice, with the blunter end facing into the glacial movement. Drumlins are sometimes compared to kames, but their formation is distinctively different. A drumlin is not originally shaped by meltwater, but by the ice itself and has a quite regular shape. It occurs in fine grained material, such as clay or shale, not in sands and gravels. And drumlins usually have concentric layers of material, as the ice successively plasters new layers in its movement.
parentDefinition: A rounded elevation of limited extent rising above the surrounding land with local relief of less than 300m.

classDefinition: A lake that has either permanently or temporally lost its water.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
classComment: Classes like this pose a logical problem. This probably shouldn't be a lake (water body) but a depression. Lakes which have temporarily lost water should be distinguished from permanently dry lakes.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A lake that has either permanently or temporally lost its water.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.
classComment: Classes like this pose a logical problem. This probably shouldn't be a lake (water body) but a depression. Lakes which have temporarily lost water should be distinguished from permanently dry lakes.

classDefinition: A stream channel through which no water flows and which has dried, containing no appreciable accumulations of water.
parentDefinition: A depressed landform which physically confines a river, slough or ocean strait, and which consists of a bed and banks.

classDefinition: A flat expanse of ground covered with salt and other minerals, usually shining white under the sun. A salt pan is formed where water pools. A saline pan would be a lake or a pond if it were located in a climate where the rate of water evaporation were not faster than the rate of water precipitation, i.e., if it were not in a desert. If the water is unable to drain into the ground, it remains on the surface until it evaporates, leaving behind whatever minerals were dissolved. Over thousands of years, the minerals (usually salts) accumulate on the surface.
parentDefinition: A lake bed which is dry. That is, the bed of a dry lake.
parentComment: Deliberately disjoint with "lake bed", which must be covered with water.

classDefinition: A slope which separates different physiogeographic provinces that are typically composed of rocks of different age and compositoin.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and relatively flat surrounding land.
classComment: An escarpment usually represents the line of erosional loss of the newer rock over the older.

classDefinition: An action of exogenic processes (such as water flow or wind) which remove environmental material from one location on the surface of an astronomical body, transporting it to another location where it is deposited.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: A rock formed by deposition of either clastic sediments, organic matter, or chemical precipitates (evaporites), followed by compaction of the particulate matter and cementation during diagenesis.
parentDefinition: A rock is a naturally occurring solid aggregate of one or more minerals or mineraloids.
parentComment: From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ [A mineral] is different from a rock, which can be an aggregate of minerals or non-minerals and does not have a specific chemical composition. The exact definition of a mineral is under debate, especially with respect to the requirement a valid species be abiogenic, and to a lesser extent with regards to it having an ordered atomic structure.

classDefinition: An escarpment resulting from a fault.
parentDefinition: A slope which separates different physiogeographic provinces that are typically composed of rocks of different age and compositoin.
parentComment: An escarpment usually represents the line of erosional loss of the newer rock over the older.

classDefinition: A long, winding ridge of stratified sand and gravel which occur in glaciated and formerly glaciated regions of Europe and North America.
parentDefinition: A long and narrow elevation with steep sides.

classDefinition: A long and narrow elevation with steep sides.
parentDefinition: A landform elevated above the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A thickness which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A size quality which is relatively low.

classDefinition: A thickness which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A 1-D extent quality which is equal to the dimension through an object as opposed to its length or width.

classDefinition: A surface mine that utilizes a technique of extracting rock or minerals from the earth by their removal from an open pit or borrow.
parentDefinition: An excavation in the Earth for the purpose of extracting earth materials.

classDefinition: A bed which is composed of quicksand forming a soft, shifting mass that yields easily to pressure.
parentDefinition: A layer of some material entity which is adjacent to one or more of its external boundaries and directly interacts with its immediate surroundings.
parentComment: This class is distinct from a geometric surface, which is two-dimensional. The idea of "uppermost" may be problematic. Further, the definition of layer (the superclass of surface in rev 133) references surface. This may be another issue. Perhaps this can be made into an inferred class using 'bounding layer of' some material entity, note that 'bounding layer' implies containment, which may not be valid here.

classDefinition: Particulate environmental material which 1) is primarily composed of a fine, granular material such as sand, silt, or clay suspended in and saturated by water and 2) readily liquefies when weight is applied, losing strength and permitting objects to sink until their weight and buoyancy offset the weight of the displaced quicksand.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is composed primarily of particles.

classDefinition: An area reclaimed from the sea by diking and draining.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: An isolated hill with steep sides and a small flat top, smaller than mesas and plateaus. Buttes are formed by erosion when a cap of hard rock, usually of volcanic origin, covers a layer of softer rock that is easily worn away. This hard rock avoids erosion while the rock around it wears down.
parentDefinition: An elevation which is flattened across its highest surface.

An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.

classDefinition: The raised fault block bounded by normal faults. The raised block is a portion of the Earth's crust that has remained stationary while the land has sunk on either side of it or has been crushed by a mountain range against it.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: The raised fault block bounded by normal faults. The raised block is a portion of the Earth's crust that has remained stationary while the land has sunk on either side of it or has been crushed by a mountain range against it.
parentDefinition: A landform elevated above the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A depressed block of land bordered by parallel faults. A graben is the result of a block of land being downthrown producing a valley with a distinct scarp on each side. Grabens often occur side-by-side with horsts. Horst and graben structures are indicative of tensional forces and crustal stretching.
