parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A depressed block of land bordered by parallel faults. A graben is the result of a block of land being downthrown producing a valley with a distinct scarp on each side. Grabens often occur side-by-side with horsts. Horst and graben structures are indicative of tensional forces and crustal stretching.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: An extent or area of land where surface water from rain and melting snow or ice converges to a single point at lower elevation, usually the exit of the basin, where the waters join another waterbody.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: An extent or area of land where surface water from rain and melting snow or ice converges to a single point at lower elevation, usually the exit of the basin, where the waters join another waterbody.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: The separation between neighbouring drainage basins (catchments). In hilly country, the divide lies along topographical peaks and ridges, but in flat country or on a high plateau (especially where the ground is marshy) the divide may be invisible - just a more or less notional line on the ground on either side of which falling raindrops will start a journey to different rivers, and even to different sides of a country or continent.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

classDefinition: A watershed such that water falling on one side of the line eventually travels to one ocean or body of water, and water on the other side travels to another, generally on the opposite side of the continent.
parentDefinition: The separation between neighbouring drainage basins (catchments). In hilly country, the divide lies along topographical peaks and ridges, but in flat country or on a high plateau (especially where the ground is marshy) the divide may be invisible - just a more or less notional line on the ground on either side of which falling raindrops will start a journey to different rivers, and even to different sides of a country or continent.

classDefinition: A facility in which fish are raised commercially in tanks or enclosures, usually for food.
parentComment: As with other classes that are "features", the subclasses of this class are being moved to more informative locations. Their relation to agriculture will be modelled by something more akin to a quality or relation to an agricultural process.

classDefinition: A hatchery in which the eggs of fish are hatched under artificial conditions.
parentDefinition: A construction in which eggs are hatched under artificial conditions.

classDefinition: A construction in which eggs are hatched under artificial conditions.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: A paddy field for the cultivation of rice.
parentDefinition: An intentional planting of a crop, on a large scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming.

classDefinition: A flooded parcel of arable land used for growing rice and other semiaquatic crops.
parentDefinition: A field which is located on land and used for agricultural purposes, such as the grazing of livestock or the cultivation of crops.

classDefinition: A large mass of detached land ice in the sea or stranded in shallow water.
parentDefinition: An ice mass which is suspended in a water body, being sufficiently buoyant for part of the mass to breach the surface of that water body.

classDefinition: A large mass of detached land ice in the sea or stranded in shallow water.
parentDefinition: An ice mass which has broken away from a larger ice mass on land, such as a glacier or ice shelf, and may be either afloat or aground.
parentComment: The greater part of an iceberg's mass (4/5 to 8/9) is below sea level, which makes them dangerous to shipping in high and mid-latitude regions of the ocean. The top of an ice berg usually protrudes more than 5 m above water-level and typically extends from tens of meters to many tens of kilometres across. Icebergs may be described as tabular, dome-shaped, sloping, pinnacled, dry-docked, blocky, weathered or glacier bergs in addition to having a size qualifier. Icebergs are not sea ice, when they melt they add fresh water to the ocean.  The unmodified term "iceberg" usually refers to the irregular masses of ice formed by the calving of glaciers along an orographically rough coast, whereas tabular icebergs and ice islands are calved from an ice shelf, while bergs formed from sea ice are called floebergs. In decreasing size, they are classified as: ice island (few thousand square meters to 500 km^2 in area); tabular iceberg; iceberg; bergy bit (less than 5 m above sea level, between 1 and 200 m^2 in area); and growler (less than 1 m above sea level, about 20 m^2 in area). Alaskan icebergs rarely exceed 500 feet in maximum dimension.  Antarctic icebergs originate from the ice mass of the Antarctic continent that has accumulated over many thousands of years.

classDefinition: An ice mass which is suspended in a water body, being sufficiently buoyant for part of the mass to breach the surface of that water body.
parentDefinition: A mass of water ice.

classDefinition: An ice mass which has broken away from a larger ice mass on land, such as a glacier or ice shelf, and may be either afloat or aground.
parentDefinition: An ice mass which has formed over land.
classComment: The greater part of an iceberg's mass (4/5 to 8/9) is below sea level, which makes them dangerous to shipping in high and mid-latitude regions of the ocean. The top of an ice berg usually protrudes more than 5 m above water-level and typically extends from tens of meters to many tens of kilometres across. Icebergs may be described as tabular, dome-shaped, sloping, pinnacled, dry-docked, blocky, weathered or glacier bergs in addition to having a size qualifier. Icebergs are not sea ice, when they melt they add fresh water to the ocean.  The unmodified term "iceberg" usually refers to the irregular masses of ice formed by the calving of glaciers along an orographically rough coast, whereas tabular icebergs and ice islands are calved from an ice shelf, while bergs formed from sea ice are called floebergs. In decreasing size, they are classified as: ice island (few thousand square meters to 500 km^2 in area); tabular iceberg; iceberg; bergy bit (less than 5 m above sea level, between 1 and 200 m^2 in area); and growler (less than 1 m above sea level, about 20 m^2 in area). Alaskan icebergs rarely exceed 500 feet in maximum dimension.  Antarctic icebergs originate from the ice mass of the Antarctic continent that has accumulated over many thousands of years.
parentComment: Land ice is any part of the Earth's seasonal or perennial ice cover that has formed over land as the result, principally, of the freezing of precipitation; opposed to sea ice formed by the freezing of seawater.  Thus, an iceberg or tabular iceberg is land ice as well as its parent glacier, ice sheet, or ice shelf. The two major concentrations of land ice are the ice sheets of Greenland and Antarctica. Glaciers and ice caps are the other important forms; however, some members of the glaciology community hold that glaciers (i.e. rock glaciers) need not have any ice.

classDefinition: A field of ice, formed in regions of perennial frost.
parentDefinition: An unbroken expanse (as of ice)
classComment: Ice mass may need to be resolved from ice field, the former referring simply to an accumulation of ice.
parentComment: This class was created to accommodate "fields" from agricultural fields to marine mesoscale eddy fields. Thus, it has a very broad definition which makes it less than informative when annotating. Please consider using or requesting an appropriate subclass.

classDefinition: A field of ice, formed in regions of perennial frost.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous mass of snow and/or ice.
classComment: Ice mass may need to be resolved from ice field, the former referring simply to an accumulation of ice.

classDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous mass of snow and/or ice.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

classDefinition: Area covered with low-growing or stunted perennial vegetation and usually not mixed with trees.
parentDefinition: A vegetated area is a geographic feature which has ground cover dominated by plant communities.

classDefinition: A shrubland area found primarily in regions with a Mediterranean climate (mid, wet winters and hot dry summers) often shaped by wildfires.
parentDefinition: Area covered with low-growing or stunted perennial vegetation and usually not mixed with trees.

classDefinition: A mediterranean condition is a subtropical condition in which hot dry summers and winters with moderate to high rainfall.
parentDefinition: A subtropical condition is an environmental condition in which an envrionmental system receives more solar irradiance than those with temperate conditions, but less than those with tropical conditions. At low elevations, this typically results in eight months of the year having average temperatures greater than or equal to 10 degrees Celsius with the coldest monthly temperature averaging between 2 and 13 degrees Celsius.
classComment: These regions are under the constant influence of the subtropical ridge.
parentComment:
As with most other climatic zones and conditions, multiple classification schemes have somehat different definitions and criteria. To quote from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ "Several methods have been used to define the subtropical climate. In the Trewartha climate classification, a subtropical region should have at least eight months with a mean temperature of 10 °C (50.0 °F) or above. German climatologists Carl Troll and Karlheinz Paffen defined Warm temperate zones as plain and hilly lands having an average temperature of the coldest month between 2 °C (35.6 °F) and 13 °C (55.4 °F) in the Northern Hemisphere and between 6 °C (42.8 °F) and 13 °C (55.4 °F) in the Southern Hemisphere, excluding oceanic and continental climates. According to the Troll-Paffen climate classification, there generally exists one large subtropical zone named the warm-temperate subtropical zone,[4] which is subdivided into seven smaller areas.[5]

According to the E. Neef climate classification, the subtropical zone is divided into two parts: Rainy winters of the west sides and Eastern subtropical climate.[6] According to the Wilhelm Lauer & Peter Frankenberg climate classification, the subtropical zone is divided into three parts: high-continental, continental, and maritime.[7] According to the Siegmund/Frankenberg climate classification, subtropical is one of six climate zones in the world.[8]"

classDefinition: A valley created by the formation of a rift, i.e. place where a planet's lithosphere is being pulled apart by tectonic forces.
parentDefinition: A depression which has been formed as a result of erosion by water or ice and which is low-lying, bordered by higher ground, and especially elongate.
parentComment: Valleys are typically located between hills our mountains.

classDefinition: A coast is the area where land meets the sea, ocean, or lake.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is composed of a continuous medium bearing liquid, gaseous, and solid material in variable quantities.
classComment: Used for both marine and lake coasts. The boundary of the coast is fuzzy and it overlaps both the water body and land in quesiton. Compared to 'shore'

classDefinition: A body of land jutting out into and nearly surrounded by water.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A body of land jutting out into and nearly surrounded by water.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the landmass of that body.

classDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the landmass of that body.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

classDefinition: A quality inhering into a bearer by virtue of the bearer's extending out above or beyond its surface or boundary and outwards in relation to the physical space occupied by another entity.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's extending out above or beyond a surface or boundary.

classDefinition: A deposition landform found off coasts. A spit is a type of bar or beach that develops where a re-entrant occurs, such as at a cove, bay, ria, or river mouth. Spits are formed by the movement of sediment (typically sand) along a shore by a process known as longshore drift. Where the direction of the shore turns inland (reenters) the longshore current spreads out or dissipates. No longer able to carry the full load, much of the sediment is dropped. This causes a bar to build out from the shore, eventually becoming a spit.
parentDefinition: A linear shoaling landform feature within a body of water. Bars tend to be long and narrow (linear) and develop where a current (or waves) promote deposition of granular material, resulting in localized shallowing (shoaling) of the water. Bars can appear in the sea, in a lake, or in a river. They are typically composed of sand, although could be of any granular matter that the moving water has access to and is capable of shifting around (for example, soil, silt, gravel, cobble, shingle, or even boulders). The grain size of the material comprising a bar is related: to the size of the waves or the strength of the currents moving the material, but the availability of material to be worked by waves and currents is also important.

classDefinition: A portion of a glacier characterized by rapid flow, a chaotic crevassed surface, and a pronounced, at times vertical, slope.
parentDefinition: An ice mass which has formed over land.
classComment: Icefalls may be formed as glaciers flow through narrow openings in landmasses.
parentComment: Land ice is any part of the Earth's seasonal or perennial ice cover that has formed over land as the result, principally, of the freezing of precipitation; opposed to sea ice formed by the freezing of seawater.  Thus, an iceberg or tabular iceberg is land ice as well as its parent glacier, ice sheet, or ice shelf. The two major concentrations of land ice are the ice sheets of Greenland and Antarctica. Glaciers and ice caps are the other important forms; however, some members of the glaciology community hold that glaciers (i.e. rock glaciers) need not have any ice.

classDefinition: A deep fissure in snow or ice.
parentDefinition: A geological fracture is any separation in a geologic formation, such as a joint or a fault that divides a mass of rock into two or more pieces.

classDefinition: A valley or trough between two dunes.
parentDefinition: A depression which has been formed as a result of erosion by water or ice and which is low-lying, bordered by higher ground, and especially elongate.
parentComment: Valleys are typically located between hills our mountains.

classDefinition: An elevation which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A positional quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's vertical distance of a point above or below a reference surface.

classDefinition: An elevation which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A positional which is relatively low.
A shape quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's having an oblique or slanted direction.

classDefinition: A crater caused by the impact of a meteor.
parentDefinition: A crater which was formed as a result of the impact of one astronomical body on another.
classComment: For the moment, no distinction is made between meteroids, lithometeors, or meteorites in this class. These can be added if needed.

classDefinition: A crater which was formed as a result of the impact of one astronomical body on another.
parentDefinition: A generally circular saucer or bowl-shaped depression caused by explosive action.

classDefinition: An impact event during which a meteoroid collides with another astronomical body.
parentDefinition: An impact event is a collision between astronomical bodies.

classDefinition: A fluvioglacial landform occurring as the result of blocks of ice calving from the front of a receding glacier and becoming partially to wholly buried by glacial outwash. Glacial outwash is generated when sediment laden streams of meltwater flow away from the glacier and are deposited to form broad outwash plains called sandurs. When the ice blocks melt, holes are left in the sandur.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A fluvioglacial landform occurring as the result of blocks of ice calving from the front of a receding glacier and becoming partially to wholly buried by glacial outwash. Glacial outwash is generated when sediment laden streams of meltwater flow away from the glacier and are deposited to form broad outwash plains called sandurs. When the ice blocks melt, holes are left in the sandur.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: The plain formed by the large amounts of silt and sediment, picked up as a glacier erodes the underlying rocks as it moves slowly downhill, and at the snout of the glacier, meltwater can carry this sediment away from the glacier and deposit it on a broad plain. The material in the outwash plain is often size-sorted by the water runoff of the melting glacier with the finest materials, like silt, being the most distantly re-deposited, whereas larger boulders are the closest to the original terminus of the glacier.
parentDefinition: A region of general uniform slope, comparatively level, and of considerable extent.

classDefinition: A sandy depression in a sand dune ecosystem (psammosere) caused by the removal of sediments by wind.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A sandy depression in a sand dune ecosystem (psammosere) caused by the removal of sediments by wind.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A fan-shaped deposit formed where a fast flowing stream flattens, slows, and spreads typically at the exit of a canyon onto a flatter plain.
parentDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water.

classDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer that is shaped in the form of a fan.
parentDefinition: A shape that inheres in a 2 dimensional entity, such as a cross section or projection of a 3 dimensional entity.

classDefinition: A process during which material entities are added to a landform or to a feature upon the landform.
parentDefinition: A process during which the mass of one or more materials, present within a given site, increases.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material accumulation process ends a material transport process.

classDefinition: A convergence of neighboring alluvial fans into a single apron of deposits against a slope.
parentDefinition: A fan-shaped deposit formed where a fast flowing stream flattens, slows, and spreads typically at the exit of a canyon onto a flatter plain.

classDefinition: The area of the foreshore and seabed that is exposed to the air at low tide and submerged at high tide, i.e., the area between tide marks.
parentDefinition: An astronomical body part which is part of a marine environment.
classComment: Very similar to the "marine eulittoral zone" class, but without reference to seasonal tide marks. Some sources make no distinction between these zones, thus, they are currently related synonyms.
parentComment: This class will eventually be populated by inference alone, with its subclasses distributed in more process-linked hierarchies to improve semantic density.

classDefinition: An astronomical body part which is part of a marine environment.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: This class will eventually be populated by inference alone, with its subclasses distributed in more process-linked hierarchies to improve semantic density.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: An ecosystem which overlaps those areas of the foreshore and seabed that are exposed to the air at low tide and submerged at high tide.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: These semantics link with those of environmental zones. Use this class to refer to the ecosystem rather than the area that it occupies.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: An ecosystem which overlaps those areas of the foreshore and seabed that are exposed to the air at low tide and submerged at high tide.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which overlaps both terrestrial and marine ecosystems.
classComment: These semantics link with those of environmental zones. Use this class to refer to the ecosystem rather than the area that it occupies.

classDefinition: Pools formed as a high tide comes in over a rocky shore. Water fills depressions in the ground, which turn into isolated pools as the tide retreats.
parentDefinition: A lentic water body is a water body in which the accumulated water, in its totality, has very little to no directed flow.

classDefinition: The tide zone that is flooded during high tide only, and is a highly saline environment.
parentDefinition: An astronomical body part which is part of a marine environment.
parentComment: This class will eventually be populated by inference alone, with its subclasses distributed in more process-linked hierarchies to improve semantic density.

classDefinition: The tidal zone that is mostly submerged, only being exposed at the point of low tide and for a longer period of time during extremely low tides.
parentDefinition: An astronomical body part which is part of a marine environment.
parentComment: This class will eventually be populated by inference alone, with its subclasses distributed in more process-linked hierarchies to improve semantic density.

classDefinition: A deep fissure in rock.
parentDefinition: A geological fracture is any separation in a geologic formation, such as a joint or a fault that divides a mass of rock into two or more pieces.

classDefinition: A cavity developed along a joint and elongate in cross-section.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.

classDefinition: A cave formed at the same time as the surrounding rock.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.

classDefinition: A cave from which a stream flows or formerly did so and which cannot be followed upstream to the surface.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.

classDefinition: A large closed depression draining underground, with a flat floor across which there may be an intermittent or perennial stream and which may be liable to flood and become a lake. The floor makes a sharp break with parts of surrounding slopes.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A large closed depression draining underground, with a flat floor across which there may be an intermittent or perennial stream and which may be liable to flood and become a lake. The floor makes a sharp break with parts of surrounding slopes.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A morphological quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's affording blocked passage or view.
parentDefinition: A morphological quality pertaining to the degree to which an object contains an opening, aperture, orifice or vent.

classDefinition: A cave in present-day or emerged sea cliffs, formed by wave attack or solution.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.

classDefinition: A secondary mineral deposit formed in caves, most commonly calcite.
parentDefinition: A mineral deposit is a physiographic feature which has unusually high concentrations of one or more minerals.
parentComment: Note that the definition of the term mineral is debatable; however, a mineral generally must be naturally occuring, stable at room temperature, representable by a chemical formula (unlike rocks, which may include a wide variety of components), are usually formed by geophysical processes (i.e. are abiogenic), and have an ordered atomic arrangement.

classDefinition: A mineral deposit is a physiographic feature which has unusually high concentrations of one or more minerals.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
classComment: Note that the definition of the term mineral is debatable; however, a mineral generally must be naturally occuring, stable at room temperature, representable by a chemical formula (unlike rocks, which may include a wide variety of components), are usually formed by geophysical processes (i.e. are abiogenic), and have an ordered atomic arrangement.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: An interface layer which 1) is primarily composed of solid materials, 2) separates the land surface and phreatic zone, and 3) contains groundwater at atmospheric pressure.
parentDefinition: A layer which is primarily composed of some solid material, allowing for non-solid parts such as interstitial pockets of gas or liquid.
classComment: If the vadose zone includes portions of soil, the water contained therein is termed soil moisture. In fine grained soils, capillary action can cause the pores of the soil to be fully saturated above the water table at a pressure less than atmospheric. In such soils, therefore, the unsaturated zone is the upper section of the vadose zone and not identical to it.

classDefinition: An interface layer which 1) is primarily composed of solid materials, 2) separates the land surface and phreatic zone, and 3) contains groundwater at atmospheric pressure.
parentDefinition: A layer which separates two portions of environmental material which possess 1) differing compositions, 2) a discontinuity of some property, or 3) some derivative of some property in a direction normal to the interface.
classComment: If the vadose zone includes portions of soil, the water contained therein is termed soil moisture. In fine grained soils, capillary action can cause the pores of the soil to be fully saturated above the water table at a pressure less than atmospheric. In such soils, therefore, the unsaturated zone is the upper section of the vadose zone and not identical to it.

classDefinition: A layer which is primarily composed of some solid material, allowing for non-solid parts such as interstitial pockets of gas or liquid.
parentDefinition: A material entity which 1) is spatially continuous, 2) is composed of material of comparable thickness, composition, and physical properties, and 3) is physically distinct from adjacent portions of environmental material.

classDefinition: A layer which separates two portions of environmental material which possess 1) differing compositions, 2) a discontinuity of some property, or 3) some derivative of some property in a direction normal to the interface.
parentDefinition: A material entity which 1) is spatially continuous, 2) is composed of material of comparable thickness, composition, and physical properties, and 3) is physically distinct from adjacent portions of environmental material.

classDefinition: A compound astronomical body part which is located beneath the land surface and in which all interstices are filled with water that has a hydraulic head greater than atmospheric pressure due to the weight of overlying groundwater.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is composed of a continuous medium bearing liquid, gaseous, and solid material in variable quantities.

classDefinition: A surface layer of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material and is not covered by oceans or other bodies of water.
parentDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of solid environmental material.

classDefinition: A surface layer of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material and is not covered by oceans or other bodies of water.
parentDefinition: A surface layer where the solid or liquid material of an astronomical body comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
parentComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities

classDefinition: A surface layer of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material and is not covered by oceans or other bodies of water.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

classDefinition: A porosity quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's being capable of admitting the passage of gas or liquid through pores or interstices.
parentDefinition: A structure quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's disposition to admit the passage of gas or liquid through pores or interstices.

classDefinition: A speleothem projecting vertically upwards from a cave floor and formed by precipitation from drips.
parentDefinition: A secondary mineral deposit formed in caves, most commonly calcite.

classDefinition: A speleothem hanging downwards from a roof or wall, of cylindrical or conical form, usually with a central hollow tube.
parentDefinition: A secondary mineral deposit formed in caves, most commonly calcite.

classDefinition: A closed depression draining underground in karst, of simple but variable form, e.g. cylindrical, conical, bowl- or dish-shaped. From a few to many hundreds of metres in dimensions.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A closed depression draining underground in karst, of simple but variable form, e.g. cylindrical, conical, bowl- or dish-shaped. From a few to many hundreds of metres in dimensions.
parentComment: A landform which is located under the surface of a landmass.

parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which has been formed from and is composed primarily of the matter of that astronomical body.
classComment: A landform which is located under the surface of a landmass.
parentComment: Landforms may be natural or anthropogenic. This term has often has loose usage when referencing entities which are either subterranean or submerged below water bodies. In some cases, oceans themselves are considered landforms. Here, we have provided subclasses to resolve this ambiguity, but place oceans and other water bodies elsewhere.In later revisions, this hiearchy is likely to be reordered based on the formation processes of the entities within it.

classDefinition: Karst developed in soluble beds underlying other rock formations; the surface may or may not be affected by the karst development.
parentDefinition: A surface landform which is formed by the dissolution of a soluble layer or layers of bedrock.
parentComment: Karsts usually form in masses of carbonate rock such as limestone or dolomite. Karst landscapes display distinctive surface features and underground drainages, and in some examples there may be little or no surface drainage.

classDefinition: Karst developed in eolian calcarenite when the development of karst features has taken place at the same time as the lithification of dune sand.
parentDefinition: A surface landform which is formed by the dissolution of a soluble layer or layers of bedrock.
parentComment: Karsts usually form in masses of carbonate rock such as limestone or dolomite. Karst landscapes display distinctive surface features and underground drainages, and in some examples there may be little or no surface drainage.

classDefinition: Karst completely pitted by closed depressions so that divides between them form a crudely polygonal network.
parentDefinition: A surface landform which is formed by the dissolution of a soluble layer or layers of bedrock.
parentComment: Karsts usually form in masses of carbonate rock such as limestone or dolomite. Karst landscapes display distinctive surface features and underground drainages, and in some examples there may be little or no surface drainage.

classDefinition: Karst dominated by closed depressions, chiefly dolines, perforating a simple surface.
parentDefinition: A surface landform which is formed by the dissolution of a soluble layer or layers of bedrock.
parentComment: Karsts usually form in masses of carbonate rock such as limestone or dolomite. Karst landscapes display distinctive surface features and underground drainages, and in some examples there may be little or no surface drainage.

classDefinition: A bodily fluid material which is composed primarily of vomit, a bodily fluid consisting of the expulsed contents of the stomach of an organism disgorged through the mouth or nose.
parentDefinition: An organic material which is primarily composed of some natural bodily fluid or secretion such as blood, semen, saliva, blood plasma, intracellular and interstitial fluids.
classComment: ENVO bodily fluid classes differ from UBERON's treatment of bodily fluids. UBERON refers to the substance itself ("S"). We assert that UBERON's classes are the primary compositional component of the terms in ENVO ("S material"). Use of the ENVO terms is typically recommended when you wish to indicate that there may be other materials intermixed with S.
parentComment: ENVO bodily fluid classes differ from UBERON's treatment of bodily fluids. UBERON refers to the substance itself ("S"). We assert that UBERON's classes are the primary compositional component of the terms in ENVO ("S material"). Use of the ENVO terms is typically recommended when you wish to indicate that there may be other materials intermixed with S.

classDefinition: An organic material which is primarily composed of some natural bodily fluid or secretion such as blood, semen, saliva, blood plasma, intracellular and interstitial fluids.
parentDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.
classComment: ENVO bodily fluid classes differ from UBERON's treatment of bodily fluids. UBERON refers to the substance itself ("S"). We assert that UBERON's classes are the primary compositional component of the terms in ENVO ("S material"). Use of the ENVO terms is typically recommended when you wish to indicate that there may be other materials intermixed with S.

classDefinition: A bodily fluid consisting of the expulsed contents of the stomach disgorged through the mouth or nose that happens as a result of a vomit reflex.
parentDefinition: A bodily fluid consisting of the contents of the digestive tract expulsed through the anterior portion of the digestive tract.

classDefinition: An mass of environmental material which is composed primarily of a solid environmental material
parentDefinition: An object which is composed primarily of an environmental material
classComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.
parentComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.

classDefinition: A particle which 1) is composed primarily of and derived from rock or mineral sources and 2) is or was part of a portion of sand.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is either 1) a minute fragment of a larger mass or 2) one of a collection of small masses composing an aggregate.
classComment: In general, sand grains are larger than those of silt, but finer than those of gravel.

classDefinition: A mass of solid material which is either 1) a minute fragment of a larger mass or 2) one of a collection of small masses composing an aggregate.
parentDefinition: An mass of environmental material which is composed primarily of a solid environmental material
parentComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.

classDefinition: A piece of rock which is between two and 64 millimetres in length along its largest dimension.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is composed primarily of rock.
classComment: Arguably, this could be placed in the "particle" hierarchy, but is usually considered too large in everyday semantics.

classDefinition: A comparatively elevated area on an icecap.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A comparatively elevated area on an icecap.
parentDefinition: A landform elevated above the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A curvature quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's having a shape resembling a dome.
parentDefinition: A curvature quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's having or being marked by a curve or smoothly rounded bend.

classDefinition: A particle which 1) is primarily composed of quartz or feldspar and 2) is or was part of a portion of silt.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is either 1) a minute fragment of a larger mass or 2) one of a collection of small masses composing an aggregate.
classComment: The distinction between silt and clay varies by discipline. Geologists and soil scientists usually consider the separation to occur at a particle size of 2 μm (clays being finer than silts), sedimentologists often use 4–5 μm, and colloid chemists use 1 μm. Geotechnical engineers distinguish between silts and clays based on the plasticity properties of the soil, as measured by the soils' Atterberg limits. ISO 14688 grades clay particles as being smaller than 2 μm and silt particles as being larger. Mixtures of sand, silt and less than 40% clay are called loam.

classDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is primarily composed of silt particles.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is composed primarily of particles.
classComment: This definition is intentionally ambiguous to support the multiple thresholds set by different authorities. Some authorities consider this soil material that contains 80% or more silt and less than 12% clay. In the Udden-Wentworth scale (due to Krumbein), silt particles range between 0.0039 to 0.0625 mm, larger than clay but smaller than sand particles. ISO 14688 grades silts between 0.002 mm and 0.063 mm. In actuality, silt is chemically distinct from clay, and unlike clay, grains of silt are approximately the same size in all dimensions; furthermore, their size ranges overlap. Clays are formed from thin plate-shaped particles held together by electrostatic forces, so present a cohesion. According to the U.S. Department of Agriculture Soil Texture Classification system, the sand-silt distinction is made at the 0.05 mm particle size. The USDA system has been adopted by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO). In the Unified Soil Classification System (USCS) and the AASHTO Soil Classification system, the sand-silt distinction is made at the 0.075 mm particle size (i.e., material passing the #200 sieve). Silts and clays are distinguished mechanically by their plasticity.

parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.
A particle which 1) is composed primarily of and derived from rock or mineral sources and 2) is or was part of a portion of sand.
parentComment: In general, sand grains are larger than those of silt, but finer than those of gravel.

classDefinition: Sand which is part of a desert.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: Sand which is part of a desert.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is composed primarily of particles of sand with only minor proportions of other substances.
parentComment: This definition is intentionally ambiguous to support the multiple thresholds set by different authorities. Some authorities consider as sands soil material that contains 85% or more sand; the percentage of silt plus 1.5 times the percentage of clay does not exceed 15. coarse sand (sable grossier) 25% or more very coarse and coarse sand, and less than 50% any other one grade of sand.

parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.
A particle which 1) is composed primarily of and derived from rock or mineral sources and 2) is or was part of a portion of sand.
parentComment: In general, sand grains are larger than those of silt, but finer than those of gravel.

classDefinition: A terrarium is a vivarium which simulates a terrestrial environment.
parentDefinition: A vivarium is an enclosure for keeping and raising organisms for observation or research. Often, a portion of the ecosystem for a particular species is simulated on a smaller scale, with controls for environmental conditions.

classDefinition: A vivarium is an enclosure for keeping and raising organisms for observation or research. Often, a portion of the ecosystem for a particular species is simulated on a smaller scale, with controls for environmental conditions.
parentDefinition: A manufactured product which has been designed to contain a mass of biomaterial.

classDefinition: A volcanic caldera that has been partially filled by a new central cone.
parentDefinition: An opening, or rupture, in the Earth's surface or crust, which allows hot, molten rock, ash and gases to escape from deep below the surface.
classComment: This may be more a subclass of 'caldera'

classDefinition: A chain of volcanic islands or mountains formed by plate tectonics as an oceanic tectonic plate subducts under another tectonic plate and produces magma.
parentDefinition: A group of geographically or geologically associated islands.

classDefinition: A volcanic arc formed by the subduction of oceanic crust below continental crust.
parentDefinition: A chain of volcanic islands or mountains formed by plate tectonics as an oceanic tectonic plate subducts under another tectonic plate and produces magma.

classDefinition: A volcanic arc formed by the subduction of oceanic crust other oceanic crust on an adjacent tectonic plate.
parentDefinition: A chain of volcanic islands or mountains formed by plate tectonics as an oceanic tectonic plate subducts under another tectonic plate and produces magma.

classDefinition: A geothermal field which is prone to localized volcanic activity.
parentDefinition: A field in which geothermal processes occur.
parentComment: In many geothermally active fields, wells can be drilled to obtain elements contained in solution in hot brines or to tap heat energy.

classDefinition: A field in which geothermal processes occur.
parentDefinition: An unbroken expanse (as of ice)
classComment: In many geothermally active fields, wells can be drilled to obtain elements contained in solution in hot brines or to tap heat energy.
parentComment: This class was created to accommodate "fields" from agricultural fields to marine mesoscale eddy fields. Thus, it has a very broad definition which makes it less than informative when annotating. Please consider using or requesting an appropriate subclass.

classDefinition: A volcanic field of small, scattered volcanic vents. These volcanic fields, containing numerous monogenetic volcanoes, are noted for having only one short eruptive event. Monogenetic fields occur only where the magma supply to the volcano is low or where vents are not close enough or large enough to develop plumbing systems for continuous feeding of magma.
parentDefinition: A geothermal field which is prone to localized volcanic activity.

classDefinition: A cone made of material ejected from a volcano. The material can range from finest particles. In comparison, cinder cones are more uniform. They are usually found in or on larger features, such as stratovolcanoes, shield volcanoes and can be found inside calderas, however they can also be an independent feature. They can range from a few metres in height and are usually formed by a single eruption.
parentDefinition: Built by fragments (called ejecta) thrown up (ejected) from a volcanic vent, piling up around the vent in the shape of a cone with a central crater.

classDefinition: Built by fragments (called ejecta) thrown up (ejected) from a volcanic vent, piling up around the vent in the shape of a cone with a central crater.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body associated with a volcano - an opening, or rupture, in that body's surface or crust - which allows hot, molten rock, ash and gases to escape from deep below the surface.

classDefinition: Built by fragments (called ejecta) thrown up (ejected) from a volcanic vent, piling up around the vent in the shape of a cone with a central crater.
parentDefinition: A landform elevated above the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A device for raising and lowering boats between stretches of water of different levels on river and canal waterways. The distinguishing feature of a lock is a fixed chamber whose water level can be varied.
parentDefinition: A construction which enables the movement of humans, their animals or their vehicles.

classDefinition: An area of land or of a body of water in which management practices,  through legal or other effective means, prioritise the protection and maintenance of biological diversity, and of natural and associated cultural resources.
parentDefinition: An environmental zone which 1) contains ecosystems, constructed features, or other entities deemed to be of natural, historical, cultural, or other significance and 2) has been afforded legal protections restricting one or more forms of use by a competent authority.
classComment: This class needs revision. Protected areas may be designated for multiple uses, and more clarity is needed. Further, the protections applied to the entities within the site may not prioritise biodiversity conservation. At a very general level, "protection" suggests that some forms of use are, in principle, excluded.

parentLabel: fiat part of an astronomical object
classDefinition: An environmental zone which 1) contains ecosystems, constructed features, or other entities deemed to be of natural, historical, cultural, or other significance and 2) has been afforded legal protections restricting one or more forms of use by a competent authority.
parentDefinition: A part of an environmental system whose boundaries are determined by fiat.
parentComment: Subclasses of this class have fiat (and only fiat) boundaries - that is, boundaries which are determined by human consensus or opinion rather than (and sometimes in contrast to) well-defined physical discontinuities. We distinguish these from entities that have fuzzy or hard to define boundaries that do overlap some form of physical discontinuity.

classDefinition: A natural environment which has been designated by a competent authority as having outstanding or unique value because of its rarity, aesthetic qualities, or cultural significance.
parentDefinition: An environmental system in which minimal to no anthropisation has occurred and non-human agents are the primary determinants of the system's dynamics and composition.
classComment: The commemorative value may be associated with one or more components of the environment in question, such as a mountain, tree, or river.
parentComment: In most contexts, 'natural' is defined by the lack of intervention or influence by humans and their activities. On Earth, most environments fall on a scale between completely natural and anthropised.

classDefinition: An environmental system in which minimal to no anthropisation has occurred and non-human agents are the primary determinants of the system's dynamics and composition.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
classComment: In most contexts, 'natural' is defined by the lack of intervention or influence by humans and their activities. On Earth, most environments fall on a scale between completely natural and anthropised.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: A protected forest or woodland area in the United States. National forests are controlled by the federal government and managed by the United States Forest Service, under the direction of the United States Department of Agriculture.
parentDefinition: An area of land or of a body of water in which management practices,  through legal or other effective means, prioritise the protection and maintenance of biological diversity, and of natural and associated cultural resources.
parentComment: This class needs revision. Protected areas may be designated for multiple uses, and more clarity is needed. Further, the protections applied to the entities within the site may not prioritise biodiversity conservation. At a very general level, "protection" suggests that some forms of use are, in principle, excluded.

classDefinition: A conservation designation denoting a protected area in the United Kingdom. SSSIs are the basic 'building block' of nature conservation legislation and most other legal nature/geological conservation designations are based upon them, including National Nature Reserves, Ramsar Sites, Special Protection Areas, and Special Areas of Conservation.
parentDefinition: An area of land or of a body of water in which management practices,  through legal or other effective means, prioritise the protection and maintenance of biological diversity, and of natural and associated cultural resources.
parentComment: This class needs revision. Protected areas may be designated for multiple uses, and more clarity is needed. Further, the protections applied to the entities within the site may not prioritise biodiversity conservation. At a very general level, "protection" suggests that some forms of use are, in principle, excluded.

classDefinition: A protected area of the sea usually established to preserve a specific habitat and ensure the ecosystem is sustained for the organisms that exist there. Most marine parks are designated by governments, and organized like watery national parks.
parentDefinition: An area of land or of a body of water in which management practices,  through legal or other effective means, prioritise the protection and maintenance of biological diversity, and of natural and associated cultural resources.
parentComment: This class needs revision. Protected areas may be designated for multiple uses, and more clarity is needed. Further, the protections applied to the entities within the site may not prioritise biodiversity conservation. At a very general level, "protection" suggests that some forms of use are, in principle, excluded.

classLabel: area designated as a nature reserve
classDefinition: A protected area of importance for wildlife, flora, fauna or features of geological or other special interest, which is reserved and managed for conservation and to provide special opportunities for study or research. Nature reserves may be designated by government institutions in some countries, such as the United Kingdom, or by private landowners, such as charities and research institutions, regardless of nationality.
parentDefinition: An area of land or of a body of water in which management practices,  through legal or other effective means, prioritise the protection and maintenance of biological diversity, and of natural and associated cultural resources.
parentComment: This class needs revision. Protected areas may be designated for multiple uses, and more clarity is needed. Further, the protections applied to the entities within the site may not prioritise biodiversity conservation. At a very general level, "protection" suggests that some forms of use are, in principle, excluded.

classDefinition: A designation for certain protected areas of the United States managed by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. The National Wildlife Refuge system is a network of lands and waters managed to protect wildlife and wildlife habitat.
parentDefinition: A protected area with the purpose of protecting and managing wild life.

classDefinition: A protected area with the purpose of protecting and managing wild life.
parentDefinition: An area of land or of a body of water in which management practices,  through legal or other effective means, prioritise the protection and maintenance of biological diversity, and of natural and associated cultural resources.

Further, the protections applied to the entities within the site may not prioritise biodiversity conservation. At a very general level, "protection" suggests that some forms of use are, in principle, excluded.

parentLabel: area designated as a nature reserve
classDefinition: A wetland protected by the terms of the Ramsar Convention (The Convention on Wetlands of International Importance, especially as Waterfowl Habitat).
parentDefinition: A protected area of importance for wildlife, flora, fauna or features of geological or other special interest, which is reserved and managed for conservation and to provide special opportunities for study or research. Nature reserves may be designated by government institutions in some countries, such as the United Kingdom, or by private landowners, such as charities and research institutions, regardless of nationality.

classLabel: area designated as a national nature reserve
classDefinition: An area of protected biodiversity which is of national significance for biological or Earth science interest.
parentDefinition: An area of land or of a body of water in which management practices,  through legal or other effective means, prioritise the protection and maintenance of biological diversity, and of natural and associated cultural resources.
classComment: Used as a designation in the United Kingdom.
parentComment: This class needs revision. Protected areas may be designated for multiple uses, and more clarity is needed. Further, the protections applied to the entities within the site may not prioritise biodiversity conservation. At a very general level, "protection" suggests that some forms of use are, in principle, excluded.

parentLabel: area protected according to IUCN guidelines
classDefinition: An IUCN protected area which 1) primarily consists of ecosystems which are able to maintain their natural composition, structure, and function at a regional scale and which are deemed to be representative of a region's natural bio- and geodiversity, 2) is sufficiently large to allow its constituent ecosystems to function, develop, and recover from natural perturbations without human intervention, and 3) is managed to preserve natural ecosystem integrity and functioning at a regional scale, while allowing human access for the purposes of conservation, cultural and spiritural activities, research, education, tourism, subsistence use by indigenous communities, and recreation.
parentDefinition: A protected area in which management objectives have been declared, by a local governing body or authority, to adhere to the guidelines set forth by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
classComment: Note that this ENVO class is not authoritative: see the associated IUCN references for a complete definition of all Protected Areas. These areas often serve as migration corridors between other natural and semi-natural ecosystems and pools of biodiversity. They may have core zones that are similar to IUCN Protected Area classes Ia and Ib.
parentComment: The international recognition of an area as an IUCN protected area generally depends on the assigning government or authority reporting its assignments to the United Nations Environment Programme World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

classLabel: area protected according to IUCN guidelines
classDefinition: A protected area in which management objectives have been declared, by a local governing body or authority, to adhere to the guidelines set forth by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
parentDefinition: An area of land or of a body of water in which management practices,  through legal or other effective means, prioritise the protection and maintenance of biological diversity, and of natural and associated cultural resources.
classComment: The international recognition of an area as an IUCN protected area generally depends on the assigning government or authority reporting its assignments to the United Nations Environment Programme World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

classDefinition: An island, usually the consequence of the activity of a submarine volcano, that only exists for a short period or short periods of time after its formation, then being eroded or otherwise disappearing beneath the surface of a body of water.
parentDefinition: Area of dry or relatively dry land surrounded by water or low wetland.

classDefinition:
MERGED DEFINITION:
TARGET DEFINITION: A large area of brine on the ocean basin near cold seep vents which release methane into the water. These pools are concentrations of water having an extremely high salinity as compared to the surrounding ocean, caused by the motion of large salt deposits through salt tectonics.
--------------------
SOURCE DEFINITION: Marine brine pools are large areas of brine on the ocean basin. These pools are bodies of water that have a salinity three to five times greater than the surrounding ocean. For deep-sea brine pools the source of the salt is the dissolution of large salt deposits through salt tectonics. The brine often contains high concentrations of methane, providing energy to chemosynthetic animals that live near the pool.
parentDefinition: A lentic water body is a water body in which the accumulated water, in its totality, has very little to no directed flow.

classDefinition:
MERGED DEFINITION:
TARGET DEFINITION: A large area of brine on the ocean basin near cold seep vents which release methane into the water. These pools are concentrations of water having an extremely high salinity as compared to the surrounding ocean, caused by the motion of large salt deposits through salt tectonics.

parentDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous volume of liquid water and is held in shape or sustained by an environmental process.
parentComment: Similar, in spirit, to landform.

classDefinition: A distinctive, flat-topped, steep-sided volcano formed when lava erupts through a thick glacier or ice sheet.
parentDefinition: An opening, or rupture, in the Earth's surface or crust, which allows hot, molten rock, ash and gases to escape from deep below the surface.

classDefinition: A volcano with more than one feature. They form because changes of their eruptive characteristics or the location of multiple vents in an area. Stratovolcanoes may form complex volcanoes, because they may overlap another from explosive eruptions, lava flows, pyroclastic flows and by repeated eruptions, to make multiple summits and vents. Stratovolcanoes could also form a large caldera that gets filled in by multiple small cinder cones, lava domes and craters may also develop on the caldera's rim.
parentDefinition: An opening, or rupture, in the Earth's surface or crust, which allows hot, molten rock, ash and gases to escape from deep below the surface.

classDefinition: A shield volcano that is formed mostly of pyroclastic and highly explosive eruptions rather than relatively fluid basaltic lava issuing from vents or fissures on the surface of the volcano. They typically display low-angle flank slopes and have little or no central collapse, although a shallow sag in the shield is commonly observed. Lava is commonly extruded after the cessation of explosive activity commonly superposes the vent region.
parentDefinition: A large volcano with shallowly-sloping sides.

classDefinition: A large volcano with shallowly-sloping sides.
parentDefinition: An opening, or rupture, in the Earth's surface or crust, which allows hot, molten rock, ash and gases to escape from deep below the surface.

classDefinition: A protected area that is a specific site (such as a forest, mountain, lake, desert, monument, building, complex, or city) that has been nominated and confirmed for inclusion on the list maintained by the international World Heritage Programme administered by the UNESCO World Heritage Committee.
parentDefinition: An environmental zone which 1) contains ecosystems, constructed features, or other entities deemed to be of natural, historical, cultural, or other significance and 2) has been afforded legal protections restricting one or more forms of use by a competent authority.

classDefinition: An international conservation designation given by UNESCO under its Programme on Man and the Biosphere (MAB).
parentDefinition: An area of land or of a body of water in which management practices,  through legal or other effective means, prioritise the protection and maintenance of biological diversity, and of natural and associated cultural resources.
parentComment: This class needs revision. Protected areas may be designated for multiple uses, and more clarity is needed. Further, the protections applied to the entities within the site may not prioritise biodiversity conservation. At a very general level, "protection" suggests that some forms of use are, in principle, excluded.

classDefinition: A reservoir constructed for the purpose of maintaining water levels in a canal or canals.
parentDefinition: An artificial body of water, often contained by a dam, constructed for the purpose of water storage.

classDefinition: The disposition of an environmental system to be covered by liquid water.
parentDefinition: A disposition which is realised by an environmental system or system parts thereof.
parentComment: This class and its subclasses are experimental and are being developed with NCEAS use cases in mind.

classDefinition: A disposition which is realised by an environmental system or system parts thereof.
classComment: This class and its subclasses are experimental and are being developed with NCEAS use cases in mind.

classDefinition: An ice mass which 1) is attached to the coast 2) at least 2 meters in thickness 3) forms where a glacier or ice mass flows down to a coastline and onto the ocean surface and 4) grows by annual snow accumulation or by the seaward extension of land glaciers.
classComment: An ice shelf may grow hundreds of miles out to sea.  Usually of great horizontal extent and with a level or gently undulating surface. Nourished by annual snow accumulation and also by the seaward extension of land glaciers. Limited areas may be aground. Ice shelves are much thicker than sea ice often filling embayments in the coastline of an ice sheet.. Currently, nearly all ice shelves are in Antarctica, where most of the ice discharged into the ocean flows via ice shelves. The mass balance of an ice shelf may have significant components of both gain and loss at the base. The seaward edge is termed an ice front.  The calving of an ice shelf forms tabular icebergs and ice islands.

classDefinition: An ice mass which 1) is attached to the coast 2) at least 2 meters in thickness 3) forms where a glacier or ice mass flows down to a coastline and onto the ocean surface and 4) grows by annual snow accumulation or by the seaward extension of land glaciers.
parentDefinition: An ice mass which has formed over land.
classComment: An ice shelf may grow hundreds of miles out to sea.  Usually of great horizontal extent and with a level or gently undulating surface. Nourished by annual snow accumulation and also by the seaward extension of land glaciers. Limited areas may be aground. Ice shelves are much thicker than sea ice often filling embayments in the coastline of an ice sheet.. Currently, nearly all ice shelves are in Antarctica, where most of the ice discharged into the ocean flows via ice shelves. The mass balance of an ice shelf may have significant components of both gain and loss at the base. The seaward edge is termed an ice front.  The calving of an ice shelf forms tabular icebergs and ice islands.
parentComment: Land ice is any part of the Earth's seasonal or perennial ice cover that has formed over land as the result, principally, of the freezing of precipitation; opposed to sea ice formed by the freezing of seawater.  Thus, an iceberg or tabular iceberg is land ice as well as its parent glacier, ice sheet, or ice shelf. The two major concentrations of land ice are the ice sheets of Greenland and Antarctica. Glaciers and ice caps are the other important forms; however, some members of the glaciology community hold that glaciers (i.e. rock glaciers) need not have any ice.

classDefinition: An atmosphere is a layer of gases surrounding a material body of sufficient mass that is held in place by the gravity of the body.
parentDefinition: A layer which is composed primarily of some fluid.

classDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's disposition to rise or float in a fluid medium such as water or air.
parentDefinition: A quality of a physical entity that exists through action of continuants at the physical level of organisation in relation to other entities.

classDefinition: A hydrological process in which irregular aggregates of snow fall to the surface of an astronomical body.
parentDefinition: Hydrological precipitation is a process during which any product of the condensation of atmospheric water vapour is pulled to the planetary surface by gravity.
parentComment: "process" is included in the label to make it clear that we are not referring to the precipitated material (e.g. snow, rain, sleet)

classDefinition: An advective transport process during which a mass of ice is transported from one location to another.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which a volume of material is displaced due to a disequilibrium in physical forces and during which 1) the qualities that inhere in that volume and 2) the processes that are unfolding within it are largely unchanged.
parentComment: Advective processes are disjoint from diffusive processes. Typically, fluids are advected.

classDefinition: A section of the Earths's crust that is demarcated by faults or flexures. In the movement of the crust, a massif tends to retain its internal structure while being displaced as a whole.
parentDefinition: A landform elevated above the surrounding area.

classDefinition: The general region of indefinite width that extends from a lake inland to the first major change in terrain features.
parentDefinition: A coast is the area where land meets the sea, ocean, or lake.
classComment: Usually reserved for large lakes.
parentComment: Used for both marine and lake coasts. The boundary of the coast is fuzzy and it overlaps both the water body and land in quesiton. Compared to 'shore'

classDefinition: The channel bottom of a stream; the physical confine of the normal water flow.
parentDefinition: The portion of the ground surface which lies below water.

classDefinition: The channel bottom of a river; the physical confine of the normal water flow.
parentDefinition: The channel bottom of a stream; the physical confine of the normal water flow.

classDefinition: The exit or point of discharge of a stream into another stream, lake or sea.
parentDefinition: A flowing body of water.

parentLabel: container of an intermittent water body
classDefinition: A depression which intermittently contains a lake.
parentDefinition: A depression which is is periodically filled with water when water supply exceeds evapotranspiration and bed seepage.
classComment: This has been moved from the lake hierarchy.
parentComment: This was formerly represented as a water body, which would not be valid during dry periods. This class more properly refers to the container of the water body, thusfar always some depression, which periodically contains a water body.

classLabel: container of an intermittent water body
classDefinition: A depression which is is periodically filled with water when water supply exceeds evapotranspiration and bed seepage.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
classComment: This was formerly represented as a water body, which would not be valid during dry periods. This class more properly refers to the container of the water body, thusfar always some depression, which periodically contains a water body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classLabel: container of an intermittent water body
classDefinition: A depression which is is periodically filled with water when water supply exceeds evapotranspiration and bed seepage.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.
classComment: This was formerly represented as a water body, which would not be valid during dry periods. This class more properly refers to the container of the water body, thusfar always some depression, which periodically contains a water body.

classDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which is sometimes inundated or saturated by surface or ground water sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances do support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions.
parentDefinition: A terrestrial ecosystem which is inundated or saturated by surface or ground water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances does support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions.

classDefinition: A spur which is part of a mountain.
parentDefinition: A slope of land descending laterally from a hill, mountain or main crest of a ridge.

classDefinition: A slope of land descending laterally from a hill, mountain or main crest of a ridge.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and relatively flat surrounding land.

classDefinition: An isthmus or other land connection between what at other times are separate land masses which allows animals and plants to cross and colonise new lands. Land bridges are commonly created by regression, in which sea levels fall exposing previously submerged sections of continental shelf. Land bridges are also formed by: (a) upthrust at the edge of continental plates; and (b) glacial retreat alleviating pressure on shallow marine formations.
parentDefinition: Narrow section of land in a body of water connecting two larger land areas.

classDefinition: A long and narrow sheet of ice projecting out from the coastline. An ice tongue forms when a valley glacier moves very rapidly out into the ocean or a lake.
parentDefinition: An ice mass which has formed over land.
parentComment: Land ice is any part of the Earth's seasonal or perennial ice cover that has formed over land as the result, principally, of the freezing of precipitation; opposed to sea ice formed by the freezing of seawater.  Thus, an iceberg or tabular iceberg is land ice as well as its parent glacier, ice sheet, or ice shelf. The two major concentrations of land ice are the ice sheets of Greenland and Antarctica. Glaciers and ice caps are the other important forms; however, some members of the glaciology community hold that glaciers (i.e. rock glaciers) need not have any ice.

classDefinition: A long and narrow sheet of ice projecting out from the coastline. An ice tongue forms when a valley glacier moves very rapidly out into the ocean or a lake.
parentDefinition: An ice mass which is suspended in a water body, being sufficiently buoyant for part of the mass to breach the surface of that water body.

classDefinition: A glacier which 1) flows for all or most of its length within the walls of a valley, in consequence having a distinct tongue and a well-defined outline and 2) descends from either high mountains, from an ice cap on a plateau, or from an ice sheet.
parentDefinition: An ice mass which is of sufficient mass that the action of gravity upon it overcomes the frictional forces holding it in place, causing it to deform and flow towards lower elevation.
classComment: These glaciers typically flow down pre-existing valleys and have ice-free slopes overlooking the glacier surface.
parentComment: The definition of glacier is highly variable. Two main issues exist: 1) Whether or not a mass of ice must currently show movement to be considered a glacier or not and 2) What is the relationship between ice sheets and glaciers (i.e., which is the parent in a parent/child relationship or whether they are distinct terms).

classDefinition: A large sea or ocean inlet larger than a bay, deeper than a bight, wider than a fjord, or it may identify a narrow sea or ocean channel between two bodies of land.
parentDefinition: An opening of the sea into the land.

classDefinition: A narrow channel of water that connects two larger bodies of water, and thus lies between two land masses.
parentDefinition: A depressed landform which physically confines a river, slough or ocean strait, and which consists of a bed and banks.

classDefinition: A channel of a watercourse which contains marine water.
parentDefinition: A depressed landform which physically confines a river, slough or ocean strait, and which consists of a bed and banks.

classDefinition: A channel of a watercourse which contains lake water.
parentDefinition: A depressed landform which physically confines a river, slough or ocean strait, and which consists of a bed and banks.

classDefinition: A convex 3-D shape quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's resembling a cone (a 3-D shape with a round cross section that tapers).
