classDefinition: A texture quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's processing a surface free of roughness or irregularities.
parentDefinition: A morphologic quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's relative size, organization and distribution of its surface elements or the representation or invention of the appearance of its surface; visual and tactile surface characteristics.

classDefinition: A convex 3-D shape quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's exhibiting a consistently-sized round cross section.
parentDefinition: A complete three dimensional shape in which for every line connecting pair of points on the object is within the object. Or: a shape lacking cavities. Contrast: concave.

classDefinition: A low obstruction built across the path of s stream to raise its level.
parentDefinition: A barrier constructed across a watercourse to control the flow or raise the level of water.

classDefinition: An annular depression that may not be continuous, located at the base of many seamounts, islands, and other isolated elevations.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A high altitude or high latitude bare, flat area covered with large angular rocks.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A high altitude or high latitude bare, flat area covered with large angular rocks.
parentDefinition: A landform elevated above the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A piece of rock with a grain size above 300 millimetres in diameter.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is composed primarily of rock.

classDefinition: An undersea area of subdued corrugations.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: The low part of a gap or saddle separating basins.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A lake which is primarily composed of brackish water, having a higher salinity than fresh water but a lower salinity than marine water.
parentDefinition: A lake whose water contains a considerable concentration of dissolved salts.

classDefinition: A lake which is primarily composed of brackish water, having a higher salinity than fresh water but a lower salinity than marine water.
parentDefinition: A body of water which is primarily composed of brackish water.
parentComment: This class has its subclasses populated by inference.

classDefinition: A body of water which is primarily composed of brackish water.
parentDefinition: A body of water which is primarily composed of saline water.
classComment: This class has its subclasses populated by inference.
parentComment: This class has its subclasses populated by inference.

classDefinition: A pond which is composed primarily of brackish water.
parentDefinition: A body of water, usually of smaller size than a lake.

classDefinition: A pond which is composed primarily of brackish water.
parentDefinition: A body of water which is primarily composed of brackish water.
parentComment: This class has its subclasses populated by inference.

classDefinition: Water which has a higher salinity than fresh water but a lower salinity than marine water.
parentDefinition: Water which contains a significant concentration of dissolved salts.
parentComment: The threshold salt concentration for classifying water as saline varies, but typically begins at about 1,000 to 3,000 parts salt per million parts water or 0.1–0.3% salt by weight.

classDefinition: A material entity which 1) is spatially continuous, 2) is composed of material of comparable thickness, composition, and physical properties, and 3) is physically distinct from adjacent portions of environmental material.
parentDefinition: An independent continuant that is spatially extended whose identity is independent of that of other entities and can be maintained through time.

classDefinition: A material entity which 1) is spatially continuous, 2) is composed of material of comparable thickness, composition, and physical properties, and 3) is physically distinct from adjacent portions of environmental material.
parentDefinition: An independent continuant that is spatially extended whose identity is independent of that of other entities and can be maintained through time.

classDefinition: A spatial pattern inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's exhibiting a layered configuration.
parentDefinition: A spatial pattern inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's layered configuration.

classDefinition: A depression which comprises a low tract of land, especially when moist or marshy.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
classComment: The term can refer to a natural landscape feature or a human-created one. When created by humans, this open drain system is designed to manage water runoff.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A depression which comprises a low tract of land, especially when moist or marshy.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.
classComment: The term can refer to a natural landscape feature or a human-created one. When created by humans, this open drain system is designed to manage water runoff.

classDefinition: A man-made watercourse, or makeshift aqueduct, often an artificial channel which supplies water to a watermill or its mill pond, collecting water from upstream of the mill so that the natural level of the driving water is above the level of the stream at the mill. Alternatively to may deliver water for mineral washing and concentration, irrigation or to a dye works.
parentDefinition: A channel of a watercource which has been constructed by humans or their technologies.

classDefinition: A beach which is armoured with pebbles or small to medium sized cobbles.
parentDefinition: A landform consisting of loose rock particles such as sand, gravel, shingle, pebbles, cobble, or even shell fragments along the shoreline of a body of water.

classDefinition: Lake sediment is sediment which covers the bottom of a lake. Lake sediments are comprised mainly of clastic material (sediment of clay, silt, and sand sizes), organic debris, chemical precipitates, or combinations of these.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is formed as a result of the transport and deposition of particles by flowing liquid.
parentComment: Sediment is typically deposited on the bed or bottom of a body of water or other liquid.

classDefinition: A material accumulation process during which solid particles are pulled through a water body by gravitation or centrifugal force and which ends when they settle on a solid surface.
parentDefinition: A process during which the mass of one or more materials, present within a given site, increases.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material accumulation process ends a material transport process.

classDefinition: A pond, often temporary or seasonal, used as a drinking place by mammals and birds.
parentDefinition: A body of water, usually of smaller size than a lake.

classDefinition: A field which is composed primarily of gravel.
parentDefinition: An unbroken expanse (as of ice)
parentComment: This class was created to accommodate "fields" from agricultural fields to marine mesoscale eddy fields. Thus, it has a very broad definition which makes it less than informative when annotating. Please consider using or requesting an appropriate subclass.

classDefinition: A field which is composed primarily of gravel.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

classDefinition: An area of unfrozen ground surrounded by permafrost.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: An area of unfrozen ground surrounded by permafrost.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the landmass of that body.

classDefinition: A dam constructed for more than one purpose.
parentDefinition: A barrier constructed across a watercourse to control the flow or raise the level of water.

classDefinition: An auxiliary dam constructed to confine the reservoir created by a primary dam either to permit a higher water elevation and storage or to limit the extent of a reservoir for increased efficiency.
parentDefinition: A barrier constructed across a watercourse to control the flow or raise the level of water.

classDefinition: A dam designed to reduce flow velocity and control soil erosion.
parentDefinition: A barrier constructed across a watercourse to control the flow or raise the level of water.

classDefinition: A dam that only partly restricts a waterway, creating a faster channel that resists the accumulation of sediment.
parentDefinition: A barrier constructed across a watercourse to control the flow or raise the level of water.

classDefinition: A dam designed to control flooding. It normally holds back no water and allows the channel to flow freely, except during periods of intense flow that would otherwise cause flooding downstream.
parentDefinition: A barrier constructed across a watercourse to control the flow or raise the level of water.

classDefinition: A dam designed to divert all or a portion of the flow of a river from its natural course.
parentDefinition: A barrier constructed across a watercourse to control the flow or raise the level of water.

classDefinition: A region at which weapons, typically military, are tested.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic geographic feature is a geographic feature resulting from the influence of human beings on nature.

classDefinition: A weapons test site at which nuclear weapons are, or have been, tested.
parentDefinition: A region at which weapons, typically military, are tested.

classDefinition: A region in which military personnel train.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic geographic feature is a geographic feature resulting from the influence of human beings on nature.

classLabel: usage of an environment for defence
classDefinition: A planned environmental usage process during which an environment supports activities which aim to protect citizens or any geographical area by preparing for or by using military means to resist the attack of an enemy.
parentDefinition: A planned process during which humans access and obtain resources, benefits, or services from a natural or anthropised ecosystem.
classComment: This class includes activities carried out in defence establishments, including camps, airfields, and live firing training areas. It excludes sites where defence personnel reside, such as barracks.

classDefinition: A bounded area of land, or water, usually in its natural or semi-natural (landscaped) state and set aside for some purpose, usually to do with recreation or conservation.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic geographic feature is a geographic feature resulting from the influence of human beings on nature.

classDefinition: An active management process which has the conservation of an ecosystem, or a part thereof, as its primary objective.
parentDefinition: A process during which an ecosystem, its parts, or the processes it participates in are modified by human intervention to accomplish an objective.

classLabel: usage of an environment for recreation
classDefinition: A planned environmental usage process during which humans access an environment in order to promote the refreshment of their physical and psychological health through relaxation and leisure activities.
parentDefinition: A planned process during which humans access and obtain resources, benefits, or services from a natural or anthropised ecosystem.

classDefinition: A raised walkway over water, supported by piles or pillars.
parentDefinition: A construction which enables the movement of humans, their animals or their vehicles.

classDefinition: A place (or group of physical sites) in which evidence of past activity is preserved (either prehistoric or historic or contemporary), and which is, has been, or may be, investigated using the discipline of archaeology.

A place (or group of physical sites) in which evidence of past activity is preserved (either prehistoric or historic or contemporary), and which is, has been, or may be, investigated using the discipline of archaeology.
A building or region where sports activities can be carried out.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: A sports facility constructed for skiing and allied sports that require snow and/or ice.
parentDefinition: A building or region where sports activities can be carried out.

classDefinition: A deep valley with steep sides, typically of limestone, in part submerged by the sea.
parentDefinition: A depression which has been formed as a result of erosion by water or ice and which is low-lying, bordered by higher ground, and especially elongate.
parentComment: Valleys are typically located between hills our mountains.

classDefinition: A sedimentary rock which is composed primarily of calcium carbonate in the form of calcite or aragnoite.
parentDefinition: A rock formed by deposition of either clastic sediments, organic matter, or chemical precipitates (evaporites), followed by compaction of the particulate matter and cementation during diagenesis.

classDefinition: Incorporated populated place.
parentDefinition: A settlement with a high density of buildings and inhabitants.
parentComment: The thresholds for what makes a settlment "dense" can be determined as needed. If there is a specific threshold that should be added to ENVO, please make a new class request.

classDefinition: A settlement with a high density of buildings and inhabitants.
parentDefinition: An anthropised ecosystem which is determined by the presence of humans and their constructions.
classComment: The thresholds for what makes a settlment "dense" can be determined as needed. If there is a specific threshold that should be added to ENVO, please make a new class request.

classDefinition: An aquatic biome which is determined by a body of freshwater.
parentDefinition: A biome which is determined by a water body and which has ecological climax communities adapted to life in or on water.

classDefinition: An aquatic biome which is determined by a body of freshwater.
A freshwater river biome which is determined by a large river.
parentDefinition: A freshwater biome which is determined by a freshwater river.
classComment: "Large" is ambiguous. For details on "Large rivers" (e.g. the Mekong river) see http://worldwildlife.org/biomes/large-river-ecosystems This class will be replaced with a less ambiguous class.

classDefinition: A freshwater biome which is determined by a freshwater river.
parentDefinition: An aquatic biome which is determined by a body of freshwater.

classDefinition: A freshwater river biome which is determined by the headwaters of a large river.
parentDefinition: A freshwater biome which is determined by a freshwater river.
classComment: "Large" is ambiguous. For details on "Large river headwaters" (e.g. the Upper Amazon headwaters) see http://worldwildlife.org/biomes/large-river-headwater-ecosystems This class will be replaced with a less ambiguous class.

classDefinition: A freshwater river biome which is determined by the delta of a large river.
parentDefinition: A freshwater biome which is determined by a freshwater river.
classComment: "Large" is ambiguous. For details on "Large river deltas" (e.g. the Niger river delta) see http://worldwildlife.org/biomes/large-river-delta-ecosystems This class will be replaced with a less ambiguous class.

classDefinition: A freshwater river biome which is determined by a small river.
parentDefinition: A freshwater biome which is determined by a freshwater river.
classComment: "Small" is ambiguous. For details on "Small rivers" (e.g. the Salween river) see http://worldwildlife.org/biomes/small-river-ecosystems. This class will be replaced with a less ambiguous class.

classDefinition: A freshwater biome which is determined by a large lake.
parentDefinition: A biome which is determined by a freshwater lake.
classComment: "Large" is ambiguous. For details on "Large lakes" (e.g. African rift lakes) see http://worldwildlife.org/biomes/large-lake-ecosystems This class will be replaced with a less ambiguous class.

classDefinition: A biome which is determined by a freshwater lake.
parentDefinition: An aquatic biome which is determined by a body of freshwater.

classDefinition: A freshwater lake biome which is determined by a small lake.
parentDefinition: A biome which is determined by a freshwater lake.
classComment: "Small" is ambiguous. For details on "Small lakes" (e.g. Cameroon crater lakes)  see http://worldwildlife.org/biomes/small-lake-ecosystems. This class will be replaced with a less ambiguous class.

classDefinition: A biome which has little permanent surface water and a low relative abundance of springs.
parentDefinition: An aquatic biome which is determined by a body of freshwater.

classDefinition: A spring through which fresh water flows.
parentDefinition: A surface landform which provides an egress for groundwater or steam to flow out of the ground.
parentComment: Springs are typically where an aquifer surface meets the ground surface or where there is a fissure.

classDefinition: A spring through which fresh water flows.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of liquid material.

classDefinition: A hardness quality of being rigid and resistant to pressure.
parentDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's resistance to pressure, being broken, or pierced

classDefinition: A hardness quality of being rigid and resistant to pressure.
parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is increased compared to normal or average.

classDefinition: A mineral material is an environmental material which is primarily composed of some substance that is naturally occurring, solid and stable at room temperature, representable by a chemical formula, usually abiogenic, and that has an ordered atomic structure.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: The outflow of water from a mine.
parentDefinition: A flowing body of water.

classDefinition: A mine drainage with an acidic pH.
parentDefinition: The outflow of water from a mine.

classDefinition: An medium acidity quality inhering in a solution by virtue of the bearer's a high concentration of H+ ions.
parentDefinition: A concentration quality inhering in a medium by virtue of the bearer's tendency to hydronate a specific reference base.

classDefinition: An astronomical body part which is composed of soil, subject to soil formation processes, and found on the surface of a lithosphere.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: This is a very broad and, in practice, poorly defined term. Please consider using or requesting a more specific class.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: Particulate environmental material which 1) is composed primarily of clay particles, with only minor proportions of other materials, 2) demonstrates plasticity when wet, and 3) is capable of hardening when dried or fired.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is composed primarily of particles.
classComment: This definition is intentionally ambiguous to support the multiple thresholds set by different authorities.The distinction between silt and clay varies by discipline. Geologists and soil scientists usually consider the separation to occur at a particle size of 2 μm (clays being finer than silts), sedimentologists often use 4–5 μm, and colloid chemists use 1 μm. Geotechnical engineers distinguish between silts and clays based on the plasticity properties of the soil, as measured by the soils' Atterberg limits. ISO 14688 grades clay particles as being smaller than 2 μm and silt particles as being larger. Mixtures of sand, silt and less than 40% clay are called loam. Similar mixtures with greater than 40% clay are often considered clay soils.

classDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: Water-holding capacity which inheres in some soil.
parentDefinition: A disposition of a material entity which is realised when it is saturated with liquid water.

classDefinition: A shape quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's having an oblique or slanted direction.
parentDefinition: A morphological quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's ratios of distances between its features (points, edges, surfaces and also holes etc).

classDefinition: Water that has been adversely affected in quality by anthropogenic influence.
Water that has been adversely affected in quality by anthropogenic influence.
parentDefinition: A material which is not the desired output of a process and which is typically the input of a process which removes it from its producer (e.g. a disposal process).

classDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a liquid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: most of its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: A role that is realized in some process wherein the bearer is discarded or not utilized further.
parentDefinition: A realizable entity  the manifestation of which brings about some result or end that is not essential to a continuant  in virtue of the kind of thing that it is but that can be served or participated in by that kind of continuant  in some kinds of natural, social or institutional contexts.

classDefinition: A role that is realized in some process wherein the bearer is discarded or not utilized further.
parentDefinition: A role is particular behaviour which a material entity may exhibit.

classDefinition: An excreta material which is composed primarily of feces, an excreta consisting of waste products expelled from an animal's digestive tract through the anus (or cloaca) during defecation.
parentDefinition: A bodily fluid material which is composed primarily of excreta, bodily fluids consisting of matter which contains the waste products of biological processes, including urine or feces, discharged from an organism's body.
classComment: ENVO bodily fluid classes differ from UBERON's treatment of bodily fluids. UBERON refers to the substance itself ("S"). We assert that UBERON's classes are the primary compositional component of the terms in ENVO ("S material"). Use of the ENVO terms is typically recommended when you wish to indicate that there may be other materials intermixed with S.

classDefinition: Water which contains a highly increased concentration of dissolved salts, surpassing the average salinity of seawater.
parentDefinition: Water which contains a significant concentration of dissolved salts.
classComment: The average salinity of sea water is assumed to be around 35,000 ppm, equivalent to 35 grams of salt per one liter (or kilogram) of water.
parentComment: The threshold salt concentration for classifying water as saline varies, but typically begins at about 1,000 to 3,000 parts salt per million parts water or 0.1–0.3% salt by weight.

classDefinition: Rock formed from molten magma.
parentDefinition: A rock is a naturally occurring solid aggregate of one or more minerals or mineraloids.
parentComment: From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ [A mineral] is different from a rock, which can be an aggregate of minerals or non-minerals and does not have a specific chemical composition. The exact definition of a mineral is under debate, especially with respect to the requirement a valid species be abiogenic, and to a lesser extent with regards to it having an ordered atomic structure.

classDefinition: Lava is a mixture of molten or semi-molten rock, volatiles, and solids which has extruded beyond a planetary crust.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is unable to resist shear forces and continuously deforms when subject to them.
classComment: Some use 'lava' to refer to rock that is formed when lava cools. This is not the intended meaning of this class. See 'igneous rock' or similar.

classDefinition: An igneous rock that results from the crystallization of a magma below the surface of the Earth.
parentDefinition: Rock formed from molten magma.

classDefinition: An igneous rock that results from magma reaching the surface either as lava or fragmental ejecta.
parentDefinition: A rock is a naturally occurring solid aggregate of one or more minerals or mineraloids.
classComment: Due to the general suggestion that volcanic rock simply comes from a volcanic process, it's not immediately clear whether this is interchangeable with igneous rock.
parentComment: From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ [A mineral] is different from a rock, which can be an aggregate of minerals or non-minerals and does not have a specific chemical composition. The exact definition of a mineral is under debate, especially with respect to the requirement a valid species be abiogenic, and to a lesser extent with regards to it having an ordered atomic structure.

classDefinition: A rock formed by subjecting any rock type (including previously-formed metamorphic rock) to different temperature and pressure conditions than those in which the original rock was formed. These temperatures and pressures are always higher than those at the Earth's surface and must be sufficiently high so as to change the original minerals into other mineral types or else into other forms of the same minerals (e.g. by recrystallisation).
parentDefinition: A rock is a naturally occurring solid aggregate of one or more minerals or mineraloids.

parentDefinition: An object which is formed as a result of one or more biological processes and is composed primarily of organic material.

parentComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.

classDefinition: A viability quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the cessation of the bearer's life.
parentDefinition: An organismal quality inhering in a bearer or a population by virtue of the bearer's disposition to survive and develop normally or the number of surviving individuals in a given population.

classDefinition: Biological entity that is either an individual member of a biological species or constitutes the structural organization of an individual member of a biological species.
parentDefinition: A continuant that is a bearer of quality and realizable entity entities, in which other entities inhere and which itself cannot inhere in anything.

classDefinition: Biological entity that is either an individual member of a biological species or constitutes the structural organization of an individual member of a biological species.

classDefinition: A complex aggregation of microorganisms marked by the excretion of a protective and adhesive matrix; usually adhering to a substratum.

parentDefinition: An mass of environmental materials which has appreciable quantities of several individual materials, such that the removal of one would convert the mass into a different entity.

classDefinition: A natural object originating in outer space that survives an impact with a planetary surface without being destroyed.
parentDefinition: An mass of environmental material which is composed primarily of a solid environmental material

classDefinition: The surface layer of a volume of water.

classComment: If there is only one astronomical body involved, this class is equivalent to ENVO:01000799. This may be problematic with reasoning, but it seems to be true to the rather fuzzy definitions found thus far.

parentDefinition: An industrial building is a building within which goods are produced and, optionally, stored or within which services are rendered.

The United Nations' International Standard Industrial Classification should be referred to when expanding this branch. ISIC can also be used to identify processes. See http://unstats.un.org/unsd/cr/registry/regcst.asp?Cl=27&Lg=1.

classDefinition: A stony meteorite that have not been modified due to melting or differentiation of the parent body.

parentDefinition: A natural object originating in outer space that survives an impact with a planetary surface without being destroyed.

A meteorite that consists of a mixture of iron-nickel metal and silicate minerals.

classDefinition: A meteorite that overwhelmingly of nickel-iron alloys.
parentDefinition: A natural object originating in outer space that survives an impact with a planetary surface without being destroyed.

classDefinition: Chemical precipitation is a process in which a portion of some solid substance segregates from a material in which that substance or its precursors were dissolved in and settles due to a force such as gravity or centrifugal force. Segregation may occur due to the solubility limits of the precipitating substance being exceeded or due to a chemical reaction that forms a solid product from aqueous reagents.
parentDefinition: A precipitation process is a process in which a portion of some substance segregates from a material in which that substance or its precursors were dissolved or suspended in and settles due to a force such as gravity or centrifugal force.

classDefinition: Limestone which is soft, white, and porous.
parentDefinition: A sedimentary rock which is composed primarily of calcium carbonate in the form of calcite or aragnoite.

classDefinition: An achromatic color of maximum brightness; the color of objects that reflect nearly all light of all visible wavelengths.
parentDefinition: A composite chromatic quality composed of hue, saturation and intensity parts.

classDefinition: A sedimentary rock composed mainly of sand-size mineral or rock grains.
parentDefinition: Clastic sedimentary rocks are sedimentary rocks that are composed of silicate minerals and rock fragments that were transported by moving fluids. Clastic rocks are composed largely of quartz, feldspar, rock (lithic) fragments, clay minerals, and mica; numerous other minerals may be present as accessories and may be important locally.

classDefinition: Clastic sedimentary rocks are sedimentary rocks that are composed of silicate minerals and rock fragments that were transported by moving fluids. Clastic rocks are composed largely of quartz, feldspar, rock (lithic) fragments, clay minerals, and mica; numerous other minerals may be present as accessories and may be important locally.
parentDefinition: A rock formed by deposition of either clastic sediments, organic matter, or chemical precipitates (evaporites), followed by compaction of the particulate matter and cementation during diagenesis.

classDefinition: A fine-grained sedimentary rock whose original constituents were clays or muds. It is characterized by thin laminae breaking with an irregular curving fracture, often splintery and usually parallel to the often-indistinguishable bedding plane.
parentDefinition: Clastic sedimentary rocks are sedimentary rocks that are composed of silicate minerals and rock fragments that were transported by moving fluids. Clastic rocks are composed largely of quartz, feldspar, rock (lithic) fragments, clay minerals, and mica; numerous other minerals may be present as accessories and may be important locally.
The residual semi-solid material left from domestic or industrial processes, or wastewater treatment processes.
The residual semi-solid material left from domestic or industrial processes, or wastewater treatment processes.

classDefinition: A treated form of sludge, sometimes used as a fertilizer in agriculture.
parentDefinition: The residual semi-solid material left from domestic or industrial processes, or wastewater treatment processes.

classDefinition: A solid or gel in motor oil caused by the oil gelling or solidifying, usually at temperatures lower than 100deg C.

parentDefinition: The residual semi-solid material left from domestic or industrial processes, or wastewater treatment processes.

classDefinition: The result of the unintentional release of liquid petroleum hydrocarbon into the environment as a result of human activity.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic geographic feature which has increased levels of contaminants in its consituent materials.

classDefinition: An anthropogenic geographic feature which has increased levels of contaminants in its consituent materials.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic geographic feature is a geographic feature resulting from the influence of human beings on nature.

classDefinition: A nonpolar, hydrophobic, and lipophilic material which is a viscous liquid at ambient temperatures (about 20 degrees Celsius) or slightly warmer.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a liquid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: most of its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: A nonpolar, hydrophobic, and lipophilic material which is a viscous liquid at ambient temperatures (about 20 degrees Celsius) or slightly warmer.
The result of the release of natural hydrocarbons to the surface of the earth, including beneath the sea, by natural geological processes.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of liquid material.

classDefinition: Mine drainage which is formed as a result of the mining of gold.
parentDefinition: The outflow of water from a mine.

classDefinition: Sediment that accumulates in the flat or very gently sloping areas of the deep ocean basin floor. The three main types of deep marine sediment, also known as pelagic sediment, are siliceous oozes, calcareous oozes, and red clays.
parentDefinition: Sediment which has been transported through the marine water column, settling on the seafloor.
parentComment: Particles of marine sediment are primarily generated by 1) processes in terrestrial systems and transported to the marine realm by the action of rivers or aeolian processes (amongst other routes) , 2) marine organisms, 3) chemical processes in seawater, or 4) cosmogeneous input.

classDefinition: Sediment which has been transported through the marine water column, settling on the seafloor.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is formed as a result of the transport and deposition of particles by flowing liquid.
classComment: Particles of marine sediment are primarily generated by 1) processes in terrestrial systems and transported to the marine realm by the action of rivers or aeolian processes (amongst other routes) , 2) marine organisms, 3) chemical processes in seawater, or 4) cosmogeneous input.
parentComment: Sediment is typically deposited on the bed or bottom of a body of water or other liquid.

classDefinition: Sediment which has increased levels of one or more chemical compounds.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is formed as a result of the transport and deposition of particles by flowing liquid.
parentComment: Sediment is typically deposited on the bed or bottom of a body of water or other liquid.

classDefinition: Organically enriched sediment which has increased levels of petroleum.
parentDefinition: Chemically-enriched sediment which has increased levels of organic compounds.

classDefinition: Chemically-enriched sediment which has increased levels of organic compounds.
parentDefinition: Sediment which has increased levels of one or more chemical compounds.

classDefinition: A naturally occurring flammable liquid consisting of a complex mixture of hydrocarbons of various molecular weights and other liquid organic compounds, that are found in geologic formations beneath the planetary surfaces.
parentDefinition: A nonpolar, hydrophobic, and lipophilic material which is a viscous liquid at ambient temperatures (about 20 degrees Celsius) or slightly warmer.

classDefinition: A portion of contaminated soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of some contaminant.
parentDefinition: A portion of enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of some material entity.
classComment: "contaminant" is more of a disposition - any material entity can be a contaminant in particular circumstances.
parentComment: This could be demoted to an inferred class if issues with double inheritance arise.

classDefinition: A portion of enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of some material entity.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
classComment: This could be demoted to an inferred class if issues with double inheritance arise.
parentComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

" The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm."  Soil taxonomy, 2nd Ed., quoted in http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/edu/?cid=nrcs142p2_054280

classDefinition: Soil which has elevated concentrations of creosote.
parentDefinition: A portion of contaminated soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of some contaminant.
parentComment: "contaminant" is more of a disposition - any material entity can be a contaminant in particular circumstances.

classDefinition: The portion of chemical products obtained by the distillation of a tar that remains heavier than water, notably useful for its anti-septic and preservative properties
parentDefinition: A manufactured product that is some mixture of chemicals created through some chemical engineering process

classDefinition: A mineral spring through which water with a high pH flows.
parentDefinition: A spring which  water contains a significant amount of dissolved minerals, that derive from the rocks through which the water flows.

classDefinition: A portion of alkaline water is a portion of water with a pH greater than 7.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

classDefinition: A spring through which water with a low pH flows.
parentDefinition: A surface landform which provides an egress for groundwater or steam to flow out of the ground.

classDefinition: A portion of acidic water is a portion of water with a pH less than 7.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

classDefinition: A saline lake which has a high pH.
parentDefinition: A lake whose water contains a considerable concentration of dissolved salts.
classComment: The pH of alkaline lakes is typically between 9 and 12. They are characterized by high concentrations of carbonate salts, typically sodium carbonate (and related salt complexes), giving rise to their alkalinity. In addition, many soda lakes also contain high concentrations of sodium chloride and other dissolved salts, making them saline or hypersaline lakes as well. High pH and salinity often coincide, because of how soda lakes develop.

classDefinition: Mud which has elevated concentrations of arsenic.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is a liquid or semi-liquid mixture of water and some combination of soil, silt, and clay particles.

classDefinition: A manufactured product which has been designed to contain a mass of biomaterial.

classDefinition: A layer which is part of a lake.

classDefinition: A layer which is part of a lake.

classDefinition: A cline which is part of a lake and across which temperature changes rapidly with depth.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: Especially used in connection with meromictic lakes.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: A cline which is part of a lake and across which temperature changes rapidly with depth.

classDefinition: The top-most layer in a thermally stratified lake, occurring above the deeper hypolimnion. It is warmer and typically has a higher pH and dissolved oxygen concentration than the hypolimnion.
parentDefinition: A layer which is part of a lake.
parentComment: Note that this class does not contain metalimnion as a subclass. The metaliminon is classified as a thermocline.

classDefinition: A cline across which temperature changes rapidly.
parentDefinition: A fluid front which is 1) thin in comparison to the fluid mass it is a part of and 2) across which a property of that fluid mass varies greatly over short vertical distance, relative to variation across the entire fluid mass.
parentComment: A similar term exists in linguistics and mathematics. An ecocline, or biological cline, is a related concept; however, may be better placed as a child of a class like "ecotone". Further, some definitions of "layer" require a layer's constiuent materials to have consistent properties, thus "cline" would not qualify as a subclass. The term "gradient" has been proposed as a more suitable superclass. Discussion in Issue #286)

We distinguish these from entities that have fuzzy or hard to define boundaries that do overlap some form of physical discontinuity.

classDefinition: Water ice which has formed by the freezing of sea water.
parentDefinition: Ice which has formed as the result of freezing of water which was part of a water body.
classComment: In the United States, NOAA sea ice operations does not include superstructure icing as being sea ice. In sea ice operations however, sea ice is any form of ice found at sea which has originated from the freezing of sea water. It presents the main kind of floating ice encountered at sea. Except where it forms ridges, sea ice is up to a few metres thick, in which respect it differs from shelf ice.  Sea ice may be discontinuous pieces (ice floes) moved on the ocean surface by wind and currents (pack ice), or a motionless sheet attached to the coast (land-fast ice). In brief, it forms first as lolly ice (frazil crystals), thickens into sludge, and coagulates into sheet ice, pancake ice, or into floes of various shapes and sizes. Thereafter, sea ice may develop into pack ice and/or become a form of pressure ice.  Sea ice less than one year old is called first-year ice. Perennial ice is sea ice that survives at least one summer. It may be subdivided into second-year ice and multi-year ice, where multiyear ice has survived at least two summers.
parentComment: In the United States, NOAA considers ice formed from the freezing of the waters of the Great Lakes as being the same as sea ice. This class attempts to provide a distinction for clarity.

classDefinition: Ice which has formed as the result of freezing of water which was part of a water body.
parentDefinition: Ice which is formed from water.
classComment: In the United States, NOAA considers ice formed from the freezing of the waters of the Great Lakes as being the same as sea ice. This class attempts to provide a distinction for clarity.
parentComment:
Water ice can appear transparent or opaque bluish-white color, depending on the presence of impurities or air inclusions. The addition of other materials such as soil may further alter its appearance.

When speaking about ice on Earth, usually water ice is meant - the solid, crystalline form of water found in the atmosphere as snow crystals, hail, ice pellets, etc., and on the earth's surface in forms such as hoarfrost, rime, glaze, sea ice, glacier ice, ground ice, frazil, anchor ice, etc.

This form of water is, strictly speaking, called ice Ih, the Roman numeral I distinguishing it from more than a dozen other phases and the letter h distinguishing it from the metastable cubic phase ice Ic. Ice Ih is the only one of the several known phases of water ice that is stable at commonly occurring temperatures and pressures. (Some of the other forms have very unusual properties, ice VII, for example, being stable only at pressures above 22 400 kg/cm^2, but then existing at temperatures up to about 100C.)

It has an open structure with a specific gravity of 0.9166 which is slightly less than water; because the water molecules bond to their neighbors covalently only in four directions; it therefore floats on higher density water, where broken molecular bonds permit closer packing. All commonly occurring forms of ice are crystalline, although large single crystals are relatively rare except in glaciers. The ice crystal lattice possesses hexagonal symmetry that manifests itself in the gross forms of such single crystals as are sometimes found in snow. At an air pressure of one atmosphere, ice melts at 0 C by definition of the Celsius temperature scale. (Strictly speaking the equilibrium point among water, ice, and vapor occurs at +0.01C, the triple point.) On the other hand, ice does not invariably form in liquid water cooled below this temperature; it has a tendency to supercool, more so in the absence of ice nuclei.

In permafrost regions, ice may occupy voids in soils and rocks and may develop in a variety of forms. Ice may be colourless to pale blue or greenish-blue. It may appear white due to included gas bubbles; in exposures, ground ice may also appear black.

In nature ice is formed either by: (a) the freezing of water, (b) the condensation of atmospheric water vapour direct into ice crystals, (c) the compaction of snow with or without the motion of a glacier, or (d) the impregnation of porous snow masses with water which subsequently freeze.

parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is decreased compared to normal or average.

classDefinition: A concentration which is lower relative to the normal or average.
parentDefinition: A concentration quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's exhibiting concentration.

classDefinition: Water with a high nutrient level.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

classDefinition: Water with a nutrient level intermediate between eutrophic and oligotrophic.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

classDefinition: A lithified mass of rock that lies under the loose softer material (regolith) at the surface of the Earth or other terrestrial planet.
parentDefinition: A rock is a naturally occurring solid aggregate of one or more minerals or mineraloids.
parentComment: From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ [A mineral] is different from a rock, which can be an aggregate of minerals or non-minerals and does not have a specific chemical composition. The exact definition of a mineral is under debate, especially with respect to the requirement a valid species be abiogenic, and to a lesser extent with regards to it having an ordered atomic structure.

parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

parentDefinition: Water which has a low concentration of dissolved solutes, particularly that of sodium chloride.
parentComment: The lower bound of solute concentration required for water to be considered freshwater is variable, but is always less than that of seawater, and often cited as less than 1 gram of solutes per 1 litre of water.

classDefinition: Arenosols are sandy soils, including both soils developed in residual sands after in situ weathering of usually quartz-rich sediments or rock, and soils developed in recently deposited sands such as dunes in deserts and beach lands.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
parentComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

" The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm."  Soil taxonomy, 2nd Ed., quoted in http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/edu/?cid=nrcs142p2_054280

classDefinition: Anthrosols comprise soils that have been modified profoundly through human activities, such as addition of organic materials or household wastes, irrigation and cultivation.
parentDefinition: Anthropogenic material in or on which organisms may live.

classDefinition: Anthrosols comprise soils that have been modified profoundly through human activities, such as addition of organic materials or household wastes, irrigation and cultivation.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.

classDefinition: Alisols are soils that have a higher clay content in the subsoil than in the topsoil as a result of pedogenetic processes (especially clay migration) leading to an argic subsoil horizon. Alisols have a low base saturation at certain depths and high-activity clays throughout the argic horizon. They lack the albeluvic tonguing as in Albeluvisols. They occur predominantly in humid tropical, humid subtropical and warm temperate regions.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.

classDefinition: Andosols are soils that develop in volcanic ejecta or glasses under almost any climate (except under hyperarid climate conditions). However, Andosols may also develop in other silicate-rich materials under acid weathering in humid and perhumid climates.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.

classDefinition: Silica-based glass is a glass composed primarily of silicon dioxide, the primary constituent of sand.
parentDefinition: Glass is an amorphous (non-crystalline) solid which is often transparent.
classComment: Silica-based glasses are the most common manufactured variety of glass.
parentComment: This class refers to all forms of glass. For the familiar form present in window panes and drinking glasses, consider silica-based glass.

classDefinition: Albeluvisols are soils that have, beginning within 1 m of the soil surface, a clay illuviation horizon with an irregular or broken upper boundary resulting in tonguing of bleached soil material into the illuviation horizon.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.

classDefinition: Acrisols are soils that have a higher clay content in the subsoil than in the topsoil as a result of pedogenetic processes (especially clay migration) leading to an argic subsoil horizon. Acrisols have in certain depths a low base saturation and low-activity clays.
parentDefinition: A soil which has high mineral content and which contain no calcareous material, have less than 10% weatherable minerals its surface layer, and have less than 35% base saturation throughout its volume.
parentComment: The word "ultisol" is derived from "ultimate", because ultisols were seen as the ultimate product of continuous weathering of minerals in a humid, temperate climate without new soil formation via glaciation.

classDefinition: A soil which has high mineral content and which contain no calcareous material, have less than 10% weatherable minerals its surface layer, and have less than 35% base saturation throughout its volume.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.

classDefinition: Cambisols combine soils with at least an incipient subsurface soil formation. Transformation of parent material is evident from structure formation and mostly brownish discoloration, increasing clay percentage, and/or carbonate removal.

classDefinition: Cryosols comprise mineral soils formed in a permafrost environment. Where water is present, it occurs primarily in the form of ice. Cryogenic processes are the dominant soil-forming processes.
parentDefinition: Soil which is below the freezing point of water.

classDefinition: Soil which is below the freezing point of water.

classDefinition: Durisols are associated mainly with old surfaces in arid and semi-arid environments and accommodate very shallow to moderately deep, moderately well- to well-drained soils that contain cemented secondary silica (SiO2) within 100 cm of the soil surface.

classDefinition: Calcisols are soils in which there is substantial secondary accumulation of lime. Calcisols are common in highly calcareous parent materials and widespread in arid and semi-arid environments.

classDefinition: Kastanozems are dry grassland soils, among them the zonal soils of the short-grass steppe belt, south of the Eurasian tall-grass steppe belt with Chernozems. Kastanozems have a similar profile to that of Chernozems but the humus-rich surface horizon is thinner and not as dark as that of the Chernozems and they show more prominent accumulation of secondary carbonates.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.

classDefinition: Histosols comprise soils formed in organic material. These vary from soils developed in predominantly moss peat in boreal, arctic and subarctic regions, via moss peat, reeds/ sedge peat (fen) and forest peat in temperate regions to mangrove peat and swamp forest peat in the humid tropics. Histosols are found at all altitudes, but the vast majority occurs in lowlands.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.

classDefinition: Gleysols are wetland soils that, unless drained, are saturated with groundwater for long enough periods to develop a characteristic gleyic colour pattern. This pattern is essentially made up of reddish, brownish or yellowish colours at ped surfaces and/or in the upper soil layer or layers, in combination with greyish/bluish colours inside the peds and/or deeper in the soil.

classDefinition: Ferralsols represent the classical, deeply weathered, red or yellow soils of the humid tropics. These soils have diffuse horizon boundaries, a clay assemblage dominated by low-activity clays (mainly kaolinite) and a high content of sesquioxides.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
parentComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

" The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm."  Soil taxonomy, 2nd Ed., quoted in http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/edu/?cid=nrcs142p2_054280

classDefinition: Nitisols are deep, well-drained, red, tropical soils with diffuse horizon boundaries and a subsurface horizon with more than 30 percent clay and moderate to strong angular blocky structure elements that easily fall apart into characteristic shiny, polyhedric (nutty) elements. Weathering is relatively advanced but Nitisols are far more productive than most other red, tropical soils.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.

classDefinition: Luvisols are soils that have a higher clay content in the subsoil than in the topsoil as a result of pedogenetic processes (especially clay migration) leading to an argic subsoil horizon. Luvisols have high-activity clays throughout the argic horizon and a high base saturation at certain depths.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.

classDefinition: Phaeozems accommodate soils of relatively wet grassland and forest regions in moderately continental climates. Phaeozems are much like Chernozems and Kastanozems but are leached more intensively. Consequently, they have dark, humus rich surface horizons that, in comparison with Chernozems and Kastanozems, are less rich in bases. Phaeozems may or may not have secondary carbonates but have a high base saturation in the upper metre of the soil.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
parentComment:

classDefinition: Plinthosols are soils with plinthite, petroplinthite or pisoliths. Plinthite is an Fe-rich (in some cases also Mn-rich), humus-poor mixture of kaolinitic clay (and other products of strong weathering such as gibbsite) with quartz and other constituents that changes irreversibly to a layer with hard nodules, a hardpan or irregular aggregates on exposure to repeated wetting and drying. Petroplinthite is a continuous, fractured or broken sheet of connected, strongly cemented to indurated nodules or mottles. Pisoliths are discrete strongly cemented to indurated nodules. Both petroplinthite and pisoliths develop from plinthite by hardening.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.

classDefinition: Planosols are soils with a light-coloured, surface horizon that shows signs of periodic water stagnation and abruptly overlies a dense, slowly permeable subsoil with significantly more clay than the surface horizon.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.

classDefinition: Solonchaks are soils that have a high concentration of soluble salts at some time in the year. Solonchaks are largely confined to the arid and semi-arid climate zones and to coastal regions in all climates.

classDefinition: Umbrisols are soils in which organic matter has accumulated within the mineral surface soil (in most cases with low base saturation) to the extent that it significantly affects the behaviour and utilization of the soil.

classDefinition: A soil in which there is a high content of expansive clay known as montmorillonite that forms deep cracks in drier seasons or years. Alternate shrinking and swelling causes self-mulching, where the soil material consistently mixes itself, causing vertisols to have an extremely deep A horizon and no B horizon.

classDefinition: Solonetz are soils with a dense, strongly structured, clayey subsurface horizon that has a high proportion of adsorbed Na and/or Mg ions. Solonetz that contain free soda (Na2CO3) are strongly alkaline (field pH > 8.5).

classDefinition: Regosols form a taxonomic remnant group containing all soils that could not be accommodated in any of the other RSGs. In practice, Regosols are very weakly developed mineral soils in unconsolidated materials that do not have a mollic or umbric horizon, are not very shallow or very rich in gravels (Leptosols), sandy (Arenosols) or with fluvic materials (Fluvisols). Regosols are extensive in eroding lands, particularly in arid and semi-arid areas and in mountainous terrain.

classDefinition: Podzols are soils with a typically ash-grey upper subsurface horizon, bleached by loss of organic matter and iron oxides, on top of a dark accumulation horizon with brown, reddish or black illuviated humus and/or reddish Fe compounds. Podzols occur in humid areas in the boreal and temperate zones and locally also in the tropics.

parentDefinition: Agricultural waste is waste produced as a result of various agricultural operations. It includes manure and other wastes from farms, poultry houses and slaughterhouses; harvest waste; fertilizer run- off from fields; pesticides that enter into water, air or soils; and salt and silt drained from fields.
parentComment: As with other wastes, this is more a role than a material in itself. This should be revised.

classDefinition: Agricultural waste is waste produced as a result of various agricultural operations. It includes manure and other wastes from farms, poultry houses and slaughterhouses; harvest waste; fertilizer run- off from fields; pesticides that enter into water, air or soils; and salt and silt drained from fields.
parentDefinition: A material which is not the desired output of a process and which is typically the input of a process which removes it from its producer (e.g. a disposal process).
classComment: As with other wastes, this is more a role than a material in itself. This should be revised.

classDefinition: A peatland dominated by species of the Bryophyte Sphagnum.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem which accumulates acidic peat, a deposit of dead plant material.

classDefinition: A fluid front which is 1) thin in comparison to the fluid mass it is a part of and 2) across which a property of that fluid mass varies greatly over short vertical distance, relative to variation across the entire fluid mass.
parentDefinition: A fluid interface which separates two fluid masses with differing properties.
classComment: A similar term exists in linguistics and mathematics. An ecocline, or biological cline, is a related concept; however, may be better placed as a child of a class like "ecotone". Further, some definitions of "layer" require a layer's constiuent materials to have consistent properties, thus "cline" would not qualify as a subclass. The term "gradient" has been proposed as a more suitable superclass. Discussion in Issue #286)

classDefinition: A cline across which the chemical composition of a fluid changes rapidly.
parentDefinition: A fluid front which is 1) thin in comparison to the fluid mass it is a part of and 2) across which a property of that fluid mass varies greatly over short vertical distance, relative to variation across the entire fluid mass.
classComment: This cline is typically horizontal, with qualities varying with depth.
parentComment: A similar term exists in linguistics and mathematics. An ecocline, or biological cline, is a related concept; however, may be better placed as a child of a class like "ecotone". Further, some definitions of "layer" require a layer's constiuent materials to have consistent properties, thus "cline" would not qualify as a subclass. The term "gradient" has been proposed as a more suitable superclass. Discussion in Issue #286)

classDefinition: A nuclear power plant is a power plant which uses heat generated by a radioactive decay in a nuclear reactor to convert water into steam in order to drive turbines in electrical generators through pressure.
parentDefinition: A power plant is a building which contains one or more generators which convert mechanical energy into electrical energy through the relative motion between a magnetic field and a conductor. The energy source harnessed to turn the generator varies widely.

classDefinition: potential energy that binds nucleons to form the atomic nucleus (and nuclear reactions).
parentDefinition: Energy possessed by an object because of its position relative to other objects, stresses within itself, its electric charge, or other factors.

classDefinition: A nuclear reactor which is used as a source of power.
parentDefinition: A human construction which is used to initiate and control a fission nuclear chain reaction or nuclear fusion reactions.

classDefinition: Fluvisols accommodate genetically young, azonal soils in alluvial deposits.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
parentComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

" The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm."  Soil taxonomy, 2nd Ed., quoted in http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/edu/?cid=nrcs142p2_054280

classDefinition: Stagnosols are soils with a perched water table showing redoximorphic features caused by surface water. Stagnosols are periodically wet and mottled in the topsoil and subsoil, with or without concretions and/or bleaching.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
parentComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

" The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm."  Soil taxonomy, 2nd Ed., quoted in http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/edu/?cid=nrcs142p2_054280

classDefinition: Technosols are soils whose properties and pedogenesis are dominated by their technical origin. They contain a significant amount of artefacts (something in the soil recognizably made or extracted from the earth by humans), or are sealed by technic hard rock (material created by humans, having properties unlike natural rock). They include soils from wastes (landfills, sludge, cinders, mine spoils and ashes), pavements with their underlying unconsolidated materials, soils with geomembranes and constructed soils in human-made materials.

parentComment:
