parentDefinition: Biological waste is waste containing mostly natural organic materials (remains of plants, animal excrement, biological sludge from waste-water treatment plants and so forth).

classDefinition: A depression in the sea floor that results from the collision of continental plates; the weight of the sinking plate causes the overlying plate to stretch and thin, causing a basin in the overlying plate. Sometimes, the Earth's crust in these basins stretches so much it cracks, allowing magma through from the mantle beneath. Hence, basins often contain active volcanoes and hydrothermal vents.
parentDefinition: A structural basin is a geological depression formed by tectonic warping of previously flat lying rock strata.

classDefinition: Hay is grass, legumes or other herbaceous plants that have been cut, dried, and stored for use as animal fodder, particularly for grazing livestock such as cattle, horses, goats, and sheep.
parentComment: This is quite odd and it probably should be obsoleted. Any material that is a participant in an agricultural process can be seen as an agricultural material.

parentDefinition: Anthropogenic material in or on which organisms may live.
classComment: This is quite odd and it probably should be obsoleted. Any material that is a participant in an agricultural process can be seen as an agricultural material.

classDefinition: A natural building material mode from sand, clay, water, and some kind of fibrous or organic material (sticks, straw, and/or manure).
parentDefinition: Anthropogenic material in or on which organisms may live.

classDefinition: A natural building material mode from sand, clay, water, and some kind of fibrous or organic material (sticks, straw, and/or manure).
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: A natural building material mode from sand, clay, water, and some kind of fibrous or organic material (sticks, straw, and/or manure).
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: The biomass remaining after sugarcane stalks are crushed to extract their juice.
parentDefinition: A material which is not the desired output of a process and which is typically the input of a process which removes it from its producer (e.g. a disposal process).

classDefinition: Biological waste is waste containing mostly natural organic materials (remains of plants, animal excrement, biological sludge from waste-water treatment plants and so forth).
parentDefinition: A material which is not the desired output of a process and which is typically the input of a process which removes it from its producer (e.g. a disposal process).

classDefinition: A manufactuered product which is capable of removing heat and controlling the humidity of the air within a site.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: Soil which has elevated concentrations of oil.
parentDefinition: A portion of contaminated soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of some contaminant.
parentComment: "contaminant" is more of a disposition - any material entity can be a contaminant in particular circumstances.

parentDefinition: A seep is a spring in which water has filtered through permeable earth to the surface.

classDefinition: A seep is a spring in which water has filtered through permeable earth to the surface.
parentDefinition: A surface landform which provides an egress for groundwater or steam to flow out of the ground.
parentComment: Springs are typically where an aquifer surface meets the ground surface or where there is a fissure.

classDefinition: A particle which 1) is composed primarily of hydrous aluminium phyllosilicate minerals, in turn composed of aluminium and silicon ions bonded into tiny, thin plates by interconnecting oxygen and hydroxide ions, and 2) is or was part of a portion of clay.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is either 1) a minute fragment of a larger mass or 2) one of a collection of small masses composing an aggregate.
classComment: The distinction between silt and clay varies by discipline. Geologists and soil scientists usually consider the separation to occur at a particle size of 2 μm (clays being finer than silts), sedimentologists often use 4–5 μm, and colloid chemists use 1 μm. Geotechnical engineers distinguish between silts and clays based on the plasticity properties of the soil, as measured by the soils' Atterberg limits. ISO 14688 grades clay particles as being smaller than 2 μm and silt particles as being larger. Mixtures of sand, silt and less than 40% clay are called loam.

classDefinition: A composition quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's containing granules.
parentDefinition: A single physical entity inhering in an bearer by virtue of the bearer's quantities or relative ratios of subparts.

classDefinition: An oil which 1) is liquid at room temperature (approximately 20 degrees Celsius) 2) is intended to be burned in a furnace or boiler for the generation of heat or used in an engine for the generation of power, 3) is obtained from petroleum distillation, either as a distillate or a residue, 4) composed of long hydrocarbon chains, particularly alkanes, cycloalkanes and aromatics.
parentDefinition: A nonpolar, hydrophobic, and lipophilic material which is a viscous liquid at ambient temperatures (about 20 degrees Celsius) or slightly warmer.
classComment: Oils having a flash point of approximately 42 degrees Celsius and oils burned in cotton or wool-wick burners are not typically considered fuel oils. The term fuel oil is also used in a stricter sense to refer only to the heaviest commercial fuel that can be obtained from crude oil, i.e., heavier than gasoline and naphtha.

parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's lacking affinity for water; tending to repel and not absorb water; tending not to dissolve in or mix with or be wetted by water.
parentDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue the bearer's disposition to being water-repellent; tending to repel and not absorb water.

classDefinition: A fermented, high-moisture forage that can be fed to ruminants.
parentComment: This is quite odd and it probably should be obsoleted. Any material that is a participant in an agricultural process can be seen as an agricultural material.

classDefinition: Manure which is derived from the waste products of animals.
parentDefinition: An environmental material consisting of organic matter from plants and/or animals that is used in agriculture as fertilizer.
classComment: This is interesting in that the "role" aspect of "waste" is (or can be) replaced by another role "fertilizer". Thus, the positioning of "manure" under waste may not be totally correct.
parentComment: Most manure consists of animal feces; other sources include compost and green manure.

parentDefinition: Manure which is derived from the waste products of animals.
parentComment: This is interesting in that the "role" aspect of "waste" is (or can be) replaced by another role "fertilizer". Thus, the positioning of "manure" under waste may not be totally correct.

classDefinition: A compost which generally consists of a combination of wheat straw, dried blood, horse manure and ground chalk, composted together and is the residual compost waste generated by industrial mushroom production.
parentDefinition: Manure which has been derived from the aerobically decomposed remnants of organic materials.

classDefinition: A house used for sheltering non-human animals.
parentDefinition: A house is a building that provides a dwelling-place for a living entity.
classComment: While humans are animals, this class does not refer to human houses.
parentComment: The provisioning of a dwelling-place can perhaps be modelled as a role.

classDefinition: A house is a building that provides a dwelling-place for a living entity.
parentDefinition: A permanent walled and roofed construction.
classComment: The provisioning of a dwelling-place can perhaps be modelled as a role.

classDefinition: An animal house which is used to shelter cows.
parentDefinition: A house used for sheltering non-human animals.
parentComment: While humans are animals, this class does not refer to human houses.

classDefinition: An animal house which is used to house pigs.
parentDefinition: A house used for sheltering non-human animals.
parentComment: While humans are animals, this class does not refer to human houses.

classDefinition: A waste treatment plant which equipped to treat sewage such that its potential for environmental contamination is reduced.
Water saturated or nearly saturated with salt (NaCl).
parentDefinition: Water which contains a highly increased concentration of dissolved salts, surpassing the average salinity of seawater.
classComment: It is used (now less popular than historically) to preserve vegetables, fish, and meat.
parentComment: The average salinity of sea water is assumed to be around 35,000 ppm, equivalent to 35 grams of salt per one liter (or kilogram) of water.

parentDefinition: Water saturated or nearly saturated with salt (NaCl).
parentComment: It is used (now less popular than historically) to preserve vegetables, fish, and meat.

classDefinition: Drinking water is water which may be consumed by humans with no adverse effects on their health.
parentDefinition: Water which has a low concentration of dissolved solutes, particularly that of sodium chloride.
parentComment: The lower bound of solute concentration required for water to be considered freshwater is variable, but is always less than that of seawater, and often cited as less than 1 gram of solutes per 1 litre of water.

parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.
A fermented, high-moisture forage that can be fed to ruminants.

classDefinition: A planned process during which raw or recycled materials are transformed into products for use or sale using labour and machines, tools, chemical and biological processing, or formulation.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which is driven by the action of humans.
classComment: The term may refer to a range of human activity, from handicraft to high tech, but is most commonly applied to industrial production, in which raw materials are transformed into finished goods on a large scale.

classDefinition: A planned process during which raw or recycled materials are transformed into products for use or sale using labour and machines, tools, chemical and biological processing, or formulation.
parentDefinition: A process that realizes a plan which is the concretization of a plan specification.
classComment: The term may refer to a range of human activity, from handicraft to high tech, but is most commonly applied to industrial production, in which raw materials are transformed into finished goods on a large scale.

classDefinition: A function realised by an environmental material when used to bind material entities together.
classComment: This sounds more like a role than a material, per se.

parentComment: The lower bound of solute concentration required for water to be considered freshwater is variable, but is always less than that of seawater, and often cited as less than 1 gram of solutes per 1 litre of water.

parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

classDefinition: A tannery is a building in which the skins of animals are treated with chemicals to alter the structure of their constituent proteins, creating leather.
parentDefinition: An industrial building is a building within which goods are produced and, optionally, stored or within which services are rendered.
parentComment: It's possible that this will become an inferred class in the future. The United Nations' International Standard Industrial Classification should be referred to when expanding this branch. ISIC can also be used to identify processes. See http://unstats.un.org/unsd/cr/registry/regcst.asp?Cl=27&Lg=1.

parentDefinition: Manure which is derived from the waste products of animals.
parentComment: This is interesting in that the "role" aspect of "waste" is (or can be) replaced by another role "fertilizer". Thus, the positioning of "manure" under waste may not be totally correct.

classDefinition: Manure which is primarily composed of pig feces.
parentDefinition: Manure which is derived from the waste products of animals.
parentComment: This is interesting in that the "role" aspect of "waste" is (or can be) replaced by another role "fertilizer". Thus, the positioning of "manure" under waste may not be totally correct.

classLabel: usage of an environment for industry
classDefinition: A planned environmental usage process during which an environment supports manufacturing facilities producing commodities that are sold with the expectation of recovering the total cost of production.
parentDefinition: A planned process during which humans access and obtain resources, benefits, or services from a natural or anthropised ecosystem.
classComment: This class includes environments used to support the facilities engaged with a broad variety of manufacturing activities from food and tobacco, to textiles, metals, vehicles, and chemicals.

classDefinition: A dairy is a building in which animal milk is harvested and, optionally, processed for human consumption.
parentDefinition: An industrial building is a building within which goods are produced and, optionally, stored or within which services are rendered.
classComment: 'Terminology differs between countries. For example, in the United States, the entire dairy farm is commonly called a "dairy." The building or farm area where milk is harvested from the cow is often called a "milking parlor" or "parlor." The farm area where milk is stored in bulk tanks is known as the farm's "milk house." Milk is then hauled (usually by truck) to a "dairy plant," also referred to as a "dairy", where raw milk is further processed and prepared for commercial sale of dairy products. In New Zealand, farm areas for milk harvesting are also called "milking parlours", and are historically known as "milking sheds."' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dairy
parentComment: It's possible that this will become an inferred class in the future. The United Nations' International Standard Industrial Classification should be referred to when expanding this branch. ISIC can also be used to identify processes. See http://unstats.un.org/unsd/cr/registry/regcst.asp?Cl=27&Lg=1.

classDefinition: A food processing building is a building in which materials that contain or consist of essential body nutrients - such as carbohydrates, fats, proteins, vitamins, or minerals - and may be ingested and assimilated by an organism to produce energy, stimulate growth, and maintain life are converted alternative forms.
parentDefinition: An industrial building is a building within which goods are produced and, optionally, stored or within which services are rendered.
classComment: The semantics of food are being handled by FOODON http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/foodon.owl
parentComment: It's possible that this will become an inferred class in the future. The United Nations' International Standard Industrial Classification should be referred to when expanding this branch. ISIC can also be used to identify processes. See http://unstats.un.org/unsd/cr/registry/regcst.asp?Cl=27&Lg=1.

classDefinition: A bakery is a building in which raw flour-based food is baked in an oven to produce food products such as bread, cakes, pastries, and pies. These products are often sold from the bakery itself.
parentDefinition: An industrial building is a building within which goods are produced and, optionally, stored or within which services are rendered.
classComment: A bakery is a food processing building and a 'food shop' at the same time. This needs to be resolved.
parentComment: It's possible that this will become an inferred class in the future. The United Nations' International Standard Industrial Classification should be referred to when expanding this branch. ISIC can also be used to identify processes. See http://unstats.un.org/unsd/cr/registry/regcst.asp?Cl=27&Lg=1.

classDefinition: An agricultural byproduct, the dry stalk of a cereal plant, after the nutrient grain or seed has been removed.
parentComment: This is quite odd and it probably should be obsoleted. Any material that is a participant in an agricultural process can be seen as an agricultural material.

parentDefinition: An agricultural byproduct, the dry stalk of a cereal plant, after the nutrient grain or seed has been removed.
Manure which is derived from the waste products of animals.
parentComment: This is interesting in that the "role" aspect of "waste" is (or can be) replaced by another role "fertilizer". Thus, the positioning of "manure" under waste may not be totally correct.

classDefinition: A brewery is a building in which alcoholic beverages are produced by brewing, that is, steeping a starch source (commonly cereal grains) in water and fermenting the resulting sweet liquid with yeast. At times, the products are also sold from the brewery.
parentDefinition: An industrial building is a building within which goods are produced and, optionally, stored or within which services are rendered.

classDefinition: A manufactured product which has been formulated to modifying the appearance of external human anatomical parts.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A cosmetic product which has been formulated 2) to have a viscous, fatty, liquid consistency resembling the fat-rich component of milk and 2) to be applied to human facial skin to modify its appearance or functioning.
parentDefinition: A manufactured product which has been formulated to modifying the appearance of external human anatomical parts.

classDefinition: A product which is composed primarily of paper.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A paper product which is used as legal tender in economic or other monetary trasactions.
parentDefinition: A product which is composed primarily of paper.
A nonpolar, hydrophobic, and lipophilic material which is a viscous liquid at ambient temperatures (about 20 degrees Celsius) or slightly warmer.

classDefinition: A sake brewery is a brewery which produces rice wine by fermenting rice which has been polished to remove the bran.
parentDefinition: A brewery is a building in which alcoholic beverages are produced by brewing, that is, steeping a starch source (commonly cereal grains) in water and fermenting the resulting sweet liquid with yeast. At times, the products are also sold from the brewery.

classDefinition: Soil which has increased levels of chalk.
parentDefinition: A portion of enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of some material entity.
parentComment: This could be demoted to an inferred class if issues with double inheritance arise.

classDefinition: A building or collection of co-located buildings constructed for the purpose of undertaking scientific research.
parentDefinition: A facility, permanent or temporary, on land, in air, space or water, where scientific research or measurements can be undertaken.
Manure which is derived from the waste products of animals.
parentComment: This is interesting in that the "role" aspect of "waste" is (or can be) replaced by another role "fertilizer". Thus, the positioning of "manure" under waste may not be totally correct.

classDefinition: A layer of impurities that accumulates at the surface of a liquid (especially water or molten metal).

classDefinition: A warehouse is a building which is used for the storage of goods.
parentDefinition: A building which is primarily used to facilitate the buying or selling of goods or services.
parentComment: "Commerce includes legal, economic, political, social, cultural and technological systems that are in operation in any country or internationally."

classDefinition: A tobacco warehouse is a warehouse used to store cured leaves of plants from the genus Nicotiana, primarily  N. tabacum and N. rustica.
parentDefinition: A warehouse is a building which is used for the storage of goods.

classDefinition: A creamery is a part of a dairy where cream is separated from whole milk.
parentDefinition: A building part is a construction which is part of a building.
parentComment: Not recommended for annotation. This class is likely to be made into an inferred class as its subclasses are distributed among more meaningful superclasses (i.e. ceiling is_a surface layer). See for example, "building floor". The boundaries between building parts may be bona fide or fiat.

classDefinition: An air filter is a device that removes some substance from air.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.
classComment: This is a general definition derived from the definitions for particulate, chemical, and other air filters. Subclasses should be created if needed.

parentDefinition: A fermented, high-moisture forage that can be fed to ruminants.

classDefinition: Limestone which is deposited from the water of mineral springs or streams saturated with calcium carbonate.
parentDefinition: A sedimentary rock which is composed primarily of calcium carbonate in the form of calcite or aragnoite.

classDefinition: A building within which logs are cut into lumber products.
parentDefinition: An industrial building is a building within which goods are produced and, optionally, stored or within which services are rendered.
parentComment: It's possible that this will become an inferred class in the future. The United Nations' International Standard Industrial Classification should be referred to when expanding this branch. ISIC can also be used to identify processes. See http://unstats.un.org/unsd/cr/registry/regcst.asp?Cl=27&Lg=1.

classDefinition: A process during which wood is processed into beams or planks.
parentDefinition: A manufacturing process which occurs on a planet.
parentComment: See https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/issues/513 for discussion.

classDefinition: A large flat plain in karst territory with areas usually 5 to 400 sqaure kilometres.
parentDefinition: A region of general uniform slope, comparatively level, and of considerable extent.

classDefinition: An environmental material which has the quality of a foam.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: An environmental material which has the quality of a foam.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: A foamy environmental material which 1) is created by the agitation of seawater, 2) whose stability depends on the content of the seawater.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which has the quality of a foam.
classComment: The lifetime of sea foam can vary from only seconds to several hours or days. The longer-lasting foam are formed in particular when seawater contain higher concentration of dissolved organic matter that derived from sources such as algal blooms.

classDefinition: Soil which is part of a paddy field.
parentDefinition: Soil which is part of an ecosystem used for agricultural activities.

classDefinition: Soil which is part of a paddy field.
parentDefinition: Soil which is part of an agricultural field.

classDefinition: Soil which is part of an agricultural field.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
parentComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

" The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm."  Soil taxonomy, 2nd Ed., quoted in http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/edu/?cid=nrcs142p2_054280

classDefinition: Soil which is part of an alpine environment.

classDefinition: An altitudinal condition which inheres in a bearer by virtue of the bearer having a monthly mean temperature is less than 10 degrees Celsius and being located at altitudes above the tree line and below the snowline.
parentDefinition: An altitudinal condition is an environmental condition in which ranges of factors such as temperature, humidity, soil composition, solar irradiation, and tree density vary with ranges in altitude.
classComment: Requested term with preliminary def. See Issue 29 on the envo tracker.
parentComment: Depending on the latitude (and, to a lesser extent, other factors), the actual location of the zones where these conditions are in effect will change.

classDefinition: Soil which has been amended with mineral additives to increase its pH.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
classComment:
Common liming agents include calcium- and magnesium-rich materials in various forms, including marl, chalk, limestone, burnt lime or hydrated lime. Liming often improves plant growth and increases the activity of soil bacteria, but oversupply may result in harm to plant life.
Liming can also improve aggregate stability on clay soils. For this purpose structure lime, products containing calcium oxide (CaO) or hydroxide (Ca(OH)2) in mixes with calcium carbonate (CaCO3), are often used. Structure liming can reduce losses of clay and nutrients from soil aggregates.
parentComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm."  Soil taxonomy, 2nd Ed., quoted in http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/edu/?cid=nrcs142p2_054280

classDefinition: The elimination by an organism of the waste products that arise as a result of metabolic activity. These products include water, carbon dioxide (CO2), and nitrogenous compounds.
parentDefinition: A multicellular organismal process carried out by any of the organs or tissues in an organ system. An organ system is a regularly interacting or interdependent group of organs or tissues that work together to carry out a biological objective.

classDefinition: Soil which is part of a woodland dominated by leafy trees.
parentDefinition: A portion of soil which is found in a forested area.

classDefinition: Soil which is part of a forest whose communites of arborescent plants are dominated the genus Picea.
parentDefinition: A portion of soil which is found in a forested area.

classDefinition: Soil which is part of a forest whose communites of arborescent plants are dominated the genus Eucalyptus.
parentDefinition: A portion of soil which is found in a forested area.
Soil which is part of an ecosystem used for agricultural activities.
classComment: Soil which is part of a rubber plantation.

parentDefinition: A portion of soil which is part of a cropland or a rangeland biome.
classComment: Soil which is part of a rubber plantation.

classDefinition: Bluegrass field soil is a soil which is found in a field of Kentucky Bluegrass (Poa pratensis).
parentDefinition: Soil which is part of an ecosystem used for agricultural activities.

classDefinition: Soil which has 1) low concentrations of nutrients and humus, 2) low water retention capacity, 3) textural variation from sand to clay, 4) a porous and friable structure, and 5) low concentrations of soluble salts.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
classComment:
Red soil typically derives from crystalline rock in warm, temperate, moist climates under deciduous or mixed forest. It has thin organic and organic-mineral layers, a black brown leached layer resting on an illuvium red layer. The majority of red soils have a loamy texture. Their chemical composition varies across regions, but often includes non-soluble material 90.47%, iron 3.61%, aluminium 2.92%, organic matter 1.01%, magnesium 0.70%, lime 0.56%, carbon dioxide 0.30%, potash 0.24%, soda 0.12%, phosphorus 0.09% and nitrogen 0.08%. 

On the uplands, they are thin, poor and gravelly, sandy, or stony and porous, light-colored soils on which food crops like bajra can be grown. In contrast, on the lower plains and valleys they are rich, deep, dark colored fertile loam on which, under irrigation, can produce excellent crops like cotton, wheat, pulses, tobacco, jowar, linseed, millet, potatoes and fruits.
parentComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm."  Soil taxonomy, 2nd Ed., quoted in http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/edu/?cid=nrcs142p2_054280

classDefinition: Sterile water is water which does not contain lliving organisms.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

classDefinition: Water which has physicochemical properties determined by processes which occur beneath the planetary crust.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.
classComment: This class references any water that's under a planetary surface. For water that is in an aquifer, see "groundwater" (ENVO:01001004). Previously, this class included both.

parentLabel: subsurface zone of an astronomical body
classDefinition: Regions of a planet which are not exposed to the planet's atmosphere or space, often comprising parts of one or more planetary structural layers.
parentDefinition: An environmental zone which includes those regions of an astronomical body which are not exposed to its atmosphere or space.
An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.
A layer of impurities that accumulates at the surface of a liquid (especially water or molten metal).

classDefinition: Mud which is part of a marine ecosystem.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: Mud which is part of a marine ecosystem.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is a liquid or semi-liquid mixture of water and some combination of soil, silt, and clay particles.
The residual semi-solid material left from domestic or industrial processes, or wastewater treatment processes.

classDefinition: Mud which constitutes the bed of a lake.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. classDefinition: Mud which constitutes the bed of a lake.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is a liquid or semi-liquid mixture of water and some combination of soil, silt, and clay particles.

classDefinition: A landform which has been rendered barren or partially barren by environmental extremes, especially by low rainfall, and which loses more liquid water by evapotranspiration than is supplied by precipitation.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: The narrow region of soil that is directly influenced by root secretions and associated soil microorganisms.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: The narrow region of soil that is directly influenced by root secretions and associated soil microorganisms.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classDefinition: An ecological community which is composed of co-existing populations of microbial organisms that interact, directly or indirectly, such that they impact one another's ecological fitness.
parentDefinition: A multi-species collection of organisms of at least two different species, living in a particular area. Must have at least two populations of different species as members.
classComment: The definition of a microbial species is deeply debated, however, units of phylogenetic and functional diversity are recognised with respect to their varying roles in an ecosystem. In turn, there exist multiple operational definitions of microbial community, such as local, phenomenological, and indexical communities. This class seeks to capture microbial communities in a very broad sense, as collections of phylogenetically and functionally divergent microbial organisms co-existing, potentially interacting, and competing for niche space in the same ecosystem over a period of time in which their causal footprints overlap one another.
parentComment: Ecological community is defined broadly here, but includes both ecological interactions (inherited from parent term community) and spatial co-existence. It may be used to describe every organisms living in an area, but is often used to refer only to organisms of a particular taxon or guild (e.g., the plant community, the insect community, the herbivore community). The word community, as it often used to describe a group of humans living together, is a type of single-species collection of organisms, not an ecological community.

classDefinition: An ecological community which is composed of co-existing populations of microbial organisms that interact, directly or indirectly, such that they impact one another's ecological fitness.
parentDefinition: A multi-species collection of organisms that consists of two or more microbes from at least two species.
classComment: The definition of a microbial species is deeply debated, however, units of phylogenetic and functional diversity are recognised with respect to their varying roles in an ecosystem. In turn, there exist multiple operational definitions of microbial community, such as local, phenomenological, and indexical communities. This class seeks to capture microbial communities in a very broad sense, as collections of phylogenetically and functionally divergent microbial organisms co-existing, potentially interacting, and competing for niche space in the same ecosystem over a period of time in which their causal footprints overlap one another.

classDefinition: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces root meristems (PO:0006085), the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them and the parts thereof.
parentDefinition: A collective plant structure (PO:0025497) that is a proper part of a whole plant (PO:0000003), and is composed of two or more adjacent plant organs (PO:0009008) and the associated portions of plant tissue (PO:0009007).
classComment: Generally the below ground portion of a vascular plant.
parentComment: Organs can be of the same type or different types. Examples include flower (PO:0009046), perianth (PO:0009058), and inflorescence (PO:0009049). See also collective organ part structure (PO:0025269), for plant structures composed of parts of multiple organs, but no complete plant organs. This was formerly named collective plant structure.

classDefinition: Soil that is not penetrated by the root systems of plants.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
parentComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil
