classDefinition: An aquatic environment which is the part of a sea, lake, or river that is close to the shore.
parentDefinition: An environment whose dynamics are strongly influenced by water.
classComment: The adjacency of water has many consequences including the generation of microclimates and impacts on the biology. This class is intended to capture littoral zones that are associated with marine, freshwater, and any other aquatic environments. Note that there is no single definition of the extent of the "littoral zone", associated with any water body. Here, we use definitions that will be more familiar to marine biologists rather than military organisations, although the latter can be added on request. This class will likely be superceded by a CMECs compliant class.

classDefinition: The marine sublittoral zone is part of the marine littoral zone which is permanently covered by seawater. In physical oceanography, the sublittoral zone refers to coastal regions with significant tidal flows and energy dissipation, including non-linear flows, internal waves, river outflows and oceanic fronts. In practice, this typically extends to the edge of the continental shelf, with depths around 200 meters. In marine biology, the sublittoral refers to the areas where sunlight reaches the ocean floor, that is, where the water is never so deep as to take it out of the photic zone.
parentDefinition: An astronomical body part which is part of a marine environment.
parentComment: This class will eventually be populated by inference alone, with its subclasses distributed in more process-linked hierarchies to improve semantic density.

classDefinition: A marine benthic biome which is determined by a cold seep.
parentDefinition: The marine benthic biome (benthic meaning 'bottom') encompasses the seafloor and includes such areas as shores, littoral or intertidal areas, marine coral reefs, and the deep seabed.
classComment: The marine cold seep biome comprises regions of the marine benthic biome where seepage of methane, hydrogen sulphide, hydrocarbon rich fluids and other fluids occurs.

classDefinition:
MERGED DEFINITION:
TARGET DEFINITION: A cold seep is a seep in which methane and other hydrocarbon-rich fluids rise to the sea floor.
--------------------
SOURCE DEFINITION: An area of the ocean floor where hydrogen sulfide, methane and other hydrocarbon-rich fluid seepage occurs. Cold seeps are distinct from hydrothermal vents: the former's emissions are of the same temperature as the surrounding seawater, whereas the latter's emissions are super-heated.
parentDefinition: A seep is a spring in which water has filtered through permeable earth to the surface.

classDefinition: The dilution basin mediterranean sea biome comprises expressions of the mediterranean sea biome with lower salinity than the surrounding ocean due to freshwater gains such as rainfall and rivers. Water exchange consists of outflow of the fresher mediterranean water in the upper layer and inflow of the saltier oceanic water in the lower layer of the channel. Renewal of deep water may not be sufficient to supply oxygen to the bottom.
parentDefinition: The mediterranean sea biome comprises mostly enclosed seas that have limited exchange of deep water with outer oceans and where the water circulation is dominated by salinity and temperature differences rather than winds.

classDefinition: A column of solid material which has been progressively deposited around a hydrothermal vent.
parentDefinition: A landform which is submerged underneath a body of liquid.

classDefinition: A landform which is submerged underneath a body of liquid.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which has been formed from and is composed primarily of the matter of that astronomical body.
parentComment: Landforms may be natural or anthropogenic. This term has often has loose usage when referencing entities which are either subterranean or submerged below water bodies. In some cases, oceans themselves are considered landforms. Here, we have provided subclasses to resolve this ambiguity, but place oceans and other water bodies elsewhere.In later revisions, this hiearchy is likely to be reordered based on the formation processes of the entities within it.

classDefinition: A marine hydrothermal vent plume, part of a marine hydrothermal vent, is a high temperature water jet laden with dissolved metals and minerals that is driven by heat generated due to tectonic activity below the vent.
parentDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous volume of liquid water and is held in shape or sustained by an environmental process.
parentComment: Similar, in spirit, to landform.

classDefinition: Sediment characterised by a temperature of 15-45 degrees Celsius and high-to-low oxygenation. Often impacted by hydrothermal fluid flows.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is formed as a result of the transport and deposition of particles by flowing liquid.
parentComment: Sediment is typically deposited on the bed or bottom of a body of water or other liquid.

classDefinition: Sediment characterised by a temperature of 45-75 degrees Celsius and low to no oxygen content. Often impacted by hydrothermal fluid flows.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is formed as a result of the transport and deposition of particles by flowing liquid.
parentComment: Sediment is typically deposited on the bed or bottom of a body of water or other liquid.

classDefinition: Sediment characterised by a temperature of 80-125 degrees Celsius and no oxygen content. Often impacted by hydrothermal fluid flows.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is formed as a result of the transport and deposition of particles by flowing liquid.
parentComment: Sediment is typically deposited on the bed or bottom of a body of water or other liquid.

classDefinition: High temperature water ejected from hydrothermal vents and laden with dissolved metals and minerals as a result of percolation through crustal rocks.
parentDefinition: The liquid produced when water percolates through any permeable material. It can contain either dissolved or suspended material, or usually both.

classDefinition: Sediment hosting and characterised by active nitrate reducing microbial communities.
parentDefinition: Sediment characterised by the absence of oxygen.

classDefinition: A piece of rock which fell vertically through the water column into finer-grained water-deposited sedimentary rocks.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.
classComment: Drop stones range in size from small pebbles to boulders.

classDefinition: A piece of rock which fell vertically through the water column into finer-grained water-deposited sedimentary rocks.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is composed primarily of rock.
classComment: Drop stones range in size from small pebbles to boulders.

classDefinition: An accumulation of organic matter that has fallen to the bottom of a body of water.
The carcass of an animal that has fallen to the bottom of a body of water.
parentDefinition: The dead body of an animal.

classDefinition: Whale fall is the term used for a whale carcass that has fallen to the ocean floor. When a whale dies in shallow water, its carcass is typically devoured by scavengers over a relatively short period of time: within several months. However, in deeper water (depths of 2,000 m/6,600 ft or greater), fewer scavenger species exist, and the carcass can provide sustenance for a complex localized ecosystem over periods of decades.
parentDefinition: The carcass of an animal that has fallen to the bottom of a body of water.

classDefinition: Seal fall is the term used for a seal carcass that has fallen to the ocean floor.
parentDefinition: The carcass of an animal that has fallen to the bottom of a body of water.

classDefinition: A wood fall describes an accumulation of woody plant material that has fallen to the ocean floor.
parentDefinition: A accumulation of plant matter that has fallen to the bottom of a body of water.
A reef which is located in a marine water body.
A reef which is located in a marine water body.
A reef which is located in a marine water body.
A reef which is located in a marine water body.
A reef which is located in a marine water body.

classLabel: marine coral reef deep fore reef
parentDefinition: A reef which is located in a marine water body.

classDefinition: A rocky reef which is located in the subtidal zone of a marine water body.
parentDefinition: A ridge of rocks, lying near the surface of the sea, which may be visible at low tide, but is usually covered by water.

classDefinition: A rocky reef which is located in the subtidal zone of a marine water body.
parentDefinition: A reef which is located in a marine water body.

classDefinition: Sediment hosting and characterised by active manganese reducing microbial communities.
parentDefinition: Sediment characterised by the absence of oxygen.

classDefinition: Sediment hosting and characterised by active iron reducing microbial communities.
parentDefinition: Sediment characterised by the absence of oxygen.

classDefinition: Sediment hosting and characterised by active sulphate reducing microbial communities.
parentDefinition: Sediment characterised by the absence of oxygen.

classDefinition: Sediment hosting and characterised by active carbon dioxide reducing microbial communities.
parentDefinition: Sediment characterised by the absence of oxygen.

classDefinition: Material derived from a biofilm, an aggregate of microorganisms in which cells adhere to each other and/or to a surface. These adherent cells are frequently embedded within a self-produced matrix of extracellular polymeric substance (EPS). Biofilm EPS, which is also referred to as slime, is a polymeric conglomeration generally composed of extracellular DNA, proteins, and polysaccharides in various configurations.
parentDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.

classDefinition: Material derived from a microbial mat, a multi-layered sheet of micro-organisms, mainly bacteria and archaea. Microbial mats create a wide range of internal chemical environments.
parentDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.

classDefinition: Marine snow is a continuous shower of mostly organic detritus falling from the upper layers of the water column. Its origin lies in activities within the productive photic zone.
parentDefinition: An organic material which is primarily composed of dead particulate matter.

classDefinition: An organic material which is primarily composed of dead particulate matter.
parentDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.

classDefinition: Pockmarks are craters in the seabed resulting from the release of gas or liquid. Generally, they are formed in soft, fine-grained seabed sediments by the escape of fluids (gas or water, but mainly methane) into the water column.
parentDefinition: A generally circular saucer or bowl-shaped depression caused by explosive action.

classDefinition: A marine sponge reef is marine reefs primarily built by marine sponges. The primary frame-building sponges are all members of the order Hexactinosa. They are found only in glacier-scoured troughs of low-angle continental shelf. The seafloor is stable and consists of rock, coarse gravel, and large boulders.
parentDefinition: A reef which is located in a marine water body.

classDefinition: A collection of tissues joined in structural unit to serve a common function.
parentDefinition: An object which is formed as a result of one or more biological processes and is composed primarily of organic material.

classDefinition: A photophore is a light-emitting organ which appears as luminous spots on various marine animals, including fish and cephalopods. The organ can be simple, or as complex as the human eye; equipped with lenses, shutters, color filters and reflectors. The light can be produced from compounds during the digestion of prey, from specialized mitochondrial cells in the organism, called photocytes ("light producing" cells) , or, similarly, associated with symbiotic  bacteria in the organism.
parentDefinition: A collection of tissues joined in structural unit to serve a common function.

classDefinition: Root nodules occur on the roots of plants that associate with symbiotic nitrogen-fixing bacteria.
parentDefinition: A collection of tissues joined in structural unit to serve a common function.

classDefinition: A specialised organ found in deep-sea tube worms populating hydrothermal vent environments that is colonised by chemosynthetic bacteria which supply the host worm with organic compounds. The term may be applied to similar organs in other worms.
parentDefinition: A collection of tissues joined in structural unit to serve a common function.

classDefinition: A specialized organ that is linked to the gut in beetles and host to a symbiotic yeast. The yeast cells assist in the digestion of less nutritious foods, supply needed B-vitamins and sterols, and provide resistance to certain toxins.
parentDefinition: A collection of tissues joined in structural unit to serve a common function.

classDefinition: Determinate nodules are root nodules found on tropical (sub)legumes, such as those of the genera Glycine (soybean), Phaseolus  (common bean), Lotus, and Vigna. Determinate nodules lose meristematic activity shortly after initiation, thus growth is due to cell expansion resulting in mature nodules which are spherical in shape.
parentDefinition: Root nodules occur on the roots of plants that associate with symbiotic nitrogen-fixing bacteria.

classDefinition: Indeterminate nodules are found on temperate legumes like Pisum  (pea), Medicago (alfalfa), Trifolium (clover), and Vicia (vetch). They earned the moniker "indeterminate" because they maintain an active apical meristem that produces new cells for growth over the life of the nodule. Because they are actively growing, indeterminate nodules manifest zones which demarcate different stages of development/symbiosis.
parentDefinition: Root nodules occur on the roots of plants that associate with symbiotic nitrogen-fixing bacteria.

classDefinition: A part of an indeterminate root nodule where new nodule tissue is formed which will later differentiate into the other zones of the nodule.
parentDefinition: Indeterminate nodules are found on temperate legumes like Pisum  (pea), Medicago (alfalfa), Trifolium (clover), and Vicia (vetch). They earned the moniker "indeterminate" because they maintain an active apical meristem that produces new cells for growth over the life of the nodule. Because they are actively growing, indeterminate nodules manifest zones which demarcate different stages of development/symbiosis.

classDefinition: A part of an indeterminate root nodule permeated with infection threads full of bacteria. The plant cells are larger than in the previous zone and cell division is halted.
parentDefinition: Indeterminate nodules are found on temperate legumes like Pisum  (pea), Medicago (alfalfa), Trifolium (clover), and Vicia (vetch). They earned the moniker "indeterminate" because they maintain an active apical meristem that produces new cells for growth over the life of the nodule. Because they are actively growing, indeterminate nodules manifest zones which demarcate different stages of development/symbiosis.

classLabel: indeterminate root nodule nitrogen fixation zone
classDefinition: A part of an indeterminate root nodule where each cell contains a large, central vacuole and the cytoplasm is filled with fully differentiated bacteroids which are actively fixing nitrogen. Typically, the plant provides these cells with leghemoglobin, resulting in a distinct pink color.
parentDefinition: Indeterminate nodules are found on temperate legumes like Pisum  (pea), Medicago (alfalfa), Trifolium (clover), and Vicia (vetch). They earned the moniker "indeterminate" because they maintain an active apical meristem that produces new cells for growth over the life of the nodule. Because they are actively growing, indeterminate nodules manifest zones which demarcate different stages of development/symbiosis.

classDefinition: A part of an indeterminate root nodule where plant cells and their bacteroid contents are being degraded. The breakdown of the heme component of leghemoglobin results in a visible greening at the base of the nodule.
parentDefinition: Indeterminate nodules are found on temperate legumes like Pisum  (pea), Medicago (alfalfa), Trifolium (clover), and Vicia (vetch). They earned the moniker "indeterminate" because they maintain an active apical meristem that produces new cells for growth over the life of the nodule. Because they are actively growing, indeterminate nodules manifest zones which demarcate different stages of development/symbiosis.

classDefinition: Water which lacks dissolved oxygen.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

classDefinition: A forest ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which is determined by communities of plants with a tree growth form and in which members of those communities form continuous or discontinuous regions of canopy cover.
parentComment: The definitions of forest can vary greatly, and different classes will be needed to support the major categories. Tree cover alone is not enough to distinguish between forests and plantations. The international definition proposed by the 2010 FAO Forestry Resource Assessment: "land spanning more than 0.5 ha with trees higher than 5 metres and canopy cover of more than 10 percent, or trees able to reach these thresholds in situ . It does not include land that is predominantly under agricultural or urban land use." - FAO.  2010. Global forest resources assessment 2010, Main report, FAO Forestry Paper 163. Rome.

classDefinition: A forest ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentDefinition: A biome which is  primarily or completely situated on a landmass.

classDefinition: A woodland biome is a terrestrial biome which includes, across its entire spatial extent, woody plants spaced sufficiently far apart to allow light penetration to support communities of herbaceous plants or shrubs living closer to the woodland floor.
parentDefinition: A biome which is  primarily or completely situated on a landmass.
classComment: Preliminary definition.

classDefinition: A shrubland biome is a terrestrial biome which includes, across its entire spatial extent, dense groups of shrubs.
parentDefinition: A biome which is  primarily or completely situated on a landmass.
classComment: Preliminary definition.

classDefinition: A grassland ecosystem in which dominant ecological communities have reached their climax successional state.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem in which grasses (Graminae) are the dominant form of vegetation and determine the system's structure and dynamics.

classDefinition: A grassland ecosystem in which dominant ecological communities have reached their climax successional state.
parentDefinition: A biome which is  primarily or completely situated on a landmass.

classDefinition: A woodland biome which has seasonal water availability and includes trees spaced sufficiently far apart to allow an unbroken layer of grass, sedge (Cyperaceae) or  rush (Juncaceae) communities to live.
parentDefinition: A woodland biome is a terrestrial biome which includes, across its entire spatial extent, woody plants spaced sufficiently far apart to allow light penetration to support communities of herbaceous plants or shrubs living closer to the woodland floor.
parentComment: Preliminary definition.

classDefinition: A desert ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentDefinition: A biome is an ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentComment: In this definition, there is an assumption that no major perturbations are occurring or have occurred in a time frame affects the successional dynamics of the ecosystem. A "major" perturbation is one which disrupts the community's ability to restore its (near) equilibrium. Usually, pioneer or early secondary successional processes would be in effect in such scenarios.

classDefinition: A desert ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem in which the composition, structure, and function of resident ecological assemblages are primarily determined by a desert.

classDefinition: An ecosystem in which the composition, structure, and function of resident ecological assemblages are primarily determined by a desert.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: An ecosystem in which the composition, structure, and function of resident ecological assemblages are primarily determined by a desert.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classDefinition: A mangrove biome is a terrestrial biome which includes, across its spatial extent, mangrove plants (Rhizophoraceae). Mangrove plants are able to withstand high levels of salinity as well as regions of anoxia and frequent tidal inundation. Mangrove biomes often occur near tropical and sub-tropical estuaries and depositional marine coastal environments where fine sediments (often with high organic content) collect in areas protected from high energy wave action.
parentDefinition: A biome which is  primarily or completely situated on a landmass.
classComment: Preliminary definition. Depending on whether mangrove trees or shrubs are present, this class could be a child of shrubland biome or woodland biome. Consider creating the appropriate classes.

classDefinition: A temperate desert biome is a desert biome which has communities adapted to intermediate insolation, low rainfall, and large temperature variations between winter and summer. Winter temperatures may fall below 0 degrees Celsius. Some precipitation in this biome may fall as snow.
parentDefinition: A desert ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
classComment: Preliminary definition. The semantics and definitions of "mediterranean", "subtropical", "tropical", "temperate", "polar", and similar climate types may be transferred to an "environmental condition" class once the semantics of this class have been established.

classDefinition: A temperate desert biome is a desert biome which has communities adapted to intermediate insolation, low rainfall, and large temperature variations between winter and summer. Winter temperatures may fall below 0 degrees Celsius. Some precipitation in this biome may fall as snow.
parentDefinition: A biome which is subject to temperate climatic conditions.
classComment: Preliminary definition. The semantics and definitions of "mediterranean", "subtropical", "tropical", "temperate", "polar", and similar climate types may be transferred to an "environmental condition" class once the semantics of this class have been established.

classDefinition: A biome which is subject to temperate climatic conditions.
parentDefinition: A biome is an ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentComment: In this definition, there is an assumption that no major perturbations are occurring or have occurred in a time frame affects the successional dynamics of the ecosystem. A "major" perturbation is one which disrupts the community's ability to restore its (near) equilibrium. Usually, pioneer or early secondary successional processes would be in effect in such scenarios.

classDefinition: A biome which is subject to temperate climatic conditions.
parentDefinition: An environment which is located in a part of an astronomical body subject to temperate climatic conditions.

classDefinition: A tropical desert biome is a desert biome which has communities adapted to temperatures above a monthly average of 18 degrees Celsius, high daily temperature ranges of approximately 20 degrees Celsius, very high insolation due to inhibited cloud formation, and very low precipitation. Tropical desert biomes located near coasts with cold upwellings may have cooler temperatures and reduced insolution due to fog.
parentDefinition: A desert ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
classComment: Preliminary definition. The semantics and definitions of "mediterranean", "subtropical", "tropical", "temperate", "polar", and similar climate types may be transferred to an "environmental condition" class once the semantics of this class have been established.

classDefinition: A tropical desert biome is a desert biome which has communities adapted to temperatures above a monthly average of 18 degrees Celsius, high daily temperature ranges of approximately 20 degrees Celsius, very high insolation due to inhibited cloud formation, and very low precipitation. Tropical desert biomes located near coasts with cold upwellings may have cooler temperatures and reduced insolution due to fog.
parentDefinition: A biome which is subject to tropical climatic conditions.
classComment: Preliminary definition. The semantics and definitions of "mediterranean", "subtropical", "tropical", "temperate", "polar", and similar climate types may be transferred to an "environmental condition" class once the semantics of this class have been established.

classDefinition: A biome which is subject to tropical climatic conditions.
parentDefinition: A biome is an ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentComment: In this definition, there is an assumption that no major perturbations are occurring or have occurred in a time frame affects the successional dynamics of the ecosystem. A "major" perturbation is one which disrupts the community's ability to restore its (near) equilibrium. Usually, pioneer or early secondary successional processes would be in effect in such scenarios.

classDefinition: A biome which is subject to tropical climatic conditions.
parentDefinition: An environment which has a climate with continually high temperatures and with considerable precipitation, at least during part of the year.

classDefinition: A subtropical desert biome is a desert biome which has communities adapted to temperatures above a monthly average of 18 degrees Celsius, high daily temperature ranges of approximately 20 degrees Celsius, high insolation (but lower than that of a tropical desert biome), inhibited cloud formation, and very low precipitation. Subtropical desert biomes located near coasts with cold upwellings may have cooler temperatures and reduced insolution due to fog.
parentDefinition: A desert ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
classComment: Preliminary definition. The semantics and definitions of "mediterranean", "subtropical", "tropical", "temperate", "polar", and similar climate types may be transferred to an "environmental condition" class once the semantics of this class have been established.

classDefinition: A subtropical desert biome is a desert biome which has communities adapted to temperatures above a monthly average of 18 degrees Celsius, high daily temperature ranges of approximately 20 degrees Celsius, high insolation (but lower than that of a tropical desert biome), inhibited cloud formation, and very low precipitation. Subtropical desert biomes located near coasts with cold upwellings may have cooler temperatures and reduced insolution due to fog.
parentDefinition: A biome which is subject to subtropical climatic conditions.
classComment: Preliminary definition. The semantics and definitions of "mediterranean", "subtropical", "tropical", "temperate", "polar", and similar climate types may be transferred to an "environmental condition" class once the semantics of this class have been established.

classDefinition: A biome which is subject to subtropical climatic conditions.

A "major" perturbation is one which disrupts the community's ability to restore its (near) equilibrium. classDefinition: A biome which is subject to subtropical climatic conditions.
parentDefinition: An environment which has a climate with warm temperatures and with meagre precipitation.

classDefinition: A montane desert biome is a desert biome which occurs in regions elevated above sea level and which has community structure determined by elevation-dependent environmental conditions.
parentDefinition: A desert ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
classComment: Preliminary definition.

classDefinition: A montane desert biome is a desert biome which occurs in regions elevated above sea level and which has community structure determined by elevation-dependent environmental conditions.
parentDefinition: A biome which is subject to montane altitudinal conditions.

classDefinition: A biome which is subject to montane altitudinal conditions.

parentComment: In this definition, there is an assumption that no major perturbations are occurring or have occurred in a time frame affects the successional dynamics of the ecosystem. A "major" perturbation is one which disrupts the community's ability to restore its (near) equilibrium. Usually, pioneer or early secondary successional processes would be in effect in such scenarios.

classDefinition: A polar desert biome is a desert biome which is subject to low levels of insolation, annual precipitation less than 250 millimeters, and a mean temperature less than 10 degrees Celsius during its warmest month. Temperature changes in polar deserts frequently cross the freezing point of water.
parentDefinition: A desert ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
classComment: Preliminary definition. The semantics and definitions of "mediterranean", "subtropical", "tropical", "temperate", "polar", and similar climate types may be transferred to an "environmental condition" class once the semantics of this class have been established.

classDefinition: A polar desert biome is a desert biome which is subject to low levels of insolation, annual precipitation less than 250 millimeters, and a mean temperature less than 10 degrees Celsius during its warmest month. parentDefinition: A biome which is subject to polar climatic conditions.

parentComment: This class is primarily for inference and, in general, should not be used directly by annotators. If you're an annotator, please consider using a more informative term such as 'tundra biome'.

parentComment: The definitions of forest can vary greatly, and different classes will be needed to support the major categories. Tree cover alone is not enough to distinguish between forests and plantations. The international definition proposed by the 2010 FAO Forestry Resource Assessment: "land spanning more than 0.5 ha with trees higher than 5 metres and canopy cover of more than 10 percent, or trees able to reach these thresholds in situ . It does not include land that is predominantly under agricultural or urban land use." - FAO.  2010. Global forest resources assessment 2010, Main report, FAO Forestry Paper 163. Rome.

classDefinition: An environmental condition is a range of a determinate quality or combination of qualities that are present in an environmental system.
parentDefinition: A quality of a physical entity that exists through action of continuants at the physical level of organisation in relation to other entities.
classComment: A condition defines a restricted range of a given quality or combination of qualities. If an environment class, E, has_condition C, then all qualities listed in C are restricted to the ranges defined in C in E. This is not intended as a logical conditional.

classDefinition: A quality of a physical entity that exists through action of continuants at the physical level of organisation in relation to other entities.

classDefinition: A temperate condition is an environmental condition in which an environmental system receives less solar irradiance than those with subpolar conditions, but greater than those with subtropical conditions.

parentDefinition: A broadleaf forest which is subject to tropical climate conditions.

classDefinition: A savanna biome which is subject to mediterranean climate patterns.
parentDefinition: A biome which is subject to mediterranean climatic conditions.

classDefinition: A savanna biome which is subject to mediterranean climate patterns.
parentDefinition: A savanna biome which is subject to subtropical climate patterns.
parentComment: Preliminary definition. The semantics and definitions of "mediterranean", "subtropical", "tropical", "temperate", "polar", and similar climate types may be transferred to an "environmental condition" class once the semantics of this class have been established.

classDefinition: An environmental material which is unable to resist shear forces and continuously deforms when subject to them.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: An environmental material which is unable to resist shear forces and continuously deforms when subject to them.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: Magma is a mixture of molten or semi-molten rock, volatiles, and solids that is found beneath the uppermost solid layer of a planetary body. Besides molten rock, magma may also contain suspended crystals, dissolved gas and sometimes gas bubbles.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is unable to resist shear forces and continuously deforms when subject to them.

classDefinition: A physical quality inhering in an entity exhibiting the physical characteristics of an amorphous (non-crystalline) form of matter between a gas and a solid that has a definite volume, but no definite shape.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of its constitution.

classDefinition: Felsic lava is lava which is high in silica (> 69 percent by weight), aluminium, potassium, sodium, and calcium, forming a polymerized liquid rich in feldspar and quartz. Felsic lava has a  higher viscosity than other magma types. Felsic magmas can erupt at temperatures as low as 650 to 750 °C. Unusually hot (>950 °C) rhyolite lavas, however, may flow for distances of many tens of kilometres
parentDefinition: Lava is a mixture of molten or semi-molten rock, volatiles, and solids which has extruded beyond a planetary crust.
parentComment: Some use 'lava' to refer to rock that is formed when lava cools. This is not the intended meaning of this class. See 'igneous rock' or similar.

classDefinition: Intermediate lava is lava which, relative to felsic lava, is lower in aluminium and silica (between 52 and 63 percent by weight), and usually somewhat richer in magnesium and iron. The temperature of intermediate lava ranges from 750 to 950 degrees Celsius, destroying polymerized bonds and promoting more fluid behaviour relative to felsic lavas and also a greater tendency to form phenocrysts. Higher iron and magnesium tends to manifest as a darker groundmass, and also occasionally amphibole or pyroxene phenocrysts.
parentDefinition: Lava is a mixture of molten or semi-molten rock, volatiles, and solids which has extruded beyond a planetary crust.
parentComment: Some use 'lava' to refer to rock that is formed when lava cools. This is not the intended meaning of this class. See 'igneous rock' or similar.

classDefinition: Mafic lava is lava which, relative to other lava types other than ultramafic lava, has a  high ferromagnesian content and low aluminium and silica content, with silca making up between 45 and 52 percent of its weight.
parentDefinition: Lava is a mixture of molten or semi-molten rock, volatiles, and solids which has extruded beyond a planetary crust.
classComment: Mafic lava generally erupts at temperatures in excess of 950 degrees Celsius. The high temperature and low polymerisation in mafic lava favors low viscosity and chemical diffusion, promoting the formation of large, well-formed phenocrysts.
parentComment: Some use 'lava' to refer to rock that is formed when lava cools. This is not the intended meaning of this class. See 'igneous rock' or similar.

classDefinition: Lava which, relative to other lava types, has very high magnesium oxide content and less than 45 percent silica by weight.
parentDefinition: Lava is a mixture of molten or semi-molten rock, volatiles, and solids which has extruded beyond a planetary crust.
classComment: Ultramafic lava generally erupts at temperatures of 1600 degrees Celsius. Due to its high temperature and composition, the viscosity of ultramafic lava is very low.
parentComment: Some use 'lava' to refer to rock that is formed when lava cools. This is not the intended meaning of this class. See 'igneous rock' or similar.

classDefinition: Basalt is a volcanic rock which is formed by the rapid cooling of basaltic lava.
parentDefinition: Rock formed from molten magma.

classDefinition: A coastal scrubland is a scrubland which is part of a coast.
parentDefinition: Area covered with low-growing or stunted perennial vegetation and usually not mixed with trees.

classDefinition: A polar condition is an environmental condition in which an environmental system receives low, yearly solar irradiance per unit area, resulting in colder climatic conditions.
parentDefinition: An environmental condition is a range of a determinate quality or combination of qualities that are present in an environmental system.
classComment: On Earth, polar conditions are such that every month has average temperature lower than 10 degrees Celsius. Note that  this class refers to a climatic rather than a positional condition.
parentComment: A condition defines a restricted range of a given quality or combination of qualities. If an environment class, E, has_condition C, then all qualities listed in C are restricted to the ranges defined in C in E. This is not intended as a logical conditional.

classDefinition: An oak woodland is a woodland which has a tree community primarily composed of oak trees.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which is determined by communities of plants with a tree growth form and in which members of those communities are spaced sufficiently far apart to allow sunlight to illuminate the understory.
parentComment: Woodland understories are often populated with communities of shrubs and herbaceous plants including grasses. There are varying distinctions between woodland and forest, with a large degree of ambiguity.

classDefinition: An ecosystem which is determined by communities of plants with a tree growth form and in which members of those communities are spaced sufficiently far apart to allow sunlight to illuminate the understory.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which primarily occurs on land.
classComment: Woodland understories are often populated with communities of shrubs and herbaceous plants including grasses. There are varying distinctions between woodland and forest, with a large degree of ambiguity.

classDefinition: A conifer woodland is a woodland which has a tree community primarily composed of coniferous trees, from the Division Pinophyta, also known as Coniferophyta or Coniferae.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which is determined by communities of plants with a tree growth form and in which members of those communities are spaced sufficiently far apart to allow sunlight to illuminate the understory.
parentComment: Woodland understories are often populated with communities of shrubs and herbaceous plants including grasses. There are varying distinctions between woodland and forest, with a large degree of ambiguity.

classDefinition: A juniper woodland is a woodland which has a tree community primarily composed of trees of the genus Juniperus.
parentDefinition: A conifer woodland is a woodland which has a tree community primarily composed of coniferous trees, from the Division Pinophyta, also known as Coniferophyta or Coniferae.

classDefinition: A scrubland which is located in a desert.
parentDefinition: Area covered with low-growing or stunted perennial vegetation and usually not mixed with trees.

classDefinition: A pinyon juniper woodland is a conifer woodland which has a tree community primarily composed of trees of the subsection Cembroides of the genus Pinus and the genus Juniperus.
parentDefinition: A conifer woodland is a woodland which has a tree community primarily composed of coniferous trees, from the Division Pinophyta, also known as Coniferophyta or Coniferae.

classDefinition: An ecosystem which 1) is determined by communities of annual crops, perennial woody crops, or by actively tilled land, 2) is primarily used for agricultural activity, and 3) contains no village or larger human settlement.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which is formed as a result of human activity or impact.

classDefinition: An ecosystem which 1) is determined by communities of annual crops, perennial woody crops, or by actively tilled land, 2) is primarily used for agricultural activity, and 3) contains no village or larger human settlement.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which primarily occurs on land.

classDefinition: A village biome is an anthropogenic terrestrial biome which contains settlements such as villages, towns, and/or small cities and which is primarily used for agricultural activity.
parentDefinition: A biome is an ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
classComment: Villages are also described as agricultural settlements with greater than 100 persons per square kilometre; however, no upper limit is defined.
parentComment: In this definition, there is an assumption that no major perturbations are occurring or have occurred in a time frame affects the successional dynamics of the ecosystem. A "major" perturbation is one which disrupts the community's ability to restore its (near) equilibrium. Usually, pioneer or early secondary successional processes would be in effect in such scenarios.

classDefinition: A village biome is an anthropogenic terrestrial biome which contains settlements such as villages, towns, and/or small cities and which is primarily used for agricultural activity.
parentDefinition: A village is a clustered human settlement or community, larger than a hamlet but smaller than a town, with a population ranging from a few hundred to a few thousand. Though often located in rural areas, the term urban village is also applied to certain urban neighbourhoods. Villages are normally permanent, with fixed dwellings; however, transient villages can occur. Further, the dwellings of a village are fairly close to one another, not scattered broadly over the landscape, as a dispersed settlement.
classComment: Villages are also described as agricultural settlements with greater than 100 persons per square kilometre; however, no upper limit is defined.

classDefinition: A village is a clustered human settlement or community, larger than a hamlet but smaller than a town, with a population ranging from a few hundred to a few thousand. Though often located in rural areas, the term urban village is also applied to certain urban neighbourhoods. Villages are normally permanent, with fixed dwellings; however, transient villages can occur. Further, the dwellings of a village are fairly close to one another, not scattered broadly over the landscape, as a dispersed settlement.
parentDefinition: An anthropised ecosystem which is determined by the presence of humans and their constructions.

classDefinition: A dense settlement biome is an anthropogenic terrestrial biome which is primarily used for human habitation, recreation, and industry within built structures with little other land use.
parentDefinition: A biome is an ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentComment: In this definition, there is an assumption that no major perturbations are occurring or have occurred in a time frame affects the successional dynamics of the ecosystem. A "major" perturbation is one which disrupts the community's ability to restore its (near) equilibrium. Usually, pioneer or early secondary successional processes would be in effect in such scenarios.

classDefinition: A dense settlement biome is an anthropogenic terrestrial biome which is primarily used for human habitation, recreation, and industry within built structures with little other land use.
parentDefinition: A settlement with a high density of buildings and inhabitants.
parentComment: The thresholds for what makes a settlment "dense" can be determined as needed. If there is a specific threshold that should be added to ENVO, please make a new class request.

classDefinition: An urban biome is a dense settlement biome which has been urbanised.
parentDefinition: A dense settlement biome is an anthropogenic terrestrial biome which is primarily used for human habitation, recreation, and industry within built structures with little other land use.

classDefinition: A  coniferous forest biome which includes communities adapted to subpolar conditions.
parentDefinition: A coniferous forest biome is a forest biome which contains densely packed populations or communities of coniferous trees, strongly limiting light penetration to the forest floor.
parentComment: Preliminary definition.

classDefinition: A  coniferous forest biome which includes communities adapted to subpolar conditions.
parentDefinition: A biome which is subject to subpolar climatic conditions.

classDefinition: A biome which is subject to subpolar climatic conditions.
parentDefinition: A biome is an ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentComment: In this definition, there is an assumption that no major perturbations are occurring or have occurred in a time frame affects the successional dynamics of the ecosystem. A "major" perturbation is one which disrupts the community's ability to restore its (near) equilibrium. Usually, pioneer or early secondary successional processes would be in effect in such scenarios.

classDefinition: A biome which is subject to subpolar climatic conditions.
parentDefinition: An environment which is located in a part of an astronomical body subject to subpolar climatic conditions.

classDefinition: A subpolar condition is an environmental condition in which an environmental system receives low, yearly solar irradiance per unit area and is surrounded by large land masses. This results in very cold winters with temperatures potentially falling to around -40 degrees Celsius and summers which last no more than 3 months of the year with a 24-hour average temperature of at least 10 degrees Celsius.
parentDefinition: An environmental condition is a range of a determinate quality or combination of qualities that are present in an environmental system.
classComment: Note that  this class refers to a climatic rather than a positional condition.
parentComment: A condition defines a restricted range of a given quality or combination of qualities. If an environment class, E, has_condition C, then all qualities listed in C are restricted to the ranges defined in C in E. This is not intended as a logical conditional.

classDefinition: A river where fresh water flows.
parentDefinition: A stream which, through permanent or seasonal flow processes, moves from elevated land towards lower elevations through a definite channel and empties either into a sea, lake, or another river or ends on land as bed seepage and evapotranspiration exceed water supply.
classComment: Preliminary definition.
parentComment: "There are no official definitions for the generic term river as applied to geographic features, although in some countries or communities a stream is defined by its size. Many names for small rivers are specific to geographic location; examples are "run" in some parts of the United States, "burn" in Scotland and northeast England, and "beck" in northern England. Sometimes a river is defined as being larger than a creek, but not always: the language is vague."

classDefinition: A river where fresh water flows.
parentDefinition: A stream which is composed primarily of fresh water.
classComment: Preliminary definition.

classDefinition: A hydrothermal vent found on the ocean floor which emits lighter-hued minerals, such as those containing barium, calcium and silicon. These alkaline hydrothermal vents also continuously generate acetyl thioesters, providing both the starting point for more complex organic molecules and the energy needed to produce them.
parentDefinition: A marine hydrothermal vent is a marine benthic feature where heat generated due to tectonic activity, either at divergent plate boundaries or convergent ocean plates where back-arc spreading occurs, is released or 'vented' to the surface. The resultant high temperature water jets are laden with dissolved metals and minerals.

classDefinition: A fluid interface which separates two fluid masses with differing properties.
parentDefinition: A surface layer which separates two portions of fluid with respect to either 1) a discontinuity of some fluid property or 2) some derivative of one of these properties in a direction normal to the interface.

classDefinition: A cline across which nutrient content of a fluid changes rapidly.
parentDefinition: A fluid front which is 1) thin in comparison to the fluid mass it is a part of and 2) across which a property of that fluid mass varies greatly over short vertical distance, relative to variation across the entire fluid mass.
parentComment: A similar term exists in linguistics and mathematics. An ecocline, or biological cline, is a related concept; however, may be better placed as a child of a class like "ecotone". Further, some definitions of "layer" require a layer's constiuent materials to have consistent properties, thus "cline" would not qualify as a subclass. The term "gradient" has been proposed as a more suitable superclass. Discussion in Issue #286)

classDefinition: A hydrothermal seep is a seep in which diffuse flow of geothermally heated fluids with high methane concentrations. This seep has been proposed as an intermediate between cold seeps and hydrothermal vents.
parentDefinition: A seep is a spring in which water has filtered through permeable earth to the surface.

classDefinition: A layer which is composed primarily of some fluid.
parentDefinition: A material entity which 1) is spatially continuous, 2) is composed of material of comparable thickness, composition, and physical properties, and 3) is physically distinct from adjacent portions of environmental material.

classDefinition: An object which is naturally occuring, bound together by gravitational or electromagnetic forces, and surrounded by space.
parentDefinition: An object which is composed of one or more gravitationally bound structures that are associated with a position in space.
classComment: Astronomical bodies are usually cohesive, thus the use of the term 'object' sensu BFO 'object'.
parentComment: If there is only one astronomical body involved, this class is equivalent to ENVO:01000799. This may be problematic with reasoning, but it seems to be true to the rather fuzzy definitions found thus far.

classDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's exhibiting the physical characteristics of an entity consisting of particles that have neither a defined volume nor defined shape.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of its constitution.

classDefinition: Atmospheric water vapour is water vapour that is part of an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: Water vapour is a vapour which is the gas phase of water.
parentComment: Perhaps a better relation between water vapour and water can be found in or added to RO?

classDefinition: A sedimentary rock which is composed mainly of silt. This rock has a grainsize in the silt range, finer than sandstone and coarser than claystones.
parentDefinition: Clastic sedimentary rocks are sedimentary rocks that are composed of silicate minerals and rock fragments that were transported by moving fluids. Clastic rocks are composed largely of quartz, feldspar, rock (lithic) fragments, clay minerals, and mica; numerous other minerals may be present as accessories and may be important locally.

classDefinition: A clastic sedimentary rock which is composed primarily of clay sized particles.
parentDefinition: Clastic sedimentary rocks are sedimentary rocks that are composed of silicate minerals and rock fragments that were transported by moving fluids. Clastic rocks are composed largely of quartz, feldspar, rock (lithic) fragments, clay minerals, and mica; numerous other minerals may be present as accessories and may be important locally.

classDefinition: A mudstone is a clastic sedimentary rock which contains a mixture of at least one third of silt- and one third of clay-sized particles.
parentDefinition: Clastic sedimentary rocks are sedimentary rocks that are composed of silicate minerals and rock fragments that were transported by moving fluids. Clastic rocks are composed largely of quartz, feldspar, rock (lithic) fragments, clay minerals, and mica; numerous other minerals may be present as accessories and may be important locally.
classComment: There is debate on the usage of mudstone and mudrock, and some ambiguity is to be expected. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ The terminology of "mudstone" is not to be confused with the Dunham classification scheme for limestones. In Dunham's classification, a mudstone is any limestone containing less than ten percent carbonate grains. Note, a siliciclastic mudstone does not deal with carbonate grains. Friedman, Sanders, and Kopaska-Merkel (1992) suggest the use of "lime mudstone" to avoid confusion with siliciclastic rocks.

classDefinition: Lime mudstone is a limestone which is primarily composed of either clay-size or both silt-size and clay-size detrital (transported) carbonate grains.
parentDefinition: A sedimentary rock which is composed primarily of calcium carbonate in the form of calcite or aragnoite.
classComment: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ The terminology of "mudstone" is not to be confused with the Dunham classification scheme for limestones. In Dunham's classification, a mudstone is any limestone containing less than ten percent carbonate grains. Note, a siliciclastic mudstone does not deal with carbonate grains. Friedman, Sanders, and Kopaska-Merkel (1992) suggest the use of "lime mudstone" to avoid confusion with siliciclastic rocks.

classDefinition: Slate is a metamorphic rock which is fine-grained, foliated, homogeneous, Slates are derived from clastic sedimentary rocks.
parentDefinition: A rock formed by subjecting any rock type (including previously-formed metamorphic rock) to different temperature and pressure conditions than those in which the original rock was formed. These temperatures and pressures are always higher than those at the Earth's surface and must be sufficiently high so as to change the original minerals into other mineral types or else into other forms of the same minerals (e.g. by recrystallisation).

classLabel: freezing of water into water ice
classDefinition: A freezing process during which liquid water is transformed into water ice.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classLabel: freezing of water into water ice
classDefinition: A freezing process during which liquid water is transformed into water ice.
parentDefinition: A material congelation process during which a liquid turns into a solid when its temperature is lowered below its melting point.

classDefinition: A physical process during which atoms, molecules, or other consituents of a material entity are forced closer together.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classLabel: desublimation of water vapour into ice
classDefinition: A desublimation process during which water vapour is frozen into water ice.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classLabel: desublimation of water vapour into ice
classDefinition: A desublimation process during which water vapour is frozen into water ice.
parentDefinition: Desublimation is a process in which a portion of some gas undergoes a phase transition into a portion of some solid.

classDefinition: A depression caused by the collapse of a pingo.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A depression caused by the collapse of a pingo.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A quality of a single process inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's being uninterrupted in time, sequence, substance, or extent.
parentDefinition: A quality of a single process inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's occurrence.

classDefinition: A solid layer which is composed primarily of sedimentary rock or soil.
parentDefinition: A layer which is primarily composed of some solid material, allowing for non-solid parts such as interstitial pockets of gas or liquid.

classDefinition: A lake which is permanently covered by ice, does not mix, and exhibit inverse cold water stratification whereby water temperature increases with depth below the ice surface.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A dimitic lake is a holomictic lake which mixes from top to bottom during two mixing periods each year. Mixing typically occurs during the spring and autumn, when the lake is "isothermal" (i.e., at the same temperature from the top to the bottom). At this time the water throughout the lake is about 4°C, and, in the absence of any temperature or density differences, the lake readily mixes from top to bottom. These lakes are common in regions with temperate climates.
parentDefinition: A holomictic lake is a lake which mixes at least once per year. Mixing is caused by a uniform temperature distribution from the upper to lower layers of the lake.

classDefinition: A polymictic lake is a holomictic lake which is too shallow to allow thermal stratification and which can mix from top to bottom through the ice-free period of the year.
parentDefinition: A holomictic lake is a lake which mixes at least once per year. Mixing is caused by a uniform temperature distribution from the upper to lower layers of the lake.

classDefinition: A monomictic  lake is a holomictic lake which mixes from top to bottom during one mixing period each year.
parentDefinition: A holomictic lake is a lake which mixes at least once per year. Mixing is caused by a uniform temperature distribution from the upper to lower layers of the lake.

classDefinition: A monomictic lake which is covered by ice throughout much of the year and only mixes when its surface ice melts and the lake lacks thermal stratification.
parentDefinition: A monomictic  lake is a holomictic lake which mixes from top to bottom during one mixing period each year.

classDefinition: A monomictic lake which does not freeze and is thermally stratified throughout most of the year, only mixing in winter when cooler temperatures ease stratification.
parentDefinition: A monomictic  lake is a holomictic lake which mixes from top to bottom during one mixing period each year.

classDefinition: A cold polymictic lake is a polymictic lake which is covered by ice in winter.
parentDefinition: A polymictic lake is a holomictic lake which is too shallow to allow thermal stratification and which can mix from top to bottom through the ice-free period of the year.

classDefinition: A warm polymictic lake is a polymictic lake which is not covered by ice at any point during the year.
parentDefinition: A polymictic lake is a holomictic lake which is too shallow to allow thermal stratification and which can mix from top to bottom through the ice-free period of the year.

classDefinition: An astronomical body part which is composed primarily of environmental materials in their frozen form.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment:
The term generally refers to the portions of the Earth where water is in solid form, including snow cover, floating ice, glaciers, ice caps, ice sheets, seasonally frozen ground and perennially frozen ground (permafrost). The Cryosphere may be divided into the cryoatmosphere, the cryohydrosphere (snow cover, glaciers, and river, lake and sea Ice) and the cryolithosphere (perennially and seasonally cryotic ground, rock glacier). Some definitions consider the cryosphere to include any area of Earth which is sufficiently cold for pure water to freeze for at least a part of each year. It should be noted that "Some authorities exclude the earth's atmosphere from the Earth's Cryosphere; others restrict the term Cryosphere to the regions of the earth's crust where Permafrost exists."

Definitions of Cryosphere come from several glossaries including:
- PhysicalGeography.net http://physicalgeography.net/
-  van Everdingen, Robert, ed., 2005 (1998 revised May 2005). Multi-language glossary of permafrost and related ground-ice terms. Boulder, CO: National Snow and Ice Data Center/World Data Center for Glaciology. [https://globalcryospherewatch.org/reference/glossary_docs/Glossary_of_Permafrost_and_Ground-Ice_IPA_2005.pdf]
- American Meteorological Society, 2015. Glossary of Meteorology [online], Available at: http://glossary.ametsoc.org/wiki/Main_Page. [Accessed 27/01/2017].
- EU Climate-ADAPT (The European Climate Adaptation Platform), no date, Glossary, Available from: http://climate-adapt.eea.europa.eu/glossary
- IPCC, 2014: Annex II: Glossary [Agard, J., Schipper, E. L. F., (ed.)]. In: Climate Change 2014: Impacts, Adaptation, and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change [Birkmann, J., Campos, M., Dubeux, C., Nojiri, Y., Olsson, L., Osman-Elasha, B., Pelling, M., Prather, M. J., Rivera-Ferre M. G., Ruppel, O. C., Sallenger, A., Smith, K. R., St. Clair, A. L.,]. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, United Kingdom and New York, NY, USA. [Link]
- NSIDC, The National Snow and Ice Data Center glossary is available at https://nsidc.org/cryosphere/glossary, Last accessed [26/01/2016].
- Trombotto, D., P. Wainstein & L. Arenson, 2014, Guía Terminológica de la Geocriología Sudamericana” / “Terminological Guide of the South American Geocryology, 1a ed. 128 pp. [Link]
- UNESCO-WMO, 2012, International Glossary of Hydrology, 3rd edition, WMO-No. 385. [Link]
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: Outer space is a hard vacuum containing a low density of particles, predominantly a plasma of hydrogen and helium as well as electromagnetic radiation, magnetic fields, neutrinos, dust and cosmic rays that exists between celestial bodies.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: Outer space is a hard vacuum containing a low density of particles, predominantly a plasma of hydrogen and helium as well as electromagnetic radiation, magnetic fields, neutrinos, dust and cosmic rays that exists between celestial bodies.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: A stream which is composed primarily of fresh water.
parentDefinition: A watercourse which is linear and flows across the solid portion of a planetary surface.

classDefinition: Oceanic crust is the uppermost layer of the oceanic portion of a tectonic plate.
parentDefinition: A planetary structural layer is laminar part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough to have differentiation by density. Planetary layers have differing physicochemical properties and composition.

classDefinition: An advective transport process during which a fluid moves.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which a volume of material is displaced due to a disequilibrium in physical forces and during which 1) the qualities that inhere in that volume and 2) the processes that are unfolding within it are largely unchanged.
parentComment: Advective processes are disjoint from diffusive processes. Typically, fluids are advected.

classDefinition: An atmospheric Taylor column is a Taylor column that is formed in the atmosphere. Atmospheric Taylor columns often form above islands resulting in vortex streets in the atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A Taylor column is a column of deflected fluid flow which is formed in a perturbed, rotating fluid, is parallel to the axis of rotation, and extends above the obstacle perturbing the fluid in a rigid manner.
parentComment: This is an interesting class. It's not really a column in the sense of a water column, nor is it a current, exactly. It may also occur in any fluid, gaseous or liquid.

classDefinition: Brackish water which is part of an estuary.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: Brackish water which is part of an estuary.
parentDefinition: Water which has a higher salinity than fresh water but a lower salinity than marine water.

classDefinition: A portion of environmental material which protrudes through a surface layer.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
classComment: This is kept as a general class. One can specify subclasses by identifying the protruding material (e.g. rock outcroup, mineral outcrop, etc ) and the material(s) the protrusion emerges from. Possible logical definition:   A portion of ENVO:environmental material which has_quality PATO:"protruding out of" a ENVO:surface layer of an ENVO:environmental material.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: An endolithic environment is an environment that exists within solid rock.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a quality
classDefinition: A high pressure environment is an environment in which all material entities are exposed to a high ratio of force per unit area.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by materials bearing roughly homogeneous qualities.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation.

classLabel: environmental system determined by a quality
classDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by materials bearing roughly homogeneous qualities.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
classComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: A pressure which is relatively high.
parentDefinition: A physical quality that inheres in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's amount of force per unit area it exerts.

classDefinition: A pressure which is relatively high.
parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is increased compared to normal or average.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a quality
classDefinition: A high temperature environment is an environment in which material entities are exposed to increased levels of heat radiation or which have molecules or atoms moving randomly with increased levels of average kinietic energy.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by materials bearing roughly homogeneous qualities.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation.

classDefinition: An aquatic environment which is determined by freshwater.
parentDefinition: An environment whose dynamics are strongly influenced by water.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a quality
classDefinition: An environment whose dynamics are strongly influenced by water.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by materials bearing roughly homogeneous qualities.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a material
classDefinition: An environment whose dynamics are strongly influenced by water.
parentDefinition: An environmental system within which an environmental material strongly influences the system's composition and properties.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation. Subclasses describe environments which are usually permeated by an environmental material. They may also describe environments which are sufficiently close to a material, that their dynamics are strongly influenced by it (e.g. a patch of forest ecosystem neighbouring a uranium dump).

classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by saline water.
parentDefinition: An environment whose dynamics are strongly influenced by water.

classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by saline water.
parentDefinition: An environment which is determined by materials which bear significant concentrations of salts.
parentComment: The thresholds for "significant" concentrations of salts vary widely and thus no committment is made in this class. Subclasses with more explicit thresholds can be made upon request.

classDefinition: An environment which is determined by materials which bear significant concentrations of salts.
parentDefinition: A high osmolarity environment is an environment in which entities are exposed to high concentrations of solutes.
classComment: The thresholds for "significant" concentrations of salts vary widely and thus no committment is made in this class. Subclasses with more explicit thresholds can be made upon request.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a material
classDefinition: An environment which is determined by materials which bear significant concentrations of salts.
parentDefinition: An environmental system within which an environmental material strongly influences the system's composition and properties.
classComment: The thresholds for "significant" concentrations of salts vary widely and thus no committment is made in this class. Subclasses with more explicit thresholds can be made upon request.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation. Subclasses describe environments which are usually permeated by an environmental material. They may also describe environments which are sufficiently close to a material, that their dynamics are strongly influenced by it (e.g. a patch of forest ecosystem neighbouring a uranium dump).

classDefinition: An environmental system which is located beyond the Earth's exosphere and away from the Earth's core.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: An environment which has a lower temperature than some local or global average.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
classComment: The definition of the deprecated 'cold temperature habitat' class, which this class was derived from, quotes an upper threshold of 15 degrees Celsius for 'coldness'.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: A haline environment is an environment in which entities are exposed to high concentrations of salt, typically above 2 molar.
parentDefinition: A high osmolarity environment is an environment in which entities are exposed to high concentrations of solutes.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a quality
classDefinition: A high osmolarity environment is an environment in which entities are exposed to high concentrations of solutes.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by materials bearing roughly homogeneous qualities.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation.

classDefinition: A cultivated environment is an environment that has been modified by humans by the preparation of the land, usually for the purposes of growing crops.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic environment is an environmental system which is the product of human activity.
parentComment: Unsatisfactory definition here. Must consider the threshold that makes an environmental system anthropogenic.

classDefinition: An anthropogenic environment is an environmental system which is the product of human activity.
