parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
classComment: Unsatisfactory definition here. Must consider the threshold that makes an environmental system anthropogenic.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: A culturing environment is an environment which is maintained by humans for the purposes of preparing cell, organ, tissue and plant tissue cultures.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic environment is an environmental system which is the product of human activity.
parentComment: Unsatisfactory definition here. Must consider the threshold that makes an environmental system anthropogenic.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a quality
classDefinition: An acidic environment is an environment in which material entities are exposed to a low pH.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by materials bearing roughly homogeneous qualities.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a quality
classDefinition: An alkaline environment is an environment in which entities are exposed to high pH, typically greater than a pH of 9.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by materials bearing roughly homogeneous qualities.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation.

classLabel: environmental system determined by a material
classDefinition: An environmental system within which an environmental material strongly influences the system's composition and properties.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
classComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation. Subclasses describe environments which are usually permeated by an environmental material. They may also describe environments which are sufficiently close to a material, that their dynamics are strongly influenced by it (e.g. a patch of forest ecosystem neighbouring a uranium dump).
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: An extreme high temperature environment is a high temperature environment in which entities are exposed to temperatures above 80 degrees Celsius.
parentDefinition: A high temperature environment is an environment in which material entities are exposed to increased levels of heat radiation or which have molecules or atoms moving randomly with increased levels of average kinietic energy.
classComment: The lower threshold, 80 degrees Celsius, is derived from the definition of the obsolete class "extreme high temperature habitat" which this class replaces.

classDefinition: A rocky slope is a slope which has a surface primarily composed of rock.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and relatively flat surrounding land.

classDefinition: A marine environment and enviroment which is determined by a marine water body.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: A marine environment and enviroment which is determined by a marine water body.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: An environmental system determined by seawater.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by saline water.

classDefinition: An environment determined by the presence of brackish water.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by saline water.
classComment: This may refer to environments submerged in brackish water or those that are determined by its presence, such as a brackish water pond environment.

classDefinition: The atmospheric boundary layer is the lowest layer of an atmosphere which is strongly influenced by its contact with a planetary surface with strong vertical mixing and in which physical quantities such as flow velocity, temperature, and moisture display rapid fluctuations (turbulence).
parentDefinition: A boundary layer is a layer of fluid in the immediate vicinity of a bounding surface where the effects of viscosity are significant enough to distort the surrounding non-viscous flow.

classDefinition: The atmospheric boundary layer is the lowest layer of an atmosphere which is strongly influenced by its contact with a planetary surface with strong vertical mixing and in which physical quantities such as flow velocity, temperature, and moisture display rapid fluctuations (turbulence).
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of the atmosphere.
parentComment: This could be made into an inferred class, rather than having asserted subclasses.

classDefinition: A boundary layer is a layer of fluid in the immediate vicinity of a bounding surface where the effects of viscosity are significant enough to distort the surrounding non-viscous flow.
parentDefinition: A surface layer which separates two portions of fluid with respect to either 1) a discontinuity of some fluid property or 2) some derivative of one of these properties in a direction normal to the interface.

classDefinition: A planetary surface is a surface layer where the solid or liquid material of a planet comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
parentDefinition: A surface layer where the solid or liquid material of an astronomical body comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
classComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities
parentComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities

classDefinition: A layer that is part of the atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A layer which is composed primarily of some fluid.
classComment: This could be made into an inferred class, rather than having asserted subclasses.

classDefinition: A planet is an astronomical body orbiting a star or stellar remnant that is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity, is not massive enough to cause thermonuclear fusion, and has cleared its neighbouring region of planetesimals.
parentDefinition: An object which is naturally occuring, bound together by gravitational or electromagnetic forces, and surrounded by space.
classComment: Considerable debate on the definition of planet exists.
parentComment: Astronomical bodies are usually cohesive, thus the use of the term 'object' sensu BFO 'object'.

classDefinition: A layer which is primarily composed of some liquid material.
parentDefinition: A layer which is composed primarily of some fluid.

classDefinition: A subsurface layer in a water body, typically an ocean or lake, in which chlorophyll concentrations reach their maximum.
parentDefinition: A layer in a water mass, itself composed primarily of water.
classComment: The DCM may or may not indicate greater abundance of photosynthetic, chlorophyll-bearing cells, as shade-adapted cells may have a greater chlorophyll to biomass ration than surface variants. Further, some DCMs may be formed by the sinking of cells from surface zones or the subduction of surface waters, rather than through biotic, community-level processess.
parentComment: This class will eventually be populated by inference, and its asserted subclasses removed.

classDefinition: A strand swamp is a swamp that forms linear drainage channels on flatlands.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem in which land mass is permanently inundated by shallow bodies of water, generally with a substantial number of hummocks, or dry-land protrusions.

classDefinition: A dome swamp is a swamp which occurs in a depression where deeper waters at the centre of the swamp allow  trees to grow taller relative to those in shallower regions of the depression. This creates a dome-like shape.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem in which land mass is permanently inundated by shallow bodies of water, generally with a substantial number of hummocks, or dry-land protrusions.
classComment: The logical def should be improved with the idea of a vegetation unit growing in a depression expressed.

classDefinition: A cypress dome swamp is a dome swamp which has a plant community dominated by Cupressaceae, often swamp cypresses. Swamp cypresses typically belong to the genus Taxodium or the species Glyptostrobus pensilis and Actinostrobus pyramidalis.
parentDefinition: A dome swamp is a swamp which occurs in a depression where deeper waters at the centre of the swamp allow  trees to grow taller relative to those in shallower regions of the depression. This creates a dome-like shape.
classComment: Requires import of some taxonomy for differentia
parentComment: The logical def should be improved with the idea of a vegetation unit growing in a depression expressed.

classDefinition: A cypress strand swamp is a strand swamp which has a plant community dominated by Cupressaceae, often swamp cypresses. Swamp cypresses typically belong to the genus Taxodium or the species Glyptostrobus pensilis and Actinostrobus pyramidalis.
parentDefinition: A strand swamp is a swamp that forms linear drainage channels on flatlands.
classComment: Requires import of some taxonomy for differentia

classDefinition: A cypress swamp is a swamp which has a plant community dominated by Cupressaceae, often swamp cypresses. Swamp cypresses typically belong to the genus Taxodium or the species Glyptostrobus pensilis and Actinostrobus pyramidalis.
parentDefinition: A wetland ecosystem in which land mass is permanently inundated by shallow bodies of water, generally with a substantial number of hummocks, or dry-land protrusions.
classComment: Requires import of some taxonomy for differentia

classDefinition: A gravelly slope is a slope which has a surface primarily composed of gravel.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and relatively flat surrounding land.

classDefinition: A hillside is a slope that is part of a hill.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and relatively flat surrounding land.

classDefinition: A talus slope is a slope which has a surface layer composed of scree.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and relatively flat surrounding land.

classDefinition: An understory is a layer of plant life which grows below the canopy without penetrating it.
parentDefinition: A layer which is determined by a form of vegetation.
parentComment: Usually found in woodlands and forests.

classDefinition: A layer which is determined by a form of vegetation.
parentDefinition: A material entity which 1) is spatially continuous, 2) is composed of material of comparable thickness, composition, and physical properties, and 3) is physically distinct from adjacent portions of environmental material.
classComment: Usually found in woodlands and forests.

classDefinition: A shrub layer is a layer of vegetation in a woodland or forest consisting of low, woody vegetation of frutescent form.
parentDefinition: A layer which is determined by a form of vegetation.
parentComment: Usually found in woodlands and forests.

classDefinition: A herb and fern layer is a layer of a forest or woodland which is composed of all vascular plant life that are one metre or less in height.
parentDefinition: A layer which is determined by a form of vegetation.
classComment: This definition is inclusive of non-herbaceous plants that may be transiently present in the "herb layer". See Gilliam FS (2007) The Ecological Significance of the Herbaceous Layer in Temperate Forest Ecosystems. BioScience. 57(10):845-858. (http://dx.doi.org/10.1641/B571007) for rationale and a review of definitional and terminological variation.
parentComment: Usually found in woodlands and forests.

classDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's upper parts die back to the rootstock at the end of the growing season.
parentDefinition: An organismal quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's disposition to lose an entity by natural process.

classComment: Refers to the ground layer of a forest or woodland where leaf litter or other plant matter accumulates

parentDefinition: A layer which is determined by a form of vegetation.
classComment: Refers to the ground layer of a forest or woodland where leaf litter or other plant matter accumulates
parentComment: Usually found in woodlands and forests.

classDefinition: Leaf litter is dead plant material, such as leaves, bark, needles, and twigs, that has fallen to the ground.
Leaf litter is dead plant material, such as leaves, bark, needles, and twigs, that has fallen to the ground.
parentDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.

classDefinition: An environment which is located in a part of an astronomical body subject to polar climatic conditions.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: An altitudinal condition is an environmental condition in which ranges of factors such as temperature, humidity, soil composition, solar irradiation, and tree density vary with ranges in altitude.
parentDefinition: An environmental condition is a range of a determinate quality or combination of qualities that are present in an environmental system.
classComment: Depending on the latitude (and, to a lesser extent, other factors), the actual location of the zones where these conditions are in effect will change.
parentComment: A condition defines a restricted range of a given quality or combination of qualities. If an environment class, E, has_condition C, then all qualities listed in C are restricted to the ranges defined in C in E. This is not intended as a logical conditional.

classDefinition: An altitudinal condition which inheres in a bearer by virtue of the bearer being located at an altitude immediately below the tree line of an elevation.
parentDefinition: An altitudinal condition is an environmental condition in which ranges of factors such as temperature, humidity, soil composition, solar irradiation, and tree density vary with ranges in altitude.
classComment: Requested in Issue 33 of our tracker. The lower boundry of this condition's range, that is, the lower altitudinal limit of an elevation that is considuered subalpine, is not clear in this definition.
parentComment: Depending on the latitude (and, to a lesser extent, other factors), the actual location of the zones where these conditions are in effect will change.

classDefinition: An altitudinal condition which inheres in a bearer by virtue of the bearer being located at an altitude between mid-altitude forests and the tree line.
parentDefinition: An altitudinal condition is an environmental condition in which ranges of factors such as temperature, humidity, soil composition, solar irradiation, and tree density vary with ranges in altitude.
classComment: The exact level of the tree line varies with local climate, but typically the tree line is found where mean monthly soil temperatures never exceed 10.0 degrees C and the mean annual soil temperatures are around 6.7 degrees C. In the tropics, this region is typified by montane rain forest (above 3,000 ft) while at higher latitudes coniferous forests often dominate.
parentComment: Depending on the latitude (and, to a lesser extent, other factors), the actual location of the zones where these conditions are in effect will change.

classDefinition: An altitudinal condition which inheres in a bearer by virtue of the bearer having extremely limited vegetation cover, silica-enriched soils, and ground cover dominated by snow and ice at altitudes above the snowline.
parentDefinition: An altitudinal condition is an environmental condition in which ranges of factors such as temperature, humidity, soil composition, solar irradiation, and tree density vary with ranges in altitude.
parentComment: Depending on the latitude (and, to a lesser extent, other factors), the actual location of the zones where these conditions are in effect will change.

classDefinition: An upper montane condition is a montane condition in which an altitude range falls immediately below the tree line.
parentDefinition: An altitudinal condition which inheres in a bearer by virtue of the bearer being located at an altitude between mid-altitude forests and the tree line.
classComment: This definition is somewhat odd in that it doesn't clearly define a lower boundary.
parentComment: The exact level of the tree line varies with local climate, but typically the tree line is found where mean monthly soil temperatures never exceed 10.0 degrees C and the mean annual soil temperatures are around 6.7 degrees C. In the tropics, this region is typified by montane rain forest (above 3,000 ft) while at higher latitudes coniferous forests often dominate.

classDefinition: A lower montane condition is a montane condition in which an altitude range falls immediately above mid-altitude forests.
parentDefinition: An altitudinal condition which inheres in a bearer by virtue of the bearer being located at an altitude between mid-altitude forests and the tree line.
classComment: This definition does not define an upper boundary.
parentComment: The exact level of the tree line varies with local climate, but typically the tree line is found where mean monthly soil temperatures never exceed 10.0 degrees C and the mean annual soil temperatures are around 6.7 degrees C. In the tropics, this region is typified by montane rain forest (above 3,000 ft) while at higher latitudes coniferous forests often dominate.

classDefinition: A montane conifer woodland is a conifer woodland which is located within an altitude range that falls between mid-altitude forests and the tree line.
parentDefinition: A conifer woodland is a woodland which has a tree community primarily composed of coniferous trees, from the Division Pinophyta, also known as Coniferophyta or Coniferae.
classComment: Requested in Issue 56.

classDefinition: A field  used for the cultivation of corn or related crop plants.
parentDefinition: A field which is located on land and used for agricultural purposes, such as the grazing of livestock or the cultivation of crops.
classComment: Requested in Issue 112 as part of the curation of metagenome submissions in the European Nucleotide Archive.

classDefinition: An organic material primarily composed of a portion of plant root.
parentDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.
classComment: Requested in Issue 115 as part of the annotation of metagenomic submissions present in the European Nucleotide Archive.

classDefinition: A plant axis (PO:0025004) that lacks shoot axis nodes (PO:0005004) and usually grows indeterminately.
parentDefinition: An axial plant organ (PO:0009008).
classComment: Roots function in the absorption of water and inorganic nutrients, anchoring the plant body to the substrate and supporting it, storage of food and nutrients, and vegetative reproduction. The roots of most vascular plant species enter into symbiosis with soil-borne microorganisms. Roots are usually positively geotropic and found underground, although there are many exceptions such as the aerial roots of orchids. Roots often form secondary thickening from the root lateral meristem (PO:0006308). Commonly thought of as one of the three basic parts of the plant body, along with the shoot axis (PO:0025029) and leaves (PO:0025034).
parentComment: Includes roots and shoots.

classDefinition: Autoclaved sand is sand that has been sterlised by exposure to high pressure saturated steam at at least 121 degrees Celsius.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is composed primarily of particles of sand with only minor proportions of other substances.
classComment: Requested in Issue 116 as part of the annotation of metagenomic submissions present in the European Nucleotide Archive.
parentComment: This definition is intentionally ambiguous to support the multiple thresholds set by different authorities. Some authorities consider as sands soil material that contains 85% or more sand; the percentage of silt plus 1.5 times the percentage of clay does not exceed 15. coarse sand (sable grossier) 25% or more very coarse and coarse sand, and less than 50% any other one grade of sand.

classDefinition: A mesoscale eddy field is an expanse of marine water which includes coherent vortices, as well as a rich cascade of other structures such as filaments, squirts and spirals and is characterized by temperature and salinity anomalies with associated flow anomalies that are nearly in geostrophic balance. Although only the surface expression of mesoscale eddies is visible in satellite images of sea surface height or temperature, they are in fact three dimensional structures that reach down into the pycnocline.
parentDefinition: An unbroken expanse (as of ice)
parentComment: This class was created to accommodate "fields" from agricultural fields to marine mesoscale eddy fields. Thus, it has a very broad definition which makes it less than informative when annotating. Please consider using or requesting an appropriate subclass.

classDefinition: An ice cap climatic condition is a polar condition in which the montly average temperature does not exceed 0 degrees Celsius.
parentDefinition: A polar condition is an environmental condition in which an environmental system receives low, yearly solar irradiance per unit area, resulting in colder climatic conditions.
parentComment: On Earth, polar conditions are such that every month has average temperature lower than 10 degrees Celsius. Note that  this class refers to a climatic rather than a positional condition.

classDefinition: A portion of granite is a portion of igneous  rock which  is intrusive, felsic, granular, and phaneritic.
parentDefinition: Rock formed from molten magma.
classComment: Requested in issue 45. Some relations to PATO and SWEET classes suggested.

classDefinition: A cave formed by the dissolution of soluble rock or other solid material such as limestone, chalk, dolomite, gypsum, salt or marble.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.
classComment: Can be linked to a solutional environmental process and acidic groundwater.

classDefinition: A cave that is formed by the action of pressurised lava pushing against surrounding rock and then draining away.
parentDefinition: A cave formed in volcanic rock.
parentComment: "Lave cave" is differentiated from "volcanic cave": the former is formed in volcanic rock, the latter is formed by volcanic processes.

classDefinition: A cave formed by erosion caused by flowing streams carrying rocks or sediments.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.

classDefinition: A glacier cave is a cave formed within or under a glacier.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.

classDefinition: An ice cave is a bedrock cave which contains year-round ice formations.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.

classDefinition: A talus cave is a cave formed by the openings between large boulders which have fallen into a random heap.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.

classDefinition: An anchialine cave is a cave which contains an anchialine pool.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.

classDefinition: An anchialine pool is a landlocked water body with a subterranean connection to the ocean and which has fresh water towards its surface with saline water in its deeper layers.
parentDefinition: A body of water, usually of smaller size than a lake.

classDefinition: A cave which is within a vadose zone.
parentDefinition: Naturally formed, subterranean open area or chamber.

classDefinition: Household waste refers to waste material usually generated in the residential environment. Waste with similar characteristics may be generated in other economic activities and can thus be treated and disposed of together with household waste.
parentDefinition: A material which is not the desired output of a process and which is typically the input of a process which removes it from its producer (e.g. a disposal process).

classDefinition: A dry woodland is a woodland which occurs in areas of rain shadow in a tropical marine climate,  receives very little rainfall,  typically has rapidly draining soils and trees which have adaptations to dry climates such as thick bark, small leaves, and the disposition to shed their leaves.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which is determined by communities of plants with a tree growth form and in which members of those communities are spaced sufficiently far apart to allow sunlight to illuminate the understory.
parentComment: Woodland understories are often populated with communities of shrubs and herbaceous plants including grasses. There are varying distinctions between woodland and forest, with a large degree of ambiguity.

classDefinition: A dry woodland is a woodland which occurs in areas of rain shadow in a tropical marine climate,  receives very little rainfall,  typically has rapidly draining soils and trees which have adaptations to dry climates such as thick bark, small leaves, and the disposition to shed their leaves.
parentDefinition: An environment which has a climate with continually high temperatures and with considerable precipitation, at least during part of the year.

classDefinition: An environment which has a climate with continually high temperatures and with considerable precipitation, at least during part of the year.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: A tropical marine condition is a tropical condition in which the ocean strongly influences the climate and a wet and dry season occur.
parentDefinition: A tropical condition is an environmental condition in which an environmental system receives high yearly solar irradiance per unit area and, on Earth, the Sun reaches a subsolar point at least once during the solar year. This results in a hot and moist year-round climate at low elevations, which have a monthly average temperature above 18 degrees Celsius.

classDefinition: A semi-evergreen forest is a forest which undergoes a long dry season and, as a consequence, has a two-storey layer structure,  a dry canopy, a leaf litter layer that only decays during moist periods trees with very small leaves or which shed their leaves to conserve water and which flower during the dry season and grow during the wet season.
parentDefinition: A forest ecosystem which is subject to tropical climate conditions.
parentComment: This class is primarily to be populated by inference.

classDefinition: A forest ecosystem which is subject to tropical climate conditions.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which is determined by communities of plants with a tree growth form and in which members of those communities form continuous or discontinuous regions of canopy cover.
classComment: This class is primarily to be populated by inference.
parentComment: The definitions of forest can vary greatly, and different classes will be needed to support the major categories. Tree cover alone is not enough to distinguish between forests and plantations. The international definition proposed by the 2010 FAO Forestry Resource Assessment: "land spanning more than 0.5 ha with trees higher than 5 metres and canopy cover of more than 10 percent, or trees able to reach these thresholds in situ . It does not include land that is predominantly under agricultural or urban land use." - FAO.  2010. Global forest resources assessment 2010, Main report, FAO Forestry Paper 163. Rome.

classDefinition: A forest ecosystem which is subject to tropical climate conditions.
parentDefinition: An environment which has a climate with continually high temperatures and with considerable precipitation, at least during part of the year.
classComment: This class is primarily to be populated by inference.

classDefinition: A quality inhering in a plant by virtue of the bearer's disposition to being between evergeen and deciduous.
parentDefinition: An organismal quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's disposition to lose an entity by natural process.

classDefinition: A humid subtropical condition is a subtropical condition in which an environmental system has hot, humid summers, warm to cool dry winters, and average annual precipitation either evenly distributed throughout the year or marked by a dry season or drying trend during winter
parentDefinition: A subtropical condition is an environmental condition in which an envrionmental system receives more solar irradiance than those with temperate conditions, but less than those with tropical conditions. At low elevations, this typically results in eight months of the year having average temperatures greater than or equal to 10 degrees Celsius with the coldest monthly temperature averaging between 2 and 13 degrees Celsius.
classComment: In cases where rainfall is evenly distributed throughout the year, this condition falls into the Cfa category of the Köppen climate classification. In cases marked by a dry season or drying trend during winter, this condition falls into the Cwa category of the Köppen climate classification. Environmental systems with this condition usually occur on the eastern side of continents.
parentComment:
As with most other climatic zones and conditions, multiple classification schemes have somehat different definitions and criteria. To quote from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ "Several methods have been used to define the subtropical climate. In the Trewartha climate classification, a subtropical region should have at least eight months with a mean temperature of 10 °C (50.0 °F) or above. German climatologists Carl Troll and Karlheinz Paffen defined Warm temperate zones as plain and hilly lands having an average temperature of the coldest month between 2 °C (35.6 °F) and 13 °C (55.4 °F) in the Northern Hemisphere and between 6 °C (42.8 °F) and 13 °C (55.4 °F) in the Southern Hemisphere, excluding oceanic and continental climates. According to the Troll-Paffen climate classification, there generally exists one large subtropical zone named the warm-temperate subtropical zone,[4] which is subdivided into seven smaller areas.[5]

According to the E. Neef climate classification, the subtropical zone is divided into two parts: Rainy winters of the west sides and Eastern subtropical climate.[6] According to the Wilhelm Lauer & Peter Frankenberg climate classification, the subtropical zone is divided into three parts: high-continental, continental, and maritime.[7] According to the Siegmund/Frankenberg climate classification, subtropical is one of six climate zones in the world.[8]"

classDefinition: An arid subtropical condition is a subtropical condition in which an environmental system has an annual average temperature near 18.2 degrees Celsius with their coldest month averaging between 2 and 13 degrees Celsius, the absence of regular rainfall, and high humidity.
parentDefinition: A subtropical condition is an environmental condition in which an envrionmental system receives more solar irradiance than those with temperate conditions, but less than those with tropical conditions. At low elevations, this typically results in eight months of the year having average temperatures greater than or equal to 10 degrees Celsius with the coldest monthly temperature averaging between 2 and 13 degrees Celsius.
classComment: Mild variants are generally located in areas adjacent to powerful cold ocean currents.
parentComment:
As with most other climatic zones and conditions, multiple classification schemes have somehat different definitions and criteria. To quote from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ "Several methods have been used to define the subtropical climate. In the Trewartha climate classification, a subtropical region should have at least eight months with a mean temperature of 10 °C (50.0 °F) or above. German climatologists Carl Troll and Karlheinz Paffen defined Warm temperate zones as plain and hilly lands having an average temperature of the coldest month between 2 °C (35.6 °F) and 13 °C (55.4 °F) in the Northern Hemisphere and between 6 °C (42.8 °F) and 13 °C (55.4 °F) in the Southern Hemisphere, excluding oceanic and continental climates. According to the Troll-Paffen climate classification, there generally exists one large subtropical zone named the warm-temperate subtropical zone,[4] which is subdivided into seven smaller areas.[5]

According to the E. Neef climate classification, the subtropical zone is divided into two parts: Rainy winters of the west sides and Eastern subtropical climate.[6] According to the Wilhelm Lauer & Peter Frankenberg climate classification, the subtropical zone is divided into three parts: high-continental, continental, and maritime.[7] According to the Siegmund/Frankenberg climate classification, subtropical is one of six climate zones in the world.[8]"

classDefinition: A highland subtropical condition is a subtropical condition in which increased elevation results in mild summers, cooler winters, and, in some instances,  snowfall associated with montly temperature averages below 22 but above -3 degrees Celsius.
parentDefinition: A subtropical condition is an environmental condition in which an envrionmental system receives more solar irradiance than those with temperate conditions, but less than those with tropical conditions. At low elevations, this typically results in eight months of the year having average temperatures greater than or equal to 10 degrees Celsius with the coldest monthly temperature averaging between 2 and 13 degrees Celsius.
classComment: This is an interesting overlap of a latitudinal and altitudinal condition. Some link between this condition and the altitudinal conditions should be considered. This condition corresponds to the Cfb and Cwb categories of Köppen climate classification.
parentComment:
As with most other climatic zones and conditions, multiple classification schemes have somehat different definitions and criteria. To quote from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ "Several methods have been used to define the subtropical climate. In the Trewartha climate classification, a subtropical region should have at least eight months with a mean temperature of 10 °C (50.0 °F) or above. German climatologists Carl Troll and Karlheinz Paffen defined Warm temperate zones as plain and hilly lands having an average temperature of the coldest month between 2 °C (35.6 °F) and 13 °C (55.4 °F) in the Northern Hemisphere and between 6 °C (42.8 °F) and 13 °C (55.4 °F) in the Southern Hemisphere, excluding oceanic and continental climates. According to the Troll-Paffen climate classification, there generally exists one large subtropical zone named the warm-temperate subtropical zone,[4] which is subdivided into seven smaller areas.[5]

According to the E. Neef climate classification, the subtropical zone is divided into two parts: Rainy winters of the west sides and Eastern subtropical climate.[6] According to the Wilhelm Lauer & Peter Frankenberg climate classification, the subtropical zone is divided into three parts: high-continental, continental, and maritime.[7] According to the Siegmund/Frankenberg climate classification, subtropical is one of six climate zones in the world.[8]"

classDefinition: An oceanic temperate condition is a temperate condition which is strongly influenced by oceans and oceanic winds. Summers are cool and winters are cool, but not cold, and there is little frozen precipitation at lower elevations.
parentDefinition: A temperate condition is an environmental condition in which an environmental system receives less solar irradiance than those with subpolar conditions, but greater than those with subtropical conditions.
classComment: This condition is typically present on the western coasts of large continental landmasses.
parentComment: This class' definition is less satisfactory than the other latitudinal conditoins.

classDefinition: A continental temperate condition is a temperate condition which is influenced by large land masses. Summers are warm to hot and winters are often  long, cold, and snowy.
parentDefinition: A temperate condition is an environmental condition in which an environmental system receives less solar irradiance than those with subpolar conditions, but greater than those with subtropical conditions.
parentComment: This class' definition is less satisfactory than the other latitudinal conditoins.

classDefinition: A cold desert is a desert which has hot summers and cold, dry winters with temperatures below 0 degrees Celsius
parentDefinition: A region rendered barren or partially barren by environmental extremes, especially by low rainfall.
classComment: This variant of the desert climate is somewhat rare outside of Asia. A cold desert climate is typically found in temperate zones, almost always in the rain shadow of high mountains which restrict precipitation from the westerly winds, or in the case of Central Asia, from the monsoon. The Gobi desert in Mongolia is a classic example of a region with a cold desert climate. Though hot in summer, it shares the very cold winters of the rest of Central Asia. The Kyzyl Kum and Taklamakan deserts of Central Asia and the drier portions of the Great Basin Desert of the western United States are other major examples of BWk climates. The Ladakh region, lying in the Great Himalayas in India also has a cold desert climate.

classDefinition: A portion of respirable suspended particulate matter is a form of particulate matter composed primarily of solid particles each with a diameter of 10 micrometers or less.
parentDefinition: An aerosol which has non-gaseous parts that are primarily composed of solid particles.

classDefinition: A portion of respirable suspended particulate matter is a form of particulate matter composed primarily of solid particles each with a diameter of 10 micrometers or less.
parentDefinition: A solid material which does not have a regularly organised internal structure.

classDefinition: An aerosol which has non-gaseous parts that are primarily composed of solid particles.
parentDefinition: Airborne solid particles (also called dust or particulate matter (PM)) or liquid droplets.
parentComment: Should connect to PATO as "quality of an aerosol"

classDefinition: A solid material which does not have a regularly organised internal structure.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: A water ice crystal which is constituted by water molecules aligned in a hexagonal array.
parentDefinition: A crystal which is primarily composed of water ice.
parentComment: Any one of a number of macroscopic, crystalline forms in which ice appears, including hexagonal columns, hexagonal platelets, dendritic crystals, ice needles, and combinations of these forms.  The crystal lattice of ice is hexagonal in its symmetry under most atmospheric conditions.

classDefinition: A freshwater littoral zone is a littoral zone which extends offshore from the shore of a freshwater body of water to the limit of occupancy of rooted plants.
parentDefinition: An aquatic environment which is the part of a sea, lake, or river that is close to the shore.
classComment: The littoral zone may form a narrow or broad fringing wetland, with extensive areas of aquatic plants sorted by their tolerance to different water depths. Typically, four zones are recognized, from higher to lower on the shore: wooded wetland, wet meadow, marsh and aquatic vegetation.  Keddy, P.A. 2010. Wetland Ecology: Principles and Conservation (2nd edition). Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. Chapter 2.
parentComment: The adjacency of water has many consequences including the generation of microclimates and impacts on the biology. This class is intended to capture littoral zones that are associated with marine, freshwater, and any other aquatic environments. Note that there is no single definition of the extent of the "littoral zone", associated with any water body. Here, we use definitions that will be more familiar to marine biologists rather than military organisations, although the latter can be added on request. This class will likely be superceded by a CMECs compliant class.

classDefinition: A zone which is part of the sublittoral zone and is dominated by algae. This zone usually extends up to five metres below the low water mark.
parentDefinition: An astronomical body part which is part of a marine environment.
parentComment: This class will eventually be populated by inference alone, with its subclasses distributed in more process-linked hierarchies to improve semantic density.

classDefinition: A zone which is part of the sublittoral zone and is dominated by sessile animals such as oysters. This zone usually begins at a depth greater than the infralittoral zone.
parentDefinition: An astronomical body part which is part of a marine environment.
parentComment: This class will eventually be populated by inference alone, with its subclasses distributed in more process-linked hierarchies to improve semantic density.

classDefinition: A whole plant which is relatively old
parentDefinition: A plant structure (PO:0005679) which is a whole organism.
parentComment: Examples include plant embryo (PO:0009009), megagametophyte (PO:0025279) and microgametophyte (PO:0025280).

classDefinition: An age which is relatively high.
parentDefinition: A time quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of how long the bearer has existed.

classDefinition: A whole plant which is relatively young.
parentDefinition: A plant structure (PO:0005679) which is a whole organism.
parentComment: Examples include plant embryo (PO:0009009), megagametophyte (PO:0025279) and microgametophyte (PO:0025280).

classDefinition: An age which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A time quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of how long the bearer has existed.

classDefinition: A portion of fine respirable suspended particulate matter is a form of particulate matter composed primarily of solid particles each with a diameter of 2.5 micrometers or less.
parentDefinition: A portion of respirable suspended particulate matter is a form of particulate matter composed primarily of solid particles each with a diameter of 10 micrometers or less.

classDefinition: A portion of fine respirable suspended particulate matter is a form of particulate matter composed primarily of solid particles each with a diameter of  100 nanometers or less.
parentDefinition: A portion of fine respirable suspended particulate matter is a form of particulate matter composed primarily of solid particles each with a diameter of 2.5 micrometers or less.
classComment: Regulations do not exist for this size class of ambient air pollution particles, which are far smaller than the regulated PM10 and PM2.5 particle classes and are believed to have several more aggressive health implications than those classes of larger particulates.

parentDefinition: A house is a building that provides a dwelling-place for a living entity.
classComment: A human house is a house which provides a dwelling-place for humans.
parentComment: The provisioning of a dwelling-place can perhaps be modelled as a role.

parentDefinition: A building which is primarily used for the long-term habitation of humans.
classComment: A human house is a house which provides a dwelling-place for humans.

classDefinition: A building which is primarily used for the long-term habitation of humans.
parentDefinition: A permanent walled and roofed construction.

classDefinition: A garden that is associated with a human house. This association is generally one of spatial proximity or parthood.
parentDefinition: An enclosure for displaying selected plant or animal life.

classDefinition: An indoor kitchen is a room or part of a room primarily used  for cooking or food preparation, but which may have other funcitons such as dining, food storage, dishwashing, or laundry.
parentDefinition: A building part is a construction which is part of a building.
classComment: Not a sublcass of room as this may just be part of some room.
parentComment: Not recommended for annotation. This class is likely to be made into an inferred class as its subclasses are distributed among more meaningful superclasses (i.e. ceiling is_a surface layer). See for example, "building floor". The boundaries between building parts may be bona fide or fiat.

classDefinition: A bathroom is a room which contains a washbasin or other fixture, such as a shower or bath, used for bathing by humans.
parentDefinition: A building part which is separated from other building parts by one or more interior walls and, optionally, outdoor areas by one or more exterior walls.

classDefinition: A building part which is separated from other building parts by one or more interior walls and, optionally, outdoor areas by one or more exterior walls.
parentDefinition: A building part is a construction which is part of a building.
parentComment: Not recommended for annotation. This class is likely to be made into an inferred class as its subclasses are distributed among more meaningful superclasses (i.e. ceiling is_a surface layer). See for example, "building floor". The boundaries between building parts may be bona fide or fiat.

classDefinition: A living room is a room in a human house which is used for social and domestic leisure activities.
parentDefinition: A building part which is separated from other building parts by one or more interior walls and, optionally, outdoor areas by one or more exterior walls.
classComment: The logical definitions must state which social and leisure activities are included here. Jet-skiing and mass rallies are probably not the range.

classDefinition: A patio is a paved outdoor area, adjacent to a human house, and used for dining or recreation.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: An indoor toilet is a room which contains a sanitation fixture used primarily for the disposal of human urine and faeces.
parentDefinition: A building part which is separated from other building parts by one or more interior walls and, optionally, outdoor areas by one or more exterior walls.

classDefinition: A fixture which is used primarily for the collection and, in some cases, disposal of human urine and feces.
parentDefinition: An exchangeable device which can be connected to a plumbing system to deliver and drain water.
classComment: "disposal" may not be the most precise way to describe fill-in latrines. Note that no assertion is made on whether these fixtures are in- or outdoors.

classDefinition: A portion of carbon nanotube enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of carbon nanotubes.
parentDefinition: A portion of enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of some material entity.
classComment: Logical definition will be created pending import of "carbon nanotube" from CHEBI
parentComment: This could be demoted to an inferred class if issues with double inheritance arise.

classDefinition: A rocky shore is an intertidal area of a seacoast where solid rock is the predominant substrate.
parentDefinition: The area of the foreshore and seabed that is exposed to the air at low tide and submerged at high tide, i.e., the area between tide marks.
classComment: This label is usually used to refer to 'rocky intertidal shores', i.e. a marine environment. Other types of rocky shore should be requested explicitly. Additionally, "rocky" could be a quality, this would link this with rocky deserts etc.
parentComment: Very similar to the "marine eulittoral zone" class, but without reference to seasonal tide marks. Some sources make no distinction between these zones, thus, they are currently related synonyms.

classDefinition: A burrow is a hole or tunnel excavated into the ground by an animal to create a space suitable for habitation, temporary refuge, or as a byproduct of locomotion
parentDefinition: An underground or underwater passage.
classComment: Should be better defined logically aggregating 'hole' or 'tunnel' with some sort of relation to 'habitation' etc.

classDefinition: Particulate environmental material in which small portions of solid material are surrounded by water.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is composed primarily of particles.

classDefinition: A lava field is an expanse of flat-lying lava flows. Such features are generally composed of highly fluid basalt lava, and can extend for tens or even hundreds of miles across the underlying terrain.
parentDefinition: An unbroken expanse (as of ice)
parentComment: This class was created to accommodate "fields" from agricultural fields to marine mesoscale eddy fields. Thus, it has a very broad definition which makes it less than informative when annotating. Please consider using or requesting an appropriate subclass.

classDefinition: A lava flow is a moving outpouring of lava, which is created during a non-explosive effusive eruption.
parentDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which is continuous and is delimited by physical discontinuities or non-liquid boundaries.

classDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which is continuous and is delimited by physical discontinuities or non-liquid boundaries.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of liquid material.

classDefinition: An effusive eruption is a volcanic eruption during which lava flows onto the ground.
parentDefinition: A volcanic eruption is a process during which lava, tephra (ash, lapilli, volcanic bombs and blocks), and assorted gases are expelled from a volcanic vent or fissure.

classDefinition: A volcano which has been formed as a result of the eruption of andesitic lava.
parentDefinition: An opening, or rupture, in the Earth's surface or crust, which allows hot, molten rock, ash and gases to escape from deep below the surface.

classDefinition: Andesite is an extrusive igneous, volcanic rock, of intermediate composition, with aphanitic to porphyritic texture.
parentDefinition: Rock formed from molten magma.
classComment: In a general sense, it is the intermediate type between basalt and dacite, and ranges from 57 to 63 percent silicon dioxide as illustrated in TAS diagrams. The mineral assemblage is typically dominated by plagioclase plus pyroxene and/or hornblende. Magnetite, zircon, apatite, ilmenite, biotite, and garnet are common accessory minerals. Alkali feldspar may be present in minor amounts.

classDefinition: A volcano which has been formed as a result of the eruption of dacitic lava.
parentDefinition: An opening, or rupture, in the Earth's surface or crust, which allows hot, molten rock, ash and gases to escape from deep below the surface.

classDefinition: Dacite is an igneous, volcanic rock. It has an aphanitic to porphyritic texture and is intermediate in composition between andesite and rhyolite.  Dacite consists mostly of plagioclase feldspar with biotite, hornblende, and pyroxene (augite and/or enstatite). It has quartz as rounded, corroded phenocrysts, or as an element of the ground-mass. The plagioclase ranges from oligoclase to andesine and labradorite. Sanidine occurs, although in small proportions, in some dacites, and when abundant gives rise to rocks that form transitions to the rhyolites.
parentDefinition: Rock formed from molten magma.

classDefinition: Lava which is high in silica and low in alkali metal oxides.
parentDefinition: Lava is a mixture of molten or semi-molten rock, volatiles, and solids which has extruded beyond a planetary crust.
classComment: Rapid solidification of this lava forms dacite.
parentComment: Some use 'lava' to refer to rock that is formed when lava cools. This is not the intended meaning of this class. See 'igneous rock' or similar.

classDefinition: An accumulation of a salt, typically sodium chloride.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

A mineral material is an environmental material which is primarily composed of some substance that is naturally occurring, solid and stable at room temperature, representable by a chemical formula, usually abiogenic, and that has an ordered atomic structure.

classDefinition: An ecosystem which has been subject to a perturbation, that is, the ecosystem has undergone a pronounced change in response to a change in environmental conditions or other perturbation.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
classComment: This is often used by plant collectors when early successional species are observed in an area.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classDefinition: A ravine is a small, narrow, steep-sided valley that is larger than a gully and smaller than a canyon and that is usually worn by running water.
parentDefinition: A depression which has been formed as a result of erosion by water or ice and which is low-lying, bordered by higher ground, and especially elongate.
parentComment: Valleys are typically located between hills our mountains.

classDefinition: A grassland which contains a mixture of tall and short grasses.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem in which grasses (Graminae) are the dominant form of vegetation and determine the system's structure and dynamics.

classDefinition: A mass of salt which has erupted onto a planetary surface, usually through sedimentary rock.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A mass of salt which has erupted onto a planetary surface, usually through sedimentary rock.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of a salt, typically sodium chloride.

classDefinition: Atmospheric carbon dioxide is an environmental material composed of carbon dioxide in its gaseous form present in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A material entity which is composed of one or more chemical entities and has neither independent shape nor volume but tends to expand indefinitely.
classComment: This could also be considered a part of an environmental material like air.

classDefinition: The disposition of an environmental system to sequester and store carbon.
parentDefinition: The disposition of an environmental system to sequester and store some material entity.

classDefinition: The disposition of an environmental system to sequester and store some material entity.
parentDefinition: A disposition which is realised by an environmental system or system parts thereof.
parentComment: This class and its subclasses are experimental and are being developed with NCEAS use cases in mind.

classDefinition: The disposition of an environment to sequester carbon dioxide, subsequently storing the carbon component thereof.
parentDefinition: The disposition of an environmental system to sequester and store carbon.

classDefinition: A concrete masonry unit is a large, rectangular masonry unit primarily composed of concrete.
parentDefinition: A masonry unit is a solid piece of material, usually with a regular shape, used as a component in the construction of buildings. Masonry units are usually composed of brick, stone, marble, granite, travertine, limestone, cast stone, concrete block, glass block, stucco, tile, or cob.

classDefinition: A masonry unit is a solid piece of material, usually with a regular shape, used as a component in the construction of buildings. Masonry units are usually composed of brick, stone, marble, granite, travertine, limestone, cast stone, concrete block, glass block, stucco, tile, or cob.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: Concrete is a composite material composed of an aggregate bonded together with a fluid cement which hardens over time.
parentDefinition: Anthropogenic material in or on which organisms may live.
classComment: Missing the class for "aggregate" - tricky to define what it is, exactly. Again, seems more like some sort of material/disposition hybrid.

classDefinition: Masonry cement is a substance used in construction that has the disposition to set and harden and thus may be used to bind materials together.
parentDefinition: Anthropogenic material in or on which organisms may live.
classComment: "Cement" refers more to a disposition than a specific material.

classDefinition: Asphaltic concrete is a concrete which uses refined asphalt as a cement.
parentDefinition: Concrete is a composite material composed of an aggregate bonded together with a fluid cement which hardens over time.
parentComment: Missing the class for "aggregate" - tricky to define what it is, exactly. Again, seems more like some sort of material/disposition hybrid.

classDefinition: Refined asphalt is a sticky, black, and highly viscous liquid or semi-solid with a boiling point above 500 degrees Celsius, obtained from the fractional distillation of crude oil.
parentDefinition: Anthropogenic material in or on which organisms may live.

classDefinition: Refined asphalt is a sticky, black, and highly viscous liquid or semi-solid with a boiling point above 500 degrees Celsius, obtained from the fractional distillation of crude oil.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a liquid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: most of its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: Refined asphalt is a sticky, black, and highly viscous liquid or semi-solid with a boiling point above 500 degrees Celsius, obtained from the fractional distillation of crude oil.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: Asphalt also known as bitumen is a sticky, black, and highly viscous liquid or semi-solid form of petroleum.
parentDefinition: A naturally occurring flammable liquid consisting of a complex mixture of hydrocarbons of various molecular weights and other liquid organic compounds, that are found in geologic formations beneath the planetary surfaces.
classComment: This class refers to naturally-occuring asphalt or bitumen.

classDefinition: Hydraulic cement is a masonry cement which contains activated aluminium silicates or pozzolans, such as fly ash, allowing it to set in wet conditions or underwater.
parentDefinition: Masonry cement is a substance used in construction that has the disposition to set and harden and thus may be used to bind materials together.
parentComment: "Cement" refers more to a disposition than a specific material.

classDefinition: Non-hydraulic cement is a cement which sets by reacting with carbon dioxide in the air and will not set in wet conditions or underwater. It is susceptible to attack by aggresive chemicals after setting.
parentDefinition: Masonry cement is a substance used in construction that has the disposition to set and harden and thus may be used to bind materials together.
parentComment: "Cement" refers more to a disposition than a specific material.

classDefinition: Building walls are bulding parts which serve to support roofs, floors and ceilings; enclose a space as part of the building envelope; give buildings form; and to provide shelter and security.
parentDefinition: A building part is a construction which is part of a building.
classComment: This is a building part and not the same as a standalone wall, which is a building in its own right.
parentComment: Not recommended for annotation. This class is likely to be made into an inferred class as its subclasses are distributed among more meaningful superclasses (i.e. ceiling is_a surface layer). See for example, "building floor". The boundaries between building parts may be bona fide or fiat.

classDefinition: A boundary wall is a constructed barrier which is usually opaque, constructed from masonry, and of greater structural strength than a fence.
parentDefinition: A constructed barrier is a freestanding wall, berm, or fence built to limit movement of entities across a boundary.
classComment: This is not the same as a wall that is part of a building. use ENVO:01000420 for the latter.

classDefinition: A fence is a constructed barrier which is  generally of lighter construction than a wall and used to provide visual sectioning of spaces.
parentDefinition: A constructed barrier is a freestanding wall, berm, or fence built to limit movement of entities across a boundary.

classDefinition: An exterior wall is a building wall which separates the interior of a building from the buildings surrounding environment.
parentDefinition: Building walls are bulding parts which serve to support roofs, floors and ceilings; enclose a space as part of the building envelope; give buildings form; and to provide shelter and security.
parentComment: This is a building part and not the same as a standalone wall, which is a building in its own right.

classDefinition:
A building envelope is a building part composed of those building parts which physically separate the interior of a building from its surrounding environment.
The building envelope provides resistance to air, water, heat, light, and noise transfer. The three basic elements of a building envelope are a weather barrier, air barrier, and thermal barrier.
parentDefinition: A building part is a construction which is part of a building.
parentComment: Not recommended for annotation. This class is likely to be made into an inferred class as its subclasses are distributed among more meaningful superclasses (i.e. ceiling is_a surface layer). See for example, "building floor". The boundaries between building parts may be bona fide or fiat.

classDefinition: A roof is the covering on the uppermost part of a building which provides protection from animals and weather, notably rain, but also heat, wind and sunlight. A roof is also the framing or structure which supports the covering
parentDefinition: A building part is a construction which is part of a building.
classComment: This class is meant to represent roofs which are parts of buildings, rather than a roofs of cave and other natural formations.
parentComment: Not recommended for annotation. This class is likely to be made into an inferred class as its subclasses are distributed among more meaningful superclasses (i.e. ceiling is_a surface layer). See for example, "building floor". The boundaries between building parts may be bona fide or fiat.

parentDefinition: A building part is a construction which is part of a building.
parentComment: Not recommended for annotation. This class is likely to be made into an inferred class as its subclasses are distributed among more meaningful superclasses (i.e. ceiling is_a surface layer). See for example, "building floor". The boundaries between building parts may be bona fide or fiat.

classDefinition: Thatch is material composed of dry vegetation such as straw, water reed, sedge (Cladium mariscus), rushes, or heather.
classComment:
Some sort of logical definition towards:
composed_primarily_of some ((straw or 'water reed' or rushes or sedge or heather) and has_quality dry)
should be considered, where "rushes", "sedge", etc are represented as materials rather than some sort of taxon.
parentComment: This is quite odd and it probably should be obsoleted. Any material that is a participant in an agricultural process can be seen as an agricultural material.

classDefinition: A portion of brick material is a material derived from a brick which is composed of  kneaded clay-bearing soil, expanded clay aggregate, sand and lime, or concrete that has been fire-hardened or air-dried.
parentDefinition: Anthropogenic material in or on which organisms may live.

classDefinition: A portion of brick material is a material derived from a brick which is composed of  kneaded clay-bearing soil, expanded clay aggregate, sand and lime, or concrete that has been fire-hardened or air-dried.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: A portion of brick material is a material derived from a brick which is composed of  kneaded clay-bearing soil, expanded clay aggregate, sand and lime, or concrete that has been fire-hardened or air-dried.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A brick is a masonry unit which is composed of kneaded clay-bearing soil, expanded clay aggregate, sand and lime, or concrete material, fire-hardened or air-dried.
parentDefinition: A masonry unit is a solid piece of material, usually with a regular shape, used as a component in the construction of buildings. Masonry units are usually composed of brick, stone, marble, granite, travertine, limestone, cast stone, concrete block, glass block, stucco, tile, or cob.
classComment: Generally used to refer to the masonry unit rather than a material.

classDefinition: Plaster is a building material which has the disposition to harden when it reacts with water, liberating heat through crystallization. Plaster is manufactured as a dry powder and is mixed with water to form a paste when used.
parentDefinition: Anthropogenic material in or on which organisms may live.

classDefinition: Gypsum plaster is a plaster which is formed by partially dehydrating gypsum by heating it to approximately 150 degrees Celsius and grinding the product into a powder. Gypsum anhydride - formed by heating gypsum above 200 degrees Celsius - may also be used as plaster.
parentDefinition: Plaster is a building material which has the disposition to harden when it reacts with water, liberating heat through crystallization. Plaster is manufactured as a dry powder and is mixed with water to form a paste when used.

Plaster is a building material which has the disposition to harden when it reacts with water, liberating heat through crystallization. Plaster is manufactured as a dry powder and is mixed with water to form a paste when used.

classDefinition: Lime plaster is a plaster which is primarily composed of calcium hydroxide and an inert filler (such as sand). Coversion of the calcium hydroxide to calcium carbonate through a reaction with carbon dioxide in the air causes the plaster to set.
parentDefinition: Plaster is a building material which has the disposition to harden when it reacts with water, liberating heat through crystallization. Plaster is manufactured as a dry powder and is mixed with water to form a paste when used.

classDefinition: Glass is an amorphous (non-crystalline) solid which is often transparent.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
classComment: This class refers to all forms of glass. For the familiar form present in window panes and drinking glasses, consider silica-based glass.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: Soda-lime glass is a silica-based glass which is composed of approximately 75% silicon dioxide, with sodium oxide and calcium oxide consituting most of its remaining composition.
parentDefinition: Silica-based glass is a glass composed primarily of silicon dioxide, the primary constituent of sand.
classComment: This type of glass constitutes 90% of manufactured glass.
parentComment: Silica-based glasses are the most common manufactured variety of glass.

classDefinition: Flat glass is a soda-lime glass which is composed of approximately 73% silicon dioxide (silica), 14% sodium oxide, 9% calcium oxide, 4% magnesium oxide, 0.15% aluminium oxide, 0.03% potassium oxide, 0.02% titanum dioxide, and 0.01% iron III oxide.
parentDefinition: Soda-lime glass is a silica-based glass which is composed of approximately 75% silicon dioxide, with sodium oxide and calcium oxide consituting most of its remaining composition.
classComment: Most flat glass is soda-lime glass produced by the float glass process. It is more water soluble than container glass.
parentComment: This type of glass constitutes 90% of manufactured glass.

classDefinition: Container glass is a soda-lime glass which is composed of approximately 74% silicon dioxide (silica), 13% sodium oxide, 10.5% calcium oxide, 1.3% aluminium oxide, 0.3% potassium oxide, 0.2% sulphur trioxide, 0.2% magnesium oxide,  0.04% iron III oxide, and 0.01%  titanum dioxide.
parentDefinition: Soda-lime glass is a silica-based glass which is composed of approximately 75% silicon dioxide, with sodium oxide and calcium oxide consituting most of its remaining composition.
classComment: Container glass is less water soluble than flat glass.
parentComment: This type of glass constitutes 90% of manufactured glass.

classDefinition: Quartz glass is a glass which is composed of silica in amorphous (non-crystalline) form.
parentDefinition: Silica-based glass is a glass composed primarily of silicon dioxide, the primary constituent of sand.
classComment: This is "pure" silica glass. As an ENVO:"environmental material" this class assumes that there remains some possibility that 'contaminants' being present.
parentComment: Silica-based glasses are the most common manufactured variety of glass.

classDefinition: A building floor is a surface layer which is part of a building and used for walking.
parentDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of solid environmental material.
classComment: To be more precise, a subfloor and a floor covering may be specified. Please request these classes and propose definitions if they are needed.

classDefinition: A building floor is a surface layer which is part of a building and used for walking.
parentDefinition: A surface layer where the solid or liquid material of an astronomical body comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
classComment: To be more precise, a subfloor and a floor covering may be specified. Please request these classes and propose definitions if they are needed.
parentComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities

classDefinition: A building floor is a surface layer which is part of a building and used for walking.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.
classComment: To be more precise, a subfloor and a floor covering may be specified. Please request these classes and propose definitions if they are needed.

classDefinition: A brick building floor is a building floor that is composed primarily of brick material or is built from bricks.
parentDefinition: A building floor is a surface layer which is part of a building and used for walking.
parentComment: To be more precise, a subfloor and a floor covering may be specified. Please request these classes and propose definitions if they are needed.

classDefinition: A wooden building floor is a building floor that is composed primarily of wood.
parentDefinition: A building floor is a surface layer which is part of a building and used for walking.
parentComment: To be more precise, a subfloor and a floor covering may be specified. Please request these classes and propose definitions if they are needed.

classDefinition: A wooden building floor is a building floor that is composed primarily of wood.
parentDefinition: A surface layer through which liquids or gases cannot pass.

classDefinition: A surface layer through which liquids or gases cannot pass.
parentDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of solid environmental material.

classDefinition: A concrete building floor is a building floor that is composed primarily of concrete
parentDefinition: A building floor is a surface layer which is part of a building and used for walking.
classComment: At times, this is called a cement floor, although that is probably not accurate.
parentComment: To be more precise, a subfloor and a floor covering may be specified. Please request these classes and propose definitions if they are needed.

classDefinition: A concrete building floor is a building floor that is composed primarily of concrete
parentDefinition: A surface layer through which liquids or gases cannot pass.
classComment: At times, this is called a cement floor, although that is probably not accurate.

classDefinition: A sandy building floor is a building floor that is composed primarily of sand.
parentDefinition: A building floor is a surface layer which is part of a building and used for walking.
parentComment: To be more precise, a subfloor and a floor covering may be specified. Please request these classes and propose definitions if they are needed.

classDefinition: A glass building floor is a building floor which is composed primarily of glass.
parentDefinition: A building floor is a surface layer which is part of a building and used for walking.
parentComment: To be more precise, a subfloor and a floor covering may be specified. Please request these classes and propose definitions if they are needed.

classDefinition: A glass building floor is a building floor which is composed primarily of glass.
parentDefinition: A surface layer through which liquids or gases cannot pass.

classDefinition: A dung building floor is a building floor which is composed primarily of dried animal feces.
parentDefinition: A building floor is a surface layer which is part of a building and used for walking.
parentComment: To be more precise, a subfloor and a floor covering may be specified. Please request these classes and propose definitions if they are needed.

classDefinition: A stone building floor is a building floor that is composed primarily of rock.
parentDefinition: A building floor is a surface layer which is part of a building and used for walking.
parentComment: To be more precise, a subfloor and a floor covering may be specified. Please request these classes and propose definitions if they are needed.

classDefinition: A stone building floor is a building floor that is composed primarily of rock.
parentDefinition: A surface layer through which liquids or gases cannot pass.

classDefinition: A thatched exterior wall is an exterior wall that is composed primarily of thatch.
parentDefinition: An exterior wall is a building wall which separates the interior of a building from the buildings surrounding environment.

classDefinition: A stone exterior wall is an exterior wall that is composed primarily of rock.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

classDefinition: A stone exterior wall is an exterior wall that is composed primarily of rock.
parentDefinition: An exterior wall is a building wall which separates the interior of a building from the buildings surrounding environment.

classDefinition: A straw exterior wall is an exterior wall that is composed primarily of straw.
parentDefinition: An exterior wall is a building wall which separates the interior of a building from the buildings surrounding environment.

classDefinition: A mud exterior wall is an exterior wall that is composed primarily of mud.
parentDefinition: An exterior wall is a building wall which separates the interior of a building from the buildings surrounding environment.

classDefinition: A solid, cylindrical object or column with its length greater than its diameter.
