classComment: This was created in response to a user request, but it is an odd class in that it specifies a shape rather than a particular material entity. It may, therefore, be deprecated when more meaningful or sensible alternatives become apparent.

classDefinition: A pole-reinforced mud exterior wall is a mud exterior wall which is supported and reinforced by poles.
parentDefinition: A mud exterior wall is an exterior wall that is composed primarily of mud.

classDefinition: A brick exterior wall is an exterior wall that is built from bricks.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

classDefinition: A brick exterior wall is an exterior wall that is built from bricks.
parentDefinition: An exterior wall is a building wall which separates the interior of a building from the buildings surrounding environment.

classDefinition: A burnt brick is a brick which has been dried at an elvated temperature in a kiln, furnace, or with similar technology .
parentDefinition: A brick is a masonry unit which is composed of kneaded clay-bearing soil, expanded clay aggregate, sand and lime, or concrete material, fire-hardened or air-dried.
parentComment: Generally used to refer to the masonry unit rather than a material.

classDefinition: An unburnt brick is a brick which has been air dried rather than dried at an elvated temperature in a kiln, furnace, or with similar technology .
parentDefinition: A brick is a masonry unit which is composed of kneaded clay-bearing soil, expanded clay aggregate, sand and lime, or concrete material, fire-hardened or air-dried.
parentComment: Generally used to refer to the masonry unit rather than a material.

classDefinition: A burnt brick exterior wall is an exterior wall that is built from burnt bricks.
parentDefinition: A brick exterior wall is an exterior wall that is built from bricks.

classDefinition: An unburnt brick exterior wall is an exterior wall that is built from unburnt bricks.
parentDefinition: A brick exterior wall is an exterior wall that is built from bricks.

classDefinition: A dome-shaped mass of salt formed when a thick bed of evaporite minerals (mainly salt, or halite) found at depth intrudes vertically into surrounding rock strata, forming a diapir.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A dome-shaped mass of salt formed when a thick bed of evaporite minerals (mainly salt, or halite) found at depth intrudes vertically into surrounding rock strata, forming a diapir.
parentDefinition: A landform elevated above the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A dome-shaped mass of salt formed when a thick bed of evaporite minerals (mainly salt, or halite) found at depth intrudes vertically into surrounding rock strata, forming a diapir.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of a salt, typically sodium chloride.

classDefinition: A concrete exterior wall is an exterior wall that is composed primarily of concrete.
parentDefinition: An exterior wall is a building wall which separates the interior of a building from the buildings surrounding environment.

classDefinition: An iron sheet is a mass of iron which has been forged into a roughly planar form of less than 6 millimetres in thickness.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A sheet-iron exterior wall is an exterior wall that is built from sheets of iron.
parentDefinition: An exterior wall is a building wall which separates the interior of a building from the buildings surrounding environment.

classDefinition: A sheet-iron building roof is a building roof that is built from sheets of iron.
parentDefinition: A roof is the covering on the uppermost part of a building which provides protection from animals and weather, notably rain, but also heat, wind and sunlight. A roof is also the framing or structure which supports the covering
parentComment: This class is meant to represent roofs which are parts of buildings, rather than a roofs of cave and other natural formations.

classDefinition: A thatched building roof is a building roof that is built by thatching (or out of thatch).
parentDefinition: A roof is the covering on the uppermost part of a building which provides protection from animals and weather, notably rain, but also heat, wind and sunlight. A roof is also the framing or structure which supports the covering
parentComment: This class is meant to represent roofs which are parts of buildings, rather than a roofs of cave and other natural formations.

classDefinition: A wooden building roof is a building roof that is built from wood.
parentDefinition: A roof is the covering on the uppermost part of a building which provides protection from animals and weather, notably rain, but also heat, wind and sunlight. A roof is also the framing or structure which supports the covering
parentComment: This class is meant to represent roofs which are parts of buildings, rather than a roofs of cave and other natural formations.

classDefinition: An asbestos building roof is a building roof that is built from asbestos.
parentDefinition: A roof is the covering on the uppermost part of a building which provides protection from animals and weather, notably rain, but also heat, wind and sunlight. A roof is also the framing or structure which supports the covering
classComment: asbestos exists in CHEBI and will be imported to complete this class' logical def.
parentComment: This class is meant to represent roofs which are parts of buildings, rather than a roofs of cave and other natural formations.

classDefinition: A tile is a manufactured piece of hard-wearing material such as ceramic, stone, metal, or even glass, generally used for covering roofs, floors, walls, showers, or other objects such as tabletops. Alternatively, tile can sometimes refer to similar units made from lightweight materials such as perlite, wood, and mineral wool, typically used for wall and ceiling applications.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A tile building roof is a building roof that is built using tiles.
parentDefinition: A roof is the covering on the uppermost part of a building which provides protection from animals and weather, notably rain, but also heat, wind and sunlight. A roof is also the framing or structure which supports the covering
parentComment: This class is meant to represent roofs which are parts of buildings, rather than a roofs of cave and other natural formations.

classDefinition: An exchangeable device which can be connected to a plumbing system to deliver and drain water.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A pit latrine is a latrine which is constructed by digging a hole in the ground.
parentDefinition: A latrine is a toilet which is of simple construction (relative to a flush or chemical toilet) and typically intended for communal use.
classComment: This class refers to human latrines. Note that some pit latrines can use pour-flush mechanisms. "Infectious diarrhea resulted in about 0.7 million deaths in children under five years old in 2011 and 250 million lost school days.[4][5] Pit latrines are the lowest cost method of separating feces from people.[3]" - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pit_latrine
parentComment: This class refers to human latrines.

classDefinition: A latrine is a toilet which is of simple construction (relative to a flush or chemical toilet) and typically intended for communal use.
parentDefinition: A fixture which is used primarily for the collection and, in some cases, disposal of human urine and feces.
classComment: This class refers to human latrines.
parentComment: "disposal" may not be the most precise way to describe fill-in latrines. Note that no assertion is made on whether these fixtures are in- or outdoors.

classDefinition: A latrine pit is an artificial hole or cavity in the ground used to collect human excreta.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.
classComment: A latrine pit is typically at least 3 metres (10 feet) deep and 1 metre (3.2 feet) across.

classDefinition: A latrine pit is an artificial hole or cavity in the ground used to collect human excreta.
parentDefinition: A depression in the ground resembling a hole or cavity, either natural or anthropogenic.
classComment: A latrine pit is typically at least 3 metres (10 feet) deep and 1 metre (3.2 feet) across.

classDefinition: A diapir is a type of geologic intrusion in which a more mobile and ductily deformable material is forced into brittle overlying rocks due to its higher buoyancy.
parentDefinition: An intrusion which is primarily composed of rock which has been formed within a pre-existing fracture in a larger mass of rock.
parentComment: While some intrusions are still located in the fracture where they formed, others may be (partially) exposed by erosional processes.

classDefinition: An intrusion which is primarily composed of rock which has been formed within a pre-existing fracture in a larger mass of rock.
parentDefinition: A mass of environmental material which has been formed as the result of its transport into an existing mass of another material.
classComment: While some intrusions are still located in the fracture where they formed, others may be (partially) exposed by erosional processes.

classDefinition: A latrine slab is a  broad, flat, thick piece of solid material (typically stone or concrete) used as the floor of a latrine and which includes a hole through which excreta are deposited into a latrine pit.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.
classComment:
This could be moved to "surface layer" like other floors, although more thought has to be given to "floor": a role of a surface layer?
"The hole in the slab should not be larger than 25 centimeters (9.8 inches) to prevent children falling in." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pit_latrine

classDefinition: A structure quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's delimited by a surface with holes.
parentDefinition: A morphology quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's relative position, shape, arrangements and connectivity of an organism's various parts; the pattern underlying its form.

classDefinition: A batholith is an area of mostly continuous plutonic (igneous intrusive) rock that covers an area larger than 100 square kilometers, formed in the planetary crust, and exposed by erosion. On Earth, Batholiths are almost always made mostly of felsic or intermediate rock-types, such as granite, quartz monzonite, or diorite.
parentDefinition: An igneous intrusion is a mass of rock and minerals formed when magma cools, solidifies, and undergoes fractional crystallisation without reaching the surface.
parentComment: "Intrusion" can refer to the solidified mass or the molten rock.

classDefinition: A process whereby rising magma cools and solidifies without reaching the surface. Instead, the cooled and solidified igneous mass crystallises within the crust to form an igneous intrusion.
parentDefinition: A process whereby the precursors of rock, such as magma or sedimentary particles, fill a fracture in a mass of rock.

classDefinition: A depression in the ground resembling a hole or cavity, either natural or anthropogenic.
parentDefinition: A landform sunken or depressed below the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A pit latrine with a slab floor is a pit latrine which has a latrine slab as a floor.
parentDefinition: A pit latrine is a latrine which is constructed by digging a hole in the ground.
classComment: This class refers to human latrines. "Infectious diarrhea resulted in about 0.7 million deaths in children under five years old in 2011 and 250 million lost school days.[4][5] Pit latrines are the lowest cost method of separating feces from people.[3]" - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pit_latrine
parentComment: This class refers to human latrines. Note that some pit latrines can use pour-flush mechanisms. "Infectious diarrhea resulted in about 0.7 million deaths in children under five years old in 2011 and 250 million lost school days.[4][5] Pit latrines are the lowest cost method of separating feces from people.[3]" - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pit_latrine

classDefinition: An outhouse is a small structure, separate from a main building, which covers a pit latrine or a dry toilet.
parentDefinition: A permanent walled and roofed construction.
classComment: "Outside North America, the term "outhouse" refers not to a toilet but to outbuildings in a general sense."

classDefinition: A mass of environmental material which has been formed as the result of its transport into an existing mass of another material.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

classDefinition: A process whereby the precursors of rock, such as magma or sedimentary particles, fill a fracture in a mass of rock.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: A rock intrusion which is composed primarily of sedimentary rock.
parentDefinition: An intrusion which is primarily composed of rock which has been formed within a pre-existing fracture in a larger mass of rock.
parentComment: While some intrusions are still located in the fracture where they formed, others may be (partially) exposed by erosional processes.

classDefinition: A toilet fixture which uses water to flush liquid and solid excreta into a sewage containment or processing facility through a drainpipe.
parentDefinition: A fixture which is used primarily for the collection and, in some cases, disposal of human urine and feces.
parentComment: "disposal" may not be the most precise way to describe fill-in latrines. Note that no assertion is made on whether these fixtures are in- or outdoors.

classDefinition: A toilet fixture which uses little to no water; excreta is removed manually or composted in situ.
parentDefinition: A fixture which is used primarily for the collection and, in some cases, disposal of human urine and feces.
classComment: Subclasses will probably be filled in by inference.
parentComment: "disposal" may not be the most precise way to describe fill-in latrines. Note that no assertion is made on whether these fixtures are in- or outdoors.

classDefinition: A chemical toilet fixture is a toilet fixture which uses chemicals to deodorise and treat excreta which is stored in the fixture.
parentDefinition: A fixture which is used primarily for the collection and, in some cases, disposal of human urine and feces.
classComment: "In the past, disinfection was generally carried out by mixing formaldehyde, bleach or similar chemicals with the toilet water when flushed...[F]ormaldehyde is very irritating to the eyes, ears, skin, nose, and throat, it is being replaced by other proprietary blends such as glutaraldehyde and quaternary ammonium compounds, with non-staining dyes and nature-identical perfume oils. Additionally, enzyme hybrids are sometimes used." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemical_toilet
parentComment: "disposal" may not be the most precise way to describe fill-in latrines. Note that no assertion is made on whether these fixtures are in- or outdoors.

classDefinition: A ventilated improved pit latrine is a pit latrine which includes a vent pipe fitted to the pit with a flyscreen covering the pipe's outlet. Air currents moving across the outlet of the vent pipe create a vaccum which draws odors out of the latrine's superstructure.
parentDefinition: A pit latrine is a latrine which is constructed by digging a hole in the ground.
parentComment: This class refers to human latrines. Note that some pit latrines can use pour-flush mechanisms. "Infectious diarrhea resulted in about 0.7 million deaths in children under five years old in 2011 and 250 million lost school days.[4][5] Pit latrines are the lowest cost method of separating feces from people.[3]" - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pit_latrine

classDefinition: A covered latrine is a building which comprises a latrine sheltered by an outhouse.
parentDefinition: A permanent walled and roofed construction.

classDefinition: A covered pit latrine is a building which comprises a pit latrine sheltered by an outhouse.
parentDefinition: A covered latrine is a building which comprises a latrine sheltered by an outhouse.

classLabel: covered pit latrine with slab floor
classDefinition: A covered pit latrine with slab is a building which comprises a pit latrine with a slab floor sheltered by an outhouse.
parentDefinition: A covered pit latrine is a building which comprises a pit latrine sheltered by an outhouse.

classDefinition: A flush toilet fixture into which water is manually poured to dispose of excreta.
parentDefinition: A toilet fixture which uses water to flush liquid and solid excreta into a sewage containment or processing facility through a drainpipe.

classDefinition: A pit latrine which includes a water seal (U-trap or siphon) used over one or two offset pits instead of a plain hole or seat. Water is manually poured through the trap to flush excreta into the latrine pit.
parentDefinition: A pit latrine is a latrine which is constructed by digging a hole in the ground.
parentComment: This class refers to human latrines. Note that some pit latrines can use pour-flush mechanisms. "Infectious diarrhea resulted in about 0.7 million deaths in children under five years old in 2011 and 250 million lost school days.[4][5] Pit latrines are the lowest cost method of separating feces from people.[3]" - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pit_latrine

classDefinition: A factory (previously manufactory) or manufacturing plant is an industrial site, usually consisting of buildings and machinery, or more commonly a complex having several buildings, where workers manufacture goods or operate machines processing one product into another.
parentDefinition: An industrial building is a building within which goods are produced and, optionally, stored or within which services are rendered.
parentComment: It's possible that this will become an inferred class in the future. The United Nations' International Standard Industrial Classification should be referred to when expanding this branch. ISIC can also be used to identify processes. See http://unstats.un.org/unsd/cr/registry/regcst.asp?Cl=27&Lg=1.

classDefinition: Atmospheric ozone is an environmental material primarily composed of ozone in its gaseous form and present in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A material entity which is composed of one or more chemical entities and has neither independent shape nor volume but tends to expand indefinitely.

classDefinition: The layer of the atmosphere which is sandwiched between the troposphere and mesosphere. Of the energy that reaches the Earth from the sun, only 3% is absorbed in the stratosphere, but that includes the vitally important process of absorption of ultraviolet radiation by the stratospheric ozone layer. The stratosphere is cloudless and dust free, and almost unaffected by the turbulent conditions of the underlying level of the atmosphere. (Source: WRIGHT)
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of the atmosphere.
classComment: Definition from GEMET - will be refined.
parentComment: This could be made into an inferred class, rather than having asserted subclasses.

classDefinition: The mesosphere is part of the earth's atmosphere which is between the stratosphere and the thermosphere in which temperature decreases with altitude to the atmosphere's absolute minimum
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of the atmosphere.
parentComment: This could be made into an inferred class, rather than having asserted subclasses.

classDefinition: The lowest of the concentric layers of the atmosphere, occurring between the Earth's surface and the tropopause. It is the zone where atmospheric turbulence is at its greatest and where the bulk of the Earth's weather is generated. It contains almost all the water vapour and aerosols and three-quarters of the total gaseous mass of the atmosphere. Throughout the troposphere temperature decreases with height at a mean rate of 6.5°C/km and the whole zone is capped by either an inversion of temperature or an isothermal layer at the tropopause. (Source: WHIT)
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of the atmosphere.
classComment: Definition from GEMET - will be refined.
parentComment: This could be made into an inferred class, rather than having asserted subclasses.

classDefinition: The thermosphere is a part of the earth's atmosphere that begins at about 50 miles (80 kilometers) above the earth's surface, extends to outer space, and is characterized by steadily increasing temperature with height
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of the atmosphere.
parentComment: This could be made into an inferred class, rather than having asserted subclasses.

classDefinition: The ozone layer is a layer of gases in the stratosphere which contains high concentrations of ozone gas relative to other parts of the atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of the atmosphere.
classComment: "The ozone layer contains less than 10 parts per million of ozone, while the average ozone concentration in Earth's atmosphere as a whole is only about 0.3 parts per million. The ozone layer is mainly found in the lower portion of the stratosphere, from approximately 20 to 30 kilometres (12 to 19 mi) above Earth, though the thickness varies seasonally and geographically"- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ozone_layer
parentComment: This could be made into an inferred class, rather than having asserted subclasses.

classDefinition: A surface layer which separates two portions of fluid with respect to either 1) a discontinuity of some fluid property or 2) some derivative of one of these properties in a direction normal to the interface.
parentDefinition: A layer which separates two portions of environmental material which possess 1) differing compositions, 2) a discontinuity of some property, or 3) some derivative of some property in a direction normal to the interface.

classDefinition: A surface layer which separates two portions of fluid with respect to either 1) a discontinuity of some fluid property or 2) some derivative of one of these properties in a direction normal to the interface.
parentDefinition: A layer which is composed primarily of some fluid.

classDefinition: The ionosphere is a layer of the Earth's atmosphere which extends from about 60 to 1,000 kilometers above the planetary surface and is ionised by solar radiation. It includes the thermosphere and parts of the mesosphere and exosphere.
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of the atmosphere.
parentComment: This could be made into an inferred class, rather than having asserted subclasses.

classDefinition: The exosphere is an atmospheric layer where molecules are gravitationally bound to a planetary body, but where their density is too low for them to behave as a gas by colliding with each other. In the case of bodies with substantial atmospheres, such as Earth's atmosphere, the exosphere is the uppermost layer, where the atmosphere thins out and merges with interplanetary space. It is located directly above the thermosphere.
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of the atmosphere.
parentComment: This could be made into an inferred class, rather than having asserted subclasses.

classDefinition: A glaze ice layer is a smooth, transparent and homogeneous ice layer which coats some surface and which is formed when freezing rain or drizzle hits that surface.
parentDefinition: A solid layer which is primarily composed of some water-based ice.

classDefinition: A solid layer which is primarily composed of some water-based ice.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous mass of snow and/or ice.

classDefinition: A solid layer which is primarily composed of some water-based ice.
parentDefinition: A layer which is primarily composed of some solid material, allowing for non-solid parts such as interstitial pockets of gas or liquid.

classDefinition: A solid layer which is primarily composed of some water-based ice.
parentDefinition: A layer which is part of a cryosphere.

classDefinition: Water-based rainfall which freezes either 1) on impact with a surface to form a coating of clear ice (glaze) or 2) after percolating through surface layers.
parentDefinition: A hydrological precipitation process in which atmospheric water vapour condenses to form droplets of liquid water massive enough to fall to a planetary surface due to the planet's gravity.
classComment: A surface temperature inversion is usually required. In such an inversion, the surface must have a temperature below freezing, while the temperature of the atmosphere where the precipitation forms is above freezing. Alternately, if the temperature of the ground surface and glazed objects is typically near or below freezing (0C or 32F), it is necessary that the water drops be supercooled before striking. Freezing rain can sometimes occur on surfaces exposed to the air (such as tree limbs) with air temperatures slightly above freezing in strong winds. Local evaporational cooling may result in freezing. Freezing rain frequently occurs, therefore, as a transient condition between the occurrence of rain and ice pellets (sleet). When encountered by an aircraft in flight, freezing rain can cause a dangerous accretion of clear icing. In aviation weather observations, this hydrometeor is encoded ZR by NOAA.
parentComment: This is the process which typically happens on Earth. Other planets may have different liquids involved in the process.

classDefinition: A lake which has nutrient-rich water.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A composting toilet fixture is a dry toilet fixture in which managed, aerobic decomposition converts human excreta into organic matter suitable for the fertilisation or amendment of soils.
parentDefinition: A toilet fixture which uses little to no water; excreta is removed manually or composted in situ.
parentComment: Subclasses will probably be filled in by inference.

classDefinition: A fuel oil which is 1) composed primarily of alkanes having between 5-15 carbon atoms with the general formula CnH2n+2, 2) is generally odorless or has only a slight odor, 3) produces only small amounts of soot relative to other fuel oils, 4) is highly refined.
parentDefinition: An oil which 1) is liquid at room temperature (approximately 20 degrees Celsius) 2) is intended to be burned in a furnace or boiler for the generation of heat or used in an engine for the generation of power, 3) is obtained from petroleum distillation, either as a distillate or a residue, 4) composed of long hydrocarbon chains, particularly alkanes, cycloalkanes and aromatics.
parentComment: Oils having a flash point of approximately 42 degrees Celsius and oils burned in cotton or wool-wick burners are not typically considered fuel oils. The term fuel oil is also used in a stricter sense to refer only to the heaviest commercial fuel that can be obtained from crude oil, i.e., heavier than gasoline and naphtha.

classDefinition: Natural gas is a hydrocarbon gas mixture consisting primarily of methane, but commonly includes varying amounts of other higher alkanes and sometimes a usually lesser percentage of carbon dioxide, nitrogen, and/or hydrogen sulfide. Natural gas is a fossil fuel formed when layers of buried plants and gases are exposed to intense heat and pressure over thousands of years.
parentDefinition: A gas that is primarily composed of hydrocarbon molecules.

classDefinition: A gas that is primarily composed of hydrocarbon molecules.
parentDefinition: A material entity which is composed of one or more chemical entities and has neither independent shape nor volume but tends to expand indefinitely.

classDefinition: A gas that is primarily composed of hydrocarbon molecules.

Liquified petroleum gas or liquid petroleum gas (LPG or LP gas), also referred to as simply propane or butane, are flammable mixtures of hydrocarbon gases used as fuel in heating appliances, cooking equipment, and vehicles.

parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a liquid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: most of its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: Compressed natural gas is a natural gas stored at high pressures, typically 20–25 Megapascals.
parentDefinition: Natural gas is a hydrocarbon gas mixture consisting primarily of methane, but commonly includes varying amounts of other higher alkanes and sometimes a usually lesser percentage of carbon dioxide, nitrogen, and/or hydrogen sulfide. Natural gas is a fossil fuel formed when layers of buried plants and gases are exposed to intense heat and pressure over thousands of years.

classDefinition: Biogas is a mixture of different gases produced by the breakdown of organic matter in the absence of oxygen,  is primarily composed of methane and carbon dioxide, and may have small amounts of hydrogen sulfide, water, and siloxanes.
parentDefinition: A gas that is primarily composed of hydrocarbon molecules.
classComment: This is distinct from natural gas which is a fossil fuel product.

classDefinition: Liquefied natural gas (LNG) is natural gas (predominantly methane, CH4) that has been converted to liquid form for ease of storage or transport. It takes up about 1/600th the volume of natural gas in the gaseous state. It is odorless, colorless, non-toxic and non-corrosive. LNG achieves a higher reduction in volume than compressed natural gas (CNG) so that the (volumetric) energy density of LNG is 2.4 times greater than that of CNG or 60 percent of that of diesel fuel.
A structural quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's being thicker or more closely packed together; pressed tightly together.
parentDefinition: A morphology quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's relative position, shape, arrangements and connectivity of an organism's various parts; the pattern underlying its form.

classDefinition: Compressed biogas is biogas stored at increased pressures.
parentDefinition: Biogas is a mixture of different gases produced by the breakdown of organic matter in the absence of oxygen,  is primarily composed of methane and carbon dioxide, and may have small amounts of hydrogen sulfide, water, and siloxanes.
classComment: This is distinct from compressed natural gas, which refers to the compressed form of a fossil fuel.
parentComment: This is distinct from natural gas which is a fossil fuel product.

classDefinition: Charcoal is a light, black residue, consisting of carbon and any remaining ash, obtained by removing water and other volatile constituents from animal and vegetation substances. Charcoal is usually produced by slow pyrolysis, the heating of wood or other substances in the absence of oxygen.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: Charcoal is a light, black residue, consisting of carbon and any remaining ash, obtained by removing water and other volatile constituents from animal and vegetation substances. Charcoal is usually produced by slow pyrolysis, the heating of wood or other substances in the absence of oxygen.
parentDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.

classDefinition: Charcoal is a light, black residue, consisting of carbon and any remaining ash, obtained by removing water and other volatile constituents from animal and vegetation substances. Charcoal is usually produced by slow pyrolysis, the heating of wood or other substances in the absence of oxygen.
A thermolysis process in which organic material is decomposed in the absence of oxygen.
parentDefinition: A chemical decomposition (the separation of a single chemical compound into its two or more elemental parts or to simpler compounds) caused by heat.

classDefinition: A thermolysis process in which organic material is decomposed in the absence of oxygen.
parentDefinition: A material transformation process during which solid or liquid particles form and are suspended in a mass of air, thus creating an aerosol.

classDefinition: A paraffin lamp is a type of lighting device which burns paraffin to generate light and heat.
parentDefinition: A lamp is an object which generates heat, light, or any other form of radiation.

classDefinition: A lamp is an object which generates heat, light, or any other form of radiation.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A flat-wick lamp is a simple type of paraffin lamp, which burns paraffin drawn up through a wick by capillary action.
parentDefinition: A paraffin lamp is a type of lighting device which burns paraffin to generate light and heat.

classDefinition: A central-draught lamp is a paraffin lamp which burns a parrafin saturated, tubular wick contained between two structural tubes and supplied with oxygen by a central draught of air through the innermost of these tube.
parentDefinition: A paraffin lamp is a type of lighting device which burns paraffin to generate light and heat.

classDefinition: A mantle lamp is a central-draught lamp which includes a pear-shaped, fabric mesh containing thorium or other rare-earth salts placed over the burner. On first use the fabric burns away and the rare-earth salts are converted to oxides, leaving a very fragile structure which incandesces (glows brightly) upon exposure to the heat of the burner flame.
parentDefinition: A central-draught lamp is a paraffin lamp which burns a parrafin saturated, tubular wick contained between two structural tubes and supplied with oxygen by a central draught of air through the innermost of these tube.

classDefinition: A lantern is a portable device or mounted fixture comprising a light source protected by a translucent case.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A paraffin lantern is a lantern which houses a parrafin lamp in a structure of soldered or crimped-together sheet metal stampings and glass or other translucent material.
parentDefinition: A lantern is a portable device or mounted fixture comprising a light source protected by a translucent case.

classDefinition: A tubular paraffin lantern is a paraffin lantern which includes metal tubes in its casing that direct air to the burning wick.
parentDefinition: A paraffin lantern is a lantern which houses a parrafin lamp in a structure of soldered or crimped-together sheet metal stampings and glass or other translucent material.

classDefinition: A dead-flame paraffin lantern is a paraffin lantern which has a wick housed in a glass globe with airflow channelled upwards by vents below the burning wick and an open chimney above it.
parentDefinition: A paraffin lantern is a lantern which houses a parrafin lamp in a structure of soldered or crimped-together sheet metal stampings and glass or other translucent material.

classDefinition: A hot-blast paraffin lantern is a tubular paraffin lantern which collects hot air from the top of the lantern globe and circulates it, through metal tubes, to the burning wick.
parentDefinition: A tubular paraffin lantern is a paraffin lantern which includes metal tubes in its casing that direct air to the burning wick.

classDefinition: A cold-blast paraffin lantern is a tubular paraffin lantern which collects cool air from around the top of the lantern globe and circulates it, through metal tubes, to the burning wick.
parentDefinition: A tubular paraffin lantern is a paraffin lantern which includes metal tubes in its casing that direct air to the burning wick.

classDefinition: An electric lamp is a lamp which produces light from electricity.
parentDefinition: A lamp is an object which generates heat, light, or any other form of radiation.

classDefinition: A battery-powered electric lamp is an electric lamp which draws its power from a device composed of two or more electrochemical cells that convert stored chemical energy into electrical energy.
parentDefinition: An electric lamp is a lamp which produces light from electricity.

classDefinition: A candle is a lamp composed of a wax within which an ignitable wick is embedded.
parentDefinition: A lamp is an object which generates heat, light, or any other form of radiation.

classDefinition: A wax is an environmental material which is primarily composed of lipids or other organic compounds that consist of long alkyl chains. Waxes are are malleable near ambient temperatures and melt at approximately 45 degrees Celsius.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: A wax is an environmental material which is primarily composed of lipids or other organic compounds that consist of long alkyl chains. Waxes are are malleable near ambient temperatures and melt at approximately 45 degrees Celsius.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: An apiary is a place where beehives of honey bees are kept and maintained by beekeepers.
parentComment: As with other classes that are "features", the subclasses of this class are being moved to more informative locations. Their relation to agriculture will be modelled by something more akin to a quality or relation to an agricultural process.

classDefinition: A device capable of receiving and/or transmitting information encoded in electromagnetic radiation through wave modulation.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A cassette deck is a device capable of playing and recording audio compact cassettes.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A television set is a device that combines a tuner, display, and loudspeakers for the purpose of converting digital or analog information signals into moving images and sound.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A telephone is a telecommunications device which converts sound into electronic signals suitable for transmission via cables or other transmission media, and reconverts such signals into sound waves.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A mobile phone is a telephone which transmits sound information to a mobile phone network via radio transmissions.
parentDefinition: A telephone is a telecommunications device which converts sound into electronic signals suitable for transmission via cables or other transmission media, and reconverts such signals into sound waves.

classDefinition: A landline telephone is a telephone which is connected to a telephone network with wires through which electronic signals are carried.
parentDefinition: A telephone is a telecommunications device which converts sound into electronic signals suitable for transmission via cables or other transmission media, and reconverts such signals into sound waves.

classDefinition: A refrigerator is a device which consists of a thermally insulated compartment and a mechanical, chemical, or electronic heat pump that transfers heat from the inside of the fridge to its external environment such that the inside of the fridge is cooled to a temperature below the ambient temperature of the room
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A table is a form of furniture with a flat horizontal upper surface used to support objects, for storage, show, and/or manipulation.
parentDefinition: A piece of furniture is a movable object intended to support various human activities such as seating (e.g., chairs, stools and sofas) and sleeping (e.g., beds).
parentComment: The assumption is that furniture is manufactured, which is arguable. Further, according to Black's Law Dictionary (http://thelawdictionary.org/furniture/) many classes can be subclasses of 'piece of furntiure': "This term includes that which furnishes, or with which anything is furnished or supplied; whatever must be supplied to a house, a room, or the like, to make it habitable, convenient, or agreeable; goods, vessels, utensils, and other appendages necessary or convenient for housekeeping; whatever is added to the interior of a house or apartment, for use or convenience. Bell v. Holding, 27 Ind. 173.The term “furniture” embraces everything about the house that has been usually enjoyed there, including plate, linen, china, and pictures. 1 Endicott v. Endicott, 41N. J. Eq. 96, 3 Atl. 157.The word “furniture” made use of in the disposition of the law. or in the conventions or acts of persons, comprehends only such furniture as is intended for use and ornament of apartments, but not libraries which happen to be there, nor plate. Civ.Code La. art. 477." However, this would eventually be absurd and limit other groupings. Perhaps some sort of 'furnishing' BFO:function would be a better way to handle this.

classDefinition: A piece of furniture is a movable object intended to support various human activities such as seating (e.g., chairs, stools and sofas) and sleeping (e.g., beds).
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.
classComment: The assumption is that furniture is manufactured, which is arguable. Further, according to Black's Law Dictionary (http://thelawdictionary.org/furniture/) many classes can be subclasses of 'piece of furntiure': "This term includes that which furnishes, or with which anything is furnished or supplied; whatever must be supplied to a house, a room, or the like, to make it habitable, convenient, or agreeable; goods, vessels, utensils, and other appendages necessary or convenient for housekeeping; whatever is added to the interior of a house or apartment, for use or convenience. Bell v. Holding, 27 Ind. 173.The term “furniture” embraces everything about the house that has been usually enjoyed there, including plate, linen, china, and pictures. 1 Endicott v. Endicott, 41N. J. Eq. 96, 3 Atl. 157.The word “furniture” made use of in the disposition of the law. or in the conventions or acts of persons, comprehends only such furniture as is intended for use and ornament of apartments, but not libraries which happen to be there, nor plate. Civ.Code La. art. 477." However, this would eventually be absurd and limit other groupings. Perhaps some sort of 'furnishing' BFO:function would be a better way to handle this.

classDefinition: A desk is a table which is intended for information-manipulation tasks, including writing and use of interactive electronics.
parentDefinition: A table is a form of furniture with a flat horizontal upper surface used to support objects, for storage, show, and/or manipulation.
classComment: The intentional nature of this definition is problematic, but the restricted range of activities visited upon a desk is of interest.

classDefinition: A chair is a piece of furniture with a raised surface commonly used to seat a single person.
parentDefinition: A piece of furniture is a movable object intended to support various human activities such as seating (e.g., chairs, stools and sofas) and sleeping (e.g., beds).
classComment: This class, along with benches, stools, and the like, can be grouped under "seating furniture" or similar. However, this is probably better as an inferred class using some sort of BFO:function in the subclass annotation.
parentComment: The assumption is that furniture is manufactured, which is arguable. Civ.Code La. art. 477." However, this would eventually be absurd and limit other groupings. Perhaps some sort of 'furnishing' BFO:function would be a better way to handle this.

classDefinition: A sofa is a bench which is partially or entirely upholstered, and often fitted with springs and tailored cushions.
parentDefinition: A bench is a piece of furniture, on which several people may sit at the same time.

classDefinition: A bench is a piece of furniture, on which several people may sit at the same time.
parentDefinition: A piece of furniture is a movable object intended to support various human activities such as seating (e.g., chairs, stools and sofas) and sleeping (e.g., beds).

classDefinition: A mattress is a mass of material which is able to cushion and support a reclining body and is used as or on a bed.

classDefinition: A bed frame is a piece of furniture which is used to position a mattress and bed base and may include a means of supporting a canopy.
parentDefinition: A piece of furniture is a movable object intended to support various human activities such as seating (e.g., chairs, stools and sofas) and sleeping (e.g., beds).
parentComment: The assumption is that furniture is manufactured, which is arguable. classDefinition: A framed bed is a piece of furniture which is composed of a mattress supported by a bed base and held in place by a bed frame.
parentDefinition: A piece of furniture is a movable object intended to support various human activities such as seating (e.g., chairs, stools and sofas) and sleeping (e.g., beds).

classDefinition: A cabinet is a roughly cuboidal piece of furniture which is used to store miscellaneous items in compartments accessible through doors or drawers.
parentDefinition: A piece of furniture is a movable object intended to support various human activities such as seating (e.g., chairs, stools and sofas) and sleeping (e.g., beds).
parentComment: The assumption is that furniture is manufactured, which is arguable. Further, according to Black's Law Dictionary (http://thelawdictionary.org/furniture/) many classes can be subclasses of 'piece of furntiure': "This term includes that which furnishes, or with which anything is furnished or supplied; whatever must be supplied to a house, a room, or the like, to make it habitable, convenient, or agreeable; goods, vessels, utensils, and other appendages necessary or convenient for housekeeping; whatever is added to the interior of a house or apartment, for use or convenience. classDefinition: A cupboard is a cabinet which is used indoors to store household objects such as food, crockery, textiles and liquor, and to protect them from dust and dirt
parentDefinition: A cabinet is a roughly cuboidal piece of furniture which is used to store miscellaneous items in compartments accessible through doors or drawers.

classDefinition: A clock is an instrument which may indicate, keep, and/or co-ordinate time.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A pressure lamp is a portable paraffin or oil lamp in which fuel is forced up into the mantle or burner by air pressure in the reservoir, which can be increased by pumping with a plunger.
parentDefinition: A lamp is an object which generates heat, light, or any other form of radiation.
classComment: This may be a paraffin or an oil lamp. It can potentially be filled by inference if we can express that any lamp with pressurised fuel in the lamp reservoir is a pressure lamp. See Issue #228.

parentDefinition: Water which is part of a stream.

classDefinition: Water which is part of a stream.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: Water which is part of a stream.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

classDefinition: Rainwater is liquid water which has precipitated in the form of droplets through the condensation of atmospheric water vapour.
parentDefinition: Water which has a low concentration of dissolved solutes, particularly that of sodium chloride.
parentComment: The lower bound of solute concentration required for water to be considered freshwater is variable, but is always less than that of seawater, and often cited as less than 1 gram of solutes per 1 litre of water.

classDefinition: Hydrological precipitation is a process during which any product of the condensation of atmospheric water vapour is pulled to the planetary surface by gravity.
parentDefinition: A precipitation process is a process in which a portion of some substance segregates from a material in which that substance or its precursors were dissolved or suspended in and settles due to a force such as gravity or centrifugal force.
classComment: "process" is included in the label to make it clear that we are not referring to the precipitated material (e.g. snow, rain, sleet)

classDefinition: A motor vehicle is a vehicle which is propelled by an engine or motor and that does not operate on rails.
parentDefinition: A vehicle is a mobile machine which transports people or cargo.
classComment: Subclasses will be added by inference.

classDefinition: A vehicle is a mobile machine which transports people or cargo.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A motor is a machine designed to convert one or more forms of energy into mechanical energy.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A truck is a motor vehicle which, as its primary funcion, transports cargo rather than human passangers.
parentDefinition: A motor vehicle is a vehicle which is propelled by an engine or motor and that does not operate on rails.
parentComment: Subclasses will be added by inference.

classDefinition: A water truck is a truck which transports water.
parentDefinition: A truck is a motor vehicle which, as its primary funcion, transports cargo rather than human passangers.

classDefinition: A car is a wheeled motor vehicle used primarily for the transportation of human passengers. Most definitions of the term specify that cars are designed to run primarily on roads, to have seating for one to eight people, to typically have four wheels, and to be constructed principally for the transport of people rather than goods.
parentDefinition: A motor vehicle is a vehicle which is propelled by an engine or motor and that does not operate on rails.
parentComment: Subclasses will be added by inference.

classDefinition: A cart is a vehicle which has two wheels and is designed to transport human passengers or cargo.
parentDefinition: A vehicle is a mobile machine which transports people or cargo.
classComment: NB: "[A cart]...is different from a dray or wagon, which is a heavy transport vehicle with four wheels and typically two or more horses, or a carriage, which is used exclusively for transporting humans...Over time, the term "cart" has come to mean nearly any small conveyance, from shopping carts to golf carts, without regard to number of wheels, load carried, or means of propulsion." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cart

classDefinition: An animal-drawn cart is a cart which is attached to one or more working or draught animals.
parentDefinition: A cart is a vehicle which has two wheels and is designed to transport human passengers or cargo.
parentComment: NB: "[A cart]...is different from a dray or wagon, which is a heavy transport vehicle with four wheels and typically two or more horses, or a carriage, which is used exclusively for transporting humans...Over time, the term "cart" has come to mean nearly any small conveyance, from shopping carts to golf carts, without regard to number of wheels, load carried, or means of propulsion." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cart

classDefinition: A boat is a watercraft of any size which is able to float or plane on water.
parentDefinition: A watercraft is a vehicle which is able to travel on or through water.
classComment: Difficult to distinguish from "ships". Similar to mountains and hills. " In naval terms, a boat is a vessel small enough to be carried aboard another vessel (a ship). Another less restrictive definition is a vessel that can be lifted out of the water. Some definitions do not make a distinction in size, as bulk freighters 1,000 feet (300 m) long on the Great Lakes are called oreboats. For reasons of naval tradition, submarines are usually referred to as 'boats' rather than 'ships', regardless of their size and shape." - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boat
parentComment: Ships, boats, hovercraft and submarines are all considered watercraft. The term would normally imply some propulsive capability (whether by sail, oar or engine) and hence is distinct from a simple device that merely floats, such as a log raft. - Wikipedia

classDefinition: A watercraft is a vehicle which is able to travel on or through water.
parentDefinition: A vehicle is a mobile machine which transports people or cargo.
classComment: Ships, boats, hovercraft and submarines are all considered watercraft. The term would normally imply some propulsive capability (whether by sail, oar or engine) and hence is distinct from a simple device that merely floats, such as a log raft. - Wikipedia

classDefinition: A motor boat is a boat which is propelled by a motor.
parentDefinition: A motor vehicle is a vehicle which is propelled by an engine or motor and that does not operate on rails.
parentComment: Subclasses will be added by inference.

classDefinition: A motor boat is a boat which is propelled by a motor.
parentDefinition: A boat is a watercraft of any size which is able to float or plane on water.
parentComment: Difficult to distinguish from "ships". Similar to mountains and hills. " In naval terms, a boat is a vessel small enough to be carried aboard another vessel (a ship). Another less restrictive definition is a vessel that can be lifted out of the water. Some definitions do not make a distinction in size, as bulk freighters 1,000 feet (300 m) long on the Great Lakes are called oreboats. For reasons of naval tradition, submarines are usually referred to as 'boats' rather than 'ships', regardless of their size and shape." - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boat

classDefinition: A bus is a road vehicle designed to carry many passengers.
parentDefinition: A motor vehicle is a vehicle which is propelled by an engine or motor and that does not operate on rails.
parentComment: Subclasses will be added by inference.

classDefinition: A taxicab is a car which may be hired, along with its operator, to transport passengers between locations of their choosing.
parentDefinition: A car is a wheeled motor vehicle used primarily for the transportation of human passengers. Most definitions of the term specify that cars are designed to run primarily on roads, to have seating for one to eight people, to typically have four wheels, and to be constructed principally for the transport of people rather than goods.
classComment: Depth can be added with specifications of BFO:role for both the car and the human operator.

classDefinition: A bicycle is a human-powered, pedal-driven, single-track vehicle, having two wheels attached to a frame, one behind the other.
parentDefinition: A vehicle is a mobile machine which transports people or cargo.

classDefinition: A motorcycle is a two- or three-wheeled motor vehicle.
parentDefinition: A motor vehicle is a vehicle which is propelled by an engine or motor and that does not operate on rails.
parentComment: Subclasses will be added by inference.

classDefinition: A scooter or motor scooter is a motorcycle with step-through frame and a platform for the rider's feet.
parentDefinition: A motorcycle is a two- or three-wheeled motor vehicle.

classDefinition: A closed ecological system is a vivarium which does not rely on matter exchange with any part outside the system.
parentDefinition: A vivarium is an enclosure for keeping and raising organisms for observation or research. Often, a portion of the ecosystem for a particular species is simulated on a smaller scale, with controls for environmental conditions.
classComment: This class refers to strictly sealed enclosures such as Biosphere 2 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biosphere_2), rather than vivaria which allow matter exchange with external environmental systems.

classDefinition: A mesocosm is a vivarium that is embedded within a natural environment and is used to place a relatively small part of that environment under experimental control for the purposes of scientific investigation.
parentDefinition: A vivarium is an enclosure for keeping and raising organisms for observation or research. Often, a portion of the ecosystem for a particular species is simulated on a smaller scale, with controls for environmental conditions.

classDefinition: A microcosm is a vivarium within which a simple ecosystem is artificially established and used to simulate and predict the behaviour of natural ecosystems under controlled conditions.
parentDefinition: A vivarium is an enclosure for keeping and raising organisms for observation or research. Often, a portion of the ecosystem for a particular species is simulated on a smaller scale, with controls for environmental conditions.

classDefinition: Vaporisation of an element or compound is process whereby that element or compound undergoes a phase transition from the liquid to vapor.
parentDefinition: A process during which a portion of some environmental material is converted into a different material or a collection of materials.
classComment: Note that a vapor describes an element or compound in the gas phase at a temperature lower than its critical point,
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material transformation process only refers to ENVO:environmental material classes (e.g. bulk and typically impure substances), rather than transformations converting a specific chemical into another.

classDefinition: A process during which a portion of some environmental material is converted into a different material or a collection of materials.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
classComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material transformation process only refers to ENVO:environmental material classes (e.g. bulk and typically impure substances), rather than transformations converting a specific chemical into another.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: Boiling is a form of vaporisation which occurs when a liquid is heated to a temperature at which the vapor pressure of the liquid is equal to the pressure exerted on the liquid by the surrounding environmental pressure.
parentDefinition: Vaporisation of an element or compound is process whereby that element or compound undergoes a phase transition from the liquid to vapor.
parentComment: Note that a vapor describes an element or compound in the gas phase at a temperature lower than its critical point,

classDefinition: Hydrological condensation is a process in which atmospheric water vapour undergoes a phase transition from the gas phase to the liquid phase.
parentDefinition: Condensation is a process during which a gas undergoes a phase transition into a liquid.
classComment: "process" is included in the label to make it clear that we are not referring to the condensed material (e.g. water droplets, window fog)

classDefinition: Hydrological condensation is a process in which atmospheric water vapour undergoes a phase transition from the gas phase to the liquid phase.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
classComment: "process" is included in the label to make it clear that we are not referring to the condensed material (e.g. water droplets, window fog)
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: Condensation is a process during which a gas undergoes a phase transition into a liquid.
parentDefinition: A material transformation process during which a material's viscosity increase either through a reduction in temperature, through chemical reactions, or other physical effects.
parentComment: Sometimes the increase in viscosity is great enough to crystallize or solidify the substance in question.

classDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
classComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A manufactured structure made of interspaced structural elements such as metal or wooden bars or wires held together such that they may be used to confine, contain, or protect something.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A drylot is an enclosure of limited size usually bare of vegetation and used for fattening livestock.
parentDefinition: A feedlot is a plot of land on which livestock are fattened for market

classDefinition: A feedlot is a plot of land on which livestock are fattened for market
parentComment: As with other classes that are "features", the subclasses of this class are being moved to more informative locations. Their relation to agriculture will be modelled by something more akin to a quality or relation to an agricultural process.

classDefinition: A phyllome (PO:0006001) that is not associated with a reproductive structure.
parentDefinition: A lateral plant organ (PO:0009008) produced by a shoot apical meristem (PO:0020148).

classDefinition: The long-term fluctuations in temperature, precipitation, wind, and all other aspects of the Earth's climate. External processes, such as solar-irradiance variations, variations of the Earth's orbital parameters (eccentricity, precession, and inclination), lithosphere motions, and volcanic activity, are factors in climatic variation. Internal variations of the climate system, e.g., changes in the abundance of greenhouse gases, also may produce fluctuations of sufficient magnitude and variability to explain observed climate change through the feedback processes interrelating the components of the climate system.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
classComment: Definition vebatim from GEMET. Will need to be refined. Further, distinction between "climate change" and (one or many) "climate change process" will need to be discussed. Fluctuations are not processes, per se.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
parentDefinition: An occurrent that has temporal proper parts and for some time t, p s-depends_on some material entity at t.
classComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
parentDefinition: p is a process = Def. p is an occurrent that has temporal proper parts and for some time t, p s-depends_on some material entity at t. (axiom label in BFO2 Reference: [083-003])
classComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A system which consists of an atmosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere, land surface, and  biosphere, forced or influenced by external processes.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
classComment: This class, from the IPCC report, is naturally focused on the Earth's climate. The report cites the Sun as the agent of the most important forcing processes. It also considers the direct effect of human activities on the climate system an external forcing
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classDefinition: Recurrent and often more or less cyclic alteration.
parentDefinition: A variability quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of whether the bearer exhibits variation or change.

classDefinition: Acidification of an aquatic environment is a process whereby the pH of an aquatic environment, biome, or water body is lowered.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: Ocean acidification is a process during which the pH of a sea or ocean is lowered.
parentDefinition: Acidification of an aquatic environment is a process whereby the pH of an aquatic environment, biome, or water body is lowered.
classComment: On Earth, the major cause of ocean acidification is the update of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.

classDefinition: A chonolith is an igneous rock intrusion of irregular shape with a demonstrable base, absent in other types of irregularly-shaped intrusions.
parentDefinition: An intrusion which is primarily composed of rock which has been formed within a pre-existing fracture in a larger mass of rock.
parentComment: While some intrusions are still located in the fracture where they formed, others may be (partially) exposed by erosional processes.

classDefinition: A process which consists of all aerobic respiration processes instantiated in an ecosystem.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: A process which consists of all aerobic respiration processes instantiated in an ecosystem.
parentDefinition: A process which consists of all respiration processes instantiated in an ecosystem.

classDefinition: A process which consists of all respiration processes instantiated in an ecosystem.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
classComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

parentDefinition: A planetary surface is a surface layer where the solid or liquid material of a planet comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
parentComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities

parentLabel: liquid surface of an astronomical body
parentDefinition: A surface of an astronomical body which is part of a water body present on that body.

classLabel: liquid surface of an astronomical body
classDefinition: A surface of an astronomical body which is part of a water body present on that body.
parentDefinition: A surface layer where the solid or liquid material of an astronomical body comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
parentComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities

classDefinition: A planetary structural layer is laminar part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough to have differentiation by density. Planetary layers have differing physicochemical properties and composition.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: A planetary structural layer is laminar part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough to have differentiation by density. Planetary layers have differing physicochemical properties and composition.
parentDefinition: A material entity which 1) is spatially continuous, 2) is composed of material of comparable thickness, composition, and physical properties, and 3) is physically distinct from adjacent portions of environmental material.

classDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's exhibiting the physical characteristics of an entity characterized by particles arranged such that their shape and volume are relatively stable.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of its constitution.

classDefinition: A planetary mantle is a planetary layer which is an interior part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough to have differentiation by density.
parentDefinition: A planetary structural layer is laminar part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough to have differentiation by density. Planetary layers have differing physicochemical properties and composition.
classComment: This class is meant to be applicable accross planets. Earth's mantle would be an instance.

classDefinition: A planetary core is the innermost structural layer or layers of a planet. The core may be entirely liquid, entirely solid, or have both liquid and solid parts.
parentDefinition: A planetary structural layer is laminar part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough to have differentiation by density. Planetary layers have differing physicochemical properties and composition.
classComment: "Not to be confused with planetary core in the core accretion theory, referring to a central accretionary body surrounded by a halo of dust and gas which serves to trap debris and increase the rate of accretion.." WIkipedia:Planetary_core. This class is meant to be applicable accross planets. Earth's core would be an instance. The "layer" aspect of cores may be problematic.

parentDefinition: A planetary core is the innermost structural layer or layers of a planet. The core may be entirely liquid, entirely solid, or have both liquid and solid parts.
classComment: Needs a general definition that holds for Earth as well as other planets.
parentComment: "Not to be confused with planetary core in the core accretion theory, referring to a central accretionary body surrounded by a halo of dust and gas which serves to trap debris and increase the rate of accretion.." WIkipedia:Planetary_core. This class is meant to be applicable accross planets. Earth's core would be an instance. The "layer" aspect of cores may be problematic.

parentDefinition: A planetary core is the innermost structural layer or layers of a planet. The core may be entirely liquid, entirely solid, or have both liquid and solid parts.
classComment: Needs a general definition that holds for Earth as well as other planets.
parentComment: "Not to be confused with planetary core in the core accretion theory, referring to a central accretionary body surrounded by a halo of dust and gas which serves to trap debris and increase the rate of accretion.." WIkipedia:Planetary_core. This class is meant to be applicable accross planets. Earth's core would be an instance. The "layer" aspect of cores may be problematic.

classDefinition: A liquid planetary core is a planetary core which is primarily composed of liquid material.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of liquid material.

classDefinition: A liquid planetary core is a planetary core which is primarily composed of liquid material.
parentDefinition: A layer which is primarily composed of some liquid material.

classDefinition: A liquid planetary core is a planetary core which is primarily composed of liquid material.
parentDefinition: A planetary core is the innermost structural layer or layers of a planet. The core may be entirely liquid, entirely solid, or have both liquid and solid parts.
parentComment: "Not to be confused with planetary core in the core accretion theory, referring to a central accretionary body surrounded by a halo of dust and gas which serves to trap debris and increase the rate of accretion.." WIkipedia:Planetary_core. This class is meant to be applicable accross planets. Earth's core would be an instance. The "layer" aspect of cores may be problematic.

classDefinition: A solid planetary core is a planetary core which is primarily composed of solid material.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

classDefinition: A solid planetary core is a planetary core which is primarily composed of solid material.
parentDefinition: A layer which is primarily composed of some solid material, allowing for non-solid parts such as interstitial pockets of gas or liquid.

classDefinition: A solid planetary core is a planetary core which is primarily composed of solid material.
parentDefinition: A planetary core is the innermost structural layer or layers of a planet. The core may be entirely liquid, entirely solid, or have both liquid and solid parts.
parentComment: "Not to be confused with planetary core in the core accretion theory, referring to a central accretionary body surrounded by a halo of dust and gas which serves to trap debris and increase the rate of accretion.." WIkipedia:Planetary_core. This class is meant to be applicable accross planets. Earth's core would be an instance. The "layer" aspect of cores may be problematic.

classDefinition: A lithosphere is the outermost shell of a terrestrial-type planet or natural satellite that is defined by its rigid mechanical properties.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.
classComment: Earth's lithosphere includes the crust and uppermost mantle.

classDefinition: A lithosphere is the outermost shell of a terrestrial-type planet or natural satellite that is defined by its rigid mechanical properties.
parentDefinition: A layer which is primarily composed of some solid material, allowing for non-solid parts such as interstitial pockets of gas or liquid.
classComment: Earth's lithosphere includes the crust and uppermost mantle.

classDefinition: A lithosphere is the outermost shell of a terrestrial-type planet or natural satellite that is defined by its rigid mechanical properties.
parentDefinition: A planetary structural layer is laminar part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough to have differentiation by density. Planetary layers have differing physicochemical properties and composition.
classComment: Earth's lithosphere includes the crust and uppermost mantle.

classDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's inability of being turned, bowed, or twisted without breaking.
parentDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's disposition to being turned, bowed, or twisted without breaking.

classDefinition: An asthenosphere is a layer of a terrestrial-type planet or natural satellite which is highly viscous, mechanically weak, and ductilely deforming.
