parentDefinition: A planetary structural layer is laminar part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough to have differentiation by density. Planetary layers have differing physicochemical properties and composition.

classDefinition: A viscosity quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's having viscosity.
parentDefinition: A physical quality of a fluid inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's disposition to internal resistance to flow.

classDefinition: A strength which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is decreased compared to normal or average.

classDefinition: A strength which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's power or force.

classDefinition: An ocean strait is a strait which connects two oceans.
parentDefinition: A narrow channel of water that connects two larger bodies of water, and thus lies between two land masses.

classDefinition: A slum is a heavily populated urban informal settlement with substandard housing in which households lack any one of the following: access to improved water, access to improved sanitation, sufficient-living area, durability of housing, or security of tenure.
parentDefinition: A settlement with a high density of buildings and inhabitants.
parentComment: The thresholds for what makes a settlment "dense" can be determined as needed. If there is a specific threshold that should be added to ENVO, please make a new class request.

classDefinition: An undersea trough is a trough which is below a marine water body.
parentDefinition: A linear structural depression that extends laterally over a distance, while being less steep than a trench. A trough can be a narrow basin or a geologic rift. There are various oceanic troughs, troughs found under oceans; examples include the rift along the mid-oceanic ridge and the Cayman Trough.

classDefinition: An explosive eruption is a volcanic process in which pressurised magma is violently expelled and froths into volcanic ash. Explosive eruptions can eject a cloud of rocks, dust, gas, and pyroclastic material  which may then collapse, creating a pyroclastic flow of hot volcanic matter.
parentDefinition: A volcanic eruption is a process during which lava, tephra (ash, lapilli, volcanic bombs and blocks), and assorted gases are expelled from a volcanic vent or fissure.

classDefinition: A process in which a volume of lava emitted during an effusive eruption moves along a solid surface.
parentDefinition: A process whereby a volume of liquid moves due to a disequilibrium of physical forces.
parentComment: This class can refer to the flow of any material in a liquid phase.

classDefinition: An anthropised ecosystem which is determined by the presence of humans and their constructions.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: An anthropised ecosystem which is determined by the presence of humans and their constructions.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which is formed as a result of human activity or impact.

classDefinition: An anthropised ecosystem which is determined by the presence of humans and their constructions.
parentDefinition: An environmental system determined by an animal.

parentLabel: environment associated with an animal part or small animal
classDefinition: An anthropised ecosystem which is determined by the presence of humans and their constructions.
parentDefinition: An environmental system determined by part of a living or dead animal, or a whole small animal.

classDefinition: Tuff is a type of rock made of volcanic ash ejected from a vent during a volcanic eruption.
parentDefinition: A rock is a naturally occurring solid aggregate of one or more minerals or mineraloids.
parentComment: From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ [A mineral] is different from a rock, which can be an aggregate of minerals or non-minerals and does not have a specific chemical composition. The exact definition of a mineral is under debate, especially with respect to the requirement a valid species be abiogenic, and to a lesser extent with regards to it having an ordered atomic structure.

classDefinition: A cone that is composed of consolidated volcanic ash.
parentDefinition: Built by fragments (called ejecta) thrown up (ejected) from a volcanic vent, piling up around the vent in the shape of a cone with a central crater.

classDefinition: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of water in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of open water generally have less than 25% cover of vegetation or soil. A specific threshold is not asserted in this definition.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

parentLabel: fiat part of an astronomical object
classDefinition: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of water in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
parentDefinition: A part of an environmental system whose boundaries are determined by fiat.
classComment: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of open water generally have less than 25% cover of vegetation or soil. A specific threshold is not asserted in this definition.
parentComment: Subclasses of this class have fiat (and only fiat) boundaries - that is, boundaries which are determined by human consensus or opinion rather than (and sometimes in contrast to) well-defined physical discontinuities. We distinguish these from entities that have fuzzy or hard to define boundaries that do overlap some form of physical discontinuity.

classDefinition: A geological fault is a planar fracture or discontinuity in a volume of rock, across which there has been significant displacement as a result of rock mass movement.
parentDefinition: A geological fracture is any separation in a geologic formation, such as a joint or a fault that divides a mass of rock into two or more pieces.
classComment: The relationship between faults and active plate boundaries must be further developed, as there is some overlap.

classDefinition: An active fault is a fault that is likely to become the source of another earthquake sometime in the future. Geologists commonly consider faults to be active if there has been movement observed or evidence of seismic activity during the last 10,000 years.
parentDefinition: A geological fault is a planar fracture or discontinuity in a volume of rock, across which there has been significant displacement as a result of rock mass movement.
parentComment: The relationship between faults and active plate boundaries must be further developed, as there is some overlap.

classDefinition: A vein is a geological fracture which is filled with minerals precipitated out of an aqueous solution.
parentDefinition: A geological fracture is any separation in a geologic formation, such as a joint or a fault that divides a mass of rock into two or more pieces.

classDefinition: A joint is a geological fracture which has no measureable shear displacement
parentDefinition: A geological fracture is any separation in a geologic formation, such as a joint or a fault that divides a mass of rock into two or more pieces.

classDefinition: A geological fracture across which shear displacement has occurred
parentDefinition: A geological fracture is any separation in a geologic formation, such as a joint or a fault that divides a mass of rock into two or more pieces.
classComment: Sounds like this should be populated by inference.

classDefinition: A microfracture is a small fracture which is found in a portion of solid material along which further fracturing tends to occur. Microfractures are considered imperfections which to pre-exist any fractures formed by the application of stress to a material.
parentDefinition: A geological fracture is any separation in a geologic formation, such as a joint or a fault that divides a mass of rock into two or more pieces.

classDefinition: A size quality which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A morphology quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's physical magnitude.

classDefinition: A size quality which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is decreased compared to normal or average.

parentLabel: fiat part of an astronomical object
classDefinition: A fiat part of an atmosphere which is defined as a vertical, three-dimensional pillar extending from a unit area on a planetary surface and bounded by the top of the atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A part of an environmental system whose boundaries are determined by fiat.
classComment: Once defined, an atmospheric column can be used to quantify an atmospheric parameter such as pressure, ozone or precipitable water.
parentComment: Subclasses of this class have fiat (and only fiat) boundaries - that is, boundaries which are determined by human consensus or opinion rather than (and sometimes in contrast to) well-defined physical discontinuities. We distinguish these from entities that have fuzzy or hard to define boundaries that do overlap some form of physical discontinuity.

classDefinition: Contaminated air is air which has sufficient concentrations of environmental pollutants such that it may adversely affect a given ecosystem.
parentDefinition: The mixture of gases (roughly (by molar content/volume: 78% nitrogen, 20.95% oxygen, 0.93% argon, 0.038% carbon dioxide, trace amounts of other gases, and a variable amount (average around 1%) of water vapor) that surrounds the planet Earth.

classDefinition: An earthquake is a process during which energy is released in an astronomical body's crust, causing the displacement of crustal parts and the generation of seismic waves.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
classComment: Elastic strain, gravity, chemical reactions, or even the motion of massive bodies can produce earthquakes.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: An earthquake caused by the sudden release of energy accumulated in an astronomical body's crust, as the elastic strain placed on constituent rock masses causes them to fracture.
parentDefinition: An earthquake is a process during which energy is released in an astronomical body's crust, causing the displacement of crustal parts and the generation of seismic waves.
parentComment: Elastic strain, gravity, chemical reactions, or even the motion of massive bodies can produce earthquakes.

classDefinition: A process during which the ability of a material entity to maintain its internal organisation fails, resulting in deformation and a breakdown of that organisation.
parentDefinition: A process during which one entity loses energy to another entity.
classComment: This is a very general concept, and should likely be elevated to OBO Core rather than held in ENVO.

classDefinition: A megathrust earthquake is a tectonic earthquake which occurs at subduction zones at destructive plate boundaries (convergent boundaries). These interplate earthquakes are the planet's most powerful, with moment magnitudes that can exceed 9.0.
parentDefinition: An earthquake caused by the sudden release of energy accumulated in an astronomical body's crust, as the elastic strain placed on constituent rock masses causes them to fracture.

classDefinition: A geomorphological feature which is formed where two or more tectonic plates are actively moving towards one another, resulting in deformation of the lithosphere that forces one plate below the other where it melts in the mantle.
parentDefinition: A geomorphological feature which is formed where two or more tectonic plates move towards, away from, or along one another, resulting in deformation of the lithosphere.

classDefinition: A lake which has concentrations of environmental contaminants high enough to harm the ecosystems associated with it.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A mineral material composed primarily of sodium chloride.
A glacial abrasion process is an erosional process during which debris in the basal ice scrapes along the bed, polishing and gouging the underlying rocks, similar to sandpaper on wood.
parentDefinition: An erosion process during which the movement of a glacier across a terrestrial surface causes the removal of material from that surface.

classDefinition: Glacial plucking is an erosional process during which pieces of bedrock are cracked off due to the mechanical force of a moving glacier.
parentDefinition: An erosion process during which the movement of a glacier across a terrestrial surface causes the removal of material from that surface.

classDefinition: Glacial ice thrusting is an erosional process during which a moving glacier which has frozen to its bed surges forward and moves large sheets of sediment frozen to the glacial mass.
parentDefinition: An erosion process during which the movement of a glacier across a terrestrial surface causes the removal of material from that surface.

classDefinition: A tsunami is a process during which a series of waves is generated in a water body, typically an ocean or large lake, by the displacement of a large volume of water. Earthquakes, volcanic eruptions and other underwater explosions (including detonations of underwater nuclear devices), landslides, glacier calvings, meteorite impacts and other disturbances above or below water all have the potential to generate a tsunami.
parentDefinition: A process whereby a volume of liquid moves due to a disequilibrium of physical forces.
parentComment: This class can refer to the flow of any material in a liquid phase.

classDefinition: A process whereby a volume of liquid moves due to a disequilibrium of physical forces.
parentDefinition: An advective transport process during which a fluid moves.
classComment: This class can refer to the flow of any material in a liquid phase.

classDefinition: Mass wasting is the geomorphic process by which solid environmental material such as soil, sand, regolith, and/or rock move downslope typically as a mass, largely under the force of gravity, but frequently affected by water and water content as in submarine environments and mudslides.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
classComment: Of interest for future development: Some causes of mass wasting earthquakes, increased overburden from structures, increased soil moisture, reduction of roots holding the soil to bedrock, undercutting of the slope by excavation or erosion, weathering by frost heave, bioturbation, volcanic edifice over-steepening. Some processes that reduce mass wasting: Afforestation, Reforestation, Terracing steps on slopes (reduce angle of slope). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_wasting.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: A process during which the mass of one or more materials, present within a given site, increases.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
classComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material accumulation process ends a material transport process.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A process during which a mass composed of one or more environmental materials, present within a given site, decreases.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
classComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A mass wasting flow during which snow rapidly flows down a sloping surface.
parentDefinition: A mass wasting flow is a form of mass wasting during which the moving materials behave similarly to a flowing fluid. Water, air and ice are often involved in enabling fluidlike motion of the material.

classDefinition: A mass wasting flow is a form of mass wasting during which the moving materials behave similarly to a flowing fluid. Water, air and ice are often involved in enabling fluidlike motion of the material.
parentDefinition: Mass wasting is the geomorphic process by which solid environmental material such as soil, sand, regolith, and/or rock move downslope typically as a mass, largely under the force of gravity, but frequently affected by water and water content as in submarine environments and mudslides.
parentComment: Of interest for future development: Some causes of mass wasting earthquakes, increased overburden from structures, increased soil moisture, reduction of roots holding the soil to bedrock, undercutting of the slope by excavation or erosion, weathering by frost heave, bioturbation, volcanic edifice over-steepening. Some processes that reduce mass wasting: Afforestation, Reforestation, Terracing steps on slopes (reduce angle of slope). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_wasting.

parentDefinition: Mass wasting is the geomorphic process by which solid environmental material such as soil, sand, regolith, and/or rock move downslope typically as a mass, largely under the force of gravity, but frequently affected by water and water content as in submarine environments and mudslides.
parentComment: Of interest for future development: Some causes of mass wasting earthquakes, increased overburden from structures, increased soil moisture, reduction of roots holding the soil to bedrock, undercutting of the slope by excavation or erosion, weathering by frost heave, bioturbation, volcanic edifice over-steepening. Some processes that reduce mass wasting: Afforestation, Reforestation, Terracing steps on slopes (reduce angle of slope). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_wasting.

classDefinition: A material transport process during which a geological surface shifts downward relative to a datum such as sea-level.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

parentDefinition: Mass wasting is the geomorphic process by which solid environmental material such as soil, sand, regolith, and/or rock move downslope typically as a mass, largely under the force of gravity, but frequently affected by water and water content as in submarine environments and mudslides.
parentComment: Of interest for future development: Some causes of mass wasting earthquakes, increased overburden from structures, increased soil moisture, reduction of roots holding the soil to bedrock, undercutting of the slope by excavation or erosion, weathering by frost heave, bioturbation, volcanic edifice over-steepening. Some processes that reduce mass wasting: Afforestation, Reforestation, Terracing steps on slopes (reduce angle of slope). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_wasting.

classDefinition: A mudflow is a form of mass wasting which involves very rapid to extremely rapid surging flow of debris that has become partially or fully liquified by the addition of significant amounts of water to clay-rich source material.
parentDefinition: A mass wasting flow is a form of mass wasting during which the moving materials behave similarly to a flowing fluid. Water, air and ice are often involved in enabling fluidlike motion of the material.
classComment: "Mudflows are often called mudslides, a term applied indiscriminately by the mass media to a variety of mass wasting events. Mudflows often start as slides, becoming flows as water is entrained along the flow path; such events are often called flow slides." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mudflow

classDefinition: A mass wasting flow during which water-laden masses of soil and fragmented rock rush down the slopes of elevations, funnel into stream channels, entrain objects in their paths, and form thick, muddy deposits on valley floors.
parentDefinition: A mass wasting flow is a form of mass wasting during which the moving materials behave similarly to a flowing fluid. Water, air and ice are often involved in enabling fluidlike motion of the material.

classDefinition: A lahar is a type of mudflow or debris flow composed of a slurry of pyroclastic material, rocky debris, and water. The material flows down from a volcano, typically along a river valley.
parentDefinition: A mudflow is a form of mass wasting which involves very rapid to extremely rapid surging flow of debris that has become partially or fully liquified by the addition of significant amounts of water to clay-rich source material.
parentComment: "Mudflows are often called mudslides, a term applied indiscriminately by the mass media to a variety of mass wasting events. Mudflows often start as slides, becoming flows as water is entrained along the flow path; such events are often called flow slides." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mudflow

classDefinition: An andosol which derives its silica content from glass and tephra ejected during a volcanic eruption.
parentDefinition: Andosols are soils that develop in volcanic ejecta or glasses under almost any climate (except under hyperarid climate conditions). However, Andosols may also develop in other silicate-rich materials under acid weathering in humid and perhumid climates.

classDefinition: A sturzstrom is a landslide consisting which has a great amount of kinetic energy resulting in greater horizontal movement when compared to its initial vertical drop — as much as 20 or 30 times the vertical distance. By contrast a normal landslide will typically travel a horizontal distance that is less than twice the distance that the material has fallen.
parentDefinition: A landslide is a process whereby a large mass of earth and rocks moves down a hill or a mountainside.

classDefinition: An ash fall process is a process in which volcanic ash formed during an explosive volcanic eruption, phreatomagmatic eruption, or during material transport in pyroclastic density currents is pulled towards the planetary surface by gravity.
parentDefinition: A precipitation process is a process in which a portion of some substance segregates from a material in which that substance or its precursors were dissolved or suspended in and settles due to a force such as gravity or centrifugal force.

classDefinition: A precipitation process is a process in which a portion of some substance segregates from a material in which that substance or its precursors were dissolved or suspended in and settles due to a force such as gravity or centrifugal force.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: Hydrological evaporation is the evaporation of water, generally as part of a planetary water cycle.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: Hydrological evaporation is the evaporation of water, generally as part of a planetary water cycle.
parentDefinition: Evaporation is a form of vaporisation which occurs when a portion of the surface layer of a liquid in contact with a gaseous material, which is not saturated with the evaporating substance, vaporises.

classDefinition: Evaporation is a form of vaporisation which occurs when a portion of the surface layer of a liquid in contact with a gaseous material, which is not saturated with the evaporating substance, vaporises.
parentDefinition: Vaporisation of an element or compound is process whereby that element or compound undergoes a phase transition from the liquid to vapor.
parentComment: Note that a vapor describes an element or compound in the gas phase at a temperature lower than its critical point,

classDefinition: Soil degradation is a process which results in a change in soil health status resulting in a diminished capacity of the ecosystem in which the soil occurs to provide goods and services for its  beneficiaries.
parentDefinition: A process which diminishes the functioning of an ecosystem located on land.
parentComment: This could include, for example, reducing soil health, pollinator activity, or an ecosystem's ability  to sequester carbon.

classDefinition: A process which diminishes the functioning of an ecosystem located on land.
parentDefinition: An environmental process either driven by or primarily impacting the parts or emergent properties of an ecosystem.
classComment: This could include, for example, reducing soil health, pollinator activity, or an ecosystem's ability  to sequester carbon.

classDefinition: Soil erosion is a process in which exogenic processes remove soil from one location on the Earth's crust and transport it to another location where it is deposited.
parentDefinition: An action of exogenic processes (such as water flow or wind) which remove environmental material from one part of a planet's crust, transporting it to another location where it is deposited.
classComment: "Soil Erosion is a common term that is often confused with soil degradation as a whole,  but in fact refers only to absolute soil losses in terms of topsoil and nutrients. This  is indeed the most visible effect of soil degradation, but does not cover all of its aspects. Soil erosion is a natural process in mountainous areas, but is often made much worse by poor management practices." http://www.fao.org/soils-portal/soil-degradation-restoration/en/

classDefinition: Coastal flooding is a process in which normally dry, low-lying land near a coast is flooded by sea water.
parentDefinition: A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow of inland and/or tidal waters, and/or the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. A great flow along a watercourse or a flow causing inundation of lands not normally covered by water.

classDefinition: A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow of inland and/or tidal waters, and/or the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. A great flow along a watercourse or a flow causing inundation of lands not normally covered by water.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which a volume of liquid water is transported due to a disequilibria in physical forces.

classDefinition: Riverine flooding is a process in which the flow rate of river water exceeds the capacity of its channel, thus flooding neighbouring land. Bends and meanders in a river channel are particularly disposed to such flooding.
parentDefinition: A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow of inland and/or tidal waters, and/or the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. A great flow along a watercourse or a flow causing inundation of lands not normally covered by water.

classDefinition: Flash flooding is a process in which low-lying land is inundated with water for a short period of time and are usually the result of precipitation or a breach in the container of a water body.
parentDefinition: A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow of inland and/or tidal waters, and/or the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. A great flow along a watercourse or a flow causing inundation of lands not normally covered by water.
classComment: Flash floods generally last no more than six hours. http://www.srh.noaa.gov/mrx/hydro/flooddef.php

classDefinition: A coastal flood is a flood which is formed as a result of large amounts of water from marine water bodies or large lakes being transported to usually dry land by displacement processes such as high winds or seismic activity.
parentDefinition: An unusual accumulation of water above the ground caused by high tide, heavy rain, melting snow or rapid runoff from paved areas.

classDefinition: A riverine flood is a flood which is formed as a result of a river's flow rate exceeding the capacity of its channel.
parentDefinition: An unusual accumulation of water above the ground caused by high tide, heavy rain, melting snow or rapid runoff from paved areas.

classDefinition: A flash flood is a flood formed by the rapid flooding of geomorphic low-lying areas. It may be caused by heavy rain associated with a severe thunderstorm, hurricane, tropical storm, or meltwater from ice or snow flowing over ice sheets or snowfields. Flash floods may also occur after the collapse of a natural ice or debris dam, or a human structure such as a man-made dam. Flash floods are distinguished from a regular flood by a timescale of less than six hours.
parentDefinition: An unusual accumulation of water above the ground caused by high tide, heavy rain, melting snow or rapid runoff from paved areas.

classDefinition: A storm surge is a coastal flood which is caused by low-pressure weather systems such as tropical cyclones and strong extratropical cyclones, the severity of which is affected by the shallowness and orientation of the water body relative to storm path, and the timing of tides.
parentDefinition: A coastal flood is a flood which is formed as a result of large amounts of water from marine water bodies or large lakes being transported to usually dry land by displacement processes such as high winds or seismic activity.

classDefinition: A storm surge process is a coastal flooding process which is caused by low pressure weather systems such as tropical cyclones and strong extratropical cyclones, the severity of which is affected by the shallowness and orientation of the water body relative to storm path, and the timing of tides.
parentDefinition: Coastal flooding is a process in which normally dry, low-lying land near a coast is flooded by sea water.

classDefinition: A meteotsunami is a tsunami caused by atmospheric processes and differences in air pressure.
parentDefinition: A tsunami is a process during which a series of waves is generated in a water body, typically an ocean or large lake, by the displacement of a large volume of water. Earthquakes, volcanic eruptions and other underwater explosions (including detonations of underwater nuclear devices), landslides, glacier calvings, meteorite impacts and other disturbances above or below water all have the potential to generate a tsunami.

classDefinition: Areal flooding is a flooding process in which flat or low-lying areas become inundated with water due to water input exceeding infiltration, evaporation, or run off.
parentDefinition: A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow of inland and/or tidal waters, and/or the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. A great flow along a watercourse or a flow causing inundation of lands not normally covered by water.

classDefinition: Urban flooding is a flooding process in which land or property in a built environment, particularly in more densely populated areas, is inundated due to the rate of water input exceeding that of water drainage provided by the environment's drainage systems.
parentDefinition: A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow of inland and/or tidal waters, and/or the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. A great flow along a watercourse or a flow causing inundation of lands not normally covered by water.

classDefinition: Snowmelt is a hydrological melting process in which water is produced by the melting of snow and becomes part of the hydrological surface runoff.
parentDefinition: A melting process during which water-based ice, snow, or other solid phase water transitions into a liquid phase.
parentComment: Here, we've nexted melting within thawing as one approach to resolve the semantics of thawing of ice-free materials. Expert group revision is requried.

classDefinition: A melting process during which water-based ice, snow, or other solid phase water transitions into a liquid phase.
parentDefinition: Melting is a material transformation process which results in the phase transition of a substance from a solid to a liquid.
classComment: Here, we've nexted melting within thawing as one approach to resolve the semantics of thawing of ice-free materials. Expert group revision is requried.
parentComment: Note that melting need not be due to warming, thus the classes are separated.

classDefinition: A melting process during which water-based ice, snow, or other solid phase water transitions into a liquid phase.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
classComment: Here, we've nexted melting within thawing as one approach to resolve the semantics of thawing of ice-free materials. Expert group revision is requried.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: A warming process during which the thermal energy in a portion of environmental material is sufficient to melt water-based ice or snow.
parentDefinition: A process during which the temperature of a portion of environmental material is increased, along with the kinetic energy of its constituent molecules.
classComment: Note that ice or snow need not be present in the material in order for it to undergo thawing. The semantics of 'thaw' vs 'melt' are debated in fields such as permafrost geology/physics. This module is thus likely to be dynamic.
parentComment: Note that melting need not involve warming (e.g. due to extreme gravitational effects). See the melting hierarchy for more terms.

classDefinition: Icemelt is a hydrological melthing process in which water is produced by the melting of ice and becomes part of the hydrological surface runoff.
parentDefinition: A melting process during which water-based ice, snow, or other solid phase water transitions into a liquid phase.
parentComment: Here, we've nexted melting within thawing as one approach to resolve the semantics of thawing of ice-free materials. Expert group revision is requried.

classDefinition: A material transformation process during which a material's viscosity increase either through a reduction in temperature, through chemical reactions, or other physical effects.
parentDefinition: A process during which a portion of some environmental material is converted into a different material or a collection of materials.
classComment: Sometimes the increase in viscosity is great enough to crystallize or solidify the substance in question.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material transformation process only refers to ENVO:environmental material classes (e.g. bulk and typically impure substances), rather than transformations converting a specific chemical into another.

classDefinition: Desublimation is a process in which a portion of some gas undergoes a phase transition into a portion of some solid.
parentDefinition: A material transformation process during which a material's viscosity increase either through a reduction in temperature, through chemical reactions, or other physical effects.
parentComment: Sometimes the increase in viscosity is great enough to crystallize or solidify the substance in question.

classDefinition: Sublimation is a process during which a portion of some solid undergoes a phase transition into a portion of some gas.
parentDefinition: A process during which a portion of some environmental material is converted into a different material or a collection of materials.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material transformation process only refers to ENVO:environmental material classes (e.g. bulk and typically impure substances), rather than transformations converting a specific chemical into another.

classDefinition: A tectonic uplift process is a geomorphologic process in which a geological surface shifts upward relative to a datum such as sea-level due to forces other than isostatic responses to unloading.
parentDefinition: A process during which pieces of a planetary crust and uppermost mantle move.

classDefinition: A material transport process during which a mass of air moves through an atmosphere towards a planetary surface.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
classComment: This process usually refers to large-scale air motion, rather than local winds.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: An atmospheric wind during which cold atmospheric gas flows downwards towards the surface of an astronomical body.
classComment: "From its etymology, the term means simply "going down" or "descending," and thus could refer to any descending flow; some authors have further generalized it to include downslope flows such as the foehn or chinook even though they do not represent a flow of cold air. This concept has given rise to the expression katafront, which indicates flow down a sloped cold-frontal surface."

classDefinition: A mass of igneous rock formed when hot magma flows out (extrudes) onto a planetary surface as lava or explodes violently into the atmosphere to fall back as pyroclastics or tuff.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body associated with a volcano - an opening, or rupture, in that body's surface or crust - which allows hot, molten rock, ash and gases to escape from deep below the surface.

classDefinition: A dike formed when sediment fills a pre-existing fracture in a mass of rock.
parentDefinition: A sheet of rock that formed in a fracture in a pre-existing rock body.

classDefinition: A dike formed when sediment fills a pre-existing fracture in a mass of rock.
parentDefinition: A rock intrusion which is composed primarily of sedimentary rock.

classDefinition: A stock is a discordant igneous intrusion having a surface exposure of less than 100 square kilometres. Stocks differ from batholiths only in being smaller.
parentDefinition: An igneous intrusion is a mass of rock and minerals formed when magma cools, solidifies, and undergoes fractional crystallisation without reaching the surface.
parentComment: "Intrusion" can refer to the solidified mass or the molten rock.

classDefinition: A sheet intrusion (or concordant pluton) that has been injected between two layers of sedimentary rock. The pressure of the magma is high enough that the overlying strata are forced upward, giving the laccolith a dome or mushroom-like form with a generally planar base.
parentDefinition: An intrusion which is primarily composed of rock which has been formed within a pre-existing fracture in a larger mass of rock.
parentComment: While some intrusions are still located in the fracture where they formed, others may be (partially) exposed by erosional processes.

classDefinition: A large igneous intrusion which is lenticular in shape with a depressed central region.
parentDefinition: An intrusion which is primarily composed of rock which has been formed within a pre-existing fracture in a larger mass of rock.
parentComment: While some intrusions are still located in the fracture where they formed, others may be (partially) exposed by erosional processes.

classDefinition: A phacolith is an intrusion parallel to the bedding plane or foliation of folded country rock. More specifically, it is a typically lens-shaped intrusion that occupies either the crest of an anticline or the trough of a syncline.
parentDefinition: An intrusion which is primarily composed of rock which has been formed within a pre-existing fracture in a larger mass of rock.
parentComment: While some intrusions are still located in the fracture where they formed, others may be (partially) exposed by erosional processes.

classDefinition: A tabular sheet intrusion that has intruded between older layers of sedimentary rock, beds of volcanic lava or tuff, or along the direction of foliation in metamorphic rock.
parentDefinition: An intrusion which is primarily composed of rock which has been formed within a pre-existing fracture in a larger mass of rock.
parentComment: While some intrusions are still located in the fracture where they formed, others may be (partially) exposed by erosional processes.

classDefinition: An environmental system which can sustain and allow the growth of an ecological population.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: A habitat's specificity to an ecological population differentiates it from other environment classes.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: An environmental system which can sustain and allow the growth of an ecological population.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
classComment: A habitat's specificity to an ecological population differentiates it from other environment classes.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classDefinition: A collection of organisms, all of the same species, that live in the same place.
classComment:
It is sometimes difficult to define the physical boundaries of a population. In the case of sexually reproducing organisms, the individuals within a population have the potential to reproduce with one another during the course of their lifetimes. 'Community', as often used to describe a group of humans, is a type of population of organisms. 

Classes for population already  exist in IDO ('organism population', IDO_0000509) and OBI ('population', OBI_0000181). The definitions should be standardized across OBO Foundry ontologies and only one term used.

classDefinition: A collection of organisms, all of the same species, that live in the same place.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has as parts two or more organisms, viruses, or viroids of the same species and no members of any other species.
classComment:
It is sometimes difficult to define the physical boundaries of a population. In the case of sexually reproducing organisms, the individuals within a population have the potential to reproduce with one another during the course of their lifetimes. 'Community', as often used to describe a group of humans, is a type of population of organisms. 

Classes for population already  exist in IDO ('organism population', IDO_0000509) and OBI ('population', OBI_0000181). The definitions should be standardized across OBO Foundry ontologies and only one term used.

parentLabel: area of perennial ice or snow
classDefinition: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of water ice, present throughout multiple years, in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
parentDefinition: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of snow or water ice, present throughout multiple years, in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
classComment: This class covers part of the NLCD "Perennial Ice/Snow" class.
parentComment: According to the NLCD 2011, these areas are characterised by ice and/or snow cover generally greater than 25% of total cover. The definition of perennial needs clarification.

classLabel: area of perennial ice or snow
classDefinition: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of snow or water ice, present throughout multiple years, in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: According to the NLCD 2011, these areas are characterised by ice and/or snow cover generally greater than 25% of total cover. The definition of perennial needs clarification.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classLabel: area of perennial ice or snow
parentLabel: fiat part of an astronomical object
classDefinition: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of snow or water ice, present throughout multiple years, in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
parentDefinition: A part of an environmental system whose boundaries are determined by fiat.
classComment: According to the NLCD 2011, these areas are characterised by ice and/or snow cover generally greater than 25% of total cover. The definition of perennial needs clarification.
parentComment: Subclasses of this class have fiat (and only fiat) boundaries - that is, boundaries which are determined by human consensus or opinion rather than (and sometimes in contrast to) well-defined physical discontinuities. We distinguish these from entities that have fuzzy or hard to define boundaries that do overlap some form of physical discontinuity.

classDefinition: A process during which materials deemed as waste are separated and converted into a form which can be used as input by the same processes which generated them.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which is driven by the action of humans.
classComment: This has been created for SDGIO. Revision is likely, but the general meaning should be stable. The frame of reference for determining what is 'waste' and what is a  'resource' is unclear.

classDefinition: An environmental process which is driven by the action of humans.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A carbon emission process is any environmental process which outputs a carbon-bearing gas.
parentDefinition: A gas emission process during which a portion of hydrocarbon gas is transported into the atmosphere.
classComment: Requested for SDGIO. Likely to be revised.
parentComment: Some hydrocarbon gasses within the atmosphere contribute to the planetary green house gas effect by increasing absorption of solar energy.

classDefinition: A gas emission process during which a portion of hydrocarbon gas is transported into the atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which a portion of gaseous environmental material is transported into the atmosphere.
classComment: Some hydrocarbon gasses within the atmosphere contribute to the planetary green house gas effect by increasing absorption of solar energy.

classDefinition: A process in which natural ecosystems present over an expanse of land are removed and replaced with anthropogenic ecosystems.
parentDefinition: A process during which a natural environmental system is altered by human action.
classComment: These anthropogenic ecosystems may include urban or other built-up settlements or anthropogenic ecosystems used for activities such as forestry or agriculture.
parentComment: An area may be classified as anthropized even though it looks natural, such as grasslands that have been deforested by humans. It can be difficult to determine how much a site has been anthropized in the case of urbanization because one must be able to estimate the state of the landscape before significant human action.

classDefinition: An anthropisation process during which terrestrial environments - natural or anthropised - or parts thereof are altered to facilitate human activities such as agriculture, settlement, or commerce.
parentDefinition: A process in which natural ecosystems present over an expanse of land are removed and replaced with anthropogenic ecosystems.
classComment: Further examples include subdividing real estate into lots, typically for the purpose of building homes and converting unused factories into condominia.
parentComment: These anthropogenic ecosystems may include urban or other built-up settlements or anthropogenic ecosystems used for activities such as forestry or agriculture.

classDefinition: A self-contained constructed feature used by one or more households as a home, such as a house, apartment, mobile home, houseboat or other 'substantial' structure. A dwelling typically includes nearby outbuildings, sheds etc. within the curtilage of the property, excluding any 'open fields beyond'. It has significance in relation to search and seizure, conveyancing of real property, burglary, trespass, and land use planning.
parentDefinition: A building which is primarily used for the long-term habitation of humans.

parentLabel: area of perennial ice or snow
classDefinition: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of snow, present throughout multiple years, in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
parentDefinition: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of snow or water ice, present throughout multiple years, in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
classComment: This class covers part of the NLCD "Perennial Ice/Snow" class.
parentComment: According to the NLCD 2011, these areas are characterised by ice and/or snow cover generally greater than 25% of total cover. The definition of perennial needs clarification.

classDefinition: A solid layer which is composed primarily of loose, heterogeneous, superficial material covering solid rock.
parentDefinition: A layer which is primarily composed of some solid material, allowing for non-solid parts such as interstitial pockets of gas or liquid.
classComment: Regolith typically includes dust, soil, broken rock, and similar materials, but can be highly variable.

classDefinition: The Mohorovicic discontinuity, usually referred to as the Moho, is the boundary between the Earth's crust and the mantle, indicating a change in composition.
parentDefinition: A planetary structural layer is laminar part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough to have differentiation by density. Planetary layers have differing physicochemical properties and composition.

classDefinition: An environmental zone which is bounded by material parts of a land mass or the atmosphere or space adjacent to it.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: An environmental zone which is bounded by material parts of a land mass or the atmosphere or space adjacent to it.
parentDefinition: A site which has its extent determined by the presence or influence of one or more components of an environmental system or the processes occurring therein.
parentComment: Formerly, this class was an experimental class and a subclass of "environmental feature". It is now aligned to BFO. The class was not obsoleted as the core semantics maintained their stability through its transition.

classDefinition: A hollow tower of ice formed by the freezing of steam escaping a fumarole.
parentDefinition: A landform which occurs on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The usage of "surface" here aligns with that of planetary surface: in contact with the atmosphere or space. The extent of the "surface" can vary. For rocky planets like Earth, astrogeologists consider the crust as the surface.

classDefinition: A hollow tower of ice formed by the freezing of steam escaping a fumarole.
parentDefinition: A landform elevated above the surrounding area.

classDefinition: A hollow tower of ice formed by the freezing of steam escaping a fumarole.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous mass of snow and/or ice.

classDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of a continuous volume of gaseous or aerosolised material held in shape by one or more environmental processes.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of gaseous material.
classComment: Similar, in spirit, to landform. This class may need to be split into aerosols and 'pure' volumes of gas.

classDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of gaseous material.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is composed of a continuous medium bearing liquid, gaseous, and solid material in variable quantities.

classDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of gaseous material.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of fluid.

classDefinition: A cloud is a visible mass of aerosolised liquid droplets or frozen crystals suspended in an atmosphere above the surface of a planetary body.
parentDefinition: A meteor is any matter- or energy-based entity which is located in the atmosphere of an astronomical body.
classComment: On Earth clouds are formed by the saturation of air in the homosphere when air cools or gains water vapor. Please use the "water-based cloud" class and its subclasses for Earth's clouds. Note that this class describes clouds as countable objects, rather than 'cloud material'. It also refers only to clouds made up of a water-based material.

classDefinition: A meteor is any matter- or energy-based entity which is located in the atmosphere of an astronomical body.
An aerosol which has non-gaseous parts that are primarily composed of liquid droplets.
parentDefinition: Airborne solid particles (also called dust or particulate matter (PM)) or liquid droplets.
parentComment: Should connect to PATO as "quality of an aerosol"

classDefinition: An aerosol which has non-gaseous parts that are primarily composed of liquid droplets.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is unable to resist shear forces and continuously deforms when subject to them.

classDefinition: A solid material whose constituents, such as atoms, molecules or ions, are arranged in a highly ordered microscopic structure, forming a crystal lattice that extends in all directions.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
classComment: This class refers to a portion of crystal and not an individual crystal.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: Polar stratospheric clouds are clouds which form in the winter polar stratosphere at altitudes of 15,000–25,000 metres and which support chemical reactions that produce active chlorine and remove gaseous nitric acid, catalysing ozone destruction.
parentDefinition: A cloud which is primarily composed of water-based aerosols.
parentComment: On Earth clouds are formed by the saturation of air in the homosphere when air cools or gains water vapor. Note that this class describes clouds as countable objects, rather than 'cloud material'. It also refers only to clouds made up of a water-based material.

classDefinition: A cloud which is primarily composed of water-based aerosols.
parentDefinition: A cloud is a visible mass of aerosolised liquid droplets or frozen crystals suspended in an atmosphere above the surface of a planetary body.
classComment: On Earth clouds are formed by the saturation of air in the homosphere when air cools or gains water vapor. Note that this class describes clouds as countable objects, rather than 'cloud material'. It also refers only to clouds made up of a water-based material.
parentComment: On Earth clouds are formed by the saturation of air in the homosphere when air cools or gains water vapor. Please use the "water-based cloud" class and its subclasses for Earth's clouds. Note that this class describes clouds as countable objects, rather than 'cloud material'. It also refers only to clouds made up of a water-based material.

classDefinition: A cloud which is primarily composed of water-based aerosols.
parentDefinition: A meteor which is primarily composed of water.
classComment: On Earth clouds are formed by the saturation of air in the homosphere when air cools or gains water vapor. Note that this class describes clouds as countable objects, rather than 'cloud material'. It also refers only to clouds made up of a water-based material.

classDefinition: A settlement with a low density of buildings and inhabitants.
parentDefinition: An anthropised ecosystem which is determined by the presence of humans and their constructions.
classComment: The thresholds for what makes a settlment "sparsely populated" can be determined as needed. These are usually "sparse" in relation to urban environments. If there is a specific threshold that should be added to ENVO, please make a new class request.

classDefinition: A settlement which has lower population density than a town, city, or other urban environment and is primarily used for agricultural or pastoral activity.
parentDefinition: A settlement with a low density of buildings and inhabitants.
classComment: A class created fro SDGIO. The definition of rural is highly varied, dealing with areas, settlements, and populations interchangeably. The 'rural' classes in ENVO aim to clarify these differing definitions. See issue #272.
parentComment: The thresholds for what makes a settlment "sparsely populated" can be determined as needed. These are usually "sparse" in relation to urban environments. If there is a specific threshold that should be added to ENVO, please make a new class request.

classDefinition: An area which is outside of a town, city, or urban area. Rural areas are primarily used for agriculture or pastoralism and may contain rural settlements.
parentDefinition: A terrestrial zone which is bounded by constructed, manufactured, or other anthropogenic material entities.
classComment: A class created fro SDGIO. The definition of rural is highly varied, dealing with areas, settlements, and populations interchangeably. The 'rural' classes in ENVO aim to clarify these differing definitions. See issue #272.

classDefinition: A settlement which has been established and is managed through officially sanctioned processes and is recognised as legal by a competent authority.
parentDefinition: An anthropised ecosystem which is determined by the presence of humans and their constructions.

classDefinition: A settlement which is not associated with or directed by official planning processes and which typically lacks municipal services and infrastructure such as sanitation, water services, and waste management services.
parentDefinition: An anthropised ecosystem which is determined by the presence of humans and their constructions.
classComment: Informal settlements need not be illegal.

classDefinition: A settlement on land that the inhabitants have a legal claim to.
parentDefinition: An anthropised ecosystem which is determined by the presence of humans and their constructions.

classDefinition: A settlement on land that the inhabitants have no legal claim to or occupy illegally.
parentDefinition: An anthropised ecosystem which is determined by the presence of humans and their constructions.

classDefinition: Forest which originally covered a region before changes in the environment brought about by people. (Source: PHC)
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which is determined by communities of plants with a tree growth form and in which members of those communities form continuous or discontinuous regions of canopy cover.
parentComment: The definitions of forest can vary greatly, and different classes will be needed to support the major categories. Tree cover alone is not enough to distinguish between forests and plantations. The international definition proposed by the 2010 FAO Forestry Resource Assessment: "land spanning more than 0.5 ha with trees higher than 5 metres and canopy cover of more than 10 percent, or trees able to reach these thresholds in situ . It does not include land that is predominantly under agricultural or urban land use." - FAO.  2010. Global forest resources assessment 2010, Main report, FAO Forestry Paper 163. Rome.

classDefinition: A carbon emission process is any environmental process which releases carbon dioxide gas into the atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A carbon emission process is any environmental process which outputs a carbon-bearing gas.
classComment: Requested for SDGIO. This class may be revised in future once the offical definitions become more clear.
parentComment: Requested for SDGIO. Likely to be revised.

classDefinition: A process by which thermal radiation from a planetary surface is absorbed by atmospheric greenhouse gases, and is re-radiated in all directions. Since part of this re-radiation is back towards the surface and the lower atmosphere, it results in an elevation of the average surface temperature above what it would be in the absence of the gases.
parentDefinition: A process which occurs within an atmosphere.
parentComment: This class will be populated by inference and is primarily organisational.

classDefinition: A volume of carbon dioxide gas emitted by a carbon dioxide emission process.
parentDefinition: Atmospheric carbon dioxide is an environmental material composed of carbon dioxide in its gaseous form present in an atmosphere.
classComment: This is a working definition for #280. Which processes will ultimately be included in the axioms is still open.
parentComment: This could also be considered a part of an environmental material like air.

classDefinition: A road which is usable across all seasons.
parentDefinition: An open way for the passage of vehicles, persons, or animals on land.
classComment: Created for SDGIO, indicator 9.1.1. See #272.

classDefinition: A terrestrial zone which is bounded by constructed, manufactured, or other anthropogenic material entities.
parentDefinition: An environmental zone which is bounded by material parts of a land mass or the atmosphere or space adjacent to it.

classDefinition: A lake which has nutrient-poor water.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake with medium nutrient levels, which allow moderate productivity.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.
classComment: What constitutes a "medium" nutrient level is subject to debate. The thresholds should be set either on a data level or through new subclasses.

classDefinition: A mass of solid material which is primarily composed of plastic.
parentDefinition: An mass of environmental material which is composed primarily of a solid environmental material
parentComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.

classDefinition: A plastic which is composed primarily of polymers produced by a manufacturing process.
parentDefinition: An environnmental material which 1) is composed primarily of polymers with high molecular mass and 2) once deformed does not spontaneously return to its original shape.
parentComment: "High molecular mass" can be ambiguous as it does not set a threshold for what is considered "high". Here we make no commitment to a threshold.

classDefinition: A plastic pellet which is produced such that its size allows it to be rapidly melted and used as input for further downstream manufacturing processes.
parentDefinition: A piece of plastic which is 1) hard, 2) has a smooth external surface, and 3) has a roughly spherical or granular shape.

classDefinition: A piece of plastic which is 1) hard, 2) has a smooth external surface, and 3) has a roughly spherical or granular shape.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is primarily composed of plastic.

classDefinition: An environmental zone which contains, as determined by an officially mandated selection process, one or more ecosystems which include, as parts, ecological communities of global significance for conservation due to their vulnerability and irreplaceability.
parentDefinition: An area of land or of a body of water in which management practices,  through legal or other effective means, prioritise the protection and maintenance of biological diversity, and of natural and associated cultural resources.
classComment: The selection process which determines the whether an area is an important site must follow the best practice specifications and guidelines developed by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), using globally standardised criteria and thresholds. Note that the label 'important site' is chosen to align with SDGIO. The definition is that of "key biodiversity area".
parentComment: This class needs revision. Protected areas may be designated for multiple uses, and more clarity is needed. Further, the protections applied to the entities within the site may not prioritise biodiversity conservation. At a very general level, "protection" suggests that some forms of use are, in principle, excluded.

classDefinition: The system of public works in a country, state or region, including roads, utility lines and public buildings.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.
classComment: We label this as 'public infrastructure', as the OECD definition refers specifically to public constructed features. The parts of public infrastructure are not exhaustive and should be extended as needed.

classLabel: usage of an environment for infrastructure and utilities
classDefinition: A planned environmental usage process during which an environment supports 1) enterprises concerned with the provision to the public of essentials, such as electricity or water or 2) the basic network or foundation of capital facilities or community investments which are necessary to support economic and community activities.
parentDefinition: A planned process during which humans access and obtain resources, benefits, or services from a natural or anthropised ecosystem.

classDefinition: A road which is publically accessible.
parentDefinition: An open way for the passage of vehicles, persons, or animals on land.

classDefinition: A building which is publically accessible.
parentDefinition: A permanent walled and roofed construction.

classDefinition: A cable used to trasmit electricity from its point of production to its point of consumption.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: A cable used to trasmit electricity from its point of production to its point of consumption.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A utility line which services the public power grid.
parentDefinition: A cable used to trasmit electricity from its point of production to its point of consumption.
classComment: Created for SDGIO, we treat "public" as "publically accessible" where the semantics of access are dealt with in SDGIO.

classDefinition: A populated place where groups of housing units have been constructed on land that the occupants have no legal claim to, or occupy illegally, or where dwellings are not in compliance with current planning and building regulations.
parentDefinition: A settlement which is not associated with or directed by official planning processes and which typically lacks municipal services and infrastructure such as sanitation, water services, and waste management services.
classComment: Informal settlements may be urban or rural.
parentComment: Informal settlements need not be illegal.

classDefinition: A process that realizes a plan which is the concretization of a plan specification.
parentDefinition: An occurrent that has temporal proper parts and for some time t, p s-depends_on some material entity at t.

classDefinition: A process that realizes a plan which is the concretization of a plan specification.
parentDefinition: p is a process = Def. p is an occurrent that has temporal proper parts and for some time t, p s-depends_on some material entity at t. (axiom label in BFO2 Reference: [083-003])

classDefinition: A fire is a process whereby rapid and exothermic oxidation of a material through a combustion process releases heat, light, and other products.
parentDefinition: Combustion or burning is a high-temperature exothermic redox chemical reaction between a fuel and an oxidant that produces oxidized, often gaseous products, in a mixture termed as smoke.
classComment: Not to be confused with a flame - the visible portion of gas released by a fire . Oxidation processes such as rusting or biological digestion are not subsumed here.
parentComment: Unlike the "combustion" class in the Chemical Methods Ontology, this class is not necessarily a planned process. http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/CHMO_0001473

classDefinition: A conflagration which is uncontrolled and combusts material in a vegetated area, be it rural or wild.
parentDefinition: A fire which occurs in a large spatial area poses a risk to human life, animal life, health, and/or property.
classComment: The definition of "wildland" or "wild" is ambiguous.

classDefinition: A fire which occurs in a large spatial area poses a risk to human life, animal life, health, and/or property.
parentDefinition: A fire is a process whereby rapid and exothermic oxidation of a material through a combustion process releases heat, light, and other products.
parentComment: Not to be confused with a flame - the visible portion of gas released by a fire . Oxidation processes such as rusting or biological digestion are not subsumed here.

classDefinition: A flame which is produced by the combustion of hydrocarbon fuel.
parentDefinition: A portion of gas which is emitted by a fire or other exothermic reaction, is of increased temperature, and typically emits light in the visible range.

classDefinition: A portion of gas which is emitted by a fire or other exothermic reaction, is of increased temperature, and typically emits light in the visible range.
parentDefinition: A material entity which is composed of one or more chemical entities and has neither independent shape nor volume but tends to expand indefinitely.

classDefinition: A wildfire which occurs in a forest, primarily consuming vegetation as fuel.
parentDefinition: A fire which occurs on land, typically consuming a terrestrial ecosystem as fuel.

classDefinition: A fire which occurs on land, typically consuming a terrestrial ecosystem as fuel.
parentDefinition: A conflagration which is uncontrolled and combusts material in a vegetated area, be it rural or wild.
parentComment: The definition of "wildland" or "wild" is ambiguous.

classDefinition: A process whereby a large volume of gas moves due to a disequilibrium of physical forces.
parentDefinition: An advective transport process during which a fluid moves.
classComment: This class refers to all forms of "wind": from the familiar movement of air in the Earth's atmosphere to the solar wind. Use a subclass to be more precise.

parentDefinition: A process whereby a large volume of gas moves due to a disequilibrium of physical forces.
parentComment: This class refers to all forms of "wind": from the familiar movement of air in the Earth's atmosphere to the solar wind. Use a subclass to be more precise.

parentDefinition: A process which occurs within an atmosphere.
parentComment: This class will be populated by inference and is primarily organisational.

classDefinition: A process which occurs within an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
classComment: This class will be populated by inference and is primarily organisational.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A stream of plasma primarily composed of electrons, protons, and alpha particles ejected from the upper atmosphere of a star.
parentDefinition: A process whereby a large volume of plasma moves due to a disequilibrium of physical forces.

classDefinition: A process whereby a large volume of plasma moves due to a disequilibrium of physical forces.
parentDefinition: An advective transport process during which a fluid moves.

classDefinition: An electromagnetic radiation process during which electromagnetic waves or their quanta are emitted from a star.
parentDefinition: A radiation process during which waves (or their quanta, photons) of the electromagnetic field propagate (radiate) through space carrying electromagnetic energy.
parentComment: Note that this class is concerned only with active radiative processes: static electric and magnetic fields are not inlcuded. All electromagnetic radiation carries radiant energy.

classDefinition: An astronomical object which is composed primarily of luminous plasma held in a spherical form by gravitational forces.
parentDefinition: An object which is naturally occuring, bound together by gravitational or electromagnetic forces, and surrounded by space.
parentComment: Astronomical bodies are usually cohesive, thus the use of the term 'object' sensu BFO 'object'.

classDefinition: An astronomical object which is composed primarily of luminous plasma held in a spherical form by gravitational forces.
