parentDefinition: A process during which a mass composed of one or more environmental materials, present within a given site, decreases.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: A process during which a part of an ice mass breaks away from the main mass.
parentDefinition: Mass wasting is the geomorphic process by which solid environmental material such as soil, sand, regolith, and/or rock move downslope typically as a mass, largely under the force of gravity, but frequently affected by water and water content as in submarine environments and mudslides.
parentComment: Of interest for future development: Some causes of mass wasting earthquakes, increased overburden from structures, increased soil moisture, reduction of roots holding the soil to bedrock, undercutting of the slope by excavation or erosion, weathering by frost heave, bioturbation, volcanic edifice over-steepening. Some processes that reduce mass wasting: Afforestation, Reforestation, Terracing steps on slopes (reduce angle of slope). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_wasting.

classDefinition: A mass which is lower than normal or average.
parentDefinition: A physical quality that inheres in a bearer by virtue of the proportion of the bearer's amount of matter.

classDefinition: A mass which is lower than normal or average.
parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is decreased compared to normal or average.

classDefinition: A mass wasting process during which refuse from human activities, usually accumulated at a dumping site, falls down a slope under the force of gravity.
parentDefinition: Mass wasting is the geomorphic process by which solid environmental material such as soil, sand, regolith, and/or rock move downslope typically as a mass, largely under the force of gravity, but frequently affected by water and water content as in submarine environments and mudslides.
classComment: "At least 48 people have been killed in a landslide at a vast rubbish dump on the outskirts of Ethiopia's capital Addis Ababa, officials say...Hundreds of people attempt to make a living by scavenging at the landfill site, sifting through the rubbish for items they can sell, the BBC's Emmanuel Igunza in Addis Ababa reports" BBC Africa reports
parentComment: Of interest for future development: Some causes of mass wasting earthquakes, increased overburden from structures, increased soil moisture, reduction of roots holding the soil to bedrock, undercutting of the slope by excavation or erosion, weathering by frost heave, bioturbation, volcanic edifice over-steepening. Some processes that reduce mass wasting: Afforestation, Reforestation, Terracing steps on slopes (reduce angle of slope). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_wasting.

classDefinition: An animal house which is only partially surrounded by a building envelope.
parentDefinition: A house used for sheltering non-human animals.
parentComment: While humans are animals, this class does not refer to human houses.

classDefinition: A morphological quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's affording unobstructed passage or view.
parentDefinition: A morphological quality pertaining to the degree to which an object contains an opening, aperture, orifice or vent.

classDefinition: An ice loss process which occurs in the low-altitude area of a glacier or ice sheet below the firn layer.
parentDefinition: An environmental system process which occurs within a glacier or ice sheet.

classDefinition: An ice loss process which occurs in the low-altitude area of a glacier or ice sheet below the firn layer.
parentDefinition: A process during which the mass of ice constituting a glacier decreases.

classDefinition: An environmental system process which occurs within a glacier or ice sheet.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A process during which the mass of ice constituting a glacier decreases.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: A process during which the mass of ice constituting a glacier decreases.
parentDefinition: A material decumulation process during which the mass of an existing ice mass decreases in size.

classDefinition: A process during which the mass of ice constituting a glacier decreases.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which involves glaciers or ice sheets.
parentComment: Note that ice sheets and glaciers are confounded and confused in multiple communities and across multiple sources.

classDefinition: A sublimation process during which water ice transitions into a gaseous state.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: A sublimation process during which water ice transitions into a gaseous state.
parentDefinition: Sublimation is a process during which a portion of some solid undergoes a phase transition into a portion of some gas.

classDefinition: An animal house which has a complete building envelope.
parentDefinition: A house used for sheltering non-human animals.
parentComment: While humans are animals, this class does not refer to human houses.

classDefinition: A manufactured cage which may be used to confine, contain, or protect an animal.
parentDefinition: A manufactured structure made of interspaced structural elements such as metal or wooden bars or wires held together such that they may be used to confine, contain, or protect something.

classDefinition: A petting zoo is a zoological garden which contains domesticated non-human animals and some wild non-human animals that are docile enough for humans to touch and feed.
parentDefinition: A facility in which animals are confined within enclosures and displayed to the public, and in which they may also be bred.
classComment: Petting zoos are often nested within a zoological garden featuring wild non-human animals, not docile enough for humans to touch.

classDefinition: An artificial channel which transports unwanted water or waste liquids away from their source, either to a more useful area, a receptacle, or into sewers or stormwater mains as waste discharge to be released or processed.
parentDefinition: A channel of a watercource which has been constructed by humans or their technologies.

classDefinition: A facility in which non-human animals are slaughtered and processed for human consumption.
parentDefinition: An industrial building is a building within which goods are produced and, optionally, stored or within which services are rendered.
parentComment: It's possible that this will become an inferred class in the future. The United Nations' International Standard Industrial Classification should be referred to when expanding this branch. ISIC can also be used to identify processes. See http://unstats.un.org/unsd/cr/registry/regcst.asp?Cl=27&Lg=1.

classDefinition: A facility in which non-human animals are slaughtered and processed, but not for human consumption.
parentDefinition: An industrial building is a building within which goods are produced and, optionally, stored or within which services are rendered.
classComment: Animals killed in knacker's yards are not fit for human consumption or can no longer be used to perform work.
parentComment: It's possible that this will become an inferred class in the future. The United Nations' International Standard Industrial Classification should be referred to when expanding this branch. ISIC can also be used to identify processes. See http://unstats.un.org/unsd/cr/registry/regcst.asp?Cl=27&Lg=1.

classDefinition: A building which is used to care for a human child during the working day by a person, outside the child's immediate family, other than that child's legal guardians.
parentDefinition: A building which is primarily used to facilitate the buying or selling of goods or services.
classComment: This is a kind of day care facility. A facility need not be a building.
parentComment: "Commerce includes legal, economic, political, social, cultural and technological systems that are in operation in any country or internationally."

classDefinition: A building in which fish are subject to a series of operations to prepare them for human consumption.
parentDefinition: A food processing building is a building in which materials that contain or consist of essential body nutrients - such as carbohydrates, fats, proteins, vitamins, or minerals - and may be ingested and assimilated by an organism to produce energy, stimulate growth, and maintain life are converted alternative forms.
classComment: This is a kind of fish processing facility. Facilities need not be buildings, factory ships may be considered fish processing facilities.
parentComment: The semantics of food are being handled by FOODON http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/foodon.owl

parentDefinition: An environment which is determined by an anatomical entity.
classComment: An environment determined by the presence of a mushroom.

classDefinition: An environment which is determined by an anatomical entity.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: An ecosystem which bridges two or more adjoining ecosystems and through which organisms may move or propagate.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
classComment: Ecological corridors may or may not provide habitats for the organisms which move through them. They serve to mitigate the effects of habitat fragmentation by allowing genetic exchange between populations that would otherwise be separated by, e.g., human activity.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classDefinition: An ecological corridor through which organisms move during a migration process.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which bridges two or more adjoining ecosystems and through which organisms may move or propagate.
classComment: This term refers to the ecosystem(s) the organisms traverse, rather than the spatial track they cover. The latter is better placed in a geospatial ontology.
parentComment: Ecological corridors may or may not provide habitats for the organisms which move through them. They serve to mitigate the effects of habitat fragmentation by allowing genetic exchange between populations that would otherwise be separated by, e.g., human activity.

classDefinition: A building in which nursing aides and skilled nurses provide care and treatment to residents who have significant difficulty coping with the required activities of daily living.
parentDefinition: A human construction in which healthcare is provided.

classDefinition: A human house which serves as a long-term shelter for its inhabitants and within which they store personal property.
classComment: This term is not to be used for hotels, hostels, inns and the like, which provides shorter-term stays.
parentComment: A human house is a house which provides a dwelling-place for humans.

classDefinition: A building within which food and drink are prepared and served to customers in exchange for money or other goods and/or services.
parentDefinition: A building which is primarily used to facilitate the buying or selling of goods or services.
parentComment: "Commerce includes legal, economic, political, social, cultural and technological systems that are in operation in any country or internationally."

classDefinition: A part of an ecosystem which may be or has been used for one or more overnight stays by humans sheltering in tents, camper vans, caravans, or improvised shelters.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic geographic feature is a geographic feature resulting from the influence of human beings on nature.

classDefinition: A campground which has been modified by humans to provide and maintain facilities for camping such as fire pits, road access, latrines, and garbage bins.
parentDefinition: A part of an ecosystem which may be or has been used for one or more overnight stays by humans sheltering in tents, camper vans, caravans, or improvised shelters.

classDefinition: A campground which has no pre-existing facilities installed or maintained by humans, usually found outside of anthropised ecosystems.
parentDefinition: A part of an ecosystem which may be or has been used for one or more overnight stays by humans sheltering in tents, camper vans, caravans, or improvised shelters.

classDefinition: A manufactured product which may hold a volume of heated water suitable for one or more humans to bathe in, usually for the purposes of hydrotherapy or pleasure.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: An open system in non-equilibrium with its environment that exhibits time translation symmetry breaking.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: While the usage of the term is still debated, the general idea is that time crystals (which have been made using ytterbium ions and defect-bearing diamonds) break temporal symmetry analogously to how mineral crystal break spatial symmetry. While spatial crystals are inhomogeneous in space (vs a gas, which is distributed evenly) due to the ordering of their atoms, the properties of atoms in a time crystal are inhomogeneous in the time dimension.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: An open system in non-equilibrium with its environment that exhibits time translation symmetry breaking.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: While the usage of the term is still debated, the general idea is that time crystals (which have been made using ytterbium ions and defect-bearing diamonds) break temporal symmetry analogously to how mineral crystal break spatial symmetry. While spatial crystals are inhomogeneous in space (vs a gas, which is distributed evenly) due to the ordering of their atoms, the properties of atoms in a time crystal are inhomogeneous in the time dimension.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: Water which is partially contained within a fissure or a geological fracture.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.
classComment: While containment is often enough to classify this subtype of water, it is expected that the water's composition is altered by contact with the solid material bounding the fissure's site.

classLabel: subsurface zone of an astronomical body
classDefinition: An environmental zone which includes those regions of an astronomical body which are not exposed to its atmosphere or space.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classLabel: subsurface zone of an astronomical body
classDefinition: An environmental zone which includes those regions of an astronomical body which are not exposed to its atmosphere or space.
parentDefinition: A site which has its extent determined by the presence or influence of one or more components of an environmental system or the processes occurring therein.
parentComment: Formerly, this class was an experimental class and a subclass of "environmental feature". It is now aligned to BFO. The class was not obsoleted as the core semantics maintained their stability through its transition.

classDefinition: A region which overlaps parts of one or more planetary structural layers which are located below a continental landmass.
parentDefinition: Regions of a planet which are not exposed to the planet's atmosphere or space, often comprising parts of one or more planetary structural layers.

classDefinition: A hill which has a surface that is partially or wholly covered by plant communities.
parentDefinition: A rounded elevation of limited extent rising above the surrounding land with local relief of less than 300m.
classComment: This class will be axiomatised to coordinate with the 'vegetated area' class.

classDefinition: A piece of plastic which has a diameter less than five millimetres.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is primarily composed of plastic.
classComment: This classification is based on the thresholds detailed in GESAMP report # 99 on recommendation from the SDG 14 indicator team. While the definition is in accordance with the common use of this term (as per GESAMP report # 99), alternative size classifications exist. Alternative classifications are a piece of plastic which is between 1 and 5 millimetres in diameter, a piece of plastic which has a diameter less than 1 millimetre, or a piece of plastic which has a diameter greater than 330 micrometres. The use of the word diameter in this case was understood to mean the generalised form of diameter, i.e. the largest distance between two points belonging to an object.

classDefinition: A microplastic particle which is the direct output of a manufacturing process.
parentDefinition: A piece of plastic which has a diameter less than five millimetres.
parentComment: This classification is based on the thresholds detailed in GESAMP report # 99 on recommendation from the SDG 14 indicator team. While the definition is in accordance with the common use of this term (as per GESAMP report # 99), alternative size classifications exist. Alternative classifications are a piece of plastic which is between 1 and 5 millimetres in diameter, a piece of plastic which has a diameter less than 1 millimetre, or a piece of plastic which has a diameter greater than 330 micrometres. The use of the word diameter in this case was understood to mean the generalised form of diameter, i.e. the largest distance between two points belonging to an object.

classDefinition: A microplastic particle which is derived from the breakdown of larger plastic debris.
parentDefinition: A piece of plastic which has a diameter less than five millimetres.
classComment: The debris that make up the Great Pacific Garbage Patch constantly release microplastics as they break down.
parentComment: This classification is based on the thresholds detailed in GESAMP report # 99 on recommendation from the SDG 14 indicator team. While the definition is in accordance with the common use of this term (as per GESAMP report # 99), alternative size classifications exist. Alternative classifications are a piece of plastic which is between 1 and 5 millimetres in diameter, a piece of plastic which has a diameter less than 1 millimetre, or a piece of plastic which has a diameter greater than 330 micrometres. The use of the word diameter in this case was understood to mean the generalised form of diameter, i.e. the largest distance between two points belonging to an object.

classDefinition: An envirommental system which bridges two or more biomes and which includes ecological communities which blend these biomes' phylogenetic and phenotypic compositions.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
classComment: There are many subtypes of ecotone, some with sharp transitions and others with gradual, patchy transitions between communities. From Wikipedia:Ecotone - The word ecotone was coined from a combination of eco(logy) plus -tone, from the Greek tonos or tension – in other words, a place where ecologies are in tension.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classDefinition: An ecotone which bridges a subpolar coniferous forest biome and a tundra biome.
parentDefinition: An ecotone which overlaps at least one biome which supports the growth and persistence of trees and at least one that does not. Before ceasing altogether, tree growth becomes sparse and trees appear stunted as conditions become less favourable along this ecotone.
classComment:
Major vegetational ecotones such as that between the northern edge of the Boreal Forest in North America (or taiga in Russia) and the arctic tundra, known as the arctic tree-line ecotone, are controlled largely by large-scale airmass contrasts and are sensitive to climatic change, as noted by R. A. Bryson (1966).
Harvey Nichols, Ph.D. , April 23, 2017
Emeritus Professor of Biology.

classDefinition: A woodland which has an understory partially covered by lichen mats and tundra-like vegetation.
parentDefinition: A conifer woodland is a woodland which has a tree community primarily composed of coniferous trees, from the Division Pinophyta, also known as Coniferophyta or Coniferae.

classDefinition: A material transformation process during which water ice is formed.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: A material transformation process during which water ice is formed.
parentDefinition: A material transformation process during which a material's viscosity increase either through a reduction in temperature, through chemical reactions, or other physical effects.
parentComment: Sometimes the increase in viscosity is great enough to crystallize or solidify the substance in question.

classDefinition: A material congelation process during which a liquid turns into a solid when its temperature is lowered below its melting point.
parentDefinition: A material transformation process during which a material's viscosity increase either through a reduction in temperature, through chemical reactions, or other physical effects.
parentComment: Sometimes the increase in viscosity is great enough to crystallize or solidify the substance in question.

classDefinition: A process during which an ecosystem - natural or anthropised - is changed by the actions of humans.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which is driven by the action of humans.

classDefinition: A tree line ecotone across which trees cease to grow due to the low temperatures or duration of snow cover that occur at increased elevations above mean sea level.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: A tree line ecotone across which trees cease to grow due to the low temperatures or duration of snow cover that occur at increased elevations above mean sea level.
parentDefinition: An ecotone which overlaps at least one biome which supports the growth and persistence of trees and at least one that does not. Before ceasing altogether, tree growth becomes sparse and trees appear stunted as conditions become less favourable along this ecotone.

classDefinition: A tree line ecotone across which trees cease to grow due to insufficient water availability due to a lack of water-based precipitation.
parentDefinition: An ecotone which overlaps at least one biome which supports the growth and persistence of trees and at least one that does not. Before ceasing altogether, tree growth becomes sparse and trees appear stunted as conditions become less favourable along this ecotone.

classDefinition: A tree line ecotone across which trees cease to grow due to insufficient water availability caused by exposure to increased solar radiation and a lack of rainfall.
parentDefinition: A tree line ecotone across which trees cease to grow due to insufficient water availability due to a lack of water-based precipitation.
classComment: The lack of rainfall in these ecotones is often due to their elevation above the condensation line of atmospheric water vapour.

classDefinition: A tree line ecotone which contains gaps in tree coverage due to decreased biodiversity in tree-forming plant species: gaps are above the alpine tree line for some species yet below the desert tree line for others, and no species with intermediate tolerances are present.
parentDefinition: An ecotone which overlaps at least one biome which supports the growth and persistence of trees and at least one that does not. Before ceasing altogether, tree growth becomes sparse and trees appear stunted as conditions become less favourable along this ecotone.
classComment: Mountain ranges isolated by oceans or deserts may have restricted repertoires of tree species and contain double tree lines.

classDefinition: A planet that is composed primarily of silicate rocks or metals.
parentDefinition: A planet is an astronomical body orbiting a star or stellar remnant that is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity, is not massive enough to cause thermonuclear fusion, and has cleared its neighbouring region of planetesimals.
parentComment: Considerable debate on the definition of planet exists.

classDefinition: A material which is composed primarily of one or more pure metals and which shows their properties.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: While this class allows for some degree of contamination by non-metal substances, the material represented should show at least some of the typical features of a pure metal: hardness (except for liquid metals), opacity, lustre, malleability, fusibility, ductile  and good electrical and thermal conductivity.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: A material which is composed primarily of one or more pure metals and which shows their properties.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: While this class allows for some degree of contamination by non-metal substances, the material represented should show at least some of the typical features of a pure metal: hardness (except for liquid metals), opacity, lustre, malleability, fusibility, ductile  and good electrical and thermal conductivity.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: A planetary atmosphere which is formed as a result of the accretion of gaseous matter from the accretion disc of the planet's star.
parentDefinition: An atmosphere which surrounds a planet.
classComment: Planets such as Jupiter and Saturn have primary atmospheres. Primary atmospheres are very thick compared to secondary atmospheres like the one found on Earth. The primary atmosphere was lost on the terrestrial planets due to a combination of surface temperature, mass of the atoms and escape velocity of the planet.

classDefinition: A planetary atmosphere which has formed as a result of its planet's volcanic activity, or by accumulation of material from comet impacts.
parentDefinition: An atmosphere which surrounds a planet.
classComment: A secondary atmosphere is found on many terrestrial planets such as Mercury, Venus, and Mars. Secondary atmospheres are relatively thin compared to primary atmospheres like Jupiter's. Earth has a tertiary atmosphere due to biotic processes.

classDefinition: A planetary atmosphere which has formed as a result of biotic processes modifying a secondary atmosphere.
parentDefinition: An atmosphere which surrounds a planet.
classComment: Further processing of a secondary atmosphere, for example by the processes of biological life, can produce a tertiary atmosphere, such as that of Earth.

classDefinition: A sedimentary rock which is primarily composed of the fossilized, siliceous remains of diatoms mixed with varying amounts of other clays and minerals.
parentDefinition: A rock formed by deposition of either clastic sediments, organic matter, or chemical precipitates (evaporites), followed by compaction of the particulate matter and cementation during diagenesis.
classComment: This material is easily crumbled into a fine white to off-white powder. The powder has a particle size ranging from less than 3 micrometres to more than 1 millimetre, but typically 10 to 200 micrometres. The diatoms in each deposit contain different amounts of silica, depending on the age of the deposit. The species of diatom may differ among deposits. The species of diatom is dependent upon the age and paleo-environment of the deposit. In turn, the shape of a diatom is determined by its species. The typical chemical composition of oven-dried diatomaceous earth is 80 to 90% silica, with 2 to 4% alumina (attributed mostly to clay minerals) and 0.5 to 2% iron oxide.

classDefinition: A piece of rock which is primarily composed of diatomite: the fossilized, siliceous remains of diatoms mixed with varying amounts of other clays and minerals.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is composed primarily of rock.
classComment: Diatomite is easily crumbled into a fine white to off-white powder. The powder has a particle size ranging from less than 3 micrometres to more than 1 millimetre, but typically 10 to 200 micrometres. The diatoms in each deposit contain different amounts of silica, depending on the age of the deposit. The species of diatom may differ among deposits. The species of diatom is dependent upon the age and paleo-environment of the deposit. In turn, the shape of a diatom is determined by its species. The typical chemical composition of oven-dried diatomaceous earth is 80 to 90% silica, with 2 to 4% alumina (attributed mostly to clay minerals) and 0.5 to 2% iron oxide.

classDefinition: Wastewater which is produced by industrial activity and which contains chemical contaminants other than those associated with urine and fecal matter.
parentDefinition: Water that has been adversely affected in quality by anthropogenic influence.

classDefinition: A construction which is designed to hold water in which humans may swim or perform other leisure activities.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: A constructed swimming pool which is owned by a non-governmental legal entity or a collective of such entities.
parentDefinition: A construction which is designed to hold water in which humans may swim or perform other leisure activities.

classDefinition: A constructed swimming pool which is owned by a governmental or state entity.
parentDefinition: A construction which is designed to hold water in which humans may swim or perform other leisure activities.

classDefinition: A hydraulic-engineering installation which transports water - in specified amounts, of a specified quality, and in accordance with a water-consumption plan - from a source of supply into a conduit.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.
classComment: Sources of water include rivers, lakes, reservoirs, and other water bodies. Conduits include canals, pipelines, and tunnels. Water intakes typically transport water for purposes of hydroelectric power engineering, water supply, or irrigation.

classDefinition: A building which provides the site for food services with little or no waiting staff furnishing table service.
parentDefinition: A building within which food and drink are prepared and served to customers in exchange for money or other goods and/or services.

classDefinition: A food shop which sells a selection of food products that are not typical dietary components of the human population it is co-located with.
parentDefinition: A food shop in which food products are the primary offer for sale or trade.
classComment: The food products sold in a delicatessen are often considered unusual by the majority of its customers and may come from foreign food supplies which are not widely imported into its region of operation.

classDefinition: A food shop in which food products are the primary offer for sale or trade.
parentDefinition: A shop in which a business offers food products for sale or trade.
parentComment: Whether food is the primary product offered by the business or simply one of the products it offers is not specified in this class.

classDefinition: A truck which is equipped to cook and sell food.
parentDefinition: A truck is a motor vehicle which, as its primary funcion, transports cargo rather than human passangers.
classComment: Due to the facilities on board, food trucks are often larger than other trucks with comparable mechanics.

classDefinition: A restaurant which provides prepared meals or other food products that the purchaser must eat off its premises.
parentDefinition: A building within which food and drink are prepared and served to customers in exchange for money or other goods and/or services.

classDefinition: A booth with an open window on one side.
parentDefinition: A building which is primarily used to facilitate the buying or selling of goods or services.
classComment: This definition of kiosk is characteristic of the Western hemisphere and used in English-speaking countries.
parentComment: "Commerce includes legal, economic, political, social, cultural and technological systems that are in operation in any country or internationally."

classDefinition: A kiosk from which food products are sold.
parentDefinition: A booth with an open window on one side.
classComment: This definition of kiosk is characteristic of the Western hemisphere and used in English-speaking countries.
parentComment: This definition of kiosk is characteristic of the Western hemisphere and used in English-speaking countries.

classDefinition: A manufactured product which is designed to catch and hold animals.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: An animal trap which consists of a container set flush with the ground such that animals moving along the ground may fall in and be available for examination or collection.
parentDefinition: A manufactured product which is designed to catch and hold animals.

classDefinition: A pitfall trap in which a glass, plastic, or metal container devoid of accumulations of any liquid is used to contain any animal that falls inside.
parentDefinition: An animal trap which consists of a container set flush with the ground such that animals moving along the ground may fall in and be available for examination or collection.

classDefinition: A pitfall trap in which the container used to hold trapped animals is filled with a liquid solution formulated to hold, kill, and preserve any animal or animals which falls within it.
parentDefinition: An animal trap which consists of a container set flush with the ground such that animals moving along the ground may fall in and be available for examination or collection.
classComment: Aqueous solutions used in these traps include: formalin (10% formaldehyde), alcohol, methylated spirits, trisodium phosphate and picric acid.

classDefinition: A channel of an intermittent stream which contains a river when water supply exceeds evapotranspiration and bed seepage.
parentDefinition: A channel through which a directional flow of water periodically occurs, ceasing when bed seepage or evapotranspiration exceed the available water supply.

parentLabel: container of an intermittent water body
classDefinition: A channel through which a directional flow of water periodically occurs, ceasing when bed seepage or evapotranspiration exceed the available water supply.
parentDefinition: A depression which is is periodically filled with water when water supply exceeds evapotranspiration and bed seepage.
parentComment: This was formerly represented as a water body, which would not be valid during dry periods. This class more properly refers to the container of the water body, thusfar always some depression, which periodically contains a water body.

classDefinition: A part of an ecosystem which has been allocated to host a gathering of people for multiple entertainment or commercial activities.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic geographic feature is a geographic feature resulting from the influence of human beings on nature.
classComment: Fairgrounds, or parts thereof, may be constructed (e.g. concreted over) or be natural (e.g. clearings or heaths), thus land use is the key differentia.

classDefinition: A fairground which is used to exhibit agricultural technology, livestock, and farm-related activity.
parentDefinition: A part of an ecosystem which has been allocated to host a gathering of people for multiple entertainment or commercial activities.
parentComment: Fairgrounds, or parts thereof, may be constructed (e.g. concreted over) or be natural (e.g. clearings or heaths), thus land use is the key differentia.

classDefinition: A part of an ecosystem where people gather for the purchase and sale of provisions, livestock, and other goods.
parentDefinition: An anthropogenic geographic feature is a geographic feature resulting from the influence of human beings on nature.
classComment: As with campgrounds and fairgrounds, land use is the key differentia here. The regularity of marketplace activities may provide a differentia for further growth of this branch.

classLabel: usage of an environment for business
classDefinition: A planned environmental usage process during which an environment supports facilities associated with commerce or the earning of a livelihood through means other than manufacturing or the provision of a public service.
parentDefinition: A planned process during which humans access and obtain resources, benefits, or services from a natural or anthropised ecosystem.
classComment: This class includes activities carried out in commercial offices, meeting centres, art studios, recording studios, film sets, warehouses, and distribution centres.

classDefinition: A food shop in which the food products on offer are restricted to those produced in a region and cultural setting other than that of the shop's locality.
parentDefinition: A shop in which a business offers food products for sale or trade.
parentComment: Whether food is the primary product offered by the business or simply one of the products it offers is not specified in this class.

classDefinition: A plumbing fixture which is bowl-shaped and used for washing hands, dishwashing, and other purposes.
parentDefinition: An exchangeable device which can be connected to a plumbing system to deliver and drain water.

classDefinition: A plumbing fixture which may serve as a container for water in which humans or other animals may bathe.
parentDefinition: An exchangeable device which can be connected to a plumbing system to deliver and drain water.
classComment: Of course, there are other uses for bathtubs.

classDefinition: A plumbing fixture within which a human or other animal may bathe under a spray of water.
parentDefinition: An exchangeable device which can be connected to a plumbing system to deliver and drain water.
classComment: Indoors, there is a drain in the floor. Most showers have temperature, spray pressure and adjustable showerhead nozzle. Showering is common in Western culture due to the efficiency of using it compared with a bathtub. Its use in hygiene is, therefore, common practice. A shower uses less water on average than a bath: 80 litres for a shower compared with 150 litres for a bath.

classDefinition: A manufacturing process which occurs on a planet.
parentDefinition: A planned process during which raw or recycled materials are transformed into products for use or sale using labour and machines, tools, chemical and biological processing, or formulation.
classComment: See https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/issues/513 for discussion.
parentComment: The term may refer to a range of human activity, from handicraft to high tech, but is most commonly applied to industrial production, in which raw materials are transformed into finished goods on a large scale.

classDefinition: A dry stream channel through which a river had flowed, but now contains no appreciable accumulations of water.
parentDefinition: A stream channel through which no water flows and which has dried, containing no appreciable accumulations of water.
classComment: See http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_01000979 for the channel of an intermittent river.

classDefinition: An environmental system determined by the presence of a plant rhizosphere.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by an organism
classDefinition: An environmental system determined by a green plant.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by a living organism.

classLabel: environmental system determined by an organism
classDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by a living organism.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by an organism
classDefinition: An environmental system determined by an animal.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by a living organism.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a quality
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by materials bearing roughly homogeneous qualities.
classComment: This class (term) is defined by the lack of a quality (i.e. the lack of salinity or increased osmolarity), which is not best-practice ontologically. Use for annotation is generally discouraged and users should use classes which positively describe the material or environment sampled (i.e. stating the qualities the entity has, rather than those it does not).
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation.

classDefinition: A lunar rainbow is a rainbow produced by the refraction of light, which has been reflected from a moon's surface, by water droplets in an astronomical body's atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A rainbow is a photometeor which consists of a spectral separation of light, formed as a result of the reflection, refraction, and dispersion of light in water droplets suspended in an astronomical body's atmosphere.
parentComment: The term 'rainbow' is usually used to refer to solar rainbows, but greater specificity should be used when possible.

classDefinition: A rainbow is a photometeor which consists of a spectral separation of light, formed as a result of the reflection, refraction, and dispersion of light in water droplets suspended in an astronomical body's atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A meteor that is primarily composed of light.
classComment: The term 'rainbow' is usually used to refer to solar rainbows, but greater specificity should be used when possible.

classDefinition: A meteor that is primarily composed of light.
parentDefinition: A meteor is any matter- or energy-based entity which is located in the atmosphere of an astronomical body.

classDefinition: A solar rainbow is a rainbow produced by the refraction of light. which has been emitted by a star, by water droplets in the atmosphere of an astronomical body.
parentDefinition: A rainbow is a photometeor which consists of a spectral separation of light, formed as a result of the reflection, refraction, and dispersion of light in water droplets suspended in an astronomical body's atmosphere.
classComment: The astronomical body where the rainbow occurs is understood to orbit the star which produces the light which forms the rainbow.
parentComment: The term 'rainbow' is usually used to refer to solar rainbows, but greater specificity should be used when possible.

classDefinition: A meteor which is primarily composed of water.
parentDefinition: A meteor is any matter- or energy-based entity which is located in the atmosphere of an astronomical body.

classDefinition: A photometeor which is formed as a result of sudden electrostatic discharge in the atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A meteor that is primarily composed of light.
classComment: This phenomenon is often treated as interchangeable with the process of electrostatic discharge that causes it.

classDefinition: A meteor which is primarily composed of rock.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is composed primarily of rock.

classDefinition: A meteor which is primarily composed of rock.
parentDefinition: A meteor is any matter- or energy-based entity which is located in the atmosphere of an astronomical body.

classDefinition: An astronomical body which is composed of rocky or metallic materials and is considerably smaller than asteroids.
parentDefinition: An object which is naturally occuring, bound together by gravitational or electromagnetic forces, and surrounded by space.
parentComment: Astronomical bodies are usually cohesive, thus the use of the term 'object' sensu BFO 'object'.

classDefinition: A rainbow which forms from sunlight which has been reflected off a body of water prior to its interaction with water droplets in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A rainbow is a photometeor which consists of a spectral separation of light, formed as a result of the reflection, refraction, and dispersion of light in water droplets suspended in an astronomical body's atmosphere.
classComment: Not to be confused with a reflected rainbow, which is not a photometeor.
parentComment: The term 'rainbow' is usually used to refer to solar rainbows, but greater specificity should be used when possible.

classDefinition: A solar rainbow which is formed by a narrow band of wavelengths, the rest of the spectrum having been scattered away by an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A solar rainbow is a rainbow produced by the refraction of light. which has been emitted by a star, by water droplets in the atmosphere of an astronomical body.
parentComment: The astronomical body where the rainbow occurs is understood to orbit the star which produces the light which forms the rainbow.

classDefinition: A rainbow which forms through the interaction of sunlight with the water droplets which constitute fog or clouds; light is diffracted by these droplets such that the photometeor appears almost white with faint reds on the sky-facing side and faint blues on the planet-facing side of the bow.
parentDefinition: A rainbow is a photometeor which consists of a spectral separation of light, formed as a result of the reflection, refraction, and dispersion of light in water droplets suspended in an astronomical body's atmosphere.
classComment: Often, fogbows are treated as separate from rainbows; however, as the formation processes are much the same, we currently classify these as a subclass of rainbow pending input from domain experts.
parentComment: The term 'rainbow' is usually used to refer to solar rainbows, but greater specificity should be used when possible.

classDefinition: A photometeor which is formed by wave interference of light refracted within water droplets which constitute mist or clouds and consists of one or more concentric, successively dimmer rings, each of which has red wavelengths distant to the glory's centre and blue wavelengths towards the centre.
parentDefinition: A meteor that is primarily composed of light.
classComment: This is not to be confused with a circular rainbow, which is formed through different processes.

classDefinition: A photometeor which is produced by light that is reflected, refracted, and dispersed by ice crystals, capable of acting as prisms and mirrors, suspended in an astronomical body's atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A meteor that is primarily composed of light.

classDefinition: Water which has a very high concentration of nutrients.
parentDefinition: Water with a high nutrient level.
classComment: The thresholds of eutrophy are fluid and often locally defined.

classDefinition: A lake which is composed primarily of water with very high nutrient concentrations.
parentDefinition: A lake which has nutrient-rich water.

classDefinition: A lake which is primarily composed of water with a concentration of dissolved salts greater than that of ocean water.
parentDefinition: A lake whose water contains a considerable concentration of dissolved salts.

classDefinition: A lake which is composed primarily water with high concentrations of humic substances and organic acids, resulting in brown- or tea-coloured colouration.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.
classComment: In response to historical misuse of the term in literature, these lakes are better referred to as "humic lakes". Although dystrophic lakes are often considered acidic and nutrient-poor (oligotrophic), these lakes actually vary greatly in terms of both pH and productivity. Due to the low pH associated with dystrophic lakes, few bacterial species and other aquatic life are able to survive. They are common in the taiga of North America and Eurasia.

classDefinition: A lake which has formed as the result of processes that are not or are only minimally driven by human activity.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A process during which energy is emitted or transmitted in the form of waves or particles through space or a material medium.
parentDefinition: A process during which one entity loses energy to another entity.

classDefinition: A process during which one entity loses energy to another entity.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A radiation process during which energy is transmitted or emitted by means of fast-moving subatomic particles.
parentDefinition: A process during which energy is emitted or transmitted in the form of waves or particles through space or a material medium.

classDefinition: A particle radiation process during which subatomic particles move in the same direction.
parentDefinition: A radiation process during which energy is transmitted or emitted by means of fast-moving subatomic particles.

classDefinition: A radiation process during which waves (or their quanta, photons) of the electromagnetic field propagate (radiate) through space carrying electromagnetic energy.
parentDefinition: A process during which energy is emitted or transmitted in the form of waves or particles through space or a material medium.
classComment: Note that this class is concerned only with active radiative processes: static electric and magnetic fields are not inlcuded. All electromagnetic radiation carries radiant energy.

classDefinition: A radiation process during which mechanical waves generated by oscillations radiate through an environmental material.
parentDefinition: A process during which energy is emitted or transmitted in the form of waves or particles through space or a material medium.
classComment: The mechanical waves generated by this process are also referred to as pressure waves.

classDefinition: Sediment which has its porespace filled by water which has very low levels of sodium chloride and/or other salts.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is formed as a result of the transport and deposition of particles by flowing liquid.
classComment: We do not specify numeric thresholds for saline vs. non-saline here, as this is variable. Consider specifying this on the information and/or data layer for your purposes. If you require an ENVO class with a fixed threshold, please request one using our issue tracker.
parentComment: Sediment is typically deposited on the bed or bottom of a body of water or other liquid.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a material
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by feces.
parentDefinition: An environmental system within which an environmental material strongly influences the system's composition and properties.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation. Subclasses describe environments which are usually permeated by an environmental material. They may also describe environments which are sufficiently close to a material, that their dynamics are strongly influenced by it (e.g. a patch of forest ecosystem neighbouring a uranium dump).

classLabel: environment determined by a metazoan secretion
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a bodily secretion of a metazoan.
parentDefinition: An environment which is determined by an anatomical entity.

classDefinition: A portion of organism substance that is produced by exocrine glands.
parentDefinition: Material anatomical entity in a gaseous, liquid, semisolid or solid state; produced by anatomical structures or derived from inhaled and ingested substances that have been modified by anatomical structures as they pass through the body.

classLabel: environment determined by a plant substance
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a substance produced by a plant.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: A portion of organism substance that is or was part of a plant.
parentDefinition: An anatomical entity that is or was part of a plant.
classComment: Refers to organism substance (CARO:0000004) which is defined as: Material anatomical entity in a gaseous, liquid, semisolid or solid state; produced by anatomical structures or derived from inhaled and ingested substances that have been modified by anatomical structures as they pass through the body and that does not have inherent 3D shape generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome. For plants, the word "body" refers to a whole plant, or part thereof.  Includes substances such as latex, xylem sap, phloem sap, resin, mucilage, oil, cuticle, cutin, and sporopollenin.
parentComment: Includes both material entities such as plant structures and immaterial entities such as plant anatomical spaces. CARO:0000000 'anatomical entity' is defined as: A part of a cellular organism that is either an immaterial entity or a material entity with granularity aboove the level of a protein complex.  Or, a substance produced by a cellular organism with granularity above the level of a protein complex.  Refers to BFO:0000004 'independent continuant'.

classLabel: environment determined by a biofilm on a plant surface
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on the surface of a plant.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classLabel: environment determined by a biofilm on a plant surface
parentLabel: environmental system determined by a material
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on the surface of a plant.
parentDefinition: An environmental system within which an environmental material strongly influences the system's composition and properties.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation. Subclasses describe environments which are usually permeated by an environmental material. They may also describe environments which are sufficiently close to a material, that their dynamics are strongly influenced by it (e.g. a patch of forest ecosystem neighbouring a uranium dump).

classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a digestive tract.
parentDefinition: An environment which is determined by an anatomical entity.

classDefinition: A tube extending from the mouth to the anus.
parentDefinition: Any hollow cylindrical anatomical structure containing a lumen through which substances are transported.

classLabel: environment determined by a biofilm on an animal surface
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on the surface of a animal.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classLabel: environment determined by a biofilm on an animal surface
parentLabel: environmental system determined by a material
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on the surface of a animal.
parentDefinition: An environmental system within which an environmental material strongly influences the system's composition and properties.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation. Subclasses describe environments which are usually permeated by an environmental material. They may also describe environments which are sufficiently close to a material, that their dynamics are strongly influenced by it (e.g. a patch of forest ecosystem neighbouring a uranium dump).

classDefinition: Material anatomical entity that forms the outermost boundary of an anatomical structure.
parentDefinition: Anatomical entity that has mass.

classLabel: environment determined by a biofilm on a fungal surface
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on the surface of a fungus.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classLabel: environment determined by a biofilm on a fungal surface
parentLabel: environmental system determined by a material
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on the surface of a fungus.
parentDefinition: An environmental system within which an environmental material strongly influences the system's composition and properties.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation. Subclasses describe environments which are usually permeated by an environmental material. They may also describe environments which are sufficiently close to a material, that their dynamics are strongly influenced by it (e.g. a patch of forest ecosystem neighbouring a uranium dump).

classDefinition: An anatomical structure that forms all or part of a fungus.
parentDefinition: Material anatomical entity that is a single connected structure with inherent 3D shape generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome.

classDefinition: Sediment which has its porespace filled by water with increased levels of sodium chloride and other salts.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is formed as a result of the transport and deposition of particles by flowing liquid.
classComment: We do not specify numeric thresholds for saline vs. non-saline here, as this is variable. Consider specifying this on the information and/or data layer for your purposes. If you require an ENVO class with a fixed threshold, please request one using our issue tracker.
parentComment: Sediment is typically deposited on the bed or bottom of a body of water or other liquid.

classDefinition: Water which contains a slightly increased concentration of dissolved salts, relative to their concentration in freshwater.
parentDefinition: Water which contains a significant concentration of dissolved salts.
classComment: The United States Geological Survey classifies slightly saline water as having around 1,000 to 3,000 ppm (0.1–0.3%) of dissolved salts.
parentComment: The threshold salt concentration for classifying water as saline varies, but typically begins at about 1,000 to 3,000 parts salt per million parts water or 0.1–0.3% salt by weight.

classDefinition: Water which contains a moderately increased concentration of dissolved salts, relative to their concentration in freshwater.
parentDefinition: Water which contains a significant concentration of dissolved salts.
classComment: The United States Geological Survey classifies moderately saline water as having around 3,000 to 10,000 ppm (0.3–1%) of dissolved salts.
parentComment: The threshold salt concentration for classifying water as saline varies, but typically begins at about 1,000 to 3,000 parts salt per million parts water or 0.1–0.3% salt by weight.

classDefinition: Water which contains a highly increased concentration of dissolved salts, relative to their concentration in freshwater.
parentDefinition: Water which contains a significant concentration of dissolved salts.
classComment: The United States Geological Survey classifies highly saline water as having around 10,000 to 35,000 ppm (1–3.5%) of dissolved salts.
parentComment: The threshold salt concentration for classifying water as saline varies, but typically begins at about 1,000 to 3,000 parts salt per million parts water or 0.1–0.3% salt by weight.

classDefinition: An environmental system determined by a fungal structure.
parentDefinition: An environment which is determined by an anatomical entity.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by an organism
classDefinition: An environmental system determined by a fungal structure.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by a living organism.

classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by sterile water.
parentDefinition: An environment whose dynamics are strongly influenced by water.
classComment: This term can be understood as a negative experimental control primarily composed of sterile water. The quantity of sterile water used may be contaminated; to express pure sterile water, please use http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00005791

classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by hypersaline water.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by saline water.

classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by soil.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a quality
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by soil.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by materials bearing roughly homogeneous qualities.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a material
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by soil.
parentDefinition: An environmental system within which an environmental material strongly influences the system's composition and properties.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation. Subclasses describe environments which are usually permeated by an environmental material. They may also describe environments which are sufficiently close to a material, that their dynamics are strongly influenced by it (e.g. a patch of forest ecosystem neighbouring a uranium dump).

classDefinition: A region which overlaps parts of one or more planetary structural layers which are located below an oceanic plate.
parentDefinition: Regions of a planet which are not exposed to the planet's atmosphere or space, often comprising parts of one or more planetary structural layers.

classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by the subsurface zone of a planet.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by those parts of a planetary subsurface zone which are not saline.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by the subsurface zone of a planet.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a quality
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by sediment.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by materials bearing roughly homogeneous qualities.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a material
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by sediment.
parentDefinition: An environmental system within which an environmental material strongly influences the system's composition and properties.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation. Subclasses describe environments which are usually permeated by an environmental material. They may also describe environments which are sufficiently close to a material, that their dynamics are strongly influenced by it (e.g. a patch of forest ecosystem neighbouring a uranium dump).

classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by sediment permeated by non-saline water.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by sediment.

classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by sediment permeated by saline water.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by sediment.

classLabel: environment determined by a biofilm on a non-saline surface
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on a surface which is exposed to non-saline materials.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classLabel: environment determined by a biofilm on a non-saline surface
parentLabel: environmental system determined by a material
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on a surface which is exposed to non-saline materials.
parentDefinition: An environmental system within which an environmental material strongly influences the system's composition and properties.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation. Subclasses describe environments which are usually permeated by an environmental material. They may also describe environments which are sufficiently close to a material, that their dynamics are strongly influenced by it (e.g. a patch of forest ecosystem neighbouring a uranium dump).

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a quality
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by an aerosol.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by materials bearing roughly homogeneous qualities.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a material
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by an aerosol.
parentDefinition: An environmental system within which an environmental material strongly influences the system's composition and properties.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation. Subclasses describe environments which are usually permeated by an environmental material. They may also describe environments which are sufficiently close to a material, that their dynamics are strongly influenced by it (e.g. a patch of forest ecosystem neighbouring a uranium dump).

classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a saline aerosol.
parentDefinition: An environment which is determined by materials which bear significant concentrations of salts.
parentComment: The thresholds for "significant" concentrations of salts vary widely and thus no committment is made in this class. Subclasses with more explicit thresholds can be made upon request.

classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a saline aerosol.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by an aerosol.

classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by an aerosol with a low concentration of dissolved solutes.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by an aerosol.

classLabel: environment associated with an animal part or small animal
classDefinition: An environmental system determined by part of a living or dead animal, or a whole small animal.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classLabel: environment determined by a biofilm on a saline surface
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on a surface which is exposed to saline materials.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classLabel: environment determined by a biofilm on a saline surface
parentLabel: environmental system determined by a material
classDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on a surface which is exposed to saline materials.
parentDefinition: An environmental system within which an environmental material strongly influences the system's composition and properties.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation. Subclasses describe environments which are usually permeated by an environmental material. They may also describe environments which are sufficiently close to a material, that their dynamics are strongly influenced by it (e.g. a patch of forest ecosystem neighbouring a uranium dump).

classLabel: environment associated with a plant part or small plant
classDefinition: An environmental system determined by part of a living or dead plant, or a whole small plant.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classDefinition: An anatomical entity that is or was part of a plant.
parentDefinition: An independent continuant that is spatially extended whose identity is independent of that of other entities and can be maintained through time.
classComment: Includes both material entities such as plant structures and immaterial entities such as plant anatomical spaces. CARO:0000000 'anatomical entity' is defined as: A part of a cellular organism that is either an immaterial entity or a material entity with granularity aboove the level of a protein complex.  Or, a substance produced by a cellular organism with granularity above the level of a protein complex.  Refers to BFO:0000004 'independent continuant'.

classDefinition: An anatomical entity that is or was part of a plant.
parentDefinition: An independent continuant that is spatially extended whose identity is independent of that of other entities and can be maintained through time.
classComment: Includes both material entities such as plant structures and immaterial entities such as plant anatomical spaces. CARO:0000000 'anatomical entity' is defined as: A part of a cellular organism that is either an immaterial entity or a material entity with granularity aboove the level of a protein complex.  Or, a substance produced by a cellular organism with granularity above the level of a protein complex.  Refers to BFO:0000004 'independent continuant'.

classLabel: environment associated with a fungal tissue
classDefinition: An environmental system determined by part of a living or dead fungus.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classLabel: environment associated with a fungal tissue
classDefinition: An environmental system determined by part of a living or dead fungus.
parentDefinition: An environment which is determined by an anatomical entity.
