classDefinition: A cell culture which is composed of a microbial community of known composition.
parentDefinition: A cell culture is a growth of cells in vitro in an artificial medium for experimental research.
classComment: Mock communities are typically used as positive controls in experiments.

classDefinition: A cell culture is a growth of cells in vitro in an artificial medium for experimental research.
parentDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.

classDefinition: A cell culture which is composed of a single population of bacterial or archaeal cells.
parentDefinition: A cell culture is a growth of cells in vitro in an artificial medium for experimental research.

classDefinition: A lake which is contained within a caldera.
parentDefinition: A lake contained within a volcanic crater.

classDefinition: Water which has an appreciable concentration of dissolved oxygen.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.
classComment: The threshold dissolved oxygen concentration past which water is considered oxic is variable. Typically, this is understood as the concentration at and beyond which organisms inhabiting that water can sustain aerobic metabolism and good health. For most systems, this is above 80% oxygen saturation. Input is welcome here https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/issues/536

classDefinition: A concentration which is higher relative to the normal or average.
parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is increased compared to normal or average.

classDefinition: A concentration which is higher relative to the normal or average.
parentDefinition: A concentration quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's exhibiting concentration.

classDefinition: Water which has low levels of dissolved oxygen.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.
classComment: As with oxic and anoxic water, the thresholds for hypoxia are variable. Typically, a hypoxic state is asserted when dissolved oxygen levels decrease to a level where they have detrimental effects on aerobic aquatic organisms, typically below 30% oxygen saturation.

classDefinition: A lake which is contained in a crater formed by a meteorite impact.
parentDefinition: A lake which is contained in a crater formed by an impact event.

classDefinition: A lake which is contained in a crater formed by an impact event.
parentDefinition: A lake contained within a crater.
parentComment: Note that this class does not commit to what kind of crater contains the lake in question. Please see the subclasses for more specificity.

classDefinition: An impact event is a collision between astronomical bodies.
parentDefinition: An impact event is a collision between material entities, resulting in changes in one or both of those entities.
parentComment: This class is valid for impacts of celestial bodies as well as impacts of missiles, etc. See https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/issues/860

classDefinition: An impact event is a collision between material entities, resulting in changes in one or both of those entities.
parentDefinition: A process during which one entity loses energy to another entity.
classComment: This class is valid for impacts of celestial bodies as well as impacts of missiles, etc. See https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/issues/860

classDefinition: A optical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's not being clear; not transmitting or reflecting light or radiant energy.
parentDefinition: An optical quality which obtains by virtue of the ability of the bearer to absorb visible light.

classDefinition: A lake which is primarily composed of anoxic water.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake which has a hypolimnion composed primarily of anoxic water.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake which has a hypolimnion composed primarily of hypoxic water.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake which is primarily composed of hypoxic water.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake which is primarily composed of oxic water.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake which has a hypolimnion composed primarily of oxic water.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: Environmental variability which inheres in an astronomical body part or in outer space.
parentDefinition: A condition which inheres in an environmental system by virtue of that system undergoing variation in its composition, the distribution of the qualities its components bear, and/or in the processes which occur within it and which it participates in.
classComment: This class refers to all weather, including atmospheric and space weather. Please use a subclass for more specificity.
parentComment: This class is very general, but the nature of environmental variability is indeed quite variable. This class may be refined once we have more subclasses to consider.

classDefinition: A condition which inheres in an environmental system by virtue of that system undergoing variation in its composition, the distribution of the qualities its components bear, and/or in the processes which occur within it and which it participates in.
parentDefinition: An environmental condition is a range of a determinate quality or combination of qualities that are present in an environmental system.
classComment: This class is very general, but the nature of environmental variability is indeed quite variable. This class may be refined once we have more subclasses to consider.
parentComment: A condition defines a restricted range of a given quality or combination of qualities. If an environment class, E, has_condition C, then all qualities listed in C are restricted to the ranges defined in C in E. This is not intended as a logical conditional.

classDefinition: Weather which inheres in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: Environmental variability which inheres in an astronomical body part or in outer space.
classComment: This class refers to the common usage of "weather", referencing the state of a (part of) an astronomical body's atmosphere.
parentComment: This class refers to all weather, including atmospheric and space weather. Please use a subclass for more specificity.

classDefinition: Weather which inheres in outer space.
parentDefinition: Environmental variability which inheres in an astronomical body part or in outer space.
parentComment: This class refers to all weather, including atmospheric and space weather. Please use a subclass for more specificity.

classDefinition: The disposition of an environmental system, particularly those influencing atmospheres, to manifest a cyclic pattern of weather over time.
parentDefinition: A disposition which is realised by an environmental system or system parts thereof.
classComment: Climate is commonly defined as the weather averaged, or otherwise summarised, over a period of time much longer than the duration of any phenomenon that constitutes weather. The standard averaging period is 30 years, but other periods may be used depending on the purpose.
parentComment: This class and its subclasses are experimental and are being developed with NCEAS use cases in mind.

classDefinition: A process during which microscopic solid or liquid objects are formed.
parentDefinition: A process during which a portion of some environmental material is converted into a different material or a collection of materials.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material transformation process only refers to ENVO:environmental material classes (e.g. bulk and typically impure substances), rather than transformations converting a specific chemical into another.

classDefinition: An aerosol formation process which occurs in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A process which occurs within an atmosphere.
parentComment: This class will be populated by inference and is primarily organisational.

classDefinition: An aerosol formation process which occurs in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A material transformation process during which solid or liquid particles form and are suspended in a mass of air, thus creating an aerosol.

classLabel: formation of a solid aerosol in an atmosphere
classDefinition: A process during which an aerosol, consisting of solid particulates suspended in a gas, is formed in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: An aerosol formation process which occurs in an atmosphere.

classLabel: formation of a liquid aerosol in an atmosphere
classDefinition: A process during which an aerosol, consisting of droplets of liquid suspended in gas, is formed in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: An aerosol formation process which occurs in an atmosphere.

classLabel: formation of a solid aerosol from gaseous material in an atmosphere
parentLabel: formation of a solid aerosol in an atmosphere
classDefinition: A process during which microscopic solid particulates are formed from gaseous materials in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A process during which an aerosol, consisting of solid particulates suspended in a gas, is formed in an atmosphere.

classLabel: formation of a liquid aerosol from gaseous material in an atmosphere
parentLabel: formation of a liquid aerosol in an atmosphere
classDefinition: A process during which microscopic liquid droplets are formed from gaseous materials in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A process during which an aerosol, consisting of droplets of liquid suspended in gas, is formed in an atmosphere.

classDefinition: A part of a lithosphere which is separated by other such parts by geographic faults or similar geomorphological discontinuities.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

classDefinition: A process during which pieces of a planetary crust and uppermost mantle move towards one another.
parentDefinition: A process during which pieces of a planetary crust and uppermost mantle move.

classDefinition: A geomorphological feature which is formed where two or more tectonic plates are actively moving away from one another, resulting in deformation of the lithosphere that forms rifts or ridges.
parentDefinition: A geomorphological feature which is formed where two or more tectonic plates move towards, away from, or along one another, resulting in deformation of the lithosphere.

classDefinition: A process during which pieces of a planetary crust and uppermost mantle move along each other in a predominantly horizontal manner, either in a sinistral (left lateral) or dextral (right lateral) direction.
parentDefinition: A process during which pieces of a planetary crust and uppermost mantle move.

classDefinition: A geomorphological feature which is formed where two or more tectonic plates are actively moving along one another in either a sinistral (left lateral) or dextral (right lateral) horizontal direction.
parentDefinition: A geomorphological feature which is formed where two or more tectonic plates move towards, away from, or along one another, resulting in deformation of the lithosphere.

classDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's being roundish, flattish shape, possibly with a slightly angled edge.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's having a horizontal surface without a slope, tilt, or curvature.

classDefinition: A geomorphological feature which is formed where two or more tectonic plates move towards, away from, or along one another, resulting in deformation of the lithosphere.
parentDefinition: A site which has its extent determined by the presence or influence of one or more components of an environmental system or the processes occurring therein.
parentComment: Formerly, this class was an experimental class and a subclass of "environmental feature". It is now aligned to BFO. The class was not obsoleted as the core semantics maintained their stability through its transition.

classDefinition: A convergent tectonic movement process during which one plate moves under another and is forced or sinks due to gravity into a mantle.
parentDefinition: A process during which pieces of a planetary crust and uppermost mantle move towards one another.

classDefinition: A compound astronomical body part in which extensional tectonic processes occur and where the lithosphere is being pulled apart.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is composed of a continuous medium bearing liquid, gaseous, and solid material in variable quantities.

classDefinition: A lake which fills a basin that has been dammed by wind-blown sand,  formed between sand dunes oriented by winds; or formed by wind action under previously arid paleoenvironments.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake which fills a depression where drainage is blocked by solid material transported by a landslide.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake which fills a depression where drainage is blocked by solid material transported by a rockslide.
parentDefinition: A lake which fills a depression where drainage is blocked by solid material transported by a landslide.

classDefinition: A succession of swirling vortices caused by the unsteady separation of flow of a fluid around one or more blunt bodies.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of fluid.
classComment: These vortices are responsible for such phenomena as the "singing" of suspended telephone or power lines, and the vibration of a car antenna at certain speeds.

classDefinition: A channel which was formed as a result of an annelid burrowing through soil, where organic residues lining the burrow have subsequently initiated fossilization.
parentDefinition: A structure which traverses a mass of one or more environmental materials, and encloses a roughly tubular site.

classDefinition: Material which is primarily conposed of the vegetation present in tended pastures: mainly grasses, with an interspersion of legumes and other forbs.
parentComment: This is quite odd and it probably should be obsoleted. Any material that is a participant in an agricultural process can be seen as an agricultural material.

classDefinition: Organic material which is primarily composed of plant structures, living or dead.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: Organic material which is primarily composed of plant structures, living or dead.
parentDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.

classDefinition: A physical space, which may or may not be in a construction, which is used to store animal feed for agricultural purposes.
parentComment: As with other classes that are "features", the subclasses of this class are being moved to more informative locations. Their relation to agriculture will be modelled by something more akin to a quality or relation to an agricultural process.

classDefinition: A physical space, which may or may not be in a construction, which is used to store animal manure for agricultural purposes.
parentComment: As with other classes that are "features", the subclasses of this class are being moved to more informative locations. Their relation to agriculture will be modelled by something more akin to a quality or relation to an agricultural process.

classDefinition: Manure which has been collected directly or indirectly from dairy cattle, as from flushing of manure from concrete feed lanes, free stalls, and milking facilities.
parentDefinition: Manure which is derived from the waste products of animals.
parentComment: This is interesting in that the "role" aspect of "waste" is (or can be) replaced by another role "fertilizer". Thus, the positioning of "manure" under waste may not be totally correct.

classDefinition: Manure which is composed primarily of the feces of poultry.
parentDefinition: Manure which is derived from the waste products of animals.
parentComment: This is interesting in that the "role" aspect of "waste" is (or can be) replaced by another role "fertilizer". Thus, the positioning of "manure" under waste may not be totally correct.

classDefinition: Manure which has been subjected to heat treatment for solidification and/or sterilization purposes.
parentDefinition: Manure which is derived from the waste products of animals.
parentComment: This is interesting in that the "role" aspect of "waste" is (or can be) replaced by another role "fertilizer". Thus, the positioning of "manure" under waste may not be totally correct.

classDefinition: Manure which has been subjected to a natural process of 'rotting' or decomposition of its organic matter content by microorganisms under controlled conditions.
parentDefinition: Manure which is derived from the waste products of animals.
parentComment: This is interesting in that the "role" aspect of "waste" is (or can be) replaced by another role "fertilizer". Thus, the positioning of "manure" under waste may not be totally correct.

classDefinition: A planet which is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium.
parentDefinition: A planet is an astronomical body orbiting a star or stellar remnant that is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity, is not massive enough to cause thermonuclear fusion, and has cleared its neighbouring region of planetesimals.
classComment: Gas giants are composed of about 90% hydrogen and helium. Jupiter and Saturn are examples of gas giants.
parentComment: Considerable debate on the definition of planet exists.

classDefinition: A planet which is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium.
parentDefinition: An object which is composed primarily of an environmental material
classComment: Gas giants are composed of about 90% hydrogen and helium. Jupiter and Saturn are examples of gas giants.
parentComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.

classDefinition: An astrogeological volatile which is composed primarily of chemical compounds with boiling points around those of hydrogen and helium.
parentDefinition: A material which is composed primarily of chemical elements and compounds with relatively low boiling points, equilibrium condensation temperatures below 1300 Kelvin, and which are part of the crust or atmosphere of a moon or planet.
classComment: This is a term native to the fields of planetary science and astrophysics.  Hydrogen has a boiling point of 20.271 Kelvin and a melting point of 13.99 Kelvin. Helium has a boiling point of 4.222 Kelvin and a melting point of 0.95 Kelvin.
parentComment: Examples include nitrogen, water, carbon dioxide, ammonia, hydrogen, methane and sulfur dioxide. In astrogeology, these compounds, in their solid state, often comprise large proportions of the crusts of moons and dwarf planets.

classDefinition: A gas planet which 1) is considerably smaller than a gas giant and 2) has a rocky core around which a thick envelope primarily composed of hydrogen, helium, and smaller proportions of volatiles.
parentDefinition: A planet which is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium.
classComment: The physical make-up of gas dwarfs limit their size, which gravitate towards a total radius between 1.7 and 3.9 Earth-radii.
parentComment: Gas giants are composed of about 90% hydrogen and helium. Jupiter and Saturn are examples of gas giants.

classDefinition: A gas planet which has mass and size comparable to Jupiter and Saturn.
parentDefinition: A planet which is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium.
parentComment: Gas giants are composed of about 90% hydrogen and helium. Jupiter and Saturn are examples of gas giants.

classDefinition: An astrogeological volatile which is composed primarily of chemical compounds with freezing points above an approximate threshold of 100 Kelvin.
parentDefinition: A material which is composed primarily of chemical elements and compounds with relatively low boiling points, equilibrium condensation temperatures below 1300 Kelvin, and which are part of the crust or atmosphere of a moon or planet.
classComment: This is a term native to the fields of planetary science and astrophysics.  Water, ammonia, and methane are considered "ices" with freezing points of 273 K, 195 K, and 91 K, respectively.
parentComment: Examples include nitrogen, water, carbon dioxide, ammonia, hydrogen, methane and sulfur dioxide. In astrogeology, these compounds, in their solid state, often comprise large proportions of the crusts of moons and dwarf planets.

classDefinition: A material which is composed primarily of chemical elements and compounds with relatively low boiling points, equilibrium condensation temperatures below 1300 Kelvin, and which are part of the crust or atmosphere of a moon or planet.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: Examples include nitrogen, water, carbon dioxide, ammonia, hydrogen, methane and sulfur dioxide. In astrogeology, these compounds, in their solid state, often comprise large proportions of the crusts of moons and dwarf planets.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: A material which is composed primarily of chemical elements and compounds with relatively low boiling points, equilibrium condensation temperatures below 1300 Kelvin, and which are part of the crust or atmosphere of a moon or planet.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: Examples include nitrogen, water, carbon dioxide, ammonia, hydrogen, methane and sulfur dioxide. In astrogeology, these compounds, in their solid state, often comprise large proportions of the crusts of moons and dwarf planets.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: A giant planet which is primarily composed of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium, volatile chemical compounds with freezing points above about 100 Kelvin.
parentDefinition: A planet is an astronomical body orbiting a star or stellar remnant that is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity, is not massive enough to cause thermonuclear fusion, and has cleared its neighbouring region of planetesimals.
classComment: Uranus and Neptune are considered ice giants, a separate class relative to the gas giants, Jupiter and Saturn. Ice giants consist of only about 20% hydrogen and helium in mass.  A large portion of the mass in an ice giant was incorporated by the capture of ice (as defined in planetary science) or as gas trapped in water ice.
parentComment: Considerable debate on the definition of planet exists.

classDefinition: A giant planet which is primarily composed of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium, volatile chemical compounds with freezing points above about 100 Kelvin.
parentDefinition: An object which is composed primarily of an environmental material
classComment: Uranus and Neptune are considered ice giants, a separate class relative to the gas giants, Jupiter and Saturn. Ice giants consist of only about 20% hydrogen and helium in mass.  A large portion of the mass in an ice giant was incorporated by the capture of ice (as defined in planetary science) or as gas trapped in water ice.
parentComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.

classDefinition: A gas planet which has an atmosphere composed of hydrogen and helium  - probably with deep layers of ice, rock or liquid oceans (made of water, ammonia, a mixture of both, or heavier volatiles) - and a small core made of low-density volatiles.
parentDefinition: A planet which is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium.
classComment: These planets have a mass up to 10 Earth masses, notably smaller than Uranus or Neptune, which are about 14.5 and 17 Earth masses, respectively.
parentComment: Gas giants are composed of about 90% hydrogen and helium. Jupiter and Saturn are examples of gas giants.

classDefinition: An astronomical object which is more massive than the planet Jupiter.
parentDefinition: An object which is naturally occuring, bound together by gravitational or electromagnetic forces, and surrounded by space.
classComment: Due to their immense size, super-Jupiter class objects straddle the space between planets and other objects such as brown dwarfs. While they may be more massive than Jupiter, super-Jupiters tend to be the same approximate size, with increasing density as their mass increases up to about 80 Jupiter masses.
parentComment: Astronomical bodies are usually cohesive, thus the use of the term 'object' sensu BFO 'object'.

classDefinition: A process during which one or more entities move along geodesics in a region of spacetime that has been sufficiently curved towards an entity with sufficient mass and/or energy.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A giant gas planet which has a jovian-scale mass (0.36–11.8 Jupiter masses), a short orbital period (1.3–111 Earth days), and which is close to the star it orbits, resulting in extreme and exotic atmospheric properties.
parentDefinition: A gas planet which has mass and size comparable to Jupiter and Saturn.
classComment: It is assumed that the mass of a hot Jupiter cannot be greater than approximately 13.6 Jupiter masses, beyond which the planet would start burning deuterium and become a brown dwarf.

classDefinition: A gas planet which has a mass similar to that of Neptune or Uranus and which closely orbits its star (normally at a distance less than 1 Astronomical Unit).
parentDefinition: A planet which is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium.
parentComment: Gas giants are composed of about 90% hydrogen and helium. Jupiter and Saturn are examples of gas giants.

classDefinition: A terrestrial exoplanet which is at least ten times the mass of Earth.
parentDefinition: A planet that is composed primarily of silicate rocks or metals.

classDefinition: A terrestrial planet which has a mass higher than Earth's, but substantially below the masses of Uranus and Neptune (15 and 17 Earth masses, respectively).
parentDefinition: A planet that is composed primarily of silicate rocks or metals.
classComment: The upper bound of a super-Earth's mass is generally agreed on as 10 Earth masses. In general, super-Earths are defined exclusively by their masses, and the term does not imply temperatures, compositions, orbital properties, habitability, or environments.

classDefinition: A terrestrial planet which has a surface dominated by hot deserts.
parentDefinition: A planet that is composed primarily of silicate rocks or metals.
classComment: This class of planet is still mostly theoretical.

classDefinition: A planet which has a surface layer that nearly completely or completely covered by water, and which has a substantial portion of its mass composed of water.
parentDefinition: A planet is an astronomical body orbiting a star or stellar remnant that is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity, is not massive enough to cause thermonuclear fusion, and has cleared its neighbouring region of planetesimals.
classComment: While this planetary form is still mostly theoretical, strong candidates exist such as the extrasolar planet GJ 1214 b and ocean planet candidate Kepler-22b.
parentComment: Considerable debate on the definition of planet exists.

classDefinition: A planet which has a surface layer that nearly completely or completely covered by ice, and which has a substantial portion of its mass composed of ice.
parentDefinition: A planet is an astronomical body orbiting a star or stellar remnant that is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity, is not massive enough to cause thermonuclear fusion, and has cleared its neighbouring region of planetesimals.
classComment: While this planetary form is still mostly theoretical, strong candidates exist such as OGLE-2005-BLG-390Lb, OGLE-2013-BLG-0341L b and MOA-2007-BLG-192Lb. Pluto was considered an ice planet until its reclassification in 2006 CE.  Surface temperatures of ice planets would have to be below 260 K (−13°C) if composed primarily of water, below 180 K (−93°C) if primarily composed of CO2 and ammonia, and below 80 K (−193°C) if composed primarily of methane.
parentComment: Considerable debate on the definition of planet exists.

classDefinition: Ice which is primarily composed of carbon dioxide.
parentDefinition: An ice is an environmental material which is either frozen or which is maintained in a solid state by gravitational forces or pressure.
parentComment: Note that ice may be formed at very high temperatures, due to gravitational effects and/or pressure.

classDefinition: Ice which is primarily composed of methane.
parentDefinition: An ice is an environmental material which is either frozen or which is maintained in a solid state by gravitational forces or pressure.
parentComment: Note that ice may be formed at very high temperatures, due to gravitational effects and/or pressure.

classDefinition: Ice which is primarily composed of methane.
Ice which is primarily composed of ammonia.
parentDefinition: An ice is an environmental material which is either frozen or which is maintained in a solid state by gravitational forces or pressure.
parentComment: Note that ice may be formed at very high temperatures, due to gravitational effects and/or pressure.

classDefinition: Ice which is primarily composed of carbon monoxide.
parentDefinition: An ice is an environmental material which is either frozen or which is maintained in a solid state by gravitational forces or pressure.
parentComment: Note that ice may be formed at very high temperatures, due to gravitational effects and/or pressure.

classDefinition: A planet which in primarily composed of an iron-rich core with little to no mantle
parentDefinition: A planet that is composed primarily of silicate rocks or metals.
classComment: Mercury is the largest iron planet in the Solar System, the other terrestrial planets being composed of silicate rocks. Some extrasolar planet candidates that may be composed mainly of iron are KOI-1843 b,[5] Kepler-70b and Kepler-10b.

classDefinition: A planet which has a surface layer that nearly completely or completely covered by lava, and which has a substantial portion of its mass composed of lava.
parentDefinition: A planet is an astronomical body orbiting a star or stellar remnant that is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity, is not massive enough to cause thermonuclear fusion, and has cleared its neighbouring region of planetesimals.
classComment: This class of planets is still mostly theoretical, however, lava planets are thought plausible shortly after a terrestrial planet is formed, soon after a terrestrial planet has suffered a large collision event, or if a terrestrial planet is orbiting very close to its star, causing intense irradiation and tidal forces.  Likely lava exoplanets include COROT-7b, Kepler-10b, Alpha Centauri Bb, and Kepler-78b.
parentComment: Considerable debate on the definition of planet exists.

classDefinition: A terrestrial planet which has a mass smaller than Earth's, such that 1) it lacks a magnetic field strong enough to shield its atmosphere from erosion by stellar wind and 2) it has comparatively short periods of geological activity unless it is subject to gravitational tidal forces from a much more massive object.
parentDefinition: A planet that is composed primarily of silicate rocks or metals.
classComment: The first sub-Earths were discovered by the Kepler Orbiting Observatory space telescope on 2012-01-10, orbiting the star Kepler-42. As of June 2014, Kepler has 45 confirmed planets that are smaller than Earth, with 17 of them being smaller than 0.8 Earth radii. In addition, there are over 310 planet candidates with an estimated radius of less than 1 Earth radius, with 135 of them being smaller than 0.8 Earth radii.

classDefinition: A planet which is formed as a result of a gas giant's hydrogen and helium atmosphere, as well as its outer layers, being stripped away by a stellar wind through photoevaporation and hydrodynamic escape.
parentDefinition: A planet is an astronomical body orbiting a star or stellar remnant that is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity, is not massive enough to cause thermonuclear fusion, and has cleared its neighbouring region of planetesimals.
classComment: This class is largely theoretical, however, some likely candidates exist. HD 209458 b and Gliese 436b are examples of a gas giants that are in the process of having their atmospheres stripped away. COROT-7b is the first exoplanet found that might be chthonian.
parentComment: Considerable debate on the definition of planet exists.

classDefinition: A process during which energetic radiation ionises gas and causes it to disperse away from the ionising source.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
classComment: This process is responsible for the stripping away of gases from the atmosphere of planets and related bodies by acceleration on interaction with high energy photons and other electromagnetic radiation.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: An atmospheric escape process during which atoms that are parts of a planetary atmosphere escape into outer space through numerous collisions with lighter atoms in that atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A process during which gases that constitute a planetary atmosphere escape that planet's gravitational field and move away into outer space.

classDefinition: A gas planet which has an atmosphere composed primarily of helium.
parentDefinition: A planet which is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium.
classComment: A helium planet might form via hydrogen evaporation from a gaseous planet orbiting close to a star. Low-mass white dwarfs may transition into objects which are essentially helium planets by hydrogen depletion through mass transfer to a massive object such as a neutron star.  Gliese 436 b is a candidate helium planet.
parentComment: Gas giants are composed of about 90% hydrogen and helium. Jupiter and Saturn are examples of gas giants.

classDefinition: An astronomical body which 1) is held together by its own gravity, 2)  can attract other, similar bodies through mutual gravitational influence, and 3) has orbital dynamics that are not significantly affected by gas drag.
parentDefinition: An object which is naturally occuring, bound together by gravitational or electromagnetic forces, and surrounded by space.
classComment: In the Solar nebula, planetesimals are usually larger than approximately 1 kilometer.
parentComment: Astronomical bodies are usually cohesive, thus the use of the term 'object' sensu BFO 'object'.

classDefinition: An astronomical object that forms within a protoplanetary disc when planetesimals and other solid debris aggregate and, due to gravitational forces,  fuse and initiate internal melting to produce a differentiated interior.
parentDefinition: An object which is naturally occuring, bound together by gravitational or electromagnetic forces, and surrounded by space.
classComment: Protoplanets are thought to form out of kilometer-sized planetesimals that gravitationally perturb each other's orbits and collide, gradually coalescing into the dominant planets. The exact sequence of events which lead to planetary formation from protoplanets is not fully understood.
parentComment: Astronomical bodies are usually cohesive, thus the use of the term 'object' sensu BFO 'object'.

classDefinition: An astronomical object which is composed of dense gas and dust rotating around a young newly formed star, a T Tauri star, or a Herbig Ae/Be star in a disk-shaped configuration.
parentDefinition: An object which is composed of one or more gravitationally bound structures that are associated with a position in space.
parentComment: If there is only one astronomical body involved, this class is equivalent to ENVO:01000799. This may be problematic with reasoning, but it seems to be true to the rather fuzzy definitions found thus far.

classDefinition: A physical quality which inheres in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's exhibiting density.
parentDefinition: A physical quality which inheres in a bearer by virtue of some influence is exerted by the bearer's mass per unit size.

classDefinition: A protoplanetary disk which is externally illuminated and undergoing photoevaporation.
parentDefinition: An astronomical object which is composed of dense gas and dust rotating around a young newly formed star, a T Tauri star, or a Herbig Ae/Be star in a disk-shaped configuration.

classDefinition: A planet which is smaller than Mercury but larger than Ceres.
parentDefinition: A planet is an astronomical body orbiting a star or stellar remnant that is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity, is not massive enough to cause thermonuclear fusion, and has cleared its neighbouring region of planetesimals.
parentComment: Considerable debate on the definition of planet exists.

classDefinition: A planet which orbits two stars.
parentDefinition: A planet is an astronomical body orbiting a star or stellar remnant that is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity, is not massive enough to cause thermonuclear fusion, and has cleared its neighbouring region of planetesimals.
classComment: Because of the short orbits of some binary stars, the only way for planets to form is by forming outside the orbit of the two stars.
parentComment: Considerable debate on the definition of planet exists.

classDefinition: A material which is composed primarily of chemical elements and compounds which have equilibrium condensation temperatures above approximately 1300 Kelvin and which are part of the crust or atmosphere of a moon or planet.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: The refractory group includes elements and compounds like metals and silicates (commonly termed rocks) which make up the bulk of the mass of the terrestrial planets and asteroids in the inner belt.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: A material which is composed primarily of chemical elements and compounds which have equilibrium condensation temperatures above approximately 1300 Kelvin and which are part of the crust or atmosphere of a moon or planet.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: The refractory group includes elements and compounds like metals and silicates (commonly termed rocks) which make up the bulk of the mass of the terrestrial planets and asteroids in the inner belt.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: A cloud which is cirriform and is formed by condensation events centred on an aircraft's contrail.
parentDefinition: A cloud which 1) has been shaped into detached fibrous filaments, 2) is almost exclusively composed of ice crystals, 3) is located in the high level of the atmosphere (high étage).
parentComment: When present in aggregates, individual cirrus clouds are organised in patches or narrow bands. When organised in sheets of fibres they can give a silky sheen. When well-illuminated by sunlight (excluding during sunrise and sunset) cirrus clouds appear white or mostly white. Absence of any precipitation.

classDefinition: A cloud which is cirriform and is formed by condensation events centred on an aircraft's contrail.
parentDefinition: A cloud which is formed by condensation events triggered by some anthropogenic processes or the outputs thereof, such as aircraft contrails or emissions from chimneys.

classDefinition: A cloud which 1) has been shaped into detached fibrous filaments, 2) is almost exclusively composed of ice crystals, 3) is located in the high level of the atmosphere (high étage).
parentDefinition: A mass of water ice.
classComment: When present in aggregates, individual cirrus clouds are organised in patches or narrow bands. When organised in sheets of fibres they can give a silky sheen. When well-illuminated by sunlight (excluding during sunrise and sunset) cirrus clouds appear white or mostly white. Absence of any precipitation.

classDefinition: A cloud which 1) has been shaped into detached fibrous filaments, 2) is almost exclusively composed of ice crystals, 3) is located in the high level of the atmosphere (high étage).
parentDefinition: A cloud which is primarily composed of water-based aerosols.
classComment: When present in aggregates, individual cirrus clouds are organised in patches or narrow bands. When organised in sheets of fibres they can give a silky sheen. When well-illuminated by sunlight (excluding during sunrise and sunset) cirrus clouds appear white or mostly white. Absence of any precipitation.
parentComment: On Earth clouds are formed by the saturation of air in the homosphere when air cools or gains water vapor. Note that this class describes clouds as countable objects, rather than 'cloud material'. It also refers only to clouds made up of a water-based material.

classDefinition: A cloud which is formed by condensation events triggered by some anthropogenic processes or the outputs thereof, such as aircraft contrails or emissions from chimneys.
parentDefinition: A cloud which is primarily composed of water-based aerosols.
parentComment: On Earth clouds are formed by the saturation of air in the homosphere when air cools or gains water vapor. Note that this class describes clouds as countable objects, rather than 'cloud material'. It also refers only to clouds made up of a water-based material.

parentDefinition: A layer that is part of the atmosphere.
classComment: A part of the troposphere which extends from 3 km to 8 km (10 000 – 25 000 ft) height in the polar region, from 5 km to 13 km (16 500 – 45 000 ft) height in the temperate region, and from 6 km to 18 km (20 000 – 60 000 ft) height in the tropical region.
parentComment: This could be made into an inferred class, rather than having asserted subclasses.

classDefinition: A shape quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's having thin filamentous extensions at its edge.
parentDefinition: A morphological quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's ratios of distances between its features (points, edges, surfaces and also holes etc).

parentLabel: area protected according to IUCN guidelines
classDefinition: An IUCN protected area in which human visitation, use and impacts are strictly controlled and limited to ensure protection and conservation of natural biodiversity and/or geodiversity, natural ecosystem assemblages and processes, and any associated cultural and spiritual values.
parentDefinition: A protected area in which management objectives have been declared, by a local governing body or authority, to adhere to the guidelines set forth by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
classComment: Note that this ENVO class is not authoritative: see the associated IUCN references for a complete definition of all Protected Areas. Previous anthropogenic impacts (e.g. by early human settlement) may be present in these sites; these should be reversible by either natural processes or brief restorative interventions. Note that this ENVO class is not authoritative: see the associated IUCN references for a complete definition of all Protected Areas.
parentComment: The international recognition of an area as an IUCN protected area generally depends on the assigning government or authority reporting its assignments to the United Nations Environment Programme World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

parentLabel: area protected according to IUCN guidelines
classDefinition: An IUCN protected area which 1) is dominated by natural ecosystems, 2) is sufficiently large to allow those ecosystems to function and develop without local anthropogenic perturbation, 3) is  managed to prevent perturbations by proximate or local anthropisation, including those caused by local and/or indigenous human communities or human visitation.
parentDefinition: A protected area in which management objectives have been declared, by a local governing body or authority, to adhere to the guidelines set forth by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
classComment: Note that this ENVO class is not authoritative: see the associated IUCN references for a complete definition of all Protected Areas. These areas exclude permanent built infrastructure, activities by extractive industries, commercial or intensive agriculture, extensive access by motor vehicles, unregulated visitation supported by any infrastructure, as well as other activities that may lead to significant ecosystem perturbations.
parentComment: The international recognition of an area as an IUCN protected area generally depends on the assigning government or authority reporting its assignments to the United Nations Environment Programme World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

classDefinition: A quality which inheres in a continuant.
A quality which inheres in a continuant.
parentDefinition: A dependent entity that inheres in a bearer by virtue of how the bearer is related to other entities

parentLabel: area protected according to IUCN guidelines
classDefinition: An IUCN protected area which includes a primarily natural formation designated to be of high natural heritage value and the environmental systems which it determines (e.g. the spray zone of a waterfall monument).
parentDefinition: A protected area in which management objectives have been declared, by a local governing body or authority, to adhere to the guidelines set forth by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
classComment: Note that this ENVO class is not authoritative: see the associated IUCN references for a complete definition of all Protected Areas. Further, note that the use of "natural" in the IUCN definition may allow for some anthropisation such as the presence of cave dwellings or spiritual sites. These areas tend to be smaller than other IUCN protected areas and are sites of frequent human visitation and high tourism value. They often serve to conserve natural heritage in land- or seascapes which have otherwise been anthropised. Frequently, these areas have high spiritual and cultural value as well as bio- and geodiversity value. It is not clear what would happen to the status of a IUCN Category III protected area if its key natural monument dies or degrades. IUCN acknowledges that larger ecosystem areas may need protection or management to sustain the area given Category III protection.
parentComment: The international recognition of an area as an IUCN protected area generally depends on the assigning government or authority reporting its assignments to the United Nations Environment Programme World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

parentLabel: area protected according to IUCN guidelines
classDefinition: An IUCN protected area within which the habitats of or ecosystems used by floral and faunal species deemed to be of international, national, or local importance are maintained, conserved, or restored such that their composition and functional integrity are maintained.
parentDefinition: A protected area in which management objectives have been declared, by a local governing body or authority, to adhere to the guidelines set forth by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
classComment: Note that this ENVO class is not authoritative: see the associated IUCN references for a complete definition of all Protected Areas. Note that many Category IV sites require frequent interventions to maintain habitats for the species conserved, particularly as many of these areas are ecosystem fragments which are unable to sustain themselves. Additionally, many are used for public outreach, education, and recreation, implying regular human visitation. What qualifies a species as important is variable and often ill-defined.
parentComment: The international recognition of an area as an IUCN protected area generally depends on the assigning government or authority reporting its assignments to the United Nations Environment Programme World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

classDefinition: An ecosystem which has been causally isolated from a larger ecosystem within which it was previously embedded, such that the direct exchange of materials, resources, and energy between these systems is severely or entirely curtailed.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
classComment: Often, ecosystem fragments are unable to sustain themselves without human intervention and management as they are not large enough to perform self-sustaining functions (e.g. nutrient recycling) or hold sufficient ecological resources such as genetic diversity of populations.
parentComment: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.

classDefinition: A process during which one or more parts of an ecosystem become causally isolated such that the direct flow or exchange of materials, resources, and energy between a given fragment and the remainder of the original system is severely curtailed or entirely halted.
parentDefinition: A biological process represents a specific objective that the organism is genetically programmed to achieve. Biological processes are often described by their outcome or ending state, e.g., the biological process of cell division results in the creation of two daughter cells (a divided cell) from a single parent cell. A biological process is accomplished by a particular set of molecular functions carried out by specific gene products (or macromolecular complexes), often in a highly regulated manner and in a particular temporal sequence.

classDefinition: A process during which one or more parts of an ecosystem become causally isolated such that the direct flow or exchange of materials, resources, and energy between a given fragment and the remainder of the original system is severely curtailed or entirely halted.
parentDefinition: An environmental process either driven by or primarily impacting the parts or emergent properties of an ecosystem.

classDefinition: A process during which an ecosystem fragment loses its system integrity, with many of its resident ecological populations 1) losing their habitats, 2) undergoing a loss of functional and phylogenetic diversity, and 3) undergoing a subsequent genetic destabilisation through inbreeding.
parentDefinition: An environmental process either driven by or primarily impacting the parts or emergent properties of an ecosystem.
classComment: This process may be caused by direct anthropisation (i.e. the fragmentation of ecosystems due to the establishment of cropland) or by more natural events such as forest fires or erosion of land bridges.

classDefinition: A process during which an ecosystem, its parts, or the processes it participates in are modified by human intervention to accomplish an objective.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which is driven by the action of humans.

classDefinition: A process during which an ecosystem, its parts, or the processes it participates in are modified by human intervention to accomplish an objective.
parentDefinition: A process during which humans apply technology to alter the magnitude, duration, rate, or impact of an environmental process.
parentComment: Relabel the obo foundry unique label to be generic process

classDefinition: A process during which humans apply technology to alter the magnitude, duration, rate, or impact of an environmental process.
parentDefinition: A process that realizes a plan which is the concretization of a plan specification.
classComment: Relabel the obo foundry unique label to be generic process

parentLabel: area protected according to IUCN guidelines
classDefinition: An IUCN protected area which 1) includes entities that have been deemed to be of high scenic quality, 2) is composed of a historically stable assemblage of causally interlinked natural and anthropised ecosystems that provides cultural ecosystem services, and 3) hosts traditional and sustainable human activities.
parentDefinition: A protected area in which management objectives have been declared, by a local governing body or authority, to adhere to the guidelines set forth by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
classComment: Note that this ENVO class is not authoritative: see the associated IUCN references for a complete definition of all Protected Areas. The IUCN note that the integrity of balanced natural and anthropogenic ecosystems may be compromised in some Category V areas, as long as "there is reasonable hope of restoring that integrity".
parentComment: The international recognition of an area as an IUCN protected area generally depends on the assigning government or authority reporting its assignments to the United Nations Environment Programme World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

classDefinition: A fiat object part which contains entities of high spiritual or cultural significance to one or more human groups.
A fiat object part which contains entities of high spiritual or cultural significance to one or more human groups.
An ecosystem fragmentation process during which discontinuities emerge in the habitats of one or more ecological populations.
parentDefinition: A process during which one or more parts of an ecosystem become causally isolated such that the direct flow or exchange of materials, resources, and energy between a given fragment and the remainder of the original system is severely curtailed or entirely halted.

classLabel: environment associated with an aquatic invertebrate
classDefinition: An environment which has its properties and composition largely determined by the presence of a metazoan which lacks a vetebral column and which has a habitat that is found in an aquatic environmental system.
parentDefinition: An environmental system determined by an animal.

classLabel: environment associated with an aquatic invertebrate
parentLabel: environment associated with an animal part or small animal
classDefinition: An environment which has its properties and composition largely determined by the presence of a metazoan which lacks a vetebral column and which has a habitat that is found in an aquatic environmental system.
parentDefinition: An environmental system determined by part of a living or dead animal, or a whole small animal.

classDefinition: Land which is regularly manipulated by human activities, such as plowing or tilling, in order to grow crops.
parentDefinition: A surface layer of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material and is not covered by oceans or other bodies of water.

classDefinition: A quality inhereing in a bearer by virtue of the bearer being periodically and mechanically manipulated to loosen and mix any soil which it has as a part.
parentDefinition: An environmental condition is a range of a determinate quality or combination of qualities that are present in an environmental system.
parentComment: A condition defines a restricted range of a given quality or combination of qualities. If an environment class, E, has_condition C, then all qualities listed in C are restricted to the ranges defined in C in E. This is not intended as a logical conditional.

classDefinition: Land which hosts a community of herbaceous plants - such as grasses and forbs - upon which animals may graze.
parentDefinition: A surface layer of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material and is not covered by oceans or other bodies of water.

classDefinition: An environmental system determined by a cnidarian or part of a cnidarian.
parentDefinition: An environmental system determined by an animal.

classDefinition: An environment which has its properties and composition determined by a portion of Bondon cheese.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: A surface layer which is composed of the external surface of a root, together with closely adhering soil particles and debris
parentDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of solid environmental material.

classDefinition: Pasturable land which is maintained by human activities in order to provide grazing oppoturnities for livestock.
parentDefinition: Land which hosts a community of herbaceous plants - such as grasses and forbs - upon which animals may graze.

classDefinition: Land which either hosts plant communities upon which animals may graze has been manipulated by tilling, ploughing, or other human activity for the purposes of seed sowing or planting crops.
parentDefinition: A surface layer of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material and is not covered by oceans or other bodies of water.
classComment: This class does not refer to the land that is potenitally cultivable, only referencing land that is being managed for cultivation. This class has been created to support the FAO definition of arable lands in FAOSTAT.

classDefinition: Soil which has increased levels of molecules or ions capable of donating a hydron (proton or hydrogen ion) to other chemical entities, or, alternatively, capable of forming covalent bonds with other chemicals via the acceptance of an electron pair, resulting in a bulk pH measurement of less than 7.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
parentComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

" The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm."  Soil taxonomy, 2nd Ed., quoted in http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/edu/?cid=nrcs142p2_054280

classDefinition: Volcanic ash which has increased levels of molecules or ions capable of donating a hydron (proton or hydrogen ion) to other chemical entities, or, alternatively, capable of forming covalent bonds with other chemicals via the acceptance of an electron pair, resulting in a bulk pH measurement of less than 7.
parentDefinition: Volcanic ash is an environmental material which consists of fragments of pulverized rock, minerals, and volcanic glass, created during volcanic eruptions and measuring less than 2 millimetres in diameter. Volcanic ash is formed during explosive volcanic eruptions, phreatomagmatic eruptions and during transport in pyroclastic density currents.

classDefinition: A digestive tract environment which has its properties and dynamics determined by the digestive tract of an echinoderm from the class Holothuroidea.
parentDefinition: A tube extending from the mouth to the anus.

classDefinition: A bodily fluid which is present in the digestive tract of a member of the Holothuroidea.
parentDefinition: Liquid components of living organisms. includes fluids that are excreted or secreted from the body as well as body water that normally is not.

classDefinition: Liquid components of living organisms. includes fluids that are excreted or secreted from the body as well as body water that normally is not.
parentDefinition: Material anatomical entity in a gaseous, liquid, semisolid or solid state; produced by anatomical structures or derived from inhaled and ingested substances that have been modified by anatomical structures as they pass through the body.
Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.
classComment: An organic material which is primarily composed of living or dead algae, along with their exudates.

classDefinition: Sea ice which has a brown colouration, either due to 1) the presence of pigments which are or were contained in the members of ecological assemblages, such as algal communities, living or trapped within the ice or 2) due to the presence of trapped sediments.
parentDefinition: Water ice which has formed by the freezing of sea water.
parentComment: In the United States, NOAA sea ice operations does not include superstructure icing as being sea ice. In sea ice operations however, sea ice is any form of ice found at sea which has originated from the freezing of sea water. It presents the main kind of floating ice encountered at sea. Except where it forms ridges, sea ice is up to a few metres thick, in which respect it differs from shelf ice.  Sea ice may be discontinuous pieces (ice floes) moved on the ocean surface by wind and currents (pack ice), or a motionless sheet attached to the coast (land-fast ice). In brief, it forms first as lolly ice (frazil crystals), thickens into sludge, and coagulates into sheet ice, pancake ice, or into floes of various shapes and sizes. Thereafter, sea ice may develop into pack ice and/or become a form of pressure ice.  Sea ice less than one year old is called first-year ice. Perennial ice is sea ice that survives at least one summer. It may be subdivided into second-year ice and multi-year ice, where multiyear ice has survived at least two summers.

classDefinition: A color consisting of dark orange, red, of very low intensity.
parentDefinition: A composite chromatic quality composed of hue, saturation and intensity parts.

classDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of some liquid.
parentDefinition: A layer which is primarily composed of some liquid material.

classDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of some liquid.
parentDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of some liquid or gas.

classDefinition: The surface layer of a mass of sediment.
parentDefinition: A layer of some material entity which is adjacent to one or more of its external boundaries and directly interacts with its immediate surroundings.
parentComment: This class is distinct from a geometric surface, which is two-dimensional. The idea of "uppermost" may be problematic. Further, the definition of layer (the superclass of surface in rev 133) references surface. This may be another issue. Perhaps this can be made into an inferred class using 'bounding layer of' some material entity, note that 'bounding layer' implies containment, which may not be valid here.

parentDefinition: A layer in a water mass, itself composed primarily of water.
classComment: This includes the surface layers of all volumes of water exposed to space or the planet's atmosphere.
parentComment: This class will eventually be populated by inference, and its asserted subclasses removed.

parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of liquid material.
classComment: This includes the surface layers of all volumes of water exposed to space or the planet's atmosphere.
This includes the surface layers of all volumes of water exposed to space or the planet's atmosphere.

parentDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of some liquid.
classComment: This includes the surface layers of all volumes of water exposed to space or the planet's atmosphere.

classDefinition: A site in which charged particles are influenced by an astronomical body's magnetic field.
classComment: Magentospheres are generated by the motion of active hot iron and nickle or metallic planetary cores or by the interactions of plasma in stars.. The magnetic field near the surface of many astronomical bodies resembles that of a dipole. The field lines farther away from the surface can be significantly distorted by the flow of electrically conducting plasma emitted from a nearby star. The structure and behaviour of magnetospheres depend on numerous variables, including the type of astronomical body which generates it, the period of the object's spin, the properties of the axis about which the object spins, the axis of the magnetic dipole, and the magnitude and direction of the flow of stellar wind.

classDefinition: A radiation shielding disposition which inheres in a material or immaterial entity which attenuates or blocks cosmic rays.
parentDefinition: An environmental disposition which inheres in an entity that intercepts, attenuates, or blocks radiation.

classDefinition: An environmental disposition which inheres in an entity that intercepts, attenuates, or blocks radiation.
parentDefinition: A disposition which is realised by an environmental system or system parts thereof.
parentComment: This class and its subclasses are experimental and are being developed with NCEAS use cases in mind.

classDefinition: A magnetosphere which either 1) cannot withstand the pressure of the stellar wind interacting with it, thus allowing the stellar wind to interact with the ionosphere, atmosphere, or surface of the planet generating it or 2) is formed by the interaction of the stellar wind with an astronomical body unshielded by its own magnetosphere.
parentDefinition: A site in which charged particles are influenced by an astronomical body's magnetic field.

classDefinition: Soil or sediment which has been eroded and influenced by flowing water and redeposited in a non-marine setting.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: Soil or sediment which has been eroded and influenced by flowing water and redeposited in a non-marine setting.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: Sediment which has been transported by flowing water and redeposited in a non-marine setting.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is formed as a result of the transport and deposition of particles by flowing liquid.
parentComment: Sediment is typically deposited on the bed or bottom of a body of water or other liquid.

classDefinition: A rock which is formed as a result of the lithification of alluvium.
parentDefinition: A rock is a naturally occurring solid aggregate of one or more minerals or mineraloids.
parentComment: From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ [A mineral] is different from a rock, which can be an aggregate of minerals or non-minerals and does not have a specific chemical composition. The exact definition of a mineral is under debate, especially with respect to the requirement a valid species be abiogenic, and to a lesser extent with regards to it having an ordered atomic structure.

classDefinition: A process during which sediments compact under pressure, expel connate fluids, and gradually become solid sedimentary rock.
parentDefinition: A biological process represents a specific objective that the organism is genetically programmed to achieve. Biological processes are often described by their outcome or ending state, e.g., the biological process of cell division results in the creation of two daughter cells (a divided cell) from a single parent cell. A biological process is accomplished by a particular set of molecular functions carried out by specific gene products (or macromolecular complexes), often in a highly regulated manner and in a particular temporal sequence.

classDefinition: A process during which sediments compact under pressure, expel connate fluids, and gradually become solid sedimentary rock.
parentDefinition: A process during which a portion of some environmental material is converted into a different material or a collection of materials.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material transformation process only refers to ENVO:environmental material classes (e.g. bulk and typically impure substances), rather than transformations converting a specific chemical into another.

classDefinition: An area of wetland which overlaps a swamp ecosystem.
parentDefinition: An vegetated area which overlaps a wetland ecosystem.

classDefinition: A planned process during which an environmental system is modified to mitigate or nullify the impacts of flooding.
parentDefinition: A process during which humans apply technology to alter the magnitude, duration, rate, or impact of an environmental process.
parentComment: Relabel the obo foundry unique label to be generic process

classDefinition: A stellar radiation process during which electromagnetic waves or their quanta are emitted from a star at wavelengths and frequencies which travel exclusively in a line-of-sight fashion and which may produce molecular rotation and torsion on contact with matter.
parentDefinition: An electromagnetic radiation process during which electromagnetic waves or their quanta are emitted from a star.
classComment: This definition focuses on the properties of microwaves rather than their wavelength or frequency limits. Considerable ambiguity exists around the wavelength and frequency thresholds of microwaves. The ISO 21348 definition bounds these waves at 1 mm and 15 mm, with frequencies between 100 GHz and 0.225 GHz.

parentComment: Note that this class is concerned only with active radiative processes: static electric and magnetic fields are not inlcuded. All electromagnetic radiation carries radiant energy.

classComment: As with microwaves, considerable variation exists in the delimitation of frequency and wavelength thresholds for radiowaves. The ISO 21348 standard allows a wavelength range of 0.10 mm to 100 m and a frequency range of 300 GHz to 3 MHz. However, much lower thresholds also exist.

classDefinition: A stellar radiation process during which penetrating electromagnetic radiation is emitted by high-energy electrons as they fall into a lower state of energy.
parentDefinition: A radiation process during which penetrating electromagnetic radiation is emitted by high-energy electrons as they fall into a lower state of energy.
classComment: Ambiguity exists in the definition of x-rays and their differentiation from gamma rays. Photons with sufficient energy to be classified as x-rays may be emitted by other processes than electrons falling to lower energy states. Most x-rays have wavelengths ranging from 0.01 to 10 nanometers, corresponding to frequencies in the range of 30 petahertz to 30 exahertz and energies in the range of 100 eV to 100 keV.

classDefinition: A stellar radiation process during which penetrating electromagnetic radiation is emitted by high-energy electrons as they fall into a lower state of energy.

classDefinition: A stellar radiation process during which penetrating electromagnetic radiation is emitted from the radioactive decay (gamma decay) of atomic nuclei.
parentDefinition: A stellar radiation process during which electromagnetic waves or their quanta are emitted from a star with sufficient energy to disrupt molecular bonds or alter the electron number of atoms.
classComment: Ambiguity exists in the definition of gamma rays. As a rule of thumb, gamma rays have energies above 100 keV, frequencies above 10 exahertz, and wavelengths less than 10 picometers. However, regardless of the energy released, electromagnetic radiation from radioactive decay of atomic nuclei is referred to as "gamma rays". In astronomy, however, gamma rays are defined by their energy, and no production process needs to be specified.

classDefinition: A stellar radiation process during which penetrating electromagnetic radiation is emitted from the radioactive decay (gamma decay) of atomic nuclei.
