classDefinition: A material accumulation process during which the volume of liquid entity increases.
parentDefinition: A process during which the mass of one or more materials, present within a given site, increases.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material accumulation process ends a material transport process.

classDefinition: A commercial building which contains parts used as workplaces primarily for administrative and managerial workers.
parentDefinition: A building which is primarily used to facilitate the buying or selling of goods or services.
classComment: "An office building will be divided into sections for different companies or may be dedicated to one company. In either case, each company will typically have a reception area, one or several meeting rooms, singular or open-plan offices, as well as toilets."
parentComment: "Commerce includes legal, economic, political, social, cultural and technological systems that are in operation in any country or internationally."

classDefinition: A building part within which administrative work is done by an organisations users in order to support and realise the objectives of that organization.
parentDefinition: A building part is a construction which is part of a building.
parentComment: Not recommended for annotation. This class is likely to be made into an inferred class as its subclasses are distributed among more meaningful superclasses (i.e. ceiling is_a surface layer). See for example, "building floor". The boundaries between building parts may be bona fide or fiat.

classLabel: IUCN protected area with sustainable use of natural resources
parentLabel: area protected according to IUCN guidelines
classDefinition: An IUCN protected area within which 1) natural ecosystems and their resources are either conserved or used through non-industrial human activities, 2) usage activites contribute to conservation goals, ensuring inter-generational security for local communities' livelihoods, and 3) the majority of benefits derived from the use of ecosystems are received by communities living near or in the area.
parentDefinition: A protected area in which management objectives have been declared, by a local governing body or authority, to adhere to the guidelines set forth by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
classComment: Note that this ENVO class is not authoritative: see the associated IUCN references for a complete definition of all Protected Areas.  Note, that the IUCN recommends that a proportion of the area is retained in a natural condition (e.g. a no-take management zone). As this is a recommendation rather than a rule, this ENVO class does not include IUCN categories with strict conservation regimes as necessary parts. An emphasis is placed on the integration of  cultural approaches, belief systems and world-views possessed by human populations in and around the protected area into the conservation approaches used. Further, these areas host activities which facilitate scientific research, environmental monitoring, recreation, and "appropriate" small-scale tourism.
parentComment: The international recognition of an area as an IUCN protected area generally depends on the assigning government or authority reporting its assignments to the United Nations Environment Programme World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

classDefinition: A natural environment which is located on a land mass.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: A natural environment which is located on a land mass.
parentDefinition: An environmental system in which minimal to no anthropisation has occurred and non-human agents are the primary determinants of the system's dynamics and composition.
parentComment: In most contexts, 'natural' is defined by the lack of intervention or influence by humans and their activities. On Earth, most environments fall on a scale between completely natural and anthropised.

classDefinition: A natural environment which is within a water body.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.

classDefinition: A site in which the attraction of satellites by gravitation is dominated by an astronomical body, bounded by a zero-velocity surface.

A site in which the combined gravitational pull of the two large astronomical bodies is such that a smaller body, affected only by gravity, can maintain a stable position relative to those two large bodies and orbit with them due to centripetal force.
A marginal sea biome which is located in a region with a tropical climate.
parentDefinition: The marginal sea biome comprises parts of an ocean partially enclosed by land such as islands, archipelagos, or peninsulas. Unlike mediterranean seas, marginal seas have ocean currents caused by ocean winds. Many marginal seas are enclosed by island arcs that were formed from the subduction of one oceanic plate beneath another.

classDefinition: A marginal sea biome which is located in a region with a tropical climate.
parentDefinition: A biome which is subject to tropical climatic conditions.

classDefinition: Organic material which is in a solid phase and contained in sedimentary rock.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: Organic material which is in a solid phase and contained in sedimentary rock.
parentDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.

classDefinition: Kerogen which cotains alginite, amorphous organic matter, cyanobacteria, freshwater algae, and land plant resins, thus having a hydrogen to carbon ratio above 1.25, and oxygen to carbon ratio below 0.15, readily produces liquid hydrocarbons, has reduced concentrations of aromatic structures, and primarily derived from proteins and lipids.
parentDefinition: Organic material which is in a solid phase and contained in sedimentary rock.

classDefinition: Kerogen from which heavy hydrocarbons (such as oils) are derived following chemical break down.
parentDefinition: Organic material which is in a solid phase and contained in sedimentary rock.

classDefinition: Kerogen from which light hydrocarbons (such as hydrocarbon gases) are derived following chemical break down.
parentDefinition: Organic material which is in a solid phase and contained in sedimentary rock.

classDefinition: Kerogen which is enriched in sulfur compounds, has a hydrogen to carbon ratio under 1.25, an oxygen to carbon ratio between 0.03 and 0.18, derives into mixtures of hydrocarbon gas and oil, and derives from marine organic materials (primarily lipids) which are formed in reducing environments.
parentDefinition: Organic material which is in a solid phase and contained in sedimentary rock.

classDefinition: Planktonic kerogen which has high concentrations of sulfur compounds.

classDefinition: Kerogen which derives from land plants, resembles wood or coral in structure, has a hydrogen to carbon ratio under 1, an oxygen to carbon ratio between 0.03 to 0.3, and which primarily produces coal or hydrocarbon gas on degradation.

classDefinition: Kerogen which has a hydrogen to carbon ratio less than  0.5 and primarily composed of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.

classDefinition: An aquaculture process during which humans rear animals.
parentDefinition: A process during which humans rear animals or plants in bodies of water for harvest and consumption.
parentComment: In 1988, the FAO introduced a definition of aquaculture which reduces its confusion with capture fisheries: Aquaculture is the farming of aquatic organisms, including fish, molluscs, crustaceans and aquatic plants. Farming implies some form of intervention in the rearing process to enhance production, such as regular stocking, feeding, protection from predators, etc. Farming also implies individual or corporate ownership of the stock being cultivated. For statistical purposes, aquatic organisms which are harvested by an individual or corporate body which has owned them throughout their rearing period contribute to aquaculture, while aquatic organisms which are exploitable by the public as a common property resources, with or without appropriate licences, are the harvest of fisheries.

classDefinition: An aquaculture process during which humans rear finfish.
parentDefinition: An aquaculture process during which humans rear animals.

classDefinition: An aquaculture process during which humans rear molluscs.
parentDefinition: An aquaculture process during which humans rear animals.

parentDefinition: An aquaculture process during which humans rear plants.

parentDefinition: A process during which humans rear animals or plants in bodies of water for harvest and consumption.
parentComment: In 1988, the FAO introduced a definition of aquaculture which reduces its confusion with capture fisheries: Aquaculture is the farming of aquatic organisms, including fish, molluscs, crustaceans and aquatic plants. Farming implies some form of intervention in the rearing process to enhance production, such as regular stocking, feeding, protection from predators, etc. Farming also implies individual or corporate ownership of the stock being cultivated. For statistical purposes, aquatic organisms which are harvested by an individual or corporate body which has owned them throughout their rearing period contribute to aquaculture, while aquatic organisms which are exploitable by the public as a common property resources, with or without appropriate licences, are the harvest of fisheries.

classDefinition: An aquaculture process during which humans rear freshwater macrophytes.
parentDefinition: An aquaculture process during which humans rear plants.

classDefinition: A shrimp pond which is embedded in a coastal water body.
parentDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous volume of liquid water and is held in shape or sustained by an environmental process.
classComment: "Shrimp" is a common language term that may refer to multiple crustacean species, typically in the groups Caridea or Dendrobranchiatamarine. These may be marine or freshwater organisms.
parentComment: Similar, in spirit, to landform.

classDefinition: A shrimp pond which is embedded in a coastal water body.
parentDefinition: A lentic water body which is used for the artificial culture of shrimp.
classComment: "Shrimp" is a common language term that may refer to multiple crustacean species, typically in the groups Caridea or Dendrobranchiatamarine. These may be marine or freshwater organisms.
parentComment: "Shrimp" is a common language term that may refer to multiple crustacean species, typically in the groups Caridea or Dendrobranchiatamarine. These may be marine or freshwater organisms.

classDefinition: Coastal water is a marine water body bordering a coast.
parentDefinition: A lentic water body which is composed primarily of marine water.

classDefinition: Saline water which is derived from sea water and used during the cultivation of crustaceans.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: Saline water which is derived from sea water and used during the cultivation of crustaceans.
parentDefinition: Water which contains a significant concentration of dissolved salts.
parentComment: The threshold salt concentration for classifying water as saline varies, but typically begins at about 1,000 to 3,000 parts salt per million parts water or 0.1–0.3% salt by weight.

classDefinition: A fog which is composed of liquid aerosols and gases derived from volcanic gas emissions (primarily sulfur oxides), formed when sulfur-bearing gases react with sunlight, oxygen, and moisture in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A visible mass of cloud water droplets or ice crystals suspended in the air at or near the surface of an astronomical body.
classComment: "Vog and smog are different. Vog is formed when sulfur oxides emitted by a volcano react with moisture to form an aerosol. The aerosol scatters light, thus making the vog visible. Smog is formed largely from the incomplete combustion of fuel, reacting with nitrogen oxides and ozone produced from carbon monoxide by reactions with sunlight. The result is also a visible aerosol."
parentComment: Fog is more opaque than mist, reducing visibility to under one kilometre. This class refers only to fog formed by materials primarily composed of water. "Fog can be considered a type of low-lying cloud and is heavily influenced by nearby bodies of water, topography, and wind conditions. In turn, fog has affected many human activities, such as shipping, travel, and warfare." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fog

classDefinition: A material transport process during which a portion of gaseous environmental material is transported into the atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classLabel: transport of waste to a designated storage site
classDefinition: A process during which materials deemed to be waste are removed from a site and transported to another site designated for its storage.
parentDefinition: A process during which materials deemed to be waste are transported away from a site.

classDefinition: A process during which materials deemed to be waste are transported away from a site.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which is driven by the action of humans.

classDefinition: A process during which materials deemed to be waste are transported away from a site.
parentDefinition: A planned process during which the amount of pollutants released into an environmental system is regulated.

classDefinition: A planned process during which the amount of pollutants released into an environmental system is regulated.
parentDefinition: A process during which humans apply technology to alter the magnitude, duration, rate, or impact of an environmental process.
parentComment: Relabel the obo foundry unique label to be generic process

classLabel: transport of child feces to a designated site
parentLabel: transport of waste to a designated storage site
classDefinition: A waste disposal process during which the feces of human children is transported to a designated storage site.
parentDefinition: A process during which materials deemed to be waste are removed from a site and transported to another site designated for its storage.

classLabel: transport of household waste to a designated storage site
parentLabel: transport of waste to a designated storage site
classDefinition: A process during which materials used in a household and deemed to be waste are removed from the housing unit and transported to another site designated for its storage.
parentDefinition: A process during which materials deemed to be waste are removed from a site and transported to another site designated for its storage.

parentLabel: fiat part of an astronomical object
classDefinition: A site which has been designated as a place where humans may defecate.
parentDefinition: A part of an environmental system whose boundaries are determined by fiat.
parentComment: Subclasses of this class have fiat (and only fiat) boundaries - that is, boundaries which are determined by human consensus or opinion rather than (and sometimes in contrast to) well-defined physical discontinuities. We distinguish these from entities that have fuzzy or hard to define boundaries that do overlap some form of physical discontinuity.

classDefinition: An environmental pollution process during which the temperature of an environmental system, or parts thereof, is raised above its natural levels.
parentDefinition: An environmental system process that results in the introduction of contaminants into an environment.
parentComment: Pollutants may be material or immaterial (e.g. heat energy)

classDefinition: An environmental system process that results in the introduction of contaminants into an environment.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
classComment: Pollutants may be material or immaterial (e.g. heat energy)
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classLabel: thermal pollution of an aquatic system
classDefinition: A thermal pollution process which occurs in a water body or aquatic environment.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classLabel: thermal pollution of an aquatic system
classDefinition: A thermal pollution process which occurs in a water body or aquatic environment.
parentDefinition: An environmental pollution process during which the temperature of an environmental system, or parts thereof, is raised above its natural levels.

classLabel: thermal pollution of an aquatic system
classDefinition: A thermal pollution process which occurs in a water body or aquatic environment.
parentDefinition: A pollution process during which contaminants are released into water.

classDefinition: A pollution process during which contaminants are released into water.
parentDefinition: An environmental system process that results in the introduction of contaminants into an environment.
parentComment: Pollutants may be material or immaterial (e.g. heat energy)

classDefinition: Water which accumulates on a solid surface during precipitation events and snow/ice melt.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.
classComment: "Stormwater can soak into the soil (infiltrate), be held on the surface and evaporate, or runoff and end up in nearby streams, rivers, or other water bodies (surface water)."

classDefinition: Stormwater which accumulates in an urban ecosystem.
parentDefinition: Water which accumulates on a solid surface during precipitation events and snow/ice melt.
classComment: "Stormwater can soak into the soil (infiltrate), be held on the surface and evaporate, or runoff and end up in nearby streams, rivers, or other water bodies (surface water)."
parentComment: "Stormwater can soak into the soil (infiltrate), be held on the surface and evaporate, or runoff and end up in nearby streams, rivers, or other water bodies (surface water)."

classDefinition: Stormwater which accumulates in a rural ecosystem.
parentDefinition: Water which accumulates on a solid surface during precipitation events and snow/ice melt.
classComment: "Stormwater can soak into the soil (infiltrate), be held on the surface and evaporate, or runoff and end up in nearby streams, rivers, or other water bodies (surface water)."
parentComment: "Stormwater can soak into the soil (infiltrate), be held on the surface and evaporate, or runoff and end up in nearby streams, rivers, or other water bodies (surface water)."

classDefinition: A permeability quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's being incapable of being permeated or pervaded by a gas or liquid (as by osmosis or diffusion).
parentDefinition: A structural quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's disposition to being permeated or pervaded by a gas or liquid (as by osmosis or diffusion).

classDefinition: A layer throughout which one or more qualities (e.g. pressure, temperature, velocity, density) maintain an approximately constant value.
parentDefinition: A material entity which 1) is spatially continuous, 2) is composed of material of comparable thickness, composition, and physical properties, and 3) is physically distinct from adjacent portions of environmental material.
classComment: Isosurfaces are not equivalent to a "surface layer" in the sense of overlapping an external boundary. Further, this class is concerned only with material isosurfaces, not with mathematical abstractions.

classDefinition: A layer which is part of a cryosphere.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: A layer which is part of a cryosphere.
parentDefinition: A material entity which 1) is spatially continuous, 2) is composed of material of comparable thickness, composition, and physical properties, and 3) is physically distinct from adjacent portions of environmental material.

classDefinition: A road which is primarily composed of asphalt.
parentDefinition: An open way for the passage of vehicles, persons, or animals on land.

classDefinition: A road which is primarily composed of asphalt.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of liquid material.

classDefinition: A road which is primarily composed of concrete.
parentDefinition: An open way for the passage of vehicles, persons, or animals on land.

classDefinition: A constructed pavement which is built on the side of a road and intended for foot traffic.
parentDefinition: A construction which comprises a durable surface layer overlying a solid surface intended to sustain vehicular or foot traffic.
classComment: "In some places, the same term may also be used for a paved path, trail or footpath that is not next to a road, for example, a path through a park."

classDefinition: A road which is used for local access to one or more structures, and is privately owned and maintained by an individual or group.
parentDefinition: An open way for the passage of vehicles, persons, or animals on land.

classDefinition: A constructed pavement which is used for parking vehicles.
parentDefinition: A construction which comprises a durable surface layer overlying a solid surface intended to sustain vehicular or foot traffic.

classDefinition: Dust which is composed primarily of slicon dioxide.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material with diameters less than 500 micrometers.
parentComment: Dust occurs in and may be deposited from the atmosphere.

classDefinition: Dust which is primarily composed of aluminium particles.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material with diameters less than 500 micrometers.
parentComment: Dust occurs in and may be deposited from the atmosphere.

classDefinition: Dust which is primarily composed of barium particles.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material with diameters less than 500 micrometers.
parentComment: Dust occurs in and may be deposited from the atmosphere.

classDefinition: Dust which is primarily composed of hydrated magnesium silicate (talc) particles.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material with diameters less than 500 micrometers.
parentComment: Dust occurs in and may be deposited from the atmosphere.

classDefinition: Dust which is primarily composed of slate particles.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material with diameters less than 500 micrometers.
parentComment: Dust occurs in and may be deposited from the atmosphere.

classDefinition: A fire which occurs in an industrial area or building.
parentDefinition: A fire is a process whereby rapid and exothermic oxidation of a material through a combustion process releases heat, light, and other products.
parentComment: Not to be confused with a flame - the visible portion of gas released by a fire . Oxidation processes such as rusting or biological digestion are not subsumed here.

classDefinition: Dust which is primarily composed of kaolinite particles.
parentDefinition: Dust which is derived from mineral material.

classDefinition: Dust which is derived from mineral material.
parentDefinition: A mineral material is an environmental material which is primarily composed of some substance that is naturally occurring, solid and stable at room temperature, representable by a chemical formula, usually abiogenic, and that has an ordered atomic structure.

classDefinition: Dust which is derived from mineral material.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material with diameters less than 500 micrometers.
parentComment: Dust occurs in and may be deposited from the atmosphere.

classDefinition: A land fire which consumes low-growing plants such as scrub and brush.
parentDefinition: A fire which occurs on land, typically consuming a terrestrial ecosystem as fuel.

classDefinition: A land fire which occurs in a large uncleared or sparsely settled area (as in Australia) usually scrub-covered or forested.
parentDefinition: A fire which occurs on land, typically consuming a terrestrial ecosystem as fuel.
classComment: "Bush" is a rather loosely defined regional term, primarily used in Australia.

classDefinition: A fire which occurs in a pastureland.
parentDefinition: A fire which occurs in a grassland, combusting biomass stored in grasses as its primary fuel.

classDefinition: A fire which occurs in a grassland, combusting biomass stored in grasses as its primary fuel.
parentDefinition: A fire which occurs on land, typically consuming a terrestrial ecosystem as fuel.

classDefinition: A material transport process which arises spontaneously due to physical heterogeneities in a portion of a material and forces which act throughout its volume.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
classComment: Most commonly, convective flows are generated by heterogeneities in density or the effects of gravity. When the cause of the convection is unspecified, convection due to the effects of thermal expansion and buoyancy can be assumed. Convection frequently occurs in fluids, but may also take place in soft solids or mixtures where particles can flow.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: An object which is composed of a continuous mass of air.
parentDefinition: An object which is composed primarily of a gas.
parentComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.

classDefinition: A warm-core cyclone which occurs in the middle and high latitudes, primarily drawing energy from horizontal temperature contrasts between atmospheric fronts.
parentDefinition: A cyclone which rotates around an area low atmospheric pressure with increased temperature.
classComment: "When associated with cold fronts, extratropical cyclones may be particularly damaging (e.g. European winter/windstorm, Nor’easter)."
parentComment: The threshold of  what is "warm" is variable, and thus data-level thresholding should be applied when using this class.

classDefinition: A cyclone which rotates around an area low atmospheric pressure with increased temperature.
parentDefinition: An atmospheric storm during which a large mass of atmospheric gas rotates around a centre of low atmospheric pressure, generating high winds which spiral towards that centre.
classComment: The threshold of  what is "warm" is variable, and thus data-level thresholding should be applied when using this class.

classDefinition: A an atmospheric storm which originates over tropical or subtropical waters and possesses a warm-core, non-frontal synoptic-scale cyclone with a low pressure centre, spiral rain bands and strong winds.
parentDefinition: An atmospheric storm is a process in which a portion of an astronomical body's atmosphere is strongly perturbed from its prevaling weather.

classDefinition: An atmospheric storm during which a large mass of atmospheric gas rotates around a centre of low atmospheric pressure, generating high winds which spiral towards that centre.
parentDefinition: An atmospheric storm is a process in which a portion of an astronomical body's atmosphere is strongly perturbed from its prevaling weather.

classDefinition: A gaseous part of an atmosphere in which gases have reduced atmospheric pressure.
parentDefinition: That part of an atmosphere which is composed of gaseous material.
classComment: Air is not specified directly (although the definition subsumes air masses) to allow for other forms of low pressure areas in planetary atmospheres.

classDefinition: A positional quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's being located in a position equidistant from edges.
parentDefinition: A spatial quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's spatial location relative to other objects in the vicinity.

classDefinition: A mass fluid flow which moves  in the same direction as a planet's rotation, rotating due to a Coriolis effect.
parentDefinition: An advective transport process during which a fluid moves.

classDefinition: An environmental zone which is part of an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A site which has its extent determined by the presence or influence of one or more components of an environmental system or the processes occurring therein.
parentComment: Formerly, this class was an experimental class and a subclass of "environmental feature". It is now aligned to BFO. The class was not obsoleted as the core semantics maintained their stability through its transition.

classDefinition: That part of an atmosphere which is composed of gaseous material.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of gaseous material.

classDefinition: A pressure which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A physical quality that inheres in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's amount of force per unit area it exerts.

classDefinition: A pressure which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is decreased compared to normal or average.

classDefinition: A layer of liquid that is part of an estuary.
parentDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous volume of liquid water and is held in shape or sustained by an environmental process.
parentComment: Similar, in spirit, to landform.

classDefinition: A layer of liquid that is part of an estuary.
parentDefinition: A layer in a water mass, itself composed primarily of water.
parentComment: This class will eventually be populated by inference, and its asserted subclasses removed.

classDefinition: A layer of estuarine water which extends a few centimeters from the surface of the water column towards the estuary bed and from the shore to a fiat boundary where the estuary bed below the water column reaches a depth of 4 meters.
parentDefinition: A liquid surface layer which is in contact with air.
classComment: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). In ENVO, we may adapt the definition for consistency, but the semantics (meaning) of the term should be unaffected. Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions.

classDefinition: A layer of estuarine water which extends a few centimeters from the surface of the water column towards the estuary bed and from the shore to a fiat boundary where the estuary bed below the water column reaches a depth of 4 meters.
parentDefinition: A surface layer where the solid or liquid material of an astronomical body comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
classComment: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). In ENVO, we may adapt the definition for consistency, but the semantics (meaning) of the term should be unaffected. Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions.
parentComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities

classDefinition: A role which is may be realised by an environmental system
parentDefinition: A realizable entity  the manifestation of which brings about some result or end that is not essential to a continuant  in virtue of the kind of thing that it is but that can be served or participated in by that kind of continuant  in some kinds of natural, social or institutional contexts.
classComment: Experimental class.

classDefinition: A role which is may be realised by an environmental system
parentDefinition: A role is particular behaviour which a material entity may exhibit.
classComment: Experimental class.

classDefinition: An environment which is determined by a bone element.
parentDefinition: An environment which is determined by an anatomical entity.

classDefinition: Skeletal element that is composed of bone tissue.
parentDefinition: Organ consisting of skeletal tissue. Encompasses whole bones, fused bones, cartilaginious elements, teeth, dermal denticles.

classDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of some liquid or gas.
parentDefinition: A layer of some material entity which is adjacent to one or more of its external boundaries and directly interacts with its immediate surroundings.
parentComment: This class is distinct from a geometric surface, which is two-dimensional. The idea of "uppermost" may be problematic. Further, the definition of layer (the superclass of surface in rev 133) references surface. This may be another issue. Perhaps this can be made into an inferred class using 'bounding layer of' some material entity, note that 'bounding layer' implies containment, which may not be valid here.

classDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of some liquid or gas.
parentDefinition: A surface layer which separates two portions of fluid with respect to either 1) a discontinuity of some fluid property or 2) some derivative of one of these properties in a direction normal to the interface.

classDefinition: A layer of estuarine water which extends from the surface of the water column to the pycnocline or mid-depth and from the shore to a fiat boundary where the estuary bed below the water column reaches a depth of 4 meters.

classLabel: estuarine tidal riverine coastal surface layer
classDefinition: A layer of fresh estuarine water which extends a few centimeters from the surface of the water column towards the estuary bed and from the land-water interface to a fiat boundary where the estuary bed below the water column reaches a depth of 4 meters.
parentDefinition: A layer of estuarine water which extends a few centimeters from the surface of the water column towards the estuary bed and from the shore to a fiat boundary where the estuary bed below the water column reaches a depth of 4 meters.
classComment: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). In ENVO, we may adapt the definition for consistency, but the semantics (meaning) of the term should be unaffected. Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions.

classLabel: estuarine tidal riverine coastal upper water column
classDefinition: A layer of fresh estuarine water which extends from the surface of the water column to the pycnocline or mid-depth and from the land-water interface to a fiat boundary where the estuary bed below the water column reaches a depth of 4 meters.
parentDefinition: A layer of estuarine water which extends from the surface of the water column to the pycnocline or mid-depth and from the shore to a fiat boundary where the estuary bed below the water column reaches a depth of 4 meters.
classComment: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). classLabel: estuarine open water lower water column
classDefinition: A layer of estuarine water which extends from an estuarine pycnocline or mid-depth to the estuary bed and from a fiat boundary where the estuary bed below the water column reaches a depth of 4 meters to end of the estuary most distal from the coast.
parentDefinition: A layer of liquid that is part of an estuary.
classComment: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). In ENVO, we may adapt the definition for consistency, but the semantics (meaning) of the term should be unaffected. Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions.

classDefinition: An estuarine coastal pycnocline which is composed primarily of fresh tidal water.
parentDefinition: A pycnocline which is part of an estuarine water body, spanning from the shore to a fiat boundary where the estuary bed below the water column reaches a depth of 4 meters.
classComment: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). parentDefinition: A layer of estuarine water which extends from an estuarine pycnocline or mid-depth to the estuarine bed and from the shore to a fiat boundary where the estuary bed below the water column reaches a depth of 4 meters.

classDefinition: A biogeochemical cycle which has nitrogen-bearing chemical entities as participants.
parentDefinition: A biogeochemical process during which one or more chemical compounds are sequentially converted into a series of related compounds in a regularly repeating, periodic fashion.

classDefinition: A biogeochemical process during which one or more chemical compounds are sequentially converted into a series of related compounds in a regularly repeating, periodic fashion.
parentDefinition: A process during which chemicals that are involved in natural ecosystem processes are transported or transformed, and which impact the activity of biological entities

classDefinition: A biogeochemical cycle which has sulfur-bearing chemical entities as participants.
parentDefinition: A biogeochemical process during which one or more chemical compounds are sequentially converted into a series of related compounds in a regularly repeating, periodic fashion.

classDefinition: A biogeochemical cycle which has phosphorous-bearing chemical entities as participants.
parentDefinition: A biogeochemical process during which one or more chemical compounds are sequentially converted into a series of related compounds in a regularly repeating, periodic fashion.

classDefinition: A tidal flow process which occurs in an ocean or sea and during which tidal movements generate advective flows, often amplified in velocity when moving through an inlet, pass or channel.
parentDefinition: A water flow process during which movements of water masses caused by varying gravitational and rotational forces from astronomical bodies, combined with the rotation of the astronomical body containing the water mass, cause waters to undergo periodic depth oscillations (tides).
classComment: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). In ENVO, we may adapt the definition for consistency, but the semantics (meaning) of the term should be unaffected. Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions.

classDefinition: A material transport process during which a volume of material is displaced due to a disequilibrium in physical forces and during which 1) the qualities that inhere in that volume and 2) the processes that are unfolding within it are largely unchanged.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
classComment: Advective processes are disjoint from diffusive processes. Typically, fluids are advected.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: A physical quality of a process which is characteristic of process that transport material without, themselves, changing the qualities of those materials or the processes that are unfolding within them.
A material transport process during which material moves from a region of higher concentration to a region of lower concentration.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
classComment: Diffusion is also applied to the movement of energy, thus the more specific label. This class will be repositioned (but with the core of its definition intact) if we include other forms of diffusion in ENVO.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: An ice mass which is attached to a bed underneath a body of water.
An ice mass which is attached to a bed underneath a body of water.
parentDefinition: A mass of water ice.

classDefinition: A marine current which is maintained by a tidal flow process.
parentDefinition: A water current which is maintained by a continuous, directed movement of marine water, generated by forces caused by breaking waves, wind, Coriolis force, temperature and salinity differences, and tides caused by the gravitational pull of astronomical bodies. Depth contours, shoreline configurations and interaction with other currents influence a current's direction and strength.
classComment: This class aligns to an ambiguously defined unit of the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS), "Tidal Flow" (https://cmecscatalog.org/cmecs/classification/unit/643.html).  In CMECS, this is treated as a hydroform, but is defined as a process (while some of its subclasses are not). In ENVO, we have aligned the CMECS unit according to its definition as a process (ENVO:01001333); however, we maintain this class to allow reference to the hydroform maintained by that process.

classDefinition: Anchor ice which is attached to a riverbed.
parentDefinition: An ice mass which is attached to a bed underneath a body of water.

classDefinition: A marine zone in which ocean waters undergo a diurnal (once per day) tidal oscillation - with one high and one low tide per day - due to the supression of a second daily oscillation by the geometry of the ocean basin and obstructions presented by land masses.
parentDefinition: An environmental zone in which varying gravitational forces from astronomical bodies, combined with the rotation of the astronomical body containing the zone, cause marine waters to undergo periodic depth oscillations (tides).
classComment: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). In ENVO, we may adapt the definition for consistency, but the semantics (meaning) of the term should be unaffected. In this case, the definition aligns with ENVO's "environmental zone" semantics. Alternate classes have been created to accommodate the process of diurnal tidal flow. The as the frequency of the process does not influence the semantics of the resulting hydroform, please use ENVO_01001336 to reference the hydroform rather than the zone or the process. Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions.

classDefinition: An environmental zone in which varying gravitational forces from astronomical bodies, combined with the rotation of the astronomical body containing the zone, cause marine waters to undergo periodic depth oscillations (tides).
parentDefinition: An astronomical body part which is part of a marine environment.
parentComment: This class will eventually be populated by inference alone, with its subclasses distributed in more process-linked hierarchies to improve semantic density.

classDefinition: A tidal flow process which occurs once per day in ocean waters where a second daily oscillation is blocked by land masses or ocean basin geometry.
parentDefinition: A tidal flow process which occurs in an ocean or sea and during which tidal movements generate advective flows, often amplified in velocity when moving through an inlet, pass or channel.
classComment: This class broadly aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). This class is provided as the processual equivalent of CMECS unit 664 "Diurnal Tidal Flow" (https://cmecscatalog.org/cmecs/classification/unit/664.html); however, based on its definition, CMECS:664 is more accurately mapped to ENVO:01001338 as the definition aligns with ENVO's "environmental zone" semantics. A class has been created to accommodate the  semantics of the resulting hydroform (ENVO:01001336). Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions.
parentComment: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). In ENVO, we may adapt the definition for consistency, but the semantics (meaning) of the term should be unaffected. Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions.

classDefinition: A marine tidal flow zone in which ocean waters undergo a semi-diurnal (twice per day) tidal oscillation - with two high and two low tides per day of roughly equal amplitude.
parentDefinition: An environmental zone in which varying gravitational forces from astronomical bodies, combined with the rotation of the astronomical body containing the zone, cause marine waters to undergo periodic depth oscillations (tides).
classComment: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). In ENVO, we may adapt the definition for consistency, but the semantics (meaning) of the term should be unaffected. In this case, the definition aligns with ENVO's "environmental zone" semantics. Alternate classes have been created to accommodate the process of diurnal tidal flow. The as the frequency of the process does not influence the semantics of the resulting hydroform, please use ENVO:01001336 to reference the hydroform rather than the zone or the process. Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions.

classDefinition: A marine tidal flow process which occurs twice per day, resulting in two high and two low tides per day, both of roughly equal amplitude.
parentDefinition: A tidal flow process which occurs in an ocean or sea and during which tidal movements generate advective flows, often amplified in velocity when moving through an inlet, pass or channel.
classComment: This class broadly aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). This class is provided as the processual equivalent of CMECS unit 666 "Semi-diurnal Tidal Flow" (https://cmecscatalog.org/cmecs/classification/unit/666.html); however, based on its definition, CMECS:666 is more accurately mapped to ENVO:01001340 as the definition aligns with ENVO's "environmental zone" semantics. A class has been created to accommodate the  semantics of the resulting hydroform (ENVO:01001336). Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions.
parentComment: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). In ENVO, we may adapt the definition for consistency, but the semantics (meaning) of the term should be unaffected. Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions.

classDefinition: Anchor ice which is attached to a riverbed where a river flows into a marine water body and which is formed by the freezing of freshwater seeping out of the riverbed's sediments.
parentDefinition: Anchor ice which is attached to a riverbed.

classDefinition: A zone on a glacier which is roughly linear and where the rates of ice ablation and accumulation are approximately equal.
parentDefinition: An environmental zone in which the rates of two or more processes are roughly equal to one another.

classDefinition: An environmental zone in which the rates of two or more processes are roughly equal to one another.
parentDefinition: A site which has its extent determined by the presence or influence of one or more components of an environmental system or the processes occurring therein.
parentComment: Formerly, this class was an experimental class and a subclass of "environmental feature". It is now aligned to BFO. The class was not obsoleted as the core semantics maintained their stability through its transition.

classDefinition: A process during which the mass of ice constituting a glacier increases.
parentDefinition: A material accumulation process during which the mass of an existing ice mass increases.

classDefinition: A process during which the mass of ice constituting a glacier increases.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which involves glaciers or ice sheets.
parentComment: Note that ice sheets and glaciers are confounded and confused in multiple communities and across multiple sources.

classDefinition: An ice accumulation zone which overlaps part of a glacier.
parentDefinition: A material accumulation zone in which the rates of ice formation processes exceed those of ice decumulation processes, leading to a net icrease in some mass of ice.
classComment: This zone usually occurs at higher elevations and generally overlaps the conversion of snow to glacial ice.

classDefinition: An ablation zone which is part of a glacier.
parentDefinition: An environmental zone which overlaps a glacier or an ice sheet, and in which ice loss exceeds ice gain.
classComment: This class is more fully defined as: "The part of the glacier, usually at lower elevations, where ablation exceeds accumulation in magnitude, that is, where the cumulative mass balance relative to the start of the mass-balance year is negative. Unless qualified, for example by giving a date within the year, references to the ablation zone refer to its extent at the end of the mass-balance year. The extent of the ablation zone can vary strongly from year to year. A synonym of ablation area." - GCW Terminology and Vocabulary Assessment Report 2018”, GCW report #23/2018

classDefinition: A zone in which the deposition and accumulation of an environmental material occurs.
parentDefinition: A site which has its extent determined by the presence or influence of one or more components of an environmental system or the processes occurring therein.
parentComment: Formerly, this class was an experimental class and a subclass of "environmental feature". It is now aligned to BFO. The class was not obsoleted as the core semantics maintained their stability through its transition.

classDefinition: A zone in which processes resulting in the removal of one or more environmental materials have higher rates than pocesses which result in their deposition and accumulation.
parentDefinition: A site which has its extent determined by the presence or influence of one or more components of an environmental system or the processes occurring therein.
parentComment: Formerly, this class was an experimental class and a subclass of "environmental feature". It is now aligned to BFO. The class was not obsoleted as the core semantics maintained their stability through its transition.

classDefinition: A material accumulation zone in which the rates of ice formation processes exceed those of ice decumulation processes, leading to a net icrease in some mass of ice.
parentDefinition: A zone in which the deposition and accumulation of an environmental material occurs.

classDefinition: A material accumulation process during which the mass of an existing ice mass increases.
parentDefinition: A material accumulation process during which ice forms in an environmental material or an existing accumulation of ice increases in mass.

classDefinition: A glacier which is contained in the site bounded by a volcanic crater.
parentDefinition: An ice mass which is of sufficient mass that the action of gravity upon it overcomes the frictional forces holding it in place, causing it to deform and flow towards lower elevation.
parentComment: The definition of glacier is highly variable. Two main issues exist: 1) Whether or not a mass of ice must currently show movement to be considered a glacier or not and 2) What is the relationship between ice sheets and glaciers (i.e., which is the parent in a parent/child relationship or whether they are distinct terms).

classDefinition: The site which is located in a volcanic crater.
parentDefinition: The site which is located in a crater.

classDefinition: The site which is located in a crater.
parentDefinition: A site which has its extent determined by the presence or influence of one or more components of an environmental system or the processes occurring therein.
parentComment: Formerly, this class was an experimental class and a subclass of "environmental feature". It is now aligned to BFO. The class was not obsoleted as the core semantics maintained their stability through its transition.

classDefinition: A climate which is realised through hydrological processes.
parentDefinition: The disposition of an environmental system, particularly those influencing atmospheres, to manifest a cyclic pattern of weather over time.
parentComment: Climate is commonly defined as the weather averaged, or otherwise summarised, over a period of time much longer than the duration of any phenomenon that constitutes weather. The standard averaging period is 30 years, but other periods may be used depending on the purpose.

classDefinition: An aerosol formation event  which occurs in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A process which occurs within an atmosphere.
classComment: Note that the detection of such events, and thus the thresholds used to define them in the field, are operational and dependent on the technology and observation strategy used. The event must be intense enough, occur in a large enough area, and persist for enough time to allow the formed particle population to be observed. There are no exact or universally agreed upon thresholds for the intensity, area and duration of such events. If elevated new particle formation rate is observed in the atmosphere (away from direct sources of the related gas-phase molecules) for an operationally defined period of time, practitioners often declare that such an event has taken place.
parentComment: This class will be populated by inference and is primarily organisational.

classDefinition: An aerosol formation event  which occurs in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: An aerosol formation process during which the rate of particle formation exceeds that which is normally present in the site of its occurrence.
classComment: Note that the detection of such events, and thus the thresholds used to define them in the field, are operational and dependent on the technology and observation strategy used. The event must be intense enough, occur in a large enough area, and persist for enough time to allow the formed particle population to be observed. There are no exact or universally agreed upon thresholds for the intensity, area and duration of such events. If elevated new particle formation rate is observed in the atmosphere (away from direct sources of the related gas-phase molecules) for an operationally defined period of time, practitioners often declare that such an event has taken place.
parentComment: This is similar to the semantics of storms, where increased rates are observed due to external forcings.

classDefinition: An aerosol formation process during which the rate of particle formation exceeds that which is normally present in the site of its occurrence.
parentDefinition: A process during which particles suspended in a gaseous medium are formed.
classComment: This is similar to the semantics of storms, where increased rates are observed due to external forcings.

classDefinition: An alpine tundra ecosystem which exists above the continuous timberline but below the permanent snowline on elevated land in tropical regions.
parentDefinition: An environment which has a climate with continually high temperatures and with considerable precipitation, at least during part of the year.
classComment: Paramo ecosystems are known to be evolutionary hotspots and large daily fluctuations in temperature and humidity, often resulting in dialy freez-thaw cycles.

classDefinition: An alpine tundra ecosystem which exists above the continuous timberline but below the permanent snowline on elevated land in tropical regions.
parentDefinition: A tundra ecosystem which exists at high altitudes and where vegetation is stunted due to low temperatures and high winds.
classComment: Paramo ecosystems are known to be evolutionary hotspots and large daily fluctuations in temperature and humidity, often resulting in dialy freez-thaw cycles.

classDefinition: A tundra ecosystem which exists at high altitudes and where vegetation is stunted due to low temperatures and high winds.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem which 1) typically has monthly average temperatures below 10 degrees Celsius 2) has a low evapotranspiration ratio 3) is dominated by treeless terrain, covered by communities of low-growing vegetation such as dwarf shrubs, sedges and grasses, mosses, and lichens, 4) contains areas of soil underlain by permafrost with a thin active layer and 5) occurs in both polar and alpine regions (i.e., both high latitudes and high altitudes), and 5) does not have permanent snow or ice cover.
parentComment: Tundra ecosysems are often underlaid by permafrost, with the result that drainage is bad and the soil may be saturated for long periods. It does not have a permanent snow-ice cover.  Productivity is low in this biome because of the extremes of climate.

classDefinition: A direction which inheres in an atmospheric wind, typically expressed as the inverse of the direction the wind is moving in.
parentDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's orientation in space.

classDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's orientation in space.
parentDefinition: A quality of a physical entity that exists through action of continuants at the physical level of organisation in relation to other entities.

classDefinition: The speed of an atmospheric wind.
parentDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's scalar absolute value of the rate of change of the bearer's position.

classDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's scalar absolute value of the rate of change of the bearer's position.
parentDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's participation in movement.

classDefinition: The volume of water which has fallen during a precipitation process.
parentDefinition: A 3-D extent quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's amount of 3-dimensional space it occupies.
classComment: While the precipitated material may be water in any of its forms, the volume that this class refers to is that of liquid water.

classDefinition: A 3-D extent quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's amount of 3-dimensional space it occupies.
parentDefinition: A size quality inhering in an bearer by virtue of the bearer's extension in three dimensions.

classDefinition: A process during which gas-phase molecules form solid or liquid particles that are stable enough to continue growing in size - via the condensation or aggregation of other gas-phase molecules - at a greater rate than their constituents re-enter gas phase.
parentDefinition: A process which occurs within an atmosphere.
parentComment: This class will be populated by inference and is primarily organisational.

classDefinition: A process during which gas-phase molecules form solid or liquid particles that are stable enough to continue growing in size - via the condensation or aggregation of other gas-phase molecules - at a greater rate than their constituents re-enter gas phase.
parentDefinition: An aerosol formation process during which solid or liquid particles are either 1) formed in a volume of gas through gas-to-liquid or gas-to-solid conversions or 2) increase in size through aggregation with other particles.

classDefinition: An aerosol formation process during which solid or liquid particles are either 1) formed in a volume of gas through gas-to-liquid or gas-to-solid conversions or 2) increase in size through aggregation with other particles.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A process during which particles suspended in a gaseous medium are formed.
parentDefinition: A process during which microscopic solid or liquid objects are formed.

classDefinition: A material transport process during which solid or liquid particles are directly introduced into a volume of gas.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classLabel: accumulation of matter on aerosolised particles
parentDefinition: A process during which the mass of one or more materials, present within a given site, increases.
classComment: A material accumulation process during which the solid or liquid parts of an aerosol increase in mass due to mechanical aggregation of existing particles or through chemical conversion of gas-phase material.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material accumulation process ends a material transport process.

classDefinition: A shrubland biome which is densely vegetated by dwarf or short mangroves (and associates) that are generally less than 6 meters in height, is tidally influenced,  is located in tropical or subtropical areas.
parentDefinition: A shrubland biome is a terrestrial biome which includes, across its entire spatial extent, dense groups of shrubs.
classComment: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). In ENVO, we may adapt the definition for consistency, but the semantics (meaning) of the term should be unaffected. Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions. CMECS provides the following notes: "Commonly found on intertidal mud flats along the shores of estuaries. Tidal mangrove shrublands may include immature stands or stunted mature trees that indicate a harsh growing environment. Areas characterized by tall mangroves (> 6 meters) are placed in the Tidal Mangrove Forest Biotic Group. Where tidal amplitude is relatively low, the vegetation forms narrow bands along the coastal plains, and it rarely penetrates inland more than several kilometers along rivers. Where tidal amplitude is greater, mangroves extend further inland along river courses, forming extensive stands in the major river deltas. Also, mangrove cays may occur within the lagoon complex of barrier reefs. The list of biotic communities for this group is long: a few examples are provided below, and the complete list is available in Appendix F"
parentComment: Preliminary definition.

classDefinition: An area of tundra which is present in a region subject to alpine conditions.
parentDefinition: A vegetated area which is part of a tundra ecosystem.

classDefinition: A secondary aerosol formation process which occurs in an atmosphere at an increased rate relative to background processes of the same kind.
parentDefinition: An aerosol formation process during which solid or liquid particles are either 1) formed in a volume of gas through gas-to-liquid or gas-to-solid conversions or 2) increase in size through aggregation with other particles.
classComment: Note that the detection of such events, and thus the thresholds used to define them in the field, are operational and dependent on the technology and observation strategy used. The event must be intense enough, occur in a large enough area, and persist for enough time to allow the formed particle population to be observed. There are no exact or universally agreed upon thresholds for the intensity, area and duration of such events. If elevated new particle formation rate is observed in the atmosphere (away from direct sources of the related gas-phase molecules) for an operationally defined period of time, practitioners often declare that such an event has taken place.

classDefinition: A physical quality which inheres in a marine water body by virtue of the height, wavelength, period, and directional energy flux of its waves which evolve into swell through nonlinear dynamics.
parentDefinition: A quality of a physical entity that exists through action of continuants at the physical level of organisation in relation to other entities.

classDefinition: A variability quality which inheres in sea ice, particularly in its concentration, area and extent, type, motion, deformation, age, thickness, and volume.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's disposition to varying or changing.
classComment: The EOV specification sheet is simply titled as "sea ice", but the description of the EOV is of the variability of sea ice.

classDefinition: A quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's disposition to varying or changing.
parentDefinition: A dependent entity that inheres in a bearer by virtue of how the bearer is related to other entities

classDefinition: A marine bed which is covered by animals which have benthic habitats, including attached, clinging, sessile, infaunal, burrowing, laying, interstitial, and slow-moving animals, but not animals that have created substrate.
parentDefinition: A submerged bed which underlies a marine water body.
classComment: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). In ENVO, we may adapt the definition for consistency, but the semantics (meaning) of the term should be unaffected. Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions. An excerpt of the CMECS description: "Faunal Beds are highly dependent on substrate type. Individual species and entire biotic communities have adapted specialized anatomies and behaviors for survival on hard substrates; other species and communities have specialized and developed adaptations for life on soft substrates. Generalist fauna also occur (e.g., certain holothurians, crustaceans, and sponges) that can succeed on both substrate types. However, substrate type is such a defining aspect of the Faunal Bed class that CMECS Faunal Bed subclasses are assigned as physical-biological associations involving both biota and substrate."

classDefinition: A elevation quality which inheres in a marine water body by virtue of the position of that water body's surface layer (adjacent to an atmosphere) relative to some reference elevation.
parentDefinition: A positional quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's vertical distance of a point above or below a reference surface.

classDefinition: A positional quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's vertical distance of a point above or below a reference surface.
parentDefinition: A spatial quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's spatial location relative to other objects in the vicinity.

classDefinition: A marine faunal bed which is dominated by mussels of the Mytilus or Modiolus genera either 1) resting on the sediment surface, 2)  partially embedded in the sediment, 3) attached to conspecifics (by using their byssal threads), or 4) attached to a piece of gravel in slightly gravelly fine sediments.

classDefinition: A marine reef which is located on a shelf (i.e. in the neritic zone) and primarily composed of self-adhered or conglomerated mussel shells.

classDefinition: An area which is dominated by dense accumulations of mussels attached to a substrate other than conspecifics, including the associated faunal communities and predators present on the mussels (e.g., starfish).
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: This class aligns to the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). In ENVO, we may adapt the definition for consistency, but the semantics (meaning) of the term should be unaffected. Please consult the CMECS catalogue (https://cmecscatalog.org/) for authoritative and semantically unconstrained definitions. From the CMECs definition: "Areas where mussels have constructed substrate are classified as Mussel Reef. Areas where mussels are not attached to a hard substrate are classified as Soft Sediment Fauna, Mussel Bed."
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

parentDefinition: A mussel bed which is located in benthic regions beyond (offshore to) a continental shelf.

parentDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.
classComment: An organic environmental material which is primarily composed of gill tissue.

classDefinition: Multicellular anatomical structure that consists of many cells of one or a few types, arranged in an extracellular matrix such that their long-range organisation is at least partly a repetition of their short-range organisation.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that has more than one cell as a part.

classDefinition: Anatomical surface structure found in many aquatic organisms. It is a respiration organ whose function is the extraction of oxygen from water and the excretion of carbon dioxide. The microscopic structure of a gill is such that it presents a very large surface area to the external environment. Gills usually consist of thin filaments of tissue, branches, or slender tufted processes which have a highly folded surface to increase surface area. A high surface area is crucial to the gas exchange of aquatic organisms as water contains only 1/20 parts dissolved Oxygen compared to air. With the exception of some aquatic insects, the filaments and lamellae (folds) contain blood or coelomic fluid, from which gases are exchanged through the thin walls. Oxygen is carried by the blood to other parts of the body. Carbon dioxide passes from the blood through the thin gill tissue into the water. Gills or gill-like organs, located in different parts of the body, are found in various groups of aquatic animals, including mollusks, crustaceans, insects, fish, and amphibians.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that performs a specific function or group of functions [WP].

classComment: Gill tissue material which is part of salt-water mussel in the family Mytilidae
parentComment: An organic environmental material which is primarily composed of gill tissue.

classComment: Mussel gill tissue material which is part of a member of the genus Bathymodiolus.
parentComment: Gill tissue material which is part of salt-water mussel in the family Mytilidae

classDefinition: Biomass which is composed primarily of dead organisms, their parts, or their organic derivatives.
parentDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.

classDefinition: Clay which is part of an abyssal plain.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: Clay which is part of an abyssal plain.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which 1) is composed primarily of clay particles, with only minor proportions of other materials, 2) demonstrates plasticity when wet, and 3) is capable of hardening when dried or fired.
parentComment: This definition is intentionally ambiguous to support the multiple thresholds set by different authorities.The distinction between silt and clay varies by discipline. Geologists and soil scientists usually consider the separation to occur at a particle size of 2 μm (clays being finer than silts), sedimentologists often use 4–5 μm, and colloid chemists use 1 μm. Geotechnical engineers distinguish between silts and clays based on the plasticity properties of the soil, as measured by the soils' Atterberg limits. ISO 14688 grades clay particles as being smaller than 2 μm and silt particles as being larger. Mixtures of sand, silt and less than 40% clay are called loam. Similar mixtures with greater than 40% clay are often considered clay soils.

classDefinition: A mass which is higher than normal or average.
parentDefinition: A physical quality that inheres in a bearer by virtue of the proportion of the bearer's amount of matter.

classDefinition: A mass which is higher than normal or average.
parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is increased compared to normal or average.

classDefinition: A primary aerosol formation process during which dust particles are suspended in a gaseous medium.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which solid or liquid particles are directly introduced into a volume of gas.

classDefinition: A process during which dust is aerosolised in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A process which occurs within an atmosphere.
parentComment: This class will be populated by inference and is primarily organisational.

classDefinition: A process during which dust is aerosolised in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A primary aerosol formation process during which dust particles are suspended in a gaseous medium.

classDefinition: An aeroform which is formed as a result of strong upper winds spreading a cirrus homogenitus cloud in the atmosphere and, in turn, causing internal tranformations which result in the cloud taking on the appearnce of natural cirri-form clouds.
parentDefinition: A cloud which is primarily composed of water-based aerosols.
classComment: Once these clouds resemble natural cirri-form clouds (Cirrus, Cirrocumulus, Cirrostratus), they are classified as such.
parentComment: On Earth clouds are formed by the saturation of air in the homosphere when air cools or gains water vapor. Note that this class describes clouds as countable objects, rather than 'cloud material'. It also refers only to clouds made up of a water-based material.

classDefinition: An environmental process during which a haze is formed by the aerosolisation of solid particles, including natural materials and anthropogenic pollutants, in an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A process which occurs within an atmosphere.
parentComment: This class will be populated by inference and is primarily organisational.

classDefinition: An aersolised mass of dust, smoke, or other dry particulates which scatters visible light thus obsscuring visibility through an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: An aerosol which has non-gaseous parts that are primarily composed of solid particles.

classDefinition: An aersolised mass of dust, smoke, or other dry particulates which scatters visible light thus obsscuring visibility through an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: An aerosol that is suspended in an atmosphere.

classDefinition: A haze formation process which has an increased rate relative to that which is usually present in a given site.
