parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: A mariculture process during which organisms are cultivated in cages which allow the passage of materials such as wastes, pathogens, antibiotics, and - should a containment breach occur - cultivated organisms themselves to and from the surrounding marine environment.
parentDefinition: An aquaculture process during which marine organisms are cultivated in the open ocean, an enclosure in the ocean, or in tanks, ponds or raceways which are filled with seawater.

classLabel: frontal surface of a weather front
classDefinition: A gaseous surface layer which is composed of the warmer air mass(es) along the horizontal density and temperature discontinuity in a weather front.
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of the atmosphere.
classComment: As stated in the AMS Glossary, this is one interpretation of the term "front", namely "frontal surfaces across which the horizontal density gradient is discontinuous (frontal surface usually refers specifically to the warmer side of the frontal zone);"
parentComment: This could be made into an inferred class, rather than having asserted subclasses.

classLabel: frontal surface of a weather front
classDefinition: A gaseous surface layer which is composed of the warmer air mass(es) along the horizontal density and temperature discontinuity in a weather front.
parentDefinition: A fluid surface layer which is composed primarily of some gaseous material.
classComment: As stated in the AMS Glossary, this is one interpretation of the term "front", namely "frontal surfaces across which the horizontal density gradient is discontinuous (frontal surface usually refers specifically to the warmer side of the frontal zone);"

classDefinition: A fluid surface layer which is composed primarily of some gaseous material.
parentDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of some liquid or gas.

classDefinition: A fluid front which is composed primarily of gaseous material and separates at least two gaseous masses.
parentDefinition: A fluid interface which separates two fluid masses with differing properties.

classDefinition: An object which is composed primarily of a gas.
parentDefinition: An object which is composed primarily of a fluid.
classComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.
parentComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.

classDefinition: A mass of gas which is separated from its surroundings by either 1) a thin liquid layer or 2) a physical or compositional discontinuity.
parentDefinition: An object which is composed primarily of a gas.
classComment: The thin liquid layer case applies to, e.g., soap bubbles in air. The physical or compositional discontinuity case applies to, e.g., bubbles of CO2 in air or bubbles of air in water.
parentComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.

classDefinition: An object which is composed primarily of a fluid.
parentDefinition: An object which is composed primarily of an environmental material
classComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.
parentComment: This class and its subclasses refer to objects that are discrete accumulations of environmental materials, generally primarily composed of one or a few main material types.

classDefinition: A bubble which is composed primarily of methane.
parentDefinition: A mass of gas which is separated from its surroundings by either 1) a thin liquid layer or 2) a physical or compositional discontinuity.
parentComment: The thin liquid layer case applies to, e.g., soap bubbles in air. The physical or compositional discontinuity case applies to, e.g., bubbles of CO2 in air or bubbles of air in water.

classDefinition: A material isosurface within which pressure is approximately constant.
parentDefinition: A layer throughout which one or more qualities (e.g. pressure, temperature, velocity, density) maintain an approximately constant value.
parentComment: Isosurfaces are not equivalent to a "surface layer" in the sense of overlapping an external boundary. Further, this class is concerned only with material isosurfaces, not with mathematical abstractions.

classDefinition: An isobaric surface that is part of an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A material isosurface within which pressure is approximately constant.

classDefinition: A weather front which separates air masses of tropical and polar origin.
parentDefinition: A gaseous front which separates two masses of air with different densities and is a principal cause of meteorological phenomena.
parentComment: This class refers to Earth's weather fronts. Other forms, not composed of air, are present on other planets and can be created on request. Note: "Since the temperature distribution is the most important regulator of atmospheric density, a front almost invariably separates air masses of different temperature. Along with the basic density criterion and the common temperature criterion, many other features may distinguish a front, such as a pressure trough, a change in wind direction, a moisture discontinuity, and certain characteristic cloud and precipitation forms."

classDefinition: An environment which has a climate with warm temperatures and with meagre precipitation.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: An environment which is located in a part of an astronomical body subject to subpolar climatic conditions.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: An environment which is located in a part of an astronomical body subject to temperate climatic conditions.
parentDefinition: A system which has the disposition to environ one or more material entities.
parentComment: In ENVO's alignment with the Basic Formal Ontology, this class is being considered as a subclass of a proposed BFO class "system". The relation "environed_by" is also under development. Roughly, a system which includes a material entity (at least partially) within its site and causally influences that entity may be considered to environ it. Following the completion of this alignment, this class' definition and the definitions of its subclasses will be revised.

classDefinition: A weather front which is nonoccluded and  which moves in the direction of the warmer air mass it is adjacent to, such that colder air will occupy the site where warmer air was previously present.
parentDefinition: A gaseous front which separates two masses of air with different densities and is a principal cause of meteorological phenomena.
classComment: The direction of motion determines whether fronts are "cold", "warm", etc. A front is said to be cold if it's moving in the direction of the warmer air mass it is adjacent to. From the perspective of an observer on the ground, this appears as though the colder air "replaces" the warmer air mass.
parentComment: This class refers to Earth's weather fronts. Other forms, not composed of air, are present on other planets and can be created on request. Note: "Since the temperature distribution is the most important regulator of atmospheric density, a front almost invariably separates air masses of different temperature. Along with the basic density criterion and the common temperature criterion, many other features may distinguish a front, such as a pressure trough, a change in wind direction, a moisture discontinuity, and certain characteristic cloud and precipitation forms."

classDefinition: A weather front which is nonoccluded and which moves in the direction of the colder air mass it is adjacent to, such that warmer air will occupy the site where colder air was previously present.
parentDefinition: A gaseous front which separates two masses of air with different densities and is a principal cause of meteorological phenomena.
classComment: The direction of motion determines whether fronts are "cold", "warm", etc. A front is said to be cold if it's moving in the direction of the warmer air mass it is adjacent to. From the perspective of an observer on the ground, this appears as though the colder air "replaces" the warmer air mass.
parentComment: This class refers to Earth's weather fronts. Other forms, not composed of air, are present on other planets and can be created on request. Note: "Since the temperature distribution is the most important regulator of atmospheric density, a front almost invariably separates air masses of different temperature. Along with the basic density criterion and the common temperature criterion, many other features may distinguish a front, such as a pressure trough, a change in wind direction, a moisture discontinuity, and certain characteristic cloud and precipitation forms."

classDefinition: A weather front at which warm air is ascending to high altitudes along the frontal surface.
parentDefinition: A gaseous front which separates two masses of air with different densities and is a principal cause of meteorological phenomena.
parentComment: This class refers to Earth's weather fronts. Other forms, not composed of air, are present on other planets and can be created on request. Note: "Since the temperature distribution is the most important regulator of atmospheric density, a front almost invariably separates air masses of different temperature. Along with the basic density criterion and the common temperature criterion, many other features may distinguish a front, such as a pressure trough, a change in wind direction, a moisture discontinuity, and certain characteristic cloud and precipitation forms."

classDefinition: A weather front at which warm air is descending to lower altitudes along the frontal surface.
parentDefinition: A gaseous front which separates two masses of air with different densities and is a principal cause of meteorological phenomena.
parentComment: This class refers to Earth's weather fronts. Other forms, not composed of air, are present on other planets and can be created on request. Note: "Since the temperature distribution is the most important regulator of atmospheric density, a front almost invariably separates air masses of different temperature. Along with the basic density criterion and the common temperature criterion, many other features may distinguish a front, such as a pressure trough, a change in wind direction, a moisture discontinuity, and certain characteristic cloud and precipitation forms."

classDefinition: A weather front which exists in an equatorial trough separating the air of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres of an astronomical body.
parentDefinition: A gaseous front which separates two masses of air with different densities and is a principal cause of meteorological phenomena.
classComment: Note there is controversy if such fronts exist or at least are compatible with frontal theory.
parentComment: This class refers to Earth's weather fronts. Other forms, not composed of air, are present on other planets and can be created on request. Note: "Since the temperature distribution is the most important regulator of atmospheric density, a front almost invariably separates air masses of different temperature. Along with the basic density criterion and the common temperature criterion, many other features may distinguish a front, such as a pressure trough, a change in wind direction, a moisture discontinuity, and certain characteristic cloud and precipitation forms."

classDefinition: An air mass which is part of the free atmosphere, including the troposphere and stratosphere.
parentDefinition: An object which is composed of a continuous mass of air.

classDefinition: An atmospheric layer which 1) is located above the planetary boundary layer, 2) in which the effect of friction between moving air masses and the planetary surface is negligible, and 3) in which the air is usually treated (dynamically) as an ideal fluid.
parentDefinition: A layer that is part of the atmosphere.
classComment: "The base of the free atmosphere is usually taken as the geostrophic wind level."
parentComment: This could be made into an inferred class, rather than having asserted subclasses.

classDefinition: A weather front which is part of a mass of upper air.
parentDefinition: A gaseous front which separates two masses of air with different densities and is a principal cause of meteorological phenomena.
parentComment: This class refers to Earth's weather fronts. Other forms, not composed of air, are present on other planets and can be created on request. Note: "Since the temperature distribution is the most important regulator of atmospheric density, a front almost invariably separates air masses of different temperature. Along with the basic density criterion and the common temperature criterion, many other features may distinguish a front, such as a pressure trough, a change in wind direction, a moisture discontinuity, and certain characteristic cloud and precipitation forms."

classDefinition: A weather front which separates air behind a cold front from air ahead of a warm front.
parentDefinition: A gaseous front which separates two masses of air with different densities and is a principal cause of meteorological phenomena.
parentComment: This class refers to Earth's weather fronts. Other forms, not composed of air, are present on other planets and can be created on request. Note: "Since the temperature distribution is the most important regulator of atmospheric density, a front almost invariably separates air masses of different temperature. Along with the basic density criterion and the common temperature criterion, many other features may distinguish a front, such as a pressure trough, a change in wind direction, a moisture discontinuity, and certain characteristic cloud and precipitation forms."

classDefinition: An occluded front which is adjacent to a cold front 1) that is moving away from the coldest air in the vicinity,  2) where the neighbouring cold front undercuts the neighbouring warm front in the occulsion zone, and 3) where the coldest air in the vicinity replaces less cold air towards the surface of the astronomical body.
parentDefinition: A weather front which separates air behind a cold front from air ahead of a warm front.

classDefinition: An occluded front which is adjacent to a warm front 1) that is moving in the direction of the coldest air in the vicinity, 2) where the original cold front is forced aloft at the warm front surface, and 3) where the coldest air is replaced by less cold air at the surface of the astronomical body.
parentDefinition: A weather front which separates air behind a cold front from air ahead of a warm front.

classDefinition: An occluded front which is 1) adjacent to a cold and a warm front with no appreciable difference between the temperatures of their bordering air masses and 2) which creates a pressure trough, a wind-shift line, a band of cloudiness, and precipitation at the surface of the astronomical body.
parentDefinition: A weather front which separates air behind a cold front from air ahead of a warm front.

classDefinition: A cold front which forms behind a frontal cyclone and within a cold air mass with an appreciable horizontal temperature gradient.
parentDefinition: A weather front which is nonoccluded and  which moves in the direction of the warmer air mass it is adjacent to, such that colder air will occupy the site where warmer air was previously present.
classComment: The direction of motion determines whether fronts are "cold", "warm", etc. A front is said to be cold if it's moving in the direction of the warmer air mass it is adjacent to. From the perspective of an observer on the ground, this appears as though the colder air "replaces" the warmer air mass.
parentComment: The direction of motion determines whether fronts are "cold", "warm", etc. A front is said to be cold if it's moving in the direction of the warmer air mass it is adjacent to. From the perspective of an observer on the ground, this appears as though the colder air "replaces" the warmer air mass.

classDefinition: A katabatic wind during which atmospheric gas flows down the slope of an elevation, typically during periods of light larger-scale winds.
parentDefinition: An atmospheric wind during which cold atmospheric gas flows downwards towards the surface of an astronomical body.
classComment: "The many synonyms for downslope flow are sometimes used interchangeably, and this gives rise to ambiguity and confusion. Downslope can be used generically to denote any wind flow blowing down a slope, or it is used specifically for katabatic flows on any scale, such as the nocturnal slope-wind component of mountain–valley wind systems or mountain–plains wind systems." Note also that slope winds are typically classed separately from fall winds, which occur at larger scales.
parentComment: "From its etymology, the term means simply "going down" or "descending," and thus could refer to any descending flow; some authors have further generalized it to include downslope flows such as the foehn or chinook even though they do not represent a flow of cold air. This concept has given rise to the expression katafront, which indicates flow down a sloped cold-frontal surface."

classDefinition: A katabatic wind which is driven by the cooling and subsequent sinking of atmospheric gas masses.
parentDefinition: An atmospheric wind during which cold atmospheric gas flows downwards towards the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: "From its etymology, the term means simply "going down" or "descending," and thus could refer to any descending flow; some authors have further generalized it to include downslope flows such as the foehn or chinook even though they do not represent a flow of cold air. This concept has given rise to the expression katafront, which indicates flow down a sloped cold-frontal surface."

classDefinition: A material cooling process during which a portion of gaseous environmental material loses thermal energy to its surroundings.
parentDefinition: A material cooling process during which a portion of fluid environmental material loses thermal energy to its surroundings.

classDefinition: A downslope katabatic wind during which warm, dry atmospheric gas descends along the lee side of a mountain range as a result of synoptic-scale, cross-barrier flow over that range.
parentDefinition: A katabatic wind during which atmospheric gas flows down the slope of an elevation, typically during periods of light larger-scale winds.
parentComment: "The many synonyms for downslope flow are sometimes used interchangeably, and this gives rise to ambiguity and confusion. Downslope can be used generically to denote any wind flow blowing down a slope, or it is used specifically for katabatic flows on any scale, such as the nocturnal slope-wind component of mountain–valley wind systems or mountain–plains wind systems." Note also that slope winds are typically classed separately from fall winds, which occur at larger scales.

classDefinition: An environmental process during which a system does not thermally interact with its surroundings by virtue of a temperature difference between them.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
classComment: "In an adiabatic process any change in internal energy (for a system of fixed mass) is solely a consequence of working. For an ideal gas and for most atmospheric systems, compression results in warming, expansion results in cooling."
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: An adiabatic process during which no condensation of water vapor occurs and no liquid water is present.
parentDefinition: An environmental process during which a system does not thermally interact with its surroundings by virtue of a temperature difference between them.
parentComment: "In an adiabatic process any change in internal energy (for a system of fixed mass) is solely a consequence of working. For an ideal gas and for most atmospheric systems, compression results in warming, expansion results in cooling."

classDefinition: An adiabatic process which involves air saturated with water vapour and the presence of liquid water.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: An adiabatic process which involves air saturated with water vapour and the presence of liquid water.
parentDefinition: An environmental process during which a system does not thermally interact with its surroundings by virtue of a temperature difference between them.
parentComment: "In an adiabatic process any change in internal energy (for a system of fixed mass) is solely a consequence of working. For an ideal gas and for most atmospheric systems, compression results in warming, expansion results in cooling."

classDefinition: A katabatic wind during which the low temperature and increased density of a cold mass of atmospheric gas accelerates its descent.
parentDefinition: An atmospheric wind during which cold atmospheric gas flows downwards towards the surface of an astronomical body.
classComment: "A fall wind is a larger-scale phenomenon than the individual-slope scale and is produced by accumulated cold air spilling down a slope or over a mountain range. The cold air often either accumulates on a plateau or other elevated terrain, or is part of an extensive cold air mass approaching a mountain range as a cold front."
parentComment: "From its etymology, the term means simply "going down" or "descending," and thus could refer to any descending flow; some authors have further generalized it to include downslope flows such as the foehn or chinook even though they do not represent a flow of cold air. This concept has given rise to the expression katafront, which indicates flow down a sloped cold-frontal surface."

classDefinition: A fall wind which has a source so cold that, when the atmospheric gas reaches the lowlands or coast, the dynamic warming is insufficient to raise its temperature to the normal level for the region; hence it appears as a cold wind.
parentDefinition: A katabatic wind during which the low temperature and increased density of a cold mass of atmospheric gas accelerates its descent.
parentComment: "A fall wind is a larger-scale phenomenon than the individual-slope scale and is produced by accumulated cold air spilling down a slope or over a mountain range. The cold air often either accumulates on a plateau or other elevated terrain, or is part of an extensive cold air mass approaching a mountain range as a cold front."

classDefinition: An atmospheric wind which rapidly forms, lasts for a duration in the order of minutes, and then rapidly decreases in speed.
A storm which is nautical, localised, and of high severity local storm considered as a whole: that is, winds and cloud mass and (if any) precipitation, thunder and lightning.
parentDefinition: An atmospheric storm is a process in which a portion of an astronomical body's atmosphere is strongly perturbed from its prevaling weather.

classDefinition: A wind which is driven by the acceleration of flow through a gap, constriction, or channel resulting from large-scale pressure gradient, or by Venturi acceleration through a constricting passage.
A jet-effect which passes through a gap, constriction, or channel between mountains in a mountain range or between ranges themselves.
parentDefinition: A wind which is driven by the acceleration of flow through a gap, constriction, or channel resulting from large-scale pressure gradient, or by Venturi acceleration through a constricting passage.

classDefinition: An atmospheric wind which moves up or down a slope and is driven by heating or cooling of that slope.
An upslope wind driven by heating at the slope surface under fair-weather conditions.
parentDefinition: An atmospheric wind which moves up or down a slope and is driven by heating or cooling of that slope.
classComment: Unlike the term "katabatic wind", anabatic wind has a focused meaning and suffers from less ambiguity, thus the more precise treatement of this term and its place deeper in the hierarchy.

classDefinition: A process during which direct stellar radiation interacts with a planetary surface.
parentDefinition: A process during which energy is emitted or transmitted in the form of waves or particles through space or a material medium.

classDefinition: A material cooling process during which a portion of fluid environmental material loses thermal energy to its surroundings.
parentDefinition: A process during which the temperature of a portion of environmental material is decreased, along with the kinetic energy of its constituent molecules.
parentComment: Note that ice formation, freezing, etc may have this process as a part, but may also occur without temperature decreases (e.g. through extreme gravitational effects). See the material congelation process hierarchy for more.

classDefinition: A material cooling process during which a portion of liquid environmental material loses thermal energy to its surroundings.
parentDefinition: A material cooling process during which a portion of fluid environmental material loses thermal energy to its surroundings.

classDefinition: A material cooling process during which a portion of solid environmental material loses thermal energy to its surroundings.
parentDefinition: A process during which the temperature of a portion of environmental material is decreased, along with the kinetic energy of its constituent molecules.
parentComment: Note that ice formation, freezing, etc may have this process as a part, but may also occur without temperature decreases (e.g. through extreme gravitational effects). See the material congelation process hierarchy for more.

classDefinition: A material warming process during which the thermal energy in a volume of fluid increases.
parentDefinition: A process during which the temperature of a portion of environmental material is increased, along with the kinetic energy of its constituent molecules.
parentComment: Note that melting need not involve warming (e.g. due to extreme gravitational effects). See the melting hierarchy for more terms.

classDefinition: A process of warming a fluid during which the thermal energy in a volume of gas increases.
parentDefinition: A material warming process during which the thermal energy in a volume of fluid increases.

classDefinition: A process of warming a fluid which includes a volume of liquid as a participant.
parentDefinition: A material warming process during which the thermal energy in a volume of fluid increases.

classDefinition: A material warming process during which the thermal energy in a mass of solid material increases.
parentDefinition: A process during which the temperature of a portion of environmental material is increased, along with the kinetic energy of its constituent molecules.
parentComment: Note that melting need not involve warming (e.g. due to extreme gravitational effects). See the melting hierarchy for more terms.

classDefinition: A fluid astronomical body part which is plume shaped.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of fluid.

classDefinition: A shape that ineres in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's mass being distributed in a feather-like fashion.
parentDefinition: A morphological quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's ratios of distances between its features (points, edges, surfaces and also holes etc).

classDefinition: A downslope katabatic wind which is generated by the cooling of atmospheric gas in contact with terrain surfaces.
parentDefinition: A katabatic wind during which atmospheric gas flows down the slope of an elevation, typically during periods of light larger-scale winds.
classComment: Note that slope winds are typically classed separately from fall winds, which occur at larger scales.
parentComment: "The many synonyms for downslope flow are sometimes used interchangeably, and this gives rise to ambiguity and confusion. Downslope can be used generically to denote any wind flow blowing down a slope, or it is used specifically for katabatic flows on any scale, such as the nocturnal slope-wind component of mountain–valley wind systems or mountain–plains wind systems." Note also that slope winds are typically classed separately from fall winds, which occur at larger scales.

classDefinition: A downslope katabatic wind which is generated by the cooling of atmospheric gas in contact with terrain surfaces.
parentDefinition: A katabatic wind which is driven by the cooling and subsequent sinking of atmospheric gas masses.
classComment: Note that slope winds are typically classed separately from fall winds, which occur at larger scales.

classDefinition: A front which shows very little mobility.
parentDefinition: A gaseous front which separates two masses of air with different densities and is a principal cause of meteorological phenomena.
classComment: "Conventionally, a front that is moving at a speed less than about five knots is generally considered to be quasi-stationary. In synoptic chart analysis, a quasi-stationary front is one that has not moved appreciably from its position on the last previous synoptic chart (three or six hours before)."
parentComment: This class refers to Earth's weather fronts. Other forms, not composed of air, are present on other planets and can be created on request. Note: "Since the temperature distribution is the most important regulator of atmospheric density, a front almost invariably separates air masses of different temperature. Along with the basic density criterion and the common temperature criterion, many other features may distinguish a front, such as a pressure trough, a change in wind direction, a moisture discontinuity, and certain characteristic cloud and precipitation forms."

classDefinition: A drainage wind which flows along the icy surface of a glacier.
parentDefinition: A downslope katabatic wind which is generated by the cooling of atmospheric gas in contact with terrain surfaces.
parentComment: Note that slope winds are typically classed separately from fall winds, which occur at larger scales.

classDefinition: An atmospheric storm during which winds flow with increased rates.
parentDefinition: An atmospheric storm is a process in which a portion of an astronomical body's atmosphere is strongly perturbed from its prevaling weather.

classDefinition: A wind storm during which strong gusts of wind occur, transporting atmospheric gas in a linear fashion.
A downdraft which is of high intensity and which spreads radially, with high speed, across the planetary surface upon reaching it.
parentDefinition: A katabatic wind which is sudden and strong.

classDefinition: A katabatic wind which is sudden and strong.
parentDefinition: An atmospheric wind during which cold atmospheric gas flows downwards towards the surface of an astronomical body.
parentComment: "From its etymology, the term means simply "going down" or "descending," and thus could refer to any descending flow; some authors have further generalized it to include downslope flows such as the foehn or chinook even though they do not represent a flow of cold air. This concept has given rise to the expression katafront, which indicates flow down a sloped cold-frontal surface."

classDefinition: A macroburst during which no or very little rain is generated.
parentDefinition: A downburst during which high winds occur over an area larger than four kilometres in diameter.

classDefinition: A downburst during which high winds occur over an area larger than four kilometres in diameter.
parentDefinition: A downdraft which is of high intensity and which spreads radially, with high speed, across the planetary surface upon reaching it.

classDefinition: A rate which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A quality of a single process inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's occurrence per unit time.

classDefinition: A rate which is relatively low.
parentDefinition: A quality of a process that has a value that is decreased compared to normal or average.

classDefinition: A macroburst during which large amounts of rain are generated.
parentDefinition: A downburst during which high winds occur over an area larger than four kilometres in diameter.

classDefinition: A downburst during which high winds occur over an area less than four kilometres in diameter.
parentDefinition: A downdraft which is of high intensity and which spreads radially, with high speed, across the planetary surface upon reaching it.

classDefinition: A microburst during which large amounts of rain are generated.
parentDefinition: A downburst during which high winds occur over an area less than four kilometres in diameter.

classDefinition: A microburst during which no or very little rain is generated.
parentDefinition: A downburst during which high winds occur over an area less than four kilometres in diameter.

classDefinition: A material transport process during which parts of an elastic material oscillate around their positions of equilibrium.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: A vibration process which occurs in the solid parts of an astronomical body as low-frequency acoustic waves pass through them.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which parts of an elastic material oscillate around their positions of equilibrium.

classDefinition: A seismic vibration process which is caused by a volcanic eruption.
parentDefinition: A vibration process which occurs in the solid parts of an astronomical body as low-frequency acoustic waves pass through them.

classDefinition: A seismic vibration process which is caused by the impact of a solid object on the surface of an astronomical body.
parentDefinition: A vibration process which occurs in the solid parts of an astronomical body as low-frequency acoustic waves pass through them.

classDefinition: A seismic vibration process which is caused by an explosion.
parentDefinition: A vibration process which occurs in the solid parts of an astronomical body as low-frequency acoustic waves pass through them.

classDefinition: A process during which a material entity undergoes a rapid increase in volume, releasing gasses and various forms of energy, often including thermal, light and sound energy.
parentDefinition: Combustion or burning is a high-temperature exothermic redox chemical reaction between a fuel and an oxidant that produces oxidized, often gaseous products, in a mixture termed as smoke.
classComment: Supersonic explosions are known as detonations and subsonic explosions as deflagrations.
parentComment: Unlike the "combustion" class in the Chemical Methods Ontology, this class is not necessarily a planned process. http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/CHMO_0001473

classDefinition: A seismic vibration process which is caused by mass wasting.
parentDefinition: A vibration process which occurs in the solid parts of an astronomical body as low-frequency acoustic waves pass through them.

classDefinition: A seismic vibration process which is caused by the collapose of a material entity, sending kinetic energy into astronomical body.
parentDefinition: A vibration process which occurs in the solid parts of an astronomical body as low-frequency acoustic waves pass through them.

classDefinition: A structural collapse process during which the walls of cave are unable to support the load placed upon them.
parentDefinition: A process during which the ability of a material entity to maintain its internal organisation fails, resulting in deformation and a breakdown of that organisation.
parentComment: This is a very general concept, and should likely be elevated to OBO Core rather than held in ENVO.

classDefinition: A seismic vibration process which is caused by an earthquake.
parentDefinition: A vibration process which occurs in the solid parts of an astronomical body as low-frequency acoustic waves pass through them.

classDefinition: A tectonic earthquake which precedes the strongest tectonic earthquake in a series, linked to the same release of energy in the crust.
parentDefinition: An earthquake caused by the sudden release of energy accumulated in an astronomical body's crust, as the elastic strain placed on constituent rock masses causes them to fracture.

classDefinition: A tectonic earthquake which 1) is embedded in a series of tectonic earthquakes, linked to the same release of energy in the crust and 2) has the largest magnitude of the series.
parentDefinition: An earthquake caused by the sudden release of energy accumulated in an astronomical body's crust, as the elastic strain placed on constituent rock masses causes them to fracture.

classDefinition: A tectonic earthquake which 1) is embedded in a series of tectonic earthquakes, linked to the same release of energy in the crust and 2) occurs after the mainshock.
parentDefinition: An earthquake caused by the sudden release of energy accumulated in an astronomical body's crust, as the elastic strain placed on constituent rock masses causes them to fracture.

classDefinition: A fault across which older rocks are pushed above (away from the core of an astronomical body) younger rocks.
parentDefinition: A geological fault is a planar fracture or discontinuity in a volume of rock, across which there has been significant displacement as a result of rock mass movement.
parentComment: The relationship between faults and active plate boundaries must be further developed, as there is some overlap.

classDefinition: A tectonic earthquake which occurs along a thrust fault which does not breach the surface of an astronomical body.
parentDefinition: An earthquake caused by the sudden release of energy accumulated in an astronomical body's crust, as the elastic strain placed on constituent rock masses causes them to fracture.

classDefinition: A thrust fault which does not breach the surface of an astronomical body.
parentDefinition: A fault across which older rocks are pushed above (away from the core of an astronomical body) younger rocks.

classDefinition: A tectonic earthquake which has two or more mainshocks of similar magnitude, and which originate from the same fracture zone and stress field.
parentDefinition: An earthquake caused by the sudden release of energy accumulated in an astronomical body's crust, as the elastic strain placed on constituent rock masses causes them to fracture.
classComment: The mainshocks may be separated by seconds or years. Mainshocks must be within 1.2 units of magnitude of one another and have nearly identical seismic waveforms.

classDefinition: A tectonic earthquake which occurs at the boundary between two tectonic plates.
parentDefinition: An earthquake caused by the sudden release of energy accumulated in an astronomical body's crust, as the elastic strain placed on constituent rock masses causes them to fracture.

classDefinition: A tectonic earthquake which occurs within the interior parts of a tectonic plate.
parentDefinition: An earthquake caused by the sudden release of energy accumulated in an astronomical body's crust, as the elastic strain placed on constituent rock masses causes them to fracture.

classDefinition: A sea which shalowly covers central areas of continents during periods of high sea level that result in marine transgressions.
parentDefinition: A large expanse of saline water usually connected with an ocean.

classDefinition: A tropical mixed forest in which dominant ecological communities have reached their climax successional state.
parentDefinition: A biome which is subject to tropical climatic conditions.

classDefinition: A tropical mixed forest in which dominant ecological communities have reached their climax successional state.
parentDefinition: A mixed forest in which dominant ecological communities have reached their climax successional state.

classDefinition: A tropical mixed forest in which dominant ecological communities have reached their climax successional state.
parentDefinition: A mixed forest which is subject to tropical climatic conditions.
An ecosystem in which grasses (Graminae) are the dominant form of vegetation and determine the system's structure and dynamics.

classDefinition: Cell culturing is the aseptic maintainance and growth of collections of cells  outside of an organisms or natural environment in a suitable culture medium.
parentDefinition: Tissue culture is the culture of cells, tissues or organs in a nutrient medium under sterile conditions.
parentComment: This branch should be moved to OBI or a more appropriate ontology.

classDefinition: Tissue culture is the culture of cells, tissues or organs in a nutrient medium under sterile conditions.
parentDefinition: A process that realizes a plan which is the concretization of a plan specification.
classComment: This branch should be moved to OBI or a more appropriate ontology.

classDefinition: A biomaterial containment unit which is designed to allow the growth and propagation of the biomaterial it contains.
parentDefinition: A manufactured product which has been designed to contain a mass of biomaterial.

classDefinition: A biomaterial culturing unit which is designed to promote the growth of selected cell populations (often at the expense of others) within a community by altering the conditions of the environment within its confines.
parentDefinition: A biomaterial containment unit which is designed to allow the growth and propagation of the biomaterial it contains.

classDefinition: A biomaterial culturing unit which is designed to promote the growth and propagation of cells in an artificial medium.
parentDefinition: A biomaterial containment unit which is designed to allow the growth and propagation of the biomaterial it contains.
Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.

classDefinition: Sediment through which hydrothermally modified fluids flow, altering its properties through interaction with their own.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is formed as a result of the transport and deposition of particles by flowing liquid.
parentComment: Sediment is typically deposited on the bed or bottom of a body of water or other liquid.

classDefinition: An enrichment culturing unit which contains environmental material bearing ecological assemblages undergoing selection through experimentally imposed conditions.
parentDefinition: A biomaterial culturing unit which is designed to promote the growth of selected cell populations (often at the expense of others) within a community by altering the conditions of the environment within its confines.

classDefinition: A plume which is composed primarily of bubbles.
parentDefinition: A fluid astronomical body part which is plume shaped.

classDefinition: An ecosystem process during which the species composition of an ecosystem gradually changes as species which are more adapted to the prevailing conditions in the ecosystem replace those which are less adapted.
parentDefinition: An environmental process either driven by or primarily impacting the parts or emergent properties of an ecosystem.

classDefinition: An active enrichment culturing unit which contains environmental material maintained under conditions with no free oxygen.
parentDefinition: An enrichment culturing unit which contains environmental material bearing ecological assemblages undergoing selection through experimentally imposed conditions.

classDefinition: An active enrichment culturing unit which contains environmental material maintained under conditions that favour the reduction of sulphate.
parentDefinition: An active enrichment culturing unit which contains environmental material maintained under conditions with no free oxygen.

classDefinition: A biome which is subject to subapline altitudinal conditions.
parentDefinition: A biome is an ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentComment: In this definition, there is an assumption that no major perturbations are occurring or have occurred in a time frame affects the successional dynamics of the ecosystem. A "major" perturbation is one which disrupts the community's ability to restore its (near) equilibrium. Usually, pioneer or early secondary successional processes would be in effect in such scenarios.

classDefinition: A biome which is subject to arid environmental conditions.
parentDefinition: A biome is an ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentComment: In this definition, there is an assumption that no major perturbations are occurring or have occurred in a time frame affects the successional dynamics of the ecosystem. A "major" perturbation is one which disrupts the community's ability to restore its (near) equilibrium. Usually, pioneer or early secondary successional processes would be in effect in such scenarios.

classDefinition: An environment in which living organisms have a low likelihood of being harmed or killed
parentDefinition: An environment in which material entities have a low likelihood of being damaged or destroyed.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a quality
classDefinition: An environment in which material entities have a low likelihood of being damaged or destroyed.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by materials bearing roughly homogeneous qualities.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation.

classDefinition: An environmental process during which momentum is transferred from one material entity to another.
parentDefinition: A process during which one entity loses energy to another entity.
classComment: Momentum is a bit tricky, it's the product of mass and velocity thus can be understood as rest energy and kinetic energy. But this is variable.

classDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's velocity multiplied by its mass.
parentDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's participation in movement.

classDefinition: A momentum transfer process which unfolds as winds generate drag at the bottom of the atmosphere,coupled to dynamical forcing at the surface of the ocean.
parentDefinition: An environmental process during which momentum is transferred from one material entity to another.
parentComment: Momentum is a bit tricky, it's the product of mass and velocity thus can be understood as rest energy and kinetic energy. But this is variable.

classDefinition: A rate which inheres in an atmosphere-ocean momentum transfer process.
parentDefinition: The quality of a environmental system process.

classDefinition: A rate which inheres in an atmosphere-ocean momentum transfer process.
parentDefinition: A quality of a single process inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's occurrence per unit time.

classDefinition: The quality of a environmental system process.
parentDefinition: A quality which inheres in an process.

classDefinition: A quality of a single process inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's occurrence per unit time.
Frost which is composed of interlocking ice crystals formed by vapour transfer (sublimation followed by deposition) of water vapour on some surface.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minute ice crystals forming a fuzzy layer over a cold surface by direct deposition of water vapor.
parentComment: In British usage, a day on which the minimum temperature at the level of the ground or on the tops of low, close-growing vegetation falls to -0.9C (30.4F) or below (also called a "day with ground frost").  In more general usage, "frost" can refer to the condition that exists when the temperature of the Earth's surface and Earthbound objects fall below the melting point of water (0 degrees Celsius or 32 degrees Fahrenheit). Depending upon the actual values of ambient-air temperature, dewpoint, and the temperature attained by surface objects, frost may occur in a variety of forms. These include a general freeze, hoarfrost (or white frost), and dry freeze (or black frost). If a frost period is sufficiently severe to end the growing season (or delay its beginning), it is commonly referred to as a killing frost.

classDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minute ice crystals forming a fuzzy layer over a cold surface by direct deposition of water vapor.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
classComment: In British usage, a day on which the minimum temperature at the level of the ground or on the tops of low, close-growing vegetation falls to -0.9C (30.4F) or below (also called a "day with ground frost").  In more general usage, "frost" can refer to the condition that exists when the temperature of the Earth's surface and Earthbound objects fall below the melting point of water (0 degrees Celsius or 32 degrees Fahrenheit). Depending upon the actual values of ambient-air temperature, dewpoint, and the temperature attained by surface objects, frost may occur in a variety of forms. These include a general freeze, hoarfrost (or white frost), and dry freeze (or black frost). If a frost period is sufficiently severe to end the growing season (or delay its beginning), it is commonly referred to as a killing frost.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: Hoar which is usually cup-shaped and facetted and which forms within dry, low-density snow beneath the snow surface.
parentDefinition: Frost which is composed of interlocking ice crystals formed by vapour transfer (sublimation followed by deposition) of water vapour on some surface.
classComment: Depth hoar is associated with very fast crystal growth under large temperature gradients. Sometimes a layer of depth hoar forms just above, and may assist in identifying the summer surface. The low density and low strength of depth hoar can make it difficult to retrieve unbroken core sections during coring, and can complicate estimates of accumulation by microwave remote sensing. Layers of depth hoar also increase the likelihood of avalanching. This is one way in which firn formation may begin. Depth hoar is similar in physical origin to crevasse hoar.

parentDefinition: Frost which is composed of interlocking ice crystals formed by vapour transfer (sublimation followed by deposition) of water vapour on some surface.

classDefinition: Water ice which 1) has a white or milky and opaque appearance, 2) has a granular texture, and 3) is formed as a result of the deposition and rapid freezing of supercooled water drops as they make contact with an exposed object.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minute ice crystals forming a fuzzy layer over a cold surface by direct deposition of water vapor.
classComment: Rime is denser and harder than hoarfrost, but lighter, softer, and less transparent than glaze. Rime is composed essentially of discrete ice granules and has densities as low as 0.2-0.3 g cm-3. Glaze is generally continuous but with some air pockets and has much higher densities. Factors that favor rime formation are small drop size, slow accretion, a high degree of supercooling, and rapid dissipation of latent heat of fusion. The opposite effects favor glaze formation. Both rime and glaze occur when supercooled water drops strike an object at a temperature below freezing. Such formation on terrestrial objects constitutes an ice storm; on aircraft, it is called aircraft icing (where rime is known as rime ice). Either rime or glaze may form on snow crystals, droxtals, or other ice particles in the atmosphere. When such a deposit is wholly or chiefly of rime, snow pellets result; when most or all of the deposit is glaze, ordinary hail or ice pellets result. The alternating clear and opaque layers of some hailstones represent glaze and rime, deposited under varying conditions around the growing hailstone.
parentComment: In British usage, a day on which the minimum temperature at the level of the ground or on the tops of low, close-growing vegetation falls to -0.9C (30.4F) or below (also called a "day with ground frost").  In more general usage, "frost" can refer to the condition that exists when the temperature of the Earth's surface and Earthbound objects fall below the melting point of water (0 degrees Celsius or 32 degrees Fahrenheit). Depending upon the actual values of ambient-air temperature, dewpoint, and the temperature attained by surface objects, frost may occur in a variety of forms. These include a general freeze, hoarfrost (or white frost), and dry freeze (or black frost). If a frost period is sufficiently severe to end the growing season (or delay its beginning), it is commonly referred to as a killing frost.

parentDefinition: Frost which is composed of interlocking ice crystals formed by vapour transfer (sublimation followed by deposition) of water vapour on some surface.

classDefinition: A positional quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer being located in the vicinity of - but not adjacent to or within - a glacier or ice sheet.
parentDefinition: A spatial quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's spatial location relative to other objects in the vicinity.

classDefinition: A geothermally active field within which geothermally heated aqueous fluids are discharged from the the surface of a rocky planet.
parentDefinition: A field in which geothermal processes occur.
classComment: Hydrothermal activity in such fields often forming hot springs, geysers or other features at which anomalously hot water is released.
parentComment: In many geothermally active fields, wells can be drilled to obtain elements contained in solution in hot brines or to tap heat energy.

classDefinition: An infrared radiation process which 1) transmits radiant energy has wavelengths between 3.0 and 100 μm, 2) is emitted from a planet and its atmosphere out to space in the form of thermal radiation.
parentDefinition: A radiation process during which electromagnetic waves or their quanta are emitted when molecules change their rotational-vibrational movements, usually at wavelengths between 760 nm and 1 mm.
classComment: In the Earth's climate system, long-wave radiation involves processes of absorption, scattering, and emissions from atmospheric gases, aerosols, clouds and the surface.

classDefinition: An area density which inheres in a clouds by virtue of some influence exerted their mass exerts on a given area.
parentDefinition: A density quality which inheres in a bearer by virtue of some influence exerted by the bearer's mass on a given area.
classComment: Positioning under area density may need discussion.

classDefinition: A density quality which inheres in a bearer by virtue of some influence exerted by the bearer's mass on a given area.
parentDefinition: A physical quality which inheres in a bearer by virtue of some influence is exerted by the bearer's mass per unit size.

classDefinition: A temperature of air at which air become saturated with water vapour and below which airborne water vapour will condense to form liquid water (dew).
parentDefinition: The temperature of some air.

classDefinition: The temperature of some air.
parentDefinition: The temperature of some environmental material.

classDefinition: An atmospheric wind which 1) has an increased rate relative to other winds in the same region and 2) is followed by a lull.
classComment: According to U.S. weather observing practice, gusts are reported when the peak wind speed reaches at least 16 knots and the variation in wind speed between the peaks and lulls is at least 9 knots. The duration of a gust is usually less than 20 seconds.

classDefinition: An electromagnetic radiation process during which radiant energy with wavelengths in the visible, near-ultraviolet, or near-infrared spectra is realised.
parentDefinition: A radiation process during which waves (or their quanta, photons) of the electromagnetic field propagate (radiate) through space carrying electromagnetic energy.
classComment: There is no standard cut-off for the near-infrared range; therefore, the shortwave radiation range is also variously defined. It may be broadly defined to include all radiation with a wavelength of 0.1 micrometers and 5.0 micrometers or narrowly defined so as to include only radiation between 0.2 micrometers and 3.0 micrometers.
parentComment: Note that this class is concerned only with active radiative processes: static electric and magnetic fields are not inlcuded. All electromagnetic radiation carries radiant energy.

classDefinition: Electromagnetic radidation which involves radiant energy in a spectral range (wave band) between 400 to 700 nanometers, that photosynthetic organisms are able to use in the process of photosynthesis.
parentDefinition: A radiation process during which waves (or their quanta, photons) of the electromagnetic field propagate (radiate) through space carrying electromagnetic energy.
classComment: Many definitions specify that this is Solar radiation, but consistency is lacking.
parentComment: Note that this class is concerned only with active radiative processes: static electric and magnetic fields are not inlcuded. All electromagnetic radiation carries radiant energy.

classLabel: concentration of carbon dioxide in an atmosphere
classDefinition: The concentration of carbon dioxide when measured in air that is part of an atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a substance by virtue of the amount of the bearer's there is mixed with another substance.

classDefinition: A quality inhering in a substance by virtue of the amount of the bearer's there is mixed with another substance.
parentDefinition: A quality which inheres in a molecular entity, a single molecule, atom, ion, radical etc.

classDefinition: A planned process during which an oil or gas well is modified.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which is driven by the action of humans.
classComment: Interventions may change state of the well or well geometry, provide well diagnostics, or manage the production of the well.

classDefinition: A planned process during which an oil or gas well is modified.
parentDefinition: A process that realizes a plan which is the concretization of a plan specification.
classComment: Interventions may change state of the well or well geometry, provide well diagnostics, or manage the production of the well.

classDefinition: A well which has been drilled in order to extract natrual gas from subterranean reservoirs and bring it to the surface.
parentDefinition: A cylindrical hole, pit, or tunnel drilled or dug down to a depth from which water, oil, or gas can be pumped or brought to the surface.

classDefinition: A well intervention during which the production of an oil or gas well is increased by improving the flow of hydrocarbons from the reservoir into the well bore.
parentDefinition: A planned process during which an oil or gas well is modified.
parentComment: Interventions may change state of the well or well geometry, provide well diagnostics, or manage the production of the well.

classDefinition: A well stimulation technique during which bedrock formations are fractured through the injection of pressurized proppant-bearing liquid into a well-bore.
parentDefinition: A well intervention during which the production of an oil or gas well is increased by improving the flow of hydrocarbons from the reservoir into the well bore.
classComment: When the hydraulic pressure is removed from the well, small grains of hydraulic fracturing proppants (either sand or aluminium oxide) hold the fractures open.

classDefinition: A liquid environmental material which is composed primarily of water ammended with thickening agents and proppants.
parentDefinition: Anthropogenic material in or on which organisms may live.

classDefinition: A liquid environmental material which is composed primarily of water ammended with thickening agents and proppants.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a liquid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: most of its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: A liquid environmental material which is composed primarily of water ammended with thickening agents and proppants.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A pit which is used for the collection and storage of manure.
parentDefinition: A depression in the ground resembling a hole or cavity, either natural or anthropogenic.

classDefinition: A hatchery in which the eggs of poultry are hatched under artificial conditions.
parentDefinition: A construction in which eggs are hatched under artificial conditions.

classDefinition: A debris flow which is causally preceded by rainfall.
parentDefinition: A mass wasting flow during which water-laden masses of soil and fragmented rock rush down the slopes of elevations, funnel into stream channels, entrain objects in their paths, and form thick, muddy deposits on valley floors.

classDefinition: A transient tracer role which inheres in chemical entities in seawater.
classComment: Compounds which realise this role can be used in the ocean to quantify ventilation, transit time distribution and  transport time-scales.  These compounds are all conservative in seawater, or have well-defined decay functions, and a well-established source function over time at the ocean surface.

classDefinition: A positional quality which inheres in a bearer by virtue of the bearer in being in physical contact with, or close to, a glacial margin.
parentDefinition: A spatial quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's spatial location relative to other objects in the vicinity.
classComment: The meaning of "close to" is hard to represent accurately. Community agreement on this is not visible.

classDefinition: A positional quality which inheres in a bearer by virtue of the bearer in being in physical contact with or below a glacial bed.
parentDefinition: A spatial quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's spatial location relative to other objects in the vicinity.
classComment: The lower bound of "below" is ambiguous.

classDefinition: A positional quality which inheres in a bearer by virtue of the bearer in being in physical contact with the upper surface of a glacier or objects on top of the glacier.
parentDefinition: A spatial quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's spatial location relative to other objects in the vicinity.
classComment: The lower bound of "below" is ambiguous.

classDefinition: Hoar which a) forms on surfaces, b) occurs when the temperature of the surface is colder than the air above and colder than the frost point of that air.
parentDefinition: Frost which is composed of interlocking ice crystals formed by vapour transfer (sublimation followed by deposition) of water vapour on some surface.
classComment: When buried by snowfall, surface hoar may be considered depth hoar. The crystals formed by surface hoar are usually leaf-, fern- or plate-shaped and facetted. Two types of surface hoar are the fernlike ice crystals deposited directly on a snow surface and the hoarfrost that has grown primarily in two dimensions, as on a window or other smooth surface.

classDefinition: A water ice crystal which is a part of a deposit of hoarfrost and which only grows by desublimation.
parentDefinition: A crystal which is primarily composed of water ice.
parentComment: Any one of a number of macroscopic, crystalline forms in which ice appears, including hexagonal columns, hexagonal platelets, dendritic crystals, ice needles, and combinations of these forms.  The crystal lattice of ice is hexagonal in its symmetry under most atmospheric conditions.

classDefinition: A paper product which has been manufactured to facilitate the writing of letters.
parentDefinition: A product which is composed primarily of paper.

classDefinition: A mineral spring through which water with elevated concentrations of lithium salts flows.
parentDefinition: A spring which  water contains a significant amount of dissolved minerals, that derive from the rocks through which the water flows.

classDefinition: A spring through which water with elevated concentrations of iron salts flows.
parentDefinition: A spring which  water contains a significant amount of dissolved minerals, that derive from the rocks through which the water flows.

classDefinition: A spring through which water with elevated concentrations of hydrated double sulfate aluminium salts flows.
parentDefinition: A spring which  water contains a significant amount of dissolved minerals, that derive from the rocks through which the water flows.

classDefinition: A mineral spring through which water with elevated concentrations of sodium, calcium, or magnesium salts flows.
parentDefinition: A spring which  water contains a significant amount of dissolved minerals, that derive from the rocks through which the water flows.

classDefinition: A mineral spring through which water with elevated levels of dissolved carbon dioxide gas flows.
parentDefinition: A spring which  water contains a significant amount of dissolved minerals, that derive from the rocks through which the water flows.

classDefinition: A mineral spring through which water with elevated levels of radioactive material flows.
parentDefinition: A spring which  water contains a significant amount of dissolved minerals, that derive from the rocks through which the water flows.

classDefinition: A vehicle designed to fly in outer space.
parentDefinition: A vehicle is a mobile machine which transports people or cargo.

classDefinition: A disposition of a material entity which is realised when it is saturated with liquid water.
A one-dimensional temporal region which spans the duration an astronomical body completes one rotation on its axis.
A day during which water-based rainfall occurs.
parentDefinition: A one-dimensional temporal region which spans the duration an astronomical body completes one rotation on its axis.
classComment: The threshold of precipitation at which humans consider a day 'rainy' is aribitrary.

classDefinition: Percolation during which water moves through the interstices of soil.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which a volume of liquid water is transported due to a disequilibria in physical forces.

classDefinition: Percolation during which water moves through the interstices of soil.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which a fluid is filtered through porous soild or semi-solid materials.
parentComment: This is not necessarily advective, and the properties of and processes participated in by the fluid may change.

classDefinition: A material transport process during which a fluid is filtered through porous soild or semi-solid materials.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
classComment: This is not necessarily advective, and the properties of and processes participated in by the fluid may change.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: A water infiltration process during which water fills the pore space and interstices of soil.
parentDefinition: A water flow process during which water occupies the pores or interstices of a solid or semi-solid material.

classDefinition: A material transport process during which a liquid which is not absorbed or otherwise held in place by a material is transported away from its location.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
classComment: Drainage may occur due to natural (e.g. gravitational) or artificial processes (e.g. pumping)
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: A physical quality of a process which is characteristic of processes that transport material within a volume due to the combined effects of material property heterogeneity and body forces across that volume.

parentDefinition: A quality which inheres in an process.

classDefinition: An energy transfer process during which a material entity receives energy through radiation.
parentDefinition: A process during which one entity loses energy to another entity.
classComment: The term irradiation usually - but not always - excludes the exposure to non-ionizing radiation, such as infrared, visible light, microwaves from cellular phones or electromagnetic waves emitted by radio and TV receivers and power supplies. Please use the subclasses of this term for precision.

classDefinition: Irradiation during which a material entity receives energy through ionizing radiation.
parentDefinition: An energy transfer process during which a material entity receives energy through radiation.
classComment: Usage of this term typically excludes low or background levels of exposure, and is often linked with a purpose such as sterilisation. This class does not differentiate on such a basis, and subclasses - e.g. "irradiation by ionizing radiation for sterilization" can be created for specific applications if required.
parentComment: The term irradiation usually - but not always - excludes the exposure to non-ionizing radiation, such as infrared, visible light, microwaves from cellular phones or electromagnetic waves emitted by radio and TV receivers and power supplies. Please use the subclasses of this term for precision.

classDefinition: Irradiation during which a material entity receives energy through non-ionizing radiation.
parentDefinition: An energy transfer process during which a material entity receives energy through radiation.
classComment: Note that some forms of ultraviolet radiation can be ionising, thus it is not included in the logical axioms of this class.
parentComment: The term irradiation usually - but not always - excludes the exposure to non-ionizing radiation, such as infrared, visible light, microwaves from cellular phones or electromagnetic waves emitted by radio and TV receivers and power supplies. Please use the subclasses of this term for precision.

classDefinition: Irradiation during which a material entity receives energy through photosynthetically active radiation.
parentDefinition: Irradiation during which a material entity receives energy through non-ionizing radiation.
parentComment: Note that some forms of ultraviolet radiation can be ionising, thus it is not included in the logical axioms of this class.

classDefinition: Wave energy which inheres in perpendicular electric and magnetic fields and which is realised when they oscillate and propagate.
parentDefinition: Energy which inheres in a wave and is realised during its propagation.

classDefinition: Energy which inheres in a wave and is realised during its propagation.
parentDefinition: A disposition which is realized during the execution of work, the emission of heat, or the possession of mass.
parentComment: Consider replacing with PATO class; note that PATO class is not a disposition. This should likely go into OBO Core and also have a physicist look at it.

classDefinition: A gaseous part of an atmosphere in which gases have increased atmospheric pressure.
parentDefinition: That part of an atmosphere which is composed of gaseous material.
classComment: Air is not specified directly (although the definition subsumes air masses) to allow for other forms of low pressure areas in planetary atmospheres.

classDefinition: A hypodermic needle is a medical instrument made from a hollow needle. It is commonly used with a syringe to inject substances into the body of an organism.
parentDefinition: A manufactured product which has been designed for use in one or more medical procedures.

classDefinition: A textile is a manufactured product comprised of a network of natural or artificial fibers (often referred to as thread or yarn).
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: Bedclothing is a textile covering used on a bed as a sheet, blanket, or pillowcase.
parentDefinition: A textile is a manufactured product comprised of a network of natural or artificial fibers (often referred to as thread or yarn).

classDefinition: A pockmark field is an undersea feature formed by shallow seabed depressions, typically several tens of metres across and a few metres deep. Generally, they are formed in soft, fine-grained seabed sediments by the escape of fluids (gas or water, but mainly methane) into the water column.
parentDefinition: An unbroken expanse (as of ice)
parentComment: This class was created to accommodate "fields" from agricultural fields to marine mesoscale eddy fields. Thus, it has a very broad definition which makes it less than informative when annotating. Please consider using or requesting an appropriate subclass.

classDefinition: Nesting material is an animal habitation consisting of matierals used to cushion, insulate and protect the young of the organism. The adult will use the material to form a protective structure to house and raise their young. Nests are built primarily by birds, but also by mammals, fish, insects and reptiles.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: Nesting material is an animal habitation consisting of matierals used to cushion, insulate and protect the young of the organism. The adult will use the material to form a protective structure to house and raise their young. Nests are built primarily by birds, but also by mammals, fish, insects and reptiles.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: Plant tissue culture is the growth or maintenance of plant cells, tissues, organs or whole plants in vitro.
parentDefinition: Tissue culture is the culture of cells, tissues or organs in a nutrient medium under sterile conditions.
parentComment: This branch should be moved to OBI or a more appropriate ontology.

classDefinition: Organ culture is the aseptic culture of complete living organs of animals and plants outside the body in a suitable culture medium. Animal organs must be small enough to allow the nutrients in the culture medium to penetrate all the cells.
parentDefinition: Tissue culture is the culture of cells, tissues or organs in a nutrient medium under sterile conditions.
parentComment: This branch should be moved to OBI or a more appropriate ontology.

classDefinition: The yellow or brown waxy secretions produced by vestigial apocrine sweat glands in the external ear canal[MESH].
parentDefinition: Secretion produced by a sweat gland.

classDefinition: A bodily fluid material which is composed primarily of blood, a bodily fluid composed of blood plasma and blood cells suspended within the plasma that circulates around the organism's body. Blood performs may important functions including the supplying of oxygen and nutrients, removal of waste, circulation of white blood cells, detection of antibodes, coagulation, transportation of antibodies and the regulation of pH and body temperature.
classComment: ENVO bodily fluid classes differ from UBERON's treatment of bodily fluids. UBERON refers to the substance itself ("S"). We assert that UBERON's classes are the primary compositional component of the terms in ENVO ("S material"). Use of the ENVO terms is typically recommended when you wish to indicate that there may be other materials intermixed with S.

classDefinition: A bodily fluid material which is composed primarily of blood, a bodily fluid composed of blood plasma and blood cells suspended within the plasma that circulates around the organism's body. classDefinition: A bodily fluid material which is composed primarily of amniotic fluid, a bodily fluid consisting of watery liquid surrounding and cushioning a growing fetus within the amnion. classDefinition: Amniotic fluid is a bodily fluid consisting of watery liquid surrounding and cushioning a growing fetus within the amnion. It allows the fetus to move freely without the walls of the uterus being too tight against its body. Buoyancy is also provided. The composition of the fluid changes over the course of gestation. Initially, amniotic fluid is similar to maternal plasma, mainly water with electrolytes. As the fetus develops, proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, phospholipids originating from the lungs, fetal cells, and urea are deposited in the fluid.
