classDefinition: A portion of organism substance that is the product of an excretion process that will be eliminated from the body. An excretion process is elimination by an organism of the waste products that arise as a result of metabolic activity.

Use of the ENVO terms is typically recommended when you wish to indicate that there may be other materials intermixed with S.
parentComment: ENVO bodily fluid classes differ from UBERON's treatment of bodily fluids. UBERON refers to the substance itself ("S"). We assert that UBERON's classes are the primary compositional component of the terms in ENVO ("S material"). Use of the ENVO terms is typically recommended when you wish to indicate that there may be other materials intermixed with S.

classDefinition: Interstitial fluid is a bodily fluid consisting of a solution which bathes and surrounds the cells of multicellular animals. It is the main component of the extracellular fluid, which also includes plasma and transcellular fluid.
parentDefinition: Material anatomical entity in a gaseous, liquid, semisolid or solid state; produced by anatomical structures or derived from inhaled and ingested substances that have been modified by anatomical structures as they pass through the body.

classDefinition: A biological product is an environmental substrate comprised of any virus, therapeutic serum, toxin, antitoxin, or analogous product available to prevent, treat or cure diseases or injuries in man.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.
classComment: This definition should be revised, it is currently too ambiguous.

classDefinition: Siliceous ooze is a marine sediment composed of the debris of plankton with silica shells, such as diatoms and radiolaria. This ooze is limited to areas with high biological productivity, such as the polar oceans, and upwelling zones near the equator. The least common type of sediment, it covers only 15% of the ocean floor. It accumulates at a slower rate than calcareous ooze: 0.2-1 cm / 1000 yr.
parentDefinition: Biogenous sediment is derived from living organisms, typically planktonic organisms possessing shells, frustules or coccoliths.

classDefinition: Red clay, also known as pelagic clay, accumulates in the deepest and most remote areas of the ocean. Containing less than 30% biogenic material, its composition is a varied mix of very fine quartz and clay minerals, authigenic deposits precipitated directly from seawater, and micrometeorites. Though called "red" because it sometimes takes the color of oxidized iron minerals, it is usually brownish in color. Its ultimate origin is uncertain, but red clay seems to be mostly derived from distant rivers, and windblown dust. Covering 38% of the ocean floor, it accumulates more slowly than any other sediment type, at only 0.1-0.5 cm / 1000 yr.
parentDefinition: Biogenous sediment is derived from living organisms, typically planktonic organisms possessing shells, frustules or coccoliths.

classDefinition: Calcareous ooze is a marine sediment composed primarily of the shells--also known as tests--of foraminifera, coccolithophores, and pteropods. This is the most common pelagic sediment by area, covering 48% of the world ocean's floor. This type of ooze is limited to depths above the Carbonate Compensation Depth at time of burial. It accumulates more rapidly than any other pelagic sediment type, with a rate that varies from 0.3 - 5 cm / 1000 yr.
parentDefinition: Biogenous sediment is derived from living organisms, typically planktonic organisms possessing shells, frustules or coccoliths.

classDefinition: Food material which can be used to meet nutritional requirements of animals, particularly livestock such as cattle, goats, sheep, horses, chickens and pigs.
parentDefinition: Any substance that can be consumed by an organism to satisfy nutritional or other health needs, or to provide a social or organoleptic food experience
classComment: Most animal feed is from plants but some is of animal origin. Fodder refers particularly to food given to the animals (including plants cut and carried to them), rather than that which they forage for themselves. It includes hay, straw, silage, compressed and pelleted feeds, oils and mixed rations, and also sprouted grains and legumes.
parentComment: This class is the top of FOODON's main food product hierarchy which is described in the https://www.foodon.org website, and can be searched in lookup services like https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/

classDefinition: Any substance that can be consumed by an organism to satisfy nutritional or other health needs, or to provide a social or organoleptic food experience
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: This class is the top of FOODON's main food product hierarchy which is described in the https://www.foodon.org website, and can be searched in lookup services like https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: Any substance that can be consumed by an organism to satisfy nutritional or other health needs, or to provide a social or organoleptic food experience
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: This class is the top of FOODON's main food product hierarchy which is described in the https://www.foodon.org website, and can be searched in lookup services like https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: Contaminated animal feed is an animal feed that has become contaminated with or come contact with microorganisms or toxic chemicals.
parentDefinition: Food material which can be used to meet nutritional requirements of animals, particularly livestock such as cattle, goats, sheep, horses, chickens and pigs.
parentComment: Most animal feed is from plants but some is of animal origin. Fodder refers particularly to food given to the animals (including plants cut and carried to them), rather than that which they forage for themselves. It includes hay, straw, silage, compressed and pelleted feeds, oils and mixed rations, and also sprouted grains and legumes.

classDefinition: A canopy designed to protect against precipitation or sunlight.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A skin obtained from animals for human use typically from deer or cattle sources used to produce leather, shoes, fashion accessories, musical instruments.
parentComment: This is quite odd and it probably should be obsoleted. Any material that is a participant in an agricultural process can be seen as an agricultural material.

classDefinition: A mixture of crushed and coarsely ground bones that is used as an organic fertilizer for plants and formerly in animal feed.
parentDefinition: Food material which can be used to meet nutritional requirements of plants.

classDefinition: Food material which can be used to meet nutritional requirements of plants.
parentDefinition: Any substance that can be consumed by an organism to satisfy nutritional or other health needs, or to provide a social or organoleptic food experience
parentComment: This class is the top of FOODON's main food product hierarchy which is described in the https://www.foodon.org website, and can be searched in lookup services like https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/

classDefinition: A textile comprised of a pliable material made usually by weaving, felting, or knitting natural or synthetic fibers and filaments.
parentDefinition: A textile is a manufactured product comprised of a network of natural or artificial fibers (often referred to as thread or yarn).

classDefinition: A soil consisting of the upper layer of soil on the surface consisting of loose material capable of supporting life composed of a mixture of mineral and organic matter.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
parentComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

" The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm."  Soil taxonomy, 2nd Ed., quoted in http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/edu/?cid=nrcs142p2_054280

classDefinition: A written message from one person to another addressed to a person or organization.
parentDefinition: A generically dependent continuant that is about some thing.

classDefinition: A generically dependent continuant that is about some thing.
parentDefinition: A continuant that is dependent on one or other independent continuant bearers. For every instance of A requires some instance of (an independent continuant type) B but which instance of B serves can change from time to time.

classDefinition: A generically dependent continuant that is about some thing.
parentDefinition: b is a generically dependent continuant = Def. b is a continuant that g-depends_on one or more other entities. (axiom label in BFO2 Reference: [074-001])
Manure which is derived from the waste products of animals.
parentComment: This is interesting in that the "role" aspect of "waste" is (or can be) replaced by another role "fertilizer". Thus, the positioning of "manure" under waste may not be totally correct.

parentDefinition: An excavation in the Earth for the purpose of extracting earth materials.
a type of rock that contains sufficient minerals with important elements including metals that can be economically extracted from the rock.
An excavation in the Earth for the purpose of extracting earth materials.

classDefinition: Ore which contains uranium.
parentDefinition: a type of rock that contains sufficient minerals with important elements including metals that can be economically extracted from the rock.
classComment: The primary uranium ore mineral is uraninite

classDefinition: a type of rock that contains sufficient minerals with important elements including metals that can be economically extracted from the rock.
parentDefinition: A rock is a naturally occurring solid aggregate of one or more minerals or mineraloids.
parentComment: From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ [A mineral] is different from a rock, which can be an aggregate of minerals or non-minerals and does not have a specific chemical composition. The exact definition of a mineral is under debate, especially with respect to the requirement a valid species be abiogenic, and to a lesser extent with regards to it having an ordered atomic structure.

classDefinition: Dust which is derived from coal.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material with diameters less than 500 micrometers.
parentComment: Dust occurs in and may be deposited from the atmosphere.

classDefinition: Dust which is composed of fibrous material.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material with diameters less than 500 micrometers.
parentComment: Dust occurs in and may be deposited from the atmosphere.

parentDefinition: Dust which is composed of fibrous material.

classDefinition: Dust which is composed primarily of some metallic material.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material with diameters less than 500 micrometers.
parentComment: Dust occurs in and may be deposited from the atmosphere.

parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material with diameters less than 500 micrometers.
parentComment: Dust occurs in and may be deposited from the atmosphere.

classDefinition: Dust which is derived from clay material.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material with diameters less than 500 micrometers.
parentComment: Dust occurs in and may be deposited from the atmosphere.

parentDefinition: Dust which is composed of fibrous material.
classComment: Dust which is derived from asbestos

classDefinition: Dust that comes from grain and all the other substances associated with its cultivation & harvesting.

parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material with diameters less than 500 micrometers.
parentComment: Dust occurs in and may be deposited from the atmosphere.

parentDefinition: a type of rock that contains sufficient minerals with important elements including metals that can be economically extracted from the rock.

classDefinition: A gas, smoke, or vapor that smells strongly or is dangerous to inhale.
parentDefinition: A material entity which is composed of one or more chemical entities and has neither independent shape nor volume but tends to expand indefinitely.
A gas, smoke, or vapor that smells strongly or is dangerous to inhale.
A gas, smoke, or vapor that smells strongly or is dangerous to inhale.

classDefinition: A white or colourless soft solid derivable from petroleum, coal or oil shale, that consists of a mixture of hydrocarbon molecules containing between twenty and forty carbon atoms.
parentDefinition: A wax is an environmental material which is primarily composed of lipids or other organic compounds that consist of long alkyl chains. Waxes are are malleable near ambient temperatures and melt at approximately 45 degrees Celsius.

classDefinition: Respirable vapor of vanadium.
parentDefinition: A gas, smoke, or vapor that smells strongly or is dangerous to inhale.

classDefinition: A wax that is naturally synthesized by a plant or animal.
parentDefinition: A wax is an environmental material which is primarily composed of lipids or other organic compounds that consist of long alkyl chains. Waxes are are malleable near ambient temperatures and melt at approximately 45 degrees Celsius.

classDefinition: An organic-rich fine-grained sedimentary rock containing kerogen from which liquid hydrocarbons called shale oil can be produced.
parentDefinition: A fine-grained sedimentary rock whose original constituents were clays or muds. It is characterized by thin laminae breaking with an irregular curving fracture, often splintery and usually parallel to the often-indistinguishable bedding plane.
A gas, smoke, or vapor that smells strongly or is dangerous to inhale.
A planned process during which a portion of environmental material is removed from a material entity.
parentComment: Created for SDGIO and intended to be a more general form of resource extraction process.

parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: A drainage process during which water is transported away from peat.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which a volume of liquid water is transported due to a disequilibria in physical forces.

classDefinition: A drainage process during which water is transported away from peat.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which a liquid which is not absorbed or otherwise held in place by a material is transported away from its location.
parentComment: Drainage may occur due to natural (e.g. gravitational) or artificial processes (e.g. pumping)

classDefinition: Any liquid, liquefiable, or mastic composition that, after application to a substrate in a thin layer, converts to a solid film. It is most commonly used to protect, color, or provide texture to objects.
parentDefinition: Anthropogenic material in or on which organisms may live.

classDefinition: Any liquid, liquefiable, or mastic composition that, after application to a substrate in a thin layer, converts to a solid film. It is most commonly used to protect, color, or provide texture to objects.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a liquid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: most of its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: Paint that contains lead.
parentDefinition: Any liquid, liquefiable, or mastic composition that, after application to a substrate in a thin layer, converts to a solid film. It is most commonly used to protect, color, or provide texture to objects.

classDefinition: A planned process that is the movement of people, animals and goods from one location to another.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: the residue powder that is derived from the combustion of wood.
parentDefinition: An environmental material that is the non-aqueous, non-gaseous residues that remain after something is burned.

classDefinition: Ash that is produced from the burning of coal.
parentDefinition: An environmental material that is the non-aqueous, non-gaseous residues that remain after something is burned.

classDefinition: A very fine, powdery material composed mostly of silica made from the burning of finely ground coal in a boiler.
parentDefinition: Ash that is produced from the burning of coal.

classDefinition: a coarse, angular ash particle that is too large to be carried up into the smoke stacks so it forms in the bottom of the coal furnace.
parentDefinition: Ash that is produced from the burning of coal.

classDefinition: molten bottom ash from slag tap and cyclone type furnaces that turns into pellets that have a smooth glassy appearance after it is cooled with water.
parentDefinition: Ash that is produced from the burning of coal.

classDefinition: a material leftover from the process of reducing sulfur dioxide emissions from a coal-fired boiler that can be a wet sludge consisting of calcium sulfite or calcium sulfate or a dry powered material that is a mixture of sulfites and sulfates.
parentDefinition: Ash that is produced from the burning of coal.

classDefinition: A human construction which serves as a memorial.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.
classComment: Monuments can commemorate people, animals, populations, events, or any other entity.

classDefinition: A human construction which is used to initiate and control a fission nuclear chain reaction or nuclear fusion reactions.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: A nuclear reactor which uses a neutron moderator to slow neutrons until they approach the average kinetic energy of the surrounding particles.
parentDefinition: A nuclear reactor which is used as a source of power.

classDefinition: A nuclear reactor in which the fission chain reaction is sustained by fast neutrons.
parentDefinition: A nuclear reactor which is used as a source of power.
classComment: Fast neutrons are neutrons carrying energies above 0.5 MeV or greater, on average. They are defined as in opposition to thermal neutrons used in thermal-neutron reactors.

classDefinition: A nuclear reactor which serves primarily as a neutron source for purposes other than power.
parentDefinition: A human construction which is used to initiate and control a fission nuclear chain reaction or nuclear fusion reactions.
classComment: An example use of a research nucelar reactor is the production of radioisotopes for medicine and industry

classDefinition: A nuclear reactor which serves primarily as a neutron source for purposes other than power.
parentDefinition: A human construction which is used to initiate and control a fission nuclear chain reaction or nuclear fusion reactions.
classComment: Research reactors are simpler than power reactors and operate at lower temperatures. They need far less fuel, and far less fission products build up as the fuel is used

classDefinition: Soil which is located in a mangrove biome.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
classComment: Mangrove soils are typically saline, anoxic, acidic and frequently waterlogged.
parentComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

" The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm."  Soil taxonomy, 2nd Ed., quoted in http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/edu/?cid=nrcs142p2_054280

classDefinition: A spring that is located in the desert.
parentDefinition: A surface landform which provides an egress for groundwater or steam to flow out of the ground.
parentComment: Springs are typically where an aquifer surface meets the ground surface or where there is a fissure.

classDefinition: A human construction which is used to process materials into forms that have increased value or utility in downstream processes.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: A planned material transformation process which takes as input a material and removes impurities.
parentDefinition: A planned process which has the intention of producing, consuming, or transforming materials via the execution of chemical reactions.

classDefinition: A refinery which is capable of processing petroleum oil.
parentDefinition: A human construction which is used to process materials into forms that have increased value or utility in downstream processes.
classComment: Petroleum processing is an industrial process  in which crude oil is transformed and refined into useful products such as petroleum naphtha, gasoline, diesel fuel, asphalt base, heating oil, kerosene, liquefied petroleum gas, jet fuel and fuel oils.

classDefinition: A refinery which is capable of processing raw sugar. Raw sugar is processed from cane or beets into white refined sugar.
parentDefinition: A human construction which is used to process materials into forms that have increased value or utility in downstream processes.

classDefinition: A broad term that includes the nutritive sweeteners dextrose, fructose, galactose, lactose, maltose and sucrose, which are simple carbohydrates with molecules composed of one or two saccharide units. Note that on a product label or in a recipe, 'sugar' means *SUCROSE* and should be so indexed. Use the broad term *SUGAR* only if the specific sugar used is not known or not listed in the vocabulary.
parentDefinition: Extract, concentrate or isolate high in sugar, oligosaccharide or polysaccharide.

classDefinition: A refinery which is capable of processing natural gas. Natural-gas processing encompasses a range of industrial processes designed to purify raw natural gas by removing impurities, contaminants and higher molecular mass hydrocarbons to produce what is known as pipeline quality dry natural gas
parentDefinition: A human construction which is used to process materials into forms that have increased value or utility in downstream processes.

classDefinition: A lake underneath the surface of the Earth.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: A lake underneath the surface of the Earth.
parentDefinition: Water which has physicochemical properties determined by processes which occur beneath the planetary crust.
parentComment: This class references any water that's under a planetary surface. For water that is in an aquifer, see "groundwater" (ENVO:01001004). Previously, this class included both.

classDefinition: A planned process which has the intention of producing, consuming, or transforming materials via the execution of chemical reactions.
parentDefinition: A process that realizes a plan which is the concretization of a plan specification.

classDefinition: A chemical engineering process that produces ammonia en masse via artificial nitrogen fixation.
parentDefinition: A planned process which has the intention of producing, consuming, or transforming materials via the execution of chemical reactions.
classComment: This process is the primary synthetic means of producing fertilizer

classDefinition: A chemical engineering process which generates hydrogen gas.
parentDefinition: A planned process which has the intention of producing, consuming, or transforming materials via the execution of chemical reactions.

classDefinition: A mineral deposit that contains uranium ore.
parentDefinition: A mineral deposit is a physiographic feature which has unusually high concentrations of one or more minerals.
parentComment: Note that the definition of the term mineral is debatable; however, a mineral generally must be naturally occuring, stable at room temperature, representable by a chemical formula (unlike rocks, which may include a wide variety of components), are usually formed by geophysical processes (i.e. are abiogenic), and have an ordered atomic arrangement.

classDefinition: A uranium deposit where self-sustaining nuclear chain reactions have occurred.
parentDefinition: A mineral deposit that contains uranium ore.
classComment: Oklo is the only known location for this in the world and consists of 16 sites at which self-sustaining nuclear fission reactions are thought to have taken place approximately 1.7 billion years ago, and ran for a few hundred thousand years, averaging probably less than 100 kW of thermal power during that time

classDefinition: Sediment that is part of a mangrove biome.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: Mangroves are widely recognised as key ecosystems for climate change mitigation as they capture and store significant amounts of sediment organic carbon (SOC).
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: Sediment that is part of a mangrove biome.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is formed as a result of the transport and deposition of particles by flowing liquid.
classComment: Mangroves are widely recognised as key ecosystems for climate change mitigation as they capture and store significant amounts of sediment organic carbon (SOC).
parentComment: Sediment is typically deposited on the bed or bottom of a body of water or other liquid.

classDefinition: Sediment that is part of a salt marsh.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: Sediment that is part of a salt marsh.
parentDefinition: Sediment which has been transported through the marine water column, settling on the seafloor.
parentComment: Particles of marine sediment are primarily generated by 1) processes in terrestrial systems and transported to the marine realm by the action of rivers or aeolian processes (amongst other routes) , 2) marine organisms, 3) chemical processes in seawater, or 4) cosmogeneous input.

classDefinition: Solid material that has a waste role.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is in a solid state.
parentComment: This is a defined class: its subclasses will not be asserted, but filled by inference.

classDefinition: Solid material that has a waste role.
parentDefinition: A material which is not the desired output of a process and which is typically the input of a process which removes it from its producer (e.g. a disposal process).

classDefinition: A dairy farm which is managed using practices certified to be organic by a competent authority.
parentDefinition: A farm which produces milk or products derived from milk.

classDefinition: A dairy farm which is managed using practices certified to be organic by a competent authority.
parentDefinition: A farm which is managed using practices certified to be organic by a competent authority.
parentComment: What qualifies as an organic farm varies significantly across nations and subnational entities. In general, however, organic farming involves the use of biological pest control, mixed cropping, natural fertilisers, and the fostering of insect predators. Further, organic certification often requires that synthetic pesticides and fertilisers are not used.

classDefinition: A farm which produces milk or products derived from milk.
parentDefinition: An area of land which is used for the cultivation of crops or grazing of livestock, including any agricultural constructions therein.

classDefinition: A farm which is managed using practices certified to be organic by a competent authority.
parentDefinition: An area of land which is used for the cultivation of crops or grazing of livestock, including any agricultural constructions therein.
classComment: What qualifies as an organic farm varies significantly across nations and subnational entities. In general, however, organic farming involves the use of biological pest control, mixed cropping, natural fertilisers, and the fostering of insect predators. Further, organic certification often requires that synthetic pesticides and fertilisers are not used.

classDefinition: A landfill that receives household waste.
parentDefinition: A depression which contains objects and materials discarded by humans or their technologies.

classLabel: biological nutrient removal during wastewater treatment
classDefinition: A recycling process that uses microbes for the uptake of nitrogen and phosphorus during wastewater treatment.
parentDefinition: A process during which materials deemed as waste are separated and converted into a form which can be used as input by the same processes which generated them.
parentComment: This has been created for SDGIO. Revision is likely, but the general meaning should be stable. The frame of reference for determining what is 'waste' and what is a  'resource' is unclear.

classDefinition: A recycling process during which wastewater is treated
parentDefinition: A process during which materials deemed as waste are separated and converted into a form which can be used as input by the same processes which generated them.
parentComment: This has been created for SDGIO. Revision is likely, but the general meaning should be stable. The frame of reference for determining what is 'waste' and what is a  'resource' is unclear.

classDefinition: A type of land degradation in which terrestrial ecosystem becomes increasingly dry, typically losing its bodies of water as well as vegetation and wildlife.
parentDefinition: A process which diminishes the functioning of an ecosystem located on land.
parentComment: This could include, for example, reducing soil health, pollinator activity, or an ecosystem's ability  to sequester carbon.

classDefinition: A process which consists of all photosynthesis processes instantiated in an ecosystem.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: A process which consists of all photosynthesis processes instantiated in an ecosystem.
parentDefinition: An environmental process either driven by or primarily impacting the parts or emergent properties of an ecosystem.

parentLabel: energy derivation by oxidation of organic compounds

classDefinition: A process during which chemicals that are involved in natural ecosystem processes are transported or transformed, and which impact the activity of biological entities
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: Establishment of a new forest by seeding or planting of nonforested land.
parentDefinition: A planned process during which human agents establish plant communities in ecosystems which have previously been, partially or wholly, stripped of existing plant communities.
classComment: Prior to afforestation, the land cover of a region must not include forests.

classDefinition: A planned process during which human agents establish plant communities in ecosystems which have previously been, partially or wholly, stripped of existing plant communities.
parentDefinition: A process during which an ecosystem, its parts, or the processes it participates in are modified by human intervention to accomplish an objective.

classDefinition: The planting of trees in areas in where forests have previously been cleared.
parentDefinition: A planned process during which human agents establish plant communities in ecosystems which have previously been, partially or wholly, stripped of existing plant communities.
classComment: reforestation is reestablishment of forest where the forest recently existed[IPCC]

parentDefinition: An environmental process either driven by or primarily impacting the parts or emergent properties of an ecosystem.
An environmental process either driven by or primarily impacting the parts or emergent properties of an ecosystem.
classComment: To be populated through inference. Do not use for annotation.

classDefinition: A process during which the populations in a community of algae in a marine or freshwater ecosystem undergo rapid growth, resulting in high concentrations of algal cells that occur only periodically and briefly in that ecosystem, relative to their concentrations through the majority of the planetary orbital period.
parentDefinition: An environmental process either driven by or primarily impacting the parts or emergent properties of an ecosystem.
classComment: This class is under development. Note that cyanobacterial blooms are often confused with algal blooms. There is no globally recognised threshold beyond which community density enters a bloom state.

classDefinition: A process during which the rapid growth of algal populations that result in an algal bloom ceases, and cell densities begin to fall due to death, predation, and transport.
parentDefinition: An environmental process either driven by or primarily impacting the parts or emergent properties of an ecosystem.
An environmental process either driven by or primarily impacting the parts or emergent properties of an ecosystem.

classDefinition: A process during which the algal cells constituting an algal bloom produce biomass from abiotic components during photosynthesis.
parentDefinition: An environmental process either driven by or primarily impacting the parts or emergent properties of an ecosystem.

classLabel: accumulation of toxins from algal bloom process
classComment: TODO; add axioms pointing to GO organismal process; Add axioms pointing to toxin role

classLabel: degradation of toxins from algal bloom process

classDefinition: Transpiration is the process of water movement through a plant and its evaporation from aerial parts of that plant, such as from leaves but also from stems and flowers.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which liquid water is circulated in the vicinity of a heat source in order to absorb thermal energy and transport it away form that source.
classComment: Needs a process part "water transport" or similar and some link to plants to be complete.

classDefinition: A material transport process during which liquid water is circulated in the vicinity of a heat source in order to absorb thermal energy and transport it away form that source.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which a volume of liquid water is transported due to a disequilibria in physical forces.

classDefinition: A pollution process during which particulates or other contaminants are released into a portion of air.
parentDefinition: An environmental system process that results in the introduction of contaminants into an environment.
parentComment: Pollutants may be material or immaterial (e.g. heat energy)

classDefinition: A pollution process during which contaminants are released into soil.
parentDefinition: An environmental system process that results in the introduction of contaminants into an environment.
parentComment: Pollutants may be material or immaterial (e.g. heat energy)

classDefinition: A pollution process during which plastic contaminants are released into an environmental material.
parentDefinition: An environmental system process that results in the introduction of contaminants into an environment.
parentComment: Pollutants may be material or immaterial (e.g. heat energy)

classDefinition: An process in which environmental parameters and variables are continually assayed.
parentDefinition: A process that realizes a plan which is the concretization of a plan specification.

classDefinition: A monitoring process that assays the level of environmental pollutants to determine the presence of effect of environmental pollution.
parentDefinition: An process in which environmental parameters and variables are continually assayed.

classDefinition: A pollution process that results in increased levels of pollutants in an urban environment.
parentDefinition: An environmental system process that results in the introduction of contaminants into an environment.
parentComment: Pollutants may be material or immaterial (e.g. heat energy)

classDefinition: Partially compacted granular snow, which has undergone several cycles of melting and refreezing while being compacted, usually found on the atmosphere-exposed surface of a glacier.
parentDefinition: Snow is an environmental material which is primarily composed of flakes of crystalline water ice.
classComment: Névé that survives a full season of ablation turns into firn.

classDefinition: Uncompacted snow containing trapped atmospheric gases.
parentDefinition: Snow is an environmental material which is primarily composed of flakes of crystalline water ice.
classComment: Described as having a fluffy appearance.

classDefinition: Granular snow which contains a proportion of fused granules formed through melting and re-thawing while being compacted by the weight of overlying material and which contains interconnected gaseous pores.
parentDefinition: Snow is an environmental material which is primarily composed of flakes of crystalline water ice.
classComment: Firn derives from névé which has survived a full season of ablation and has undergone a metamorphic transition.

classDefinition: A material transformation process during which recently precipitated, powdery snow transitions into firn or névé through compaction and/or through cycles of freezing and thawing.
parentDefinition: A process during which a portion of some environmental material is converted into a different material or a collection of materials.
classComment: Often, the weight of material deposited on top of powdery snow by, for example, mass wasting, can lead to nivation.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material transformation process only refers to ENVO:environmental material classes (e.g. bulk and typically impure substances), rather than transformations converting a specific chemical into another.

classDefinition: Glacial ice which contains material liberated during a glacial erosion process.
parentDefinition: Any water ice that is part of a glacier.

classDefinition: Glacial ice which contains material liberated during a glacial erosion process.
parentDefinition: Water ice which contains material liberated during an erosion process.

classDefinition: Water ice which contains material liberated during an erosion process.
parentDefinition: Ice which is formed from water.
parentComment:
Water ice can appear transparent or opaque bluish-white color, depending on the presence of impurities or air inclusions. The addition of other materials such as soil may further alter its appearance.

When speaking about ice on Earth, usually water ice is meant - the solid, crystalline form of water found in the atmosphere as snow crystals, hail, ice pellets, etc., and on the earth's surface in forms such as hoarfrost, rime, glaze, sea ice, glacier ice, ground ice, frazil, anchor ice, etc.

This form of water is, strictly speaking, called ice Ih, the Roman numeral I distinguishing it from more than a dozen other phases and the letter h distinguishing it from the metastable cubic phase ice Ic. Ice Ih is the only one of the several known phases of water ice that is stable at commonly occurring temperatures and pressures. (Some of the other forms have very unusual properties, ice VII, for example, being stable only at pressures above 22 400 kg/cm^2, but then existing at temperatures up to about 100C.)

It has an open structure with a specific gravity of 0.9166 which is slightly less than water; because the water molecules bond to their neighbors covalently only in four directions; it therefore floats on higher density water, where broken molecular bonds permit closer packing. All commonly occurring forms of ice are crystalline, although large single crystals are relatively rare except in glaciers. The ice crystal lattice possesses hexagonal symmetry that manifests itself in the gross forms of such single crystals as are sometimes found in snow. At an air pressure of one atmosphere, ice melts at 0 C by definition of the Celsius temperature scale. (Strictly speaking the equilibrium point among water, ice, and vapor occurs at +0.01C, the triple point.) On the other hand, ice does not invariably form in liquid water cooled below this temperature; it has a tendency to supercool, more so in the absence of ice nuclei.

In permafrost regions, ice may occupy voids in soils and rocks and may develop in a variety of forms. Ice may be colourless to pale blue or greenish-blue. It may appear white due to included gas bubbles; in exposures, ground ice may also appear black.

In nature ice is formed either by: (a) the freezing of water, (b) the condensation of atmospheric water vapour direct into ice crystals, (c) the compaction of snow with or without the motion of a glacier, or (d) the impregnation of porous snow masses with water which subsequently freeze.

classDefinition: Water ice containing little to no air bubbles resulting in a reduction of internal light scattering and, given sufficient volume, a blue appearance.
parentDefinition: Ice which is formed from water.
classComment: The blue 'appearance' is to be understood as that within the visual range of humans.
parentComment:

Ice Ih is the only one of the several known phases of water ice that is stable at commonly occurring temperatures and pressures. (Some of the other forms have very unusual properties, ice VII, for example, being stable only at pressures above 22 400 kg/cm^2, but then existing at temperatures up to about 100C.)

On the other hand, ice does not invariably form in liquid water cooled below this temperature; it has a tendency to supercool, more so in the absence of ice nuclei.

In permafrost regions, ice may occupy voids in soils and rocks and may develop in a variety of forms. Ice may be colourless to pale blue or greenish-blue. It may appear white due to included gas bubbles; in exposures, ground ice may also appear black.

classDefinition: A color hue with low wavelength of that portion of the visible spectrum lying between green and indigo, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 420 to 490 nanometers.
parentDefinition: A composite chromatic quality composed of hue, saturation and intensity parts.

classDefinition: A soil which has a high bulk density and/or a low porosity. A compacted soil has a reduced rate of both water infiltration and drainage
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, interstitial gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
parentComment:
'In engineering terms, soil is referred to as regolith, or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically, the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

" The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm."  Soil taxonomy, 2nd Ed., quoted in http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detail/soils/edu/?cid=nrcs142p2_054280

classDefinition: A positional quality inhering in a bearer by virtue the bearer's being changed in position.
parentDefinition: A spatial quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's spatial location relative to other objects in the vicinity.

classDefinition: A small glacier contained within a cirque basin.
parentDefinition: An ice mass which is of sufficient mass that the action of gravity upon it overcomes the frictional forces holding it in place, causing it to deform and flow towards lower elevation.
classComment: The decreased size axiom is debatable
parentComment: The definition of glacier is highly variable. Two main issues exist: 1) Whether or not a mass of ice must currently show movement to be considered a glacier or not and 2) What is the relationship between ice sheets and glaciers (i.e., which is the parent in a parent/child relationship or whether they are distinct terms).

classDefinition: A stream which is primarily composed of meltwater and which flows within a glacier or ice sheet.
parentDefinition: A watercourse which is linear and flows across the solid portion of a planetary surface.

classDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is composed primarily of carbon particles formed through the incomplete combustion of hydrocarbons.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is composed primarily of particles.

classDefinition: A process during which a part of a glacier breaks away from the main mass as an iceberg.
parentDefinition: A process during which a part of a glacier breaks away from the main mass.
classComment: Calving is usually caused by the expansion of glaciers.
parentComment: Calving is usually caused by the expansion of glaciers.

classLabel: calving of ice from an iceberg
classDefinition: A process during which a part of an iceberg breaks away from the main mass.
parentDefinition: A process during which a part of an ice mass breaks away from the main mass.

classDefinition: Marine sediment soured from either terrestrial systems, marine organisms, seawater and or cosmogeneous sources, which is transported through the marine water column, and accumulates within shallow regions of the oceanic basin close to continents, such as the continental shelf, or continental slope.
parentDefinition: Sediment which has been transported through the marine water column, settling on the seafloor.
parentComment: Particles of marine sediment are primarily generated by 1) processes in terrestrial systems and transported to the marine realm by the action of rivers or aeolian processes (amongst other routes) , 2) marine organisms, 3) chemical processes in seawater, or 4) cosmogeneous input.

classDefinition: A water body which is located in a depression within the surface of a glacier.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is composed primarily of dust, rock, and soot, as well as the microbial communities associated with these materials, deposited on an ice mass by an aeolian process.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is composed primarily of particles.

classDefinition: A vertical thaw hole within an ice mass, formed as a result of ice melt associated with local temperature increases, due to increased absorption of solar radiation by cryoconite deposits.
parentDefinition: A channel which traverses an ice mass floating on a water body and bridges the atmosphere to the underlying water through its internal cavity.
classComment: This class doesn't refer to the site but instead the depression or hole and therefore the adjacency to the cryoconite itself.

classDefinition: A channel which traverses an ice mass floating on a water body and bridges the atmosphere to the underlying water through its internal cavity.
parentDefinition: A structure which traverses a mass of one or more environmental materials, and encloses a roughly tubular site.

classDefinition: A water body which forms as a result of localised melting taking place on the surface of a glacier or a mass of sea ice and which is contained in the cavity formed by such melting.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of water of varying size.
parentComment: The term body of water most often refers to large accumulations of water, such as oceans, seas, and lakes, but it includes smaller pools of water such as ponds, wetlands, or more rarely, puddles. A body of water does not have to be still or contained; Rivers, streams, canals, and other geographical features where water moves from one place to another are also considered bodies of water.

classDefinition: A channel through which brine flows.
parentDefinition: A structure which traverses a mass of one or more environmental materials, and encloses a roughly tubular site.

classDefinition: A channel through which brine flows.
parentDefinition: A solid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous mass of snow and/or ice.

classDefinition: A material accumulation process during which brine droplets, trapped between ice crystals formed during seawater freezing, form brine channels.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
classComment: This process may be considered a material accumulation process as it is the accumulation of brine droplets which form the channels.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: A material accumulation process during which brine droplets, trapped between ice crystals formed during seawater freezing, form brine channels.
parentDefinition: A material accumulation process during which the volume of liquid entity increases.
classComment: This process may be considered a material accumulation process as it is the accumulation of brine droplets which form the channels.

classDefinition: A material transformation process during which brine is formed due to the expulsion of salt during frazil formation or a seawater freezing process.
parentDefinition: A process during which a portion of some environmental material is converted into a different material or a collection of materials.
classComment: Expelled salt accumulates in brine droplets, which remain in a liquid state due to their increased salinity.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material transformation process only refers to ENVO:environmental material classes (e.g. bulk and typically impure substances), rather than transformations converting a specific chemical into another.

classDefinition: A material transformation process during which brine is formed due to the expulsion of salt during frazil formation or a seawater freezing process.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
classComment: Expelled salt accumulates in brine droplets, which remain in a liquid state due to their increased salinity.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: A material transformation process during which seawater freezes into sea ice.
parentDefinition: A material transformation process during which water ice is formed.

classDefinition: New ice which is composed frazil which has congealed into a thin sheet.
parentDefinition: Water ice which is formed from freezing water and is suspended in a water body.
classComment: Typically 3 to 4 millimeters in diameter. These new ice classes refer to both marine water and fresh water ice. If using this term for annotation, use it in conjunction with another envo term to express whether the ice is in a marine, freshwater, or other system.
parentComment: sea ice types include frazil, grease ice, slush, and shuga. These new ice classes refer to both marine water and fresh water ice. If using this term for annotation, use it in conjunction with another envo term to express whether the ice is in a marine, freshwater, or other system.

classDefinition: A new ice formation process during which small, needle-like crystals consisting of nearly pure fresh water, form due to the freezing of open, turbulent, supercooled water.
parentDefinition: An ice formation process during which water is frozen into a form of new ice such as frazil, grease ice, slush, or shuga.

classDefinition: An ice formation process during which water is frozen into a form of new ice such as frazil, grease ice, slush, or shuga.
parentDefinition: A material transformation process during which water ice is formed.

classDefinition: A melt pond which has a surface exposed to the atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A water body which forms as a result of localised melting taking place on the surface of a glacier or a mass of sea ice and which is contained in the cavity formed by such melting.

classDefinition: A melt pond which is completely encased in ice and thus not directly exposed to the atmosphere or underlying water.
parentDefinition: A water body which forms as a result of localised melting taking place on the surface of a glacier or a mass of sea ice and which is contained in the cavity formed by such melting.
classComment: In practice, there may be some openings which are small relative to the surface footprint of the meltpond.

classDefinition: A lake which is comprised of meltwater located underneath or within a glacier.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: New ice, which is spongy, lumpy and opaque, and forms from water which freezes in an agitated water body.
parentDefinition: Water ice which is formed from freezing water and is suspended in a water body.
classComment: These new ice classes refer to both marine water and fresh water ice. If using this term for annotation, use it in conjunction with another envo term to express whether the ice is in a marine, freshwater, or other system.
parentComment: sea ice types include frazil, grease ice, slush, and shuga. These new ice classes refer to both marine water and fresh water ice. If using this term for annotation, use it in conjunction with another envo term to express whether the ice is in a marine, freshwater, or other system.

classDefinition: A slurry of frazil, snow, and liquid water.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: These new ice classes refer to both marine water and fresh water ice. If using this term for annotation, use it in conjunction with another envo term to express whether the ice is in a marine, freshwater, or other system.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: A slurry of frazil, snow, and liquid water.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: These new ice classes refer to both marine water and fresh water ice. If using this term for annotation, use it in conjunction with another envo term to express whether the ice is in a marine, freshwater, or other system.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: A sea ice formation process during which new ice crystals freeze together, forming nilas, a thin, elastic, continuous, ice sheet of a transparent gray color.
parentDefinition: A material transformation process during which seawater freezes into sea ice.

classDefinition: A sea ice formation process during which water freezes to the bottom of an existing nilas ice floe creating a thicker ice floe known as young ice.
parentDefinition: A material transformation process during which seawater freezes into sea ice.

classDefinition: A sea ice formation process during which seawater freezes onto young ice during the cold season, forming first year ice.
parentDefinition: A material transformation process during which seawater freezes into sea ice.
classComment: First year ice that survives melting during spring and summer can transition to second year ice.

classDefinition: Sea ice which has formed over a single freezing season.
parentDefinition: Water ice which has formed by the freezing of sea water.
classComment: Sea ice develops from young ice; thickness from 0.3 to 2 meters (1 to 6.6 feet).  Sea ice be subdivided into thin first-year ice (white ice), medium first-year ice, and thick first-year ice.  First-year ice is distinguished from older ice primarily by having a higher salinity. Undeformed first-year ice differs from older ice in that it is smoother and lacks refrozen melt ponds. Characteristically level where undisturbed by pressure, but where ridges occur, they  distinguished by being larger, more angular, and more porous than multiyear ridges.
parentComment: In the United States, NOAA sea ice operations does not include superstructure icing as being sea ice. In sea ice operations however, sea ice is any form of ice found at sea which has originated from the freezing of sea water. It presents the main kind of floating ice encountered at sea. Except where it forms ridges, sea ice is up to a few metres thick, in which respect it differs from shelf ice.  Sea ice may be discontinuous pieces (ice floes) moved on the ocean surface by wind and currents (pack ice), or a motionless sheet attached to the coast (land-fast ice). In brief, it forms first as lolly ice (frazil crystals), thickens into sludge, and coagulates into sheet ice, pancake ice, or into floes of various shapes and sizes. Thereafter, sea ice may develop into pack ice and/or become a form of pressure ice.  Sea ice less than one year old is called first-year ice. Perennial ice is sea ice that survives at least one summer. It may be subdivided into second-year ice and multi-year ice, where multiyear ice has survived at least two summers.

classDefinition: A sea ice formation process during which seawater freezes onto first year ice during the cold season, forming second year sea ice.
parentDefinition: A material transformation process during which seawater freezes into sea ice.
classComment: Second year ice forms from first year ice which has previously survived one melt season.

classDefinition: Sea ice which is thicker than first year ice, and has survived a seasonal melting process.
parentDefinition: Water ice which has formed by the freezing of sea water.
parentComment: In the United States, NOAA sea ice operations does not include superstructure icing as being sea ice. In sea ice operations however, sea ice is any form of ice found at sea which has originated from the freezing of sea water. It presents the main kind of floating ice encountered at sea. Except where it forms ridges, sea ice is up to a few metres thick, in which respect it differs from shelf ice.  Sea ice may be discontinuous pieces (ice floes) moved on the ocean surface by wind and currents (pack ice), or a motionless sheet attached to the coast (land-fast ice). In brief, it forms first as lolly ice (frazil crystals), thickens into sludge, and coagulates into sheet ice, pancake ice, or into floes of various shapes and sizes. Thereafter, sea ice may develop into pack ice and/or become a form of pressure ice.  Sea ice less than one year old is called first-year ice. Perennial ice is sea ice that survives at least one summer. It may be subdivided into second-year ice and multi-year ice, where multiyear ice has survived at least two summers.

classDefinition: A sea ice formation process during which seawater freezes into second year ice during the cold season, forming multiyear ice.
parentDefinition: A material transformation process during which seawater freezes into sea ice.
classComment: Multiyear ice forms from second year ice which has previously survived at least two melt seasons.

classDefinition: Sea ice which is thicker than second year ice, and has survived more than two seasonal melting process.
parentDefinition: Water ice which has formed by the freezing of sea water.
parentComment: In the United States, NOAA sea ice operations does not include superstructure icing as being sea ice. In sea ice operations however, sea ice is any form of ice found at sea which has originated from the freezing of sea water. It presents the main kind of floating ice encountered at sea. Except where it forms ridges, sea ice is up to a few metres thick, in which respect it differs from shelf ice.  Sea ice may be discontinuous pieces (ice floes) moved on the ocean surface by wind and currents (pack ice), or a motionless sheet attached to the coast (land-fast ice). In brief, it forms first as lolly ice (frazil crystals), thickens into sludge, and coagulates into sheet ice, pancake ice, or into floes of various shapes and sizes. Thereafter, sea ice may develop into pack ice and/or become a form of pressure ice.  Sea ice less than one year old is called first-year ice. Perennial ice is sea ice that survives at least one summer. It may be subdivided into second-year ice and multi-year ice, where multiyear ice has survived at least two summers.

classDefinition: An ice floe which is formed from frozen sea water, and floats upon the surface of a marine water body.
parentDefinition: An ice mass which forms a cohesive and contiguous sheet of water ice, floating upon the surface of a water body.
parentComment:
Ice floes can exist in sea ice, in rivers or lakes. The WMO offers the following extent-based classification. Floe giant: Over 10 km across.
Floe vast: 2-10 km across. Floe big: 500-2000 m across. Floe medium: 100-500 m across. Floe small: 20-100 m across. Ice cake: Less than 20 m across. Small ice cake: Less than 2 m across.

classDefinition: A sea ice floe which has a rounded or circular shape and raised rims.
parentDefinition: An ice floe which is formed from frozen sea water, and floats upon the surface of a marine water body.

classDefinition: A optical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's lacking opacity.
parentDefinition: An optical quality which obtains by virtue of the ability of the bearer to absorb visible light.

classDefinition: An elasticity quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's ability to recover its size and shape after deformation in any way.
parentDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's disposition to recover its size and shape after deformation in any way.

classDefinition: A thickness which is relatively high.
parentDefinition: A size quality which is relatively high.

classDefinition: A thickness which is relatively high.
parentDefinition: A 1-D extent quality which is equal to the dimension through an object as opposed to its length or width.

classDefinition: A layer which consists of a thin aggregate of frazil ice crystals, which float upon the surface of a water body.
parentDefinition: A solid layer which is primarily composed of some water-based ice.
classComment: Within a marine system, grease ice makes the ocean surface resemble an oil slick.

classDefinition: A layer which consists of slush ice.
parentDefinition: A solid layer which is primarily composed of some water-based ice.

classDefinition: A new ice formation process in which slush ice is formed.
parentDefinition: An ice formation process during which water is frozen into a form of new ice such as frazil, grease ice, slush, or shuga.

classDefinition: A new ice formation process in which shuga is formed.
parentDefinition: An ice formation process during which water is frozen into a form of new ice such as frazil, grease ice, slush, or shuga.

classDefinition: A thermokarst lake through which methane gas released from thawing permafrost, or other methane stores, rises and escapes to the atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A freshwater lake which fills a depression formed by the erosion of thermokarst caused by permafrost thaw.
classComment: On Earth, the bright blue appearance, in the light spectrum visible to humans, is due to increased abundances of microorganisms attracted to sulfur compounds associated with the methane release.
parentComment: Continued thawing of the permafrost substrate can lead to the drainage and eventual disappearance of thermokarst lakes, leaving only the landform, thermokarst depression behind.

classDefinition: A hydrocarbon gas emission process during which a portion of methane gas is transported into the atmosphere.
parentDefinition: A gas emission process during which a portion of hydrocarbon gas is transported into the atmosphere.
classComment: Methane is emitted during the production and transport of coal, natural gas, and oil. Methane emissions also result from livestock and other agricultural practices and by the decay of organic waste in municipal solid waste landfills.
parentComment: Some hydrocarbon gasses within the atmosphere contribute to the planetary green house gas effect by increasing absorption of solar energy.

classDefinition: Permafrost which contains pockets of trapped methane gas.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is 1) composed primarily of soil or rock and included ice or organic material and 2) at or below the freezing point of water for two or more years.
classComment: Other hydrocarbon gasses such as carbon dioxide may also be present. These pockets can be sufficently large that the permafrost surface will undulate when pressure is applied.
parentComment: Ice is not always present, as may be in the case of nonporous bedrock, but it frequently occurs and it may be in amounts exceeding the potential hydraulic saturation of the ground material.

classLabel: permafrost crater derived from a methane explosion
classDefinition: A crater which is found in permafrost and formed as a result of an explosion fuelled by methane formerly contained in that permafrost.
parentDefinition: A generally circular saucer or bowl-shaped depression caused by explosive action.

classDefinition: An explosion during which methane-rich gas trapped in permafrost combusts.
parentDefinition: A process during which a material entity undergoes a rapid increase in volume, releasing gasses and various forms of energy, often including thermal, light and sound energy.
parentComment: Supersonic explosions are known as detonations and subsonic explosions as deflagrations.

classDefinition: A process during which the intesity of stellar radiation received by a planet's surface varies in a cyclical regime due to the planet's orbital motion around the barycentre of a planetary system and/or the tilt of its rotational axis relative to its orbital plane.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
classComment: The seasons that are generated by this process are divisions of time between warm (maximal radiation exposure) and cold (minimum radiation exposure) extremes. Depending on the planet's makeup, the resulting seasonal dynamics may include ecological and meteorological cycles which may form the basis for further divisions of the cycle (e.g. rainy season, dry season, wildfire season).
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A one-dimensional temporal region which is delimited by the occurrence of processes which serve as its delimiters.
A season during which the average temperature of a planetary part exceeds that of all other seasons it endures during a season generating process.
parentDefinition: A one-dimensional temporal region which is delimited by the occurrence of processes which serve as its delimiters.
classComment: The boundaries of seasons are typically fiat and should be defined on a data/information layer. This also pertains to the amount of time included when averaging measured values of qualities like temperature.

classDefinition: A season during which the average temperature of a planetary part is below that of all other seasons it endures during a season generating process.
parentDefinition: A one-dimensional temporal region which is delimited by the occurrence of processes which serve as its delimiters.
classComment: The boundaries of seasons are typically fiat and should be defined on a data/information layer. This also pertains to the amount of time included when averaging measured values of qualities like temperature.

classDefinition: A material transformation process during which a material entity melts during a warm season.
parentDefinition: Melting is a material transformation process which results in the phase transition of a substance from a solid to a liquid.
parentComment: Note that melting need not be due to warming, thus the classes are separated.

classDefinition: A compaction process during which a material entity subjected to heat and/or pressure is compacted into a solid mass without undergoing melting.
parentDefinition: A physical process during which atoms, molecules, or other consituents of a material entity are forced closer together.

classDefinition: A sintering process during which snow is compacted into glacial ice.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which has water - in any of its states - as a participant.
parentComment: This classes asserted subclasses will be moved away as it should be an inferred class.

classDefinition: A sintering process during which snow is compacted into glacial ice.
parentDefinition: A compaction process during which a material entity subjected to heat and/or pressure is compacted into a solid mass without undergoing melting.

classDefinition: An accumulation process during which a powdery snow carried on the wind settles on a solid surface, forming a mound.
parentDefinition: A material accumulation process during which the mass of snow on a surface increases.
parentComment:
This term is used both as a process and as an amount of mass added. Semantically speaking these are two distinct concepts (e.g., accumulation results in accumulation_amount of ice or snow gain), though accumulation_amount would more likely be an attribute.

The scope of this term varies depending on the definition.  Some definitions constrain themselves snow or ice added to glaciers; while others also include ice fields, snow cover, and/or floating ice.  How to resolve this depends on the scope desired.

Some definitions include additional discussion of the the physics involved which would be useful for connecting glacier ontologies to atmospheric, hydrologic, etc. ontologies.  This information should be captured no matter how the inconsistencies above are resolved.

classDefinition: A mass wasting process during which slab snow rapidly moves down a sloping surface.
parentDefinition: Mass wasting is the geomorphic process by which solid environmental material such as soil, sand, regolith, and/or rock move downslope typically as a mass, largely under the force of gravity, but frequently affected by water and water content as in submarine environments and mudslides.
classComment: Slab avalanches account for most back-country fatalities.
parentComment: Of interest for future development: Some causes of mass wasting earthquakes, increased overburden from structures, increased soil moisture, reduction of roots holding the soil to bedrock, undercutting of the slope by excavation or erosion, weathering by frost heave, bioturbation, volcanic edifice over-steepening. Some processes that reduce mass wasting: Afforestation, Reforestation, Terracing steps on slopes (reduce angle of slope). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_wasting.

classDefinition: An avalanche during which powdery snow rapidly flows down a sloping surface.
parentDefinition: A mass wasting flow during which snow rapidly flows down a sloping surface.

classDefinition: An avalanche during which a suspension of water and snow flows down a sloping surface.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which a volume of liquid water is transported due to a disequilibria in physical forces.
classComment: Wet snow avalanches travel at a lower velocity than other types of avalanches.

classDefinition: An avalanche during which a suspension of water and snow flows down a sloping surface.
parentDefinition: A mass wasting flow during which snow rapidly flows down a sloping surface.
classComment: Wet snow avalanches travel at a lower velocity than other types of avalanches.

classDefinition: Snow which is cohesive, hard and overlies weaker snow.
parentDefinition: Snow is an environmental material which is primarily composed of flakes of crystalline water ice.

classDefinition: An accumulation of powdery snow which was transported and deposited via a snow drifting process.
parentDefinition: A mass of snow.

classDefinition: An accumulation of snow and firn which rests upon land.
parentDefinition: A mass of snow.

classDefinition: A snow patch which forms during a cold season and melts away during the succeeding warm season.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of snow and firn which rests upon land.

classDefinition: A snow patch which persists through at least one seasonal cycle.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of snow and firn which rests upon land.
classComment: A snow patch is defined as perennial if it survives two or more melt seasons.

classDefinition: A snow mass which is large enough, and persists long enough, to undergo compaction under its own weight, leading to layer-like structural differentiation.
parentDefinition: A mass of snow.
classComment: Snowpack is found in geographic regions experiencing cold weather for extended periods of time.

classDefinition: A snow mass which is large enough, and persists long enough, to undergo compaction under its own weight, leading to layer-like structural differentiation.
