parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A lake which is connected to a marine water body via tunnels or cracks in the soil.
parentDefinition: A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.

classDefinition: Liquid water which is either part of or was removed from a marine lake.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

classDefinition: A pond which has layers of water that do not intermix.
parentDefinition: A body of water, usually of smaller size than a lake.

classDefinition: A manufactured product which is designed to function as a container for growing plants.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A manufactured product which is produced by curing, subsequent aging, slow oxidation and degradation of carotenoids in tobacco leaves.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A pond which humans have constructed for the cultivation of algae.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: A pond which humans have constructed for the cultivation of algae.
parentDefinition: A body of water, usually of smaller size than a lake.

classDefinition: A manufactured product which is composed of flexible material and is intended to be hung such that it impedes the spray of water between a shower fixture and the rest of a room.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.
classComment: Shower curtains are typically made from plastic or another water resistant or waterproof material.

classDefinition: Processed tobacco which has been treated for use by placing it between the gum and cheek or lip, chewed, or sniffed, but not smoked.
parentDefinition: A manufactured product which is produced by curing, subsequent aging, slow oxidation and degradation of carotenoids in tobacco leaves.

classDefinition: A spacecraft which is capable of supporting a human crew in orbit for an extended period of time.
parentDefinition: A vehicle designed to fly in outer space.

classDefinition: A vehicle which is used for carrying cargo or passengers on a rail transport system.
parentDefinition: A vehicle is a mobile machine which transports people or cargo.

classDefinition: A manufactured product which is controls the flow of water.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: A manufactured product which is used to give input or control to an information processing system by touching a display screen with a special stylus or one or more fingers.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.
classComment: Touching the screen with multiple fingers is considered a multi-touch gesture.

classDefinition: Anthropogenic litter which consists of an abandoned ship's remains.
parentDefinition: A material entity which has been discarded outside waste management systems by humans or their technologies.
classComment: A shipwreck can be found beached on land or sunken to the bottom of a body of water.
parentComment: Very large objects that are discarded are typically considered "debris", but this term is loosely defined and there are no standard size classifications which can be used to distinguish debris from litter.

classDefinition: A human construction which supplies drinking water by squirting it into a basin or jets water into the air for a decorative or dramatic effect.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: A water well in which a long, 100–200 millimetres-wide, stainless steel tube or pipe is bored into an underground aquifer to lift water using a pump.
parentDefinition: A well which provides access to groundwater held  in an aquifer.

classDefinition: A sedimentary rock which is made of carbonate mud whose formation is mediated by microbes in the benthic zone.
parentDefinition: A rock formed by deposition of either clastic sediments, organic matter, or chemical precipitates (evaporites), followed by compaction of the particulate matter and cementation during diagenesis.

classDefinition: Water which comes from a spring.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

classDefinition: A salt mass which consists of isometric crystals of sodium chloride (NaCl).
parentDefinition: An accumulation of a salt, typically sodium chloride.
classComment: Typically colorless or white. Halite may also occur in various color including light blue, dark blue, purple, pink, red, orange, yellow or gray depending on inclusion of other materials, impurities, and structural or isotopic abnormalities in the crystals.

classDefinition: An intensive care unit (ICU) specializing in the care of ill or premature newborn infants.
parentDefinition: A building part which has been constructed to support the provision of intensive care medicine to patients with severe or life-threatening illnesses and injuries.

classDefinition: A geological fracture which is formed during winter months by a narrow or thin piece of ice.
parentDefinition: A geological fracture is any separation in a geologic formation, such as a joint or a fault that divides a mass of rock into two or more pieces.
classComment: The ice itself can measure up to 3–4 meters in length at ground level can extend downwards into the ground up to several meters.

classDefinition: An animal habitation which is built by alligators from plants and decomposing vegetation in order to protect their eggs from predators.
parentDefinition: The dwelling of an animal or group of similar animals.
parentComment: This class represents habitations of non-human animals. This distinction may be removed in future releases.

classDefinition: An oceanic front in which mixing of river discharge and saline seawater occurs.
parentDefinition: An oceanic front is a narrow zone of enhanced horizontal gradients of water properties (temperature, salinity, nutrients, etc.) that separates broader areas with different water masses or different vertical structure (stratification).

classDefinition: A feature which arises from a rapid multiplication of cyanobacteria, causing marked visible discoloration of the water.
parentDefinition: A geographical feature associated with water.

classDefinition: A planetary structural layer which consists of oceanic crust and the underlying upper mantle and has been uplifted and exposed above sea level.
parentDefinition: A planetary structural layer is laminar part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough to have differentiation by density. Planetary layers have differing physicochemical properties and composition.
classComment: Opholites are often emplaced onto continental crustal rocks

classDefinition: Land which has elevated levels of some contaminants or substances that are potentially hazardous to health or the environment.
parentDefinition: A surface layer of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material and is not covered by oceans or other bodies of water.

classDefinition: An agricultural aquatic ecosystem in which fish, crustaceans, mollusks, aquatic plants and algae are cultivated.
parentComment: As with other classes that are "features", the subclasses of this class are being moved to more informative locations. Their relation to agriculture will be modelled by something more akin to a quality or relation to an agricultural process.

classDefinition: An industrial building in which oil-bearing seeds or vegetable materials are crushed and pressed with a grinding mill in order to extract oils.
parentDefinition: An industrial building is a building within which goods are produced and, optionally, stored or within which services are rendered.
parentComment: It's possible that this will become an inferred class in the future. The United Nations' International Standard Industrial Classification should be referred to when expanding this branch. ISIC can also be used to identify processes. See http://unstats.un.org/unsd/cr/registry/regcst.asp?Cl=27&Lg=1.

classDefinition: A human construction which confines wastewater in a depression enclosed by earthen structures.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.
classComment: Presumably the waste is detained prior to treatment.

classDefinition: A bioreactor which utilizes a light source to cultivate phototrophic microorganisms.
parentDefinition: A biomaterial containment unit which is capable of 1) containing a mass of environmental material which hosts an active collection of organisms and 2) maintaining conditions which are conducive to one or more metabolic activities of the organisms it contains.

classDefinition: An industrial building in which crude oil is transformed and refined into useful products.
parentDefinition: An industrial building is a building within which goods are produced and, optionally, stored or within which services are rendered.
classComment: The useful products include petroleum naphtha, gasoline, diesel fuel, asphalt base, heating oil, kerosene, liquefied petroleum gas, jet fuel and fuel oils. Oil refineries are typically large, sprawling industrial complexes with extensive piping running throughout, carrying streams of fluids between large chemical processing units, such as distillation columns.
parentComment: It's possible that this will become an inferred class in the future. The United Nations' International Standard Industrial Classification should be referred to when expanding this branch. ISIC can also be used to identify processes. See http://unstats.un.org/unsd/cr/registry/regcst.asp?Cl=27&Lg=1.

classDefinition: A manufactured product which is used for cutting crops, vegetables, wood, metal, paper documents, etc into small pieces.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.
classComment: A shredder could more specifically be consered a machine.

classDefinition: A human construction which is used for the purpose of industrial development.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.
classComment: Industrial parks are usually located on the edges of, or outside, the main residential area of a city and that can be thought of as a more "heavyweight" version of a business park or office park, which has offices and light industry, rather than heavy industry.

classDefinition: Fresh water which is harvested from cloud.
parentDefinition: Water which has a low concentration of dissolved solutes, particularly that of sodium chloride.
parentComment: The lower bound of solute concentration required for water to be considered freshwater is variable, but is always less than that of seawater, and often cited as less than 1 gram of solutes per 1 litre of water.

classDefinition: Fluid environmental material which is present in the continental crust and dictates the nature and extent of crustal deformation.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is unable to resist shear forces and continuously deforms when subject to them.
classComment: The presence or absence of fluids exerts a fundamental control on rheology.

classDefinition: A geological fracture, found near volacnoes in the final phase of thier activity, chiefly discharging carbon dioxide and possibly other vapors.
parentDefinition: A geological fracture is any separation in a geologic formation, such as a joint or a fault that divides a mass of rock into two or more pieces.

classDefinition: An organic material which is derived from lichen mats.
parentDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.

classDefinition: A manufactured product which floats in water and can be used a navigational marker among other purposes.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.
classComment: Buoy can be anchored (stationary) or allowed to drift with ocean currents.

classDefinition: A manufactured product which is used to remove contaminants from water impeding the flow of particles or solutes.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.
classComment: Fine physical barrier, a chemical process, or a biological process are applied in the water filter. Filters cleanse water to different extents for purposes such as providing agricultural irrigation, accessible drinking water, public and private aquariums, and the safe use of ponds and swimming pools.

classDefinition: A human construction which provides regulated climatic conditions for the growth of plants and whose walls and roof are made chiefly of transparent material, such as glass.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.

classDefinition: A fermentation pit which is constructed to facilitate the fermentation of alcoholic substances.
parentDefinition: A pit which has been constructed for use in fermentation processes that will yield alcoholic spirits.
classComment: Definition from 2021-08-05 call with Buttigieg, Duncan and Miller

classDefinition: A fermentation pit which is constructed from clay.
parentDefinition: A depression in the ground resembling a hole or cavity, either natural or anthropogenic.
classComment: Definition from 2021-08-05 call with Buttigieg, Duncan and Miller

classDefinition: A pond which has been constructed by humans or their technologies.
parentDefinition: A body of water, usually of smaller size than a lake.
classComment: Definition from 2021-08-05 call with Buttigieg, Duncan and Miller

classDefinition: A human construction that has intentionally been placed into orbit.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.
classComment: Definition from 2021-08-05 call with Buttigieg, Duncan and Miller

classDefinition: A human construction that has intentionally been placed into orbit.
parentDefinition: A construction that has been assembled by deliberate human effort.
classComment: Not to be confused with a natural satellite like the earth's moon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_satellite)

classDefinition: A water body which is created in a stream by local scour or impoundment and has some structural control.
parentDefinition: An accumulation of water of varying size.
classComment: Pool water depth is above average for the stream. If if all the running water in the stream was shut off, areas in the stream that still hold water are pools. Pool water velocity is below average for the reach, causing fine sediments to deposit in pools. Pools are generally longer than they are wide (unless they are plunge pools), and are 1.5 x deeper at their maximum depth than they are at their crest
parentComment: The term body of water most often refers to large accumulations of water, such as oceans, seas, and lakes, but it includes smaller pools of water such as ponds, wetlands, or more rarely, puddles. A body of water does not have to be still or contained; Rivers, streams, canals, and other geographical features where water moves from one place to another are also considered bodies of water.

classDefinition: A water body which is created in a stream by local scour or impoundment and has some structural control.
parentDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous volume of liquid water and is held in shape or sustained by an environmental process.
classComment: Pool water depth is above average for the stream. If if all the running water in the stream was shut off, areas in the stream that still hold water are pools. Pool water velocity is below average for the reach, causing fine sediments to deposit in pools. Pools are generally longer than they are wide (unless they are plunge pools), and are 1.5 x deeper at their maximum depth than they are at their crest
parentComment: Similar, in spirit, to landform.

classDefinition: A hydroform which is that part of a stream where water flows swiftly and uniformly with low surface water agitation.
parentDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which is primarily composed of a continuous volume of liquid water and is held in shape or sustained by an environmental process.
parentComment: Similar, in spirit, to landform.

classDefinition: A stream pool which is formed as a result of high-gradient, steep streams where water cascades over a rock or woody snag.
parentDefinition: A water body which is created in a stream by local scour or impoundment and has some structural control.
classComment: Due to the gradient and surrounding geology, this pattern continues down the stream: step (drop), pool, step, pool, etc.
parentComment: Pool water depth is above average for the stream. If if all the running water in the stream was shut off, areas in the stream that still hold water are pools. Pool water velocity is below average for the reach, causing fine sediments to deposit in pools. Pools are generally longer than they are wide (unless they are plunge pools), and are 1.5 x deeper at their maximum depth than they are at their crest

classDefinition: Biofilm consisting of a mixture of algae, cyanobacteria, microbes, and detritus.
parentDefinition: Material derived from a biofilm, an aggregate of microorganisms in which cells adhere to each other and/or to a surface. These adherent cells are frequently embedded within a self-produced matrix of extracellular polymeric substance (EPS). Biofilm EPS, which is also referred to as slime, is a polymeric conglomeration generally composed of extracellular DNA, proteins, and polysaccharides in various configurations.
classComment: Periphytic biofilm coats the submerged surfaces in most bodies of water

classDefinition: Periphyton colonizing rock substrata
parentDefinition: Biofilm consisting of a mixture of algae, cyanobacteria, microbes, and detritus.
parentComment: Periphytic biofilm coats the submerged surfaces in most bodies of water

classDefinition: Periphyton colonizing silt substrata
parentDefinition: Biofilm consisting of a mixture of algae, cyanobacteria, microbes, and detritus.
parentComment: Periphytic biofilm coats the submerged surfaces in most bodies of water

classDefinition: Periphyton colonizing surface of aquatic plants
parentDefinition: Biofilm consisting of a mixture of algae, cyanobacteria, microbes, and detritus.
parentComment: Periphytic biofilm coats the submerged surfaces in most bodies of water

classDefinition: Periphyton colonizing sand substrata
parentDefinition: Biofilm consisting of a mixture of algae, cyanobacteria, microbes, and detritus.
parentComment: Periphytic biofilm coats the submerged surfaces in most bodies of water

classDefinition: Periphyton colonizing woody substrata
parentDefinition: Biofilm consisting of a mixture of algae, cyanobacteria, microbes, and detritus.
parentComment: Periphytic biofilm coats the submerged surfaces in most bodies of water

classDefinition: A freshwater stream ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentDefinition: An aquatic biome which is determined by a body of freshwater.

classDefinition: A freshwater stream ecosystem which is undergoing climactic ecological succession.
parentDefinition: An ecosystem in which the composition, structure, and function of resident ecological assemblages are primarily determined by a freshwater stream.

classDefinition: An ecosystem in which the composition, structure, and function of resident ecological assemblages are primarily determined by a freshwater stream.

parentLabel: environmental system determined by a quality
classDefinition: An ecosystem in which the composition, structure, and function of resident ecological assemblages are primarily determined by a freshwater stream.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which is determined by materials bearing roughly homogeneous qualities.
parentComment: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation.

classDefinition: Adfreezing is a freezing process during which two objects adhere to each other via ice.
parentDefinition: A material congelation process during which a liquid turns into a solid when its temperature is lowered below its melting point.

classDefinition: A water temperature which inheres in water close to the surface of an ocean or sea.
parentDefinition: The temperature of some water.
classComment: The exact meaning of surface varies according to the measurement method used, but it is between 1 millimetre (0.04 in) and 20 metres (70 ft) below the sea surface.

classDefinition: The temperature of some water.
parentDefinition: The temperature of some environmental material.

classLabel: concentration of carbon dioxide in soil
parentLabel: concentration of organic molecular entity in soil
classDefinition: The concentration of carbon dioxide when measured in soil.
parentDefinition: The concentration of organic molecular entity when measured in soil.

classLabel: concentration of organic molecular entity in soil
classDefinition: The concentration of organic molecular entity when measured in soil.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a substance by virtue of the amount of the bearer's there is mixed with another substance.

classLabel: concentration of carbon dioxide in air
classDefinition: The concentration of carbon dioxide when measured in air.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a substance by virtue of the amount of the bearer's there is mixed with another substance.

classLabel: concentration of carbon dioxide in freshwater
classDefinition: The concentration of carbon dioxide when measured in freshwater.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a substance by virtue of the amount of the bearer's there is mixed with another substance.

classLabel: concentration of carbon dioxide in seawater
classDefinition: The concentration of carbon dioxide when measured in seawater.
parentDefinition: A quality inhering in a substance by virtue of the amount of the bearer's there is mixed with another substance.

classDefinition: Water which is part of a lake.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: Water which is part of a lake.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

classDefinition: A layer which is composed of ground that is 1) subject to annual thawing and freezing and 2) present in areas underlain by permafrost.
parentDefinition: A layer of environmental material which is subject to freeze-thaw cycles.

classDefinition: A soil surface which is exposed to the troposphere, with no appreciable cover from vegetation or other material.
parentDefinition: A surface layer which is composed primarily of soil.

classDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is composed primarily of organic material.
parentDefinition: An environmental material which is composed primarily of particles.

classDefinition: Particulate organic matter which is composed primarily of carbon.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is composed primarily of organic material.

classDefinition: Particulate organic matter which is composed primarily of nitrogen.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is composed primarily of organic material.

classDefinition: A material accumulation process during which atmospheric carbon dioxide is captured and stored.
parentDefinition: A process during which the mass of one or more materials, present within a given site, increases.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material accumulation process ends a material transport process.

classDefinition: A carbon sequestration process during which atmospheric carbon dioxide is captured and stored by biological processes.
parentDefinition: A material accumulation process during which atmospheric carbon dioxide is captured and stored.

classDefinition: A carbon sequestration process during which carbon dioxide is stored in underground geological formations.
parentDefinition: A material accumulation process during which atmospheric carbon dioxide is captured and stored.

classLabel: carbon sequestration by the ocean carbonate system
classDefinition: A carbon sequestration process during which carbon dioxide is stored in the carbonate system of an ocean.
parentDefinition: A material accumulation process during which atmospheric carbon dioxide is captured and stored.

classDefinition: A disposition inhering in a bearer by virtue of that bearer's ability to, repeatedly, become plastic on heating and harden again on cooling.
An environmental material which is capable of, repeatedly, becoming plastic when heated and hardening again when cooled.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: An environmental material which is capable of, repeatedly, becoming plastic when heated and hardening again when cooled.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: A disposition which inheres in materials capable of becoming rigid when cured by heating.
A polymer which has been irreversibly hardened by heat-induced curing.
parentDefinition: A polymer is a mixture, which is composed of macromolecules of different kinds and which may be differentiated by composition, length, degree of branching etc..
classComment:
Prior to curing, thermoset materials often occur as a soft solid or viscous liquid prepolymer or resin. In the literature, those are often referred to thermosetting resins.
During curing process, well-defined and irreversible chemical networks form in three dimensions thus giving the thermosets a strong and rigid structure that can be added to other materials to increase strength.

classDefinition: A piece of plastic which has a matrix- or sponge-like structure with numerous, hollow internal spaces.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is primarily composed of plastic.
classComment: Depending on the type of plastic used and the organisation of the foam, a piece of plastic foam can show elastic properties (even if the plastic it is made out of does not have elastic properties).

classDefinition: A piece of plastic which is flexible, thin, and planar.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is primarily composed of plastic.
classComment: The edge can be either smooth or angular.

classDefinition: A piece of plastic which 1) is hard, 2) has an irregular shape, and 3) has broken off of a larger piece of plastic.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is primarily composed of plastic.
classComment: To avoid ambiguity, we are being stricter with the "has broken off of a larger piece of plastic" aspect compared to the GESAMP report, which originally stated "having appearance of being broken down from a larger piece of litter".

classDefinition: A piece of plastic which is linear and flexible.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is primarily composed of plastic.

classDefinition: A liquid astronomical body part which 1) vertically spans a water body and 2) has fiat boundaries approximating a columnar shape.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of liquid material.

classDefinition: A collection of organisms which inhabits the same region, ecosystem, or time period.
parentDefinition: A material entity that consists of two or more organisms, viruses, or viroids.
parentComment: May be of the same or different species.

classDefinition: A biota which inhabits a marine ecosystem.
parentDefinition: A collection of organisms which inhabits the same region, ecosystem, or time period.

classDefinition: A biological process during which a material entity is broken down.
parentDefinition: A biological process represents a specific objective that the organism is genetically programmed to achieve. Biological processes are often described by their outcome or ending state, e.g., the biological process of cell division results in the creation of two daughter cells (a divided cell) from a single parent cell. A biological process is accomplished by a particular set of molecular functions carried out by specific gene products (or macromolecular complexes), often in a highly regulated manner and in a particular temporal sequence.

classDefinition: A biodegradation process during which plastic is broken down.
parentDefinition: A biological process during which a material entity is broken down.
classComment: Biodegradation of plastic will lead to reduce molecular weight of that plastic.

classDefinition: A plastic which has a matrix- or sponge-like structure with numerous, hollow internal spaces.
parentDefinition: An environnmental material which 1) is composed primarily of polymers with high molecular mass and 2) once deformed does not spontaneously return to its original shape.
parentComment: "High molecular mass" can be ambiguous as it does not set a threshold for what is considered "high". Here we make no commitment to a threshold.

classDefinition: An environnmental material which 1) is composed primarily of polymers with high molecular mass and 2) once deformed does not spontaneously return to its original shape.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: "High molecular mass" can be ambiguous as it does not set a threshold for what is considered "high". Here we make no commitment to a threshold.
parentComment: Everything under this parent must be a mass noun (i.e. not countable). All subclasses are to be understood as being composed primarily of the named entity, rather than restricted to that entity. For example, "ENVO:water" is to be understood as "environmental material composed primarly of some CHEBI:water".

classDefinition: An environnmental material which 1) is composed primarily of polymers with high molecular mass and 2) once deformed does not spontaneously return to its original shape.
parentDefinition: A material entity which other material entities in an environmental system are primarily or partially composed of.
classComment: "High molecular mass" can be ambiguous as it does not set a threshold for what is considered "high". Here we make no commitment to a threshold.
parentComment: Instances of this class are portions of environmental materials, such as seawater in bucket, a water parcel in the photic zone of a lake, or the concrete that composes a building part. Instances of these portions may have fiat or non-fiat boundaries. For example, a water parcel has not physical boundaries, while the seawater in a bucket is bounded by the internal surfaces of the bucket.

classDefinition: A physical quality which inheres in a liquid or solid bearer by virtue of that bearer trapping a gas in a colloidal suspension throughout its volume.
parentDefinition: A quality of a physical entity that exists through action of continuants at the physical level of organisation in relation to other entities.

classDefinition: A feeding behavior during which material is taken into the body of an organism.
classComment:
Note that ingestion is not limited to materials which provide nutrition to an organism; indigestible or otherwise biologically inaccessible particles may also be ingested by organisms. Ingestion is also not limited to organisms with a mouth and digestive tract, as single-celled organisms like amoebae ingest material with their cell membrane.
https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/pull/1153

classDefinition: A material accumulation process during which material adheres to a solid or liquid surface.
parentDefinition: A process during which the mass of one or more materials, present within a given site, increases.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material accumulation process ends a material transport process.

classDefinition: A material accumulation process during which material builds up on a solid surface such that a function of that surface, or the object it is a part of, is impaired.
parentDefinition: A process during which the mass of one or more materials, present within a given site, increases.
classComment: Following BFO:function semantics, this suggests that the functions of the object of which the surface is a part are affected in their realisation in one or more processes.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material accumulation process ends a material transport process.

classDefinition: A fouling process during which biological matter accumulates on a solid surface.
parentDefinition: A material accumulation process during which material builds up on a solid surface such that a function of that surface, or the object it is a part of, is impaired.
classComment: The biological matter can be microscale (e.g. biofilms created by microorganism) and macroscale (created by macroorganism).
parentComment: Following BFO:function semantics, this suggests that the functions of the object of which the surface is a part are affected in their realisation in one or more processes.

classDefinition: An environmental system process during which two dissimilar materials attach to one another.
parentDefinition: The quality of a environmental system process.
classComment:
The attachment is usually firm, and several mechanisms (mechanical, chemical, dispersive, diffusive, and electrostatic) have been proposed.

This class is related to - but distinct from - those classes listed below:
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C17597
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/GO_0022610
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/APO_0000288

classDefinition: An environmental system process during which the molecules of similar materials are electrically attracted to one another, leading to the formation and maintenance of a microscopic structure holding the materials together.
parentDefinition: The quality of a environmental system process.

classDefinition: A piece of plastic foam which has a near-spherical or granular shape.
parentDefinition: A piece of plastic which has a matrix- or sponge-like structure with numerous, hollow internal spaces.
classComment: These granules are usually white or opaque but can be any color.
parentComment: Depending on the type of plastic used and the organisation of the foam, a piece of plastic foam can show elastic properties (even if the plastic it is made out of does not have elastic properties).

classDefinition: An environmental system process during which a material entity breaks into pieces or parts.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A fragmentation process which is caused by weathering.
parentDefinition: An environmental system process during which a material entity breaks into pieces or parts.
classComment: Some example of materials that undergo fragmentation due to weathering are rocks and plastics.

classDefinition: A piece of plastic which is greater than 1 metre in its longest dimension.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is primarily composed of plastic.
classComment: This classification is based on the thresholds detailed in GESAMP report # 99 on recommendation from the SDG 14 indicator team.

classDefinition: A piece of plastic which is between 25 and 1000 millimetres in its longest dimension.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is primarily composed of plastic.
classComment: This classification is based on the thresholds detailed in GESAMP report # 99 on recommendation from the SDG 14 indicator team. While the definition is in accordance with the common use of this term (as per GESAMP report # 99), alternative size classifications exist and are detailed in the same report. An alternative classification is a piece of plastic which is between 25 and 50 millimetres in its longest dimension.

classDefinition: A piece of plastic which is between 5 and 25 millimetres in its longest dimension.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is primarily composed of plastic.
classComment: This classification is based on the thresholds detailed in GESAMP report # 99 on recommendation from the SDG 14 indicator team. While the definition is in accordance with the common use of this term (as per GESAMP report # 99), alternative size classifications exist. Alternatives classifications are a piece of plastic which is less than 25 millimetres in its longest dimension, or a piece of plastic which is between 1 and 25 millimetres in its longest dimension.

classDefinition: A piece of plastic which has a diameter less than 1 micrometre.
parentDefinition: A mass of solid material which is primarily composed of plastic.
classComment: This classification is based on the thresholds detailed in GESAMP report # 99 on recommendation from the SDG 14 indicator team. While the definition is in accordance with the common use of this term (as per GESAMP report # 99), alternative size classifications exist. An alternative classification is a piece of plastic which has a diameter less than 100 nanometres. The GESAMP report states that it assumes a spherical shape for this size classification, which was understood to mean the generalised form of diameter, i.e. the largest distance between two points belonging to an object.

classDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which includes, as parts, all the entities which are composed primarily of plastic and which are within the gravitational sphere of influence of that body.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of solid material.

classDefinition: Anthropogenic litter which is present in the marine environment.
parentDefinition: A material part of an astronomical body.
classComment: Very large objects that are discarded are typically considered "debris", but this term is loosely defined and there are no standard size classifications which can be used to distinguish debris from litter.
parentComment: Material parts of astronomical bodies generally have boundaries formed by discontinuities in qualities, composition, or other physical characterisitcs. These boundaries are sometimes sharp, and sometimes diffuse, with different classification systems and communities declaring varying thresholds (e.g. for where a shoreline, forest, or other entity begins and ends). However, some boundaries are declared by fiat - that is, by arbitrary human convention or decree - particularly by regulatory or other authorities and communities of practice. The classes in this hierarchy attempt to offer generalisable definitions that allow multiple classfiication systems to map to and interoperate through. If desired, we can create classes that declare thresholds used by a given authority or community under the more generic ones, annotated with source information.

classDefinition: Anthropogenic litter which is present in the marine environment.
parentDefinition: A material entity which has been discarded outside waste management systems by humans or their technologies.
classComment: Very large objects that are discarded are typically considered "debris", but this term is loosely defined and there are no standard size classifications which can be used to distinguish debris from litter.
parentComment: Very large objects that are discarded are typically considered "debris", but this term is loosely defined and there are no standard size classifications which can be used to distinguish debris from litter.

classDefinition: A role which 1) inheres in a material entity 2) is realised when that entity is discarded outside waste management systems by humans or their technologies.
parentDefinition: A realizable entity  the manifestation of which brings about some result or end that is not essential to a continuant  in virtue of the kind of thing that it is but that can be served or participated in by that kind of continuant  in some kinds of natural, social or institutional contexts.

classDefinition: A role which 1) inheres in a material entity 2) is realised when that entity is discarded outside waste management systems by humans or their technologies.
parentDefinition: A role is particular behaviour which a material entity may exhibit.

classDefinition: A plastisphere which is composed primarily of manufactured plastic.
parentDefinition: A part of an astronomical body which includes, as parts, all the entities which are composed primarily of plastic and which are within the gravitational sphere of influence of that body.

classDefinition: Plastic which is composed primarily of polymers produced by processes whose agents do not include humans or their technologies.
parentDefinition: An environnmental material which 1) is composed primarily of polymers with high molecular mass and 2) once deformed does not spontaneously return to its original shape.
parentComment: "High molecular mass" can be ambiguous as it does not set a threshold for what is considered "high". Here we make no commitment to a threshold.

classDefinition: A planned environmental usage process during which any number of fish are caught by humans or their technologies.
parentDefinition: A planned process during which humans access and obtain resources, benefits, or services from a natural or anthropised ecosystem.

classDefinition: An anthropogenic environmental process during which abandoned, lost, or discarded fishing gear attracts and entangles organisms.
parentDefinition: An environmental process which is driven by the action of humans.

classDefinition: A manufactured product which is used for fishing.
parentDefinition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

classDefinition: Abandoned fishing gear which was intentionally left unmaintained and uncontrolled by its custodian.
parentDefinition: Fishing gear which is not under the control of or maintained by its custodian.
classComment: In the literature, including GESAMP Report #99, this term is often referenced as part of abandoned, lost or otherwise discarded fishing gear (ALDFG).
parentComment: In the literature, including GESAMP Report #99, this term is often referenced as part of abandoned, lost or otherwise discarded fishing gear (ALDFG).

classDefinition: Fishing gear which is not under the control of or maintained by its custodian.
parentDefinition: A manufactured product which is used for fishing.
classComment: In the literature, including GESAMP Report #99, this term is often referenced as part of abandoned, lost or otherwise discarded fishing gear (ALDFG).

classDefinition: Abandoned fishing gear which was unintentionally left unmaintained and uncontrolled by its custodian.
parentDefinition: Fishing gear which is not under the control of or maintained by its custodian.
classComment: In the literature, including GESAMP Report #99, this term is often referenced as part of abandoned, lost or otherwise discarded fishing gear (ALDFG).
parentComment: In the literature, including GESAMP Report #99, this term is often referenced as part of abandoned, lost or otherwise discarded fishing gear (ALDFG).

classDefinition: A material transformation process during which the properties of a material are changed as a result of in situ exposure to atmospheric processes.
parentDefinition: A process during which a portion of some environmental material is converted into a different material or a collection of materials.
classComment: The term "weathering" should not be confused with "erosion", which is the removal and transport of environmental material away from a site via exogenic processes.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation. A material transformation process only refers to ENVO:environmental material classes (e.g. bulk and typically impure substances), rather than transformations converting a specific chemical into another.

classDefinition: An environmental system process during which material entities become entrapped, wrapped, twisted, entwined, or otherwise caught in one another.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: A structural quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's being entwined and difficult to unravel.
parentDefinition: A morphology quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's relative position, shape, arrangements and connectivity of an organism's various parts; the pattern underlying its form.

classLabel: entanglement of organisms in marine debris
classDefinition: An entanglement process during which organisms become entrapped in anthropogenic marine debris.
parentDefinition: An environmental system process during which material entities become entrapped, wrapped, twisted, entwined, or otherwise caught in one another.
classComment: Examples of marine debris include boating gear, or fishing gear (active or derelict). Marine debris may be in water or on land.

classDefinition: A polymer which is the output of a biological process.
parentDefinition: A polymer is a mixture, which is composed of macromolecules of different kinds and which may be differentiated by composition, length, degree of branching etc..

classDefinition: A polymer which is the output of a manufacturing process.
parentDefinition: A polymer is a mixture, which is composed of macromolecules of different kinds and which may be differentiated by composition, length, degree of branching etc..

classDefinition: Anthropogenic litter which is present in a coastal environment.
parentDefinition: A material entity which has been discarded outside waste management systems by humans or their technologies.
classComment: Very large objects that are discarded are typically considered "debris", but this term is loosely defined and there are no standard size classifications which can be used to distinguish debris from litter.
parentComment: Very large objects that are discarded are typically considered "debris", but this term is loosely defined and there are no standard size classifications which can be used to distinguish debris from litter.

classDefinition: A manufacturing process which includes plastic as one of its specified outputs.
parentDefinition: A planned process during which raw or recycled materials are transformed into products for use or sale using labour and machines, tools, chemical and biological processing, or formulation.
parentComment: The term may refer to a range of human activity, from handicraft to high tech, but is most commonly applied to industrial production, in which raw materials are transformed into finished goods on a large scale.

classDefinition: Weathering during which plastic is worn or broken down.
parentDefinition: A material transformation process during which the properties of a material are changed as a result of in situ exposure to atmospheric processes.
parentComment: The term "weathering" should not be confused with "erosion", which is the removal and transport of environmental material away from a site via exogenic processes.

classDefinition: A surface layer which is 1) part of a phreatic zone in contact with a vadose zone and 2) contains interstitial water with a pressure head equal to atmospheric pressure.
parentDefinition: A surface layer where the solid or liquid material of an astronomical body comes into contact with an atmosphere or outer space.
parentComment: a useful class: this can be used to define sub-terrestrial and sub-marine entities

classDefinition: Soil compaction is a compaction process during which the bulk density of soil increases and/or its porosity decreases due to externally or internally applied loads.
parentDefinition: A physical process during which atoms, molecules, or other consituents of a material entity are forced closer together.

classDefinition: An elevation which inheres in a water table by virture of its vertical distance from a land surface.
parentDefinition: A positional quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's vertical distance of a point above or below a reference surface.
classComment: While called "depth", this is not the depth of the water table but rather how far it is below a reference plane, usually the soil surface. Thus, this is placed under PATO:elevation which allows for distance above and below a reference point.

classDefinition: A rate which is characteristic of irradiance by photosynthetically active radiation by virtue of the number of photons received by an irradiated surface over time.
parentDefinition: The quality of a environmental system process.
classComment: Often represented in micromoles of photons associated with photosynthetically active radiation per square meter per second.

classDefinition: A rate which is characteristic of irradiance by photosynthetically active radiation by virtue of the number of photons received by an irradiated surface over time.
parentDefinition: A quality of a single process inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's occurrence per unit time.
classComment: Often represented in micromoles of photons associated with photosynthetically active radiation per square meter per second.

classDefinition: A rate which inheres in a soil percolation process.
parentDefinition: A quality of a single process inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's occurrence per unit time.

classDefinition: Liquid water which 1) flows over land and 2) is not absorbed or retained by the materials if flows over or through.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.
classComment: Runoff often gathers debris and solutes from the materials it flows over or through, and often flows into a water body.

classDefinition: A flux which inheres in photosynthetically active radiation.
parentDefinition: A physical quality that exists by virtue of the rate of flow of the bearer across a given surface.
classComment: Often represented in micromoles of photons associated with photosynthetically active radiation per second.

classDefinition: A physical quality that exists by virtue of the rate of flow of the bearer across a given surface.
parentDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's participation in movement.

classDefinition: The number of days during which there is precipitation
parentDefinition: The number of entities of this type that are part of the whole organism.
classComment: The threshold at which a day is considered to be a rainy day is highly variable, and determined at the instance level.

classDefinition: The number of entities of this type that are part of the whole organism.
The depth of the top part of a soil layer.
parentDefinition: A 1-D extent quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's downward or backward or inward dimension.

classDefinition: The depth of the bottom part of a soil layer.
parentDefinition: A 1-D extent quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's downward or backward or inward dimension.

classDefinition: A water flow process during which water occupies the pores or interstices of a solid or semi-solid material.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which a volume of liquid water is transported due to a disequilibria in physical forces.

classDefinition: Albedo which inheres in soil.
parentDefinition: A reflective quality restricted to a particular wavelength.

classDefinition: A reflective quality restricted to a particular wavelength.
parentDefinition: A scalar EM radiation quality which obtains by the capacity of the bearer to scatter or reflect radiation.

classDefinition: Soil albedo which inheres in dry soil.
parentDefinition: Albedo which inheres in soil.

classDefinition: Soil albedo which inheres in moist soil.
parentDefinition: Albedo which inheres in soil.
classComment: This could be axiomatised with PATO:wet, but that isn't likely to map neatly to "moist".

classDefinition: An ion which is 1) adsorbed onto the surfaces of materials with an opposing charge, 2) are readily displaced by other ions, 3) may be displaced and absorbed by organisms.
parentDefinition: A molecular entity having a net electric charge.
classComment: The exchangeable ion pool is the dominant storage pool for calcium, magnesium, and potassium ions. In soil, exchangeable ions are typically bound to the surface of clay and humus colloids.

classDefinition: A potassium ion which is capable of ion exchange.
parentDefinition: An ion which is 1) adsorbed onto the surfaces of materials with an opposing charge, 2) are readily displaced by other ions, 3) may be displaced and absorbed by organisms.
parentComment: The exchangeable ion pool is the dominant storage pool for calcium, magnesium, and potassium ions. In soil, exchangeable ions are typically bound to the surface of clay and humus colloids.

classDefinition: Liquid water which is present in soils as discontinuous volumnes of water in contact with solid and gaseous components of the soil.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

classDefinition: A calcium ion which is capable of ion exchange.
parentDefinition: An ion which is 1) adsorbed onto the surfaces of materials with an opposing charge, 2) are readily displaced by other ions, 3) may be displaced and absorbed by organisms.
parentComment: The exchangeable ion pool is the dominant storage pool for calcium, magnesium, and potassium ions. In soil, exchangeable ions are typically bound to the surface of clay and humus colloids.

classDefinition: A physical quality which inheres in an environmental material by virtue of the material's ability to adsorb exchangeable cations.
parentDefinition: A quality of a physical entity that exists through action of continuants at the physical level of organisation in relation to other entities.
classComment: In soils, these materials include clay and organic matter particles. Soil CEC is measured in millequivalents per 100 grams of soil (meq/100g). A meq is the number of ions which total a specific quantity of electrical charges. Common soil cations include: calcium (Ca++), magnesium (Mg++), potassium (K+), ammonium (NH4+), hydrogen (H+) and sodium (Na+).

classDefinition: A drainage process during which liquid water is transported away from soil.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which a volume of liquid water is transported due to a disequilibria in physical forces.

classDefinition: A drainage process during which liquid water is transported away from soil.
parentDefinition: A material transport process during which a liquid which is not absorbed or otherwise held in place by a material is transported away from its location.
parentComment: Drainage may occur due to natural (e.g. gravitational) or artificial processes (e.g. pumping)

classDefinition: A cation exchange capacity which inheres in an environmental material by virtue of the material's ability to adsorb basic exchangeable cations.
parentDefinition: A physical quality which inheres in an environmental material by virtue of the material's ability to adsorb exchangeable cations.
classComment: The basic cation exchange capacity is often expressed as the percentage of the total exchangeable cations which are basic, known as the percentage base saturation. The percentage base saturation is expressed as follows: %BS = [(Ca2+ + Mg2+ + K+)/CEC] × 100
parentComment: In soils, these materials include clay and organic matter particles. Soil CEC is measured in millequivalents per 100 grams of soil (meq/100g). A meq is the number of ions which total a specific quantity of electrical charges. Common soil cations include: calcium (Ca++), magnesium (Mg++), potassium (K+), ammonium (NH4+), hydrogen (H+) and sodium (Na+).

classDefinition: Energy which has been absorbed by an astronomical body or its parts following that body's irradiation by shortwave radiation from a star.
parentDefinition: A disposition which is realized during the execution of work, the emission of heat, or the possession of mass.
classComment: Despite the label, this is not a shortwave radiation process, but the energy that is absorbed from one. This term is used to describe, e.g., the energy absorbed from insolation and stored by the Earth. Gross shortwave radiation would also include shortwave radiation reflected back into space by clouds, aerosols, and solid surfaces with high albedo.
parentComment: Consider replacing with PATO class; note that PATO class is not a disposition. This should likely go into OBO Core and also have a physicist look at it.

classDefinition: A planned process during which a soil profile is examined and the soil horizons that compose it are described.
parentDefinition: A process that realizes a plan which is the concretization of a plan specification.

classDefinition: Waste water which was converted into an effluent that can be either returned to the water cycle with minimal environmental issues or reused.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

classDefinition: Saline water from which minerals have been removed to produce fresh water suitable for human consumption or irrigation.
parentDefinition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

classDefinition: A recycling process during which the dissolved mineral salts in water are removed
parentDefinition: A process during which materials deemed as waste are separated and converted into a form which can be used as input by the same processes which generated them.
parentComment: This has been created for SDGIO. Revision is likely, but the general meaning should be stable. The frame of reference for determining what is 'waste' and what is a  'resource' is unclear.

classDefinition: Soil which is primarily composed of sand with silt and clay in progressively smaller proportions.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is composed primarily of particles of sand with only minor proportions of other substances.
classComment: Some authorities consider this a soil type, composed of 70-86% of sand, 0-30% of silt and 0-15% of clay. Others consider this a soil material that contains at the upper limit 85 to 90% sand, and the percentage of silt plus 1.5 times the percentage of clay is not less than 15, at the lower limit it contains not less than 70 to 85% sand, and the percentage of silt plus twice the percentage of clay does not exceed 30.
parentComment: This definition is intentionally ambiguous to support the multiple thresholds set by different authorities. Some authorities consider as sands soil material that contains 85% or more sand; the percentage of silt plus 1.5 times the percentage of clay does not exceed 15. coarse sand (sable grossier) 25% or more very coarse and coarse sand, and less than 50% any other one grade of sand.

classDefinition: Sand which is composed primarily of fine particles.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which is composed primarily of particles of sand with only minor proportions of other substances.
classComment: Thresholds for what particle size is considered "fine" vary by region and authority, as well as the tolerance for proportions of other particle sizes.
parentComment: This definition is intentionally ambiguous to support the multiple thresholds set by different authorities. Some authorities consider as sands soil material that contains 85% or more sand; the percentage of silt plus 1.5 times the percentage of clay does not exceed 15. coarse sand (sable grossier) 25% or more very coarse and coarse sand, and less than 50% any other one grade of sand.

classDefinition: Loam which has a high proportion of sand in its composition.
parentDefinition: A portion of enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of some material entity.
classComment: Some authorities consider sandy loam to be a soil composed of 50-70% sand, 0-50% silt, and 0-20% clay. Others, a soil material that contains either 20% or less clay, with a percentage of silt plus twice the percentage of clay that exceeds 30, and 52% or more sand; or less than 7% clay, less than 50% silt, and between 43% and 52% sand.
parentComment: This could be demoted to an inferred class if issues with double inheritance arise.

classDefinition: Loam which has a high proportion of sand in its composition.
parentDefinition: A soil which is composed of approximately equal proportions of sand and silt, with a smaller proportion of clay.
classComment: Some authorities consider sandy loam to be a soil composed of 50-70% sand, 0-50% silt, and 0-20% clay. Others, a soil material that contains either 20% or less clay, with a percentage of silt plus twice the percentage of clay that exceeds 30, and 52% or more sand; or less than 7% clay, less than 50% silt, and between 43% and 52% sand.
parentComment: Some authorities consider loam to be any soil material that contains 7 to 27% clay, 28 to 50% silt, and less than 52% sand.

classDefinition: Loam which has a high proportion of silt in its composition.
parentDefinition: A portion of enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of some material entity.
classComment: USDA textural classes of soils
parentComment: This could be demoted to an inferred class if issues with double inheritance arise.

classDefinition: Loam which has a high proportion of silt in its composition.
parentDefinition: A portion of enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of some material entity.
classComment: Some authorities consider silt loam to be a soil composed of 20-50% of sand, 74-88% silt and 0-27% of clay.
parentComment: This could be demoted to an inferred class if issues with double inheritance arise.

classDefinition: Loam which has a high proportion of silt in its composition.
parentDefinition: A soil which is composed of approximately equal proportions of sand and silt, with a smaller proportion of clay.
classComment: USDA textural classes of soils
parentComment: Some authorities consider loam to be any soil material that contains 7 to 27% clay, 28 to 50% silt, and less than 52% sand.

classDefinition: Loam which has a high proportion of silt in its composition.
parentDefinition: A soil which is composed of approximately equal proportions of sand and silt, with a smaller proportion of clay.
classComment: Some authorities consider silt loam to be a soil composed of 20-50% of sand, 74-88% silt and 0-27% of clay.
parentComment: Some authorities consider loam to be any soil material that contains 7 to 27% clay, 28 to 50% silt, and less than 52% sand.

classDefinition: Clay loam which has a high proportion of sand in its composition.
parentDefinition: Loam which has a high proportion of clay in its composition.
classComment: Some authorities consider sandy clay loam to be a soil composed of 45-80% sand, 0-28% silt, and 20-35% clay.
parentComment: Some authorities consider clay loam to be a soil composed of 20-45% sand, 15-52% silt, and 27 to 40% clay.

classDefinition: Loam which has a high proportion of clay in its composition.
parentDefinition: A portion of enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of some material entity.
classComment: Some authorities consider clay loam to be a soil composed of 20-45% sand, 15-52% silt, and 27 to 40% clay.
parentComment: This could be demoted to an inferred class if issues with double inheritance arise.

classDefinition: Loam which has a high proportion of clay in its composition.
parentDefinition: A soil which is composed of approximately equal proportions of sand and silt, with a smaller proportion of clay.
classComment: Some authorities consider clay loam to be a soil composed of 20-45% sand, 15-52% silt, and 27 to 40% clay.
parentComment: Some authorities consider loam to be any soil material that contains 7 to 27% clay, 28 to 50% silt, and less than 52% sand.

classDefinition: Clay loam which has a high proportion of silt in its composition.
parentDefinition: Loam which has a high proportion of clay in its composition.
classComment: Some authorities consider silty clay loam to be a soil composed of 0-20% of sand, 40-73 of silt and 27-40% of clay.
parentComment: Some authorities consider clay loam to be a soil composed of 20-45% sand, 15-52% silt, and 27 to 40% clay.

classDefinition: Clay which has a high proportion of sand in its composition.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which 1) is composed primarily of clay particles, with only minor proportions of other materials, 2) demonstrates plasticity when wet, and 3) is capable of hardening when dried or fired.
classComment: Some authorities consider sandy clay to be a soil composed of 45-65% of sand, 0-20% of silt and 35-55% of clay. If the proportion of sand exceeds that of clay, it is unclear whether this is still considered clay (due to other properties) or whether a new class "clay sand" should be created.
parentComment: This definition is intentionally ambiguous to support the multiple thresholds set by different authorities.The distinction between silt and clay varies by discipline. Geologists and soil scientists usually consider the separation to occur at a particle size of 2 μm (clays being finer than silts), sedimentologists often use 4–5 μm, and colloid chemists use 1 μm. Geotechnical engineers distinguish between silts and clays based on the plasticity properties of the soil, as measured by the soils' Atterberg limits. ISO 14688 grades clay particles as being smaller than 2 μm and silt particles as being larger. Mixtures of sand, silt and less than 40% clay are called loam. Similar mixtures with greater than 40% clay are often considered clay soils.

classDefinition: Clay which has a high proportion of silt in its composition.
parentDefinition: Particulate environmental material which 1) is composed primarily of clay particles, with only minor proportions of other materials, 2) demonstrates plasticity when wet, and 3) is capable of hardening when dried or fired.
classComment: Some authorities consider this a soil composed of 0-20% of sand, 40-60% of silt and 40-60% of clay. If the proportion of silt exceeds that of clay, it is unclear whether this is still considered clay (due to other properties) or whether a new class "clay silt" should be created.
parentComment: This definition is intentionally ambiguous to support the multiple thresholds set by different authorities.The distinction between silt and clay varies by discipline. Geologists and soil scientists usually consider the separation to occur at a particle size of 2 μm (clays being finer than silts), sedimentologists often use 4–5 μm, and colloid chemists use 1 μm. Geotechnical engineers distinguish between silts and clays based on the plasticity properties of the soil, as measured by the soils' Atterberg limits. ISO 14688 grades clay particles as being smaller than 2 μm and silt particles as being larger. Mixtures of sand, silt and less than 40% clay are called loam. Similar mixtures with greater than 40% clay are often considered clay soils.

parentLabel: concentration of liquid water in soil
classDefinition: A concentration of liquid water in soil arrived at after water which is not retained by the soil has drained away.
parentDefinition: The concentration of a liquid water when measured in soil.
classComment: The determination of field capacity is variable and multiple methods to do so exist. Even in a given soil, the value of field capacity is variable, but serves as a useful measure of its water-holding capacity. Field capacity is often characterized by measuring water content after wetting a soil profile, covering it (to prevent evaporation) and monitoring the change soil moisture in the profile. Water content when the rate of change is relatively small is indicative of when drainage ceases and is called field capacity, it is also termed drained upper limit (DUL). This measure of field capacity is well-correlated with field capacity determined by applying −33 kPa (or −0.33 bar) of hydraulic head or suction pressure (less in sandy soils) to a portion of soil  and subsequently measuring the bulk water content it retains.Field capacity is usually naturally arrived at 2–3 days after rain or irrigation in pervious soils of uniform structure and texture.

classLabel: concentration of liquid water in soil

parentLabel: concentration of liquid water in soil
classDefinition: A concentration of liquid water in soil at or below which a plant will wilt and no longer recover its turgidity when placed in a water saturated atmosphere.
parentDefinition: The concentration of a liquid water when measured in soil.
classComment: The type of plant and soil are sources of variation for values of this concentration. The physical definition of the wilting point is conventionally measured as the water content at −1,500 kPa (−15 bar) of suction pressure, or negative hydraulic head.

classDefinition: The proximal portion of the digestive tract, containing the oral cavity and bounded by the oral opening. In vertebrates, this extends to the pharynx and includes gums, lips, tongue and parts of the palate. Typically also includes the teeth, except where these occur elsewhere (e.g. pharyngeal jaws) or protrude from the mouth (tusks).
parentDefinition: A proximal-distal subdivision of the digestive tract.

parentDefinition: Hydrological precipitation is a process during which any product of the condensation of atmospheric water vapour is pulled to the planetary surface by gravity.
