classDefinition: A gelatinous material primarily composed of exopolymeric compounds with colloidal properties, formed through the aggregation of marine snow particles, often found in large sheets,  flocs, and clouds.
parentDefinition: Environmental material derived from living organisms and composed primarily of one or more biomacromolecules.
classComment: The formation of marine mucilage is often associated with conditions which stress marine microorganisms such as diatoms.

classDefinition: A process in which carbohydrates are transported from the interior of an organism to its surroundings.
parentDefinition: A process during which material is displaced from its original location and transported either to a new location or back to the original location.
parentComment: Experimental class for structural purposes not recommended for annotation.

classDefinition: A process which results in the formation of an island.
parentDefinition: A process in which includes the components of an environmental system as participants.
parentComment: This is a convenience class for organisation and should not be used for annotation.

classDefinition: An island created when a continent is rifted.
parentDefinition: An island that lies on a continental shelf.
classComment: "Examples are Madagascar and Socotra off Africa, the Kerguelen Islands, New Caledonia, New Zealand, and some of the Seychelles." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Island

classDefinition: An island formed by deposition of solid material such as sand or small rocks where a water current loses some of its carrying capacity.
parentDefinition: Area of dry or relatively dry land surrounded by water or low wetland.

classDefinition: An island formed by the accumulation of sand deposited by sea currents on a continental shelves
parentDefinition: An island formed by deposition of solid material such as sand or small rocks where a water current loses some of its carrying capacity.

classDefinition: A wastewater treatment plant that treates industrial wastewater. Industrial wastewater treatment covers the mechanisms and processes used to treat waters that have been contaminated in some way by anthropogenic industrial or commercial activities prior to its release into the environment or its re-use.

A wastewater treatment plant that treats agriculatural wastewater. Agricultural wastewater treatment relates to the treatment of wastewaters produced in the course of agricultural activities. Agriculture is a highly intensified industry in many parts of the world, producing a range of wastewaters requiring a variety of treatment technologies and management practices.
An algal bloom that is located in freshwater. Freshwater algal blooms are the result of an excess of nutrients, particularly some phosphates.
parentDefinition: A feature that arises from a rapid increase or accumulation in the population of algae (typically microscopic) in an aquatic system.

classDefinition: An animal habitation constructed by termites. Termite workers build and maintain nests which house the colony. These are elaborate structures made using a combination of soil, mud, chewed wood/cellulose, saliva, and faeces. A nest has many functions such as providing a protected living space and water conservation (through controlled condensation).
parentDefinition: The dwelling of an animal or group of similar animals.
parentComment: This class represents habitations of non-human animals. This distinction may be removed in future releases.

classDefinition: charcoal that is used as a soil amendment.
parentDefinition: Charcoal is a light, black residue, consisting of carbon and any remaining ash, obtained by removing water and other volatile constituents from animal and vegetation substances. Charcoal is usually produced by slow pyrolysis, the heating of wood or other substances in the absence of oxygen.

classDefinition: A soft, brown, combustible, sedimentary rock formed from naturally compressed peat.
parentDefinition: A combustible black or brownish-black sedimentary rock usually occurring in rock strata in layers or veins called coal beds or coal seams.
classComment: It is considered the lowest rank of coal due to its relatively low heat content. It has a carbon content around 60–70 percent.

parentDefinition: A combustible black or brownish-black sedimentary rock usually occurring in rock strata in layers or veins called coal beds or coal seams.

classDefinition: a relatively soft coal containing a tarlike substance called bitumen or asphalt. It is of higher quality than lignite coal but of poorer quality than anthracite. It is an organic sedimentary rock formed by diagenetic and sub metamorphic compression of peat bog material.
parentDefinition: A combustible black or brownish-black sedimentary rock usually occurring in rock strata in layers or veins called coal beds or coal seams.

classDefinition: A hard, compact variety of coal that has a submetallic luster. It has the highest carbon content, the fewest impurities, and the highest energy density of all types of coal and is the highest ranking of coal.
parentDefinition: A combustible black or brownish-black sedimentary rock usually occurring in rock strata in layers or veins called coal beds or coal seams.
The generation of energy for use by humans
The generation of energy for use by humans

classDefinition: Energy possessed by an object because of its position relative to other objects, stresses within itself, its electric charge, or other factors.
parentDefinition: A disposition which is realized during the execution of work, the emission of heat, or the possession of mass.
parentComment: Consider replacing with PATO class; note that PATO class is not a disposition. This should likely go into OBO Core and also have a physicist look at it.

classDefinition: Energy which is the sum of 1) kinetic energy and 2) potential energy.
parentDefinition: A disposition which is realized during the execution of work, the emission of heat, or the possession of mass.
parentComment: Consider replacing with PATO class; note that PATO class is not a disposition. This should likely go into OBO Core and also have a physicist look at it.

classDefinition: potential energy due to or stored in electric fields.
parentDefinition: Energy possessed by an object because of its position relative to other objects, stresses within itself, its electric charge, or other factors.

classDefinition: potential energy due to or stored in magnetic fields.
parentDefinition: Energy possessed by an object because of its position relative to other objects, stresses within itself, its electric charge, or other factors.

classDefinition: potential energy due to or stored in gravitational fields.
parentDefinition: Energy possessed by an object because of its position relative to other objects, stresses within itself, its electric charge, or other factors.

classDefinition: Potential energy which is stored in chemical bonds and realised through reactions which break them..
parentDefinition: Energy possessed by an object because of its position relative to other objects, stresses within itself, its electric charge, or other factors.

classDefinition: potential energy that binds an electron to its atom or molecule.
parentDefinition: Energy possessed by an object because of its position relative to other objects, stresses within itself, its electric charge, or other factors.

classDefinition: Potential energy due to the energy of the gluon-mediated field of the strong force, binding quarks together into hadrons.
parentDefinition: Energy possessed by an object because of its position relative to other objects, stresses within itself, its electric charge, or other factors.

classDefinition: potential energy due to the deformation of a material (or its container) exhibiting a restorative force.
parentDefinition: Energy possessed by an object because of its position relative to other objects, stresses within itself, its electric charge, or other factors.

classDefinition: Wave energy which inheres in an elastic material and is realised when a deformational wave passes through that material.
parentDefinition: Energy which inheres in a wave and is realised during its propagation.

classDefinition: Wave energy which inheres in an elastic material and is realised when a deformational wave passes through that material.
parentDefinition: Energy which is the sum of 1) kinetic energy and 2) potential energy.

classDefinition: Potential energy which is stored in the fields of propagated by electromagnetic radiation.
parentDefinition: Energy possessed by an object because of its position relative to other objects, stresses within itself, its electric charge, or other factors.

classDefinition: potential energy due to an object's rest mass.
parentDefinition: Energy possessed by an object because of its position relative to other objects, stresses within itself, its electric charge, or other factors.

classDefinition: Kinetic energy which is realised through the microscopic motion of particles.
parentDefinition: Energy which is realised through motion.
classComment: A form of disordered mechanical energy.

classDefinition: Mechanical wave energy which inheres in an atmosphere and is realised during an atmospheric wind.
parentDefinition: Wave energy which inheres in an elastic material and is realised when a deformational wave passes through that material.
Potential energy which is stored in the fields of propagated by electromagnetic radiation.

classDefinition: A power station which burns a fossil fuel such as coal, natural gas, or petroleum to produce electricity.
parentDefinition: A power plant is a building which contains one or more generators which convert mechanical energy into electrical energy through the relative motion between a magnetic field and a conductor. The energy source harnessed to turn the generator varies widely.
A power station which burns a fossil fuel such as coal, natural gas, or petroleum to produce electricity.
A power station which burns a fossil fuel such as coal, natural gas, or petroleum to produce electricity.

A power plant is a building which contains one or more generators which convert mechanical energy into electrical energy through the relative motion between a magnetic field and a conductor. The energy source harnessed to turn the generator varies widely.

classDefinition: Coal heated in the absence of air.
parentDefinition: A combustible black or brownish-black sedimentary rock usually occurring in rock strata in layers or veins called coal beds or coal seams.

classDefinition: A biogeochemical cycle which has oxygen as participant.
parentDefinition: A biogeochemical process during which one or more chemical compounds are sequentially converted into a series of related compounds in a regularly repeating, periodic fashion.

classDefinition: An environmental system determined by an intestine.
parentDefinition: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a digestive tract.

classDefinition: Segment of the alimentary canal extending from the stomach to the anus and, in humans and other mammals, consists of two segments, the small intestine and the large intestine.
parentDefinition: A proximal-distal subdivision of the digestive tract.

classDefinition: Any portion of the organ that covers that body and consists of a layer of epidermis and a layer of dermis.
Any portion of the organ that covers that body and consists of a layer of epidermis and a layer of dermis.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the ectoderm.

classDefinition: Any portion of the organ that covers that body and consists of a layer of epidermis and a layer of dermis.

parentDefinition: An environment which is determined by an anatomical entity.

classDefinition: Connected anatomical system that forms a barrier between an animal and its environment. In vertebrates, the integumental system consists of the epidermis, dermis plus associated glands and adnexa such as hair and scales. In invertebrates, the integumental system may include cuticle.

Connected anatomical system that forms a barrier between an animal and its environment. In vertebrates, the integumental system consists of the epidermis, dermis plus associated glands and adnexa such as hair and scales. In invertebrates, the integumental system may include cuticle.
parentDefinition: Multicellular, connected anatomical structure that has multiple organs as parts and whose parts work together to achieve some shared function.
An environment determined by an area or zone of skin tissue.

classDefinition: A zone of skin that is part of the face.
parentDefinition: A zone of skin that is part of a head [Automatically generated definition].

classDefinition: One of the epidermal growths that form the distinctive outer covering, or plumage, on birds. Feathers are formed in tiny follicles in the epidermis, or outer skin layer, that produce keratin proteins.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the ectoderm.

classDefinition: One of the epidermal growths that form the distinctive outer covering, or plumage, on birds. Feathers are formed in tiny follicles in the epidermis, or outer skin layer, that produce keratin proteins.
parentDefinition: Anatomical projection that protrudes from the skin. Examples: hair, nail, feather, claw, hoof, horn, wattle, spur, beak, antler, bristle and some scales.

parentDefinition: A liquid that flows very easily at room temperature. Examples are: water, apple juice, sherry, acidophilus milk, whipping cream and some heavy liqueurs. The range of low viscosity liquid spans sucrose solutions between 0 and 45% solids (viscosity range from 1 to 10 centipoise). Prefer 'solid pieces' factor term to 'small particles' if both appear in the food.

classDefinition: A liquid that flows very easily at room temperature. Examples are: water, apple juice, sherry, acidophilus milk, whipping cream and some heavy liqueurs. The range of low viscosity liquid spans sucrose solutions between 0 and 45% solids (viscosity range from 1 to 10 centipoise). Prefer 'solid pieces' factor term to 'small particles' if both appear in the food.
parentDefinition: A state of matter between a solid and a gas, in which a substance has the capacity to flow and conforms to the shape of the container. Liquids range from water to honey, corresponding to a range in viscosity (or apparent viscosity) from 1 to 500 centipoise (viscosity is a measure of a liquid's resistance to flow). Products that are pourable but have a higher viscosity are *SEMILIQUID*.
parentComment:
SIREN DB annotation:
* has quality 'liquid' (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/FOODON_03430130)

classDefinition: Food material for humans and animals which is processed with the intention that it be consumable as a whole or added to other food products.
parentDefinition: Any substance that can be consumed by an organism to satisfy nutritional or other health needs, or to provide a social or organoleptic food experience
classComment: The FoodOn "food product" class is provided as a branch under which new food product categories and food products themselves can be placed. Here classes are provided to differentiate a food product by its food composition, processing and/or consumption characteristics. This avoids brand name products but it may include generic food dish categories. It has a much greater depth and polyhierarchy than other agency product type schemes have in an effort to group related products together.  The upper level basis of this tree originated in the environment ontology (ENVO) and from the US Code of Federal Regulations.
parentComment: This class is the top of FOODON's main food product hierarchy which is described in the https://www.foodon.org website, and can be searched in lookup services like https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/

classDefinition: A food product made from domestic pig meat (Sus domesticus or Sus scrofa scrofa).

parentDefinition: Suidae is a family of artiodactyl mammals which are commonly called pigs, hogs or boars. In addition to numerous fossil species, 17 extant species are currently recognized (or 18 counting domestic pigs and wild boars separately), classified into between four and eight genera. The family includes the domestic pig, Sus scrofa domesticus or Sus domesticus, in addition to numerous species of wild pig, such as babirusas and warthogs. All suids, or swine, are native to the Old World, ranging from Asia to Europe and Africa.

A food product from a category of domestic birds kept for meat, eggs, and feathers including fowl such as chickens, turkeys, and waterfowls such as domestic ducks and geese and other meat birds such as pigeons and doves and games birds including pheasants.

Suidae is a family of artiodactyl mammals which are commonly called pigs, hogs or boars. In addition to numerous fossil species, 17 extant species are currently recognized (or 18 counting domestic pigs and wild boars separately), classified into between four and eight genera. The family includes the domestic pig, Sus scrofa domesticus or Sus domesticus, in addition to numerous species of wild pig, such as babirusas and warthogs. All suids, or swine, are native to the Old World, ranging from Asia to Europe and Africa.
parentDefinition: A food product made of meat, the skeletal muscle and associated fat, and other edible tissues such as organs, livers, skin, brains, bone marrow, kidneys, or lungs, of mammals.

classDefinition: A food product which normally exists as an ingredient to another food product, rather than eaten on its own, and is more complex than a chemical food component.
parentDefinition: Food material for humans and animals which is processed with the intention that it be consumable as a whole or added to other food products.
parentComment: The FoodOn "food product" class is provided as a branch under which new food product categories and food products themselves can be placed. Here classes are provided to differentiate a food product by its food composition, processing and/or consumption characteristics. This avoids brand name products but it may include generic food dish categories. It has a much greater depth and polyhierarchy than other agency product type schemes have in an effort to group related products together.  The upper level basis of this tree originated in the environment ontology (ENVO) and from the US Code of Federal Regulations.

classDefinition: A beverage product derived from leaves of the tea plant (Camellia sinensis).
classComment: "While fermentation is also referred to in the production of brewed teas, this is inaccurate. Some herbal teas on the market today include probiotic cultures alongside tea leaves to maintain gut health but the tea itself hasn't been fermented. Most dried teas however don't use live cultures at all during production. Instead, harvested tea leaves undergo a natural chemical process known as oxidation, which also changes the color, flavor and level of health benefits in the resulting brew." [https://eatcultured.com/blogs/our-awesome-blog/fermented-tea]

parentLabel: extract, concentrate or isolate of plant or animal
classDefinition: A lipid food product is a food product made primarily of plant or animal fat or oil
parentDefinition: A physical-chemical component separated from the food source or its parts by extraction, centrifugation, filtration, heat processing, expressing or a similar process. The separated component may be converted through further processing. If this is done, the final substance is indexed. A water-extracted component may remain in aqueous dispersion. The extract, concentrate or isolate is indexed in preference to the anatomic part from which it is derived. For example, peanut oil is indexed under *PEANUT* combined wih *FAT OR OIL* rather than with *SEED OR KERNEL*. On the other hand, fruit and vegetable juices can be indexed under *FRUIT JUICE OR NECTAR* or *VEGETABLE JUICE* (A. PRODUCT TYPE); therefore the anatomic part of the plant should be indexed.

classDefinition: A product of the dry seeds of plants of the genus Pisum.
parentDefinition: PULSES are annual leguminous crops yielding from one to 12 grains or seeds of variable size, shape and colour within a pod. They are used for both food and feed. The term "pulses" is limited to crops harvested solely for dry grain, thereby excludingcrops harvested green for food (green peas, green beans, etc.) which are classified as vegetable crops. Also excluded are those crops used mainly for oil extraction (e.g.soybeand and groundnuts) and leguminous crops (e.g. seeds of clover and alfalfa) that are used exclusively for sowing purposes.

The term "pulses" is limited to crops harvested solely for dry grain, thereby excludingcrops harvested green for food (green peas, green beans, etc.) which are classified as vegetable crops. Also excluded are those crops used mainly for oil extraction (e.g.soybeand and groundnuts) and leguminous crops (e.g. seeds of clover and alfalfa) that are used exclusively for sowing purposes.

classDefinition: A product of the  dry seeds of Vicia sativa.

Pachyrhizus erosus, commonly known as jicama Mexican yam bean, or Mexican turnip, is the name of a native Mexican vine, although the name most commonly refers to the plant's edible tuberous root. Jícama is a species in the genus Pachyrhizus in the bean family (Fabaceae). Plants in this genus are commonly referred to as yam bean, although the term "yam bean" can be another name for jícama.

In contrast to the root, the remainder of the jícama plant is very poisonous; the seeds contain the toxin rotenone, which is used to poison insects and fish.

FAO: The yam bean is a legume but unlike its close relatives the soybean and other beans, the yam bean is cultivated for its large, tuberous roots.

parentComment: "While fermentation is also referred to in the production of brewed teas, this is inaccurate. Some herbal teas on the market today include probiotic cultures alongside tea leaves to maintain gut health but the tea itself hasn't been fermented. Most dried teas however don't use live cultures at all during production. Instead, harvested tea leaves undergo a natural chemical process known as oxidation, which also changes the color, flavor and level of health benefits in the resulting brew." [https://eatcultured.com/blogs/our-awesome-blog/fermented-tea]

classComment:
The definition of this is being discussed in issue: https://github.com/FoodOntology/foodon/issues/57

Namely, how to characterize the threshold of ingredients that make for multi-component classification? Salt, pepper, spices wouldn't normally make a food multi-component?
parentComment: The FoodOn "food product" class is provided as a branch under which new food product categories and food products themselves can be placed. Here classes are provided to differentiate a food product by its food composition, processing and/or consumption characteristics. This avoids brand name products but it may include generic food dish categories. It has a much greater depth and polyhierarchy than other agency product type schemes have in an effort to group related products together.  The upper level basis of this tree originated in the environment ontology (ENVO) and from the US Code of Federal Regulations.

parentComment: The FoodOn "food product" class is provided as a branch under which new food product categories and food products themselves can be placed. Here classes are provided to differentiate a food product by its food composition, processing and/or consumption characteristics. This avoids brand name products but it may include generic food dish categories. It has a much greater depth and polyhierarchy than other agency product type schemes have in an effort to group related products together.  The upper level basis of this tree originated in the environment ontology (ENVO) and from the US Code of Federal Regulations.

classDefinition: A preserved food, where the moisture levels in the food product have been reduced to low levels to improve shelf life.

classLabel: extract, concentrate or isolate of plant or animal
classDefinition: A physical-chemical component separated from the food source or its parts by extraction, centrifugation, filtration, heat processing, expressing or a similar process. The separated component may be converted through further processing. If this is done, the final substance is indexed. A water-extracted component may remain in aqueous dispersion. The extract, concentrate or isolate is indexed in preference to the anatomic part from which it is derived. For example, peanut oil is indexed under *PEANUT* combined wih *FAT OR OIL* rather than with *SEED OR KERNEL*. On the other hand, fruit and vegetable juices can be indexed under *FRUIT JUICE OR NECTAR* or *VEGETABLE JUICE* (A. PRODUCT TYPE); therefore the anatomic part of the plant should be indexed.
parentDefinition: A food product which normally exists as an ingredient to another food product, rather than eaten on its own, and is more complex than a chemical food component.

classDefinition: Jelled product made from one or more fruit juices and optional ingredients. Includes both fruit jelly, which may be sweetened with nutritive carbohydrate sweeteners, (21 CFR 150.140), and artificially sweetened fruit jelly (21 CFR 150.141). The finished fruit jelly must have a soluble solid content of no less than 65% and the ratio by weight of the fruit ingredient to sweetener in the starting mixture must be no less than 45:55. Artificially sweetened fruit jelly must contain no less than 55% fruit ingredient by weight.

classLabel: Codex Alimentarius classification of food and feed commodities
classDefinition:
Codex Alimentarius, Volume 2 - 1993, Section 2:  Pesticide Residues in Food.

The Codex Classification of food and animal feed commodities moving in trade and the description of the various items and groups of food and animal feedstuffs included in the present document have been developed by the Codex Committee on Pesticide Residues. It was first adopted by the 18th Session of the Codex Alimentarius Commission, (1989).

The Codex Classification includes food commodities and animal feedstuffs for which Codex maximum residue limits will not necessarily be established. The Classification is intended to be as complete a listing of food commodities in trade as possible, classified into groups on the basis of the commodity's similar potential for pesticide residues.

The Classification may also be appropriate for other purposes such as setting maximum levels for other types of residues or for other contaminants in food. The Codex Classification should be consulted in order to obtain a precise description of the food or animal feed commodities and, especially, in cases where Codex maximum residue limits have been set for groups of food and groups of animal feedstuffs. The Codex Classification is intended to promote harmonization of the terms used to describe commodities which are subject to maximum residue limits and of the approach to grouping commodities with similar potential for residue for which a common group maximum residue limit can be set.
parentDefinition: Renamed from *PRODUCT TYPE, CODEX ALIMENTARIUS* in LanguaL 2008.

parentLabel: a.  primary food commodities of plant origin (ccpr)
classDefinition:
Vegetables are foods derived from many different kinds of plants mostly annual and usually cultivated, commonly known by custom and tradition as "vegetables".
In several countries, some of these commodities grown on large areas are distinguished as "field crops" or arable crops e.g. sugar beet. For the sake of convenience in this guide such crops are classified under Type 2 Vegetables.
Exposure to pesticides is dependent on the particular part of the plant used for food and the growing practices.
Vegetables may be consumed in whole or in part and in the form of fresh, dried or processed foods.
parentComment: LanguaL curation note: This term is for CLASSIFICATION ONLY; DO NOT USE term in indexing. Use a more precise narrower term.

classDefinition:
Pulses are derived from the mature seeds naturally or artificially dried, of leguminous plants known as beans (dry) and peas (dry).
The seeds in the pods are protected from most pesticides applied during the growing season except pesticides which show a systemic action. The dried beans and peas however are often exposed to post-harvest treatments.
The dry pulses are consumed after processing or household cooking.
parentDefinition:

Exposure to pesticides is dependent on the particular part of the plant used for food and the growing practices.
Vegetables may be consumed in whole or in part and in the form of fresh, dried or processed foods.

classDefinition:
The Global System 1 (GS1) Global Product Classification (GPC) is a system that gives buyers and sellers a common language for grouping products in the same way, everywhere in the world.$br/$
The GS1 GPC classification in facet A is currently updated based on June 2017 release of GS1 GPC Standard for Food/Beverage/Tobacco, except for codes pertaining to tobacco. See the GS1 site for details [https://www.gs1.org/standards/gpc].

parentLabel: extract, concentrate or isolate of plant or animal
classDefinition: Extract, concentrate or isolate high in sugar, oligosaccharide or polysaccharide.
parentDefinition: A physical-chemical component separated from the food source or its parts by extraction, centrifugation, filtration, heat processing, expressing or a similar process. The separated component may be converted through further processing. If this is done, the final substance is indexed. A water-extracted component may remain in aqueous dispersion. The extract, concentrate or isolate is indexed in preference to the anatomic part from which it is derived. For example, peanut oil is indexed under *PEANUT* combined wih *FAT OR OIL* rather than with *SEED OR KERNEL*. On the other hand, fruit and vegetable juices can be indexed under *FRUIT JUICE OR NECTAR* or *VEGETABLE JUICE* (A. PRODUCT TYPE); therefore the anatomic part of the plant should be indexed.
parentComment: Damion Dooley's note: Items in this branch will be merged into foodon food product branch.

classDefinition: A state of matter between a solid and a gas, in which a substance has the capacity to flow and conforms to the shape of the container. Liquids range from water to honey, corresponding to a range in viscosity (or apparent viscosity) from 1 to 500 centipoise (viscosity is a measure of a liquid's resistance to flow). Products that are pourable but have a higher viscosity are *SEMILIQUID*.
parentDefinition: A class which contains food product categories qualified by a quality such as granularity or temperature, which is useful for tasks like food inspection where little prior knowledge of how the food came to be is available. Some terms like "food (frozen)" are both a quality descriptor and the output of a process.

classDefinition: A multicellular organismal process carried out by any of the organs or tissues in an organ system. An organ system is a regularly interacting or interdependent group of organs or tissues that work together to carry out a biological objective.
parentDefinition: Any biological process, occurring at the level of a multicellular organism, pertinent to its function.

classDefinition: Any biological process, occurring at the level of a multicellular organism, pertinent to its function.
parentDefinition: A biological process represents a specific objective that the organism is genetically programmed to achieve. Biological processes are often described by their outcome or ending state, e.g., the biological process of cell division results in the creation of two daughter cells (a divided cell) from a single parent cell. A biological process is accomplished by a particular set of molecular functions carried out by specific gene products (or macromolecular complexes), often in a highly regulated manner and in a particular temporal sequence.

parentDefinition: A size quality which is relatively normal or average

classDefinition: A depth quality which is relatively normal or average
parentDefinition: A 1-D extent quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's downward or backward or inward dimension.

classDefinition: A depth quality which is relatively normal or average
parentDefinition: A size quality which is relatively normal or average

classDefinition: A volume which is relatively normal or average
parentDefinition: A 3-D extent quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's amount of 3-dimensional space it occupies.

classDefinition: A volume which is relatively normal or average
parentDefinition: A size quality which is relatively normal or average

classDefinition: A width which is relatively normal or average
parentDefinition: A 1-D extent quality which is equal to the distance from one side of an object to another side which is opposite.

classDefinition: A width which is relatively normal or average
parentDefinition: A size quality which is relatively normal or average

classDefinition: A speed which is relatively normal or average
parentDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's scalar absolute value of the rate of change of the bearer's position.

classDefinition: A speed which is relatively normal or average
parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is normal or average.

classDefinition: A velocity which is relatively normal or average
parentDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's rate of change of the position.

classDefinition: A velocity which is relatively normal or average
parentDefinition: A quality of an object that has a value that is normal or average.

classDefinition: The four cardinal directions or cardinal points are the directions north, east, south, and west, commonly denoted by their initials, N, E, S, W. East and west are at right angles to north and south, with east being in the clockwise direction of rotation from north and west being directly opposite east.
parentDefinition: A physical quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's orientation in space.

classDefinition: North is one of the four compass points or cardinal directions. It is the opposite of south and is perpendicular to east and west.
parentDefinition: The four cardinal directions or cardinal points are the directions north, east, south, and west, commonly denoted by their initials, N, E, S, W. East and west are at right angles to north and south, with east being in the clockwise direction of rotation from north and west being directly opposite east.

classDefinition: East is one of the four cardinal directions or points of the compass. It is the opposite direction from west.
parentDefinition: The four cardinal directions or cardinal points are the directions north, east, south, and west, commonly denoted by their initials, N, E, S, W. East and west are at right angles to north and south, with east being in the clockwise direction of rotation from north and west being directly opposite east.

classDefinition: South is one of the four cardinal directions or compass points. South is the polar opposite of north and is perpendicular to east and west.
parentDefinition: The four cardinal directions or cardinal points are the directions north, east, south, and west, commonly denoted by their initials, N, E, S, W. East and west are at right angles to north and south, with east being in the clockwise direction of rotation from north and west being directly opposite east.

classDefinition: West is one of the four cardinal directions or points of the compass. It is the opposite direction from east.
parentDefinition: The four cardinal directions or cardinal points are the directions north, east, south, and west, commonly denoted by their initials, N, E, S, W. East and west are at right angles to north and south, with east being in the clockwise direction of rotation from north and west being directly opposite east.

classDefinition: A material entity that is one or more organisms, viruses or viroids.
parentDefinition: An independent continuant that is spatially extended whose identity is independent of that of other entities and can be maintained through time.

classDefinition: A material entity that is one or more organisms, viruses or viroids.
parentDefinition: An independent continuant that is spatially extended whose identity is independent of that of other entities and can be maintained through time.

classDefinition: A material entity that has as parts two or more organisms, viruses, or viroids of the same species and no members of any other species.
parentDefinition: A material entity that consists of two or more organisms, viruses, or viroids.
parentComment: May be of the same or different species.

classDefinition: A collection of organisms that consists of two or more organisms from at least two species.
parentDefinition: A material entity that consists of two or more organisms, viruses, or viroids.
parentComment: May be of the same or different species.

classDefinition: A multi-species collection of organisms that consists of two or more microbes from at least two species.
parentDefinition: A collection of organisms that consists of two or more organisms from at least two species.

classDefinition: A plant anatomical entity (PO:0025131) that is, or was, part of a plant, or was derived from a part of a plant.
parentDefinition: An anatomical entity that is or was part of a plant.
classComment: 'Part' includes both proper parts and the whole plant. CARO:0000003 'connected anatomical structure' is defined as: Material anatomical entity that is a single connected structure with inherent 3D shape, generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome.
parentComment: Includes both material entities such as plant structures and immaterial entities such as plant anatomical spaces. CARO:0000000 'anatomical entity' is defined as: A part of a cellular organism that is either an immaterial entity or a material entity with granularity aboove the level of a protein complex.  Or, a substance produced by a cellular organism with granularity above the level of a protein complex.  Refers to BFO:0000004 'independent continuant'.

classDefinition: A portion of plant substance (PO:0025161) composed of cutin (PO:0025385), a polyester matrix of hydroxy- and hydroxy epoxy fatty acids C16 and C18 chains, embedded and overlayed with cuticular wax (PO:0025386) and forming a layer on the surface of a plant epidermis (PO:0005679).
parentDefinition: A portion of organism substance that is or was part of a plant.
classComment: The plant cuticle is produced in and secreted by epidermal cells (PO:0004013) of leaves (PO:0025034), stems (PO:0009047), fruits (PO:0009001), and other aerial plant structures. It has as parts an inner cuticle proper (PO:0025387) and an outer layer of epicuticular wax (PO:0025388).
parentComment: Refers to organism substance (CARO:0000004) which is defined as: Material anatomical entity in a gaseous, liquid, semisolid or solid state; produced by anatomical structures or derived from inhaled and ingested substances that have been modified by anatomical structures as they pass through the body and that does not have inherent 3D shape generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome. For plants, the word "body" refers to a whole plant, or part thereof.  Includes substances such as latex, xylem sap, phloem sap, resin, mucilage, oil, cuticle, cutin, and sporopollenin.

classDefinition: A portion of plant tissue (PO:0009007) composed of epidermal cells (PO:0004013) that develops from the protoderm (PO:0006210) and covers the surface of a plant structure (PO:0009011).
parentDefinition: A plant structure (PO:0009011) that consists predominantly of similarly specialized plant cells (PO:0009002) of one or more types.
classComment: The epidermis can be composed of one or more layers of cells. In some species of vascular plants, the epidermis, which is a primary tissue, is replaced by periderm, which is secondary tissue, later in development. The epidermis can also include trichomes, stomatal pores, root hairs, and rhizoids.
parentComment: A portion of plant tissue may contain one or several types of cells that are organized in a specific spatial arrangement into a structural unit (which includes a mass of callus) and may include an intercellular matrix. May include other types of isolated cells, such as idioblasts.

classDefinition: A shoot axis (PO:0025029) that is the most distal part of a shoot system (PO:0009006) and has as parts a shoot apical meristem (PO:0020148) and the youngest primordia (PO:0025127).
parentDefinition: A plant axis (PO:0025004) that is part of a shoot system (PO:0009006).
parentComment: Often bears leaves and branches. In vascular plants, has at least one node and one internode.

classDefinition: A plant axis (PO:0025004) that is part of a shoot system (PO:0009006).
parentDefinition: An axial plant organ (PO:0009008).
classComment: Often bears leaves and branches. In vascular plants, has at least one node and one internode.
parentComment: Includes roots and shoots.

classDefinition: A portion of shoot system epidermis (PO:0006035) that is part of a shoot axis (PO:0025029).
parentDefinition: A portion of epidermis (PO:0005679) that is part of a shoot system (PO:0009006) and arises from the meristem L1 layer (PO:0009020).
classComment: Can occur on a stem or branch.
parentComment: Often interrupted by stomatal complexes (PO:0002000) and other structures. The shoot system epidermis is different from the root epidermis (PO:0006036) in its origin, function and structure.

classDefinition: A portion of epidermis (PO:0005679) that is part of a shoot system (PO:0009006) and arises from the meristem L1 layer (PO:0009020).
parentDefinition: A portion of plant tissue (PO:0009007) composed of epidermal cells (PO:0004013) that develops from the protoderm (PO:0006210) and covers the surface of a plant structure (PO:0009011).
classComment: Often interrupted by stomatal complexes (PO:0002000) and other structures. The shoot system epidermis is different from the root epidermis (PO:0006036) in its origin, function and structure.
parentComment: The epidermis can be composed of one or more layers of cells. In some species of vascular plants, the epidermis, which is a primary tissue, is replaced by periderm, which is secondary tissue, later in development. The epidermis can also include trichomes, stomatal pores, root hairs, and rhizoids.

classDefinition: A portion of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) which is the organogenic region of the meristem, characterized by higher rates of cell division.
parentDefinition: A portion of plant tissue (PO:0009007) in which plant cells (PO:0009002) have retained their embryonic characteristics, or have reverted to them secondarily, and that divide to produce new cells that can undergo differentiation to form mature tissues, i.e. they have a capacity for morphogenesis and growth.

classDefinition: A portion of plant tissue (PO:0009007) in which plant cells (PO:0009002) have retained their embryonic characteristics, or have reverted to them secondarily, and that divide to produce new cells that can undergo differentiation to form mature tissues, i.e. they have a capacity for morphogenesis and growth.
parentDefinition: A plant structure (PO:0009011) that consists predominantly of similarly specialized plant cells (PO:0009002) of one or more types.
parentComment: A portion of plant tissue may contain one or several types of cells that are organized in a specific spatial arrangement into a structural unit (which includes a mass of callus) and may include an intercellular matrix. May include other types of isolated cells, such as idioblasts.

classDefinition: A shoot system meristem (PO:0006079) formed at the apex of the shoot axis (PO:0025029), including those originating from an axillary bud meristem (PO:0000232).
parentDefinition: A portion of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) that is part of a shoot system (PO:0009006).

classDefinition: A shoot system meristem (PO:0006079) formed at the apex of the shoot axis (PO:0025029), including those originating from an axillary bud meristem (PO:0000232).
parentDefinition: A maximal portion of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) located at a shoot apex (PO:0000037) or root tip (PO:0000025).

classDefinition: A native plant cell (PO:0025606) synthesizing protoplasm and producing new cells by division and with only a primary cell wall.
parentDefinition: A plant cell (PO:0009002) that is either part of a multicellular whole plant (PO:0000003) 'in vivo' or a unicellular organism 'in natura' (i.e. part of a natural environment).
parentComment: A native plant cell is one that is not grown or maintained in vitro, nor part of an in vitro plant structure (PO:0000004).

classDefinition: A plant cell (PO:0009002) that is either part of a multicellular whole plant (PO:0000003) 'in vivo' or a unicellular organism 'in natura' (i.e. part of a natural environment).
parentDefinition: A cell which is a plant structure (PO:0009011).
classComment: A native plant cell is one that is not grown or maintained in vitro, nor part of an in vitro plant structure (PO:0000004).
parentComment: Applies to cells that are living or dead at maturity (e.g., fiber cell or tracheid) and includes any external encapsulating structures (if present) such as the plasma membrane and the plant-type cell wall. Definition of cell GO:0005623: "The basic structural and functional unit of all organisms. Includes the plasma membrane and any external encapsulating structures such as the cell wall and cell envelope". GO:0009505. Definition of plant-type cell wall (GO:0009505): A more or less rigid structure lying outside the cell membrane of a cell and composed of cellulose and pectin and other organic and inorganic substances, synonym; exact: cellulose and pectin-containing cell wall.

classDefinition: A primordium (PO:0025127) that develops from a root anlagen (PO:0025433) and is committed to the development of a root (PO:0009005).
parentDefinition: A portion of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) that has as parts protoderm (PO:0006210) and sub-epidermal meristematic tissue and is committed to the development of a particular plant structure (PO:0009011).
classComment: A root primordium may arise from cells of a pericycle (PO:0006203) in a root in most seed plant (pericyclic lateral root primordium; PO:0025492), from cells of an endodermis (PO:0000252) in ferns and some seed plants (non-pericyclic lateral root primordium: PO:0025493), or from cells of a shoot axis (PO:0025029), in the case of a basal root primordium (PO:0025479) or shoot-borne root primordium (PO:0025480). Transition from root primordium to root occurs with the formation of a root cap (PO:0020123), shortly after the development of a root apical meristem (PO:0020147).
parentComment: A primordium appears as a protrusion and is the first distinct form of a plant organ (PO:0009008), cardinal organ part (PO:0025001), or collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007). The transition from a primordium to the plant structure it develops into is marked by the development of non-meristematic cells, although meristematic cells may be present after the transition.

classDefinition: A portion of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) that has as parts protoderm (PO:0006210) and sub-epidermal meristematic tissue and is committed to the development of a particular plant structure (PO:0009011).
parentDefinition: A portion of plant tissue (PO:0009007) in which plant cells (PO:0009002) have retained their embryonic characteristics, or have reverted to them secondarily, and that divide to produce new cells that can undergo differentiation to form mature tissues, i.e. they have a capacity for morphogenesis and growth.
classComment: A primordium appears as a protrusion and is the first distinct form of a plant organ (PO:0009008), cardinal organ part (PO:0025001), or collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007). The transition from a primordium to the plant structure it develops into is marked by the development of non-meristematic cells, although meristematic cells may be present after the transition.

classDefinition: A portion of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) that is committed to the development of a root primordium (PO:0005029).
parentDefinition: A portion of plant tissue (PO:0009007) in which plant cells (PO:0009002) have retained their embryonic characteristics, or have reverted to them secondarily, and that divide to produce new cells that can undergo differentiation to form mature tissues, i.e. they have a capacity for morphogenesis and growth.
classComment: Only detectable by gene expression, not morphology. May arise in a pericycle (PO:0006203), as for lateral roots in most seed plants, an endodermis (PO:0000252), as for lateral roots in ferns, or from parenchyma cells (PO:0000074) that are part a shoot axis (PO:0025029), in the case of a basal root (PO:0025002) or shoot-borne root (PO:0000042).

classDefinition: A plant structure (PO:0009011) that consists predominantly of similarly specialized plant cells (PO:0009002) of one or more types.
parentDefinition: A plant anatomical entity (PO:0025131) that is, or was, part of a plant, or was derived from a part of a plant.
classComment: A portion of plant tissue may contain one or several types of cells that are organized in a specific spatial arrangement into a structural unit (which includes a mass of callus) and may include an intercellular matrix. May include other types of isolated cells, such as idioblasts.
parentComment: 'Part' includes both proper parts and the whole plant. CARO:0000003 'connected anatomical structure' is defined as: Material anatomical entity that is a single connected structure with inherent 3D shape, generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome.

classDefinition: A portion of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) that is the outer layer of an apical meristem (PO:0020144), or the outer layer of a plant embryo proper (PO:0000001), and gives rise to a portion of epidermis (PO:0005679).
parentDefinition: A portion of plant tissue (PO:0009007) in which plant cells (PO:0009002) have retained their embryonic characteristics, or have reverted to them secondarily, and that divide to produce new cells that can undergo differentiation to form mature tissues, i.e. they have a capacity for morphogenesis and growth.
classComment: A protoderm may or may not arise from independent initial cells (PO:0004011). Some researchers also refer to it as an epidermis in a  meristematic state.

classDefinition: A lateral plant organ (PO:0009008) produced by a shoot apical meristem (PO:0020148).
parentDefinition: A multi-tissue plant structure (PO:0025496) that is a functional unit, is a proper part of a whole plant (PO:0000003), and includes portions of plant tissue (PO:0009007) of at least two different types that derive from a common developmental path.
parentComment: Examples include stem (PO:0009047), leaf (PO:0025034), and root (PO:0009005). May include individual plant cells (PO:0009002) that are not part of a portion of plant tissue (e.g., idioblasts, PO:0000283). A plant organ may have one or more different plant organs as parts, such as a sporophyll (PO:0009026) that may have as part a sporangium (PO:0025094) or a carpel (PO:0009030) that may have as part a plant ovule (PO:0020003).

classDefinition: A multi-tissue plant structure (PO:0025496) that is a functional unit, is a proper part of a whole plant (PO:0000003), and includes portions of plant tissue (PO:0009007) of at least two different types that derive from a common developmental path.
parentDefinition: A plant structure (PO:0009011) that has as parts two or more portions of plant tissue (PO:0009007) of at least two different types and which through specific morphogenetic processes forms a single structural unit demarcated by primarily bona-fide boundaries from other structural units of different types.
classComment: Examples include stem (PO:0009047), leaf (PO:0025034), and root (PO:0009005). May include individual plant cells (PO:0009002) that are not part of a portion of plant tissue (e.g., idioblasts, PO:0000283). A plant organ may have one or more different plant organs as parts, such as a sporophyll (PO:0009026) that may have as part a sporangium (PO:0025094) or a carpel (PO:0009030) that may have as part a plant ovule (PO:0020003).
parentComment: Most multi-tissue plant structures have at least a small connection to other plant structures via a fiat boundary, such as where a leaf (PO:0025034) connects to a shoot axis (PO:0025029), a petal (PO:0009032) connects to a receptacle (PO:0009064), or a branch (PO:0025073) connects to a stem (PO:0009047).  Refers to CARO:0000055 multi-tissue structure, def'n: Anatomical structure that has as parts two or more portions of tissue of at least two different types, and which through specific morphogenetic processes, form a single distinct structural unit demarcated by bona-fide boundries from other structural units of differnt types.

classDefinition: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces shoot-borne portions of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) and the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them.
parentDefinition: A collective plant structure (PO:0025497) that is a proper part of a whole plant (PO:0000003), and is composed of two or more adjacent plant organs (PO:0009008) and the associated portions of plant tissue (PO:0009007).
classComment: The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
parentComment: Organs can be of the same type or different types. Examples include flower (PO:0009046), perianth (PO:0009058), and inflorescence (PO:0009049). See also collective organ part structure (PO:0025269), for plant structures composed of parts of multiple organs, but no complete plant organs. This was formerly named collective plant structure.

classDefinition: A primordium (PO:0025127) that develops from a phyllome anlagen (PO:0025430) and is part of a shoot apex (PO:0000037) and is committed to the development of a phyllome (PO:0006001).
parentDefinition: A portion of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) that has as parts protoderm (PO:0006210) and sub-epidermal meristematic tissue and is committed to the development of a particular plant structure (PO:0009011).
classComment: The transition from phyllome primordium to phyllome occurs when the first non-meristematic tissue develops begins to develop.
parentComment: A primordium appears as a protrusion and is the first distinct form of a plant organ (PO:0009008), cardinal organ part (PO:0025001), or collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007). The transition from a primordium to the plant structure it develops into is marked by the development of non-meristematic cells, although meristematic cells may be present after the transition.

classDefinition: A portion of phyllome epidermis (PO:0025157) that is part of a leaf (PO:0025034).
parentDefinition: A portion of shoot system epidermis (PO:0006035) that is part of a phyllome (PO:0006001).
classComment: If you are annotating to this term, please add an additional annotation to vascular leaf (PO:0009025) or non-vascular leaf (PO:0025075), depending on the species. All annotations for angiosperms, gymnosperms, and pteridophytes should go to vascular leaf and all annotations for bryophytes should go to non-vascular leaf.

classDefinition: A portion of shoot system epidermis (PO:0006035) that is part of a phyllome (PO:0006001).
parentDefinition: A portion of epidermis (PO:0005679) that is part of a shoot system (PO:0009006) and arises from the meristem L1 layer (PO:0009020).
parentComment: Often interrupted by stomatal complexes (PO:0002000) and other structures. The shoot system epidermis is different from the root epidermis (PO:0006036) in its origin, function and structure.

classDefinition: A portion of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) that is the outermost layer of a shoot apical meristem (PO:0020148) and gives rise to a shoot system epidermis (PO:0006035).
parentDefinition: A portion of plant tissue (PO:0009007) in which plant cells (PO:0009002) have retained their embryonic characteristics, or have reverted to them secondarily, and that divide to produce new cells that can undergo differentiation to form mature tissues, i.e. they have a capacity for morphogenesis and growth.
classComment: The cells of the meristem L1 layer divide in a strictly anticlinical fashion.

classDefinition: A portion of epidermis (PO:0005679) that is part of a root (PO:0009005).
parentDefinition: A portion of plant tissue (PO:0009007) composed of epidermal cells (PO:0004013) that develops from the protoderm (PO:0006210) and covers the surface of a plant structure (PO:0009011).
classComment: The root epidermis is different from the shoot epidermis in its origin, function and structure.
parentComment: The epidermis can be composed of one or more layers of cells. In some species of vascular plants, the epidermis, which is a primary tissue, is replaced by periderm, which is secondary tissue, later in development. The epidermis can also include trichomes, stomatal pores, root hairs, and rhizoids.

classDefinition: A portion of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) that is part of a shoot system (PO:0009006).
parentDefinition: A portion of plant tissue (PO:0009007) in which plant cells (PO:0009002) have retained their embryonic characteristics, or have reverted to them secondarily, and that divide to produce new cells that can undergo differentiation to form mature tissues, i.e. they have a capacity for morphogenesis and growth.

classDefinition: A plant structure development stage (PO:0009012) that has as primary participant a whole plant (PO:0000003).
parentDefinition: A stage in the life of a plant structure (PO:0009011) during which the plant structure undergoes developmental processes.
parentComment: Refers to GO:0032502 'developmental process', which includes growth, differentiation, and senescence, and BFO:0000003 'ocurrent'.

classDefinition: A stage in the life of a plant structure (PO:0009011) during which the plant structure undergoes developmental processes.
parentDefinition: An occurrent that has temporal proper parts and for some time t, p s-depends_on some material entity at t.
classComment: Refers to GO:0032502 'developmental process', which includes growth, differentiation, and senescence, and BFO:0000003 'ocurrent'.

classDefinition: A stage in the life of a plant structure (PO:0009011) during which the plant structure undergoes developmental processes.
parentDefinition: p is a process = Def. p is an occurrent that has temporal proper parts and for some time t, p s-depends_on some material entity at t. (axiom label in BFO2 Reference: [083-003])
classComment: Refers to GO:0032502 'developmental process', which includes growth, differentiation, and senescence, and BFO:0000003 'ocurrent'.

classDefinition: A cell which is a plant structure (PO:0009011).
parentDefinition: A plant anatomical entity (PO:0025131) that is, or was, part of a plant, or was derived from a part of a plant.
classComment: Applies to cells that are living or dead at maturity (e.g., fiber cell or tracheid) and includes any external encapsulating structures (if present) such as the plasma membrane and the plant-type cell wall. Definition of cell GO:0005623: "The basic structural and functional unit of all organisms. Includes the plasma membrane and any external encapsulating structures such as the cell wall and cell envelope". GO:0009505. Definition of plant-type cell wall (GO:0009505): A more or less rigid structure lying outside the cell membrane of a cell and composed of cellulose and pectin and other organic and inorganic substances, synonym; exact: cellulose and pectin-containing cell wall.
parentComment: 'Part' includes both proper parts and the whole plant. CARO:0000003 'connected anatomical structure' is defined as: Material anatomical entity that is a single connected structure with inherent 3D shape, generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome.

classDefinition: A collective plant structure (PO:0025497) that is a proper part of a whole plant (PO:0000003), and is composed of two or more adjacent plant organs (PO:0009008) and the associated portions of plant tissue (PO:0009007).
parentDefinition: A plant structure (PO:0009011) that is a proper part of a whole plant (PO:0000003) and includes two or more adjacent plant organs (PO:0009008) or adjacent cardinal organ parts (PO:0025001), along with any associated portions of plant tissue (PO:0009007).
classComment: Organs can be of the same type or different types. Examples include flower (PO:0009046), perianth (PO:0009058), and inflorescence (PO:0009049). See also collective organ part structure (PO:0025269), for plant structures composed of parts of multiple organs, but no complete plant organs. This was formerly named collective plant structure.
parentComment: This is a parent term to describe both collective organ part structure (PO:0025269)  (e.g. septum), as well as collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) (which was formerly named collective plant structure), for example shoot system (PO:0009006).

classDefinition: An axial plant organ (PO:0009008).
parentDefinition: A multi-tissue plant structure (PO:0025496) that is a functional unit, is a proper part of a whole plant (PO:0000003), and includes portions of plant tissue (PO:0009007) of at least two different types that derive from a common developmental path.
classComment: Includes roots and shoots.
parentComment: Examples include stem (PO:0009047), leaf (PO:0025034), and root (PO:0009005). May include individual plant cells (PO:0009002) that are not part of a portion of plant tissue (e.g., idioblasts, PO:0000283). A plant organ may have one or more different plant organs as parts, such as a sporophyll (PO:0009026) that may have as part a sporangium (PO:0025094) or a carpel (PO:0009030) that may have as part a plant ovule (PO:0020003).

classDefinition: A plant structure (PO:0009011) that has as parts two or more portions of plant tissue (PO:0009007) of at least two different types and which through specific morphogenetic processes forms a single structural unit demarcated by primarily bona-fide boundaries from other structural units of different types.
parentDefinition: A plant anatomical entity (PO:0025131) that is, or was, part of a plant, or was derived from a part of a plant.
classComment: Most multi-tissue plant structures have at least a small connection to other plant structures via a fiat boundary, such as where a leaf (PO:0025034) connects to a shoot axis (PO:0025029), a petal (PO:0009032) connects to a receptacle (PO:0009064), or a branch (PO:0025073) connects to a stem (PO:0009047).  Refers to CARO:0000055 multi-tissue structure, def'n: Anatomical structure that has as parts two or more portions of tissue of at least two different types, and which through specific morphogenetic processes, form a single distinct structural unit demarcated by bona-fide boundries from other structural units of differnt types.
parentComment: 'Part' includes both proper parts and the whole plant. CARO:0000003 'connected anatomical structure' is defined as: Material anatomical entity that is a single connected structure with inherent 3D shape, generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome.

classDefinition: A maximal portion of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) located at a shoot apex (PO:0000037) or root tip (PO:0000025).
parentDefinition: A portion of plant tissue (PO:0009007) in which plant cells (PO:0009002) have retained their embryonic characteristics, or have reverted to them secondarily, and that divide to produce new cells that can undergo differentiation to form mature tissues, i.e. they have a capacity for morphogenesis and growth.

classDefinition: A plant structure (PO:0009011) that is a proper part of a whole plant (PO:0000003) and includes two or more adjacent plant organs (PO:0009008) or adjacent cardinal organ parts (PO:0025001), along with any associated portions of plant tissue (PO:0009007).
parentDefinition: A plant anatomical entity (PO:0025131) that is, or was, part of a plant, or was derived from a part of a plant.
classComment: This is a parent term to describe both collective organ part structure (PO:0025269)  (e.g. septum), as well as collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) (which was formerly named collective plant structure), for example shoot system (PO:0009006).
parentComment: 'Part' includes both proper parts and the whole plant. CARO:0000003 'connected anatomical structure' is defined as: Material anatomical entity that is a single connected structure with inherent 3D shape, generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome.

classDefinition: A whole plant development stage (PO:0007033) that has as primary participant a whole plant (PO:0000003) during the interval between fertilization (or apogamy) and death.
parentDefinition: A plant structure development stage (PO:0009012) that has as primary participant a whole plant (PO:0000003).
classComment: A whole plant (PO:0000003) in the sporophyte development stage usually has twice the chromosome complement of a plant in the gametophytic phase, but may not in the case of apogamy. Examples of apogamy include both naturally occurring instances (such as sporophytes arising form haploid cells as in bryophytes or ferns) as well as in vitro instances (such as haploid embryo culture or in vitro fusion of non-gamete cells or protoplasts). During the sporophyte development stage, a plant may produce meiospores by meiosis.

classDefinition: A portion of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) that is part of a peripheral zone (PO:0000225) of a shoot apical meristem (PO:0020148) and will give rise to a phyllome primordium (PO:0025128).
parentDefinition: A portion of plant tissue (PO:0009007) in which plant cells (PO:0009002) have retained their embryonic characteristics, or have reverted to them secondarily, and that divide to produce new cells that can undergo differentiation to form mature tissues, i.e. they have a capacity for morphogenesis and growth.
classComment: The phyllome anlagen is only detectable by gene expression, not morphology.

classDefinition: A maximal whole plant development stage.
parentDefinition: A plant structure development stage (PO:0009012) that has as primary participant a whole plant (PO:0000003).
classComment: There are only two types of life of whole plant. Every life of a whole plant is either a maximal gametophyte stage or a maximal sporophyte stage.

classDefinition: A portion of plant substance (PO:0025161) that is the inner layer of a plant cuticle (PO:0000022), and is composed of a polyester matrix of hydroxy- and hydroxy epoxy fatty acid C16 and C18 chains.
parentDefinition: A portion of organism substance that is or was part of a plant.
classComment: Cutin is the insoluble, covalently cross-linked polymer that forms an electron dense layer over the epidermal cells (PO:0004013) of an aerial plant structure.
parentComment: Refers to organism substance (CARO:0000004) which is defined as: Material anatomical entity in a gaseous, liquid, semisolid or solid state; produced by anatomical structures or derived from inhaled and ingested substances that have been modified by anatomical structures as they pass through the body and that does not have inherent 3D shape generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome. For plants, the word "body" refers to a whole plant, or part thereof.  Includes substances such as latex, xylem sap, phloem sap, resin, mucilage, oil, cuticle, cutin, and sporopollenin.

classDefinition: A portion of plant substance (PO:0025161) that is the inner layer of a plant cuticle (PO:0000022), composed primarily of cutin (PO:0025385), embedded and overlayed with cuticular wax (PO:0025386).
parentDefinition: A portion of organism substance that is or was part of a plant.
parentComment: Refers to organism substance (CARO:0000004) which is defined as: Material anatomical entity in a gaseous, liquid, semisolid or solid state; produced by anatomical structures or derived from inhaled and ingested substances that have been modified by anatomical structures as they pass through the body and that does not have inherent 3D shape generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome. For plants, the word "body" refers to a whole plant, or part thereof.  Includes substances such as latex, xylem sap, phloem sap, resin, mucilage, oil, cuticle, cutin, and sporopollenin.

classDefinition: A portion of plant substance (PO:0025161) comprised predominantly of very long chain aliphatic lipids and is part of a plant cuticle (PO:0000022).
parentDefinition: A portion of organism substance that is or was part of a plant.
classComment: Also includes triterpenoids and minor secondary metabolites, such as sterols and flavonoids. May be embedded within or external to the layer of cutin of the cuticle proper.  Phenotypically, wax is distinguished as the glaucous or whitish bloom on a part of a plant shoot system that corresponds to crystalloid epicuticular wax with light scattering capacity.
parentComment: Refers to organism substance (CARO:0000004) which is defined as: Material anatomical entity in a gaseous, liquid, semisolid or solid state; produced by anatomical structures or derived from inhaled and ingested substances that have been modified by anatomical structures as they pass through the body and that does not have inherent 3D shape generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome. For plants, the word "body" refers to a whole plant, or part thereof.  Includes substances such as latex, xylem sap, phloem sap, resin, mucilage, oil, cuticle, cutin, and sporopollenin.

classDefinition: A portion of plant substance (PO:0025161) that is an aqueous solution that can be transported through the apoplast (GO:0048046) or symplast (GO:0055044).
parentDefinition: A portion of organism substance that is or was part of a plant.
classComment: Plant sap should not be confused with latex, resins or plant cell cytoplasm.
parentComment: Refers to organism substance (CARO:0000004) which is defined as: Material anatomical entity in a gaseous, liquid, semisolid or solid state; produced by anatomical structures or derived from inhaled and ingested substances that have been modified by anatomical structures as they pass through the body and that does not have inherent 3D shape generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome. For plants, the word "body" refers to a whole plant, or part thereof.  Includes substances such as latex, xylem sap, phloem sap, resin, mucilage, oil, cuticle, cutin, and sporopollenin.

classDefinition: A portion of plant substance (PO:0025161) that consists of a complex mixture of organic aromatic compounds such as mono-, sesqui-, and diterpenoids.
parentDefinition: A portion of organism substance that is or was part of a plant.
classComment: Plant resins are often produced by Gymnosperms but not restricted to those plants. In the conifers, plant resins are constitutively and inducibly produced through the secretory activity of resin cells (PO:0025604), and can be exuded through a resin canal (PO:0005665) to a site of injury or predator attack.
parentComment: Refers to organism substance (CARO:0000004) which is defined as: Material anatomical entity in a gaseous, liquid, semisolid or solid state; produced by anatomical structures or derived from inhaled and ingested substances that have been modified by anatomical structures as they pass through the body and that does not have inherent 3D shape generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome. For plants, the word "body" refers to a whole plant, or part thereof.  Includes substances such as latex, xylem sap, phloem sap, resin, mucilage, oil, cuticle, cutin, and sporopollenin.

classDefinition: A major division of the nervous system that contains nerves which connect the central nervous system (CNS) with sensory organs, other organs, muscles, blood vessels and glands.
parentDefinition: A subdivision of an anatomical system.

classDefinition: A subdivision of an anatomical system.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that has more than one cell as a part.

classDefinition: The nervous system is an organ system containing predominantly neuron and glial cells. In bilaterally symmetrical organism, it is arranged in a network of tree-like structures connected to a central body. The main functions of the nervous system are to regulate and control body functions, and to receive sensory input, process this information, and generate behavior [CUMBO].
parentDefinition: Multicellular, connected anatomical structure that has multiple organs as parts and whose parts work together to achieve some shared function.

classDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the ectoderm.
parentDefinition: Material anatomical entity that is a single connected structure with inherent 3D shape generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome.

classDefinition: The organ covering the body that consists of the dermis and epidermis.

classDefinition: The organ covering the body that consists of the dermis and epidermis.

classDefinition: The outer epithelial layer of the skin that is superficial to the dermis.
parentDefinition: The epidermis is the entire outer epithelial layer of an animal, it may be a single layer that produces an extracellular material (e.g. the cuticle of arthropods) or a complex stratified squamous epithelium, as in the case of many vertebrate species[GO].

classDefinition: The outer epithelial layer of the skin that is superficial to the dermis.
parentDefinition: Structures of the dermis, epidermis, glands and pigment cells recognizable on the external surfaces of the integument.

classDefinition: The dermis is a layer of skin between the epidermis (with which it makes up the skin) and subcutaneous tissues, and is composed of two layers, the papillary and reticular dermis[WP].
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the ectoderm.

parentLabel: structure with developmental contribution from neural crest
classDefinition: The dermis is a layer of skin between the epidermis (with which it makes up the skin) and subcutaneous tissues, and is composed of two layers, the papillary and reticular dermis[WP].

classDefinition: The dermis is a layer of skin between the epidermis (with which it makes up the skin) and subcutaneous tissues, and is composed of two layers, the papillary and reticular dermis[WP].
parentDefinition: An organ component layer that is part of a integumental system.

classDefinition: An organ of sight that includes the camera-type eyeball and supporting structures such as the lacrimal apparatus, the conjunctiva, the eyelid.

classDefinition: The subdivision of the face that includes the eye (eyeball plus adnexa such as eyelids) and the orbit of the skull and associated parts of the face such as the eyebrows, if present.

classDefinition: Transparent part of camera-type eye that helps to refract light to be focused on the retina.
parentDefinition: A transparent structure that is part of a visual sense organ, the function of which is to direct or focus light onto a photoreceptor array.

classDefinition: The retina is the innermost layer or coating at the back of the eyeball, which is sensitive to light and in which the optic nerve terminates.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the ectoderm.

classDefinition: The retina is the innermost layer or coating at the back of the eyeball, which is sensitive to light and in which the optic nerve terminates.
parentDefinition: An array of photoreceptors and any supporting cells found in an eye.

classDefinition: Multi-tissue structure that is comprised of neural and non-neural epithelial layers which will form the retina and retinal pigmented epithelium of the mature eye[ZFA]. double walled structured formed by expansion and invagination of the distal end of the optic vesicle that develops into the pigmented and sensory layers of the retina while the mouth of the optic cup eventually forms the pupil of the eye[MP].
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the ectoderm.

classDefinition: Multi-tissue structure that is comprised of neural and non-neural epithelial layers which will form the retina and retinal pigmented epithelium of the mature eye[ZFA]. double walled structured formed by expansion and invagination of the distal end of the optic vesicle that develops into the pigmented and sensory layers of the retina while the mouth of the optic cup eventually forms the pupil of the eye[MP].

classDefinition: An organ that is capable of transducing sensory stimulus to the nervous system.

parentDefinition: An anatomical group whose component structures share a common function.

classDefinition: Anatomical projection that protrudes from the skin. Examples: hair, nail, feather, claw, hoof, horn, wattle, spur, beak, antler, bristle and some scales.
parentDefinition: Anatomical projection that is part of the integumentl system.

classDefinition: Anatomical projection that is part of the integumentl system.
parentDefinition: A projection or outgrowth of tissue from a larger body or organ.

classDefinition: Anatomical projection that is part of the integumentl system.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure embedded in or located in the integument that is part of the integumental system. Examples: hair, follicles, skin glands, claws, nails, feathers.

classDefinition: Any hollow cylindrical anatomical structure containing a lumen through which substances are transported.

classDefinition: Any tube, opening or passage that connects two distinct anatomical spaces.

classDefinition: The head is the anterior-most division of the body [GO].
parentDefinition: A major subdivision of an organism that divides an organism along its main body axis (typically anterio-posterior axis). In vertebrates, this is based on the vertebral column.

classLabel: subdivision of organism along main body axis

classDefinition: The anteriormost subdivision of the body that includes the head, jaws, pharyngeal region and the neck (if present). In vertebrates this is the subdivision that includes the cervical vertebrae.

parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that has more than one cell as a part.

parentDefinition: A multicellular structure that is a part of an organ.

classDefinition: Any part or collection of parts of the central or peripheral nervous system. Parts may span both CNS and PNS.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that has as its parts two or more portions of tissue of at least two different types and which through specific morphogenetic processes forms a single distinct structural unit demarcated by bona-fide boundaries from other distinct structural units of different types.
