classDefinition: Anatomical cluster consisting of the skeletal elements and articular elements that are part of an individual subdivision of the organism.
parentDefinition: A subdivision of an anatomical system.

classDefinition: Anatomical system that is a multi-element, multi-tissue anatomical cluster that consists of the skeleton and the articular system.
parentDefinition: A subdivision of an anatomical system.

classDefinition: Organ consisting of skeletal tissue. Encompasses whole bones, fused bones, cartilaginious elements, teeth, dermal denticles.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that performs a specific function or group of functions [WP].

classDefinition: The surface (external) layer of ectoderm which begins to proliferate shortly after separation from the neuroectoderm.
parentDefinition: Epithelium which consists of a single layer of epithelial cells. Examples: endothelium, mesothelium, glandular squamous epithelium.[FMA].

classDefinition: The surface (external) layer of ectoderm which begins to proliferate shortly after separation from the neuroectoderm.
parentDefinition: A portion of tissue that is part of an embryo.

classDefinition: Epithelium which consists of a single layer of epithelial cells. Examples: endothelium, mesothelium, glandular squamous epithelium.[FMA].
parentDefinition: Portion of tissue, that consists of one or more layers of epithelial cells connected to each other by cell junctions and which is underlain by a basal lamina. Examples: simple squamous epithelium, glandular cuboidal epithelium, transitional epithelium, myoepithelium[CARO].

classDefinition: A portion of tissue that is part of an embryo.
parentDefinition: Multicellular anatomical structure that consists of many cells of one or a few types, arranged in an extracellular matrix such that their long-range organisation is at least partly a repetition of their short-range organisation.

classDefinition: Primary germ layer that is the outer of the embryo's three germ layers and gives rise to epidermis and neural tissue.
parentDefinition: A layer of cells produced during the process of gastrulation during the early development of the animal embryo, which is distinct from other such layers of cells, as an early step of cell differentiation. The three types of germ layers are the endoderm, ectoderm, and mesoderm.

classDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops from the endoderm and the mesoderm.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the endoderm.

classDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops from the endoderm and the mesoderm.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the mesoderm.

classDefinition: Primary germ layer that lies remote from the surface of the embryo and gives rise to internal tissues such as gut.
parentDefinition: A layer of cells produced during the process of gastrulation during the early development of the animal embryo, which is distinct from other such layers of cells, as an early step of cell differentiation. The three types of germ layers are the endoderm, ectoderm, and mesoderm.

classDefinition: The middle germ layer of the embryo, between the endoderm and ectoderm.
parentDefinition: A layer of cells produced during the process of gastrulation during the early development of the animal embryo, which is distinct from other such layers of cells, as an early step of cell differentiation. The three types of germ layers are the endoderm, ectoderm, and mesoderm.

classDefinition: A spatially aggregated collection of nerve cell bodies in the CNS, consisting of one or more subpopulations that share cell type, chemical phenotype, and connections, and including nearby cells that share the same cell type, chemical phenotype, and connections. (CUMBO).

parentDefinition: A multi cell part structure that is part of a central nervous system.

classDefinition: A nervous system structure composed primarily of nerve cell bodies (somas). May also include dendrites and the initial unmyelinated portion of axons.
parentDefinition: A multi cell part structure that is part of a central nervous system.

classDefinition: A proximal-distal subdivision of the digestive tract.
The part of the digestive system that excludes the hepatobiliary system.
parentDefinition: Multicellular, connected anatomical structure that has multiple organs as parts and whose parts work together to achieve some shared function.

classDefinition: Anatomical conduit that connects two adjacent body spaces (or a body space with the space surrounding the organism)[FMA,modified].
parentDefinition: Any tube, opening or passage that connects two distinct anatomical spaces.

classDefinition: Common chamber into which the intestines and excretory system opens. Arises during development in all vertebrates, but in many it becomes subdivided, lost or incorporated into other structures.
Anatomical system that has as its parts the organs concerned with the production and excretion of urine and those concerned with reproduction.
Anatomical system that has as its parts the organs concerned with the production and excretion of urine and those concerned with reproduction.
parentDefinition: Multicellular, connected anatomical structure that has multiple organs as parts and whose parts work together to achieve some shared function.

classDefinition: Endoderm-lined chamber that develops as pouch-like dilation of the caudal end of the hindgut and receives the allantois ventrally and two mesonephric ducts laterally; caudally it ends blindly at the cloacal membrane formed by the union of proctodeal (anal pit) ectoderm and cloacal endoderm, with no intervening mesoderm[MP].
parentDefinition: Common chamber into which the intestines and excretory system opens. Arises during development in all vertebrates, but in many it becomes subdivided, lost or incorporated into other structures.

classDefinition: Anatomical entity that comprises the organism in the early stages of growth and differentiation that are characterized by cleavage, the laying down of fundamental tissues, and the formation of primitive organs and organ systems. For example, for mammals, the process would begin with zygote formation and end with birth. For insects, the process would begin at zygote formation and end with larval hatching. For plant zygotic embryos, this would be from zygote formation to the end of seed dormancy. For plant vegetative embryos, this would be from the initial determination of the cell or group of cells to form an embryo until the point when the embryo becomes independent of the parent plant.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that is an individual member of a species and consists of more than one cell.

classDefinition: The renal system in an anatomical system that maintains fluid balance and contributes to electrolyte balance, acid/base balance, and disposal of nitrogenous waste products.
parentDefinition: An anatomical system that eliminates waste products that arise as a result of metabolic activity.

Anatomical structure that has as its parts two or more portions of tissue of at least two different types and which through specific morphogenetic processes forms a single distinct structural unit demarcated by bona-fide boundaries from other distinct structural units of different types.

classDefinition: The ventral part of the cloaca remaining after septation of the rectum, which further develops into part of the bladder, part of the prostatic part of the male urethra and the urethra and vestibule in females.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that is part of an embryo.

classDefinition: Anatomical structure that is part of an embryo.
The intermediate mesoderm is located between the lateral mesoderm and the paraxial mesoderm. It develops into the kidney and gonads.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that is part of an embryo.

classDefinition: The primordial mouth region of the developing head.
The primordial mouth region of the developing head.
The orifice that connects the mouth to the exterior of the body.

classDefinition: A bodily fluid consisting of the contents of the digestive tract expulsed through the anterior portion of the digestive tract.

classDefinition: Transudate contained in the pleural cavity.
parentDefinition: A transudate found in the serous sac.

classDefinition: Circulating fluid that is part of the hemolymphoid system. Blood, lymph, interstitial fluid or its analogs.
parentDefinition: Liquid components of living organisms. includes fluids that are excreted or secreted from the body as well as body water that normally is not.

classDefinition: Anatomical system that is involved in the production of hematopoietic cells.
parentDefinition: Multicellular, connected anatomical structure that has multiple organs as parts and whose parts work together to achieve some shared function.

classDefinition: Anatomical cluster consisting of the hematopoietic system and the lymphoid system, or its analogs.

classDefinition: Organism at the blastula stage - an early stage of embryonic development in animals. It is produced by cleavage of a fertilized ovum and consists of a spherical layer of around 128 cells surrounding a central fluid-filled cavity called the blastocoel. The blastula follows the morula and precedes the gastrula in the developmental sequence.
parentDefinition: Anatomical entity that comprises the organism in the early stages of growth and differentiation that are characterized by cleavage, the laying down of fundamental tissues, and the formation of primitive organs and organ systems. For example, for mammals, the process would begin with zygote formation and end with birth. For insects, the process would begin at zygote formation and end with larval hatching. For plant zygotic embryos, this would be from zygote formation to the end of seed dormancy. For plant vegetative embryos, this would be from the initial determination of the cell or group of cells to form an embryo until the point when the embryo becomes independent of the parent plant.

classDefinition: Organism at the cleavage stage.
parentDefinition: Anatomical entity that comprises the organism in the early stages of growth and differentiation that are characterized by cleavage, the laying down of fundamental tissues, and the formation of primitive organs and organ systems. For example, for mammals, the process would begin with zygote formation and end with birth. For insects, the process would begin at zygote formation and end with larval hatching. For plant zygotic embryos, this would be from zygote formation to the end of seed dormancy. For plant vegetative embryos, this would be from the initial determination of the cell or group of cells to form an embryo until the point when the embryo becomes independent of the parent plant.

classDefinition: An embryo that is at the late embryonic stage; this stage covers late steps of the embryogenesis with a fully formed embryo still developing before birth or egg hatching.
parentDefinition: Anatomical entity that comprises the organism in the early stages of growth and differentiation that are characterized by cleavage, the laying down of fundamental tissues, and the formation of primitive organs and organ systems. For example, for mammals, the process would begin with zygote formation and end with birth. For insects, the process would begin at zygote formation and end with larval hatching. For plant zygotic embryos, this would be from zygote formation to the end of seed dormancy. For plant vegetative embryos, this would be from the initial determination of the cell or group of cells to form an embryo until the point when the embryo becomes independent of the parent plant.

classDefinition: The wall of the digestive tract. This encompasses all parts of the digestive tract with the exception of the lumen (cavity).
parentDefinition: Organ component adjacent to an organ cavity and which consists of a maximal aggregate of organ component layers.

classDefinition: A lining of mostly endodermal origin, covered in epithelium, which is involved in absorption and secretion. They line various body cavities that are exposed to the external environment and internal organs. It is at several places continuous with skin: at the nostrils, the lips, the ears, the genital area, and the anus. The sticky, thick fluid secreted by the mucous membranes and gland is termed mucus. The term mucous membrane refers to where they are found in the body and not every mucous membrane secretes mucus[WP].
parentDefinition: A part of a wall of an organ that forms a layer.

classDefinition: Portion of tissue, that consists of one or more layers of epithelial cells connected to each other by cell junctions and which is underlain by a basal lamina. Examples: simple squamous epithelium, glandular cuboidal epithelium, transitional epithelium, myoepithelium[CARO].
parentDefinition: Multicellular anatomical structure that consists of many cells of one or a few types, arranged in an extracellular matrix such that their long-range organisation is at least partly a repetition of their short-range organisation.

classDefinition: Tissue with cells that deposit non-polarized extracellular matrix including connective tissue fibers and ground substance.
parentDefinition: Multicellular anatomical structure that consists of many cells of one or a few types, arranged in an extracellular matrix such that their long-range organisation is at least partly a repetition of their short-range organisation.

classDefinition: A set of midline structures surrounding the brainstem of the mammalian brain, originally described anatomically, e.g., hippocampal formation, amygdala, hypothalamus, cingulate cortex. Although the original designation was anatomical, the limbic system has come to be associated with the system in the brain subserving emotional functions. As such, it is very poorly defined and doesn't correspond closely to the anatomical meaning any longer. [BirnLex].
parentDefinition: A subdivision of an anatomical system.

classDefinition: A set of midline structures surrounding the brainstem of the mammalian brain, originally described anatomically, e.g., hippocampal formation, amygdala, hypothalamus, cingulate cortex. classDefinition: The most anterior region of the brain including both the telencephalon and diencephalon.

classDefinition: The part of the conceptus that may be lost before birth or will be discarded at birth, or when the embryo becomes an independent organism.

classDefinition: A layer of cells produced during the process of gastrulation during the early development of the animal embryo, which is distinct from other such layers of cells, as an early step of cell differentiation. The three types of germ layers are the endoderm, ectoderm, and mesoderm.

classDefinition: The brain is the center of the nervous system in all vertebrate, and most invertebrate, animals. Some primitive animals such as jellyfish and starfish have a decentralized nervous system without a brain, while sponges lack any nervous system at all. In vertebrates, the brain is located in the head, protected by the skull and close to the primary sensory apparatus of vision, hearing, balance, taste, and smell[WP].

classDefinition: The epidermis is the entire outer epithelial layer of an animal, it may be a single layer that produces an extracellular material (e.g. the cuticle of arthropods) or a complex stratified squamous epithelium, as in the case of many vertebrate species[GO].

parentDefinition: Irregular connective tissue is an irregular connective tissue, the intercellular matrix of which contains a dense irregular network of collagen and elastic fiber bundles. Examples: connective tissue of peritoneum, connective tissue of fibrous pericardium.

classDefinition: Irregular connective tissue is an irregular connective tissue, the intercellular matrix of which contains a dense irregular network of collagen and elastic fiber bundles. Examples: connective tissue of peritoneum, connective tissue of fibrous pericardium.
parentDefinition: Connective tissue, which consists of a population of connective tissue cells, the intercellular matrix of which contains an irregular network of collagen and elastic fiber bundles. Examples: areolar tissue, mucoid tissue, connective tissue of peritoneum, connective tissue of fibrous pericardium.

classDefinition: Irregular connective tissue is an irregular connective tissue, the intercellular matrix of which contains a dense irregular network of collagen and elastic fiber bundles. Examples: connective tissue of peritoneum, connective tissue of fibrous pericardium.
parentDefinition: Dense connective tissue is mainly composed of collagen type I. Crowded between the collagen fibers are rows of fibroblasts, fiber-forming cells, that manufacture the fibers. Dense connective tissue forms strong, rope-like structures such as tendons and ligaments. Tendons attach skeletal muscles to bones; ligaments connect bones to bones at joints. Ligaments are more stretchy and contain more elastic fibers than tendons. Dense connective tissue also make up the lower layers of the skin (dermis), where it is arranged in sheets.

classDefinition: Portion of tissue in the nervous system which consists of neurons and glial cells, and may also contain parts of the vasculature.

classDefinition: Portion of tissue composed of mesenchymal cells (motile cells that develop from epthelia via an epithelial to mesenchymal transition) and surrounding extracellular material. Mesenchyme has different embryological origins in different metazoan taxa - in many invertebrates it derives in whole or part from ectoderm. In vertebrates it derives largely from mesoderm, and sometimes the terms are used interchangeably, e.g. lateral plate mesoderm/mesenchyme.

In the developing vertebrate, the neural tube is the embryo's precursor to the central nervous system, which comprises the brain and spinal cord. The neural groove gradually deepens as the neural folds become elevated, and ultimately the folds meet and coalesce in the middle line and convert the groove into a closed tube, the neural tube or neural canal (which strictly speaking is the center of the neural tube), the ectodermal wall of which forms the rudiment of the nervous system. [WP,unvetted].
parentDefinition: A portion of tissue that is part of an embryo.

parentDefinition: A lining of mostly endodermal origin, covered in epithelium, which is involved in absorption and secretion. They line various body cavities that are exposed to the external environment and internal organs. It is at several places continuous with skin: at the nostrils, the lips, the ears, the genital area, and the anus. The sticky, thick fluid secreted by the mucous membranes and gland is termed mucus. The term mucous membrane refers to where they are found in the body and not every mucous membrane secretes mucus[WP].

parentDefinition: An organism subdivision that includes both an appendage and its associated girdle region. Note that this includes both the skeletal elements and associated tissues (integument, muscle, etc).

classDefinition: A subdivision of a limb or fin skeleton consisting of bones which connects the upper limb or fin to the axial skeleton on each side. It consists of the clavicle and scapula in humans and, in those species with three bones in the pectoral girdle, the coracoid. Some mammalian species (e.g. the dog and the horse) have only the scapula. In humans, the only joints between the shoulder girdle and axial skeleton are the sternoclavicular joints on each side. No joint exists between each scapula and the rib cage; instead the muscular connection between the two permits relatively great mobility of the shoulder girdle in relation to the pelvic girdle. In those species having only the scapula, no joint exists between the forelimb and the thorax, the only attachment being muscular[WP]. Examples: There are only two instances, right and left pectoral girdle skeletons.
parentDefinition: The subdivision of the skeleton of either the pectoral or pelvic girdle.

classDefinition: A lymphatic vessel that is part of a face [Automatically generated definition].

parentDefinition: A part of a wall of an organ that forms a layer.
Anatomical structure that consists of cell parts and cell substances and together does not constitute a cell or a tissue.

classDefinition: Mesenchyme that has the potential to develop into a dermis.
parentDefinition: Portion of tissue composed of mesenchymal cells (motile cells that develop from epthelia via an epithelial to mesenchymal transition) and surrounding extracellular material. Mesenchyme has different embryological origins in different metazoan taxa - in many invertebrates it derives in whole or part from ectoderm. In vertebrates it derives largely from mesoderm, and sometimes the terms are used interchangeably, e.g. lateral plate mesoderm/mesenchyme.

classDefinition: Lowermost layer of the integumentary system in vertebrates. Types of cells that are found in the hypodermis are fibroblasts, adipose cells, and macrophages. It is derived from the mesoderm, but unlike the dermis, it is not derived from the dermatome region of the mesoderm. The hypodermis is used mainly for fat storage[WP].
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the mesoderm.

classDefinition: Lowermost layer of the integumentary system in vertebrates. Types of cells that are found in the hypodermis are fibroblasts, adipose cells, and macrophages. It is derived from the mesoderm, but unlike the dermis, it is not derived from the dermatome region of the mesoderm. The hypodermis is used mainly for fat storage[WP].
parentDefinition: An organ component layer that is part of a integumental system.

classDefinition: The dermis, epidermis and hypodermis.
The dermis, epidermis and hypodermis.
parentDefinition: A subdivision of an anatomical system.

classDefinition: An organ that is located within the body cavity (or in its extension, in the scrotum); it consists of organ parts that are embryologically derived from endoderm, splanchnic mesoderm or intermediate mesoderm; together with other organs, the viscus constitutes the respiratory, gastrointestinal, urinary, reproductive and immune systems, or is the central organ of the cardiovascular system. Examples: heart, lung, esophagus, kidney, ovary, spleen.
parentDefinition: An organ or element that part of the trunk region. The trunk region can be further subdividied into thoracic (including chest and thoracic cavity) and abdominal (including abdomen and pelbis) regions.

classDefinition: An organ or element that part of the trunk region. The trunk region can be further subdividied into thoracic (including chest and thoracic cavity) and abdominal (including abdomen and pelbis) regions.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that performs a specific function or group of functions [WP].

classDefinition: The postcranial subdivision of skeleton structural components forming the long axis of the vertebrate body; in Danio, consisting of the notochord, vertebrae, ribs, supraneurals, intermuscular bones, and unpaired median fins; in human consists of the bones of the vertebral column, the thoracic cage and the pelvis[ZFA+FMA].
parentDefinition: Anatomical cluster consisting of the skeletal elements (i.e. bone elements, cartilage elements, cartilage condensations) that are part of an individual subdivision of the organism. Excludes joints.

classDefinition: Subdivision of skeleton which consists of cranial skeleton, set of all vertebrae, set of all ribs and sternum[FMA, modified].
parentDefinition: Anatomical cluster consisting of the skeletal elements (i.e. bone elements, cartilage elements, cartilage condensations) that are part of an individual subdivision of the organism. Excludes joints.

classDefinition: Subdivision of the skeletal system which consists of the postcranial axial skeleton plus associated joints.
parentDefinition: Anatomical cluster consisting of the skeletal elements and articular elements that are part of an individual subdivision of the organism.

classDefinition: Ventral somitic compartment that is a precursor of the axial skeleton[XAO]. Sclerotomes eventually differentiate into the vertebrae and most of the skull. The caudal (posterior) half of one sclerotome fuses with the rostral (anterior) half of the adjacent one to form each vertebra. From their initial location within the somite, the sclerotome cells migrate medially towards the notochord. These cells meet the sclerotome cells from the other side to form the vertebral body. From this vertebral body, sclerotome cells move dorsally and surround the developing spinal cord, forming the vertebral arch[WP].
parentDefinition: A delimited region of dense mesenchyme within looser mesenchyme.

classDefinition: Ventral somitic compartment that is a precursor of the axial skeleton[XAO]. Sclerotomes eventually differentiate into the vertebrae and most of the skull. The caudal (posterior) half of one sclerotome fuses with the rostral (anterior) half of the adjacent one to form each vertebra. From their initial location within the somite, the sclerotome cells migrate medially towards the notochord. These cells meet the sclerotome cells from the other side to form the vertebral body. From this vertebral body, sclerotome cells move dorsally and surround the developing spinal cord, forming the vertebral arch[WP].
parentDefinition: Mesenchymal cells that are migrating.

classDefinition: Subdivision of skeleton which which consists of all the skeletal elements in in the pectoral and pelvic appendage complexes[cjm].
parentDefinition: Anatomical cluster consisting of the skeletal elements (i.e. bone elements, cartilage elements, cartilage condensations) that are part of an individual subdivision of the organism. Excludes joints.

classDefinition: Subdivision of the skeletal system which consists of the appendicular skeleton plus associated joints.
parentDefinition: Anatomical cluster consisting of the skeletal elements and articular elements that are part of an individual subdivision of the organism.

Epithelium composed of cells that develops from the ectoderm[FMA,modified].

classDefinition: The thin membranous structure between the two heart atria or the thick muscular structure between the two heart ventricles.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the mesoderm.

classDefinition: The thin membranous structure between the two heart atria or the thick muscular structure between the two heart ventricles.
parentDefinition: A wall, dividing a cavity or structure into smaller ones[WP].

classDefinition: A wall, dividing a cavity or structure into smaller ones[WP].
parentDefinition: Material anatomical entity that is a single connected structure with inherent 3D shape generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome.

classDefinition: The region of the organism associated with the visceral organs.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure which is a subdivision of a whole organism, consisting of components of multiple anatomical systems, largely surrounded by a contiguous region of integument.

classDefinition: A portion of adipose tissue that is part of the hypodermis, beneath the dermis.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the mesoderm.

classDefinition: Vasculature that is part of a head [Automatically generated definition].
parentDefinition: An interconnected tubular multi-tissue structure contains fluid that is actively transported around the organism[ZFA]. Examples: vasculature of lung, vasculature of face.

classDefinition: A brain ventricle that is part of a telencephalon. In mammals and species with an evaginated telencephalon, this is one of a pair of lateral structures, one in each hemisphere.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that has some part that develops from the neural crest.

classDefinition: A brain ventricle that is part of a telencephalon. In mammals and species with an evaginated telencephalon, this is one of a pair of lateral structures, one in each hemisphere.
parentDefinition: One of the system of communicating cavities in the brain that are continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord, that like it are derived from the medullary canal of the embryo, that are lined with an epithelial ependyma, and that contain a serous fluid.

classDefinition: A neural nucleus that is part of the brain.
parentDefinition: A spatially aggregated collection of nerve cell bodies in the CNS, consisting of one or more subpopulations that share cell type, chemical phenotype, and connections, and including nearby cells that share the same cell type, chemical phenotype, and connections. (CUMBO).

classDefinition: A gray matter that is part of a brain [Automatically generated definition].
parentDefinition: A nervous system structure composed primarily of nerve cell bodies (somas). May also include dendrites and the initial unmyelinated portion of axons.

classDefinition: Somites are spheres of epithelial cells that form sequentially along the anterior-posterior axis of the embryo through mesenchymal to epithelial transition of the presomitic mesoderm.
Somites are spheres of epithelial cells that form sequentially along the anterior-posterior axis of the embryo through mesenchymal to epithelial transition of the presomitic mesoderm.
parentDefinition: A closed epithelium with a lumen.

classDefinition: A closed epithelium with a lumen.
parentDefinition: Portion of tissue, that consists of one or more layers of epithelial cells connected to each other by cell junctions and which is underlain by a basal lamina. Examples: simple squamous epithelium, glandular cuboidal epithelium, transitional epithelium, myoepithelium[CARO].

classDefinition: Unsegmented field of paraxial mesoderm present posterior to the most recently formed somite pair, from which somites will form.
parentDefinition: Portion of embryonic tissue determined by fate mapping to become a structure.

classDefinition: A specialized region of ectoderm found between the neural ectoderm (neural plate) and non-neural ectoderm and composed of highly migratory pluripotent cells that delaminate in early embryonic development from the dorsal neural tube and give rise to an astounding variety of differentiated cell types[MP].
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the ectoderm.

classDefinition: A specialized region of ectoderm found between the neural ectoderm (neural plate) and non-neural ectoderm and composed of highly migratory pluripotent cells that delaminate in early embryonic development from the dorsal neural tube and give rise to an astounding variety of differentiated cell types[MP].
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that has some part that develops from the neural crest.

classDefinition: A specialized region of ectoderm found between the neural ectoderm (neural plate) and non-neural ectoderm and composed of highly migratory pluripotent cells that delaminate in early embryonic development from the dorsal neural tube and give rise to an astounding variety of differentiated cell types[MP].

A region of embryonic ectodermal cells that lie directly above the notochord. During neurulation, they change shape and produce an infolding of the neural plate (the neural fold) that then seals to form the neural tube[XAO]. The earliest recognizable dorsal ectodermal primordium of the central nervous system present near the end of gastrulation before infolding to form the neural keel; consists of a thickened pseudostratified epithelium[ZFA].
parentDefinition: A portion of tissue that is part of an embryo.

classDefinition: A region of embryonic ectodermal cells that lie directly above the notochord. The earliest recognizable dorsal ectodermal primordium of the central nervous system present near the end of gastrulation before infolding to form the neural keel; consists of a thickened pseudostratified epithelium[ZFA].

classDefinition: Blood islands are structures in the developing embryo which lead to many different parts of the circulatory system. They primarily derive from plexuses formed from angioblasts. Within them, vacuoles appear through liquefaction of the central part of the syncytium into plasma. The lumen of the blood vessels thus formed is probably intracellular. The flattened cells at the periphery form the endothelium. The nucleated red blood corpuscles develop either from small masses of the original angioblast left attached to the inner wall of the lumen or directly from the flat endothelial cells. In either case the syncytial mass thus formed projects from and is attached to the wall of the vessel. Such a mass is known as a blood island and hemoglobin gradually accumulates within it. Later the cells on the surface round up, giving the mass a mulberry-like appearance. Then the red blood cells break loose and are carried away in the plasma. Such free blood cells continue to divide. Blood islands have been seen in the area vasculosa in the omphalomesenteric vein and arteries, and in the dorsal aorta[WP, unvetted].
parentDefinition: Portion of embryonic tissue determined by fate mapping to become a structure.

classDefinition: An organ system subdivision that is a network of vessels capable of removing accumulating protein and fluid from the interstitial space and returning it to the vascular space. In some species, this network is connected to the immune system via lymph nodes and lymphocyte-producing organs, with the whole being the lymphoid system.
parentDefinition: A subdivision of an anatomical system.

classDefinition: An epithelium that is part of the mouth and lines the oral cavity, typically stratified squamous, and may be para-, ortho- or non- keratinized. Primary barrier between oral environment and deeper tissues.
parentDefinition: A layer of epithelial cells on the surface of the mucosa.

classDefinition: An epithelium that is part of the mouth and lines the oral cavity, typically stratified squamous, and may be para-, ortho- or non- keratinized. Primary barrier between oral environment and deeper tissues.
parentDefinition: An epithelium that lines the lumen of the digestive tract.

classDefinition: A mucous membrane that lines the mouth.
parentDefinition: A lining of mostly endodermal origin, covered in epithelium, which is involved in absorption and secretion. They line various body cavities that are exposed to the external environment and internal organs. It is at several places continuous with skin: at the nostrils, the lips, the ears, the genital area, and the anus. The sticky, thick fluid secreted by the mucous membranes and gland is termed mucus. The term mucous membrane refers to where they are found in the body and not every mucous membrane secretes mucus[WP].

classDefinition: A blood vessel that is part of a choroid [Automatically generated definition].
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops from the neural crest.

classDefinition: A blood vessel that is part of a head [Automatically generated definition].
parentDefinition: A vessel through which blood circulates in the body.

classDefinition: The lymphatic system in vertebrates is a network of conduits that carry a clear fluid called lymph. It also includes the lymphoid tissue through which the lymph travels. Lymphoid tissue is found in many organs, particularly the lymph nodes, and in the lymphoid follicles associated with the digestive system such as the tonsils. The system also includes all the structures dedicated to the circulation and production of lymphocytes, which includes the spleen, thymus, bone marrow and the lymphoid tissue associated with the digestive system[WP].
parentDefinition: Multicellular, connected anatomical structure that has multiple organs as parts and whose parts work together to achieve some shared function.

classDefinition: A specialized form of connective tissue in which the extracellular matrix is firm, providing the tissue with resilience, and/or mineralized and that functions in mechanical and structural support.[VSAO].
parentDefinition: Tissue with cells that deposit non-polarized extracellular matrix including connective tissue fibers and ground substance.

classDefinition: An epithelium that is part of a iris [Automatically generated definition].
parentDefinition: Epithelium that consists of epithelial cells not arranged in one ore more layers.

classDefinition: An epithelium that is part of a iris [Automatically generated definition].
parentDefinition: An epithelium that is part of a camera-type eye.

classDefinition: In amniote animal embryology, the epiblast is a tissue type derived either from the inner cell mass in mammals or the blastodisc in birds and reptiles. It lies above the hypoblast. In mammalian embryogenesis, the columnar cells of the epiblast are adjacent to the trophoblast, while the cuboidal cells of the hypoblast are closer to the blastocoele. The epiblast, whilst referred to as the primary ectoderm, differentiates to form all three layers of the trilaminar germ disc in a process called gastrulation[WP]. The outer of the two layers of the blastoderm that form during gastrulation, corresponding to primitive ectoderm during gastrulation and to the definitive ectoderm after gastrulation[ZFA].
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that is part of an embryo.

parentLabel: structure with developmental contribution from neural crest
classDefinition: One of a series of paired bulges that develop along the lateral walls of the foregut. The pharyngeal arches have developmental contributions from endoderm, mesoderm, and neural crest cells and are separated by anterior lateral endoderm out-pockets known as pharyngeal pouches.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that has some part that develops from the neural crest.

classDefinition: One of a series of paired bulges that develop along the lateral walls of the foregut. The pharyngeal arches have developmental contributions from endoderm, mesoderm, and neural crest cells and are separated by anterior lateral endoderm out-pockets known as pharyngeal pouches.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that has as its parts two or more portions of tissue of at least two different types and which through specific morphogenetic processes forms a single distinct structural unit demarcated by bona-fide boundaries from other distinct structural units of different types.

classDefinition: One of a series of paired bulges that develop along the lateral walls of the foregut. The pharyngeal arches have developmental contributions from endoderm, mesoderm, and neural crest cells and are separated by anterior lateral endoderm out-pockets known as pharyngeal pouches.

classDefinition: A roughly circular bulge in a surface.

A transient embryonic complex that comprises the pharyngeal arches, bulges of tissues of mesoderm and neural crest derivation through which pass nerves and pharyngeal arch arteries. The arches are separated internally by pharyngeal pouches, evaginations of foregut endoderm, and externally by pharyngeal clefts, invaginations of surface ectoderm. The development of the system ends when the stucture it contributes to are forming, which may include (depending on species) the thymus, thyroid, parathyroids, maxilla, mandible, aortic arch, cardiac outflow tract, external and middle ear[GO,modified].
parentDefinition: Anatomical group that has its parts adjacent to one another.

classDefinition: A head that is part of a embryo.
parentDefinition: The head is the anterior-most division of the body [GO].

classDefinition: Ectodermal placode that develops in the head into a part of the sensory nervous system. With a few exceptions (lens, adenohypophyseal), cranial placodes are neurogenic.
parentDefinition: An ectodermal placode is a thickening of the ectoderm that is the primordium of many structures derived from the ectoderm[GO].

In vertebrates it derives largely from mesoderm, and sometimes the terms are used interchangeably, e.g. lateral plate mesoderm/mesenchyme.

classDefinition: Neural crest cells (NCCs) originating in the anterior part of the developing embryo and residing between the mid-diencephalon and the forming hindbrain; cranial NCCs migrate dorsolaterally to form the craniofacial mesenchyme that differentiates into various craniofacial cartilages and bones, cranial neurons, glia, and connective tissues of the face; these cells enter the pharyngeal pouches and arches where they give rise to thymic cells, bones of the middle ear and jaw (mandible), and the odontoblasts of the tooth primordia; like their counterparts in the trunk, cranial NCCs also contribute to the developing peripheral nervous system, along with the pigmented cell (i.e. melanocyte) lineage.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the ectoderm.

parentLabel: structure with developmental contribution from neural crest
classDefinition: Neural crest cells (NCCs) originating in the anterior part of the developing embryo and residing between the mid-diencephalon and the forming hindbrain; cranial NCCs migrate dorsolaterally to form the craniofacial mesenchyme that differentiates into various craniofacial cartilages and bones, cranial neurons, glia, and connective tissues of the face; these cells enter the pharyngeal pouches and arches where they give rise to thymic cells, bones of the middle ear and jaw (mandible), and the odontoblasts of the tooth primordia; like their counterparts in the trunk, cranial NCCs also contribute to the developing peripheral nervous system, along with the pigmented cell (i.e. melanocyte) lineage.

classDefinition: A blood island that is part of a mesoderm.
parentDefinition: Blood islands are structures in the developing embryo which lead to many different parts of the circulatory system. They primarily derive from plexuses formed from angioblasts. Within them, vacuoles appear through liquefaction of the central part of the syncytium into plasma. The lumen of the blood vessels thus formed is probably intracellular. The flattened cells at the periphery form the endothelium. The nucleated red blood corpuscles develop either from small masses of the original angioblast left attached to the inner wall of the lumen or directly from the flat endothelial cells. In either case the syncytial mass thus formed projects from and is attached to the wall of the vessel. Such a mass is known as a blood island and hemoglobin gradually accumulates within it. Later the cells on the surface round up, giving the mass a mulberry-like appearance. Then the red blood cells break loose and are carried away in the plasma. Such free blood cells continue to divide. Blood islands have been seen in the area vasculosa in the omphalomesenteric vein and arteries, and in the dorsal aorta[WP, unvetted].

In vertebrates it derives largely from mesoderm, and sometimes the terms are used interchangeably, e.g. lateral plate mesoderm/mesenchyme.

classDefinition: Organism at the gastrula stage.
parentDefinition: Anatomical entity that comprises the organism in the early stages of growth and differentiation that are characterized by cleavage, the laying down of fundamental tissues, and the formation of primitive organs and organ systems. For example, for mammals, the process would begin with zygote formation and end with birth. For insects, the process would begin at zygote formation and end with larval hatching. For plant zygotic embryos, this would be from zygote formation to the end of seed dormancy. For plant vegetative embryos, this would be from the initial determination of the cell or group of cells to form an embryo until the point when the embryo becomes independent of the parent plant.

classDefinition: Dermis-derived entity that is made of skeletal tissue.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the ectoderm.

parentLabel: structure with developmental contribution from neural crest
classDefinition: Dermis-derived entity that is made of skeletal tissue.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that has some part that develops from the neural crest.

classDefinition: Dermis-derived entity that is made of skeletal tissue.
parentDefinition: Organ consisting of skeletal tissue. Encompasses whole bones, fused bones, cartilaginious elements, teeth, dermal denticles.

classDefinition: A bone that is part of a cranium.
parentDefinition: A bone that is part of a head [Automatically generated definition].

classDefinition: Any bone that is part of the lower jaw skeleton. This includes (when present): the dentary/mandible, the articular, the splenial, the suprangular.
parentDefinition: A bone element that is part of a jaw region.

classDefinition: A bone element that is part of a jaw region.
parentDefinition: A bone that is part of a facial skeleton [Automatically generated definition].

classDefinition: A bone element that is part of a jaw region.
parentDefinition: Any of the organs or elements that are part of the digestive system. Examples: tongue, esophagus, spleen, crop, lunge feeding organ, tooth elements.

classDefinition: The mucous membrane lining the respiratory tract.
parentDefinition: A lining of mostly endodermal origin, covered in epithelium, which is involved in absorption and secretion. They line various body cavities that are exposed to the external environment and internal organs. It is at several places continuous with skin: at the nostrils, the lips, the ears, the genital area, and the anus. The sticky, thick fluid secreted by the mucous membranes and gland is termed mucus. The term mucous membrane refers to where they are found in the body and not every mucous membrane secretes mucus[WP].

classDefinition: Any of the tissue layers that comprise a blood vessel. Examples: tunica media, tunica adventitia.
parentDefinition: A part of a wall of an organ that forms a layer.

classDefinition: Any of the tissue layers that comprise a blood vessel. Examples: tunica media, tunica adventitia.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the mesoderm.
Organ component adjacent to an organ cavity and which consists of a maximal aggregate of organ component layers.
An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the mesoderm.

classDefinition: An epithelium that is part of a respiratory system [Automatically generated definition].
parentDefinition: Portion of tissue, that consists of one or more layers of epithelial cells connected to each other by cell junctions and which is underlain by a basal lamina. Examples: simple squamous epithelium, glandular cuboidal epithelium, transitional epithelium, myoepithelium[CARO].

classLabel: vasculature of central nervous system plus retina
parentDefinition: An interconnected tubular multi-tissue structure contains fluid that is actively transported around the organism[ZFA]. Examples: vasculature of lung, vasculature of face.

classDefinition: The fetal urogenital sinus (from which the prostate derives) is a simple cylinder of stratified basal epithelium, surrounded by mesenchyme and positioned between the embryonic bladder and pelvic urethra.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops from the endoderm and the mesoderm.

classDefinition: The fetal urogenital sinus (from which the prostate derives) is a simple cylinder of stratified basal epithelium, surrounded by mesenchyme and positioned between the embryonic bladder and pelvic urethra.

parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the ectoderm.

classDefinition: A portion of the gut that is derived from ectoderm.
parentDefinition: A proximal-distal subdivision of the digestive tract.

classDefinition: An epithelium surrounding a gonad.
parentDefinition: Portion of tissue, that consists of one or more layers of epithelial cells connected to each other by cell junctions and which is underlain by a basal lamina. Examples: simple squamous epithelium, glandular cuboidal epithelium, transitional epithelium, myoepithelium[CARO].

classDefinition: An epithelium surrounding a gonad.
parentDefinition: Any anatomical structure that is part of the reproductive system.

classDefinition: An organ that is part of a immune system [Automatically generated definition].
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that performs a specific function or group of functions [WP].

classDefinition: The median dorsal longitudinal groove formed in the embryo by the neural plate after the appearance of the neural folds.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that is part of an embryo.

classDefinition: An epithelial sheet bent on a linear axis.
parentDefinition: Portion of tissue, that consists of one or more layers of epithelial cells connected to each other by cell junctions and which is underlain by a basal lamina. Examples: simple squamous epithelium, glandular cuboidal epithelium, transitional epithelium, myoepithelium[CARO].

classDefinition: An intermediate stage (between the neural plate and neural rod) during the early segmentation period in the morphogenesis of the central nervous system primordium; the keel is roughly triangular shaped in cross section.
parentDefinition: Primordium that develops into the central nervous system.

classDefinition: An organ or element that is in the thoracic cavity. Examples: lung, heart, longus colli.
parentDefinition: An organ that part of the thoracic segment region. This region can be further subdividied chest and thoracic cavity regions.

classDefinition: An organ or element that is in the thoracic cavity. Examples: lung, heart, longus colli.
parentDefinition: An organ that is located within the body cavity (or in its extension, in the scrotum); it consists of organ parts that are embryologically derived from endoderm, splanchnic mesoderm or intermediate mesoderm; together with other organs, the viscus constitutes the respiratory, gastrointestinal, urinary, reproductive and immune systems, or is the central organ of the cardiovascular system. Examples: heart, lung, esophagus, kidney, ovary, spleen.

classDefinition: Sum total of mesenchyme in the embryo.
parentDefinition: Anatomical group that has its parts adjacent to one another.

classLabel: ventricular system of central nervous system
classDefinition: A set of structures containing cerebrospinal fluid in the brain. It is continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord[WP].
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the ectoderm.

classLabel: ventricular system of central nervous system
classDefinition: A set of structures containing cerebrospinal fluid in the brain. It is continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord[WP].
parentDefinition: Multicellular, connected anatomical structure that has multiple organs as parts and whose parts work together to achieve some shared function.

classDefinition: Tela chorioidea that lines the telencephalic ventricle.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the ectoderm.

parentLabel: structure with developmental contribution from neural crest
classDefinition: Tela chorioidea that lines the telencephalic ventricle.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that has some part that develops from the neural crest.

classDefinition: Tela chorioidea that lines the telencephalic ventricle.
parentDefinition: A structure found in the walls of the ventricles of the brain, consisting of part of the meninges (pia mater in mammals) plus ependyma[cjm].

classDefinition: Portion of tissue that is contiguous with the embryo and is comprised of portions of tissue or cells that will not contribute to the embryo.
parentDefinition: Multicellular anatomical structure that consists of many cells of one or a few types, arranged in an extracellular matrix such that their long-range organisation is at least partly a repetition of their short-range organisation.

classDefinition: A somite that is part of a trunk.
parentDefinition: Somites are spheres of epithelial cells that form sequentially along the anterior-posterior axis of the embryo through mesenchymal to epithelial transition of the presomitic mesoderm.

classDefinition: An epithelium that is part of a anterior chamber of eyeball.
parentDefinition: An epithelium that is part of a camera-type eye.

classDefinition: An epithelium that is part of a lens vesicle.
parentDefinition: Epithelium composed of cells that develops from the ectoderm[FMA,modified].

classDefinition: Anatomical space that is an opening in a bone, usually for passage of blood vessels or nerves.
parentDefinition: Any tube, opening or passage that connects two distinct anatomical spaces.

classDefinition: An acellular anatomical structure that is the bounding layer of a anatomical structure.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that consists of cell parts and cell substances and together does not constitute a cell or a tissue.

classDefinition: Anatomical structure that is an aggregation of similar cells from which cartilages and bones form, and from which chondrogenesis and osteogenesis are initiated during repair and/or regeneration. (Hall and Miyake 1995).
parentDefinition: Material anatomical entity that is a single connected structure with inherent 3D shape generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome.

classDefinition: One of five swellings formed during the development of the face.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that is part of an embryo.
Anatomical structure that is part of an embryo.

classDefinition: Subdivision of the skeletal system which consists of the axial skeleton plus associated joints.
Subdivision of the skeletal system which consists of the axial skeleton plus associated joints.
parentDefinition: Anatomical cluster consisting of the skeletal elements and articular elements that are part of an individual subdivision of the organism.

classDefinition: The laminar structure of the heart.
parentDefinition: A part of a wall of an organ that forms a layer.

classDefinition: The laminar structure of the heart.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the mesoderm.

classDefinition: Anatomical structure embedded in or located in the integument that is part of the integumental system. Examples: hair, follicles, skin glands, claws, nails, feathers.
parentDefinition: A multicellular structure that is a part of an organ.

classDefinition: The thin bilaminar membrane derived from the prechordal plate that is devoid of mesoderm and formed by the apposition of the stomodeal ectoderm with the foregut endoderm; after the embryonic head fold has evolved it lies at the caudal limit of the stomodeum, forming a septum between the primitive mouth and pharynx; the membrane eventually disappears, and thus a communication is established between the mouth and the future pharynx.
parentDefinition: A wall, dividing a cavity or structure into smaller ones[WP].

classDefinition: An anatomical junctions that overlaps the mouth and foregut.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that connects two structures.

classDefinition: An anatomical structure that connects two structures.
parentDefinition: Material anatomical entity that is a single connected structure with inherent 3D shape generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome.

classDefinition: Future brain vesicle that gives rise to telencephalic ventricle/lateral ventricles and 3rd ventricle.

parentDefinition: An anatomical space with at least one opening to another space or the exterior.

classDefinition: A tube that is part of a excretory system.
parentDefinition: Any hollow cylindrical anatomical structure containing a lumen through which substances are transported.

classDefinition: The pharynx is the part of the digestive system immediately posterior to the mouth[GO].
parentDefinition: A proximal-distal subdivision of the digestive tract.

classDefinition: A nucleus of brain that is part of a hypothalamus.
parentDefinition: A nucleus of brain that is part of a diencephalon.

classDefinition: A nucleus of brain that is part of a diencephalon.
parentDefinition: A neural nucleus that is part of the brain.

classDefinition: A head mesenchyme that develops_from a mesoderm.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the mesoderm.

classDefinition: A head mesenchyme that develops_from a mesoderm.
parentDefinition: Portion of primordial embryonic connective tissue of the developing head, consisting of mesenchymal cells supported in interlaminar jelly, that derive mostly from the mesoderm and contribute to head connective tissue, bone and musculature in conjunction with cranial neural crest cells.

classDefinition: A portion of tissue that will develop into vasculature.
parentDefinition: Primordia are populations of contiguous cells that are morphologically distinct and already correspond in extent to a later organ/tissue[FBbt, Hartenstein, V. (2004)].
A portion of tissue that is part of an embryo.
An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the mesoderm.

classDefinition: Cranial neural crest that migrates into the mandibular arch.
parentDefinition: Neural crest cells (NCCs) originating in the anterior part of the developing embryo and residing between the mid-diencephalon and the forming hindbrain; cranial NCCs migrate dorsolaterally to form the craniofacial mesenchyme that differentiates into various craniofacial cartilages and bones, cranial neurons, glia, and connective tissues of the face; these cells enter the pharyngeal pouches and arches where they give rise to thymic cells, bones of the middle ear and jaw (mandible), and the odontoblasts of the tooth primordia; like their counterparts in the trunk, cranial NCCs also contribute to the developing peripheral nervous system, along with the pigmented cell (i.e. melanocyte) lineage.

classDefinition: A hollow, muscular organ, which, by contracting rhythmically, contributes to the circulation of lymph, blood or analogs. Examples: a chambered vertebrate heart; the tubular peristaltic heart of ascidians; the dorsal vessel of an insect; the lymoh heart of a reptile.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that has as its parts two or more multi-tissue structures of at least two different types and which through specific morphogenetic processes forms a single distinct structural unit demarcated by bona fide boundaries from other distinct anatomical structures of different types.

classDefinition: A dark greenish mass that accumulates in the bowel during fetal life and is discharged shortly after birth.
parentDefinition: Portion of semisolid bodily waste discharged through the anus[MW,modified].

classDefinition: Mesenchyme that develops_from the neural crest[Automatically generated definition].
parentDefinition: Portion of tissue composed of mesenchymal cells (motile cells that develop from epthelia via an epithelial to mesenchymal transition) and surrounding extracellular material. Mesenchyme has different embryological origins in different metazoan taxa - in many invertebrates it derives in whole or part from ectoderm. In vertebrates it derives largely from mesoderm, and sometimes the terms are used interchangeably, e.g. lateral plate mesoderm/mesenchyme.

classDefinition: Mesenchyme that develops_from the neural crest[Automatically generated definition].
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops from the neural crest.

classDefinition: Gray matter of the central nervous system which is a collection of clustered nuclei.
Gray matter of the central nervous system which is a collection of clustered nuclei.
parentDefinition: A nervous system structure composed primarily of nerve cell bodies (somas). May also include dendrites and the initial unmyelinated portion of axons.
Mesenchyme that is part of a developing trunk.

classDefinition: Outermost layer of cells surrounding the embryo.
parentDefinition: Epithelium which consists of a single layer of epithelial cells. Examples: endothelium, mesothelium, glandular squamous epithelium.[FMA].

classDefinition: Outermost layer of cells surrounding the embryo.
parentDefinition: A portion of tissue that is part of an embryo.

classDefinition: Outermost layer of cells surrounding the embryo.
parentDefinition: Epithelium composed of cells that develops from the ectoderm[FMA,modified].

classDefinition: A bone that is part of a reproductive organ.
parentDefinition: Skeletal element that is composed of bone tissue.

classDefinition: A bone that is part of a reproductive organ.
parentDefinition: Any anatomical structure that is part of the reproductive system.

classDefinition: An organism subdivision that includes both an appendage and its associated girdle region. Note that this includes both the skeletal elements and associated tissues (integument, muscle, etc).
parentDefinition: Any structure that is placed on one side of the left-right axis of a bilaterian.

classDefinition: An organism subdivision that includes both an appendage and its associated girdle region. Note that this includes both the skeletal elements and associated tissues (integument, muscle, etc).
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure which is a subdivision of a whole organism, consisting of components of multiple anatomical systems, largely surrounded by a contiguous region of integument.

classDefinition: The subdivision of the skeleton of either the pectoral or pelvic girdle.
parentDefinition: Anatomical cluster consisting of the skeletal elements (i.e. bone elements, cartilage elements, cartilage condensations) that are part of an individual subdivision of the organism. Excludes joints.

classDefinition: A bone that is part of a appendage girdle region.
parentDefinition: A bone that is part of an appendage girdle complex (i.e. any bone in a limb, fin or girdle).

classDefinition: A bone that is part of an appendage girdle complex (i.e. any bone in a limb, fin or girdle).
parentDefinition: Skeletal element that is composed of bone tissue.

classDefinition: A bone that is part of a pectoral girdle region.
parentDefinition: A bone that is part of a appendage girdle region.

classDefinition: A bone that is part of a pectoral girdle region.
parentDefinition: A bone that is part of a pectoral complex. Examples: scapula, manus phalanx, any carpal bone, any bone of the pectoral fin.

classDefinition: A bone that is part of a pectoral complex. Examples: scapula, manus phalanx, any carpal bone, any bone of the pectoral fin.
parentDefinition: A bone that is part of an appendage girdle complex (i.e. any bone in a limb, fin or girdle).

classDefinition: The collection of all skeletal elements in a pectoral complex - i.e. the combination of free limb or fin plus pectoral girdle.
parentDefinition: Anatomical cluster consisting of the skeletal elements (i.e. bone elements, cartilage elements, cartilage condensations) that are part of an individual subdivision of the organism. Excludes joints.

classDefinition: A skeletal joint that is part of a appendage girdle region.
parentDefinition: Anatomical cluster that consists of two or more adjacent skeletal structures, which may be interconnected by various types of tissue[VSAO].

classDefinition: A brain that develops_from a neural tube.
parentDefinition: Compound organ that contains one or more macroscopic anatomical spaces.

classDefinition: A brain that develops_from a neural tube.
parentDefinition: The brain is the center of the nervous system in all vertebrate, and most invertebrate, animals. Some primitive animals such as jellyfish and starfish have a decentralized nervous system without a brain, while sponges lack any nervous system at all. In vertebrates, the brain is located in the head, protected by the skull and close to the primary sensory apparatus of vision, hearing, balance, taste, and smell[WP].

classDefinition: The axilla is the area directly under the joint where the forelimb connects to the shoulder.
parentDefinition: A region or zone on the surface of an organism that encompasses skin and any adnexa, down through muscles and bounded by underlying skeletal support structures.

classDefinition: A region or zone on the surface of an organism that encompasses skin and any adnexa, down through muscles and bounded by underlying skeletal support structures.

classDefinition: An ectoderm that is part of a buccopharyngeal membrane.

classDefinition: An endoderm that is part of a buccopharyngeal membrane.
parentDefinition: Primary germ layer that lies remote from the surface of the embryo and gives rise to internal tissues such as gut.

classDefinition: A neural plate that develops_from a future forebrain.
parentDefinition: A region of embryonic ectodermal cells that lie directly above the notochord. During neurulation, they change shape and produce an infolding of the neural plate (the neural fold) that then seals to form the neural tube[XAO]. The earliest recognizable dorsal ectodermal primordium of the central nervous system present near the end of gastrulation before infolding to form the neural keel; consists of a thickened pseudostratified epithelium[ZFA].

classDefinition: An epithelium that develops_from a ectoderm and is part of a oral epithelium.
parentDefinition: Epithelium which consists of a single layer of epithelial cells. Examples: endothelium, mesothelium, glandular squamous epithelium.[FMA].

classDefinition: An epithelium that develops_from a ectoderm and is part of a oral epithelium.
parentDefinition: Epithelium composed of cells that develops from the ectoderm[FMA,modified].

classDefinition: An epithelium that develops_from a ectoderm and is part of a oral epithelium.
parentDefinition: An epithelium that is part of the mouth and lines the oral cavity, typically stratified squamous, and may be para-, ortho- or non- keratinized. Primary barrier between oral environment and deeper tissues.

classDefinition: A principle subdivision of an organism that includes all structures along the primary axis, typically the anterior-posterior axis, from head to tail, including structures of the body proper where present (for example, ribs), but excluding appendages.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure which is a subdivision of a whole organism, consisting of components of multiple anatomical systems, largely surrounded by a contiguous region of integument.

classDefinition: A cardiovascular system that is part of a conceptus.
parentDefinition: Anatomical system that has as its parts the heart and blood vessels.

classDefinition: A nerve that is part of a head.
parentDefinition: An enclosed, cable-like bundle of axons in the peripheral nervous system originating in a nerve root in the central nervous system (or a condensed nervous structure) connecting with peripheral structures.

classDefinition: Connective tissue, which consists of a population of connective tissue cells, the intercellular matrix of which contains an irregular network of collagen and elastic fiber bundles. Examples: areolar tissue, mucoid tissue, connective tissue of peritoneum, connective tissue of fibrous pericardium.
parentDefinition: Tissue with cells that deposit non-polarized extracellular matrix including connective tissue fibers and ground substance.

classDefinition: Dense connective tissue is mainly composed of collagen type I. Crowded between the collagen fibers are rows of fibroblasts, fiber-forming cells, that manufacture the fibers. Dense connective tissue forms strong, rope-like structures such as tendons and ligaments. Tendons attach skeletal muscles to bones; ligaments connect bones to bones at joints. Ligaments are more stretchy and contain more elastic fibers than tendons. Dense connective tissue also make up the lower layers of the skin (dermis), where it is arranged in sheets.
parentDefinition: Tissue with cells that deposit non-polarized extracellular matrix including connective tissue fibers and ground substance.

classDefinition: The connective tissue bundles in the extracellular matrix of bone tissue that are composed of collagen, and play a role in tissue strength and elasticity.
Any of the organs or elements that are part of the digestive system. Examples: tongue, esophagus, spleen, crop, lunge feeding organ, tooth elements.
parentDefinition: Anatomical structure that performs a specific function or group of functions [WP].

classDefinition: The opening of the cloacal chamber to the outside of the organism. Birds maintain a single cloacal opening throughout their lives.
parentDefinition: Anatomical conduit that connects two adjacent body spaces (or a body space with the space surrounding the organism)[FMA,modified].

Non-material anatomical entity of three dimensions, that is generated by morphogenetic or other physiologic processes; is surrounded by one or more anatomical structures; contains one or more organism substances or anatomical structures.

classDefinition: A mucosa that is part of a cloaca [Automatically generated definition].
parentDefinition: A lining of mostly endodermal origin, covered in epithelium, which is involved in absorption and secretion. They line various body cavities that are exposed to the external environment and internal organs. It is at several places continuous with skin: at the nostrils, the lips, the ears, the genital area, and the anus. The sticky, thick fluid secreted by the mucous membranes and gland is termed mucus. The term mucous membrane refers to where they are found in the body and not every mucous membrane secretes mucus[WP].

classDefinition: Anatomical space that is an opening in a bone of the skull.
parentDefinition: Anatomical space that is an opening in a bone, usually for passage of blood vessels or nerves.

classDefinition: A unilaminar epithelium that develops_from a ectoderm and is part of a anal region.
parentDefinition: Epithelium which consists of a single layer of epithelial cells. Examples: endothelium, mesothelium, glandular squamous epithelium.[FMA].

classDefinition: A unilaminar epithelium that develops_from a ectoderm and is part of a anal region.
parentDefinition: Epithelium composed of cells that develops from the ectoderm[FMA,modified].

classDefinition: A neuromere that is part of the presumptive forebrain.
parentDefinition: A transverse unitary subdivision of the neural tube that shares a common dorsoventral structure (floor, basal, alar, and roof plates), but each having differential molecular identities and fates; they comprise the secondary prosencephalon, diencephalon (prosomeres), the midbrain (mesomeres), and the hindbrain (rhombomeres).

classDefinition: Any muscle organ that is part of a cloaca.
parentDefinition: Organ consisting of a tissue made up of various elongated cells that are specialized to contract and thus to produce movement and mechanical work[GO].

classDefinition: Any muscle organ that is part of a cloaca.
parentDefinition: Any of the organs or elements that are part of the digestive system. Examples: tongue, esophagus, spleen, crop, lunge feeding organ, tooth elements.

classDefinition: A basement membrane of epithelium that is part of a respiratory system.
parentDefinition: An acellular membrane that is part of the epithelium, lies adjacent to the epithelial cells, and is the fusion of the the basal lamina and the reticular lamina.

classDefinition: A zone of skin that is above the clavicle zone in the pectoral girdle region.
parentDefinition: Any portion of the organ that covers that body and consists of a layer of epidermis and a layer of dermis.

classLabel: smooth muscle layer in fatty layer of subcutaneous tissue
classDefinition: A smooth muscle tissue that is part of a hypodermis.
parentDefinition: Muscle tissue which is unstriated, composed primarily of smooth muscle fibers surrounded by a reticulum of collagen and elastic fibers. Smooth muscle differs from striated muscle in the much higher actin/myosin ratio, the absence of conspicuous sarcomeres and the ability to contract to a much smaller fraction of its resting length[GO].

A lining of mostly endodermal origin, covered in epithelium, which is involved in absorption and secretion. They line various body cavities that are exposed to the external environment and internal organs. It is at several places continuous with skin: at the nostrils, the lips, the ears, the genital area, and the anus. The sticky, thick fluid secreted by the mucous membranes and gland is termed mucus. The term mucous membrane refers to where they are found in the body and not every mucous membrane secretes mucus[WP].
Any anatomical structure that is part of the reproductive system.

classDefinition: Any region of epithelium that is part of a skin region.
parentDefinition: Epithelium composed of cells that develops from the ectoderm[FMA,modified].

classDefinition: A sweet viscid material elaborated out of the nectar of flowers in the honey sac of various bees.
parentDefinition: A bodily fluid consisting of the contents of the digestive tract expulsed through the anterior portion of the digestive tract.
Anatomical conduit that connects two adjacent body spaces (or a body space with the space surrounding the organism)[FMA,modified].

parentLabel: structure with developmental contribution from neural crest
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that has some part that develops from the neural crest.

parentLabel: wall of ventricular system of brain

classLabel: wall of ventricular system of brain
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the ectoderm.

classLabel: wall of ventricular system of brain
parentDefinition: Organ component adjacent to an organ cavity and which consists of a maximal aggregate of organ component layers.

classLabel: wall of ventricular system of brain
parentDefinition: A layer in the central nervous system that lines system of communicating cavities in the brain and spinal cord.
An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the ectoderm.
Organ component adjacent to an organ cavity and which consists of a maximal aggregate of organ component layers.

classDefinition: Wall of organ which has as its parts the endocardium, myocardium , epicardium, and the cardiac septum, surrounded by the pericardial sac proper and is continuous with the walls of the systemic and pulmonary arterial and venous trees.
parentDefinition: Organ component adjacent to an organ cavity and which consists of a maximal aggregate of organ component layers.

classDefinition: Wall of organ which has as its parts the endocardium, myocardium , epicardium, and the cardiac septum, surrounded by the pericardial sac proper and is continuous with the walls of the systemic and pulmonary arterial and venous trees.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that develops (entirely or partially) from the mesoderm.

classDefinition: An anatomical junction between two parts of the digestive tract.
parentDefinition: An anatomical structure that connects two structures.

classDefinition: Dermal, epidermal, glandular and pigment structures of the external head integument.
parentDefinition: Structures of the dermis, epidermis, glands and pigment cells recognizable on the external surfaces of the integument.

classDefinition: Dermal, epidermal, glandular and pigment structures of the body integument.
parentDefinition: Structures of the dermis, epidermis, glands and pigment cells recognizable on the external surfaces of the integument.

classDefinition: Blood vessels in respiratory skin.
parentDefinition: A blood vessel that is part of a respiratory system [Automatically generated definition].

classDefinition: Anatomical projection that is composed of bone or cartilage tissue.
parentDefinition: A projection or outgrowth of tissue from a larger body or organ.

classDefinition: An anatomical junction between two parts of the intestine.
parentDefinition: An anatomical junction between two parts of the digestive tract.
